Description: The draft Brexit agreement between Britain and the European Union gives certainty to British business whilst no deal would hinder free trade, the boss of carmaker McLaren Automotive said as Prime Minister Theresa May battles to win over her lawmakers.

Headline: No better Brexit deal available, EU ministers tell Britain
Description: Germany and other European Union states told Britain on Monday their draft Brexit agreement could not be renegoitated.

Headline: UK could ask for Brexit transition beyond 2020, business minister says
Description: The United Kingdom could ask for a longer Brexit transition period if needed, Business Secretary Greg Clark said on Monday, not ruling out the possibility it could last until 2022.

Headline: Getting rid of me risks delaying Brexit - May
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday toppling her would risk delaying Brexit and she would not let talk of a leadership challenge distract her from a critical week of negotiations with Brussels.

Headline: Conservative lawmaker says PM May faces day of reckoning on Monday
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces a day of reckoning on Monday as mutinous lawmakers try to trigger a no confidence vote over their opposition to her draft European Union divorce deal, a rebel member of her Conservative Party said.

Headline: No renegotiation of Brexit deal - German minister
Description: German Economy Minister Peter Altmaier ruled out on Monday a renegotiation of the Brexit deal reached between the European Union and Britain to make it more palatable to British lawmakers opposed to the agreement.

Headline: PM May's opponents six letters short of no confidence vote - The Sun
Description: Opponents of British Prime Minister Theresa May are six letters short of the threshold to trigger a no confidence vote, The Sun newspaper reported.

Headline: Scottish minister Russell sees Brexit deal being defeated in parliament
Description: Scotland's constitution minister, Michael Russell, predicted on Monday the British government's Brexit deal would be defeated in the UK parliament and said the Scottish government would do everything it could to ensure a common-sense alternative".

Headline: UK has intense week of Brexit negotiations ahead - May
Description: Britain has an intense week of Brexit negotiations ahead in which it expects to finalise the details of its outline future relationship with the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May will say on Monday.

Headline: 'Tragic illusion' to think can remedy Brexit deal with future relationship - Boris Johnson
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's suggestion that issues with the Brexit deal can be remedied in talks over its future ties with the bloc are "a tragic illusion" or "an attempt at deception," former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said.

Headline: Former Brexit minister Raab says May must change course on Brexit deal
Description: Britain's former Brexit minister Dominic Raab said on Sunday that Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal was fatally flawed but she could still change course.

Headline: DUP's Dodds says time to work for better Brexit deal
Description: It is time to work for a better Brexit deal which does not undermine the integrity of the United Kingdom, the deputy leader of the small Northern Irish party which props up Prime Minister Theresa May's government said on Sunday.

Headline: Factbox - Who has submitted letters of no confidence in UK PM May?
Description: Some lawmakers in Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party have said they have submitted letters of no confidence in the British leader.

Headline: Labour leader Corbyn - second Brexit referendum is for future, not today
Description: Britain's opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Sunday that a second Brexit referendum was an option for the future rather than today.

Headline: Threshold for triggering challenge to UK PM May has not yet been met - lawmaker
Description: The threshold for triggering a confidence vote in British Prime Minister Theresa May has not yet been met, the chairman of the committee in charge of Conservative Party leadership contests told BBC radio on Sunday.

Headline: PM May says leadership challenge threshold not met 'as far as I know'
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday that as far as she was aware, a formal challenge to her leadership had not yet gained enough support to trigger a confidence vote.

Headline: PM May says next seven days critical for Britain
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday the next seven days in the Brexit process would be critical for the country's future.

Headline: Junior UK Brexit minister says changing leader would be futile distraction
Description: Junior British Brexit minister Kwasi Kwarteng told the BBC on Sunday that toppling Theresa May as leader of the Conservative Party would be a futile distraction.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon says parliament should not endorse Brexit deal - BBC
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon told the BBC on Sunday that it would be a mistake and deeply irresponsible for parliament to endorse Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal.

Headline: May sees 'no alternative' to her Brexit plan
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May says she sees no alternative to the Brexit deal she presented earlier this week, amid reports that some of her senior ministers want her to renegotiate the draft agreement before meeting EU leaders next weekend.

Headline: May defends Brexit deal as opponents plot no-confidence vote
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May won the backing of the most prominent Brexiteer in her government on Friday as she fought to save a draft European Union divorce deal that has stirred up a plot to force her out of her job.

Headline: London bridges blocked by environment protest, 70 arrested
Description: British police said they arrested more than 70 people at an environmental protest on Saturday, after demonstrators blocked five bridges across the River Thames in central London.

Headline: A vote reversed - What is the path back from Brexit?
Description: To leave, or not to leave: Two and a half years since the United Kingdom voted to exit the EU, that is still the question.

Headline: Ex-Trump strategist Bannon says EU is trying to thwart Brexit
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump’s former political strategist, Steve Bannon, said on Friday that the European Union was trying to thwart Brexit.

Headline: May's Brexit deal won't get through parliament - David Davis
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's draft European Union divorce deal will not get the approval of the UK parliament, former Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Friday.

Headline: Northern Irish businesses put pressure on DUP by backing Brexit deal
Description: Northern Irish business groups lined up to back Prime Minister Theresa May's draft Brexit agreement on Friday and put pressure on her allies from the British province to drop their staunch opposition to the plan.

Headline: Irish PM says hard border highly likely without Brexit deal
Description: Ireland's prime minister said on Friday his government would find it very difficult to avoid imposing a hard border on Northern Ireland if Britain crashes out of the European Union without an exit agreement.

Headline: Irish foreign minister says don't write off Theresa May
Description: Ireland's Foreign Minister Simon Coveney on Friday lent his support to under-fire British Prime Minister Theresa May, describing her as determined and resilient and predicting a leadership challenge could actually strengthen her.

Headline: PM May appoints Stephen Barclay as UK's latest Brexit minister
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May appointed Stephen Barclay, a junior health minister who voted to leave the European Union in a 2016 referendum, as her new Brexit Secretary on Friday.

Headline: PM May must weigh parliamentary procedure carefully before big EU vote - committee
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May should have to defeat rival Brexit propositions in parliament before putting her own plan to a vote, an influential committee of lawmakers recommended on Friday, raising the risks of failure in the showdown.

Headline: May's Brexit deal sparks defiance and divisions in unionist Belfast
Description: At Sandy Row Band Supplies in the heart of Belfast's pro-British unionist community, it is easy to understand the uncompromising resistance of Prime Minister Theresa May's Northern Irish allies to her Brexit deal.

Headline: Amber Rudd to return to UK cabinet as work and pensions sec - Sunday Times reporter
Description: Former Home Secretary (interior minister) Amber Rudd will return to the British cabinet as work and pensions secretary, according to Sunday Times reporter Tim Shipman.

Headline: 'I'm going to see this through' - May vows to fight for Brexit deal
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May vowed to fight for her draft divorce deal with the European Union on Thursday after the resignation of her Brexit secretary and other ministers put her strategy and her job in peril.

Headline: Factbox: Who has submitted letters of no confidence in PM May?
Description: Some lawmakers in Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party have said they have submitted letters of no confidence in the British leader.

Headline: Germany must prepare for a no-deal Brexit - finance minister
Description: Germany must prepare for a hard Brexit but will do everything possible to avoid it, Finance Minister Olaf Scholz said on Friday.

Headline: Dutch PM Rutte - unlikely EU countries will want to alter Brexit deal
Description: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte on Friday said European Union countries would not be willing to change the proposed Brexit deal if it were rejected by the British parliament.

Headline: Factbox: Where the EU has made concessions in Brexit talks
Description: While some of Prime Minister Theresa May's critics have denounced her draft Brexit deal with the European Union as betrayal of Britain's interests, the European Union has also given ground in the unprecedented negotiations.

Headline: Number of letters to oust PM May might not be known until Monday - BBC
Description: A group of eurosceptics who are leading a bid to oust British Prime Minister Theresa May might not know until Monday if they have enough letters to trigger a vote of confidence, the BBC's political editor said on Friday.

Headline: UK eurosceptic ministers to unite around new Brexit backstop stance - The Telegraph
Description: Senior eurosceptic ministers will meet next week to agree a united position in a bid to get Prime Minister Theresa May to change the controversial "backstop" element of her draft Brexit withdrawal agreement, the Telegraph reported.

Headline: Threshold for calling confidence vote in UK PM May has nearly been met - eurosceptic lawmaker
Description: Influential British eurosceptic Conservative lawmaker Steve Baker said on Friday he believed rebels who want to oust Prime Minister Theresa May were close to having enough support to trigger a confidence vote.

Headline: PM May would survive a vote of confidence, deputy says
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May would likely win any vote of confidence in her leadership should Conservative lawmakers write enough letters to a party committee to trigger one, her deputy David Lidington said on Friday.

Headline: Fox says no-deal Brexit still a risk - CNBC
Description: British trade secretary Liam Fox said on Friday there was a chance that a no-deal Brexit could still happen, although it would be unfortunate.

Headline: I'm no Neville Chamberlain: PM May rejects comparison to mocked war leader
Description: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday rejected a suggestion that she was a modern-day Neville Chamberlain, the British leader mocked for claiming he had secured peace with Germany's Adolf Hitler a year before World War Two broke out.

Headline: Gove declines comment when asked about supporting May
Description: Michael Gove, the most prominent Brexit-supporting minister in Prime Minister Theresa May's government, declined to comment on Friday when he was asked outside his house if he supported her.

Headline: Fox says a deal is better than no-deal Brexit
Description: A Brexit deal is better than no-deal for Britain and voters should take a rational and balanced view of Prime Minister Theresa May's draft Brexit agreement, trade minister Liam Fox said on Friday, according to the BBC.

Headline: Gove says he has confidence in PM May
Description: Senior Eurosceptic minister Michael Gove said on Friday he had confidence in Prime Minister Theresa May and was focussed on working for a good deal for Britain as it leaves the European Union.

Headline: Top UK court says to consider government appeal in Brexit reversal case
Description: Britain's Supreme Court said on Friday it would consider whether to hear an appeal from the British government which wants to stop Europe's top court from examining a case seeking to determine whether the country can unilaterally reverse Brexit.

Headline: Germany preparing for all possible Brexit scenarios - ministry
Description: Germany is preparing for all possible Brexit scenarios, an Economy Ministry spokeswoman said on Friday, adding that the ministry was closely examining a draft agreement on Britain's departure from the European Union.

Headline: Easter Island delegation heads to British Museum to lobby for statue return
Description: A delegation from Easter Island will arrive in London next week to seek the return from the British Museum of one of the native Polynesians' emblematic statues.

Headline: Eurosceptic ministers agree to stay in May's government - Sunday Times
Description: Senior Eurosceptic ministers Michael Gove, Liam Fox, Chris Grayling, Penny Mordaunt and Andrea Leadsom have agreed to stay in British Prime Minister Theresa May's government, the Sunday Times reported on Friday.

Headline: PM May will face no confidence vote next week - Telegraph reporter
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will face a no confidence vote next week with Conservative lawmakers expected to submit the 48 letters required to trigger a leadership contest on Friday, a reporter at the Daily Telegraph said.

Headline: Gove won't resign over PM May's Brexit plan - reports
Description: Prominent Brexiteer Michael Gove will not quit Prime Minister Theresa May's government but remain as environment minister, British media reported on Friday, after speculation about his future following the resignation of other senior figures.

Headline: PM May refuses to rule out free vote on Brexit deal
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May repeatedly refused on Friday to rule out allowing her senior ministers to get as so called free vote, which allows lawmakers to vote against the wishes of their party, on the draft Brexit deal.

Headline: Parliament will vote down May's Brexit deal, Davis says
Description: The British parliament will vote down Prime Minister Theresa May's draft Brexit deal so she will have to go back to the European Union for a different deal, one of her former Brexit minister said on Friday.

Headline: France preparing transport and customs measures in case of no-Brexit deal
Description: France is preparing various measures, notably those dealing with customs controls and checks at ports, in case there is no Brexit deal, said French transport minister Elisabeth Borne.

Headline: Tory deal with DUP over unless May replaced - Daily Telegraph
Description: The Conservative Party's deal with Northern Ireland's DUP on Brexit is over unless Prime Minister Theresa May is replaced with a new leader, the Daily Telegraph reported.

Headline: Oxford Islamic scholar Ramadan offered bail in France rape case
Description: Swiss academic Tariq Ramadan, a professor of Islamic studies accused of rape in France and who had been in detention since February, has been offered bail while an investigation into the case continues, lawyers said on Thursday.

Headline: Ministers quit over Brexit draft, pound and bank stocks tumble, May vows to fight
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May battled on Thursday to save a draft divorce deal with the European Union after her Brexit minister, Dominic Raab, and other ministers quit in protest and eurosceptic MPs stepped up efforts to topple her.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP wants Tory leader who will 'deliver on Brexit'
Description: The Northern Irish party propping up Prime Minister Theresa May's minority government wants a Conservative Party leader who will "deliver on Brexit", its deputy leader said following calls for May to resign on Thursday.

Headline: May likens her Brexit resolve to cricketer Geoff Boycott
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May, who has vowed to see through her Brexit plan to the end, compared herself on Thursday to legendary English cricketer Geoffrey Boycott, noting that he was hard to get out even if his run-scoring was sometimes slow.

Headline: Who wants to be Britain's next prime minister?
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's position as leader of the ruling Conservative Party is under assault by eurosceptic MPs who reject her EU exit strategy and want a more pro-Brexit leader.

Headline: May - no-one has produced alternatives to my Brexit plan
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday that no-one had produced an alternative to her Brexit plan, and that all options involved a backstop arrangement that has been criticised by many in her own party.

Headline: UK must halt back-up power scheme after EU court ruling

Headline: Draft Brexit deal ends Britain's easy access to EU financial markets

Headline: UK regulators call banks after Brexit woes hammer pound, financial stocks

Headline: Factbox: Who has submitted letters of no confidence in PM May?

Headline: Gove wants to renegotiate Brexit - Telegraph reporter

Headline: PM May could be replaced in weeks rather than months - Rees-Mogg
Description: A leadership challenge to British Prime Minister Theresa May could be completed in weeks, eurosceptic lawmaker Jacob Rees-Mogg said on Thursday.

Headline: Germany: We are part of the way towards an orderly Brexit
Description: German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said on Thursday that Britain and the European Union were part of the way towards an orderly Brexit but there was still work to be done on both sides, adding that it was clear discussions in Britain would not be easy.

Headline: UK MPs have not yet submitted enough letters to trigger PM May confidence vote - BBC
Description: British MPs in Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party have not yet submitted enough letters to trigger a confidence vote in her, the BBC reported.

Headline: Gove turns down Brexit secretary job - Evening Standard

Headline: Eurosceptic Rees-Mogg: Number of no confidence letters in UK PM May growing

Headline: UK junior minister Burt asks colleagues not to submit no confidence letters in PM May
Description: Alistair Burt, a junior minister in Britain's Foreign Office, urged his Conservative colleagues on Thursday not to submit letters of no confidence in Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: EU says banks could have more time to build buffers after Brexit

Headline: Spain says has contingency plans in case of no-deal Brexit
Description: Spain has set up contingency plans in case there is no final deal on Brexit, junior EU affairs minister Luis Marco Aguiriano said on Thursday.

Headline: Conservative lawmaker Rees-Mogg to submit letter of no confidence in PM May

Headline: Spain welcomes Gibraltar protocol in Brexit deal, hopes it gets UK backing

Headline: Brexit has strengthened case for Scottish independence -Sturgeon
Description: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Thursday that Brexit had strengthened the case for Scottish independence.

Headline: PM May to meet 1922 Committee chairman - Sunday Times reporter
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will meet the head of the influential 1922 committee on Thursday, the political editor of The Sunday Times said.

Headline: Merkel warns no deal is worst-case scenario for Brexit

Headline: Britain will leave the EU in March as planned, PM May says

Headline: PM May: When asked to back Brexit deal, lawmakers must consider Brexit vote

Headline: PM May says she shares concerns of critics of Brexit backstop

Headline: Corbyn says May's government is in chaos
Description: Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of Britain's opposition Labour party, accused Prime Minister Theresa May of pushing her government into chaos by striking a Brexit deal that was a "huge and damaging failure".

Headline: Britain is still preparing for no-deal Brexit - PM May

Headline: UK junior Brexit minister Braverman resigns
Description: Suella Braverman, a junior minister in Britain's Brexit ministry, said on Thursday she had resigned over Prime Minister Theresa May's draft Brexit deal.

Headline: UK PM May loses four more ministers after a year of resignations
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has suffered 18 resignations from her government since last November, ten of which have been related to her approach to Brexit. Here is the list:

Headline: EU official says Brexit deal cannot be improved given 'red lines'

Headline: It's too early to breathe a sigh of relief on Brexit - Germany's DIHK

Headline: German minister: Brexit a tragedy not even Shakespeare could have imagined
Description: Germany's Europe Minister Michael Roth said on Thursday that Brexit was a tragedy that not even English playwright William Shakespeare would have come up with.

Headline: EU parliament progress on Brexit deal

Headline: Raab no longer expected to travel to Brussels today - Bloomberg

Headline: EU envoys end Brexit meeting, London position unclear - sources

Headline: Two UK cabinet ministers will quit on Wednesday - Telegraph

Headline: May says cabinet will decide on next steps in the national interest on Brexit

Headline: EU Commission says could make Brexit statement soon

Headline: Mordaunt wants further assurance over Brexit deal - Sun

Headline: German government: We welcome any progress towards an orderly Brexit

Headline: DUP leader warns May her party could block Brexit deal

Description: The European Union and Britain have agreed a draft text of a Brexit withdrawal agreement and Prime Minister Theresa May will present it to her senior ministers on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain agrees Brexit divorce deal with EU, May's opponents vow to thwart it

Headline: May will fail to get Brexit deal through parliament, Lib Dem leader says

Headline: DUP will wait and see before voting down Brexit deal

Headline: Labour will vote against Brexit deal if fails to meet tests - Corbyn

Headline: Special EU Brexit summit possible Nov. 25 if cabinet backs deal - sources

Headline: Ministers should reject withdrawal deal, say critics of May's Brexit plans

Headline: Brexit deal a "very, very hard sell" - DUP deputy leader

Headline: Text of Brexit withdrawal deal has been agreed - UK government source
Description: The text of a withdrawal agreement between Britain and the European Union has been agreed, a government source in London said on Tuesday.

Headline: DUP says its Brexit "red lines" well-known amid reports of Irish border deal
Description: The Brexit "red lines" set out by the small Northern Irish party propping up Prime Minister Theresa May's government are well known, a spokeswoman for the party said on Tuesday, as it waited to see the details of a final deal on Britain's withdrawal from the European Union.

Headline: EU envoys to meet on Brexit on Wednesday - diplomats
Description: Envoys from European Union member states will meet late on Wednesday to discuss Brexit, diplomats said, with some adding that they believed they could be briefed on a breakthrough in reaching a deal.

Headline: English FA to cut foreign players in Premier League - report
Description: In a bid to deal with Brexit and boost the number of homegrown players, the English Football Association (FA) is planning to reduce the number of overseas players in Premier League squads to 12 from 17, the Times newspaper reported on Tuesday.

Headline: UK government promises Brexit legal analysis, seeking to appease party rebels
Description: British lawmakers will have access to legal analysis of any EU withdrawal agreement and the chance to quiz the government's top legal advisor before being asked to vote to approve the deal, senior minister David Lidington said on Tuesday.

Headline: EU to cut Britain from emissions trading system in no-deal Brexit
Description: Britain will be excluded from the European Union's Emissions Trading System (ETS) and all other legislation to help limit the impact of climate change, if it leaves the bloc in March 2019 without a deal, the EU executive said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK cabinet to meet on Wednesday on Brexit - Times political editor
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet of senior ministers will meet on Wednesday to discuss Brexit, The Times political editor said.

Headline: Small number of issues remain in Brexit talks, negotiations ongoing - PM May's spokeswoman
Description: A small number of issues remain in Brexit talks and negotiations between London and Brussels are ongoing, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Tuesday.

Headline: DUP's Dodds says Brexit talks inching towards compromise deal
Description: The deputy leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, which props up British Prime Minister Theresa May's government, said on Tuesday that it appeared European Union and British negotiators were nearing a Brexit deal.

Headline: EU proposes visa-free travel for Britons after Brexit
Description: The European Union's executive proposed on Tuesday that Britons be allowed to visit the bloc without visas after Brexit and stepped up preparations in case of a no-deal divorce.

Headline: Labour aims to force May to publish Brexit legal advice
Description: The Labour Party said it would try to force the government in a special vote on Tuesday to publish its legal advice on leaving the European Union, including on how the deal will handle the sensitive issue of the Irish border.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP will support publication of Brexit legal advice
Description: The small Northern Irish party propping up Theresa May's government said it would vote on Tuesday in support of an attempt by opposition lawmakers to force the government to publish the legal advice it has received on Brexit.

Headline: UK government says lawmakers will have access to legal analysis of Brexit agreement
Description: British lawmakers should have access to legal analysis of any EU withdrawal agreement before being asked to vote to approve it, Cabinet Office minister David Lidington said on Tuesday.

Headline: EU's Timmermans says working for Brexit deal as bloc advances no-deal preparations
Description: The European Commission has adopted some contingency plans for no-deal Brexit, deputy head Frans Timmermans said on Tuesday, adding that a negotiated divorce with Britain was still by far the bloc's preferred solution.

Headline: Fox: no one believes "no deal" is a good Brexit outcome
Description: British Trade Secretary Liam Fox said on Tuesday a lot of effort was being put into achieving a Brexit deal with the European Union as no one believed leaving without an agreement was a good outcome.

Headline: Brexit deal "closer than it was yesterday" - UK government source
Description: Progress has been made in agreeing the text for Britain's divorce terms with the European Union, with only a couple "sticking points" left to finalise a withdrawal agreement, a government source said on Tuesday.

Headline: Boris Johnson says Brexit deal will make Britain an EU colony
Description: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May and the European Union are stage managing a Brexit deal that will doom the United Kingdom to the status of a colony, former British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK's WTO ambassador - It is dawning on other members there is a possibility of no Brexit deal
Description: It is dawning on other members of the World Trade Organization that there is a possibility Britain leaves the European Union without a deal, Britain's Ambassador to the WTO said on Tuesday.

Headline: Hunt says unclear when Brexit talks will conclude
Description: Around 95 percent of the Brexit divorce deal is done but the remaining five percent is difficult and so it is unclear when talks will conclude, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt told Reuters on Tuesday.

Headline: Tommy Robinson fails to get U.S. visa
Description: British far-right activist Tommy Robinson has not been granted a U.S. visa to meet with Republican lawmakers in Washington this week, an organizer of the meeting said on Monday.

Headline: Brexit talks are nearing their endgame, May says
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday that there were still considerable unresolved issues with the European Union over Brexit as the two sides approached the "endgame" in negotiations for departure from the bloc.

Headline: May stares into Brexit abyss as domestic opposition mounts
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy came under attack from all sides on Monday, putting in doubt her ability to steer any agreement through parliament and raising the risk of  a disruptive "no-deal" exit from the European Union next March.

Headline: May's spokesman says FT report on Barnier should be treated with scepticism
Description: A Financial Times report that the main elements of a Brexit treaty text are ready to present to the British cabinet on Tuesday should be treated with scepticism, British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said.

Headline: Far-right parents who named son after Hitler jailed in Britain
Description: A couple who named their child after Adolf Hitler were convicted in Britain on Monday for being members of banned far-right group National Action.

Headline: Chaos, deal or new vote: What is the grand Brexit finale?

Headline: May's spokesman - We expect cabinet to back PM on Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman on Monday said he expected cabinet ministers to keep backing their leader on Brexit, and that they would be called to a meeting to discuss an EU exit deal as and when there was something to talk about.

Headline: Gove: PM May is trying to get the best Brexit deal
Description: Britain's Environment Secretary Michael Gove said on Monday that Prime Minister Theresa May was trying to get the best Brexit deal.

Headline: Brexit talks are ongoing, no emergency cabinet was scheduled - UK government source
Description: No meeting of Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet was scheduled for Monday and negotiations to leave the European Union are continuing, a government source said.

Headline: Britain's 'broken' audit sector must change - MPs
Description: Britain's parliament will start an inquiry into auditing in January to ensure that two pending reviews will lead to actual reform of a "broken" sector dominated by the Big Four accounting firms, a senior lawmaker said on Monday.

Headline: Everyone must prepare for possibility of hard Brexit - Germany
Description: Everyone needs to make plans for a hard Brexit just in case, German Deputy Finance Minister Joerg Kukies said on Monday.

Headline: UK parliament will vote down May's Brexit deal, former minister says
Description: The British parliament will vote down Prime Minister Theresa May's possible Brexit so voters should be given a new referendum, May's former education minister said on Monday.

Headline: UK's Labour Party - If PM May's deal fails, we want an election

Headline: Change Brexit course or face total surrender - Boris Johnson

Headline: May cannot expect Labour to save her Brexit vote - Thornberry
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May cannot expect the opposition Labour Party to save her in a parliamentary vote on any Brexit deal, Emily Thornberry, Labour's foreign affairs policy chief, said on Sunday.

Headline: Softly, softly for now, May's enforcers gear up for big Brexit vote
Description: Less than five months before Britain leaves the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May's parliamentary enforcers are on the prowl.

Headline: Eurosceptic minister shows support for British PM on Brexit
Description: Andrea Leadsom, leader of Britain's lower house of parliament, said on Sunday she supported Prime Minister Theresa May and did not expect other ministers to resign over Brexit.

Headline: Britain cannot push for unilateral end to Brexit backstop - Hinds
Description: Britain cannot push for a unilateral mechanism to end a so-called backstop arrangement to prevent the return of a hard border between Northern Ireland and EU-member Ireland, Education Minister Damian Hinds said on Sunday.

Headline: Britain's armed forces making contingency plans for 'no deal' Brexit - defence officials
Description: Britain's armed forces are making contingency plans for how they could support the country if Britain leaves the European Union without a deal, senior British defence officials said on Sunday.

Headline: British opposition spokesperson says Labour won't vote for 'blind Brexit'
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party will not vote in parliament for a bad Brexit deal or a "blind Brexit", Labour's defence spokesperson Nia Griffith said on Sunday.

Headline: Queen launches British commemorations 100 years after WW1
Description: Britain's Queen Elizabeth and senior members of the royal family attended a Festival of Remembrance on Saturday to commemorate all those who lost their lives in conflict, on the eve of the 100th anniversary of the end of World War One.

Headline: Four UK ministers on verge of quitting, EU rejects latest plan - Sunday Times
Description: Four British ministers who back remaining in the European Union are on the verge of quitting Theresa May's government over Brexit, the Sunday Times reported, as pressures built on the prime minister from all sides.

Headline: Jo Johnson says colleagues are considering their position over Brexit
Description: Former minister Jo Johnson said some colleagues were "reflecting hard" on whether to quit over Theresa May's Brexit plan after his dramatic resignation threw the British prime minister's deal into jeopardy.

Headline: Factbox - A year of resignations from May's government
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has suffered 14 resignations from her government in the last year and a day, six of which have been related to her approach to Brexit. Here is the list:

Headline: Jo Johnson quits UK government over "delusional" Brexit deal

Headline: Instant View - Jo Johnson resigns from UK government, calls for new referendum

Headline: Fox says Britain may not get a deal with the EU
Description: Britain may not be able to reach a divorce deal with the European Union because a number of contentious issues still stand in the way, trade minister Liam Fox said on Saturday.

Headline: Ministers present May with 'plan B' for no-deal Brexit scenario - Sun
Description: Cabinet ministers have drawn up a 'plan B' for a no-deal Brexit in case parliament votes down Prime Minister Theresa May's proposed plan to leave the European Union, The Sun reported on Friday.

Headline: Brexit distracting UK from bigger challenges, says BoE's Haldane

Headline: Northern Irish kingmakers tell PM May: Don't betray United Kingdom

Headline: DUP leader says will not support May Brexit proposal in parliament

Headline: Chance of no-deal Brexit holds firm at one-in-four as clock ticks - Reuters poll

Headline: More work needed on Brexit deal, EU negotiators say

Headline: Macron and May pay tribute to fallen fighters of the Somme

Headline: There will be no second EU referendum under any circumstances - PM May's office

Headline: Germany confident Brexit deal can be reached - Foreign Minister

Headline: Belgian police hurt in Theresa May motorway mishap

Headline: Irish PM says Brexit deal in coming weeks 'more likely than not'

Headline: UK minister Lidington expects Brexit deal in coming weeks
Description: Britain's Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington on Friday said he believed his government could secure a Brexit withdrawal agreement with the European Union in the coming weeks and secure a majority in parliament to ratify it.

Headline: Irish PM says Brexit deal possible in next couple of weeks
Description: Ireland's Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said a deal between Britain and the European Union over Britain's exit from the bloc was possible within weeks.

Headline: German minister says Brexit deal more likely than not
Description: German Economy Minister Peter Altmaier said on Friday he was optimistic that Britain and its EU partners would clinch a deal on Brexit, saying success was more likely than failure.

Headline: UK will not accept Brexit deal which separates Northern Ireland from UK -  Jeremy Wright

Headline: UK government source plays down talk of imminent Brexit deal - PA

Headline: British government cannot stop Brexit case going to ECJ, Scottish court says

Headline: EU wants Brexit Britain to stick to aid, environment, rights rules - sources

Headline: Cabinet meeting on Brexit unlikely ahead of next week - UK government source

Headline: Irish foreign minister urges caution on Brexit breakthrough

Headline: UK government must show MPs legal advice on Irish backstop - Labour

Headline: Children among 21 people found in refrigerated lorry at UK port - BBC

Headline: Northern Irish DUP - We're not afraid of UK election if Brexit deal falls short

Headline: May sets up business councils to advise on post-Brexit policy
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has created five new business councils to advise on issues facing core sectors of the economy as Britain leaves the European Union, her office said on Tuesday.

Headline: PM office rejects BBC report on November Brexit timetable

Description: Qatar has agreed to buy one of London's most famous hotels, the Grosvenor House, as energy revenue enables the wealthy Gulf state to go on a buying spree despite a blockade by its neighbours.

Headline: DUP leader Foster says Dublin rhetoric could lead to no-deal

Headline: Brexit deal could come by end of week, BBC reporter says

Headline: PM May says won't seek Brexit deal "at any cost", needs more time

Headline: British cabinet will meet again when it's decision time for Brexit - source

Headline: Prince Charles, heir-to-the-British throne, turns 70 on November 14 - Factbox
Description: Prince Charles, the oldest and longest-serving heir-to-the-British throne, celebrates his 70th birthday on Nov. 14.

Headline: UK cabinet ministers to ask May to 'stare down' EU on Irish border issue - The Sun
Description: UK cabinet ministers are set to tell Prime Minister Theresa May to 'stare down' the EU on the Irish border issue or face Brexit deal being destroyed, the Sun newspaper reported http://bit.ly/2AOTXIt on Monday.

Headline: EU to offer Irish border compromise in Brexit talks - The Times
Description: The European Union is preparing to back a compromise proposal on the Irish border to resolve the last major hurdle in Brexit negotiations, the Times of London reported on Monday.

Headline: Ireland says UK cannot unilaterally scrap border backstop
Description: Ireland is willing to examine ways in which a "backstop" to keep the Irish border open after Brexit could be reviewed so long as it does not permit Britain to unilaterally walk away from it, Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Monday.

Headline: PM May - Brexit withdrawal deal 95 percent complete, confident of Northern Irish deal
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May believes a deal in which Britain will leave the European Union is almost done and is confident of a solution on Northern Ireland, currently the sticking point for Brexit to happen in time for a March deadline.

Headline: UK police say incident in London's Westminster has ended

Headline: Irish foreign minister sees middle-ground position on backstop

Headline: Significant outstanding issues related to Irish backstop - PM May's spokesman
Description: There are significant outstanding issues in Brexit negotiations over the Irish backstop and work is ongoing to resolve them, British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Britain's big Brexit vote: Will parliament back PM May?

Headline: Brexit ministry board member tells companies to prepare for no deal
Description: Susan Hooper, a British executive who sits on the board of the Brexit ministry, told businesses to prepare for a no-deal exit on Monday as time starts to run down on the "almost impossible task" of finding an agreement that works for everyone.

Headline: Britain confident of 'imminent' Brexit deal for financial sector
Description: The United Kingdom is confident that it is on the verge of reaching an agreement with the European Union to give London's vast financial centre access to EU markets after Brexit, Britain's financial services minister John Glen said on Monday.

Headline: Prince Charles acknowledges UK role in horror of slave trade
Description: Prince Charles acknowledged Britain's role in the slave trade on Monday calling it an appalling atrocity that had "left an indelible stain on the history of our world".

Headline: PM May will get a Brexit deal and parliament will pass it, Farage says
Description: Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage said Prime Minister Theresa May will probably get a withdrawal deal with the European Union at the last minute and then have it approved by parliament.

Headline: Britain tells Ireland it needs mechanism to end any Brexit backstop
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Monday told her Irish counterpart Leo Varadkar that there would need to be a mechanism to end any backstop arrangement designed to prevent a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland after Brexit.

Headline: UK announces joint Omani-British military training base

Headline: Ireland willing to examine backstop review mechanism - PM

Headline: Brexit deal will not be agreed this week - Sun political editor
Description: No Brexit deal is likely to be agreed this week between Britain and the European Union and the prospective dates for an emergency summit to seal a deal have been pushed back to Nov. 27 or 28, The Sun newspaper's political editor said on Monday.

Headline: UK working to secure Brexit deal as soon as possible - PM May's spokesman
Description: Britain is working to secure a Brexit deal as soon as possible, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday, adding that a decision on whether to hold a special Brexit summit later this month is up to the European Union.

Headline: UK to assume no-deal Brexit unless a deal done in a week, ITV political editor
Description: The British government has decided that unless there is a deal struck with the European Union within a week, the default option of a no-deal Brexit becomes the probable outcome, ITV's political editor said on Monday.

Headline: Raab wants right to scrap Irish backstop after three months - media
Description: British Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab has privately demanded the right to pull Britain out of a "backstop" arrangement for the Irish border after three months, the Telegraph reported on Sunday.

Headline: UK Brexit-supporting lawmaker Baker - We must leave the EU customs union

Headline: Raab presses May to back hardline plan on Irish border - FT

Headline: All-UK customs Brexit deal report is 'speculation' - PM May's office
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's office has dismissed as "speculation" a newspaper report that suggests an all-UK customs deal will be written into the legally binding agreement governing Britain's withdrawal from the EU

Headline: PM May's former senior adviser, Jeremy Heywood, dies aged 56

Headline: Irish PM says Brexit has undermined Good Friday Agreement
Description: Brexit has undermined the Good Friday Agreement which ended thirty years of violence in Northern Ireland, Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Saturday.

Headline: Britain, Ireland plan regular summits to maintain ties post-Brexit
Description: Britain and Ireland will seek to hold regular summits between leaders and ministers after Brexit to maintain ties strained by Britain's decision to leave the EU, senior ministers from both governments said on Friday.

Headline: Ireland, UK hopeful of Brexit deal in coming weeks - ministers
Description: Britain's Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington said he "hoped and expected" that Brexit negotiators will secure a final agreement in the coming weeks, a view shared on Friday by Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney.

Headline: Britain's Cuadrilla extracts first shale gas at English fracking site
Description: Cuadrilla extracted its first shale gas from its site in northwest England, it said on Friday, after it began fracking operations there just over two weeks ago.

Headline: Separate customs territory for Northern Ireland 'unacceptable' - PM May's spokeswoman
Description: It would be unacceptable for Northern Ireland to be in a separate customs territory from the rest of the United Kingdom after Brexit, British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Friday.

Headline: British police investigate anti-Semitic hate crimes in Labour
Description: British police said on Friday they had launched an investigation into alleged anti-Semitic hate crimes within the opposition Labour Party, after a report that Labour itself had found evidence of party members threatening politicians.

Headline: London's 15 billion pound Crossrail link gets new CEO after delay
Description: Work on London's delayed 15 billion-pound flagship train link will be concluded under a new chief executive, Crossrail said on Friday.

Headline: EU floats new Irish border compromise in tentative Brexit plan - FT
Description: European Union negotiators have floated a tentative Brexit plan to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland and to give Britain stronger guarantees that a customs border would not be needed along the Irish Sea, the Financial Times said on Thursday.

Headline: UK sports minister resigns in protest at gambling reform 'delay'
Description: British sports minister Tracey Crouch resigned from government on Thursday, accusing it of delaying a proposed reform of gambling regulations.

Headline: UK and EU make progress on Brexit deal on financial services - UK official
Description: The United Kingdom and the European Union have made progress on a deal to give London's dominant financial centre basic access to EU markets after Brexit, two British officials said, but no agreement has yet been clinched.

Headline: European businesses demand urgent Brexit deal after meeting May
Description: European business leaders said on Thursday that British Prime Minister Theresa May must find a Brexit deal with the European Union as quickly as possible because uncertainty is damaging investment and undermining growth.

Headline: UK crime agency investigates Brexit campaigner Banks over loans
Description: Britain's serious crime agency began an investigation on Thursday into Brexit backer Arron Banks and one of the main groups that campaigned to leave the European Union over the true source of millions of pounds in loans.

Headline: UK has not seen any successful interference in its democratic processes - May's spokeswoman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Thursday that the government had so far not seen any successful interference in Britain's democratic processes but it remained vigilant.

Headline: European business leaders say Brexit agreement must urgently be found
Description: European business leaders said a Brexit agreement must urgently be found as uncertainty over Britain's exit from the European Union was leading to less investment and undermining growth.

Headline: PM May's spokeswoman declines comment on Brexit campaign funding probe
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Thursday she was unable to comment on the ongoing criminal investigation into funding of the pro-Brexit campaign.

Headline: Prince Charles salutes Gambia's return to Commonwealth
Description: Britain's Prince Charles congratulated Gambia on Thursday for turning its back on "autocratic" rule at home and returning to the Commonwealth fold as he began a nine-day Africa tour.

Headline: Brexit campaigner Banks welcomes investigation
Description: Brexit campaigner Arron Banks on Thursday welcomed a National Crime Agency (NCA) investigation and added that he had never received any foreign - or Russian - funding for one of the main campaigns for Britain to leave the EU.

Headline: Barnier says EU may grant or withdraw equivalence in financial services
Description: The EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier denied on Thursday a Times report of a deal with London on post-Brexit financial services, saying the EU could grant and withdraw equivalence for some financial services on its own.

Headline: EU executive: financial services arrangement only to be discussed after Brexit divorce deal
Description: The European Commission denied on Thursday a report by the Times newspaper that Britain had secured agreement with the EU on financial services after Brexit, saying such a relationship would only be discussed after a divorce deal has been finalised.

Headline: UK-EU financial services deal has not been done - UK govt source
Description: A British government source denied a newspaper report that the UK and the EU had reached a deal on financial services.

Headline: PM May's spokesman says reports of UK-EU financial services deal are speculation
Description: Prime Minster Theresa May's spokesman said reports that Britain was close to securing a deal to give it basic access to EU financial markets were speculation, and negotiations were ongoing.

Headline: Article on UK getting post-Brexit financial services deal is incorrect - EU official
Description: A report by the Times newspaper that Britain and the European Union had reached a tentative agreement on all aspects of a future partnership on services after Brexit is wrong, an EU official said on Thursday.

Headline: UK, EU financial services deal on some access nearly done - UK source
Description: A Brexit deal is nearly done that would give UK-based financial services firms some form of access to European markets, a British official told Reuters.

Headline: Future EU-UK relationship likely an FTA plus equivalence plus MoUs - EU's Huebner
Description: The future relationship between the European Union and Britain after Brexit is likely to be governed by a free trade agreement (FTA), legal equivalence rules for financial services and memoranda of understanding, an EU official said on Thursday.

Headline: EU executive wants divorce deal with Britain, tech level contacts continue
Description: The European Commission said on Thursday it wanted to reach a deal with Britain on its exit from the European Union and that technical contacts were continuing, but that no new high level meetings were scheduled so far.

Headline: EXPLAINER - Britain nears Brexit financial services deal with EU
Description: Britain and the European Union are close to a deal giving UK-based financial services firms basic access to the bloc's markets after Brexit, a British official said.

Headline: EU negotiator plays down hopes of Brexit divorce deal in three weeks - Telegraph
Description: A senior European Union negotiator has poured cold water on hopes that a Brexit divorce deal could be reached within three weeks, Britain's Daily Telegraph reported on Thursday.

Headline: UK housing starts hit 11-year high, boosted by London jump
Description: British builders are planning to construct the biggest number of homes in 11 years, boosted by a bounce-back in London, an industry body said on Thursday.

Headline: May seeks to reassure business on Brexit progress
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May appeared assured when she met business leaders on Wednesday, attendees of the meeting said, and sounded confident on prospects for striking a Brexit deal despite concern that Britain might leave the European Union without one.

Headline: May, Hammond batted away business requests for more investment - executive
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May and Chancellor Philip Hammond batted away on Wednesday requests from business leaders  for special treatment due to Brexit, a senior executive told Reuters.

Headline: May gave robust update to business, admitted Brexit investment difficulties - Serco CEO
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May was robust in giving a pragmatic assessment of Brexit talks to executives on Wednesday but admitted there was little she could do to spur investment while uncertainty remained, Serco CEO Rupert Soames said.

Headline: May told executives Britain to be 'unequivocally' pro-business - May's office
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told 150 business leaders that her government would be "unequivocally pro-business", May's office said on Wednesday, after criticism from some quarters that business had slipped as a priority in Brexit talks.

Headline: Britain plans diplomatic expansion as it eyes post-Brexit influence
Description: Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt on Wednesday set out plans to "reinvigorate and expand" British diplomacy after years of budget cuts as the country looks to boost its influence around the world after Brexit.

Headline: Britain says no date set for end of Brexit talks after Raab hints at November deal
Description: Britain on Wednesday said there was no set date for Brexit talks to finish, backtracking from a letter by Brexit secretary Dominic Raab that suggested a deal on the terms of its departure from the European Union could be finalised by Nov. 21.

Headline: Hunt: Brexit deal by November 21 entirely possible
Description: Foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt said on Wednesday it was entirely possible that there could be enough progress in Brexit talks for a deal with the European Union to be agreed by Nov.  21.

Headline: Duchess Kate sees letters of relatives killed in WW1
Description: Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge, was shown poignant letters and documents on Wednesday relating to three of her relatives who fought and died during World War One.

Headline: UK Brexit ministry says no set date for EU negotiations to end
Description: Britain's Brexit ministry said on Wednesday that there was no set date for Brexit talks to end and Nov. 21 was simply the date MPs proposed Brexit secretary Dominic Raab should appear before a Brexit committee.

Headline: Deal on Brexit is possible by November 21 - Irish foreign minister
Description: A deal on Britain's withdrawal from the European Union is possible by November 21, Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney said on Wednesday, but it will require British negotiators in particular to step up efforts.

Headline: Brexit deal should be done by November 21, UK's Raab says
Description: A Brexit deal is now firmly in sight and should be finalised by November 21, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said in a week-old letter to a lawmaker published on Wednesday that briefly sent sterling sharply higher.

Headline: PM May's spokesman - No comment on Nov. 21 Brexit deal date, want agreement soon
Description: Prime Minster Theresa May's spokesman declined to say whether an EU exit deal was expected by Nov. 21, as indicated in a letter by her Brexit minister Dominic Raab earlier on Wednesday, but said government was working to get a deal as soon as possible.

Headline: British planes scramble to intercept suspected Russian jets
Description: British jets were scrambled to investigate suspected Russian fighter aircraft flying near United Kingdom airspace on Wednesday.

Headline: Low returns put lid on new British gas storage sites, operators say
Description: Investment in new, large gas storage sites in Britain which can help provide a buffer in times of high demand and reduced supply is seen by operators as unlikely due to market prices offering low returns.

Headline: New Brexit vote may hamper independence goal, Scottish MP says
Description: A senior member of the Scottish National Party has questioned his party's backing for a second vote on European Union membership, arguing that it could undermine its Scottish independence goal.

Headline: May says not preparing for general election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that the government was not planning for a general election.

Headline: Conservatives should not try to outspend Labour - Osborne
Description: Former British finance minister George Osborne warned the ruling Conservative Party they must not try to compete with the opposition Labour Party by committing to large increases in government spending ahead of the next election.

Headline: Uber defends its business model over UK worker rights
Description: Uber defended its business model at the Court of Appeal on Tuesday in the latest stage of a long-running battle over the classification of its drivers as self-employed, a designation that entitles them to few workplace rights in Britain.

Headline: UK, Norway agree right to remain for their citizens after Brexit
Description: British citizens already living in Norway and Norwegian citizens living in Britain will have the right to remain residents, even in case of a no-deal Brexit, the prime ministers of Britain and Norway said on Tuesday.

Headline: Budget shows UK not serious about erasing budget deficit by mid-2020s - IFS
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond's budget plans show Britain is not serious about its goal of wiping out its budget deficit by the mid-2020s, the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) said on Tuesday.

Headline: No second referendum on Brexit - PM May
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May reiterated on Tuesday there would be no second referendum on the decision by Britain to leave the European Union.

Headline: Britain to target online giants with new 'Digital Services Tax'
Description: Britain said it would tax the revenue that online platforms such as Google, Facebook and Amazon make in the country to update a system that had not kept pace with changing digital business models.

Headline: Is the UK getting ready for an election? "I hope not," Hammond says
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said on Tuesday that he hoped his budget was not an attempt to prepare for another national election.

Headline: UK academic charged with spying in UAE temporarily released, wife says
Description: A British academic charged with espionage in the United Arab Emirates has been temporarily released until his next hearing on Nov. 21, his wife said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK austerity ending, as long as Brexit deal gets done - Hammond
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond held out the prospect of an end to Britain's long spending squeeze provided the government secures a Brexit deal with the EU, putting pressure on the divided Conservative Party to back Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: UK airlines hit out at higher levy on long-haul flights
Description: Britain's aviation industry hit out at the government on Monday over its decision to increase a tax on long-haul flights, saying it made a mockery of the government's ambition for a 'Global Britain' after it leaves the European Union.

Headline: New 50 pence coin to commemorate Britain's Brexit day
Description: Britain will mint a new 50 pence coin to commemorate leaving the European Union in spring 2019, the finance ministry said on Monday.

Headline: Highlights - Chancellor Hammond delivers budget
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond delivered his annual budget statement to parliament on Monday.

Headline: UK could cut CO2 tax from 2021-22 if total carbon price remains high
Description: Britain should seek to reduce its carbon tax for power generators from 2021-22 if the total carbon price remains high, Treasury documents published as part of the country's budget showed on Monday.

Headline: Government still wants to balance budget - Treasury official
Description: Britain's government still has the ambition of balancing its budget, a Treasury official said on Monday after Chancellor Philip Hammond outlined a series of public spending measures and tax cuts in his budget.

Headline: Budget doesn't alter view of high public debt - Moody's
Description: British public debt looks set to remain high for a long time and Chancellor Philip Hammond's budget on Monday does not change that view, ratings agency Moody's said.

Headline: Government to bring forward promised income tax cuts
Description: British Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday that the government will bring forward income tax cuts for tens of millions of workers to help the economy a month after the United Kingdom is due to leave the European Union.

Headline: Government targets gambling industry with tax increases
Description: Britain's Chancellor Philip Hammond announced on Monday plans to increase taxes paid by offshore gambling companies from next year to offset lost tax revenue from cutting the amount that can be staked on fixed-odds betting terminals.

Headline: Hammond cuts budget deficit forecast for coming years
Description: Britain's government will borrow 18.5 billion pounds less by the early years of the next decade than previously forecast, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Headline: Cuadrilla pauses gas fracking again at English site after tremor
Description: British shale gas company Cuadrilla has paused fracking at its Preston New Road site in northwest England for the second time in two weeks, after a tremor with a magnitude of 1.1 was detected on Monday, the company said.

Headline: Cuadrilla pausing gas fracking at English site after seismic event
Description: British shale gas company Cuadrilla has paused fracking at its Preston New Road site in Lancashire, northwest England, after tremor of magnitude 1.1 was detected, the company said.

Headline: UK confident of a good Brexit deal, health minister says
Description: Britain's health minister said on Monday he was confident that the United Kingdom will get a good deal with the European Union before it leaves the bloc next March.

Headline: Hammond to turn up heat on Brexit rebels in budget speech
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond will use his annual  budget speech on Monday to urge his divided Conservative Party to get behind the government's push for a Brexit deal, or put at risk a long-awaited easing of austerity.

Headline: UK to give small retailers 900 million pound tax cut - finance ministry
Description: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond is likely to give a 900 million pound ($1.15 billion) tax cut to small high-street retailers in his annual budget on Monday to help them compete against online competition, the government said late on Friday.

Headline: Fitch says it no longer assumes Britain will get a smooth Brexit
Description: Ratings agency Fitch said on Friday it no longer assumed that Britain would leave the European Union in a smooth transition and said an acrimonious and disruptive "no deal" Brexit could lead to a further downgrade of its sovereign credit rating.

Headline: Merkel says Europe wants orderly Brexit, is not looking at other scenarios
Description: Europe wants an orderly solution to Brexit and is not debating other options as Britain negotiates its withdrawal from the European Union, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Friday.

Headline: Cuadrilla pauses fracking at UK site after tremor
Description: British shale gas company Cuadrilla said it has paused fracking at its Preston New Road site in Lancashire, northwest England, after a small tremor was detected.

Headline: What are confidentiality agreements at the heart of Britain's "Me Too" debate?
Description: A furore in Britain over allegations of sexual harassment against retail billionaire Philip Green this week has reignited the debate about the use of non-disclosure agreements (NDAs).

Headline: Heathrow airport raises 1.6 billion pounds to brace for Brexit
Description: Britain's Heathrow has raised about 1.6 billion pounds from global investors to boost financial resiliance ahead of Brexit and lay the groundwork for a privately funded expansion of Europe's busiest airport.

Headline: British tycoon Green named over alleged sexual harassment
Description: Retail billionaire Philip Green, one of Britain's most prominent businessmen, was named in parliament on Thursday as having taken legal action to try to prevent publication of allegations of sexual harassment against him.

Headline: Asked about Green knighthood, PM's spokeswoman says committee constantly reviews evidence
Description: Britain's honours committee constantly reviews evidence, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Friday when asked whether businessman Philip Green should be stripped of his knighthood.

Headline: Inflight hiccup as Harry and Meghan's plane aborts Sydney landing
Description: Prince Harry and his wife Meghan returned to Australia on Friday from a tour of Pacific islands after their plane was forced to abort a first landing because another aircraft was in the way.

Headline: Tongan princess greets Harry and Meghan in South Pacific nation
Description: A Tongan princess welcomed Britain's Prince Harry and his wife Meghan on Thursday when they arrived in the tiny South Pacific nation, before driving into the capital as thousands of  schoolchildren cheered and waved flags along the way.

Headline: New tribunal and rules needed to protect small firms - UK MPs
Description: A disputes tribunal underpinned by new regulation is needed to protect small companies after their "scandalous" treatment by banks, a panel of British lawmakers said on Friday.

Headline: Hammond to warn of Brexit hit to spending hopes - NIESR
Description: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond is likely to warn that a no-deal Brexit would hit the public finances and prevent an end to austerity when he delivers his annual budget next week, a think-tank said.

Headline: Bank of England tells banks to build Brexit cash cushions by March
Description: Banks in Britain must hold enough cash to withstand any disorderly Brexit hitting financial markets next March, Bank of England Deputy Governor Sam Woods said on Thursday.

Headline: Labour presses May to deliver 'end of austerity' claim
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party challenged Prime Minister Theresa May's government on Thursday to deliver immediately on its promise that nearly a decade of public spending cuts is coming to an end.

Headline: British 'all-UK' backstop falls short, may be part of solution - Irish PM
Description: Britain's proposal that a so-called "all-UK" backstop provide an insurance mechanism to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland falls short of EU demands but could form part of a solution, Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Thursday.

Headline: UK judge denies Agrokor founder permission to appeal against extradition
Description: Ivica Todoric, founder of beleaguered food production and retail conglomerate Agrokor, must return to Croatia to face allegations of fraud involving tens of millions of euros after a London court refused him permission on Thursday to appeal against his extradition.

Headline: May to meet business leaders to discuss Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May and the Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond will meet around 120 chief executives and international investors on Wednesday to discuss Brexit and next week's budget, her spokesman said.

Headline: UK says EU pragmatism could alleviate Brexit border blockages
Description: If a no-deal Brexit caused blockages at the borders of the United Kingdom then European Union pragmatism could help alleviate disruption, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said on Thursday.

Headline: UK and EU close to agreeing Brexit deal, Raab says
Description: The United Kingdom and the European Union are close to agreeing a Brexit deal, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said on Thursday.

Headline: Irish PM eyes swift conclusion to government extension talks
Description: Ireland's prime minister said talks due to start on Thursday to potentially extend a government cooperation deal with the main opposition party could be finalised quickly.

Headline: British finance watchdog to quiz polling firms over hedge fund clients
Description: Britain's financial watchdog is to meet with polling companies to check if private polls for hedge funds need regulating during events like the Brexit referendum campaign.

Headline: UK car production slumps in September
Description: British car output fell by 16.8 percent last month, hit by new emissions regulations, model changes, trade tensions and uncertainty over diesel policy and Brexit, an industry body said on Thursday.

Headline: Exclusive: UK derivatives clearers may get no-Brexit deal reprieve - EU document
Description: The European Union might grant temporary permission for clearing houses in Britain to continue serving EU customers if there is a no-deal Brexit next March, an EU document seen by Reuters showed.

Headline: PM May receives show of loyalty after talk of leadership challenge
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May received a show of support from her Conservative Party on Wednesday at a meeting in parliament, shifting the focus away from talk of an imminent leadership challenge over her Brexit strategy.

Headline: Conservative lawmakers air Brexit concerns but back PM May - former minister
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May heard lawmakers' concerns about Brexit at a meeting in parliament on Wednesday, but was also given their backing, former interior minister Amber Rudd told reporters.

Headline: Cheering heard as May arrives at meeting with Conservative lawmakers
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's arrival at a meeting of her Conservative Party's lawmakers was greeted with cheers and banging of desks, a Reuters reporter outside the private meeting said on Wednesday.

Headline: May's ministers go to Downing Street
Description: Some of Prime Minister Theresa May's senior ministers and lawmakers from the Northern Irish party which props up her government were seen entering her Downing Street residence on Wednesday, a Reuters photographer said.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon sees 'ever greater' prospect of no Brexit deal
Description: Britain looks increasingly likely to leave the European Union next year with no deal, Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Wednesday.

Headline: Tata Trusts deny patriach Ratan met UK PM Theresa May
Description: Ratan Tata, patriarch of the Indian Tata family, did not meet Prime Minister Theresa May a few weeks ago, Tata Trusts said in a statement, after a government source told Reuters last week that the pair and business minister Greg Clark had recently met. [nL8N1WW5KX]

Headline: British politics damaging chances of Brexit deal - Irish PM
Description: The chances of Brexit negotiators reaching a deal are "very adversely affected" by politics in Britain that remain very divided just five months before it leaves the European Union, Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar.

Headline: PM May clear she does not want indefinite post-Brexit transition period -spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has been clear she does not want to enter into an indefinite post-Brexit transition period with the European Union, her spokesman said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK's top civil servant to step down on medical grounds
Description: Britain's most senior civil servant Jeremy Heywood, 56, said on Wednesday he was standing down to concentrate on his recovery from ill health.

Headline: EU ready to call Brexit summit when 'decisive progress' made - Tusk
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk told the European Parliament on Wednesday that he would be ready to call a special summit on Brexit whenever negotiators said "decisive progress" had been made toward a deal.

Headline: Dutch King highlights Brexit uncertainty on visit to Britain
Description: King Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands highlighted the "shadow of uncertainty" hanging over Dutch nationals living in Britain due to Brexit in an address to the British parliament on Tuesday during a two-day state visit.

Headline: May to address her MPs on Wednesday after attacks over Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will address her Conservative Party lawmakers at a private meeting in parliament on Wednesday, her spokesman said, as she seeks to calm growing tensions over her Brexit strategy.

Headline: Explainer - How the Brexit deal is shaping up
Description: Even as British Prime Minister Theresa May battles critics in her own party, she may be closing in on a Brexit deal which has been stymied by arguments over the Irish border. Here's how:

Headline: May's Brexit transition plan could last for years - London Times
Description: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plan could leave Britain in a "long running" multiyear transition period, the London Times reported on Wednesday citing leaked documents seen by the newspaper.

Headline: 'No deal' Brexit would mean costly border disruption - UK spending watchdog
Description: Companies will suffer and criminals could benefit from the inevitable border disruption that will ensue if Britain leaves the European Union without a deal, the country's public spending watchdog said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK looking at chartering ships to ferry in supplies in no-deal Brexit - FT
Description: Britain is looking at chartering ships to ferry in critical food and medicines in the event of a "no-deal" Brexit next March, the Financial Times reported on Tuesday.

Headline: UK says Northern Ireland can not be in separate customs territory post-Brexit
Description: Britain cannot accept Northern Ireland being in a separate customs territory from the rest of the United Kingdom, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: Report rejects MPs' call for UK financial complaints tribunal
Description: A new financial complaints tribunal for small businesses would be overly costly and take years to set up, a report commissioned by financial services body UK Finance said on Tuesday as it recommended revamping existing services to meet their needs instead.

Headline: May says confident of getting Brexit deal MPs can support
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May believes she can get a Brexit deal that will win the support of parliament, her spokesman said on Tuesday, brushing aside questions about a possible leadership challenge.

Headline: Threshold not yet reached to trigger challenge to PM May - BBC
Description: The threshold of 48 letters from members of parliament that would trigger a leadership challenge to British Prime Minister Theresa May has not yet been reached, BBC Political Editor Laura Kuenssberg said on Twitter.

Headline: Harry and Meghan arrive in Fiji in British royals' first visit since 2006 coup
Description: Britain's Prince Harry and his wife Meghan touched down in Fiji on Tuesday for the first royal visit to the South Pacific nation since a military coup 12 years ago saw it suspended from the Commonwealth for eight years until democratic elections.

Headline: PM May not summoned to face MPs' committee - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has not been invited to attend a meeting of a powerful Conservative Party members of parliament committee this week, her spokesman said, amid reports she had been summoned to face angry members of parliament.

Headline: May tries to calm Brexit rebels, says deal almost done
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May urged restive lawmakers to back her in the final stages of Britain's exit from the European Union, saying talks were in their most difficult phase even if a deal was close.

Headline: Ryanair passenger's racist rant prompts British police investigation
Description: British police are investigating after footage of a man shouting racist abuse at an elderly black woman on a Ryanair flight went viral over the weekend, with the airline facing criticism over how it dealt with the incident.

Headline: UK might need to seek a short extension to Brexit transition - May
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday that London might ask for a short extension of a planned transition period to ease its exit from the European Union.

Headline: EU eyes Brexit customs deal to break Irish deadlock - sources
Description: European Union negotiators are looking at ways to promise Britain a customs deal that could stretch Brussels' Brexit red lines but might break a deadlock over the Irish border, EU sources close to the talks have told Reuters.

Headline: UK Brexit minister - parliament will have time to scrutinise EU exit deal
Description: British Brexit minister Dominic Raab said the country's parliament will have enough time to debate any exit deal Prime Minister Theresa May agrees with the European Union, and that lawmakers will have a real say on whether to approve it or not.

Headline: UK MPs cannot delay or prevent Brexit by amending vote - Raab
Description: Any attempt to change the wording of a vote by the British parliament on a Brexit deal reached by Prime Minister Theresa May will not impact the agreement itself or prevent or delay Britain's departure from the European Union, Brexit minister Dominic Raab said on Monday.

Headline: Northern Irish DUP to back rebel Brexit amendment on Irish border - Telegraph
Description: The Northern Irish party which props up British Prime Minister Theresa May will back an amendment proposed by rebel Brexiteer lawmakers that will effectively make the European Union's backstop proposal illegal, a Telegraph newspaper reporter said.

Headline: UK rebel Brexit MP set to withdraw Northern Ireland amendments, Times
Description: A prominent rebel lawmaker in Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party is set to withdraw amendments that would have made Brexit negotiations difficult, the political editor of The Times newspaper said.

Headline: Britain not looking to pay more money to EU - UK minister
Description: British financial services minister John Glen said on Monday the government would not seek to pay more money to the European Union than it had to as part of its Brexit divorce deal.

Headline: Cost of extending Brexit implementation period is for negotiation - UK minister
Description: The cost of any extension to Britain's post-Brexit transition period is a matter for negotiations with the European Union, British financial services minister John Glen said on Monday.

Headline: Factbox - How does a leadership challenge to a Conservative UK prime minister work?
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's position as leader of the Conservative Party - and consequently her premiership - is under threat, with some lawmakers who oppose her approach to negotiating Britain's departure from the European Union saying they are taking steps to call a confidence vote.

Headline: No place for personal vitriol in politics, May's spokesman says
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday that there was no place for personal vitriol in politics, after weekend media reports where an anonymous critic said "assassination is in the air".
