Description: The European Union's Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Friday he was "determined" to work for a negotiated and managed British withdrawal of the bloc.

Headline: EU's Barnier says ready for new Irish border solutions as Brexit deadline looms
Description: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said in evidence published on Friday that he was willing to consider new ways to solve the Irish border issue, the toughest of remaining issues in Britain's exit negotiation.

Headline: Russia says regrets that Western countries 'repeated lies' from London
Description: Russia's foreign ministry said on Friday it regrets that France, Germany, Canada and the United States "repeated lies" from London and accused Russia of being behind a nerve agent  attack on a former Russian spy and his daughter.

Headline: Britain's Hammond says he is sure Brexit deal will be reached by October deadline
Description: British Finance Minister Philip Hammond said on Friday he was sure Britain will reach an agreement with the European Union on its exit from the bloc by an informal October deadline, in contrast to growing expectations of a no-deal Brexit.

Headline: UK authorities working to better understand BA cyber attack - PM's spokeswoman
Description: The government is aware of a cyber attack affecting British Airways customers and authorities are working to better understand the incident, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Friday.

Headline: China warns UK ties at risk after warship mission
Description: China on Friday warned Britain ties were at risk unless it took steps to "rectify" the situation, after a British warship sailed close to South China Sea islands claimed by China, while a major newspaper said sealing a free trade deal could now be harder.

Headline: UK's former EU ambassador warns of Brexit crisis - Guardian
Description: Britain's former ambassador to the European Union has warned that there is a higher risk of a Brexit crisis than financial markets are currently pricing in, the Guardian reported.

Headline: Spy chief says Britain, allies will counter active Russian threat
Description: Britain and its allies will deploy a "full range of tools" against Russia after London accused two Russian agents of carrying out the attempted murder of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter, a British spy chief said on Thursday.

Headline: France, Germany, Canada and U.S. back Britain over Salisbury poisoning
Description: Britain, France, Germany, Canada and the United States pledged on Thursday to work to disrupt "the hostile activities of foreign intelligence networks" and called on Russia to disclose its nerve agent programme.

Headline: After Navy operation, May's spokesman says UK has strong ties with China
Description: Britain has a strong relationship with China, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Thursday, after Beijing expressed anger over a Royal Navy warship sailing close to islands claimed by China in the South China sea.

Headline: UK bids to break Northern Ireland deadlock by cutting deputies' pay
Description: The British government is to cut the pay of members of Northern Ireland's parliament in its latest attempt to break a political deadlock that has left the region with no government for almost 20 months, the minister for Northern Ireland said on Thursday.

Headline: UK plans legislation to allow Northern Ireland to keep delivering public services - minister
Description: The British government will bring forward legislation to allow Northern Ireland, whose devolved assembly has not sat for 19 months, to continue delivering public services as London plans more talks to help break the deadlock in the province.

Headline: UK regulator caps energy prices to save households about a billion pounds a year
Description: Britain's regulator on Thursday proposed a price cap on default energy bills to save households about a billion pounds a year and aims to implement it in time for winter following a government promise to tackle "rip-off" prices.

Headline: UK sets out plans for visas for non-EU migrant farm workers post-Brexit
Description: British fruit and vegetable farmers will be able to recruit non-European Union migrants on temporary visas after Brexit to help ease labour shortages during busy periods, the British government said on Thursday.

Headline: What is Russia's GRU military intelligence agency?
Description: (This September 5 story has been refiled to correct story to show Russia annexed "part of" Ukraine, not Ukraine.)

Headline: Britain charges two Russians for state-backed plot to kill Skripals
Description: Britain charged two Russians in absentia on Wednesday with the attempted murder of a former Russian spy and his daughter, and said the suspects were military intelligence officers almost certainly acting on orders from high up in the Russian state.

Headline: China criticises UK for ship entering its waters in South China Sea
Description: China's Foreign Ministry said on Thursday a British Royal Navy warship entered Chinese territorial waters around the Paracel Islands in the South China Sea without permission on Aug. 31 and that China's navy warned the British ship to leave.

Headline: From Moscow to Salisbury: UK police detail Novichok suspects' movements
Description: British police on Wednesday detailed the movements of two Russians charged with travelling from Moscow to southwest England to try to murder former Russian spy Sergei Skripal with a military-grade nerve agent.

Headline: UK envoy meets Russian foreign ministry official over Skripal case - Ifax
Description: Britain's ambassador to Russia held talks with an official at the Russian Foreign Ministry on Wednesday to discuss the poisoning of a former Russian spy and his daughter in Britain, the Interfax news agency cited the ministry as saying.

Headline: Britain to present poison evidence to U.N. on Thursday - May's spokesman
Description: Britain will present its evidence on the nerve agent poisoning in Salisbury at a U.N. Security Council meeting on Thursday, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday after she blamed Moscow for the murder attempt.

Headline: Britain and France agree a deal on scallop fishing
Description: Britain and France have agreed a deal over scallop fishing in the English Channel after fishermen from both countries became embroiled in a spat at sea last month, Britain's food and agriculture ministry said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain, France agree deal on scallop fishing after clashes
Description: Britain and France have agreed a deal over scallop fishing in the English Channel after fishermen from both countries clashed at sea last month, Britain's food and agriculture ministry said on Wednesday.

Headline: Thomas Cook says it found e-coli in Egypt hotel where Britons died
Description: British tour operator Thomas Cook said it had found a high level of e-coli and staphylococcus bacteria at the hotel in Egypt where two holidaymakers died last month.

Headline: Germany readies for all Brexit options, including no-deal
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's government said on Wednesday it is preparing for all Brexit scenarios, including a no-deal, after its cabinet approved a draft law on a transition phase for Britain after it leaves the European Union next year.

Headline: Germany has full trust in Barnier on Brexit - government spokesman
Description: The German government has full trust in the European Union's chief Brexit negotiator, who represents the bloc's 27 members in talks with Britain, a spokesman told Reuters on Wednesday.

Headline: Parliament needs to be able to make informed decision on future EU relationship - May's spokesman
Description: The British parliament will need to be able to make an informed decision about Britain's future relationship with the European Union when it votes on whether to back any Brexit deal, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Wednesday.

Headline: Kremlin says puzzled by UK's decision to name Skripal case suspects
Description: Kremlin aide Yuri Ushakov said on Wednesday that it was hard to understand what Britain was trying to signal to Moscow by naming two men it suspected of poisoning former Russian agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia.

Headline: Britain summons Russia's charge d'affaires in London over Skripal affair - RIA
Description: Britain summoned Russia's charge d'affaires in London on Wednesday after charging two suspects over the poisoning of former Russian agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter, Russia's RIA news agency reported.

Headline: UK's summer of discontent - Conservative grassroots can't stand PM's Brexit plan
Description: Over wet grilled sausages and red wine on a rainy British weekend, an evening garden gathering of ageing Conservative Party members seems an unlikely setting for subversion.

Headline: May: We think nerve agent attack was a message to other Russians
Description: A nerve agent attack on a Russian former spy and his daughter in Salisbury, southern England, was probably a message to other Russians living overseas, British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: May says Russia must rein in 'outrageous' Russian GRU
Description: Russia must rein in the activities of its military intelligence officers and account for their actions, British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. and UK stand together in holding Russia accountable for Salisbury - U.S. ambassador
Description: The United States stands with Britain in holding Russia accountable for its "act of aggression" on British soil, US Ambassador to Britain Woody Johnson said on Wednesday.

Headline: RBS to shutter another 54 branches, axe 258 jobs
Description: Britain's Royal Bank of Scotland said on Wednesday it will close a further 54 branches and axe 258 jobs, in what it called the final cut to its branch network until at least 2020.

Headline: Russia says names of men accused over Skripal 'mean nothing to us' - RIA
Description: The Russian Foreign Ministry said on Wednesday that the names of two men British prosecutors have accused of trying to murder former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia meant nothing to Moscow, the RIA news agency reported.

Headline: Russia's OPCW envoy says Russia had nothing to do with Skripal poisoning - RIA
Description: Russia's envoy to the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) said on Wednesday that Moscow had nothing to do with the poisoning of Sergei Skripal, a former Russian spy, in England, the RIA news agency reported.

Headline: May says still working towards October Brexit deal deadline
Description: Britain is still working towards reaching a Brexit deal with the European Union in October, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Merkel's allies want close ties with Britain, reject hard Brexit
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's CSU Bavarian allies said on Wednesday that they wanted to have a close relationship with Britain after its departure from the European Union.

Headline: May to make emergency statement to parliament - Times
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will make an emergency statement to parliament on Wednesday, most likely on national security, the Times newspaper reported.

Headline: Chemical weapons watchdog confirms Novichok use in Amesbury
Description: Laboratory tests by the chemical weapons watchdog confirmed British conclusions that two people in Amesbury, southwest England, were exposed to a Novichok-type nerve agent, it said on Tuesday.

Headline: Labour party moves to defuse anti-Semitism row
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party adopted an internationally accepted definition of anti-Semitism on Tuesday, trying to defuse a row that has heaped pressure on its leader at a time when the government is struggling over Brexit.

Headline: Police hunt loan sharks riding Britain's rising tide of debt
Description: Armed police shin up ladders to scale an imposing security fence and rush past palm trees to raid a sprawling mock-Tudor property in search of evidence.

Headline: Senior UK Brexit ministry official says confident plans in place for 'no-deal' Brexit
Description: The most senior official in Britain's Brexit ministry said on Tuesday he was confident that plans were in place for the possibility of Britain leaving the European Union without a deal.

Headline: No-deal Brexit odds hold at one in four, economists say - Reuters poll
Description: The chances Britain will leave the European Union in March without a deal are one in four, a Reuters poll found, and the Bank of England is likely to wait until after Brexit before raising borrowing costs again.

Headline: Critics 'chuck rocks from both sides' at May's Brexit plans
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy means disaster for Britain, her former foreign secretary Boris Johnson said, as critics at home and officials in Brussels stepped up their opposition to her plans for how to leave the European Union.

Headline: Brexit could sway Scottish voters towards independence from UK - poll
Description: Britain's exit from the European Union could tip public opinion in Scotland in favour of seeking independence, an opinion poll showed on Sunday.

Headline: New UK white collar crime boss pledges to keep agency independent
Description: The new head of Britain's white-collar crime agency pledged on Monday to keep it independent, but work more closely with international enforcement watchdogs and the private sector to stop fraud, drawing on her experience with the FBI.

Headline: World Court weighs Britain's claim to Chagos Islands
Description: Mauritius tried to persuade judges at the World Court on Monday to find that it was illegally stripped by Britain of another Indian Ocean archipelago, the Chagos Islands, now home to a major U.S. air base.

Headline: EU Parliament aims to endorse any deal just two weeks before Brexit day
Description: The European Parliament expects to be able to endorse any deal with London just two weeks before Britain leaves the EU on March 29, a leading lawmaker said on Monday, highlighting how tight the schedule is to agree on divorce terms and future ties.

Headline: PM May's Brexit plan only credible one, can get parliament's support - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May believes that her Brexit proposal is the "only credible and negotiable plan" for Britain to leave the European Union and that it can get the support of parliament, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: May stands firm on her Brexit plan, but scepticism persists
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she would not allow compromises to her Brexit strategy that went against the national interest, seeking to allay fears among some in her Conservative Party that she will cave in to Brussels' demands in negotiations.

Headline: EU-Britain customs union deal would prevent disruption - Barnier
Description: Companies will face disruption to their supply chains if Britain leaves the European Union without securing continued access to the bloc's single market or a customs union, EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier told a German newspaper.

Headline: Raab 'stubbornly optimistic' of Brexit deal with EU
Description: Brexit minister Dominic Raab said he was "stubbornly optimistic" that Britain would reach a deal with the European Union on the terms of its departure from the bloc in time for an October meeting of EU leaders.

Headline: EU, Britain talk up chances of autumn Brexit deal
Description: EU and UK negotiators on Friday talked up prospects of agreeing a Brexit deal this autumn, citing recent progress in detailing very close security cooperation to take effect after Britain leaves the bloc.

Headline: Briton jailed for life over plot to kill PM May
Description: A British man was sentenced to life in prison on Friday over a plot to kill Prime Minister Theresa May by first detonating an explosive device to get into her Downing Street office and then using a knife or a gun to attack her.

Headline: French, UK fishermen to seek scallops deal after sea skirmishes
Description: Fishing industry officials from France and Britain will try to strike a new deal on dredging for scallops next week following violent skirmishes in the Channel, authorities said on Friday.

Headline: London's Gatwick airport says runway open again after brief closure
Description: The main runway at London's Gatwick Airport was briefly closed on Friday but has reopened, a spokesman for the airport said.

Headline: Veteran Labour MP brands party leadership a 'force for anti-Semitism'
Description: One of the longest-serving lawmakers in Britain's opposition Labour Party has attacked its leadership for becoming "a force for anti-Semitism" and said he will no longer vote with the party in parliament.

Headline: Egypt investigates hotel after death of British couple - minister
Description: Egypt's tourism minister said on Thursday authorities would test food and hygiene at a hotel where a British couple stayed before dying last week, and that a forensic team would complete their postmortem in the coming days.

Headline: UK inventor Dyson outlines plans for electric car test track
Description: James Dyson, billionaire British inventor of the bagless vacuum cleaner, outlined plans on Thursday to build new testing facilities and invest another 116 million pounds ($150 million) to develop an electric car to be launched by 2020.

Headline: Britain to consider doubling charge on single-use plastic bags
Description: The British government said on Thursday it was considering doubling a 5 pence (six cents) charge for single-use plastic bags and extending it to all shops.

Headline: UK considers banning 'energy drink' sales to children in England
Description: The sale of high-caffeine soft drinks to children could be banned in England, the British government said on Thursday, citing public health concerns.

Headline: UK foreign minister attacks Google over 'child abuse content'
Description: British foreign minister Jeremy Hunt accused Google on Thursday of abandoning its moral values by failing to remove child abuse content while launching a version of its search engine in China that will block some websites.

Headline: German finmin believes much euro clearing will move to Frankfurt
Description: German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz said on Thursday he believed a large part of euro clearing would move to mainland Europe and Frankfurt over time.

Headline: Germany urges Europe not to adopt a 'Europe First' policy
Description: Germany's finance minister warned against following a "Europe First" policy and said it was unclear whether the European Union would reach a Brexit agreement with Britain.

Headline: British car output drops annual 11 percent in July
Description: British car production fell 11 percent year-on-year in July, hit by model changes, seasonal adjustments and preparations for tougher new emissions standards, an industry body said on Thursday.

Headline: Ex-Scottish leader Salmond resigns from SNP amid misconduct allegations
Description: Former Scottish first minister Alex Salmond said on Wednesday he  has resigned from the Scottish National Party, which he led for two decades, days after allegations of sexual misconduct became publicly known.

Headline: Court rules UK free to extradite Singapore bank robbery suspect
Description: A British court has ruled that a fugitive wanted by Singapore for a rare bank robbery could be extradited after the wealthy city-state agreed to waive corporal punishment if he is found guilty.

Headline: EU's Barnier offers Britain close ties but 'no single market a la carte'
Description: The European Union is prepared to offer Britain an unprecedentedly close relationship after it quits the bloc but would not allow anything that weakened the body's single market, chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK starts work on satellite system to rival EU's Galileo
Description: Britain said on Wednesday it would start work on an alternative satellite system to the European Union's Galileo project to ensure its national security if it is barred from equal access to the EU programme after Brexit.

Headline: UK sees several possible causes of no-deal Brexit
Description: A British departure from the European Union without an agreed exit deal could be triggered by several different events, Brexit minister Dominic Raab said on Wednesday, adding that Britain was prepared for the risks.

Headline: UK minister: If EU punishes City of London, non-EU financial centres will benefit
Description: Financial centres outside the European Union would be the benefactors if the European Union sought to punish the City of London as Britain leaves the bloc, Brexit minister Dominic Raab said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK could hold back EU payments without Brexit deal - UK's Raab
Description: Britain could choose to withhold some payments to the European Union if a deal to ease its exit from the bloc is not reached before it leaves in March, Brexit minister Dominic Raab told legislators on Wednesday.

Headline: UK's Brexit plan has had 'reasonably positive' reaction from EU states - minister
Description: Britain's negotiating stance on Brexit, published in July, has received a reasonably positive reaction from other members of the European Union, Brexit minister Dominic Raab said on Wednesday.

Headline: Former UK chief rabbi calls Corbyn an anti-Semite
Description: Britain's former chief rabbi Jonathan Sacks has called Labour opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn an anti-Semite and said comments about Zionists he made five years ago were the most offensive by a senior UK politician in half a century.

Headline: Britain will use aid budget to boost trade in Africa - PM May
Description: Britain will use its international aid budget to boost its own  interests while also seeking to deepen trade ties with Africa, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday, countering critics who say aid funds would be better spent at home.

Headline: May says no-deal Brexit not 'the end of the world' - Sky
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has said that failing to secure a deal with the European Union before Britain leaves the bloc next year "wouldn't be the end of the world", Sky News reported on Tuesday.

Headline: Treasury denies report it asked Carney to stay longer at BoE
Description: The Treasury denied a newspaper report on Tuesday that the government had asked Bank of England Governor Mark Carney to stay on for an extra year beyond his scheduled departure in June 2019.

Headline: Germany's Maas says hard Brexit 'not yet off the table'
Description: German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas on Tuesday said there was still the risk of a hard Brexit and the European Union must prepare for every outcome in its divorce talks with Britain.

Headline: Germany wants to avoid no-deal Brexit - Maas
Description: Germany's Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said on Tuesday that Berlin wants to avoid a disorderly Brexit, meaning the risk of Britain crashing out of the European Union without a deal, but he added that officials were also preparing for such an outcome.

Headline: Irish foreign minister urges UK to clarify its Brexit stance
Description: Ireland's Foreign Minister Simon Coveney said on Tuesday that more clarity was needed about Britain's stance regarding its planned departure from the European Union.

Headline: UK supports South African land reform - PM May
Description: Britain supports South Africa's land reform programme provided it is carried out legally, Prime Minister Theresa May said in Cape Town on Tuesday, adding that she would discuss the issue with President Cyril Ramaphosa.

Headline: France to make contingency plans for no-deal Brexit
Description: French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe on Monday asked his ministers to prepare contingency measures in case of a no-deal Brexit.

Headline: British-Iranian aid worker returns to jail after temporary release - husband
Description: A detained British-Iranian aid worker sentenced to five years in jail in Iran was returned to prison on Sunday after a request to extend her three-day temporary release was rejected, her husband said.

Headline: Irish foreign minister says no-deal Brexit 'very, very unlikely'
Description: It is "very, very unlikely" that Britain will crash out of the European Union next year without an exit deal with the bloc, Ireland's Foreign Minister Simon Coveney said on Sunday.

Headline: UK to start work on satellite system to rival EU's Galileo - Sunday Telegraph
Description: Britain is to start work on its own satellite navigation system to rival the European Union's Galileo project because the UK's access to sensitive security information could be restricted after Brexit, the Sunday Telegraph reported.

Headline: Play predicts chilling future for UK's prized health service
Description: A desperate mechanic driven to operate on his sick wife is the subject of a disturbing play which looks at the future of Britain's prized public health service, shown at the Edinburgh Fringe.

Headline: China says agrees with UK to discuss 'top notch' free trade deal
Description: China and Britain have agreed to look at the possibility of reaching a "top notch" free trade agreement after Britain leaves the European Union, China's Commerce Ministry said on Saturday after talks with British trade minister Liam Fox.

Headline: Conservatives split again by Hammond's Brexit warning
Description: The split in Britain's ruling party over how to leave the European Union was exposed again on Friday as pro-Brexit MPs turned on the Chancellor for his latest warning that a so-called hard Brexit would hurt the economy.

Headline: U.S. sanctions on Russia tied to UK attack to take effect Monday
Description: U.S. sanctions against Russia tied to a nerve agent attack in Britain, which were announced earlier this month, will come into effect on Monday, the U.S. government said on Friday, adding to the array of economic penalties it has imposed on Moscow in recent years.

Headline: UK says RAF jets interrupted path of Russian plane over Black Sea
Description: British fighter jets interrupted the path of a Russian maritime patrol aircraft over the Black Sea in the second such incident this week, Britain's defence ministry said on Friday.

Headline: British comic Elf Lyons makes economics a laughing matter
Description: You could say British comic Elf Lyons is one half of a double-act – the other half is her father Gerard Lyons, a prominent economist and former advisor to politician Boris Johnson.

Headline: UK food exports to EU may be stalled by 'no deal' Brexit - NFU
Description: Britain could be barred from exporting some food to the European Union for months if it leaves the bloc without a deal, the National Farmers Union said on Thursday after the government published reports on that scenario.

Headline: UK minister says November Brexit deal would be manageable
Description: Britain would be able to handle a delay in securing a Brexit deal with the European Union if the talks extended into November and missed their informal October deadline, cabinet office minister David Lidington said on Friday.

Headline: No-deal Brexit will bring tangle of red tape, Britain warns companies
Description: Britain on Thursday told companies trading with the European Union they would face a tangle of red tape, possible border delays and more costly credit card payments if the government fails to negotiate an exit deal before Britain leaves the bloc.

Headline: British-Iranian aid worker temporarily released from Tehran jail
Description: A detained British-Iranian aid worker sentenced to five years in jail in Iran has been released from detention for three days, her supporters and Iran's envoy to Britain said on Thursday, in a move welcomed by Britain's foreign minister.

Headline: Foreign Secretary Hunt welcomes Iran's temporary release of aid worker
Description: Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said on Thursday he welcomed news that Iran had temporarily released Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British-Iranian aid worker, from prison, but said she should not have been behind bars in the first place.

Headline: British Airways, Air France halting flights to Iran from next month
Description: British Airways and Air France said on Thursday they would halt flights to Iran from September for business reasons, months after U.S. President Donald Trump announced he would re-impose sanctions on Tehran.

Headline: Conservatives block attempt by Brexiteer Arron Banks to join party
Description: Britain's ruling Conservative party has blocked an attempt by leading Brexit supporter Arron Banks to become a member in the hope of trying to get a hardline Brexiteer elected as party leader if Prime Minister Theresa May steps down.

Headline: Britons living in EU could lose access to UK bank services in no-deal Brexit
Description: Britons living in the European Union could lose access to their UK bank account services and businesses on the continent could be cut off from investment banks in London if there is a no-deal Brexit, the British government said on Thursday.

Headline: Iran's envoy to UK regrets British Airways decision to suspend Tehran flights
Description: Iran's top envoy to Britain said on Thursday a decision by British Airways to suspend flights to Tehran from September was regrettable.

Headline: British businesses relieved at no-deal Brexit VAT tweak
Description: British business welcomed a commitment from the government to change how import VAT has to be paid should Britain leave the European Union without a deal - a technical accounting tweak that should avert a cashflow "time bomb" for many companies.

Headline: UK calls for extra six weeks of Brexit drug stockpiles
Description: The British government called on Thursday for drugmakers to build an additional six weeks of medicines stockpiles to cope with potential supply disruption in the event of a no-deal Brexit - a target the industry said would be challenging.

Headline: Factbox - Reaction to the British government's 'no deal' Brexit plans
Description: Britain on Thursday set out a series of notes detailing what could happen if it fails to reach a Brexit deal with the European Union, acknowledging that firms would face a tangle of red tape and possible delays at the border.

Headline: Labour proposes tax on tech giants in media shake-up
Description: A Labour government would aim to shake up Britain's media by levying a tax on big tech firms like Google  and Facebook  to help fund public interest journalism, party leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Thursday.

Headline: Factbox - Britain sets out plans for 'no-deal' Brexit
Description: Britain has published 25 so-called technical notices advising companies and people how to prepare for any disruption that might arise from a disorderly Brexit where there is no deal with the European Union.

Headline: Brexit minister confident Britain will reach deal with EU
Description: Britain's Brexit Minister Dominic Raab said he was confident a good deal with the European Union remained in sight, but it was right to set out a "measured and proportionate" approach outlining the risks if the two sides cannot agree.

Headline: British Typhoons scrambled from Romania to shadow Russian jets
Description: Two British Typhoon jets were scrambled from Romania to investigate suspected Russian fighter aircraft operating near NATO airspace over the Black Sea, the Royal Air Force (RAF) said on Wednesday.

Headline: British Royal Navy monitors Russian warship in English Channel
Description: The Royal Navy said one of its vessels was monitoring a Russian warship in the English Channel, the fourth UK ship required to observe Russian movements around Britain in the last two months.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon says Brexit endangers economy
Description: Scotland's pro-independence First Minister said Britain's impending departure from the European Union would damage the economy in Scotland and the rest of the United Kingdom, and that she would not block another Brexit referendum.

Headline: Corbyn to meet asylum-seekers at centre of Scottish row
Description: Opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, on a four day trip to boost his party's fortunes in Scotland, will meet asylum seekers in Glasgow on Wednesday amid a row about the treatment of would-be immigrants.

Headline: EU expects delay in Brexit deal beyond October target
Description: European Union leaders are likely to have to hold an emergency summit in November to consider any Brexit agreement struck with Britain, missing an informal deadline the previous month, diplomats in Brussels said.

Headline: EU expects delay in Brexit deal beyond October target
Description: European Union leaders are likely to have to hold an emergency summit in November to consider any Brexit agreement struck with Britain, missing an informal deadline the previous month, diplomats in Brussels said.

Headline: EU's Barnier says Brexit must keep bloc's single market intact
Description: The European Union's Brexit negotiator said on Tuesday any agreement with Britain on their future relationship must respect the bloc's single market rules.

Headline: Raab hopes Brexit deal with EU still possible in October
Description: Britain is confident it can reach a Brexit agreement with the European Union in October, the country's chief negotiator on leaving the bloc said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain presses for more EU sanctions against Russia
Description: Britain pressed the European Union on Tuesday to increase sanctions against Russia, saying it should stand "shoulder to shoulder" with the United States, which hit Moscow with new economic restrictions this month.

Headline: Russia accuses UK of trying to dictate policy to the EU and U.S.
Description: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov accused Britain on Tuesday of trying to impose its hostile Russia policy on the European Union and the United States, Russian news agencies reported.

Headline: Kremlin declines to comment on UK call for more EU sanctions against Russia
Description: The Kremlin on Tuesday declined to comment on a British call for the European Union to increase sanctions against Russia, saying it was not yet familiar with the details of what London was proposing.

Headline: Britain apologises to migrants removed in Windrush scandal
Description: Britain said it would formally apologise to 18 members of the "Windrush generation" who were forced to leave or detained because they were not issued with documents when they came to the country from the Caribbean after World War Two.

Headline: UK prosecutors drop charges against ex-police chief over Hillsborough
Description: A former British police chief constable accused of lying over his role in the 1989 Hillsborough football stadium crush that killed 96 fans will no longer face charges after a review of evidence, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain can't afford to close door to EU banks after Brexit
Description: Britain is expected to keep the door open for European Union banks and investors after Brexit to try to preserve London's global financial clout, irrespective of whether it gets a good trade deal from the bloc, bankers and industry officials say.

Headline: Britain can't afford to close door to EU banks after Brexit
Description: Britain is expected to keep the door open for European Union banks and investors after Brexit to try to preserve London's global financial clout, irrespective of whether it gets a good trade deal from the bloc, bankers and industry officials say.

Headline: Trump not the isolationist many feared - Hunt
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump has not been the isolationist that many feared he would be, Britain's Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said ahead of his first trip to the United States in the role.

Headline: London tube station shooting injures three people -  police
Description: A shooting at London's Kingsbury tube station has left three people injured, police said on Monday night, adding that the shooting is "not terror related."

Headline: UK government takes control of crisis-hit prison run by G4S
Description: The British government has taken over the running of a major prison from contractor G4S after an inspection found that staff locked themselves in offices to avoid prisoners who were using drugs and violence with near impunity.

Headline: UK parliament attack suspect appears in court, charged with attempted murder
Description: A Sudanese-born British man appeared in court on Monday to face two charges of attempted murder after a car careered into people and a barrier at Britain's parliament last week.

Headline: Business leaders' confidence in UK economy at lowest so far this year - survey
Description: Business leaders' confidence in the British economy has fallen to its lowest point this year reflecting the impact of  uncertainty over Britain's exit deal with the European Union, according to a survey published on Monday.

Headline: May could face trouble over Brexit deal, Conservative lawmaker warns
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May could face trouble getting her Brexit deal approved by the British parliament before exit day unless she changes her proposals, the head of an influential group of pro-Brexit lawmakers said in an interview published on Sunday.

Headline: Superdry co-founder gives 1 million pounds to campaign for second Brexit vote
Description: The co-founder of fashion brand Superdry  is donating a million pounds ($1.28 million) to the campaign for a referendum on the final Brexit agreement as Britain prepares to outline in more detail how a no-deal outcome would work.

Headline: UK hopes to pick up Brexit talks pace with Raab-Barnier meeting on Tuesday
Description: Britain's Brexit minister Dominic Raab will travel to Brussels on Tuesday in a bid to pick up the pace of Brexit talks with the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier, Prime Minister Theresa May's office said on Saturday.

Headline: Man to appear in court on Monday over UK parliament car incident
Description: Sudanese-born British national Salih Khater was charged with two counts of attempted murder on Saturday and will appear in court on Monday after a car careered into people and a barrier at Britain's parliament earlier this week, police said.

Headline: London mayor Khan consults disaster planners over no-deal Brexit
Description: London's mayor Sadiq Khan said on Friday he had asked the organisation that deals with militant attacks and disasters in the British capital to assess the impact of a "no-deal" Brexit on access to medicines and food and on law and order.

Headline: Scotland's Ayrshire to give free tampons to tackle period poverty
Description: Scotland's North Ayrshire Council has become the first local authority in Britain to provide free sanitary provision in public buildings, hoping to tackle "period poverty".

Headline: MPs want British vaping rules relaxed to help smokers quit
Description: Vaping rules should be relaxed to allow the promotion of e-cigarettes as tools to help tobacco smokers quit, British lawmakers said on Friday.

Headline: Rapper Stormzy to fund Cambridge university scholarship for two black students
Description: Rapper Stormzy said on Thursday he will fund two black British students to go to Cambridge university through a scholarship, after criticism of some top UK universities that their admissions processes do not do enough to ensure diversity.

Headline: Man arrested after suspected parliament attack named - source
Description: A man detained on suspicion of carrying out a terrorist attack outside Britain's parliament is Salih Khater, a British citizen of Sudanese origin, a European security source told Reuters on Wednesday.

Headline: Financial Times boss to return some of 2.6 million pound pay after staff protest
Description: Financial Times Chief Executive John Ridding is to pay back some of his 2.6 million pound salary after a group of the newspaper's reporters complained about his pay.

Headline: MPs ask Philip Green to prove BHS was going concern
Description: A British parliamentary committee has asked billionaire Philip Green to "prove" why he thought retailer BHS could stay in business before it was sold in 2015 for a token one pound, before collapsing a year later.

Headline: Man held after incident at UK parliament arrested for attempted murder
Description: A 29-year-old man detained over a suspected terrorist attack outside parliament has been further arrested for attempted murder, police said on Wednesday.

Headline: Man arrested after suspected parliament attack named as Salih Khater - source
Description: A man detained on Tuesday on suspicion of deliberately targeting pedestrians outside Britain's parliament is Salih Khater, a British citizen of Sudanese origin who was not previously known to intelligence agencies, a European security source said.

Headline: British actress can sue Weinstein for sex trafficking - U.S. judge
Description: Movie producer Harvey Weinstein must face a U.S. lawsuit by a British actress who has accused him of violating sex trafficking laws by inviting her to a hotel room in France and sexually assaulting her, a federal judge ruled on Tuesday.

Headline: Car hits pedestrians at parliament in suspected terrorist attack
Description: A man deliberately drove a car into London pedestrians and cyclists on Tuesday before ramming it into barriers outside Britain's parliament in what police said appeared to be the second terrorist attack at the building in just under 18 months.

Headline: Police searching three addresses after London incident
Description: Police investigating a man who drove into pedestrians outside parliament on Tuesday morning said they were searching two addresses in Birmingham and one in Nottingham, central England, as part of their inquiries.

Headline: Driver who hit London pedestrians was British citizen - security minister
Description: A man who drove a car into London pedestrians outside Britain's parliament on Tuesday was a British citizen who originally came from another country, security minister Ben Wallace said.

Headline: May says Westminster incident shocking, terrorism threat remains severe
Description: A suspected attack outside the Houses of Parliament on Tuesday is shocking, Prime Minister Theresa May said, warning that the terrorism threat to the United Kingdom remained severe.

Headline: Risk of no-deal Brexit rising, 'everyone needs to prepare' - Hunt
Description: The risk of a no-deal Brexit has been increasing and the European Union commission needs to change its attitude if a deal is to be reached, foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt said on Tuesday.

Headline: Trump vows 'toughness and strength' after UK parliament incident
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday said that terrorists should be treated with "toughness and strength" after a man drove a car into members of the public and a security barrier outside Britain's parliament, injuring three.

Headline: Incident at UK parliament 'deliberate act', suspect not cooperating -police
Description: Britain's counter-terrorism police chief said investigators believe a man deliberately drove a car into pedestrians before crashing into barriers outside parliament on Tuesday and the arrested suspect was not cooperating with detectives.

Headline: Corbyn trades barbs with Netanyahu on Mideast violence
Description: A furore over alleged anti-semitism in Britain's main opposition party widened on Monday when Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn exchanged accusations on Twitter over Israeli-Palestinian bloodshed.

Headline: UK emergency response committee to meet after Westminster incident
Description: The British government will hold a meeting of its COBRA emergency response committee at 1300 GMT to discuss an incident in which a man drove a car into security barriers outside parliament and injured at least two people on Tuesday, officials said.

Headline: Police say incident outside UK parliament being treated as terrorism
Description: A man has been detained on suspicion of terrorist offences, British police said on Tuesday, after a car hit pedestrians and crashed into barrier outside the UK parliament.

Headline: May - My thoughts are with those injured in Westminster incident
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said her thoughts were with those injured in an incident outside parliament on Tuesday after two people were taken to hospital when a car crashed into security barriers.

Headline: Both sides claim victory as Stati vs Kazakhstan case is dropped in UK
Description: An English appeals court has allowed a Moldovan businessman to drop a legal case against Kazakhstan, with both sides claiming tactical victories in a complicated legal battle that involves over $6 billion (£4.7 billion) in frozen Kazakh assets held abroad.

Headline: May's spokesman says level of sterling is for markets to determine
Description: The level of sterling, which has tumbled to near 13-month lows over Brexit fears and the dollar strength, is for financial markets to determine, British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Russia's foreign ministry says Skripal case allegations 'groundless'
Description: Russia's foreign ministry on Monday said allegations of Moscow's involvement in the poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal in the English town of Salisbury - an event which led to a new round of U.S. sanctions against Russia - were groundless.

Headline: Heathrow Airport passport queues reached two-and-a-half hours in July - data
Description: Passengers arriving at London's Heathrow Airport had to queue at passport control for up to two-and-a-half hours in July, official figures showed, sparking further criticism from aviation chiefs about delays caused by Britain's border regime.

Headline: Splits deepen over British ex-minister Johnson's burqa comments
Description: Former British foreign minister Boris Johnson returned from his summer holiday to face both criticism and support over his remarks about burqas, amid deepening divisions in Britain's ruling Conservative Party on Sunday.

Headline: Collapsed UK retailer BHS pension scheme secured by $1 billion insurance buyout
Description: The pensions of 9,000 employees of collapsed British department store chain BHS were secured on Sunday after a specialist insurer announced an insurance buyout of the firm's 'BHS2' scheme covering 800 million pounds  of liabilities.

Headline: Britain concerned by Yemen attack, calls for investigation - minister
Description: A transparent investigation must be held into an air strike in Yemen which killed dozens of children, a British Foreign Office minister said on Friday.

Headline: U.S. strongly condemns Russia's poisoning of former spy - White House
Description: The White House said on Friday the United States strongly condemned Russia's use of chemical weapons against a former Russian agent in Britain, two days after the U.S. State Department announced sanctions over the move.

Headline: UK economy on track to grow at fastest since fourth quarter 2016 - NIESR
Description: Britain's economy looks on track to grow at its fastest rate since the tail end of 2016, according to an estimate from the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) on Friday.

Headline: UK voters should make final Brexit decision if talks with EU collapse - poll
Description: If Brexit talks break down without a deal, half of Britons believe the final decision over whether to leave the European Union should be taken by the public in a referendum, according to a survey of more than 10,000 people published on Friday.

Headline: UK banks should raise savings rates as 'matter of trust' - MP
Description: British banks should pass on last week's Bank of England interest rate rise to savers as "a matter of trust", the chair of the parliament committee which monitors them said on Friday.

Headline: Brexit uncertainty is depressing UK growth - Hammond
Description: Uncertainty over Brexit is depressing economic growth in Britain, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Friday after official data showed lacklustre year-on-year expansion.

Headline: May's Conservative party takes lead over Labour - Times
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has taken a four point lead over Labour according to a poll published in the Times newspaper on Friday, which suggests a row over anti-Semitism is damaging the opposition party's appeal.

Headline: Russia denounces new U.S. sanctions as illegal, mulls retaliation
Description: Russia condemned a new round of U.S. sanctions as illegal on Thursday and said it had begun working on retaliatory measures after news of the curbs pushed the rouble to two-year lows over fears Moscow was locked in a spiral of never-ending sanctions.

Headline: Treasury readying Brexit contingency plans for finance industry
Description: The Treasury said on Thursday it would soon start putting contingency arrangements in place for financial services regulation if the country crashes out of the European Union without a deal.

Headline: U.S. says Russia sanctions to target security-related goods
Description: U.S. sanctions on Russia will target exports of national security-related goods including sectors such as specialised oil and gas technology and some electronics and sensors, a senior U.S. State Department official said on Thursday.

Headline: Russia to work on retaliatory measures against new U.S. sanctions - Foreign Ministry
Description: Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said on Thursday that Moscow was starting to work on retaliatory measures after the United States announced a new round of sanctions against Moscow.

Headline: Johnson will be probed by party for burqa comments - source
Description: Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson will be investigated for a possible breach of the Conservative Party's code of conduct after making comments about Muslim women who wear burqas, a party source said on Thursday.

Headline: Russia calls new U.S. sanctions draconian, rejects poisoning allegations
Description: Russia's embassy in the United States on Thursday called new U.S. sanctions draconian and said the reason for the new restrictions -- allegations it poisoned a former spy and his daughter in Britain -- were far-fetched.

Headline: UK says Russia needs to know there is a price to pay for using chemical weapons
Description: States like Russia that use or condone the use of chemical weapons need to know there is a price to pay, British Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said on Thursday.

Headline: Bangladesh acquits British citizen held since 2016 cafe attack
Description: A Bangladesh court on Wednesday acquitted a British man detained without charge for two years on suspicion of involvement in a July 2016 attack on a cafe in Dhaka that killed 22 people, his lawyer said.

Headline: May scolds Johnson for burqa remark after outcry
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has scolded her former foreign secretary, Boris Johnson, for saying that Muslim women who wear burqas look like letter boxes or bank robbers.

Headline: No-deal Brexit? What it might mean for Britain
Description: The prospect of a "no-deal Brexit" appears to have grown after the European Union's negotiator rejected last month central elements of Prime Minister Theresa May's proposals for a new trade agreement.

Headline: PM May to meet Scotland's Sturgeon after Brexit standoff
Description: Scottish leader Nicola Sturgeon accused the British government of "talking-up" a no-deal Brexit, making it more likely the United Kingdom will just drop out of the European Union at great cost to the economy.

Headline: UK will always be 'tier one' military power, says defence secretary
Description: Britain will always be a "tier one" military power, defence secretary Gavin Williamson said on Tuesday.

Headline: Heathrow Airport opponents launch legal challenge to expansion
Description: A group of local authorities opposed to the expansion of Heathrow have formally started the process to try to launch a legal challenge to the government's plan to build a new runway at Europe's busiest airport.

Headline: Timeline - Brexit at breaking point? Diary dates for Britain's EU departure
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has less than eight months to negotiate a Brexit deal, sell it to her divided Conservative Party and win parliamentary approval.

Headline: Chemical weapons inspectors to collect new samples in UK nerve agent poisoning
Description: Inspectors of the world's chemical weapons watchdog will return to Britain on request of the government to take new samples of the nerve agent which killed one person and injured another in Amesbury, England, in June.

Headline: European companies can be protected from U.S. sanctions on Iran - UK minister
Description: European companies can be protected from new U.S. sanctions on Iran, a junior British foreign minister said on Tuesday, after President Donald Trump withdrew from an international agreement designed to deny Tehran the ability to build nuclear weapons.

Headline: May still believes Britain will win a good Brexit deal - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May still believes that Britain will negotiate a good Brexit deal with the European Union rather than failing to win any agreement for its departure from the bloc, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: British Airways boss says two-hour Heathrow passport queues unacceptable
Description: Two hour-long queues for passport checks at London's Heathrow Airport are unacceptable and improvements are needed if Britain wants to show it is open for business after it leaves the European Union, the chief executive of British Airways said.

Headline: Act on anti-Semitism or face 'eternal shame', deputy leader of UK's Labour
Description: The deputy leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party increased pressure on its leader, Jeremy Corbyn, over anti-Semitism on Sunday, saying the party could "disappear into a vortex of eternal shame" unless he tackled a growing crisis.

Headline: Britain plans for opt-out organ donation scheme to save lives
Description: Britain plans to increase the number of organ donors by changing the rules of consent and presuming that people have agreed to transplants unless they have specifically opted out.

Headline: Britain's Labour leader sees 'real problem' of anti-Semitism in party
Description: The leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn, said on Friday there was a "real problem" of anti-Semitism in his party which he would root out, but he also hit back at strong criticism of Labour from Jewish newspapers.

Headline: BoE's Carney sees 'uncomfortably high' risk of no-deal Brexit
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Friday Britain faces an "uncomfortably high" risk of leaving the European Union with no deal, comments that drove sterling to an 11-day low against the dollar.

Headline: MPs study value for money from pensions
Description: MPs have launched an inquiry into whether people are getting value for money from their private pensions and impartial information from financial advisers.

Headline: British amphibious assault ship arrives in Tokyo
Description: The British Navy's flagship amphibious assault ship HMS Albion arrived in Tokyo on Friday extending Britain's naval presence in East Asia to four months as London deepens military ties in a region it considers vital to global security and economic prosperity as it exits the European Union.

Headline: Less than a third of UK business leaders planning for Brexit - survey
Description: Less than a third of 800 UK business leaders surveyed have carried out contingency planning on Brexit, the Institute of Directors (IoD) said on Friday.

Headline: India sends extradition request to UK for fugitive billionaire
Description: India has asked Britain to extradite billionaire jeweller Nirav Modi, one of the main accused in the $2 billion (1.5 billion pounds) loan fraud at state-run Punjab National Bank (PNB).

Headline: Police complete forensic investigation of London's Grenfell Tower after deadly fire
Description: British police said on Thursday they had completed the forensic examination of Grenfell Tower after a fire that killed 71 at the building last year, adding that it was no longer required as a crime scene by investigators.

Headline: UK says Brexit no-deal warnings are 'Project Reality', not 'Project Fear'
Description: Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt denied on Wednesday that warnings about fallout from a disorderly exit from the European Union were an attempt to scare opponents of the government's preferred Brexit plan into supporting it.

Headline: More drugmakers build Brexit stockpiles as EU agency faces exodus
Description: Sanofi and Novartis said on Wednesday they planned to increase stockpiles of medicines in Britain in preparation for potential disruption if the UK crashes out of the European Union without a deal.

Headline: England's Freemasons to allow women - if they were once male
Description: England's Freemasons are to admit women to their secretive society - but only if they were previously male masons.

Headline: Far-right activist Robinson released on bail after court victory
Description: Jailed far-right activist Tommy Robinson, whose case has attracted the sympathy of right-wing supporters of U.S. President Donald Trump, was released on bail on Wednesday after winning an appeal against a contempt of court ruling.

Headline: Corbyn apologises after 2010 event which compared Israel to Nazis
Description: The leader of the Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn, apologised on Wednesday for causing "concern and anxiety" by hosting a 2010 event at which another speaker was reported by a newspaper to have compared Israeli policy to Nazi policies.

Headline: BoE should raise rates, but be ready for U-turn - NIESR
Description: The Bank of England should raise interest rates this week but also tell the public it will be ready to make a U-turn if Brexit talks sour or trade tensions with the United States escalate, a leading economic think tank said on Wednesday.

Headline: Banks say UK finance exports underscore need for good Brexit deal
Description: Britain's exports of financial services to the European Union hit a record high last year, highlighting the need for the City to preserve access to the bloc after Brexit, industry officials said on Tuesday.

Headline: Families of 9/11 victims look to seize Iran assets in Britain
Description: An English court has cleared the way to consider whether it will allow the families of some of those killed in the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks on the United States to make a claim on Iranian assets in Britain.

Headline: Dublin to push for fresh Northern Irish talks in the autumn - PM
Description: The Irish government will push Northern Ireland's political parties to make a fresh attempt at restoring their devolved power-sharing government later this year, Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain's car industry cautions: No-deal Brexit is our nightmare
Description: A no-deal Brexit would seriously damage the car industry in Britain and the European Union by raising costs and sowing chaos for carmakers and consumers alike, the head of Britain's car industry warned on Tuesday.

Headline: Hunt urges France and Germany to push EU for Brexit deal
Description: Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt urged France and Germany on Tuesday to lobby European Union negotiators for a sensible outcome to Brexit talks, warning that Europe would also suffer "if Brexit goes wrong".

Headline: 'Low road' of protectionism will cost jobs and growth - Carney
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said a pursuit of the "low road" of protectionism would cost jobs and growth and there were tentative signs that a rise in trade barriers might be weighing on the world economy, Bloomberg said on Monday.

Headline: MPs criticise Lloyds' fraud redress scheme as 'unfair'
Description: A group of MPs on Monday wrote to the financial watchdog and the board of Lloyds Banking Group  accusing the bank of "victim blaming" and "unfairness" in its redress scheme for victims of a fraud at its HBOS Reading division.

Headline: Hunt to warn France, Austria of costs of no-deal Brexit
Description: British Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt will visit Paris and Vienna this week to discuss Brexit and warn of the costs to Britain and the European Union of failing to reach a transition deal, his office said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain to set out 'sensible precautions' for no deal Brexit - May's spokesman
Description: Britain will set out 'sensible precautions' in a series of notes looking at how to prepare for a possible exit from the European Union without a formal divorce deal, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Britons see Brexit turning sour, half want chance to vote again - poll
Description: Two-thirds of Britons now think the government will end up with a bad deal when Britain leaves the European Union early next year, and half want the chance to vote on what happens next, Sky News reported on Monday, citing its own poll.

Headline: Legal rulings not needed to remove life-support, London court says
Description: The doctors and families of patients in a permanent vegetative state will no longer need legal permission to end their treatment, London's Supreme Court ruled on Monday.

Headline: UK tells EU - give the City access to EU or your financial firms could suffer: Guardian
Description: Britain has warned the European Union negotiators that EU financial firms will face obstacles to working in the country after Brexit unless the City of London is allowed to operate in the bloc as it does currently, the Guardian reported on Monday.

Headline: China tempts Britain with free trade, says door to U.S. talks open
Description: China offered Britain talks on a post-Brexit free trade deal on Monday, reaching out to London as Beijing remains mired in an increasingly bitter trade war with Washington, even as a senior Chinese diplomat reiterated its door remained open for dialogue.

Headline: 'Terrible mistake' - Hunt misidentifies wife as Japanese rather than Chinese
Description: In a slip of the tongue during his maiden trip to China as Britain's new foreign secretary, Jeremy Hunt on Monday told his Chinese counterpart that his wife was Japanese, but backtracked quickly.

Headline: UK's new foreign minister in China for first overseas visit
Description: British Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt will meet his Chinese counterpart in Beijing on Monday to discuss cooperation between the two countries on his first major overseas trip since he replaced Boris Johnson earlier this month.

Headline: Italy's interior minister says EU trying to 'swindle' Britain - Sunday Times
Description: Italy's far-right interior minister, Matteo Salvini, has accused the European Union of trying to cheat Britain out of the Brexit it voted for, according to extracts from a newspaper interview published late on Saturday.

Headline: Austria seeks to avoid hard Brexit, Kurz tells May
Description: Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz said it was important to avoid a "hard" or disorderly Brexit, but negotiations about Britain's exit from the European Union were going quite well.

Headline: Brexit on agenda for September EU leaders' meeting in Salzburg - Britain
Description: European Union leaders will discuss Brexit when they next meet in the Austrian city of Salzburg on Sept. 20, British Prime Minister Theresa May's office said after discussions with Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz.

Headline: Ex-Trump strategist Bannon targets Britain in anti-EU campaign
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump's former political strategist Steve Bannon has been in contact with three potential rivals to British Prime Minister Theresa May and will make another trip to Europe in August, he told Reuters in an interview.

Headline: Fix Irish border or face hard Brexit, EU lawmakers warn May
Description: The British government has so far failed to offer a "workable" backstop plan to avoid Brexit border frictions in Ireland and must do so now if the European Parliament is to endorse a smooth transition out of the EU, lawmakers warned on Friday.

Headline: EU rejects Britain's key elements of special customs plan after Brexit
Description: EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier rejected key elements of Britain's new trade proposals on Thursday even as he and his new British counterpart Dominic Raab voiced a shared determination to reach a deal by October.

Headline: British voters increasingly unhappy with PM May and her government - poll
Description: British voters are increasingly dissatisfied with Prime Minister Theresa May and her government, according to an opinion poll on Friday, with less than a third of respondents happy with May's leadership.

Headline: Raab confident over Irish backstop, says must be time-limited
Description: Britain's Brexit minister said on Thursday he was confident that a workable "backstop" could be found to resolve the issue of the border with Ireland after Brexit, but said any such backstop needed to be limited in time.

Headline: UK temperatures set to test all-time record as heatwave continues
Description: Britons sweltered in a prolonged heatwave on Thursday, with temperatures hitting a year high and set to test national records on Friday, the Meteorological Office said.

Headline: A break from Brexit - May to holiday in Italy, Switzerland
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will holiday in Switzerland and Italy this summer, after narrowly surviving a bitter row within her government over Brexit as the country's departure from the European Union looms.

Headline: Britain to legalise medicinal use of cannabis
Description: Britain is to allow doctors to prescribe medicinal cannabis, following a relaxation of the law governing drugs derived from the banned plant.

Headline: Judge dismisses BBC bid to appeal Cliff Richard privacy ruling
Description: A High Court judge in Britain has dismissed an attempt by the BBC broadcaster to appeal a ruling that it had breached the privacy of veteran singer Cliff Richard by televising a police raid on his house.

Headline: Slump in London house-building weighs on UK housing starts
Description: British builders have cut back sharply on the number of new homes they plan to start in London, taking the shine off industry data which otherwise remained near its strongest since the global financial crisis.

Headline: EU medicines agency faces court fight over $660 million rent bill
Description: The European Medicines Agency, which is moving from London to Amsterdam because of Brexit, has been taken to court by its UK landlord, which wants it to keep paying a rent bill estimated at around 500 million pounds.

Headline: May says public should not be alarmed by medicines stockpiling
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said the public should be reassured rather than alarmed by government plans to stockpile medicines and blood products ahead of a possible no-deal Brexit.

Headline: Heat-related deaths in Britain set to treble by 2050, MPs warn
Description: Premature deaths from heatwaves in Britain could more than treble to around 7,000 a year by mid-century if the government does not take action, a committee of lawmakers said on Thursday.

Headline: Fire rages through London's West Hampstead flat, dozens evacuated
Description: A huge fire broke out in a five-storey residential building in London's West Hampstead in the early hours of Thursday, forcing rescuers to evacuate dozens of people, and it took nearly four hours to douse the blaze, the London Fire Brigade said.

Headline: UK Jewish newspapers say Labour leader Corbyn poses 'existential threat'
Description: Three British Jewish newspapers said on Wednesday that there would be an "existential threat to Jewish life in this country" if the opposition Labour Party, led by Jeremy Corbyn, won power from the ruling Conservative Party.

Headline: May says Brexit offers 'unique opportunity' for farmers
Description: Brexit offers a "unique opportunity" for Britain to transform its food, farming and environmental policies, Prime Minister Theresa May will tell farmers on Thursday, stepping up efforts to sell her vision for leaving the European Union.

Headline: U.S. general says future UK fighter jet must be compatible with F-35
Description: The top U.S. Air Force general in Europe on Wednesday said it was critical to ensure any future British fighter jet was compatible with the U.S. F-35 stealth fighter built by Lockheed Martin for a number of U.S. allies, including Britain.

Headline: Clark to warn in Italy of Brexit no-deal damage to both sides
Description: Business Secretary Greg Clark will warn of the economic damage to both the EU and Britain of either a bad or no Brexit deal when he meets Italian politicians and firms on Thursday in the latest leg of a charm offensive to win over European capitals.

Headline: UK heatwave will hit food supplies, could worsen Brexit disruption - food lobby
Description: Britain's prolonged heatwave will impact food supplies later this year and would exacerbate any disruption caused by a hard Brexit, an industry lobby group warned on Wednesday.

Headline: UK will resist any new barriers between Britain and Northern Ireland - Hammond
Description: Britain will resist any further divergence in regulations between Northern Ireland and the rest of the United Kingdom that might be proposed to smooth trade across the Irish border, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain must move in Brexit negotiations, Germany says
Description: German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said in a media interview published on Wednesday that the British government needs to get moving in Brexit negotiations, including on the Northern Ireland border issue.

Headline: Britain and EU formally start splitting WTO membership agreements
Description: Britain and the European Union formally filed for divorce at the World Trade Organization on Tuesday, following many months of diplomatic preparations to smooth the way for the historic move.

Headline: May hosts reception for divers who rescued Thai children
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May hosted a reception on Tuesday for the British divers who were involved in the rescue of 12 schoolboys from a flooded cave in Thailand earlier this month.

Headline: 'A real offer' - Raab suggests Brexit proposal to EU may be final
Description: Britain has put forward a "real offer" to a win a deal on leaving the European Union by October, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said on Tuesday, suggesting the government would not shift much from its agreed negotiating stance.

Headline: Britain to tighten foreign takeover rules amid China worries
Description: Britain is planning the biggest change to takeover rules in almost two decades, giving the government new powers to block deals in all sectors of the economy to prevent UK companies in sensitive industries from falling into foreign hands.

Headline: In first for UK, government clears Cuadrilla to frack shale gas site
Description: Shale gas developer Cuadrilla on Tuesday became the first operator in Britain to receive final consent from the government to frack an onshore horizontal exploration well, paving the way for commercial production.

Headline: May says she will lead Brexit talks from now on
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday she would now lead negotiations with the European Union, shifting the focus of the Brexit department towards preparing for Britain's departure from the bloc.

Headline: London taxi drivers mull class action suit against Uber
Description: London cab drivers are examining the possibility of bringing a class action suit against Uber, their association said on Tuesday, after the mobile app was granted a temporary licence renewal to operate in the British capital.

Headline: Brexit Secretary Raab says government will ensure food supplies if no EU exit deal
Description: The British government will ensure that there are adequate food supplies in case the country is unable to secure an exit deal with the European Union, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said on Tuesday.

Headline: Full Brexit deal with EU by March will be a challenge - Raab
Description: Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said on Tuesday that it will be "challenge" to reach a full agreement with the European Union on what their future trading relationship will look like by March next year.

Headline: Raab tells EU - it is time to speed up talks
Description: Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said on Tuesday it was now up to the European Union to respond after the government published a long-awaited white paper policy document if the bloc wanted to a reach a deal on Britain's departure by October.

Headline: UK's Brexit negotiating position a 'far advanced offer' - Raab
Description: Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said on Tuesday the government's negotiating stance set out this month by Prime Minister Theresa May was a "far advanced offer", suggesting it would not be changed fundamentally in talks.

Headline: Britain to keep EU laws during Brexit transition
Description: Britain set out on Tuesday how it plans to keep European Union laws during its transition from the bloc after next March, saying elements of the 1972 laws which make Britain a member of the bloc would need to be saved, including a role for the European Court of Justice (ECJ).

Headline: End 'botched' Brexit and protect jobs, Corbyn says
Description: Jeremy Corbyn criticised the government on Tuesday for failing business with its "botched" Brexit plan, saying only his Labour Party could make Britain's departure from the European Union work for manufacturers.

Headline: 'Brexodus' to cost UK up to 12,000 finance jobs - City chief
Description: Brexit will cost Britain up to 12,000 financial services jobs in the short-term, the City of London financial district's leader said on Tuesday, and many more jobs might disappear in the longer term.

Headline: Expansion vote closes the political debate around Heathrow, CEO says
Description: A vote by MPs to approve a third runway at Heathrow closes the political discussion on the issue after decades of uncertainty, the airport's chief executive said on Tuesday, even as it faces legal challenges.

Headline: UK public sector workers get biggest pay rise in years
Description: Around one million public-sector workers in Britain will receive their biggest pay rise in years, the government said on Tuesday, as it tries to regain momentum after a rocky few weeks of Brexit drama.

Headline: China says hopes Britain provides fair investment environment
Description: China hopes Britain can provide a fair investment environment for foreign firms and oppose any sort of protectionism, the foreign ministry said on Tuesday in response to proposed tougher British rules to protect national security.

Headline: UK child poverty rose last year as welfare cuts bite - thinktank
Description: The number of children living in poverty in Britain rose last year as the poorest families saw their incomes hit by welfare cuts, a think tank said, underscoring the challenge for the government as it tries to balance the public finances.

Headline: Britain would not block death penalty for IS suspects
Description: The British government would not object to Washington seeking the death penalty for two British Islamic State militants if they are extradited to the United States, a Home Office minister said on Monday.

Headline: How does May relax? Walking, cooking and U.S. police drama NCIS
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May gave some insight on Monday about how she deals with what one voter said was the most stressful job in the world: walking with her husband, cooking and watching U.S. police drama NCIS.

Headline: Scientists take step towards creating artificial embryos
Description: An international team of scientists has moved closer to creating artificial embryos after using mouse stem cells to make structures capable of taking a crucial step in the development of life.

Headline: Stalemate over WikiLeaks Assange's future 'coming to a head' - source
Description: The diplomatic impasse over Julian Assange's six-year stay in Ecuador's London embassy is coming to a head, a source close to the WikiLeaks founder said on Monday, after media reports the South American country would rescind his political asylum.

Headline: UK sets out full-fibre network plan to catch up with European rivals
Description: Britain could pay for the roll out of full-fibre broadband to its most remote regions with up to $6.6 billion (5.02 billion pounds) of public money to tackle its position at the bottom of the European league for "gold standard" connectivity.

Headline: UK wants two Islamic State fighters to face trial in most appropriate country - May's spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May wants two British Islamic State militants to be tried in the most appropriate jurisdiction, her spokeswoman said, after a newspaper reported that the government will send them for trial in the United States.

Headline: MoD suspends Capita contract after rival Serco challenges decision
Description: Britain's Ministry of Defence (MoD) said it had suspended a contract for outsourcing group Capita to provide firefighting services on military sites after rival Serco began a legal challenge to the decision.

Headline: British reject May's Brexit plan, some turn to Boris and far right - poll
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's plans to leave the European Union are overwhelmingly opposed by the British public and more than a third of voters would support a new right-wing political party committed to quitting the bloc, according to a new poll.

Headline: Turkish businessman to face UK extradition hearing - UK ministry
Description: Exiled Turkish businessman Akin Ipek will face an extradition hearing in Britain in September, the British interior ministry said on Saturday, following his arrest in relation to a Turkish request to extradite him.

Headline: Briton discharged from hospital after Novichok poisoning
Description: Charlie Rowley, one of two Britons poisoned with the nerve agent Novichok last month, was released from hospital on Friday.

Headline: Brexit-backer Arron Banks denies fresh allegation of Russia links
Description: British businessman Arron Banks has denied an allegation made by a former business partner that he approached Russians about investing in his diamond mines, and that the money raised went instead to his campaign to leave the European Union.

Headline: UK's Brexit plans useful, but questions remain - Barnier
Description: Britain's proposals on its future relationship with the European Union contain constructive elements, but many questions remain,  EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Friday.

Headline: Man arrested with knives near UK parliament jailed for life
Description: A British man who had made bombs for the Taliban in Afghanistan and was plotting an attack near London's parliament was jailed for life with a minimum term of 40 years at the Old Bailey court on Friday.

Headline: Under pressure at home, May demands new deal from EU on Irish border
