Description: Britain's Foreign Minister Boris Johnson on Tuesday called for all nations to support his country's proposal to give the world's chemical weapons watchdog the power to assign blame for attacks.

Headline: Taliban bomb-maker convicted of UK terrorism plot
Description: A British man who had made bombs for the Taliban in Afghanistan and was plotting an attack near London's parliament was convicted of terrorism offences on Tuesday.

Headline: MPs finally give go ahead to Heathrow runway
Description: British lawmakers voted strongly in favour of building a new runway at London's Heathrow Airport on Monday, paving the way for the airport's expansion after decades of delays and policy U-turns.

Headline: Mandelson calls for extension in EU divorce talks
Description: Britain should ask the European Union for more time for exit talks to avoid a "blind" Brexit that maximises uncertainty for the country's financial services, a British lawmaker and former top EU official said on Tuesday.

Headline: British pension rule discriminates against transgender, says EU court
Description: The European Union's top court ruled on Tuesday against a British law preventing a transgender woman from claiming a pension as a woman before her marriage was annulled. The law  was discriminatory, it said.

Headline: UK PM May distances herself from attacks on companies over Brexit warnings
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday companies should be listened to but stopped short of condemning her foreign minister who, according to accounts of remarks at a private event, used foul language to criticise business concerns over Brexit,

Headline: Responding to criticism, UK says has made 'considerable steps' on post-Brexit trade
Description: Britain has made considerable step to provide as smooth and frictionless Brexit as possible, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday responding to criticism from the automotive industry over her strategy.

Headline: Responding to criticism, UK says has made 'considerable steps' on post-Brexit trade
Description: Britain has made considerable step to provide as smooth and frictionless Brexit as possible, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday responding to criticism from the automotive industry over her strategy.

Headline: EU wants 'realistic and workable proposals' from Britain on future relationship - draft
Description: EU leaders will call on Britain to provide "realistic and workable proposals" on its future relationship with the EU and leave the door open for London to change its mind on some of its "red lines" in negotiations - draft summit conclusions showed.

Headline: Prince William meets Israeli PM Netanyahu
Description: Britain's Prince William met Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the Israeli leader's Jerusalem residence on Tuesday after visiting Israel's memorial to the six million Jews killed in the Nazi Holocaust.

Headline: Pride and worry, Britain's free health service turns 70
Description: Free, good quality healthcare for everyone, from cradle to grave. That was the mission of Britain’s National Health Service when it was founded on July 5, 1948.

Headline: UK defence spending must rise to keep strong U.S., NATO links - MPs
Description: Britain must raise defence spending to make sure it retains  influence over the United States and maintain its leading role in the NATO military alliance, a report by a committee of MPs said on Tuesday.

Headline: Prince William, at Israel's Holocaust memorial, voices horror over death camp display
Description: Britain's Prince William, visiting Israel's Holocaust memorial and museum on Tuesday, voiced his horror at the sight of shoes left behind by Jews killed in a Nazi extermination camp.

Headline: Taking lessons from Carillion, Britain toughens outsourcer rules
Description: Britain is preparing to toughen up contract terms for private companies operating in the public sector over the next 12 to 18 months after the collapse of outsourcing group Carillion, a source familiar with the plans said on Monday.

Headline: 'Vote No, Heathrow': protesters stage 'lie in' against UK vote
Description: Around a dozen demonstrators lay on the floor of the central lobby in Britain's House of Commons on Monday to protest against an upcoming vote which is expected to approve a new runway at Heathrow Airport.

Headline: BMW executive says would shut UK plants if Brexit hits supply chain
Description: BMW would have to close its Mini and Rolls-Royce plants in Britain if Brexit seriously disrupts its supply chain, an executive at the German carmaker told the Financial Times.

Headline: Prince William visits Jordan ruins where Kate was photographed
Description: Prince William visited ancient Roman ruins in Jordan where his wife Kate was photographed as a child on Monday, as part of a whirlwind tour in the run-up to the first British royal trip to Israel and the Palestinian territories.

Headline: Prince William lands in Israel, first official British royal visit to Holy Land
Description: Prince William arrived in Israel on Monday to begin the first official visit to the Holy Land by a member of the British royal family.

Headline: Government's anti-business bias hurts UK economy - London finance chief
Description: The British government's hostile attitude towards business is damaging the economy and companies will move overseas if they continue to be unfairly attacked for warning about the dangers from Brexit, the City of London's policy chief told Reuters.

Headline: PM May's spokesman - It’s up to companies if they want to air their views over Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman on Monday said it was up to individual firms to decide if they wanted to speak out about Brexit, but that the government was confident of securing an EU exit deal that businesses can get behind.

Headline: Listen to companies with respect on Brexit - British minister
Description: Any company and industry that brings jobs to Britain is entitled to be listened to, business minister Greg Clark said on Monday after aircraft manufacturer Airbus was criticised for warning the government over Brexit.

Headline: Heathrow expansion sends message about 'Global Britain' - PM May's spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May believes that expanding London's Heathrow airport sends a message about Britain's global ambitions, her spokesman said on Monday before a vote in parliament on an expansion plan.

Headline: UK ministers take aim at business over Brexit warnings
Description: The British government and business leaders clashed in a deepening row over Brexit on Sunday after a senior minister accused companies of issuing "completely inappropriate" threats and undermining the prime minister.

Headline: Firefighters quell big blaze near London's Euston train station
Description: A large fire in a pub near London's Euston train station was brought under control on Friday evening and there were no reports of casualties, the British capital's fire brigade said.

Headline: High Court rules against gender-neutral passports
Description: A campaigner has lost a legal bid to force the British government to introduce gender-neutral passports.

Headline: UK homes could face higher power costs as government looks to lower business burden
Description: Britain is considering giving more companies exemption from schemes to help pay for renewable power, but warned the move could lead to higher costs for households and non-exempt firms.

Headline: Former WPP boss Sorrell denies prostitute allegation
Description: Former WPP boss Martin Sorrell denied on Friday that he had visited a prostitute and paid using company money when pressed on a stage in front of hundreds of people about why he had left the advertising giant he founded.

Headline: Prince Charles visits UK site of nerve agent attack
Description: Prince Charles and his wife Camilla visited Salisbury on Friday to support the city as it tries to recover from the impact of this year's poison attack on a former Russian double agent and his daughter.

Headline: German says Brexit timetable can be met
Description: Germany believes the timetable for Britain's withdrawal from the European Union can be kept to, a government spokeswoman said on Friday, adding that while some issues still needed to be resolved, there were still open questions.

Headline: Junior UK trade minister resigns over plans to expand Heathrow airport
Description: A British trade minister resigned from the government on Thursday to oppose its plans to build a third runway at London's Heathrow Airport.

Headline: May dismisses report she questioned UK status as 'tier one' military power
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday a report that she asked her defence minister to justify the United Kingdom's status as a "tier one" military power was incorrect.

Headline: Britain's Fox dismisses talk of staying in single market for goods
Description: British Trade Secretary Liam Fox told Reuters on Thursday that he had heard the theory that Britain could remain in the European single market for goods but he dismissed the idea.

Headline: May faces down pro-EU rebel lawmakers to win Brexit vote
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May won a crucial Brexit vote in parliament on Wednesday, keeping her divided government's plans to end more than 40 years of British partnership with the European Union on track.

Headline: Britain's Fox says now zero chance of stopping Brexit
Description: A vote in Britain's parliament on Wednesday closed the door for good on any chance of the country staying in the European Union, Trade Minister Liam Fox told a debate in Geneva on Thursday.

Headline: Brexit will tarnish Scotland's appeal to low skilled-workers, research finds
Description: Scotland will struggle to attract the low-skilled workers it needs once Britain leaves the European Union, according to research by the universities of Edinburgh and Glasgow.

Headline: Millions of British children exposed to harmful pollution- UNICEF
Description: A third of all children living in Britain, around 4.5 million, live in areas with harmful air pollution, a report by the U.N. children's agency UNICEF said on Thursday.

Headline: Backed by EU, frustrated Irish warn UK time running out on Brexit
Description: Ireland's prime minister warned Britain on Thursday that there is not much time left to conclude a smooth withdrawal from the European Union, as the head of the EU's executive arm pledged its full support for Dublin's stance.

Headline: May committed to Britain to being a leading military power - spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is committed to Britain remaining a leading military power, her spokeswoman said on Thursday, rejecting a report that she had questioned why Britain should remain a "tier one" military nation.

Headline: EU's Juncker says backing of Irish Brexit position will not change
Description: The support of European Union members for Ireland's Brexit position will not change, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said on Thursday, advising against any temptation to isolate Ireland in a withdrawal deal.

Headline: Leading pro-EU rebel lawmaker backs down, will support government on Brexit laws
Description: The pro-European Union MP leading a group of rebels threatening to vote against Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit law said on Wednesday that he had accepted assurances from minister and would now support the government.

Headline: British police investigate World Cup fans in Nazi salute video
Description: British police said on Wednesday they were investigating images of England football fans making Nazi salutes in what appeared to be a bar in the Russian city of Volgograd, where England played Tunisia on Monday.

Headline: Unjustified medication shortened 456 lives in a UK hospital, report says
Description: More than 450 patients died prematurely in a British hospital after they were given powerful painkillers with no medical justification, in what a damning report on Wednesday found was a "disregard for human life".

Headline: PM May defeats pro-EU rebels, wins lawmakers' approval for Brexit plan
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Wednesday won approval for her plan on how much say MPs should get over Brexit, defeating a attempt by pro-European Union rebels to give parliament more influence.

Headline: Factbox - What does a 'meaningful vote' on Brexit really mean?
Description: A row over how much say Britain's parliament should have over the Brexit process is set to reach its conclusion on Wednesday as MPs finalise the wording of the laws that will end the country's membership of the European Union next year.

Headline: Government moves to calm fears over Brexit bill
Description: Government moved to calm fears in parliament over its proposal for a "meaningful vote" on any Brexit deal on Wednesday, saying MPs may be able to change ministers' plans in the event of a no deal with the European Union.

Headline: Labour could order biggest Bank of England shake-up in decades
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party could ask the Bank of England to target productivity to help boost the economy if it wins power, in the most radical change to the central bank's remit in more than two decades.

Headline: Upper chamber to debate Brexit laws later on Wednesday
Description: Britain's upper house of parliament will consider any changes made to proposed Brexit laws on Wednesday evening, shortly after they have been voted upon by the lower house of parliament, the opposition Labour Party said.

Headline: UK police see no indication of terrorism in London blast
Description: British police said on Tuesday a "small number of people" were receiving medical treatment after what they described as a minor explosion likely caused by a battery malfunction at an underground station in north London.

Headline: UK police investigating cause of 'minor explosion' at underground station in London
Description: British police said on Tuesday they were investigating the cause of a "minor explosion" at Southgate underground station in north London and were advising people to avoid the area.

Headline: British police say don't suspect terrorism after London blast
Description: British police said on Tuesday that a blast at an underground station in north London was unlikely to be terror-related but investigations were ongoing.

Headline: Setting up new showdown, May rejects Brexit proposal
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May cannot accept a proposal to hand parliament more control over Brexit, her spokesman said on Tuesday, setting up a showdown with MPs who want the right to step in if Britain risks crashing out of the EU with no deal.

Headline: EU's Barnier says progress in Brexit talks, but divergences remain on Ireland
Description: Talks between Britain and the European Commission on the country's EU exit have made progress in some issues but they still disagree on how to tackle the Irish border, the bloc's chief Brexit negotiator said on Tuesday.

Headline: EU leaders worried over Irish border issue in Brexit talks - draft
Description: European Union leaders will express concern on Friday over a lack of progress in talks with London on how to avoid reimposing controls at the border between British-ruled Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic after Brexit.

Headline: PM May hopes MPs will back Brexit plan - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May hopes MPs will back her proposal to offer them a say over a Brexit deal, her spokesman said on Tuesday, before a showdown in parliament over her plans to leave the European Union.

Headline: Denying it has lost war on drugs, UK rules out legalising cannabis
Description: Britain said on Tuesday it had no intention of legalising cannabis after a former leader of Prime Minister Theresa May's party said the government had "irreversibly lost" the battle to drive the drug off the streets.

Headline: UK government will not accept Lords proposal of 'meaningful vote' - source
Description: Britain's government will not accept a proposal from the upper house of parliament which hands lawmakers greater power over a Brexit deal, a government source said on Tuesday, setting up a showdown over plans for a "meaningful vote".

Headline: Britain stops short of criticising U.S. immigration policy
Description: Britain responded to an outcry over the U.S. separation of immigrant parents and children by saying on Tuesday it was happy with its own rules not to separate families and that child welfare was a top priority.

Headline: London construction firms rely heavily on EU workers, figures show
Description: More than a quarter of London's construction workers come from elsewhere in the European Union, according to new figures on Tuesday that highlight the British capital's reliance on EU immigrants ahead of Brexit next year.

Headline: Britain could access but not develop European GPS, Barnier says
Description: Britain could access the European Union's Galileo satellite navigation system after Brexit but will no longer be able to work on developing the project, the bloc's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Tuesday.

Headline: Londoners mark anniversary of mosque attack with minute's silence
Description: Senior British political figures joined faith and community leaders on Tuesday to commemorate the anniversary of an attack by a far-right extremist who drove a van into Muslim worshippers leaving a London mosque.

Headline: I don't want to collapse May's government, pro-EU MP Grieve says
Description: A leading pro-European Union lawmaker in Britain's ruling Conservative Party said he did not want the government to collapse in the row over parliament's role in the Brexit process.

Headline: Sense of relief overwhelms England fans after World Cup win
Description: England fans who watched their team beat Tunisia 2-1 on Monday said they had been on tenterhooks until the stoppage-time winning goal, fearing that their long trip to southern Russia might end in disappointment.

Headline: 'Be careful' - SNP warns UK government of tipping Scotland towards independence
Description: The British government is fuelling support for Scottish independence by overriding the devolved Edinburgh assembly's wishes over Brexit, the leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP) in Britain's parliament warned on Monday.

Headline: Britain to ban combustible cladding on high-rise buildings after Grenfell fire
Description: Britain plans to ban the use of combustible materials on the outside of high-rise buildings in response to the Grenfell Tower fire that killed 71 people, the housing minister said on Monday.

Headline: May's Brexit laws rejected by parliament, Wednesday showdown looms
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plans were rejected by parliament's upper chamber on Monday, setting up a confrontation with pro-EU MPs later this week which will test her ability to lead a minority government.

Headline: Brexit will give Britain more to spend on health even as payments to EU continue - May
Description: Britain will have more money to spend on its health service when it leaves the European Union, even as it continues to make payments to the bloc, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday.

Headline: Russia charges two England fans taken off World Cup train
Description: Russian authorities charged two British soccer fans with public drunkenness and hooliganism on Monday after they were taken off a train heading for Volgograd where England were due to play in a World Cup match, the interior ministry said.

Headline: British PM's Brexit plans set for Lords defeat, teeing up showdown
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plans face rejection by parliament's upper chamber on Monday, setting the stage for a confrontation with pro-EU rebel lawmakers later in the week which could rock her minority government.

Headline: UK signals changes on medicinal cannabis use after epileptic boy's case
Description: The British government will look into possible changes to rules on the use of cannabis-based medicines, a minister said on Monday, after an epileptic boy whose medication was confiscated was hospitalised.

Headline: Two British men en route to Volgograd charged with hooliganism - police
Description: Russian authorities charged two British nationals on Monday with minor hooliganism and being drunk in public, police said.

Headline: Meghan's father says UK's Prince Harry told him to 'give Donald Trump a chance'
Description: Thomas Markle, the father of Britain's new royal, said his son-in-law Prince Harry had told him to give U.S. President Donald Trump a chance and Queen Elizabeth's grandson had also said he had an open mind about Britain's exit from the European Union.

Headline: British citizen detained in Russia after incident on World Cup train - embassy
Description: The British Embassy in Moscow said on Monday that a British citizen had been detained in Russia after an incident on a train travelling to the Russian city of Volgograd for the World Cup, Interfax news agency reported.

Headline: PM May's healthcare funding rise wins broad cabinet support - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's pledge to increase healthcare funding by 20 billion pounds won broad approval from her cabinet of top ministers on Monday, her spokesman said.

Headline: Johnson says 'Brexit dividend' part of health funding
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Monday that government plans for a boost to spending on the state-run National Health Service (NHS) would come in part from savings generated by leaving the European Union.

Headline: London, other cities call for new petrol and diesel car ban to start earlier
Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan and other city leaders from across Britain said on Monday a government plan to ban the sale of new diesel and petrol cars should be brought forward by 10 years to 2030, in the latest push to improve air quality.

Headline: Pro-EU lawmaker in Conservative party - 'We could collapse government'
Description: A leading pro-European Union lawmaker in Britain's ruling Conservative Party warned on Sunday that a row over parliament's influence on the Brexit process could collapse the government, but said he hoped to find a way to avoid that.

Headline: May says need to ensure parliament does not overturn Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday it was important to ensure that parliament could not block Brexit, defending her approach to passing the legislation that will end Britain's membership of the European Union.

Headline: May pledges 20 billion extra pounds for healthcare post-Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May pledged on Sunday to increase funding for the National Health Service by 20 billion pounds after Brexit, funded by money no longer spent on membership of the European Union and possible tax rises.

Headline: UK authorities release confiscated cannabis after boy hospitalised
Description: Britain's interior minister used an exceptional power on Saturday to release medicinal cannabis oil that had been confiscated from an epileptic boy who was later hospitalised suffering from seizures.

Headline: May 'disappointed' after colleague blocks 'upskirting' law
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday she was disappointed an MP from her Conservative party had blocked a bill to make "upskirting" - surreptitiously taking photographs up women's skirts - a criminal offence.

Headline: Stephen Hawking's voice beamed into space at final send-off
Description: The voice of Stephen Hawking was beamed into space with a message of peace and hope on Friday as the British physicist, who gained international acclaim for his work on black holes, was laid to rest during a service at London's Westminster Abbey.

Headline: UK seeks 'closest possible' security pact with EU after Brexit - minister
Description: Britain wants to cement its foreign policy and security ties with the European Union via the "closest possible cooperation agreement" for when it leaves the bloc, a British minister said.

Headline: Cambridge University sticks to indirect fossil fuel investments
Description: Cambridge University said it would keep investing in funds that hold shares in fossil fuel companies, despite public pressure from hundreds of its academics.

Headline: UK to use 'Brexit dividend' to boost health spending by £4 billion - Daily Telegraph
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will increase spending on Britain's state-run National Health Service (NHS) by 4 billion pounds a year, funded by borrowing, income tax and a "Brexit dividend", the Daily Telegraph newspaper reported.

Headline: Brexit law compromise respects plans to leave EU - PM May's spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government's new amendment to her Brexit blueprint on giving parliament a greater role on the exit process respects the public's desire to leave the European Union, her spokeswoman said on Friday.

Headline: Vigils, prayers mark one year since London's Grenfell fire
Description: Survivors of London's Grenfell Tower fire, and friends and relatives of the 71 people it killed, held vigils and prayed together as they marked the first anniversary of a disaster that still haunts Britain.

Headline: UK government proposes three scenarios for parliament vote on Brexit deal
Description: Britain's Brexit department set out its proposed compromise with pro-European Union MPs on Thursday, outlining three scenarios under which a vote in parliament on its European union exit deal would be triggered.

Headline: Pro-EU UK lawmaker wants to find way out of row over Brexit meaningful vote
Description: A pro-EU lawmaker said on Thursday he would now try to find a way around a standoff with British Prime Minister Theresa May over the role of parliament in her Brexit strategy after they failed to agree on a compromise.

Headline: Government has changed position on Brexit law compromise - MP
Description: Pro-EU MP Anna Soubry said on Thursday the government had changed its position after agreeing a compromise deal on handing parliament a "meaningful vote" on any Brexit deal, and that the new proposal had not been agreed by the leading rebel.

Headline: May's Brexit compromise hits snag, wrangling to continue
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May failed on Thursday to win around pro-EU lawmakers in her party over parliament's role in the Brexit process, raising the risk of defeat in lower house votes next week.

Headline: Queen and Meghan cheered on first joint royal trip
Description: Thousands of cheering fans greeted Queen Elizabeth and Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, on Thursday as Britain's newest royal joined the monarch for a visit to the English county of Cheshire, her first official trip without Prince Harry.

Headline: Amendment on Brexit bill to be issued just before 1600 GMT - May's spokeswoman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's government will issue a compromise amendment to her Brexit blueprint just before 1600 GMT, her spokeswoman said on Thursday.

Headline: UK parliament will have meaningful vote on Brexit, says pro-EU lawmaker
Description: Pro-EU British Conservative lawmaker Anna Soubry, one of a group of rebels pressing Prime Minister Theresa May for concessions over Brexit, said on Thursday parliament would have a meaningful vote on an exit deal, and there would be no "hard Brexit".

Headline: PM May agrees compromise deal with pro-EU MPs on Brexit legislation - source
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has reached a deal with pro-EU MPs over the wording of a compromise on the government's Brexit legislation, a source familiar with the negotiations said on Thursday.

Headline: UK will press ahead with Brexit laws despite lack of consent from Scotland - Secretary of State for Scotland
Description: The government will press ahead with passing legislation to end Britain's membership of the European Union despite the devolved Scottish parliament not having granted its consent, Secretary of State for Scotland David Mundell said on Thursday.

Headline: British MPs threaten publication of report on fraud at Lloyds unit
Description: A group of British MPs said they will publish a report into what Lloyds Banking Group knew about a fraud at its HBOS Reading unit, following years of campaigns for full disclosure by its victims.

Headline: PM May will announce relaxed rules for non-EU doctors and nurses - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will announce the relaxation of immigration rules to allow more doctors and nurses from outside the European Union to work for the National Health Service (NHS), May's spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: UK not seeking regulatory alignment to solve Irish border conundrum - minister
Description: Britain is not seeking full regulatory alignment with the European Union as a solution to the post-Brexit Northern Irish border, Brexit department minister Robin Walker said on Thursday.

Headline: Weakened, May defeats final Brexit challenges in parliament
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May defeated the final challenges to her Brexit blueprint in parliament on Wednesday, leaving plans for Britain's departure from the European Union still largely on track but her authority weakened.

Headline: Brexit campaigner orders EU's Verhofstadt to retract claim of Russian collusion
Description: Lawyers for Brexit campaigner Arron Banks ordered the European Parliament’s chief Brexit coordinator on Wednesday to retract a claim that Banks colluded with Russia to deliver Britain's vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: May wins vote, parliament rejects staying in European Economic Area
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May won a vote in parliament on Wednesday that threw out a proposal which would have forced the government to negotiate staying in the European Economic Area, meaning it would participate in the European Union's single market.

Headline: May wins vote on customs in boost for her Brexit vision
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May won a vote in parliament on Wednesday that threw out a proposal which would have forced the government to report on the efforts it had made to negotiate membership of the European Union's customs union.

Headline: After winning Brexit compromise, UK's pro-EU rebels fear betrayal
Description: Pro-EU lawmakers threatened on Wednesday to withdraw their support for Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy if she does not follow through on concessions they thought they had been promised.

Headline: Haiti withdraws Oxfam GB's right to operate after misconduct scandal
Description: Haiti's government on Wednesday said it was withdrawing Oxfam Great Britain's right to operate in the Caribbean country after allegations of sexual misconduct by some of the charity's staff.

Headline: Supreme Court rules plumber in gig economy entitled to worker rights
Description: Britain's Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that a plumber hired on a self-employed basis was entitled to workers' rights, in a case that could increase pressure on firms in the gig economy to change their business models.

Headline: Irish PM says EU needs decisions from UK, not internal debate
Description: The British government needs to move on from internal debates and make choices about what it wants from Brexit, and must acknowledge that it cannot have its cake and eat it, Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Wednesday.

Headline: Scottish lawmakers walk out of UK parliament in Brexit row
Description: Lawmakers from the Scottish National Party (SNP) walked out of the British parliament on Wednesday to protest what they say is Scotland's voice being ignored over Brexit.

Headline: Scottish lawmakers walk out of UK parliament in Brexit row
Description: Lawmakers from the Scottish National Party (SNP) walked out of the British parliament on Wednesday to protest what they say is Scotland's voice being ignored over Brexit.

Headline: 'Contempt' for devolution means new UK framework needed -Scottish minister
Description: Scotland's devolved government will start to seek changes in how power is shared with Britain's four nations, as Brexit has made it clear that devolution does not work, Scotland's Brexit minister Michael Russell said on Wednesday.

Headline: May will draw up new amendment to address lawmakers' Brexit concerns
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told lawmakers on Wednesday the government was discussing concerns over parliament's role in Brexit and would come up with a new amendment to satisfy them.

Headline: May says she hopes for party support on Brexit laws - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is hoping for the support of her whole Conservative Party on the legislation that will end Britain's membership of the European Union, her spokesman said on Wednesday.

Headline: Factbox: Britain's Brexit laws - What's changed and what happens next?
Description: Parliament is finalising laws that will formally end Britain's membership of the European Union, a process which has forced the government to make some important concessions that will change the dynamic of Brexit negotiations.

Headline: MPs call for tougher pay gap rules
Description: Britain's new gender pay gap rules should be tightened to ensure that highly-paid partners at consultancies, accountants and law firms cannot circumvent the spirit of the legislation, a parliamentary committee told the government on Wednesday.

Headline: May defuses revolt in parliament over Brexit plans
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May defused a rebellion in parliament over her Brexit plans on Tuesday but only after having to compromise and hand lawmakers more control over Britain's departure from the European Union.

Headline: Brexit campaigner Wigmore says never accepted Russian money
Description: Brexit campaigner Andy Wigmore told a parliamentary committee on Tuesday that he had never accepted money from the Russian government.

Headline: Brexit campaigner Banks - Russia meetings were not an issue in the past
Description: Arron Banks, the man behind one of the main Brexit campaigns, said on Tuesday scrutiny of his meetings with the Russian ambassador over a potential business deal had turned into a "witch hunt" now Britain's relations with Moscow had soured.

Headline: Parliament votes to reinsert EU exit day in law
Description: Lower house of parliament on Tuesday voted to reinsert the fixed time and date of the country's departure from the European Union, reversing an earlier defeat by the House of Lords.

Headline: Alleged UK neo-Nazi admits buying 19-inch machete to kill MP
Description: A man accused of being a member of a white supremacist group campaigning to start a race war in Britain pleaded guilty on Tuesday to plotting to kill an elected Member of Parliament (MP).

Headline: Brexit secretary confident government can secure deal parliament will support
Description: British Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday he is confident the government will secure a deal with European Union that MPs will support, speaking during a debate on laws that could give parliament more powers over the divorce process.

Headline: Brexit campaigner Banks - I have no business interests in Russia
Description: Brexit campaigner Arron Banks, who bankrolled the Leave.EU campaign in Britain's 2016 EU referendum campaign, told a parliamentary committee on Tuesday he had no business interests in Russia.

Headline: Brexit campaigner Banks says Russian meetings 'no issue' in the past
Description: Arron Banks, a British businessman who campaigned for Brexit, told a parliamentary committee on Tuesday that his contacts with Russians had not been an issue before Britain's relations with the Kremlin soured.

Headline: Vote on government Brexit plans may complicate EU talks - PM May
Description: A vote in parliament on Tuesday on the government's plans for Brexit will send a message to the European Union and will make negotiations more difficult if lawmakers undermine the official position, Prime Minister Theresa May told her ministers.

Headline: David Davis says parliament vote cannot reverse Brexit
Description: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday there would be no reversal of the decision to leave the European Union whatever the outcome of divorce talks with the bloc.

Headline: May urges Conservative unity before parliament votes on Brexit strategy
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May urged her Conservative Party on Monday to show unity and vote against changes to her Brexit blueprint, warning lawmakers they would undermine her negotiation with the European Union.

Headline: Factbox: Brexit plan faces parliamentary test - what to expect
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces crunch votes in parliament this week and a potential showdown with pro-European rebels in her ruling party that could create yet another twist in the tortured effort to reach a Brexit deal.

Headline: UK minister resigns, plans to rebel over parliament's Brexit role
Description: A junior British justice minister said on Tuesday he will resign and will vote with pro-European Union rebels who want parliament to have the power to force the government to go back to the negotiating table if they reject a Brexit deal.

Headline: UK minister resigns over Brexit policies
Description: Phillip Lee, a minister at Britain's justice ministry, said on Tuesday he was resigning over the government's Brexit policies.

Headline: British government looking for ways around customs amendment - minister
Description: The British government is in talks with lawmakers to find a way around an amendment proposed by parliament's upper house which challenges Prime Minister Theresa May's refusal to pursue a customs union with the EU, a Brexit minister said on Monday.

Headline: PM May - my response to deadly Grenfell fire was not good enough
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday that her initial response to the Grenfell Tower fire, which killed 71 people in London a year ago, was not good enough because it had given the wrong impression that she didn't care.

Headline: After 'difficult' G7 summit, May warns against unilateral action on trade
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday that a meeting of the Group of Seven leaders in Canada had been "difficult" and that countries had to avoid taking unilateral action in order to protect the global trading system.

Headline: Prince William to meet Netanyahu, Abbas on landmark Middle East trip
Description: Britain's Prince William will meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas when he makes a landmark trip to the region later this month, his office said on Monday.

Headline: May says Russia must change before it returns to G8
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said Russia would not be invited back to join the Group of Seven nations until it stops interfering in the affairs of other countries, rebuffing calls from U.S. President Donald Trump for Moscow to return to group.

Headline: Mayor Khan says booming tech sector to help London through Brexit
Description: London's status as Europe's leading hub for the tech sector will help it weather Brexit despite the best efforts of Paris, Berlin and others to compete, the British capital's mayor Sadiq Khan said on Monday.

Headline: Mother's stand-off with British authorities over medicinal cannabis stirs debate
Description: The mother of an epileptic boy who journeyed to Canada to buy cannabis-based medication she says is keeping her son alive had her supplies confiscated by British customs officials upon her return on Monday.

Headline: Brexit and the Irish backstop riddle
Description: Efforts to avoid a "hard border" in Ireland can seem baffling but as British Prime Minister Theresa May battles parliament over Brexit, the issue is central to understanding how her demands to the European Union may change.

Headline: Pope Francis will not visit Northern Ireland on Irish trip
Description: Pope Francis will not visit British-ruled Northern Ireland this summer when he makes the first papal visit to Ireland in almost 40 years, the Vatican said on Monday.

Headline: PM May urges MPs to back EU withdrawal bill - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May urges MPs to back legislation to end Britain's membership of the European Union before crunch parliamentary votes this week, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Brexit campaigner Banks says story on Russian ties 'absolute garbage'
Description: Arron Banks, a British businessman who bankrolled one of the main campaigns for Brexit, hit back on Sunday after a report said his links with Russia went further and deeper than he had previously disclosed, saying he was a victim of a "witch hunt".

Headline: We are not Russian secret agents, Brexit campaigner Banks says
Description: Brexit campaigner Arron Banks denied on Sunday ever receiving Russian money or assistance for the campaign to leave the European Union.

Headline: May says hopes UK lawmakers will not block EU exit laws
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Saturday she hoped lawmakers would recognise the importance of passing legislation next week which will end Britain's membership of the European Union.

Headline: Pakistan army denies involvement in abduction of writer Bukhari
Description: Pakistan's army on Saturday denied any involvement in the abduction of a writer and rights activist who was kidnapped for several hours this week.

Headline: May orders ministerial 'away-day' to sort out squabbling ministers
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will gather together squabbling British ministers at her country residence after this month's European Union summit to hammer out the final details of a much-anticipated Brexit policy paper.

Headline: Focus on winning over Scots to independence from UK, Sturgeon tells SNP
Description: Scottish National Party supporters should focus on how to increase support for the independence cause, rather than on the timing of when Scotland might split from the United Kingdom, SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon said on Saturday.

Headline: Queen's honours sidetracked by row over rail boss award
Description: A row over the running of Britain's railways spilled over into Queen Elizabeth's annual birthday honours on Saturday as Network Rail's outgoing boss was decorated in a list which included actress Emma Thompson and novelist Kazuo Ishiguro.

Headline: 'More questions than answers' in UK Brexit offer - Barnier
Description: EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Friday a British proposal for avoiding border problems with Ireland after Brexit "raises more questions than answers" but was still welcome progress toward solutions.

Headline: UK steps into G7 trade dispute, warns of tit-for-tat dangers
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday warned both U.S. President Donald Trump and the European Union of the dangers of  entering a tit-for-tat trade war over tariffs, urging both sides to instead focus on China's excess steel production.

Headline: Decrying 'witch hunt' against Brexit-backers, Banks shuns MPs
Description: Arron Banks, the founder of Brexit campaign group Leave.EU, pulled out of a hearing with a parliamentary committee, saying on Friday it had been conducting a witch hunt of those who want Britain to leave the European Union.

Headline: 'Respect your own red lines' Barnier tells 'paradoxical' UK ministers
Description: Britain does not respect its own red lines in talks with the European Union about the country's withdrawal from the bloc, the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier said on Friday, responding to comments by British foreign secretary Boris Johnson.

Headline: Rebels muster as PM May battles for her Brexit vision
Description: A parliamentary vote on the shape of Britain's relationship with Europe next week is likely to force rebels in Theresa May's government into the open, threatening instability and adding yet another twist to the tortured effort to reach a Brexit deal.

Headline: PM May rebuts foreign minister's Brexit criticism
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May reacted defiantly to critical comments by her foreign minister Boris Johnson on Friday, stressing that he was not the only one with strong views on Brexit.

Headline: Brace for a possible 'Brexit meltdown' but don't panic, Johnson says -BuzzFeed
Description: Foreign secretary Boris Johnson warned there could be a Brexit meltdown but it will be "all right in the end" and said that U.S. President Trump would take a tougher stance were he leading the talks, according to BuzzFeed.

Headline: Northern Irish almost evenly split on whether to remain in the UK - survey
Description: Nearly as many Northern Irish people would back joining the republic of Ireland as support remaining in the United Kingdom, with Brexit pushing some to switch in favour of unification, according to a poll conducted for the BBC.

Headline: Sturgeon starts new route to Scottish independence after setbacks
Description: Scottish leader Nicola Sturgeon says she will set out on a new route towards independence this weekend, a strategy carrying personal political risks as well as aggravating tensions with the British government over Brexit.

Headline: UK, U.S. are good friends despite trade row - PM May
Description: Britain and the United States remain good friends who can talk frankly with each other when they disagree, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday ahead of a Group of Seven  summit.

Headline: Chinese nuclear plant developer will not seek UK state investment
Description: A planned nuclear plant to the east of London will not require state investment, the Chinese company building it said after the British government was criticised for helping another project.

Headline: Queen, 92, had eye surgery last month
Description: Queen Elizabeth, 92, the world's oldest monarch, underwent successful surgery to treat an eye cataract last month, Buckingham Palace said on Friday.

Headline: May will never accept customs border between Northern Ireland and UK - spokesman
Description: Britain will never accept a customs border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the United Kingdom and that position will not change, a government spokesman said on Friday, referring to a plan for the Irish border.

Headline: Soros-backed anti-Brexit group targets lawmakers in push for new referendum
Description: An anti-Brexit group backed by billionaire financier George Soros launched a campaign on Friday targeting lawmakers, in an attempt to strengthen its call for a second referendum that could stop Britain's exit from the European Union.

Headline: Scottish judges reject challenge over Britain's ability to reverse Brexit
Description: Scotland's top court has rejected a bid by pro-EU campaigners to ask the European Court of Justice (ECJ) to rule on whether Britain alone can reverse its decision to leave the European Union.

Headline: Hammond says Trump tactics would not deliver better Brexit
Description: Britain's finance secretary said he favoured a collaborative rather than a confrontational approach to Brexit negotiations, rejecting a suggestion from his cabinet colleague Boris Johnson that Donald Trump-style tactics would produce a better deal.

Headline: PM May to address Conservative lawmakers on Monday - The Times
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will address lawmakers from her ruling Conservative Party on Monday, the deputy political editor of The Times newspaper tweeted.

Headline: May has confidence in Johnson after Brexit meltdown comment - spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has confidence in her foreign secretary Boris Johnson after he was recorded warning that there could be a meltdown over Brexit, her spokeswoman said on Friday.

Headline: Back the bill, urges May as Brexit law faces crunch test
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged lawmakers to back the legislation that will end Britain's membership in the European Union, ahead of a series of crunch parliamentary votes that could see a rebellion by those who want closer EU ties.

Headline: British Brexit backstop plan welcome, with caveats - Irish foreign minister
Description: Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney on Friday welcomed a British plan for ensuring there are no customs checks along the Irish border when Britain leaves the European Union, but said it only told half the story.

Headline: BoE to raise rates in August so long as economy over its slump - Reuters poll
Description: The Bank of England will raise interest rates in August, a Reuters poll found, but that call is hanging in the balance as policymakers await confirmation Britain's economy is past a slump that set in earlier this year.

Headline: MPs have 'lost confidence' in TSB boss over IT crisis
Description: The chairman of TSB said on Thursday the bank's chief executive, Paul Pester, had the full support of the board, after Pester came under attack from MPs over his handling of an IT crisis, casting doubt on his position.

Headline: Britain proposes one-year Brexit backstop plan to EU
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May unveiled a one-year backstop plan for the Irish border after Brexit on Thursday, finding a compromise that may paper over differences in her government but may also struggle to win over the European Union.

Headline: UK government drops plan for 'meaningful vote' on Brexit deal - Labour
Description: Britain's government has removed a legislative proposal for a "meaningful vote" in parliament on whatever deal it negotiates to leave the European Union, opposition lawmakers said on Thursday.

Headline: May wants 'end state' customs plan up and running by end 2021
Description: Britain expects to have a permanent solution on post-Brexit customs arrangements in place by the end of 2021 at the latest, and it does not want to use the backstop arrangement it has proposed to Brussels in case of delays, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: TSB chairman says embattled CEO has 'full support' of board
Description: TSB Chairman Richard Meddings said on Thursday that the bank's Chief Executive Paul Pester had the full support of the TSB board, after MPs called on them to urgently consider the CEO's position following a severe IT crisis at the bank.

Headline: Irish PM says time-limited Brexit backstop would not be acceptable
Description: Ireland cannot agree to a time-limited version of a post-Brexit backstop arrangement that guarantees the retention of an open border between it and Northern Ireland, Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Thursday.

Headline: No UK ministers will be resigning over Brexit backstop - BBC
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will not face any ministerial resignations over disagreements over a failsafe policy to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland, the BBC's political editor said on Thursday.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP says British backstop plan a step forward
Description: The Northern Irish DUP party that supports Britain's minority government welcomed Prime Minister Theresa May's backstop plan for the Irish border on Thursday as a positive step forward.

Headline: Barnier welcomes UK Irish backstop, sets conditions
Description: EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier welcomed a new British proposal on Thursday for a backstop plan to avoid a hard border in Ireland - but he stuck by key conditions that have led to a stalemate in talks so far.

Headline: British lawmakers to discuss Brexit bill changes for two days next week
Description: British lawmakers will take two days next week to discuss amendments proposed by the upper house of parliament to the government bill ending UK membership of the European Union.

Headline: Britain looking forward to talks with EU on Brexit backstop proposal
Description: Britain is looking forward to negotiating the details of a backstop plan for the Irish border with the European Union now the government has presented its proposal, a spokeswoman for British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: Factbox - Britain sets out plan for temporary Brexit backstop arrangements
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Thursday set out new plans for a fallback policy to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland if Brexit talks with the European Union do not produce a deal.

Headline: In rare step, parliament passes motion ordering Vote Leave director to appear
Description: British lawmakers took the rare step on Thursday of ordering a director of Brexit campaign group Vote Leave to parliament to answer questions about campaign spending and advertising after he refused to comply with earlier requests.

Headline: UK top court says it can't demand abortion law change in Northern Ireland
Description: Britain's Supreme Court expressed the view on Thursday that Northern Ireland's strict abortion law was incompatible with the European Convention on Human Rights, but added it did not have the powers to make a formal declaration that the law should be changed.

Headline: UK proposes time-limited backstop, expects Brexit deal by end-2021
Description: The British government stuck to its proposal to offer the European Union a "backstop" plan that is time-limited but said it expected a future deal to be in place by the end of December 2021, a document said on Thursday.

Headline: May has 'constructive' talks with Brexit minister over backstop
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May had "constructive" talks with her Brexit secretary David Davis, whom she expects to be in his post by the end of the day after a reported disagreement, her spokeswoman said on Thursday.

Headline: Explainer - London's new runway: progress at last but no take off yet
Description: British lawmakers could approve the expansion of Heathrow this month, moving London's largest airport closer to building a new runway than it has been for years, but hurdles remain after decades of indecision and false starts.

Headline: Heathrow expansion faces challenge as Labour casts doubt over support
Description: The British government's plan to build a new runway at London's Heathrow Airport faces a potential new challenge as the opposition Labour party has indicated that its members may vote against it.

Headline: Pressuring May, Labour tries to force new single market deal
Description: The opposition Labour Party has thrown down the gauntlet to Prime Minister Theresa May on Brexit, urging MPs to defeat her in parliament by backing a proposal for Britain to stay in the EU's single market after leaving the bloc.

Headline: Britain to publish Irish border Brexit backstop plan on Thursday - BBC
Description: The British government will publish on Thursday its 'backstop' plan for dealing with the Irish border after Brexit if it fails to agree a wide-ranging trade deal with the European Union that would eliminate the need for border checks, the BBC's political editor said.

Headline: PM May sidesteps questions on publication of Brexit strategy
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May refused twice on Wednesday to answer whether her government would publish its Brexit negotiation policy proposals ahead of the June 28-29 EU summit.

Headline: Man whose flat was origin of London's Grenfell Tower blaze is blameless, inquiry hears
Description: The man in whose apartment a huge fire broke out, killing 71 people in a London tower block a year ago, was not to blame for the disaster but has been subjected to "sleazy accusations" and innuendo, his lawyer told a public inquiry on Wednesday.

Headline: Man whose flat was origin of London's Grenfell Tower blaze is blameless, inquiry hears
Description: The man in whose apartment a huge fire broke out, killing 71 people in a London tower block a year ago, was not to blame for the disaster but has been subjected to "sleazy accusations" and innuendo, his lawyer told a public inquiry on Wednesday.

Headline: Wales offers funding for world's first tidal lagoon project
Description: Wales has offered 200 million pounds in funding to help build the Swansea Bay tidal lagoon ahead of a UK government decision on whether to fund the 1.3 billion pound renewable energy project.

Headline: Ministers back new Heathrow runway
Description: Ministers backed plans for a new runway at London's Heathrow airport on Tuesday, opening the way for a parliamentary vote after decades of delays, although the project could still face challenges before building starts.

Headline: Jeremy Corbyn rejects pleas to stay in the EU single market
Description: Opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Tuesday that Britain must leave the European Union's single market, disappointing some supporters who hoped he would support a proposal to retain membership ahead of a crunch vote in parliament next week.

Headline: Heathrow approval shows government committed to post-Brexit connections - spokesman
Description: Britain's decision to back plans for a new runway at London's Heathrow airport show the government is committed to keeping London well connected after Brexit, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain takes £2 billion loss on RBS share sale
Description: Britain has sold some of its holding in Royal Bank of Scotland , the bank which it rescued in the 2008 financial crisis, but has taken a loss of more than 2 billion pounds on the deal.

Headline: London firefighters faced intolerable choices during Grenfell fire, inquiry told
Description: London firefighters battling to control the deadly Grenfell Tower blaze faced intolerable dilemmas as to whether to direct residents to stay put or try and escape through toxic smoke, a public inquiry has been told.

Headline: London's Grenfell Tower was a death trap wrapped in 'petrol', inquiry hears
Description: London's Grenfell Tower, where a huge fire killed 71 people a year ago, had been fitted during a recent refurbishment with cladding containing a material as flammable as petrol, a public inquiry heard on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain asks to join WTO procurement deal in latest Brexit step
Description: Britain has officially applied to join the World Trade Organization's government procurement agreement, a legal step it needs to take to maintain trading relationships after it leaves the European Union on March 29, 2019.

Headline: Blaze in Mayfair, central London, under control - fire brigade
Description: A blaze at a block of flats in Mayfair, central London, is now under control, the fire brigade said on Tuesday, adding that the cause of the fire in the upscale residential area was unknown.

Headline: Decision on Britain's aviation plans to be announced shortly - PM May's spokesman
Description: A decision on Britain's aviation strategy will be announced later today, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday, referring to a decision on whether the government will back plans for a new runway at Heathrow airport.

Headline: UK business warns May post-Brexit frictionless trade more important than tariffs - source
Description: British business leaders warned Prime Minister Theresa May during a meeting on Monday that maintaining frictionless trade with the European Union after Brexit was probably more important than the imposition of any tariffs, a source told Reuters.

Headline: Brexit legislation to return to House of Commons on June 12
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May faces a June 12 showdown with potential Brexit rebels, when the legislation underpinning Britain's exit from the European Union returns to the floor of parliament for a crucial debate.

Headline: U.S. tariffs 'unjustified', PM May tells Trump on call
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told President Donald Trump on Monday that U.S. tariffs imposed on European Union steel and aluminium imports were "unjustified and deeply disappointing" during a phone call.

Headline: Response to Trump metal tariffs must be measured and proportionate - UK minister
Description: Britain and the European Union's response to the imposition of U.S. steel and aluminium tariffs must be measured and proportionate, British trade secretary Liam Fox said on Monday.

Headline: UK government will seek to overturn some amendments to Brexit bill in parliament
Description: Britain's government will seek to overturn some amendments to its EU withdrawal bill to sever ties with the European Union when it returns to the lower house of parliament on June 12, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Former U.S. federal prosecutor to head Britain's fraud buster
Description: Former U.S. federal prosecutor Lisa Osofsky was named the head of Britain's Serious Fraud Office (SFO) on Monday and said she wanted to embolden an agency whose future has been in doubt.

Headline: 'Stay put' policy failed in London's deadly Grenfell fire, inquiry hears
Description: Residents of London's Grenfell Tower housing block should have been told to get out quickly rather than stay in their flats as flames engulfed the building and killed 71 people a year ago, a public inquiry heard on Monday.

Headline: Britain revises security strategy to counter 'step change' in militant threat
Description: Britain will counter what it calls a "step change" in the threat posed by militants with a revised counter-terrorism strategy published on Monday that looks to harness technology, share information more widely, and strengthen ties with businesses.

Headline: Britain should force companies to report climate risk exposure - lawmakers
Description: Britain should force large companies, pension funds and other big investors to report their exposure to climate risks by 2022 at the latest, a cross-party group of lawmakers said in a report published on Monday.

Headline: UK confident Brexit won't bring Armageddon - PM May's spokesman
Description: The government is confident there will be no Armageddon after Brexit, British Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday, responding to a report that officials had predicted petrol, food and medicine shortages if there was no deal.

Headline: Hong Kong's top court hears landmark appeal on spousal visa for British lesbian
Description: Hong Kong's top court on Monday began hearing the final appeal of a landmark LGBT rights case that has garnered public support from more than 30 top global banks and law firms, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.

Headline: Northern Irish police to retain disused stations as Brexit precaution
Description: Northern Ireland's police will not sell three disused stations along the Irish border as previously planned, a precautionary Brexit measure taken just days after asking for more officers to help secure the frontier.

Headline: Britain will have Brexit policies ready for June EU summit - minister
Description: Britain will have a good set of proposals on Brexit policy ready for a meeting of European Union leaders this month, home secretary Sajid Javid said on Sunday, adding that he expected a positive response from Brussels.

Headline: Conservative donor says Gove should replace May as PM - the Observer
Description: Prominent eurosceptic Michael Gove should replace British Prime Minister Theresa May because she is incapable of delivering Brexit, a donor to her party was quoted as saying in an early edition of the Observer newspaper seen on Saturday.

Headline: Ireland gives Britain two weeks to produce Brexit border proposals
Description: Britain must submit written proposals on how it plans to keep a frictionless border on the island of Ireland after Brexit in the next two weeks or face an uncertain summer of talks, Irish Foreign Minister Simon Coveney was quoted as saying on Saturday.

Headline: UK considering giving Northern Ireland joint UK, EU status - source
Description: The United Kingdom could propose giving Northern Ireland joint UK and European Union status so it can trade freely with both, in an attempt to break the deadlock in Brexit negotiations, a government official said.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP dismisses idea of joint UK, EU status
Description: The Northern Irish party that supports Britain's minority government dismissed the idea of giving Northern Ireland joint European Union and UK status after Brexit as at best contradictory, one of its lawmakers said, adding that the idea had not been raised with the party.

Headline: Northern Ireland police demand extra resources for post-Brexit
Description: (This May 31 story has been corrected to show Mark Lindsay is chairman of police federation, not police service)

Headline: UK plans to give Northern Ireland joint UK, EU status - The Sun
Description: The United Kingdom will attempt to break the deadlock in the Brexit negotiations with a proposal to give Northern Ireland joint UK and European Union status so that it can trade freely with both, The Sun newspaper reported.

Headline: Does FCA's Bailey want the Bank of England's top job? No comment
Description: The chief of Britain's financial regulator Andrew Bailey on Thursday declined to comment as to whether he was interested in succeeding Mark Carney as the Bank of England governor, saying he had a big job to do already.

Headline: Factbox - Energy price changes by utilities in Britain
Description: Some of Britain's biggest energy companies have announced price increases this year, citing higher wholesale prices and the cost of government policies to support renewable energy generation.

Headline: FCA to consider capping rent-to-own prices
Description: Britain's financial watchdog is considering capping "rent-to-own" prices and fundamentally reforming how banks charge for unarranged overdrafts to crack down on high cost credit, it said on Thursday

Headline: UK car output ends run of declines to rise 5 percent in April
Description: British car production overturned several months of declines to rise 5.2 percent in April, boosted by new and updated models and a comparatively poor performance in the same month last year due to the timing of Easter, a car industry body said on Thursday.

Headline: Manufacturers slam UK Brexit customs idea as naive
Description: British manufacturers turned up the pressure on the government to abandon one of its post-Brexit customs proposals on Tuesday, slamming the idea of a technology-based plan for border checks as naive and a waste of money.

Headline: Britain wants Brexit talks to be more constructive - May's spokesman
Description: Britain wants the Brexit talks to be more constructive with less focus on sounds bites and anonymous briefings, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said, after the EU's Brexit negotiator urged the government to stop playing "hide and seek".

Headline: Doctors who treated Skripals uncertain about their long-term health
Description: The doctors who treated a Russian former spy and his daughter after they were poisoned with a nerve agent in Britain say they don't know what the pair's long term health outlook is - and initially feared the incident could have been much worse.

Headline: Northern Ireland rally calls on May to ease abortion rules
Description: Hundreds of women's rights activist rallied in Belfast on Monday to put pressure on British Prime Minister Theresa May to reform Northern Ireland's highly restrictive abortion rules after neighbouring Ireland's vote to liberalise its laws.

Headline: Looking for new way to donate during Ramadan? London mosque now accepts bitcoin
Description: Looking for a new way to give money to charity as part of Ramadan? A mosque in Britain's capital is willing to receive your donation - in bitcoin.

Headline: May refuses to relax Northern Ireland abortion rules
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces a showdown with ministers and lawmakers in her Conservative party after refusing to back reform of Northern Ireland's highly restrictive abortion rules after neighbouring Ireland's vote to liberalise its laws.

Headline: Bank of England and UK finance ministry divided over city regulation after Brexit  - FT
Description: Britain's finance ministry and the Bank of England are at odds over how to regulate financial services in the City of London after Brexit, the Financial Times reported on Monday, citing unnamed officials.

Headline: Scotland wary of Northern Ireland gaining Brexit advantage
Description: Scottish leader Nicola Sturgeon cited concern about Northern Ireland gaining a competitive advantage over Scotland in any Brexit deal, to press her case in Brussels on Monday for staying in the EU single market.

Headline: Britain could sell 10 percent stake in RBS as soon as this week - Sky News
Description: Britain could sell a 10 percent stake in Royal Bank of Scotland as soon as this week, Sky News reported on Monday, citing banking sources.

Headline: Independent Scotland would not join euro - Sturgeon
Description: An independent Scotland would not join the euro currency, Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Monday, adding there was "absolutely nothing" stopping the country keeping the pound.

Headline: May to urge Trump to avoid London protests during UK visit - The Sun
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will urge U.S. President Donald Trump to avoid protesters in central London during his UK visit in July and instead meet her at her country residence, the Sun newspaper reported on Sunday.

Headline: London's Stansted has flights disrupted by lightning strike
Description: London's Stansted airport delayed, diverted and cancelled some flights after a lightning strike on an aircraft fuelling system during storms that unleashed more than 64,000 thunderbolts.

Headline: In Northern Ireland, abortion rights groups clamour for change
Description: Abortion rights activists in Northern Ireland called on the British government to end what one group described as the province's "Victorian-era abortion ban" after neighbouring Ireland voted by a landslide to liberalise its laws.

Headline: Jailed British-Iranian aid worker to face trial on security charges - Iran court head
Description: A detained British-Iranian aid worker sentenced to five years in jail in Iran is to face a second trial on new security charges, the semi-official Tasnim news agency on Saturday quoted Tehran Revolutionary Court's head Musa Ghazanfarabadi as saying.

Headline: End 'hide and seek' Brexit approach, Barnier tells UK
Description: The EU's Brexit negotiator urged the British government on Saturday to stop playing "hide and seek" over its aims for trade ties and warned that delays in agreeing on judicial oversight risk wrecking any Brexit deal.

Headline: Pacific Ocean features in new royal Markle's Coat of Arms
Description: A Coat of Arms has been created for U.S. actress Meghan Markle, who married Britain's Prince Harry in a lavish ceremony watched by millions last weekend, featuring California's state flower and a blue background to represent the Pacific Ocean.

Headline: UK energy regulator opens one-month consultation on price caps
Description: Britain's energy regulator has called for comments from gas and electricity suppliers and consumers on plans to impose price caps on certain tariffs.

Headline: Britain will build own satellite system if no access to EU's - Hammond
Description: Britain would develop its own separate satellite navigation system if it lost access to the Galileo project, the European Union's version of GPS, Britain's finance minister said on Friday.

Headline: EU dismisses latest British ideas on Ireland after Brexit
Description: Britain's post-Brexit adaptation will run through 2020, as planned, a British government spokeswoman said on Thursday as the EU dismissed London's ideas for a longer status quo on customs and trade in a fight over the Irish border.

Headline: Yerevan calling? Johnson discusses Russia with hoax caller
Description: Britain's Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson talked international relations and rude poetry with a hoax caller who pretended to be the Armenian prime minister in a new gaffe by one of Britain's most prominent politicians.

Headline: Irish border Brexit progress 'elusive', EU says after talks
Description: British and EU negotiators have made little progress this week on efforts to avoid a post-Brexit hard border in Ireland, a senior EU official said on Thursday.

Headline: UK transport minister says cost of Heathrow must be kept down
Description: The cost of expanding Heathrow Airport must be kept down, British transport minister Chris Grayling said on Thursday,  heeding airline warnings that the airport's new runway must not be so expensive that passengers end up paying higher prices.

Headline: EU told Britain 'time-limited' backstop won't work - EU official
Description: European Union Brexit negotiators told their British counterparts this week that a suggestion from London to make a backstop solution for avoiding a hard border on Ireland "time-limited" was unacceptable.

Headline: Investigation launched into hoax call to UK's Johnson - May's spokeswoman
Description: An investigation is under way to determine how a hoax caller was able to speak to British foreign minister Boris Johnson in an 18 minute phone conversation, a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: Brexit customs plan could cost UK aerospace/defence industry £2.3 billion - trade body
Description: Britain's aerospace and defence industry could face extra costs of 2.3 billion pounds ($3 billion) to comply with the customs arrangement favoured by some Brexit supporters within the cabinet, according to forecasts by trade body ADS.

Headline: Uber will soon detail plan to stop using diesel cars in London
Description: Uber [UBER.UL] said it will provide more information in the coming weeks on how it plans to stop diesel using cars in London and of a proposed scrappage scheme, as the court date nears for the taxi app to defend its right to operate in London nears.

Headline: Uber will soon detail plan to stop using diesel cars in London
Description: Uber [UBER.UL] said it will provide more information in the coming weeks on how it plans to stop diesel using cars in London and of a proposed scrappage scheme, as the court date nears for the taxi app to defend its right to operate in London nears.

Headline: Brexit customs 'mess' will hurt peace in Ireland, says Labour's Corbyn
Description: British Labour opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn attacked the government's Brexit plans on Thursday, saying its future customs proposals would undermine an open border on the island of Ireland that "is a symbol of peace".

Headline: Britain may have to extend EU customs arrangements after Brexit - MPs
Description: Britain may have to stay in the EU customs union after the post-Brexit transition period finishes at the end of 2020 because new trading arrangements will not be ready, according to a parliamentary report on Thursday.

Headline: UK set for parliamentary showdown on Brexit law 'in weeks'
Description: The British government said on Thursday its key piece of Brexit legislation would return to the House of Commons in a matter of weeks, the next stage in what is expected to be a major test of Prime Minister Theresa May's authority.

Headline: Exclusive: Yulia Skripal - Attempted assassination turned my world upside down
Description: Yulia Skripal survived an assassination attempt that UK authorities blame on Russia. But the daughter of one of Russia's most famous spies says she wants to return to her country "in the longer term", despite the poisoning.

Headline: Yulia Skripal, daughter of poisoned Russian spy, in her own words
Description: Yulia Skripal, who was found unconscious on a bench in the southern English city of Salisbury on March 4 along with her father Sergei, spoke to Reuters on Wednesday.

Headline: Boris Johnson seeks trade agreements in Chile, Latin America
Description: Britain’s Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson concluded a five-day charm offensive in Latin America on Wednesday by expressing interest in a trade agreement with Chile and other countries in Latin America's so-called Pacific Alliance.

Headline: Brexit customs paperwork to cost firms up to 20 billion pounds a year, tax official says
Description: Businesses will face a cost of up to 20 billion pounds ($27 billion) a year to comply with the customs arrangement favoured by the keenest Brexit supporters within the cabinet, Britain's most senior tax official said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain legally bound to pay Brexit bill before trade accord agreed - minister
Description: Britain is legally bound to pay its up to 39 billion pound ($52 billion) divorce bill to the European Union before it agrees a  future trade deal with the bloc, a Brexit minister said on Wednesday.

Headline: Labour loses vote to dock transport minister's pay over rail failure
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party lost a vote on Wednesday to force the government to dock the transport minister's salary over his handling of the failed contract to run the London to Edinburgh rail line.

Headline: British court convicts pensioner for raping girls in Kenya
Description: A 72-year-old pensioner has been found guilty in a British court of raping two Kenyan girls while he was on holiday in the East African nation, the latest example of cross-border collaboration to stamp out child sex offences by Western tourists.

Headline: Hammond rebuffs employers' call for customs union after Brexit
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond rejected a call from a leading employers group on Tuesday to keep Britain in a customs union with the European Union after Brexit, saying it was not needed to keep trade running smoothly.

Headline: Argentina weighs 5 airlines' plans for new Falklands flights - minister
Description: Argentina and Britain are analysing five South American airlines' proposals for new flights between the Falkland Islands and Argentina, Argentina's Foreign Minister Jorge Faurie said on Tuesday.

Headline: Hammond sets target for 15 million 'full-fibre' broadband connections by 2025
Description: Britain's telecoms industry needs to make 'full-fibre' broadband available to 15 million homes and businesses by 2025, finance minister Philip Hammond is set to announce to business leaders later on Tuesday.

Headline: Brexit exposes 'wishful thinking' of Norway's EEA foes - foreign minister
Description: Opponents of Norway's close ties to the European Union are wrong to assume a more beneficial relationship could be found, as shown by Britain's troubled negotiations to leave the bloc, the Norwegian foreign minister said on Tuesday.

Headline: Warm June in Nordics, Britain before cooling down - The Weather Company
Description: Northern mainland Europe and Scandinavia will experience warmer than normal temperatures in June before some regions cool down in July, The Weather Company said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK government launches plan to curb air pollution
Description: The British government announced on Tuesday it was launching a new plan which aims to reduce air pollution and its costs on society by 1 billion pounds ($1.4 billion) a year by 2020.

Headline: UK public finances start new tax year on strong footing
Description: Britain's government kicked off the new financial year with a smaller than expected budget deficit in April, according to data that also showed less borrowing than first estimated in the previous year.
