Description: The leader of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), Arlene Foster, said on Thursday she saw little chance of a return to devolved government in the British province in the coming weeks or months.

Headline: Britain and Saudi Arabia target 65 billion pound trade and investment ties
Description: Britain and Saudi Arabia set out an ambition to build 65 billion pounds of trade and investment ties in coming years, London said on Wednesday, calling the agreement a vote of confidence in the British economy ahead of Brexit.

Headline: EU snubs Britain's post-Brexit trade demands, offers banks no special deal
Description: The EU on Wednesday offered Britain a free trade deal for their post-Brexit ties that fell well short of ambitions set out by Prime Minister Theresa May last week, notably for the country's dominant financial sector.

Headline: UK's Hammond - trade deal with EU will only happen if it is fair
Description: A trade deal between Britain and the European Union will only happen if it is fair to both sides, finance minister Philip Hammond said on Wednesday, adding that it would be hard not to include services as well as goods.

Headline: Britain says former Russian spy poisoned with nerve agent
Description: A nerve agent was used to deliberately poison a former Russian double agent and his daughter, Britain's top counter-terrorism officer said on Wednesday, in a case that threatens to further damage London's ties with Moscow.

Headline: EU-UK trade deal could be deeper, but modelled on Canada, Japan accords - Tajani
Description: Britain and the European Union could negotiate a deeper free-trade accord that goes beyond the bloc's new deals with Canada and Japan, but such agreements remain the model, the head of the European Parliament said on Wednesday.

Headline: Trade options for UK financial services after Brexit
Description: A stand-off between Britain and the European Union over the future of London's vast financial services industry is shaping up as one of the key Brexit battlegrounds of this year.

Headline: Former PM Gordon Brown calls for police probe into Murdoch paper
Description: Former prime minister Gordon Brown called on police to examine the activities of John Ford, an ex-private investigator who told the BBC he had been used by Rupert Murdoch's Sunday Times to obtain information about government ministers.

Headline: Gravestones mark family losses of Russian agent struck down by mystery substance
Description: In the years before Sergei Skripal was struck down with his daughter by a mystery substance outside a British shopping centre, the former Russian double agent lost both a wife and a son.

Headline: Far-right UK leader, retweeted by Trump, found guilty of religious harassment
Description: The leaders of a far-right British party, one of whom gained widespread attention after a message she posted online was re-tweeted by U.S President Donald Trump, were found guilty on Wednesday of religiously aggravated harassment.

Headline: British police suspect Russians struck former Russian double agent - sources
Description: Britain's main line of inquiry is that Russians used a mystery substance to strike down former Russian double agent Sergei Skripal, two security sources said.

Headline: UK still wants Aramco listing in London, will continue lobbying - minister
Description: Britain will continue to make the case for the partial public listing of Saudi oil firm Aramco to be conducted in London, junior foreign office minister Alistair Burt said in parliament on Wednesday.

Headline: May says links with Saudi Arabia have saved British lives
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May defended Britain's links to defence and security ally Saudi Arabia in parliament on Wednesday, saying cooperation had helped save the lives of hundreds of people.

Headline: Russia - Efforts to link us to ill ex-agent in UK designed to spoil ties
Description: Russia said on Wednesday that attempts to blame it for the mysterious illness that has struck down a Russian former double agent in Britain were wrong and looked like part of a campaign to damage relations between London and Moscow.

Headline: EU to propose limited market access for British-based banks - Bloomberg
Description: The European Union plans to offer British-based financial services companies only limited access to the Single Market after Brexit, according to a draft document quoted by Bloomberg.

Headline: UK authorities know more about substance that made Russian ex-spy ill
Description: The British authorities know more about a substance which Russian ex-spy Sergei Skripal was exposed to before he became critically ill, interior minister Amber Rudd said on Wednesday, adding that police would make a further statement later.

Headline: Irish Supreme Court clears the way for May referendum on abortion
Description: Ireland's Supreme Court on Wednesday cleared the way for an abortion referendum planned for the end of May, ruling that the unborn do not have inherent constitutional rights outside the right to life in the eighth amendment of the constitution.

Headline: Russian ex-spy, daughter still critical after suspected poisoning in UK
Description: Russian former double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia remain in a critical condition in intensive care in hospital, British police said on Wednesday as they appealed for witnesses to come forward with any information about the case.

Headline: Russia - Attempts to link us to ill ex-agent in Britain designed to spoil ties
Description: The Russian Foreign Ministry said on Wednesday that attempts in Britain to link Russia to a mysterious illness which has struck down a Russian former double agent looked designed to worsen relations between London and Moscow.

Headline: Britain warns Russia over double agent's mysterious illness
Description: Britain warned Russia on Tuesday of a robust response if the Kremlin was behind a mysterious illness that has struck down a former double agent convicted of betraying dozens of spies to British intelligence.

Headline: Factbox - From polonium to a poisoned umbrella: mysterious fates of Kremlin foes
Description: Britain has warned of a robust response if it finds evidence of  Russian involvement in the collapse of a former Russian agent convicted of betraying dozens of spies to British intelligence.

Headline: Factbox - From polonium to a poisoned umbrella: mysterious fates of Kremlin foes
Description: Britain has warned of a robust response if it finds evidence of  Russian involvement in the collapse of a former Russian agent convicted of betraying dozens of spies to British intelligence.

Headline: Russia says Britain's allegations on Skripal incident "groundless"
Description: Russia's Foreign Ministry rejected as "groundless" Britain's allegations on Tuesday that Moscow may be involved in a mysterious illness that struck down a former Russian spy, the TASS news agency reported.

Headline: EU cool towards British "associate membership" in bloc's agencies
Description: The European Union is cool to the idea of Britain's "associate membership" in various agencies of the bloc as proposed by London to make Brexit less disruptive for British business, with officials saying the approach boils down to cherry picking.

Headline: Social media firms are like irresponsible landlords - UK counter-terrorism police head
Description: Technology and social media firms are allowing extremists to act with impunity and lack commitment in tackling the online terrorist threat, a senior British police officer said on Tuesday.

Headline: At national security council meeting, May briefed on Salisbury - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May was briefed at a meeting of the National Security Council on an investigation into a mystery illness that afflicted a former Russian agent, her spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: May to hold talks with Saudi Crown Prince at country residence
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will hold talks with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at her country residence on Thursday, diplomatic sources said, in another sign of the importance with which London is treating his visit.

Headline: UK parliament will not be able to overturn EU referendum - David Davis
Description: Parliament will not be able thwart Brexit by using a vote expected later this year on the final deal negotiated with the European Union to overturn the result of the 2016 referendum, Brexit secretary David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: Russian ex-spy and daughter still critically ill in mysterious UK incident
Description: Russian former double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia remain in a critical condition after they were found unconscious on Sunday in this southwestern English city, police said on Tuesday.

Headline: Russia calls British minister's comments on spy incident 'wild' - Ifax
Description: Russian Foreign Ministry Spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said on Tuesday that British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson's comments about a mysterious illness that has struck down a Russian former double agent were "wild," the Interfax news agency reported.

Headline: UK may look at World Cup officials' attendance if Russia behind ex-agent's illness - source
Description: Britain may rethink the attendance of official representatives at the soccer World Cup in Russia if Moscow is shown to be behind a mysterious illness that struck down a Russian former double agent in England, a government source said on Tuesday.

Headline: May, government kept informed about events in Salisbury - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May and government departments are being kept informed about developments in Salisbury, her spokesman said on Tuesday after two people were hospitalised following suspected exposure to an unknown substance.

Headline: Britain may look at new Russia sanctions if it is involved in ex-spy's illness
Description: Britain may have to look at new sanctions on Russia if suspicions that it is involved in the illness of a former Russian agent in Salisbury are well-founded, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain says will respond robustly if Russia behind ex-spy's illness
Description: Britain will respond robustly if it is proved that Russia was involved in an incident which left a former Russian double agent in a critical condition, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Tuesday.

Headline: Russia says Skripal incident being used to demonise Moscow
Description: Russia's embassy in London said on Tuesday it was seriously concerned by British media reporting of the hospitalisation of former Russian double agent Sergei Skripal and complained that the incident was being used to demonise Russia.

Headline: Two remain in critical condition after Salisbury incident - police
Description: Two people remain in critical condition after suspected exposure to an unknown substance in Salisbury, southwestern England, British police said on Tuesday, adding that one member of the emergency services also remained in hospital.

Headline: Two British police officers hospitalised after attending Salisbury incident - BBC
Description: Two British police officers were admitted to hospital with minor symptoms after attending an incident in Salisbury which left two others in critical condition, the BBC said on Tuesday, adding the officers had been subsequently discharged.

Headline: Jaguar Land Rover needs Brexit detail before building electric cars in Britain
Description: Jaguar Land Rover is waiting for more information on trading conditions after Brexit before it decides whether to make electric cars in its home market, the boss of Britain's biggest carmaker told Reuters.

Headline: Kremlin - We're open to work with Britain over incident involving ex-agent
Description: The Kremlin said on Tuesday it was ready to cooperate if Britain asks it for help investigating an incident involving a former Russian double agent who fell ill after exposure to an unknown substance.

Headline: Unidentified substance case in UK not being treated as terrorism - police
Description: An incident involving an unidentified substance which left two people in a critical condition in western England is not being investigated by counter-terrorism police but officers have an open mind about its cause, a local police official said.

Headline: Britain's health service 'not for sale' in U.S. trade talks - May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday that Britain's National Health Service was "not for sale" in any future trade deal with the United States after Brexit.

Headline: May calls on housebuilders to 'do their duty', ease shortage
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May called on homebuilders on Monday to "do their duty" and build new houses more quickly to meet demand, launching a draft policy on planning laws to try to ease Britain's housing shortage.

Headline: Lawmakers question biggest UK pensions over climate change risks
Description: Britain's biggest pension funds have been asked by lawmakers to explain how they are managing the impact of climate change risks on their investments.

Headline: Sky and Wiggins crossed 'ethical line' - UK parliamentary report
Description: Team Sky crossed an "ethical line" by using permitted medication to enhance the performance of Tour de France winner Bradley Wiggins, said a British parliamentary committee report published on Monday.

Headline: May tells U.S. President Trump of 'deep concern' over metals tariffs
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told U.S. President Donald Trump she had "deep concern" about the expected announcement of U.S. tariffs on aluminium and steel, May's office said on Sunday following a phone call between the two leaders.

Headline: May defends stance on post-Brexit financial services rules
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May defended her decision to rule out so-called 'passporting' rights for banks after Brexit, saying Britain could not become a "rule taker" when it came to financial services.

Headline: UK police charge three men over shop blast that killed five in Leicester
Description: British police investigating a shop blast a week ago which killed five people in the central English city of Leicester, said on Saturday they had charged three men with manslaughter and arson with intent to endanger life.

Headline: Hardliners give cautious welcome to May's Brexit vision
Description: The head of a hardline group of pro-Brexit lawmakers on Saturday gave a cautious welcome to Prime Minister Theresa May's plans for Britain's future ties with Europe, saying now was not the time to nitpick.

Headline: Setting out Brexit vision, Britain's May appeals to EU to show flexibility
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May urged the European Union on Friday to show more flexibility in talks on a future relationship after Brexit, saying Britain realised it could not get all it wanted but believed an ambitious trade deal was still possible.

Headline: Ireland, Britain grind slowly back to normal following snowstorms
Description: Airports reopened and public transport began to grind back into service on Saturday after the worst snowstorms in nearly 30 years caused two days of major disruption in Britain and shut most of Ireland.

Headline: Prince Harry and fiancee Meghan to invite public to wedding celebrations
Description: Britain's Prince Harry and his wife-to-be Meghan Markle will invite more than 2,500 members of the public to take part in their wedding day celebrations in May, his office said on Friday.

Headline: Teacher tried to create 'army of children' to launch terror attacks in London
Description: A British supporter of Islamic State was found guilty on Friday of trying to recruit children he was teaching into an "army" of jihadists to help carry out a wave of attacks across London.

Headline: Snowstorms shut down Ireland, Britain calls in army for hospitals
Description: Snowstorms shut most of Ireland on Friday and forced Britain to call in the army to help battle some of the worst weather seen for nearly 30 years.

Headline: Irish PM says remains concerned about UK Brexit position
Description: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar on Friday said he remained concerned that British Prime Minister Theresa May did not fully recognise the implications of leaving the European Union's customs union and single market.

Headline: Reaction to May's speech on Brexit
Description: Following are reactions to British prime minister Theresa May's speech on Friday setting out her priorities for Brexit ahead of negotiations this year on a new relationship with the European Union.

Headline: May to make 'real step forward' in EU talks with Friday speech
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will set out her vision for an "ambitious economic partnership" with the European Union on Friday, which her team of ministers agreed would be a "real step forward" in talks with the bloc, her spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: As May readies trade speech, Tusk sees difficulties
Description: "Real political difficulties" lie ahead for Brexit, EU summit chair Donald Tusk said after Prime Minister Theresa May gave him a preview of the vision of future trade ties she will unveil on Friday.

Headline: EU's Barnier welcomes 'clarity' in May Brexit speech
Description: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier welcomed "clarity" from Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday and her recognition that Britain faces "trade-offs" when it leaves the EU single market and customs union.

Headline: Factbox - May sets out stance for new trade ties with EU
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May delivered a speech on Friday setting out her priorities for Brexit ahead of negotiations to forge a new relationship with the European Union.

Headline: EU lawmaker Weber slams May Brexit speech
Description: The German leader of the biggest party in the European Parliament, an ally of Chancellor Angela Merkel, said Friday's speech by Prime Minister Theresa May left him worried there may be no deal on Brexit.

Headline: Highlights - May sets out Brexit vision for trade deal deeper than any other
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May set out her vision on Friday for a Brexit deal deeper and wider than any free trade agreement in the world, telling the European Union it is in their "shared interest".

Headline: Highlights - May sets out Brexit vision for trade deal deeper than any other
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May set out her vision on Friday for a Brexit deal deeper and wider than any free trade agreement in the world, telling the European Union it is in their "shared interest".

Headline: May says message to EU is clear: "let's get on with it"
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday Britain would not be buffeted by European Union demands in divorce talks nor would threaten to walk out of negotiations, adding her message to the bloc was "let's get on with it".

Headline: May tells Tusk EU draft legal text would undermine the UK
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told European Council President Donald Tusk on Thursday the European Commission's draft legal text on Brexit is unacceptable to Britain, her office said, after a meeting aimed resolving differences with the bloc.

Headline: Siberian blizzards blast Britain and Ireland as Storm Emma approaches
Description: Snow storms from Siberia blasted Britain and Ireland on Thursday with the worst weather since 1991, trapping several hundred motorists on roads in Scotland, closing thousands of schools, grounding planes and halting trains.

Headline: EU's negotiator says Britain can only get a free-trade deal now
Description: The European Union's Brexit negotiator said on Thursday that London's stance on its future ties with the bloc only left a free trade agreement as an option.

Headline: EU's Tusk talks 'real political difficulties' on Brexit with May - source
Description: The chairman of European Union leaders, Donald Tusk, and British Prime Minister Theresa May discussed on Thursday the "real political difficulties ahead" on Brexit, an EU official said.

Headline: Prince William to make groundbreaking Middle East trip
Description: Queen Elizabeth's grandson Prince William will visit Israel and the Palestinian territories this summer, his office announced on Thursday, the first official visit by a senior member of Britain's royal family.

Headline: Blair, in Brussels, urges EU to help Britons stop Brexit
Description: Former British premier Tony Blair called in Brussels on Thursday for European Union leaders to commit to reforms, notably on migration, to help convince Britons not to go ahead with leaving the bloc next year.

Headline: Britain told to 'carry on cooking' despite gas supply warning
Description: British households were told to "carry on cooking" by the government on Thursday, as a warning of a gas supply deficit spooked the market and raised questions over the country's gas policy.

Headline: UK rules out holding second part of inquiry into press ethics
Description: Britain said on Thursday it would not proceed with the second part of an inquiry into newspaper ethics called after a phone-hacking scandal at a Rupert Murdoch tabloid, prompting criticism it was betraying victims of press intrusion.

Headline: Scottish Conservatives cancel conference due to bad UK weather
Description: The Scottish Conservative Party has cancelled its conference, which was due to start in Aberdeen on Friday, because of bad weather, it said in a statement.

Headline: UK says attacks from Northern Irish based militants on mainland Britain unlikely
Description: British security services on Thursday reduced the threat level from Northern Irish-related militants to mainland Britain, saying an attack was now considered unlikely.

Headline: British homes should not see gas supply disruption despite alert - government
Description: British households should see no disruption to their gas supply on Thursday, the government said, despite a warning by National Grid of a potential supply deficit.

Headline: EU says to regulate Northern Irish trade unless Britain acts fast
Description: The European Union on Wednesday laid out how it would regulate Northern Ireland's trade if no better solution was found in the fast-closing window before Britain's departure from the EU, prompting furious reactions in London and Belfast.

Headline: No upside in Brexit for British car industry - MPs
Description: Britain must maintain free trade and European Union regulatory alignment for the automotive industry as Brexit offers no upside for the sector, a committee of MPs said.

Headline: Facebook says finds no new evidence Russia interfered in Brexit referendum
Description: Facebook Inc  has told a British parliamentary committee that further investigations have found no new evidence that Russia used social media to interfere in the June 2016 referendum in which Britain voted to leave the European Union.

Headline: British police arrest three in fatal Leicester blast
Description: British police have arrested three men on suspicion of manslaughter related to an explosion that killed five people in the city of Leicester on Sunday evening.

Headline: Anti-Brexit MEPs defect from Conservatives' EU group
Description: Two prominent British Conservative members of the European Parliament quit the Tories' Brussels group on Wednesday to join the main, pro-EU centre-right bloc as Brexit continues to divide Britain's ruling party.

Headline: Britain's royal 'Fab Four' attend first official event together
Description: U.S. actress Meghan Markle made an official appearance alongside fiance Prince Harry and his elder brother William and wife Kate on Wednesday, the first time Britain's royal "Fab Four" have carried out an engagement together.

Headline: Britain stands resolutely behind border agreement - Northern Ireland minister
Description: Britain stands resolutely behind an agreement reached with the European Union in December that presented three options to avoid the return of a border on the island of Ireland, Northern Ireland Minister Karen Bradley said on Wednesday.

Headline: Johnson says Northern Irish border issue being used to frustrate Brexit
Description: The issue of Northern Ireland's border with the Republic of Ireland is being used to try and keep Britain in a customs union with the European Union and frustrate Brexit, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Wednesday.

Headline: EU withdrawal text constitutionally unacceptable - DUP leader
Description: The draft of a Brexit treaty that the European Commission published on Wednesday is "constitutionally unacceptable", the leader of the Northern Ireland party that props up Britain's minority government said.

Headline: Toyota to build new Auris car at UK plant in Brexit boost for May
Description: Toyota said on Wednesday it will build the next generation of its Auris car in England in a welcome boost to Prime Minister Theresa May as Britain leaves the European Union, confirming a previous Reuters report.

Headline: Britain to provide update on Northern Ireland budget, politicians' pay
Description: Britain's Northern Ireland minister will make a statement next week on implementing a budget for the region and on politicians' salaries, while it continues to explore whether agreement can be reached to restore the province's power-sharing government.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP says proposed Irish border arrangements 'will not go anywhere'
Description: Reported details of a draft Brexit treaty between Britain and the EU, notably regarding proposals for a hard border with Ireland, are a "ludicrous" suggestion that will not go anywhere, the deputy leader of the Northern Ireland party that props up Britain's minority government said.

Headline: May's Northern Irish allies angry at Brexit withdrawal treaty reports
Description: Details of the draft withdrawal treaty between Britain and the EU reported on Tuesday "fundamentally breach" a deal reached last year to move Brexit talks forward, a member of the Northern Ireland party that props up Britain's minority government said.

Headline: Scotland, Wales defy London with bills to keep powers after Brexit
Description: The Scottish and Welsh governments said on Tuesday they will introduce bills into their parliaments aimed at keeping regional powers that come back from Brussels after Brexit, in a move that could complicate British plans to leave the EU.

Headline: EU's Barnier warns time running out for Brexit deal
Description: EU negotiator Michel Barnier accused the British government on Tuesday of clinging to "illusion" while time runs out for a Brexit deal to avoid massive disruption when Britain leaves the European Union next year.

Headline: Pregnant duchess Kate meets midwife who helped deliver baby Charlotte
Description: Kate, Britain's Duchess of Cambridge, met the midwife who helped deliver her daughter when the heavily pregnant royal visited London's Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (RCOG) on Tuesday to become the charity's patron.

Headline: Britain's trade choice - EU customs union or going it alone?
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has said Britain will not join a customs union with the European Union after Brexit, splitting her ruling Conservative Party and upsetting many business leaders.

Headline: Staying in a customs union would betray Brexit voters, minister says
Description: Britain’s trade minister Liam Fox attacked the opposition Labour’s party plans to remain in a customs union with the European Union on Tuesday, calling it a betrayal of the millions of people who voted for Brexit.

Headline: Saudi Crown Prince to visit Britain on March 7 - May's spokesman
Description: Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman will begin a visit to Britain on March 7 which will include talks with Prime Minister Theresa May on topics such as extremism and societal reform, May's spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: Putting pressure on May, Labour backs new customs union with EU
Description: Britain should enter a new customs union with the European Union, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Monday, setting up a possible parliamentary defeat for Prime Minister Theresa May who has vowed to leave the arrangement after Brexit.

Headline: May still thinks Northern Ireland power-share deal possible
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May still believes a deal can be reached to restore Northern Ireland's power-sharing government, her spokeswoman said on Tuesday.

Headline: British police sift through rubble at scene of fatal Leicester blast
Description: British police searched for survivors on Monday in the rubble of a shop and apartment destroyed by an explosion that killed at least five people and injured five others in the city of Leicester on Sunday evening.

Headline: Britain launches consultation on future farm policy
Description: Britain's farming and environment minister Michael Gove on Tuesday launched a consultation which could lead to the phasing out of direct payments to English farmers with funds redirected to a new scheme paying "public money for public goods".

Headline: Tory MP calls government Brexit advice to firms "extraordinary"
Description: The head of a British parliamentary committee criticised the government on Tuesday for advising companies to prepare for Brexit without first telling them what to expect when the country quits the European Union.

Headline: Britain will keep data flowing post-Brexit - minister
Description: Britain is working to ensure data will flow unhindered between the UK and Europe after Brexit, and technology companies will still be able to access the best international talent, junior trade minister Graham Stuart told Reuters on Monday.

Headline: UK expects post-Brexit devolution deal but Scotland begs to differ
Description: Britain's government said on Monday that it expected to reach an agreement with the United Kingdom's devolved nations on how power will be shared after Brexit, but its latest proposal to unlock a political impasse fell flat in Scotland.

Headline: Rolling Stones announce first British concerts in five years
Description: Rockers The Rolling Stones announced their first British concerts in five years on Monday, including shows at two different stadiums in London.

Headline: Corbyn says Brexit must not leave Britain worse off
Description: Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Monday that Brexit must not leave the country worse off and that his party would try to get the best divorce deal for jobs and the economy.

Headline: UK must be able to influence EU trade deals after Brexit - Corbyn
Description: British opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Monday that Britain must be able to influence the European Union's trade deals if the country signs up to a new customs union with the bloc after Brexit.

Headline: Corbyn blasts May for 'rigid' position on immigration
Description: Opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Monday he would take a more flexible approach than Prime Minister Theresa May to immigration after Brexit, addressing one of the concerns of employers about the risks of leaving the European Union.

Headline: Britain will not seek a post-Brexit customs union with EU - May's spokesman
Description: Britain will not seek to enter a customs union with the European Union after it leaves the bloc next year, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Bank of England's Ramsden sees case to raise rates sooner than he thought
Description: The Bank of England might need to raise British interest rates somewhat sooner than Deputy Governor Dave Ramsden had expected if wage growth picks up early this year, according to a newspaper interview released on Saturday.

Headline: Britain vows to cap 'rip off' energy prices for millions with new law
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will cap the energy bills of 11 million British households for as long as five years under a new law introduced to parliament on Monday, aimed at tackling what she describes as "rip-off" energy prices.

Headline: Labour to back customs union, says May faces Brexit 'crunch time'
Description: Britain's opposition Labour party will back a new customs union with the EU, its Brexit policy chief said - a move that would make commerce with the bloc easier but limit the country's ability to strike other trade deals.

Headline: May to set out Brexit wishes; EU says ideas so far are 'pure illusion'
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will outline her wishes for Britain's post-Brexit ties with the European Union next week after winning support from key ministers, although European Council President Donald Tusk on Friday called the ideas floated so far "pure illusion".

Headline: Design and dictatorship - exhibition celebrates North Korean graphics
Description: North Korea makes headlines with its military parades and nuclear programme but a new London exhibition puts a spotlight on graphic design in the country.

Headline: EU leaders draw up battle lines for post-Brexit budget
Description: European Union leaders staked out opening positions on Friday for a battle over EU budgets that many conceded they are unlikely to resolve before Britain leaves next year, blowing a hole in Brussels' finances.

Headline: UK ideas on post-Brexit ties are 'pure illusion', EU's Tusk says
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk on Friday dismissed as "pure illusion" the ideas floated by Britain so far on what sort of relationship it wants with the European Union after it leaves the bloc.

Headline: Ecuador says mediation with Britain over Assange has failed
Description: Ecuador blamed Britain on Friday for upending its efforts to mediate a solution for Wikileaks founder Julian Assange, who has lived in the Ecuadorean embassy in London since June 2012 to avoid extradition.

Headline: Tusk expects joint EU stance on post-Brexit ties with Britain in March
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk said on Friday he expected the 27 European Union leaders to adopt their joint stance on the bloc's post-Brexit ties with Britain in March, regardless of whether London provides input.

Headline: Chance of halting Brexit now close to 50:50, says leading campaigner
Description: Opponents of Britain's exit from the European Union are preparing a major campaign they say now has close to a 50:50 chance of stopping Brexit by blocking Prime Minister Theresa May's divorce deal, a leading pro-EU campaigner said.

Headline: France bets on English to 'conquer the world'
Description: France will take steps to improve French students' English language skills to make them better equipped to "conquer the world", the government said on Friday as it unveiled a strategy to plug a gaping trade deficit.

Headline: Who sucks? EU mocks Gove 'green Brexit' talk on plastic straws
Description: A top European Union official scoffed at Britain's environment minister, the Brexit campaigner Michael Gove, for suggesting leaving the EU will make it easier for London to pass green legislation like banning plastic drinking straws.

Headline: Labour would seek to replicate customs union post Brexit
Description: If Britain's Labour Party won power it would seek to join a new customs union with the European Union after Brexit, according to the opposition party's spokeswoman for foreign affairs.

Headline: British lecturers go on strike over pension changes
Description: Lecturers at universities across Britain began a strike on Thursday in a row over changes to pensions, the first of a series of walkouts their union said would affect more than one million students.

Headline: May 'determined' to get fire disaster answers after Stormzy criticism
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is determined to find answers to last year's Grenfell tower block fire disaster, her spokesman said on Thursday after rapper Stormzy criticised the government response at the Brit music awards.

Headline: Haiti suspends Oxfam GB's operating right amid misconduct probe
Description: Haiti has temporarily revoked Oxfam Great Britain's right to operate in the Caribbean country after allegations of sexual misconduct by some of the charity's staff there, Planning and External Cooperation Minister Aviol Fleurant said on Thursday.

Headline: Haiti suspends Oxfam GB's operating right amid misconduct probe
Description: Haiti has temporarily revoked Oxfam Great Britain's right to operate in the Caribbean country after allegations of sexual misconduct by some of the charity's staff there, Planning and External Cooperation Minister Aviol Fleurant said on Thursday.

Headline: UNICEF deputy director Justin Forsyth resigns after 'mistakes'
Description: The deputy director of the United Nations children's agency UNICEF resigned on Thursday, saying he did not want coverage of past mistakes he had made to damage the organisation or other aid bodies.

Headline: Anti-terrorism police investigate racist letter sent to St James's Palace
Description: British police said on Thursday they were investigating after a package containing a mysterious substance, which media reported was addressed to Prince Harry and his U.S. fiancee Meghan Markle, was sent to a royal palace.

Headline: Heathrow and Stansted push for airports expansion to face down European rivals
Description: Britain's biggest airport Heathrow pressed the government to  give the go-ahead to a new runway before the summer on Thursday while rival Stansted said it also wanted to expand as London's airports position themselves for more competition after Brexit.

Headline: UK, Scotland edge towards deal on devolved powers after Brexit
Description: Scotland said on Thursday progress was being made towards a deal to ensure that all devolved powers transfer back to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland after Brexit.

Headline: Net migration to UK still fading post-Brexit vote, businesses wary
Description: Net migration of European Union citizens into Britain almost halved in the 12 months to September, according to data that alarmed business groups who say Brexit is leaving companies without enough candidates to fill jobs.

Headline: EU court adviser finds against Dyson in vacuum cleaner dispute
Description: A top European court advisor has rejected a complaint by British vacuum cleaner firm Dyson that EU energy labels underplay the efficiency of its bagless devices, in an initial opinion that could sway a court ruling next month.

Headline: British construction industry faces EU worker exodus - Hays
Description: British construction sites are starting to see a labour shortage as Eastern Europeans, who have traditionally filled the bulk of on-site jobs, have stopped taking positions after Britain's decision to leave the EU, recruiter Hays said.

Headline: EU guidelines on future British relations due in March, with or without London's input
Description: European Union leaders will issue guidelines for chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier in March on the future relationship he should negotiate with Britain, regardless of whether London clarifies what it wants, a senior EU official said on Wednesday.

Headline: MPs launch inquiry into cryptocurrencies
Description: Britain's cross-party Treasury Select Committee of lawmakers on Thursday said it is launching an inquiry into digital currencies, as well as the underlying distributed ledger technology.

Headline: DUP calls on May to set budget for Northern Ireland
Description: The head of the Democratic Unionist Party Arlene Foster said on Wednesday she had asked British Prime Minister Theresa May to take steps to set a budget for Northern Ireland during a meeting aimed at restoring the region's power-sharing government.

Headline: Sinn Fein leader says UK does not have plan for restoring Northern Ireland's government
Description: Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald said on Wednesday that the British government does not have a plan for restoring Northern Ireland's power-sharing administration after holding talks with Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: Law firm Baker McKenzie reviews response to sexual assault allegation
Description: The London branch of global law firm Baker Mckenzie said on Wednesday it had appointed an external legal team to review how it had responded to an employee's allegation that she had been sexually assaulted by one of the firm's partners.

Headline: Britain's farmers union elects first female president
Description: Britain's National Farmers Union on Wednesday elected its first female president, Minette Batters, as the industry prepares for its biggest upheaval in decades.

Headline: Brexit customs deal may still lead to Irish border checks - minister
Description: Border checks could be required on the island of Ireland even if Britain strikes a "very satisfactory" customs agreement with the European Union if the post-Brexit deal does not keep standards aligned, Ireland's agriculture minister said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain still wants Brexit implementation phase of around two years - source
Description: Britain still wants an implementation phase with the European Union of around two years, a government source said on Wednesday, saying there was no change in the government's Brexit policy.

Headline: Charity Save the Children apologises for inappropriate behaviour by ex-CEO
Description: Save The Children UK apologised on Wednesday for historic inappropriate behaviour by its former chief executive and said procedures had not been properly followed in reviewing three complaints against him during his time at the charity.

Headline: MPs release RBS business report, defying regulator
Description: British lawmakers on Tuesday published in full a confidential report detailing Royal Bank of Scotland's  mistreatment of struggling businesses during and after the financial crisis.

Headline: UK should demand cost pledge for new runway - airline bosses
Description: British lawmakers should force Heathrow to promise not to raise passenger charges before they give the airport the green light to build a new runway, airline bosses said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain urges EU to work jointly on Brexit deal, won't undercut rivals
Description: Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday Britain and the European Union could reach a deal to access each others' markets and dismissed fears Britain would use Brexit to cut regulation to attract global businesses, despite past threats to do so.

Headline: UK regulator warns lawmakers over post-Brexit market rules
Description: Britain should not force its regulators into trade-offs between market stability and helping London remain a leading global financial centre after the country leaves the European Union, a top regulator said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain set to take further budgetary control of Northern Ireland
Description: Britain must take steps towards setting a budget for Northern Ireland while it explores whether agreement can be reached to restore the province's power-sharing government, the British minister for the region said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain 'steadfastly' committed to Northern Irish peace accord - May's spokesman
Description: Britain's government is "steadfastly" committed to the Belfast agreement, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday, after several MPs questioned whether the 1998 deal that ended 30 years of conflict in Northern Ireland was still working.

Headline: Corbyn warns bankers - finance will serve Britain under Labour
Description: Britain's financial sector will be "the servant of industry not the masters of all" if the opposition Labour Party gets into power, its leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Tuesday, accusing bankers of taking the economy hostage.

Headline: As clock ticks, UK manufacturers demand clarity on Brexit
Description: With little more than a year to go before Britain leaves the European Union, many British manufacturers are stepping up their calls for Prime Minister Theresa May and her government to explain what Brexit will mean for them.

Headline: Johnson says UK can leave customs union and have no hard border in Ireland
Description: Britain should be able to leave the European Union's single market and customs union and still ensure there is no hard border in Ireland after Brexit, Foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK's pensions regulator ignored trustee requests on Carillion - MPs
Description: Britain's pensions regulator twice ignored requests from trustees of collapsed outsourcing firm Carillion  to force the company to plug its pension deficit, MPs said on Tuesday.

Headline: Haiti vows abuse review of all charities after Oxfam 'hid crimes'
Description: Oxfam hid information about sexual misconduct from authorities in Haiti, a senior official in the Caribbean nation said on Monday, and he vowed to launch a wide-reaching investigation into charities operating there.

Headline: Uber drops opposition to London language test
Description: Taxi app Uber is dropping a legal appeal against the introduction of more stringent English language tests for drivers in London after the city's transport regulator said it would water down its stringent proposals.

Headline: UK Supreme Court hears key case on gig economy worker
Description: Britain's Supreme Court was hearing on Tuesday whether a plumber hired on a self-employed basis should have received workers' rights, in a case which could affect the business models of major firms operating in the gig economy.

Headline: UK Supreme Court hears key case on gig economy worker
Description: Britain's Supreme Court was hearing on Tuesday whether a plumber hired on a self-employed basis should have received workers' rights, in a case which could affect the business models of major firms operating in the gig economy.

Headline: 'Value for money', May launches review of high university fees
Description: British universities must offer students value for money, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday, launching a review that could reduce fees and restore grants in a bid to entice younger voters who helped punish her party at an election last year.

Headline: Oxfam says Haiti director admitted using prostitutes
Description: Oxfam's country director in Haiti admitted to using prostitutes at his residence during a relief mission before resigning in 2011, according to an internal investigation into allegations of sexual misconduct released by the charity on Monday.

Headline: Britain is setting out its vision for future EU ties - May's spokesman
Description: Britain's government is setting out what it wants to achieve from its future partnership with the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday, countering criticism that ministers are still divided over Brexit.

Headline: British police arrest woman over 'move your van' note on ambulance
Description: A woman who left an angry note on an ambulance responding to an emergency call telling the paramedics to "move your van" has been arrested, British police said on Monday.

Headline: Anti-EU party UKIP votes to sack leader Bolton
Description: British eurosceptic party UKIP was thrown into turmoil again on Saturday when its members removed leader Henry Bolton after less than five months in charge following criticism of his leadership and a scandal about racist comments made by his lover.

Headline: May wins backing for EU security pact, timing unclear
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May made her case on Saturday for a new security treaty with the EU from next year, winning support from EU and U.S. officials who agreed the issue was too important to risk getting subsumed in broader Brexit negotiations.

Headline: Don't tangle up Brexit, security issues, EU tells UK
Description: Britain and the European Union should resolve trade and other issues related to Britain's exit from the bloc separately from discussions about a security pact with the U.K., European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker said on Saturday.

Headline: May says no question of a second Brexit referendum
Description: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May ruled out a second vote on the country's membership of the European Union, saying there was no going back on the result of the June 2016 vote.

Headline: May calls for security treaty with EU by end 2019
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May called on Saturday for a new security treaty with the European Union that should be up and running next year to ensure military, intelligence and counter-terrorism cooperation after London leaves the bloc.

Headline: Brexit deal should strike 'fair balance', says Germany's Merkel
Description: A Brexit deal should strike a balance to ensure Britain clearly diverges from the European Union's single market but keeps close economic ties with the bloc, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said after meeting British Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday.

Headline: Oxfam agrees not to bid for new funding from UK government
Description: Oxfam has agreed not to bid for any new funding from Britain's government until London is satisfied the charity meets sufficient ethical standards, development minister Penny Mordaunt said on Friday.

Headline: Oxfam to set up independent commission to review practices
Description: British aid organisation Oxfam said on Friday that it would create an independent commission to review the charity's practices and culture after accusations of sexual misconduct in Haiti.

Headline: UK to push EU for City of London's favoured Brexit plan
Description: Britain's government is ready to push for the kind of Brexit plan for financial services that the City of London has long favoured, but which has already run into opposition in Brussels, two government officials said on Friday.

Headline: FCA refuses to publish report on RBS
Description: Britain's financial watchdog said it would not publish the full report into Royal Bank of Scotland Group's  treatment of small businesses, but instead sent a copy of the report to lawmakers on Friday.

Headline: MPs confirm receipt of confidential RBS report from regulator
Description: MPs confirmed on Friday that they had received a confidential report into Royal Bank of Scotland's alleged mistreatment of small businesses during the financial crisis.

Headline: Uber introduces new safety features as it fights to retain London licence
Description: Taxi service Uber, battling to retain its licence to operate in the British capital, said on Friday it would introduce new safety features, including 24-hour telephone support for riders and drivers.

Headline: Britain still thinks Northern Ireland power-share deal possible
Description: Britain still believes a deal can be done to restore Northern Ireland's power-sharing government, its minister for the region said on Friday after talks to end a political stalemate broke down again this week.

Headline: Ireland, Britain to seek to re-establish Northern Ireland talks
Description: The Irish and British governments will seek a way to get talks on restoring Northern Ireland's power-sharing government back on track and neither is contemplating a return of direct rule from London, Ireland's foreign minister said on Thursday.

Headline: Sinn Fein leader says there will be more Northern Ireland talks
Description: Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald said on Thursday there would be more talks on restoring devolved government in Northern Ireland, but the timing was uncertain.

Headline: Sinn Fein leader says there will be more Northern Ireland talks
Description: Sinn Fein leader Mary Lou McDonald said on Thursday there would be more talks on restoring devolved government in Northern Ireland, but the timing was uncertain.

Headline: UK watchdog slow to stop 'vulture' advisers ripping off steelworkers - MPs
Description: Britain's markets watchdog was too slow to prevent "vulture" financial advisers from ripping off steelworkers faced with critical decisions over their 14 billion pound pension pot, lawmakers said in a report on Thursday.

Headline: UK tells charities: no more cash if you don't come clean on abuse
Description: Britain will stop funding overseas aid agencies if they fail to learn the lessons from Oxfam's sex abuse scandal, and the government will discuss possible prosecutions with law enforcement, the British development minister said on Wednesday.

Headline: Northern Ireland talks collapse, London says deal still possible
Description: Talks to restart Northern Ireland's power-sharing government broke down yet again on Wednesday, the province's main parties said, blaming each other, though Britain held out hope that a solution could still be reached.

Headline: Britain says still hope for Northern Ireland agreement after talks end
Description: Britain believes there is still a chance for Northern Ireland's main parties to reach an agreement on restoring their devolved government, the minister responsible for the province said on Wednesday after talks concluded without an agreement.

Headline: Sinn Fein says DUP collapsed Northern Ireland talks when deal was within reach
Description: Northern Ireland's Sinn Fein and the Democratic Unionist Party had reached an accommodation that put a deal on restoring devolved government within reach until the DUP collapsed the talks on Wednesday, Irish nationalists Sinn Fein said.

Headline: Johnson keeps hard Brexit stance in speech aimed at mending fences
Description: British foreign minister Boris Johnson showed little sign of softening his tough stance on Brexit in a speech on Wednesday that was intended to soothe the concerns among pro-European Union voters about the economic impact leaving the bloc.

Headline: UK might stay aligned with some EU regulations - Johnson
Description: Britain may choose to remain aligned with European Union standards for some products to help trade after Brexit, British foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Wednesday, but London  must have ultimate control over national regulatory decisions.

Headline: Man dies after vehicles collide at London's Heathrow Airport
Description: A man died after two vehicles collided on the airfield at London's Heathrow Airport, Europe's biggest hub, police said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK to aid groups - no more cash if you don't come clean on abuse
Description: Britain's government will tell aid agencies on Wednesday it will withdraw funding if they cannot show they are preventing abuse by staff following allegations of sexual misconduct involving British aid organisation Oxfam.

Headline: UK border and immigration system unprepared for Brexit - report
Description: Government delays, uncertainty and under-resourcing have left the British borders and immigration system unprepared for Brexit, according to a parliamentary report on Wednesday.

Headline: Oxfam hit by new report of sex abuse by aid workers
Description: British aid organisation Oxfam faced fresh pressure on Tuesday after a former senior member of staff said her concerns about "a culture of sexual abuse" involving aid workers had not been taken seriously by the charity's bosses.

Headline: UK judge refuses to stop legal action against WikiLeaks' Assange
Description: A British judge refused on Tuesday to halt legal proceedings against WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange for jumping bail and fleeing to the Ecuadorean embassy in London in June 2012.

Headline: WikiLeaks founder Assange says he has three months to appeal UK ruling
Description: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange said on Tuesday he had three months to appeal against a British court ruling that means he still faces arrest for breach of bail conditions if he steps out of the Ecuadorean embassy in London.

Headline: Thomas Cook flies Britons to Tunisia three years after beach attack
Description: Thomas Cook flew British tourists to Tunisia on Tuesday for the first time since an Islamist militant killed 30 Britons on one of the North African country's beaches in 2015.

Headline: Powder sent to UK parliament found to be harmless
Description: Counter-terrorism police were called to Britain's parliament on Tuesday to investigate white power sent to an office in the building, but the powder was later found to be harmless, officials said.

Headline: White powder sent to UK parliament found to be non-harmful
Description: A security incident at Britain's parliament on Tuesday was triggered by the discovery of a package containing white powder which was later found to be non-harmful, the lower house of the legislature said.

Headline: Lloyds and RBS set ethnic targets for top roles
Description: (In February 12 story corrects to "nearly double" from "more than triple", paragraph 3)

Headline: London City Airport reopens after World War Two bomb removed from Thames
Description: London's City Airport reopened and was operating as usual on Tuesday, the airport said, after a World War Two bomb which was found nearby was safely removed from the River Thames.

Headline: UK government must act urgently to put energy price cap in place by next winter - MPs
Description: Britain's government must act urgently to ensure a price cap on domestic energy prices is in place by next winter to help fix the country's broken energy market, a parliamentary committee said on Tuesday.

Headline: MPs say accountancy firms face questions over Carillion collapse
Description: KPMG and other leading accountancy firms face serious questions over their work with failed construction firm Carillion after making millions of pounds out of their relationships with the company, British lawmakers said on Tuesday.

Headline: Judge to rule on Assange's bid to escape legal action in Britain
Description: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange will hear on Tuesday whether his legal bid to halt action against him for breaching bail has been successful, in a ruling that could pave the way for him to leave the Ecuadorean embassy in London.

Headline: Irish PM 'very hopeful' for North Ireland power-sharing deal this week
Description: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said he was very hopeful that the two leading parties in Northern Ireland could agree this week to revive a power-sharing government.

Headline: British, Irish PMs hopeful of Northern Ireland breakthrough after visit
Description: The British and Irish prime ministers held talks with Northern Ireland's feuding political parties on Monday and said later they were hopeful the province's year-old political stalemate would soon end.

Headline: Deputy head of Oxfam quits as Haiti sex scandal escalates
Description: The deputy head of Oxfam resigned on Monday over what she said was the British charity's failure to adequately respond to past allegations of sexual misconduct by some of its staff in Haiti and Chad.

Headline: May sees possibility of restored government in Northern Ireland very soon
Description: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May said she asked political parties in Northern Ireland on Monday to make one last effort to restore devolved government and saw the possibility of a resolution to the stalemate very soon.

Headline: London City Airport shut after WW2 bomb found in Thames
Description: All flights to and from London's City Airport were cancelled on Monday after an unexploded World War Two bomb weighing half a tonne was found buried in silt in the River Thames.

Headline: Farage warns 'Brexit betrayal' would plunge UK into crisis
Description: If Prime Minister Theresa May allows Brexit to be watered down or halted by supporters of European Union membership, Britain will be thrust into its gravest constitutional crisis since World War Two, Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage said.

Headline: Deputy head of Oxfam resigns over sex scandal
Description: British charity Oxfam said on Monday that Deputy Chief Executive Penny Lawrence had resigned, taking responsibility for how the organisation "failed to act adequately" in response to concerns raised internally about sexual misconduct by some members of staff.

Headline: Oxfam International boss says Haiti scandal 'breaks my heart'
Description: The executive director of Oxfam International said on Sunday she was heartbroken by a sexual misconduct scandal in Haiti that prompted Britain's government to threaten to cut off aid funding to charities.

Headline: Britain will do more to stop 'horrific behaviour' by some charity staff - May's spokesman
Description: Britain's government needs to do more to make charities strengthen safeguarding procedures to ensure the "horrific behaviour" of some members of Oxfam International is not repeated, a spokesman for the prime minister said.

Headline: Cambodia deports seven foreigners held over 'pornographic' dance party
Description: Cambodia has deported seven out of a group of 10 foreigners who were charged with producing pornography in connection with a party in the tourist town of Siem Reap, a court said on Monday.

Headline: UK to phase out diesel-only trains in UK by 2040 - FT
Description: The UK government has set out plans to end the use of diesel-only trains on Britain's railways by 2040, the Financial Times reported on Monday.

Headline: Investor Soros pledges new donation to pro-EU group
Description: Billionaire financier George Soros will pledge an additional 100,000 pounds to Best for Britain, a campaign group seeking to keep Britain in the European Union, the group said in an email to Reuters.

Headline: May to set out 'Road to Brexit' in speech
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will attempt to unite her feuding cabinet and convince a sceptical European Union that Britain knows what it wants from Brexit in a series of speeches over the next few weeks.

Headline: UK threatens to cut off aid cash to charities after Oxfam sex report
Description: Britain will cut off aid funding from any organisation that does not comply with a new review into charities work overseas, aid minister Penny Mordaunt said on Sunday, describing reports of sexual exploitation in the sector as "utterly despicable".

Headline: 'Common sense will prevail' on Brexit transition deal - Penny Mordaunt
Description: British aid minister Penny Mordaunt said on Sunday she believed the government would be able to strike a transitional Brexit deal with the European Union.

Headline: EU's Barnier warns Britain post-Brexit transition 'not a given'
Description: A post-Brexit transition is "not a given", Michel Barnier warned Britain on Friday, saying London had "substantial" objections to the European Union's offer and that parts of it were not up for negotiation.

Headline: Northern Irish parties making progress in last-ditch talks
Description: Northern Ireland's two main parties reported on Friday that they had made progress in a last-ditch attempt to restore devolved government, with the Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein saying talks would conclude one way or another next week.

Headline: Britain 'surprised' EU unclear on its position over transition period
Description: Brexit minister David Davis said on Friday he was surprised to hear that the European Union's chief negotiator Michel Barnier was unclear on Britain's demands in any transition period.

Headline: EU's Barnier warns Britain post-Brexit transition 'not a given'
Description: A post-Brexit transition period is "not a given", the European Union's Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier warned Britain on Friday, saying London had raised "substantial" issues with the plan proposed by the bloc.

Headline: Japan warns on Brexit - we cannot continue in UK without profit
Description: Japan warned Prime Minister Theresa May on Thursday that its companies would have to leave Britain if trade barriers after Brexit made them unprofitable.

Headline: Britain scolds EU over plan to restrict single market access to UK during transition
Description: Brexit Secretary David Davis criticised the European Union's decision to publish a document that shows it has the power to restrict British access to the single market during a transition period after it leaves the bloc.

Headline: UK and Japanese firms agree on need for quickly agreeing post-Brexit free trade
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May and Japanese companies agreed on the need for Britain to secure the most open possible trade with the European Union after Brexit, a spokesman said.

Headline: EU doubts 2020 Brexit vision, sees longer goodbye
Description: The European Union believes Britain will not be ready to make a full break from the bloc by the end of 2020 as Brexit transition plans foresee and several senior EU figures said they are bracing for a much longer goodbye.

Headline: Lebanon to put taxi driver on trial in murder of British woman
Description: A Lebanese judge has ordered the trial of a man suspected of the December murder of Rebecca Dykes, a British woman who worked at the British embassy in Beirut, court documents showed on Thursday.

Headline: UK gave nothing firm to Japanese firms on keeping free trade after Brexit - source
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May and her ministers assured Japanese businesses of the importance of maintaining free and frictionless trade after Brexit but said nothing firm on the matter, a source familiar with the discussions told Reuters.

Headline: Brexit a chance for Britain to build on ties with Japan - May
Description: Britain will have the opportunity to build on its relationship with Japan after it leaves the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May told Japanese firms at a meeting in London on Thursday.

Headline: Japan tells UK on Brexit - If there is no profit, we cannot continue
Description: Japan's ambassador said on Thursday that no firm would be able to continue to operate in Britain if they are not profitable due to Brexit-related trade barriers.

Headline: Soros donation to halt Brexit causes storm in Britain
Description: News that billionaire financier George Soros is a backer of a campaign group seeking to keep Britain in the EU added fire to Britain's Brexit debate on Thursday, with supporters of quitting the bloc accusing opponents of plotting a "coup".

Headline: Britain will not hold a second EU vote after donation to stop Brexit: May's spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government will not hold a second referendum on Britain's membership of the European Union, her spokesman said on Thursday after the billionaire George Soros donated money to stop Brexit.

Headline: One in five experience sexual harassment, says UK parliament report
Description: Nearly one in five people working in Britain's parliament were sexually harassed or witnessed inappropriate behaviour in the past year, said a report commissioned after a series of sex scandals at Westminster.

Headline: Britons' Brexit citizenship case to be heard by EU court
Description: Britons dismayed by the loss of their European Union citizenship next year as a result of Brexit will have their complaints reviewed by the EU's top court following a ruling by a Dutch judge on Wednesday.

Headline: Japanese investors to meet May on Thursday as Brexit concerns mount
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May and Chancellor Philip Hammond will meet representatives from major Japanese businesses on Thursday as concerns about Brexit grow among some of the world's biggest foreign investors.

Headline: Britain tells business - We cannot guarantee your Brexit future
Description: Britain cannot tell businesses for certain what its relationship with the European Union will be after Brexit, business secretary Greg Clark said on Wednesday, as ministers met to discuss the government's approach.

Headline: May promises to be robust with EU over Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday she would be robust in her arguments during talks to leave the European Union, calling on parliament to disregard the "noise" surrounding the Brexit talks.

Headline: Irish finance minister expects UK to honour December Brexit deal
Description: Irish Finance Minister Paschal Donohoe said on Wednesday he still expected Britain to honour the pact it made with the European Union in December, which was designed to prevent a hard border developing between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic after Brexit.

Headline: UK to consult on employment status after gig economy concerns
Description: Britain is to launch a consultation into workplace rights in the face of public and political concern that some in the "gig economy" are being exploited.

Headline: Business Secretary surprised by size of Tesco equal pay claim
Description: British Business Secretary Greg Clark was surprised by the scale of a 4 billion pound ($5.6 billion) equal pay claim that is being brought against supermarket chain Tesco , he told Sky News on Wednesday.

Headline: Carillion's former chairman takes 'full responsibility' for collapse
Description: The chairman of Carillion  said he took "full and complete" responsibility for the construction firm's collapse, which has put thousands of jobs on the line and left creditors, suppliers and pensioners facing losses of millions of pounds.

Headline: Carillion's former chairman takes 'full responsibility' for collapse
Description: The chairman of Carillion  said he took "full and complete" responsibility for the construction firm's collapse, which has put thousands of jobs on the line and left creditors, suppliers and pensioners facing losses of millions of pounds.

Headline: May hails women in politics - be yourself, not a 'stereotype of a man'
Description: "Be yourself" and not a "stereotype of a man" is the advice British Prime Minister Theresa May would have given her younger self, she said on Tuesday, calling for more women to enter politics 100 years after they first won the vote.

Headline: U.S. libel case testimony could put sources at risk - UK spy behind Trump dossier
Description: Former British spy Christopher Steele, who compiled a "dossier" of allegations linking U.S. President Donald Trump to Russia, should not be forced to give evidence in a U.S. libel case because it could put his sources at risk and harm UK national security, his lawyer said on Monday.

Headline: UK experts urge smokers to switch to e-cigarettes for big health gains
Description: Vaping, or using e-cigarettes, poses only a fraction of the health risk of tobacco smoking and should be encouraged among smokers to reap substantial health benefits, British public health experts said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain defends healthcare system after Trump Twitter attack
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump drew a fierce reaction from angry Britons, including health minister Jeremy Hunt, on Monday after criticising Britain's publicly funded healthcare system as "going broke and not working".

Headline: Britain offers two options for future customs ties with EU - May's spokesman
Description: Two possible forms of future customs ties between Britain and the European Union are still on the table as the two sides start talks on their future relationship, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday.

Headline: Key dates in Brexit process
Description: British and EU negotiators this week hold their first formal Brexit talks since an interim deal in December unlocked discussions on their future relationship.

Headline: Autistic UK man accused of hacking FBI wins appeal against extradition to U.S.
Description: An autistic British man accused of hacking into U.S. government agencies won his appeal against extradition to the United States on Monday but was told he should be prosecuted in Britain instead.

Headline: UK will not 'surrender' over bespoke Brexit deal with EU - minister
Description: Britain will not "surrender" in its fight to win a bespoke deal with the European Union that would offer tariff-free trade as well as control over immigration, a minister said on Sunday before a crunch week for the government in Brexit negotiations.

Headline: Angus Robertson steps down as Scottish National Party deputy leader
Description: Angus Robertson said on Saturday he was standing down from his role as deputy leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP) with immediate effect, after he lost his seat in the British parliament last June.

Headline: Britain, EU schedule week of Brexit talks, eye future
Description: British and European Union negotiators will spend all next week in talks on Brexit, culminating in their first formal discussion of what their future relationship will look like after Britain has left the EU.

Headline: May says Brexit transition deal will be agreed in seven weeks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday that a Brexit transition period will be agreed with the European Union in seven weeks as she tries to ease concerns that a deal may take longer to reach.

Headline: Man who drove van into London mosque worshippers jailed for 43 years
Description: A British man found guilty of murder after he drove a van into Muslim worshippers outside a London mosque last June, leaving one dead and injuring many more, was jailed for life on Friday and told he would serve at least 43 years behind bars.

Headline: Scottish court to decide early next week on legal case to stop Brexit
Description: A Scottish judge will decide early next week whether to refer to the European Court of Justice a case questioning if Britain alone can change its mind about leaving the European Union, a spokesman for Scotland's Court of Session said on Friday.

Headline: UK's Brexit minister and EU's Barnier to meet in London on Monday
Description: Britain's Bexit minister David Davis will meet the European Union's chief negotiator Michel Barnier on Monday in London to discuss Britain's exit from the bloc, Davis wrote on Twitter on Friday.

Headline: Are you OK, Aunty May? China warms to Prime Minister May
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May landed in China earlier this week fending off questions about her future amid mounting accusations of poor leadership, boring policies, and weakness over Brexit.

Headline: Ryanair asks Irish pilots to bypass union and accept pay increase
Description: Ryanair has asked pilots in its home base in Dublin to bypass their trade union and directly accept a pay rise - even as it holds talks with unions across Europe to formalise its shock decision to recognise them.

Headline: Prime Minister says she will not sack minister over Brexit remarks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday she would not sack junior Brexit minister Steve Baker over his criticism of public servants' work on leaving the European Union.

Headline: May gets 9 billion pounds in China deals, Xi promises to build on 'golden era'
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May left China on Friday with deals worth more than 9.3 billion pounds, at the end of a three-day trade mission where President Xi Jinping pledged to upgrade their "golden era" in relations.

Headline: London Mayor Khan's office to spend 15 million pounds on homes for rough sleepers
Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan said on Thursday his office will contribute 15 million pounds to a fund aiming to provide hundreds of homes at reduced rents to rough sleepers.

Headline: 'Very difficult' for Britain to stay in any EU customs union after Brexit - trade minister
Description: British Trade Minister Liam Fox said on Friday it would be very difficult for Britain to remain in any kind of customs union with the European Union after Brexit.

Headline: Britain proposes unlimited fines for car emissions cheaters
Description: Carmakers that try to cheat vehicle emissions tests could face unlimited fines and criminal charges under proposals set out on Thursday by the British government.

Headline: Prince William, Kate get warm welcome in chilly Norway
Description: Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate flew to Norway on the final leg of a Nordic trip on Thursday, and stepped out onto a red carpet laid out over a blanket of snow.

Headline: Man radicalised by TV drama rammed van into Muslims near London mosque
Description: A man who developed a hatred of Muslims after watching a TV drama about child sex abuse involving British Pakistani men was found guilty on Thursday of ploughing a van into worshippers outside a north London mosque weeks later, killing one.

Headline: British PM May has full confidence in junior Brexit minister Baker - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has full confidence in the junior Brexit minister Steve Baker, her spokesman said on Thursday, after he was accused of maligning government officials for the second time in a week.

Headline: Royal Mail, union end ten-month dispute over pensions, shares rise
Description: Britain's Royal Mail  and the Communications Workers Union (CWU) said on Thursday they had reached an agreement to end a nearly 10-month dispute over plans to replace the firm's defined benefit pension scheme, sending its shares higher.

Headline: After meeting Capita, Britain says it is not another Carillion
Description: A British government minister on Thursday played down comparisons between outsourcing company Capita  and collapsed rival Carillion  after officials met the company's senior executives following its profit warning.

Headline: MPs to quit the Palace of Westminster for refit
Description: British lawmakers will leave the Palace of Westminster for at least six years to allow for a proposed multi-billion pound refurbishment, the first time politicians have left the historic building en masse since World War Two.

Headline: May wants EU citizens' rights to change after transition - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May wants to negotiate a deal with the European Union on changing the rights for EU citizens arriving in Britain during a transition phase after that period ends, her spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: EU cannot guarantee Britain's rights vs. third states after Brexit
Description: The European Union cannot guarantee third countries will grant Britain the same benefits it currently enjoys from trade pacts and other agreements during the 21-month transition period after it quits the bloc.

Headline: Factbox - Parlez-vous Brexit? A 'Brexicon' of the UK-EU break-up
Description: As Britain's Brexit negotiations with the European Union move into a new phase, the process has generated a new language all of its own, some of it colourful, much of it mystifying to the uninitiated.

Headline: British minister preparing to resign and denounce May - Sun newspaper
Description: A British minister is preparing to resign and publicly denounce Prime Minister Theresa May in a move that could trigger her downfall, The Sun newspaper reported on Thursday.

Headline: UK government to give Ofgem new powers to prevent energy market abuse
Description: The British government said on Thursday it would give energy market regulator Ofgem additional powers to prevent manipulation and insider trading in British wholesale energy markets.

Headline: Trade minister Fox urges mutinous MPs to lay off May
Description: British Trade Minister Liam Fox on Thursday urged lawmakers to take a different view of Prime Minister Theresa May, seeking to play up her international achievements and calm growing criticism of her leadership.

Headline: EU holding line against passporting for British banks after Brexit
Description: European Union negotiators see no room for discussion with Britain on maintaining "passport" access to EU financial markets for its banks after Brexit, but they are willing to look at free trade in the sector, diplomats said.
