Headline: UK defence spending plans may fall short by 21 billion pounds - watchdog
Description: The budget set by Britain's defence ministry to support new equipment needed in the next decade could fall short by 20.8 billion pounds ($29.5 billion), Britain's independent government spending watchdog has said.

Headline: UK fraud prosecutor combs through cases for signs of 'unexplained wealth'
Description: Britain's leading fraud prosecutor says he is combing through his case load to detect signs that criminals are using the country to hide illicit wealth, as new powers come into effect that allow authorities to seize the proceeds of "dirty money".

Headline: Anti-Jewish sentiment 'becoming more common in Britain'
Description: Anti-Jewish sentiment is generally becoming more commonplace in Britain, a charity that provides security advice to the country's Jewish communities said on Thursday.

Headline: 'Our business is truth' - China editor tells BBC to open up on women's pay
Description: The BBC is failing to live up to its own editorial mission to report the truth by denying it has a problem with gender discrimination on pay, its former China editor Carrie Gracie told the British parliament's media committee on Wednesday.

Headline: China's Li says ties with Britain to stay unchanged through Brexit
Description: China's relations with Britain will remain unchanged through Brexit, Premier Li Keqiang said on Wednesday, as British Prime Minister Theresa May kicked off a three-day visit to China, where she aims to sign nine billion pounds in deals.

Headline: China's Li says ties with Britain to stay unchanged through Brexit
Description: China's relations with Britain will remain unchanged through Brexit, Premier Li Keqiang said on Wednesday, as British Prime Minister Theresa May kicked off a three-day visit to China, where she aims to sign nine billion pounds in deals.

Headline: UK appoints first woman as chief economist to Treasury
Description: Britain's finance ministry appointed a woman for the first time as its next chief economist at a time when lawmakers want to increase the number of women appointed to senior economic policy roles.

Headline: UK government will hand over Brexit analysis after damaging leak
Description: Britain's government said on Wednesday it would hand over to parliament a leaked report that suggested Brexit would hurt the economy, trying to deflect accusations that ministers are badly prepared for leaving the European Union.

Headline: Prince William, Kate kick off Nordic visit with bandy shootout
Description: Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate, who is expecting the couple's third child in April, started a four-day visit to Sweden and Norway on Tuesday, hitting the ice in a Stockholm park to try out the sport of bandy.

Headline: UK parliament committee calls for immediate publication of leaked Brexit report
Description: Britain's government should immediately publish a leaked report about the economic costs of leaving the European Union, the lower house of parliament's Treasury Committee said on Wednesday.

Headline: I'm not a quitter, says UK's May as leadership questions stack up
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Wednesday defied critics calling for her to resign, saying she was not a quitter and that she has a long-term job to do: delivering Brexit and domestic reform.

Headline: Gibraltar says can implement Brexit selectively - report
Description: Gibraltar can choose elements of any Brexit deal Britain agrees with the European Union and avoid those it considers detrimental, the chief minister of the British territory said.

Headline: May says will give parliament 'appropriate analysis' before Brexit deal vote
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday that lawmakers would be given official analysis on any Brexit deal before they are asked to approve it, dismissing a leaked document showing the economy would be worse off under all exit scenarios.

Headline: Scientists urge UK to fortify flour with folic acid to limit birth defects
Description: Britain's failure to legislate to make food producers fortify flour with folic acid to help prevent babies being born with birth defects is based on flawed analysis and should be reversed, scientists said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britons ever more deeply divided over Brexit, research finds
Description: The social divide revealed by Britain's 2016 vote to leave the European Union is not only here to stay but deepening, according to academic research published on Wednesday.

Headline: BBC denies gender bias as women staff denounce unequal pay
Description: Women working for the BBC have complained they are paid less than men in equivalent jobs and accused managers of misleading them about their pay to hide widespread gender discrimination at Britain's public broadcaster.

Headline: RBS restructuring arm did not turn around 'vast majority' of businesses - CEO
Description: Royal Bank of Scotland's restructuring business did not turn around the "vast majority" of small businesses it worked with, Chief Executive Ross McEwan said on Tuesday in response to lawmakers' questions.

Headline: Britain will get stuck in long post-Brexit transition - EU lawmaker
Description: Britain is likely to get stuck in a long transition period in which it will pay the European Union and abide by its laws but have no say in the bloc's affairs, a European lawmaker handling Brexit said.

Headline: Campaigners say UK surveillance powers must change after court ruling
Description: Britain will need to amend its law allowing for sweeping powers to carry out mass digital surveillance after a court ruled on Tuesday that previous legislation was illegal, civil rights campaigners said.

Headline: Ryanair agrees to recognise British pilots union for first time
Description: Ryanair  said it would allow Britain's pilots' association to start negotiating on issues such as pay and holidays after the Irish budget airline recognised a trade union for the first time in its 32-year history.

Headline: May promises frank discussions with China amid dash for trade
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May promised to hold "frank discussions" with China during a crucial trade visit later this week, with several awkward diplomatic issues like North Korea and Brexit expected to be discussed.

Headline: EU offers Brexit transition, but UK must 'accept rules'
Description: The European Union offered on Monday to let Britain keep its membership benefits for 21 months after Brexit to help businesses adapt but it rejected the idea that London could block new EU laws during the transition.

Headline: UK risks higher energy prices, supply shortages from Brexit - lawmakers
Description: Britain's decision to leave the European Union could lead to higher energy prices and energy supply shortages if the exit is not managed properly, a report by an upper-house parliamentary committee said on Monday.

Headline: Britain must be bound by EU changes during transition - EU's Barnier
Description: Britain will have to accept any legal changes the European Union makes during a 21-month transition period following its exit from the bloc, the EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Monday.

Headline: Britain welcomes EU agreement on transition terms
Description: Britain welcomed the European Union's agreement on Monday on transition terms after Brexit, with Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman saying the two sides' positions were well aligned.

Headline: No tolerance for hooligans at Russia World Cup - UK police chief
Description: Soccer hooligans can expect swift police action if they try to make trouble at this summer's World Cup finals in Russia where authorities are already putting strict security procedures in place, Britain's lead officer for soccer policing said.

Headline: Britain expects countries to want to renegotiate EU trade deals - Davis
Description: Britain expects countries to want to renegotiate free trade deals made by the European Union after the country leaves the bloc in March next year, Brexit minister David Davis said on Monday.

Headline: Factbox: The EU's Brexit transition demands -- and what they mean
Description: EU ministers endorsed on Monday their instructions to Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier, setting the 27 states' demands on what Britain must do to secure a transition period after leaving the European Union on March 29, 2019.

Headline: Challenged on all fronts, May faces pressure over Brexit law
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May came under further pressure over her Brexit blueprint on Monday, with members of the upper house of parliament saying there were "fundamental flaws" in a law crucial to the departure.

Headline: EU offers UK 'status quo transition', but no votes after Brexit
Description: The European Union agreed on Monday to offer Britain a 21-month transition period after Brexit next year during which it will keep the "status quo" of EU membership without getting a vote, officials said.

Headline: KPMG's audits of Carillion to be investigated - watchdog
Description: Britain's Financial Reporting Council (FRC) has opened an investigation into KPMG's auditing of the now-collapsed Carillion  covering the years 2014 to 2017, the watchdog said on Monday.

Headline: May defends record on Brexit and other policies after criticism
Description: Theresa May's record on Brexit, the environment, housing and education stands for itself, her spokesman said on Monday, defending the prime minister against criticism over her leadership style.

Headline: Carillion attempted to 'wriggle out' of pension obligations - MPs
Description: British construction outsourcing company Carillion Plc  attempted to "wriggle out of its obligations" to pensioners for the last decade, according to Parliament's Work and Pensions Select Committee.

Headline: Business survey says Brexit biggest threat to UK financial centre
Description: Uncertainty over Britain's future trading relations with the European Union after Brexit is the most serious threat to London as the world's top financial centre, a business survey showed on Monday.

Headline: Lidington calls for unity after latest Brexit skirmishes
Description: Britain's Cabinet Office minister David Lidington urged his party to unite to heal growing rifts over how to leave the European Union that could threaten the prime minister's fragile grip on the leadership.

Headline: 'Door is open' if Britain wants to change mind on Brexit, says EU's Moscovici
Description: The "door is open" should Britain want to reverse its 2016 vote to leave the European Union, Pierre Moscovici, the European Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Union, told French media in an interview on Sunday.

Headline: Lawmakers say UK regulators could help city stay top dog in finance
Description: Britain could make it a requirement for regulators to help London remain a top global financial centre after Brexit, lawmakers said on Saturday in a report pitting parliament against the Bank of England.

Headline: UK spells out Brexit transition demands as pressure mounts on May
Description: Britain wants to benefit from European Union trade deals and have a say over EU laws passed during its transition out of the bloc, Brexit minister David Davis said on Friday, seeking to defuse tension between senior ministers over the interim deal.

Headline: EU and UK negotiators eye accelerated Brexit transition talks
Description: British Brexit negotiators are expected to launch fortnightly rounds of talks in Brussels from as early as next week with the aim of agreeing a swift deal on a transition period, EU diplomats said on Friday.

Headline: Brexit minister says no difference with PM and finance minister over EU exit
Description: Britain's Brexit minister said there was no difference between himself, finance minister Philip Hammond and Prime Minister Theresa May over their aims on Brexit.

Headline: British judge to decide next month on Assange's bid for possible freedom
Description: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, holed up in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London for over five years because he fears extradition to the United States, will learn next month if he has succeeded in having a warrant for his arrest dropped.

Headline: Russia - British defence minister has lost his grasp on reason: RIA
Description: The Russian Defence Ministry said on Friday that comments by Britain's defence minister showed he had lost his understanding of what was reasonable, RIA news agency reported.

Headline: Judge to decide on February 6 on Assange's bid to drop UK arrest warrant
Description: A British judge will rule on Feb. 6 whether she will drop an arrest warrant against Julian Assange that stems from his breach of UK bail conditions, as the WikiLeaks founder steps up efforts to leave the Ecuadorean embassy in London.

Headline: Four senior BBC male journalists agree pay cuts after inequality row
Description: Four of the highest paid male BBC journalists have agreed to pay cuts, the broadcaster said on Friday, following revelations that its top male news reporters and presenters were earning significantly more than women doing similar jobs.

Headline: UK should have almost identical market access to EU after Brexit - Hunt
Description: Britain should be able to agree an almost identical level of market access to the European Union with a free trade agreement after Brexit because the two sides start from a point of regulatory alignment, the health minister said on Friday.

Headline: May's MPs considering coup if local elections go badly - Guardian
Description: Lawmakers in British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party are considering another attempt to oust her if the local elections go badly in May, the Guardian reported.

Headline: EU could dash hopes for UK to remain in aviation safety agency
Description: Britain could be excluded from the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) after it quits the EU, raising the prospect of increased certification costs for airlines and manufacturers and dashing London's hopes of keeping its membership.

Headline: U.S. President Trump will probably visit Britain in second half of year - source
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump will most probably visit Britain in the second half of this year, but officials are discussing whether it will be a state visit and when exactly it will take place, a British senior government source said on Thursday.

Headline: Two more lawmakers mull joining legal case to show UK can stop Brexit alone
Description: Two more lawmakers in Britain's national parliament are considering joining a legal case seeking to show that Britain can, if it chooses, alone change its mind on Brexit, intensifying its potential political scope.

Headline: Rees-Mogg urges May to change tone
Description: Britain's government must start promoting the opportunities from leaving the European Union and its negotiators should stop being "cowed by the EU," the leader of an influential parliamentary group in Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party said.

Headline: May 'appalled' at reports of sexual harassment at charity gala
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said she was "frankly appalled" at reports of sexual harassment at a charity gala in London and that it shows more work needs to be done to tackle the objectification of women.

Headline: UK-U.S. relationship as strong as ever - May
Description: Britain's special relationship with the United States is as strong as it ever has been, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday, adding she would discuss Syria, North Korea and Iran in a meeting with President Donald Trump at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

Headline: Britain looking for sites to host radioactive waste
Description: Britain wants to develop a geological storage site for high level radioactive waste and launched a public consultation on Thursday to solicit communities prepared to host the facility.

Headline: Brexit campaigners gear up for fight back to stop betrayal
Description: Brexit supporters are gearing up for a fightback against "ultra-Remainers" to ensure the result of Britain's referendum on leaving the European Union is fully respected, a prominent campaigner said on Wednesday.

Headline: May seeks to harness investor power in fight against online extremism
Description: Investors should use their financial clout to force internet firms into taking more responsibility for stopping militants and paedophiles using their platforms, British Prime Minister Theresa May will say on Thursday.

Headline: May seeks to harness investor power in fight against online extremism
Description: Investors should use their financial clout to force internet firms into taking more responsibility for stopping militants and paedophiles using their platforms, British Prime Minister Theresa May will say on Thursday.

Headline: Men-only gala where hostesses were groped faces backlash in Britain
Description: The London charity behind a men-only fundraising gala where specially hired hostesses were groped and harassed, according to a Financial Times report, faced a swift backlash on Wednesday with donations being returned and politicians denouncing it.

Headline: Ex-UK PM Cameron: Brexit not going as badly as we thought
Description: Former British Prime Minister David Cameron, whose failure to persuade Britons to stay in the European Union led to his exit from office, was caught on camera saying Brexit was not going as badly as he had believed it would.

Headline: Presidents Club to shut down after FT harassment report
Description: The Presidents Club, a British charity, said on Wednesday it would shut down and hold no further fundraising events after the Financial Times reported female hostesses were groped and harassed at a men-only gala it organised last week.

Headline: Foreign minister unaware of auction lot at men-only charity gala - May's spokesman
Description: British foreign minister Boris Johnson was not aware a lunch with him was on offer at an auction during a men-only charity fundraising gala, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain is not a vassal state, says minister defending EU transition deal
Description: Brexit minister David Davis was forced to defend on Wednesday a transition deal with the European Union that leaves little changed, rejecting criticism that Britain will continue to be a "vassal state".

Headline: Bank of England's Carney deeply dismayed by charity event harassment report
Description: The Bank of England said on Wednesday it had not approved any prize for an auction at the Presidents Club charity gala held last week in London, where women working as hostesses were harassed, according to the Financial Times.

Headline: After FT report on harassment, UK education ministry board member quits
Description: David Meller, one of the organisers of a men-only charity gala in London last week where women were sexually harassed according to a report in the Financial Times, is standing down as a non-executive board member at the ministry of education.

Headline: May 'uncomfortable' reading reports of alleged sexual harassment at charity gala
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May was uncomfortable reading reports of alleged sexual harassment at a charity gala in London, her spokesman said on Wednesday.

Headline: May says government will cut stakes on betting terminals
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday her government will cut the stakes on fixed odds betting terminals but had to wait for the conclusion of a consultation.

Headline: Thatcher statue proposal rejected by Westminster planners
Description: A second attempt to erect a statue of Britain's former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher outside parliament, just six months after a first proposal was thrown out over vandalism fears, has failed after councillors rejected a revised plan.

Headline: MPs to question Carillion directors over collapse
Description: British lawmakers will question the directors of Carillion to find out how the major construction and outsourcing company went bust under a mountain of debt, leaving hundreds of millions of pounds of unfinished public contracts.

Headline: Britain will not be 'vassal state' to the EU during transition - minister
Description: Britain will not be "vassal state" to the European Union during a transition period after Brexit, minister David Davis said on Wednesday, responding to criticism about plans to remain under the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice.

Headline: Brexit minister expects agreement on transition deal by end of March
Description: Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday that he expects Britain and the European Union will agree to a transition deal on exiting the bloc by the end of March.

Headline: Don't worry, you won't be deported - UK minister tells EU citizens
Description: Brexit minister David Davis told EU citizens living in Britain on Wednesday not to worry about the country's departure from the European Union, saying they were not about to be deported.

Headline: UK will be subject to ECJ rulings under Brexit transition deal - minister
Description: Britain will remain subject to the rulings of the European Court of Justice during a transitional period, Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday.

Headline: Average UK motor insurance premiums paid in 2017 highest since 2012 - ABI
Description: The average premium paid for motor insurance in Britain jumped 9 percent in 2017 to the highest level since 2012, the Association of British Insurers (ABI) said on Wednesday.

Headline: RBS to leave its London headquarters in cost-cutting move
Description: Britain's Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc will leave its current London headquarters by the end of 2019 in a cost-cutting move, it said on Tuesday.

Headline: Private firm pushes ahead with UK-France power cable despite Brexit
Description: Private investment firm Aquind is pushing ahead with plans to build a 1.4 billion euro (1.22 billion pounds) high-voltage undersea power cable between Britain and France despite uncertainties created by Brexit, its managing director said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain to set up unit to tackle 'fake news' - May's spokesman
Description: Britain will set up a new unit to beef up its efforts to counter so-called "fake news" and to try to deter disinformation campaigns by other states, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain plans a departmental spending review next year
Description: Britain's government plans to carry out a departmental spending review next year, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: May slaps down foreign minister over health funds
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May slapped down her foreign minister on Tuesday after he demanded more funding for Britain's public health service, telling him any discussion of money saved from Brexit should be kept private.

Headline: UK public finances boosted by EU credit, surging VAT receipts
Description: Britain's budget deficit fell by much more than expected last month, helped by an unusually large credit from the European Union and the strongest value-added tax receipts on record.

Headline: Brexit implementation period has not been agreed with EU - PM May's spokesman
Description: Britain is still working to agree a transitional agreement on exiting the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday, after a report by The Independent that a deal had been reached.

Headline: Northern Ireland militant splinter group says it will end violent campaign
Description: A small Northern Irish nationalist paramilitary group that has carried out bombings and shootings over the past decade called an end on Tuesday to its armed campaign against British rule of the province.

Headline: May slaps down foreign minister over health demands
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May slapped down her foreign minister on Tuesday for demanding extra funding for Britain's public health service, saying discussions between her cabinet should be kept private.

Headline: U.S. needs to pay attention to relationship with Britain, Tillerson says
Description: The United States needs to pay attention to its treasured relationship with Britain, U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said on Monday just days after Donald Trump cancelled a trip to London citing anger at the sale of an embassy.

Headline: UKIP in chaos over racist messages
Description: The United Kingdom Independence Party, which transformed British politics by securing a referendum on EU membership, was close to meltdown on Monday over the fate of its leader, whose lover made racist comments about Prince Harry’s fiancee Meghan Markle.

Headline: UKIP leader says will not resign
Description: The leader of the United Kingdom Independence Party said on Monday that he would not resign after his lover made racist comments about Prince Harry’s fiancee Meghan Markle.

Headline: Driver who targeted London mosque was angered by Islamist attacks, TV show-prosecutor
Description: A man who drove a van into Muslim worshippers outside a mosque last June was motivated by deadly Islamist attacks in Britain and an obsession with a television account of Muslim men who targeted white girls, a London court heard on Monday.

Headline: Rex Tillerson visits new U.S. embassy in London that Trump criticised
Description: Secretary of State Rex Tillerson visited the new $1 billion (£719 million) U.S. embassy in London on Monday, just days after his boss Donald Trump criticised the move to new diplomatic premises as part of a bad deal agreed by the administration of Barack Obama.

Headline: Princess Eugenie to marry long-term boyfriend
Description: Britain's Princess Eugenie has got engaged to her long-term boyfriend Jack Brooksbank, Buckingham Palace said on Monday, with the pair set to marry later this year.

Headline: Keeping up with the Russians - head of UK army wants more money
Description: Britain must ensure its armed forces can keep up with adversaries like Russia, which already has military capabilities the United Kingdom would struggle to match, according to the head of the British army.

Headline: UK economy will cope with Brexit hit as global economy grows - O'Neill
Description: Britain's economy is likely to do better in 2018 than many forecasts suggest and the benefits of global growth in the coming years will "easily dwarf" any hit from leaving the European Union, former Goldman Sachs economist Jim O'Neill said.

Headline: May says will stop companies abusing pension schemes
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said she would clamp down on bosses who try to "line their own pockets" while not protecting workers' pensions, after the collapse of outsourcer Carillion with a 900-million-pound hole in its pension scheme.

Headline: UK government questions Scottish bid to show Britain can alone revoke Brexit
Description: The British government believes the question of whether it alone can stop Brexit is irrelevant, since it does not intend to change its mind about leaving the European Union, according to its response to a legal challenge by Scottish lawmakers opposed to Brexit.

Headline: Britain to limit gambling terminal stakes to two pounds - Sunday Times
Description: The stake on gambling machines in British betting shops is set to be cut to two pounds to tackle the risks that the terminals can pose to problem gamblers, the Sunday Times reported, citing an ally of new culture secretary Matt Hancock.

Headline: Britain able to have bespoke deal with EU - Macron
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron said on Saturday Britain would be able to have a bespoke deal with the European Union after Brexit, one of Prime Minister Theresa May's objectives.

Headline: McDonald to succeed Adams as Sinn Fein leader in striking shift
Description: Mary Lou McDonald will succeed Gerry Adams as Sinn Fein leader, the party said on Saturday, completing a generational shift for the Irish nationalist party as it bids to enter government on both sides of the Irish border.

Headline: Road to ruin? Carillion collapse puts spotlight on UK outsourcing model
Description: In Balmedie, a village on the northeast coast of Scotland, an unfinished 12 km stretch of dual carriageway is a stark illustration of why British construction company Carillion went bust this week.

Headline: Road to ruin? Carillion collapse puts spotlight on UK outsourcing model
Description: In Balmedie, a village on the northeast coast of Scotland, an unfinished 12 km stretch of dual carriageway is a stark illustration of why British construction company Carillion went bust this week.

Headline: Britain's banks provide support for firms hit by Carillion collapse
Description: Britain's biggest banks have announced a range of measures to support firms and contractors hit by the collapse of construction outsourcing company Carillion.

Headline: London Mayor attacks decision not to challenge release of black-cab rapist
Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan joined a chorus of protest on Friday against a government decision not to block the release from jail of a former black-cab driver suspected of assaulting dozens, possibly hundreds of women.

Headline: Ineos’ plan to build British 4X4s started as a pub chat
Description: What started as a discussion in a pub could end up creating as many as 1,500 jobs in Britain by late 2020 as privately-owned Ineos moves ahead with plans to build a new 4x4 vehicle, one of its directors told Reuters.

Headline: France says no for now to Johnson's idea of giant Channel bridge
Description: France on Friday politely rejected Boris Johnson's idea of building a giant bridge across the English Channel after Brexit, saying that, while far-fetched ideas were worth considering, there were plenty of major European projects to finish first.

Headline: Teenager pleads not guilty to carrying out London bomb attack on train
Description: A teenager accused of planting an improvised bomb on a London commuter train which injured 30 people pleaded not guilty on Friday to charges of attempted murder and causing an explosion at Parsons Green station in southwest London last September.

Headline: May says honoured by French loan of Bayeux Tapestry
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday she was honoured that France will lend Britain the Bayeux Tapestry, an 11th century treasure that tells the story of William the Conqueror's invasion of England in 1066.

Headline: 'We must question our views': Irish opposition leader backs abortion reform
Description: The leader of Ireland's main opposition party said on Thursday that he had changed his views on Ireland's strict abortion laws and would support their removal, in a potentially significant intervention ahead of a referendum in the coming months.

Headline: British lawmaker points to Santander UK chief in scandal over RBS restructuring unit
Description: A British lawmaker on Thursday put the boss of Santander UK at the centre of a growing political storm over the Royal Bank of Scotland's (RBS) treatment of small businesses during and after the financial crisis.

Headline: Red-dragon flags greet Prince Harry and fiancee Meghan Markle in Wales
Description: Britain's Prince Harry and his American fiancee Meghan Markle visited Wales on Thursday on their third official joint appearance since announcing their engagement last November.

Headline: Lloyds Banking Group offers 50 million pounds for customers hit by Carillion collapse
Description: Lloyds Banking Group on Thursday announced 50 million pounds in emergency funding for small businesses hit by the demise of construction firm Carillion.

Headline: UK taxpayers paying billions more for privately funded projects – watchdog
Description: British taxpayers are spending billions of pounds more on hospitals and schools funded by private companies, a parliamentary watchdog said on Thursday, amid fresh concerns about whether companies should be given the work.

Headline: UK RICS house price gauge unexpectedly picks up from four-year low
Description: A key gauge of British house prices unexpectedly picked up last month from its lowest level in more than four years, helped by a less negative tone in London and neighbouring areas.

Headline: MPs back Brexit legislation, stiffer tests yet to come
Description: British MPs voted in favour of the government's legislative blueprint for Brexit on Wednesday, marking a victory for Prime Minister Theresa May over political opponents who want a softer approach to leaving the European Union.

Headline: Northern Ireland to launch new bid to restore devolved government
Description: The British and Irish governments are to launch a new round of talks between Northern Ireland's main parties next week in a bid to re-establish devolved government and avoid a return to direct rule of the region from London for the first time in a decade.

Headline: House of Commons approves bill to sever EU ties
Description: Britain's lower house of parliament approved a bill on Thursday that will sever ties with the European Union, handing the legislation over to the upper chamber where it may face a more difficult journey.

Headline: May pressured to safeguard jobs after Carillion's collapse
Description: Britain needs to allow more time for firms to take on 8,500 workers whose jobs are threatened by the demise of Carillion, unions said on Wednesday, as Prime Minister Theresa May faced criticism for the way the government outsources public services.

Headline: Farage backs off second Brexit referendum talk as EU says UK still welcome
Description: Leading British anti-EU campaigner Nigel Farage rowed back on Wednesday from remarks favouring a second referendum on Brexit, a week after he unleashed a new round of debate and a chorus of invitations from European politicians for Britain to reconsider.

Headline: EDF sees UK Hinkley C nuclear plant online by end of 2025
Description: EDF Energy said on Wednesday its Hinkley C nuclear power station in Somerset, southwest England, will come online by the end of 2025 and give the developer the experience to lower the costs of subsequent nuclear plants planned in the country.

Headline: Britain bans entry to prominent U.S. Holocaust denier
Description: Britain has banned a prominent American Holocaust denier from entering the United Kingdom, according to a copy of correspondence from the interior ministry.

Headline: Second vote not undemocratic, Irish PM says on Brexit
Description: It would not be "anti-democratic" for Britons to reverse their Brexit vote in a second referendum, Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said at the European Parliament on Wednesday, but he denied working to promote one.

Headline: Over 90 percent of private Carillion customers will pay to keep employees - UK insolvency service
Description: Over 90 percent of Carillion's private sector service customers have said they will provide funding to allow the company's official receiver to retain employees on those contracts, Britain's Insolvency Service said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK banks take steps to ease fallout from Carillion collapse
Description: Britain's banks are offering overdraft extensions and other emergency measures to help firms hit by the collapse of construction company Carillion, the banking sector's trade body said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK tells banks to remember small companies not to blame for Carillion's collapse
Description: Britain's business minister Greg Clark told banks on Wednesday that it is important they remember small businesses were not to blame for construction company Carillion's collapse, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said.

Headline: Keep going to work, May tells public service employees at Carillion
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May urged workers employed by failed services and construction company Carillion for public service contracts to keep going to work confident that they will be paid.

Headline: Vandal-proof statue of Thatcher outside parliament could be rejected again
Description: A second attempt to erect a statue of Britain's former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher outside parliament, just six months after a first proposal was thrown out over vandalism fears, looks set to fail after officials recommended it be rejected.

Headline: UK energy price cap laws should be passed by summer - minister
Description: Britain hopes to pass laws to allow the capping of the most common form of gas and electricity tariffs for millions of households by the summer, a junior minister in the business department told a parliamentary committee on Wednesday.

Headline: After 950 years, France to lend Bayeux Tapestry to Britain
Description: France will lend Britain the Bayeux Tapestry, an 11th century treasure that tells the tale of how William the Conqueror came to invade England in 1066, an official at the presidential Elysee Palace in Paris said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain must urgently bridge policy gaps to meet emissions target – advisers
Description: Britain must urgently lay out further policies to meet its domestic emissions targets, the government's climate advisers said on Wednesday.

Headline: Heathrow begins public consultation on airport expansion, motorway move
Description: Heathrow Airport launched a 10-week public consultation on its proposed expansion on Wednesday, saying it would ask locals for their views on issues such as the rerouting of a major motorway near the airport and the length of a new, third runway.

Headline: Heathrow begins public consultation on airport expansion, motorway move
Description: Heathrow Airport launched a 10-week public consultation on its proposed expansion on Wednesday, saying it would ask locals for their views on issues such as the rerouting of a major motorway near the airport and the length of a new, third runway.

Headline: Northern Ireland's Adams attempts to overturn jailbreak conviction
Description: Gerry Adams, leader of Ireland's largest nationalist party, Sinn Fein, on Tuesday launched a bid to overturn two 1975 convictions for attempting to escape from prison, arguing that his initial detention was illegal.

Headline: UK drugs regulator plays down Brexit disruption threat
Description: Britain's drugs regulator said on Tuesday it would work to minimise disruption caused by the country leaving the European Union as it tried to allay some of the worst fears of pharmaceutical companies.

Headline: UK's saving after Brexit even bigger than 350 million pounds, Johnson says
Description: Britain will have even more money to spend on public services than the disputed 350 million pounds a week Brexiteers promised after the country leaves the European Union, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said in an interview published on Tuesday.

Headline: Uber to introduce mandatory rest breaks for UK drivers
Description: Uber said on Tuesday its British drivers will have to take a six-hour break after they have accepted and made trips with passengers totalling 10 hours as the taxi app responds to criticism over excessive working hours.

Headline: May's spokesman - Britain will be leaving the EU
Description: Britain will be leaving the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday after European Council president Donald Tusk suggested the country would be welcome to change its mind and stay in the bloc.

Headline: UK government questioned over Carillion contracts after profit warnings
Description: Britain's government is under pressure from opposition parties to explain why ministers awarded construction company Carillion 1.3 billion pounds of new contracts after it was known to be in financial difficulty.

Headline: Leader of UKIP splits with girlfriend after 'appalling' Markle comments
Description: The leader of Britain's anti-European Union UKIP Party said he had split with his new girlfriend after a newspaper published derogatory comments she made about Prince Harry's fiancee Meghan Markle and black people.

Headline: Branson orders UK's Virgin Trains to re-stock Daily Mail after censorship spat
Description: Billionaire Virgin founder Richard Branson has told Virgin Trains to reintroduce the Daily Mail newspaper on their services after criticism of the British rail firm's decision to halt sales, saying the move had been made without his knowledge.

Headline: Carillion collapses after banks pull the plug
Description: Carillion collapsed on Monday when its banks pulled the plug, triggering Britain's biggest corporate failure in a decade and forcing the government to step in to guarantee public services from school meals to road works.

Headline: Brexit vote may be reversed, says British campaigner Farage
Description: Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage said on Sunday he was increasingly concerned that a vote for Britain to leave the European Union could be overturned by a powerful group of the bloc's supporters.

Headline: British government will hold emergency meeting on Carillion, says minister
Description: The British government will hold a meeting of its COBRA emergency response committee on Monday to discuss Carillion's collapse, defence minister Gavin Williamson said.

Headline: UK parliamentary committee launches inquiry after Carillion collapse
Description: A British parliamentary committee said on Monday it would hold an inquiry into government sourcing practices following the collapse of contractor Carillion.

Headline: London attacker took steroids before deadly rampage, inquest told
Description: The man who mowed down pedestrians on London's Westminster Bridge before killing a police officer outside Britain's parliament last year had taken steroids beforehand, a London court heard on Monday.

Headline: Johnson fears 'waste of time' watered-down Brexit - report
Description: Foreign minister Boris Johnson has told friends he is worried that Britain will accept a Brexit deal that leaves it subordinate to Brussels, making the 2016 EU referendum a "total waste of time", the Sun newspaper reported on Monday.

Headline: Factbox - Ripples from Carillion's collapse hit contractor's partners
Description: Britain's Carillion collapsed on Monday after its banks lost faith in the construction and services company, forcing the government to step in to guarantee major public works contracts.

Headline: May wants Brexit deal that works for whole of UK - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has been clear that she wants to negotiate an exit from the European Union works for the whole of the United Kingdom, her spokesman said on Monday after the Scottish government set out its impact assessment for Brexit.

Headline: Britain has provided additional help to France on border security - PM May's spokesman
Description: Britain has provided additional security help to France, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday when asked about the possibility of having to pay more for border security around the northern French port of Calais.

Headline: Carillion collapse regrettable, but government cannot bail it out - PM May's spokesman
Description: The British government cannot be expected to bail out construction and services firm Carillion, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday, after the firm's collapse.

Headline: UK to ensure services provided by Carillion will continue - minister
Description: Britain's government will ensure that services provided by failed construction and services group Carillion will continue and the company's joint-venture partners will be involved, minister David Lidington said on Monday.

Headline: Britain's Labour demands answers from government on Carillion
Description: Britain's main opposition party called on the government on Monday to explain why it awarded Carillion  contracts worth nearly 2 billion pounds ($2.75 billion) after the company had posted profit warnings.

Headline: Carillion in final appeal to lenders after UK refuses rescue - Sky News
Description: Carillion's directors were making a final rescue appeal to its lending banks on Sunday night after the government refused to rescue the struggling construction and services company, Sky News reported.

Headline: Labour does not support second EU referendum - Corbyn
Description: Britain's main opposition Labour Party is not supporting or calling for a second referendum on EU membership, its leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Sunday.

Headline: Scottish leader says will look at independence vote by end of year
Description: Scottish leader Nicola Sturgeon said on Sunday she would be able to make a judgment on whether to hold a second referendum on Scottish independence by the end of this year after a shape of a deal between Britain and the European Union becomes clear.

Headline: Spanish, Dutch deny joint plan to seek softer Brexit
Description: The Netherlands and Spain have not reached an agreement about how Britain should leave the European Union, a Dutch Finance Ministry official said on Friday, denying an earlier report of a deal that drove sterling sharply higher.

Headline: Explainer - Was the sale of the U.S. embassy in London a 'bad deal' done for peanuts?
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump cancelled a trip to London scheduled for next month to open a new embassy, blaming Barack Obama for selling off the old one for "peanuts" in a bad deal.

Headline: Trump cancels Britain trip, blames Obama for 'peanuts' London embassy deal
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump cancelled a trip to London scheduled for next month to open a new embassy, saying he did not want to endorse what he understood was an Obama-era decision to move out of the old one.

Headline: Factbox - Strains on the U.S.-UK 'special relationship'
Description: Donald Trump has cancelled a trip to Britain next month in another sign of strained relations with one of the closest U.S. allies since he became president.

Headline: President Trump is welcome in London - May's spokesman
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump is welcome in London and has accepted an invitation to visit, a spokesman for British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday, after Trump cancelled a trip to Britain scheduled for next month to open a new embassy.

Headline: May tells bankers they are a priority for Brexit amid job warnings
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told bankers from firms such as Goldman Sachs on Thursday they were a priority for her in the Brexit talks, just as new warnings emerged of job losses in the London financial sector unless there is a trade deal.

Headline: Horrible carriage, unwieldy crowns: Queen Elizabeth's candid views of coronation and royal jewels
Description: Speaking for the first time about her coronation 65 years ago, Britain's Queen Elizabeth has revealed how uncomfortable riding in her golden carriage to the ceremony was and how wearing the Imperial State Crown risked "breaking your neck".

Headline: Ecuador gives Assange citizenship, seeks end to embassy stay
Description: Ecuador has given citizenship to Julian Assange as part of its  efforts to allow the WikiLeaks founder to leave the country’s London embassy where he has been holed up for more than five years.

Headline: Brexiteers back second EU referendum to stop 'soft' departure from bloc
Description: Two of Britain's most prominent Brexit campaigners endorsed a second referendum on leaving the European Union on Thursday as the best way to stop EU supporters from trying to water down, or even halt, the country's departure from the bloc.

Headline: Brexit caused 37 percent fall in new London financial jobs in December - report
Description: Britain's forthcoming exit from the European Union was the main reason for a 37 percent decline in new jobs available in London's financial sector last month, according to a report from recruiting firm Morgan McKinley released on Thursday.

Headline: UK will not pay EU for access to financial services market - May's spokesman
Description: Britain will not pay the European Union for access to its financial services market after Brexit, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: May to meet financiers as London mayor warns of 'lost decade' due to Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May meets financiers from firms including Goldman Sachs on Thursday to discuss the impact of Brexit on Europe's financial capital, as London's mayor said Britain could face a "lost decade" of low growth and investment.

Headline: May pledges to cut all avoidable plastic waste by 2042
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday she would eradicate avoidable plastic waste by 2042, part of a "national plan of action" she hopes will show that her government is about more than just Brexit.

Headline: Second referendum on Brexit is only option now, says Brexit campaigner Arron Banks
Description: Britain should hold a second referendum to confirm support for a clean break with the European Union, Arron Banks, the co-founder of influential pro-Brexit campaign group Leave.EU, said on Thursday.

Headline: Bank of England to ease burden of EU insurance rules
Description: The Bank of England has proposed easing the burden of European Union capital rules for insurers, but the industry urged the regulator to go further and meet calls from British lawmakers for more radical change.

Headline: PM May says working for best Brexit deal for the British people
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday she is working to secure the best trade deal with the European Union after London's mayor warned that Britain could lose almost 500,000 jobs if it fails to agree a deal.

Headline: Britain will not hold a second EU referendum - May's spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will not hold a second referendum on Britain's membership of the European Union, her spokesman said on Thursday in response to growing calls for a new vote on Brexit.

Headline: UK lenders plan to tighten grip on consumer loans - BoE
Description: British lenders are planning to further tighten their grip on consumer lending which has already been slowing in recent months, a Bank of England survey showed on Thursday.

Headline: 'No deal' Brexit could cost UK about 500,000 jobs, London mayor says
Description: Britain could lose almost 500,000 jobs and 50 billion pounds investment over the next 12 years if it fails to agree a trade deal with the European Union, according to a report commissioned by London Mayor Sadiq Khan.

Headline: Labour's McDonnell to attend Davos summit
Description: The British opposition Labour Party's finance chief John McDonnell will attend the World Economic Forum in Davos this month to set out his vision for an alternative to the current model of capitalism, his spokesman said on Wednesday.

Headline: Italian police take computer of Cambridge tutor in Egypt murder case
Description: Italian magistrates investigating the murder of a graduate student in Cairo two years ago have seized the computer and cell phone of his Cambridge University tutor, the prosecutors' office in Rome said on Wednesday.

Headline: Cutting out Brussels middleman, UK ministers make Brexit pitch to Germany
Description: Facing a tough line from Brussels on what economic ties between Britain and the European Union will look like after Brexit, a pair of senior British ministers made a direct pitch to Germany to cut Britain a good deal.

Headline: Scotland prepares contingency Brexit laws in stand-off with London government
Description: The Scottish government said on Wednesday it was preparing legislation that would ensure legal continuity in Scotland after Brexit as a fallback option in case it fails to reach agreement with Prime Minister Theresa May on her exit plan.

Headline: Man suspected of funnelling Libyan cash to Sarkozy granted bail by UK court
Description: A French businessman suspected by investigators of funnelling money from former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi to finance Nicolas Sarkozy's successful 2007 presidential campaign was granted bail when he appeared at a London court on Wednesday.

Headline: May to meet finance bosses on Brexit
Description: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May will meet executives from major finance companies on Thursday to give them a clearer idea of what Britain's European Union exit will mean for them.

Headline: EU unity paramount to Germany in Brexit talks, insists Berlin
Description: Germany will remain focused on preserving a united stance between the European Union's 27 members in talks with London on Brexit, a government spokesman said on Wednesday after British ministers made a direct appeal to Berlin to cut it a good deal.

Headline: Britons gloomier about Brexit but no change of heart - pollster Curtice
Description: British pessimism on the economic consequences of leaving the European Union is growing, but Britons have not broadly changed their minds about how they voted, Britain's leading pollster John Curtice said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK plans three-month window after Brexit to start court cases under EU law
Description: Britain said on Tuesday it wanted to give businesses and citizens a three-month window after leaving the European Union in which they can start court cases about a breach of EU legal principles.

Headline: UK government appoints former management consultant as City minister
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has appointed a former management consultant John Glen as the new City minister to oversee a financial services sector facing upheaval as Britain prepares to leave the European Union.

Headline: UK pledges to amend EU withdrawal bill, soothe Scottish devolution worries
Description: Britain's government will amend the European Union withdrawal bill in time for it to win backing from Scotland's pro-independence devolved administration, Britain's Scotland minister said on Tuesday.

Headline: Harry and fiancee Meghan get wedding music tips on radio station visit
Description: Britain's Prince Harry and his U.S. fiancee Meghan Markle were given some street-level tips for their wedding music as they visited a pioneering radio station in south London on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain's counter-terrorism police chief Rowley to retire
Description: Britain's top counter-terrorism police officer Mark Rowley will retire in March, the Metropolitan Police Service said on Tuesday, after a 31-year career in which he led efforts to curb a rise in militant attacks.

Headline: UK engaging with Peugeot's Vauxhall over job cuts at car plant
Description: The government is in contact with Peugeot's  British brand Vauxhall over job cuts at its north of England Ellesmere Port plant after the French automaker announced a further 250 roles will go, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: PM May appoints influential eurosceptic to junior ministerial role
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May appointed influential eurosceptic lawmaker Suella Fernandes as a junior minister in the department in charge of leaving the European Union on Tuesday, bolstering the pro-Brexit ranks within her government.

Headline: After China editor quits, BBC asked to explain itself over women's pay
Description: The BBC faced mounting pressure on Tuesday over why it pays some women less than men in equivalent jobs, with lawmakers as well as Britain's anti-discrimination watchdog asking questions about the resignation of China Editor Carrie Gracie.

Headline: Boris says would not be sensible to rescind Trump visit invitation
Description: Britain's visit invitation to U.S. President Donald Trump should not be rescinded, British foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Tuesday, stressing that the United States is an important ally.

Headline: British Brexit minister complains about EU's planning for no-deal
Description: Brexit minister David Davis has complained in a letter to the prime minister that Brussels is damaging British interests by talking up the threat to companies if the UK leaves the European Union without a deal.

Headline: 'How to Lose Friends' author quits watchdog job, embarrasses PM May
Description: The author of the satirical memoir "How to Lose Friends and Alienate People" became the latest figure to embarrass British Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday, resigning from a watchdog for British universities over a history of misogynist tweets.

Headline: PM May believes she has right government team after reshuffle - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May believes she has the right government team to tackle the challenges Britain faces, her spokesman said on Tuesday, dismissing criticism that a reshuffle of her top team was shambolic.

Headline: Dutch PM Rutte: Britain must clarify post-Brexit relationship
Description: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte on Tuesday called on Britain to clarify its future relationship with key trading partners after it leaves the European Union.

Headline: Factbox - Who's in, who's out? May reshuffles her ministerial team
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May made changes to her ministerial team on Monday, hoping to re-energise a party damaged by divisions over Brexit and still smarting from an ill-judged election last year.

Headline: Wanting a new start, May changes leadership team
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May named an ally to run the ruling Conservatives and promoted younger ministers on Monday to try to give her divided party and government a new start after a year marred by an ill-judged election, rows over Brexit and scandals.

Headline: May names new Northern Ireland minister after Brokenshire resigns
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May appointed a new Northern Ireland minister on Monday after James Brokenshire resigned due to ill health, posing a new challenge in efforts to resolve a political crisis in the British province.

Headline: Karen Bradley appointed as Northern Ireland minister - PM May's office
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May appointed Karen Bradley as the government's Northern Ireland minister on Monday, moving her from her position as culture minister.

Headline: Peugeot to cut UK's Vauxhall car plant workforce by a third
Description: Peugeot-maker PSA will cut a further 250 jobs at its Vauxhall car plant in the north of England, reducing the workforce by a third as part of efforts to make the plant more efficient by reducing its output to one shift.

Headline: PM May's reshuffle aimed at helping reforms, Brexit - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's reshuffle of her top ministers is aimed at strengthening her reform agenda and to press on with Britain's departure from the European Union, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Sinn Fein suspends MP over 'indefensible' tweet on massacre anniversary
Description: Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein on Monday suspended one of its lawmakers over an "indefensible" tweet on the anniversary of the day 10 Protestant textile workers were shot dead in 1976, which police blamed on the IRA.

Headline: Paid less than male peers, BBC China editor quits and speaks out
Description: The BBC's China Editor Carrie Gracie has quit her post in Beijing to fight for her right to pay equality with male peers, posting an attack on what she called the "secretive and illegal BBC pay culture".

Headline: May appoints David Lidington as cabinet office minister - May's office
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May appointed justice minister David Lidington to the post of cabinet office minister on Monday, filling the job responsible for the administration of the government.

Headline: UK PM May appoints Brandon Lewis as chairman of Conservative Party - Sun
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May named immigration minister Brandon Lewis as the new chairman of her Conservative Party on Monday, a reporter from the Sun newspaper said on Twitter.

Headline: Conservative Party deletes tweet congratulating new chairman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party deleted a tweet announcing a new chairman on Monday, adding unexpected drama to what was expected to be a routine reshuffle of her top ministers.

Headline: Britain's May clear she wants Brexit deal that works for UK - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has been clear she wants to negotiate a Brexit deal that works for the whole of the United Kingdom and does not believe it is time for a second referendum on independence for Scotland, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: May to change government ministers soon, senior figures reported to be safe
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would announce changes to her ministerial team soon, with media reports saying her foreign, finance, interior and Brexit ministers would keep their jobs in a reshuffle starting on Monday.

Headline: May says ministerial reshuffle coming soon - BBC
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would be making changes to her team of ministers soon following the forced resignation of her deputy Damian Green in December, but declined to give further details.

Headline: Queen Elizabeth's granddaughter Zara expecting second baby
Description: Zara Tindall, the granddaughter of Britain's Queen Elizabeth, is pregnant with her second child, her spokeswoman said on Friday.

Headline: Britain outlines plans for 2025 coal-power phase out
Description: Britain will set an emission limit on coal-fired power generators from Oct. 1, 2025, forcing them to close unless they are fitted with carbon capture technology, the government said on Friday.

Headline: Farm spending to focus on environment after Brexit - Michael Gove
Description: Britain will only pay public funds to farmers who provide public benefits such as wildlife habitats or improved soil quality under a post-Brexit shake-up in agricultural policies announced on Thursday.

Headline: Council leader calls for beggars to be removed before UK royal wedding
Description: Beggars need to be cleared by police from the streets of Windsor before the wedding of Prince Harry to girlfriend Meghan Markle because their "detritus" is presenting the picturesque English town in a poor light, the local council leader has said.

Headline: May apologises as overwhelmed hospitals cancel non-emergency operations
Description: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May apologised on Thursday to tens of thousands of patients whose operations were cancelled to free up staff and beds to deal with emergency patients.

Headline: Labour Party grassroots support second Brexit vote - survey
Description: Eight out of 10 grassroots members of Britain's opposition Labour Party want a referendum on the terms of the country's exit from the European Union, according to a survey published on Thursday.

Headline: British police arrest six suspected members of far-right group
Description: British police said six people had been arrested by counter-terrorism officers on Wednesday on suspicion of being members of the banned far-right group National Action.

Headline: UK may use taxes to get tech giants to do more to fight extremism - minister
Description: Britain may impose new taxes on tech giants like Google and Facebook unless they do more to combat online extremism by taking down material aimed at radicalising people or helping them to prepare attacks, the country's security minister said.

Headline: Police charges two with terror offences
Description: British counter terrorism police said on Thursday they had charged two men with terrorism offences following an investigation.

Headline: British woman sentenced in Egypt to three years in jail for smuggling painkillers
Description: An Egyptian court sentenced a British woman to three years in prison on Tuesday for smuggling around 300 painkiller tablets into the country, in a ruling her defence team said she would appeal to have overturned or commuted.

Headline: Legal action to see whether UK could unilaterally stop Brexit gets go-ahead
Description: A group of anti-Brexit Scottish members of parliament has been given the go-ahead to pursue legal action to establish whether the United Kingdom can unilaterally stop the process of leaving the EU, a Scottish court said on Friday.

Headline: Taking back control - UK's classic blue-and-gold passport to return
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday hailed the return of Britain's classic blue passport as a benefit of leaving the EU, pleasing Brexit campaigners for whom it is a symbol of national sovereignty but attracting derision from many remainers.

Headline: Taking back control - UK's classic blue-and-gold passport to return
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday hailed the return of Britain's classic blue passport as a benefit of leaving the EU, pleasing Brexit campaigners for whom it is a symbol of national sovereignty but attracting derision from many remainers.

Headline: UK business confidence rises to five-month high in December - Lloyds
Description: Confidence among British businesses has picked up to its highest level since July as firms expect a busier 2018, though optimism remains well below its level before last year's Brexit vote, a survey by Lloyds Bank showed on Friday.

Headline: UK minister Garnier keeps job after misconduct inquiry finds no rules broken
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May wants to draw a line under allegations of misconduct against one of her junior ministers, Mark Garnier, a statement from her office said on Thursday after an investigation found he had not breached ministerial rules.

Headline: A hard knock life for London's rough sleepers
Description: Outside London's Piccadilly theatre where tickets cost up to 110 pounds and a banner advertising the musical "Annie" reads "It's a hard knock life", Bryan and Kevin sleep in small tents on the street.

Headline: May forces her deputy to resign over pornography scandal
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May forced her most senior minister, Damian Green, to resign for lying about whether he knew pornography had been found on computers in his parliamentary office.

Headline: Critics accuse UK government of not taking Brexit preparations seriously enough
Description: Pro-European campaigners accused ministers of failing to take preparations for Brexit seriously enough on Thursday, after a committee of lawmakers published the government's sector-by-sector analysis on the impact of leaving the European Union.

Headline: Prince Harry and fiancée Meghan Markle release engagement pictures
Description: Britain's Prince Harry and his American fiancée Meghan Markle have released a series of portraits by New York-based fashion photographer Alexi Lubomirski to mark their engagement.

Headline: May not expected to name new deputy on Thursday - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is not expected to name a replacement for senior minister Damian Green on Thursday, May's spokesman said.

Headline: UK's Brexit legislation to return to parliament on Jan. 16 - government
Description: The legislation underpinning Britain's exit from the European Union will return to parliament for more debate on Jan. 16 and 17, the leader of the House of Commons said on Thursday.

Headline: Household energy bills rose by 1.1 percent this year - provisional data
Description: Average household energy bills in Britain increased by 1.1 percent this year based on current prices, provisional data from the government showed on Thursday.

Headline: Explainer - Damian Green, PM's May deputy, resigns over pornography scandal
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May forced her most senior minister, Damian Green, to resign on Wednesday after an internal investigation found he had made misleading comments about pornography on computers in his parliamentary office.

Headline: Factbox - May's Brexit plan passes parliamentary test, more to come
Description: Legislation underpinning the government's plan to leave the European Union passed the latest stage in its journey through parliament on Wednesday, but still faces weeks of scrutiny before it becomes law.

Headline: May will allow Brexit delay in exceptional circumstances
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday she would permit a delay to Britain's departure from the European Union in exceptional circumstances, bowing to criticism from her own party over the government's plan to fix the exit date in law.

Headline: UK train drivers' union calls strikes on six lines next month
Description: Rail passengers in several areas of England face more disruption next month when the RMT drivers' union takes strike action on six lines in a long-running dispute over the role of guards.

Headline: Saudi Crown Prince to visit Britain next year - May's office
Description: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman will visit Britain next year, a statement from British Prime Minister Theresa May's office said on Wednesday.

Headline: Third of Uber's UK drivers logged into app for more than 40 hours a week
Description: Nearly a third of Uber's 50,000 drivers in Britain are logged into the app for more than 40 hours a week, whilst just under 8 percent are online for more than 60 hours, the company said in a letter to parliamentarians published on Wednesday.

Headline: Full Brexit in January 2021 as EU sets transition deadline
Description: The European Union wants a transition period after Brexit to end no later than the last day of 2020, according to the European Commission's negotiating directives agreed on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain will fight to retain City of London's position in Brexit talks - May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday Britain would fight hard to preserve the City of London's position as a top global financial hub in talks to leave the European Union.

Headline: Man accused of plotting to kill British PM May to face trial in June
Description: A man accused of plotting to kill British Prime Minister Theresa May will go on trial next June for five weeks, a London court said on Wednesday.

Headline: Alleged UK plotter who posted photo of Prince George to face trial in April
Description: A British man accused of posting a picture of four-year-old Prince George and the address of his London school as part of a series of possible targets for Islamist militants will face trial from April 30, a London court said on Wednesday.

Headline: Too late, Theresa - Brexit offer to EU citizens leaves many cold
Description: Back from Brussels with a hard-fought Brexit deal, Prime Minister Theresa May wrote an open letter to the three million citizens of other European Union states living in Britain.

Headline: UK house prices to rise less than inflation; London's to fall - Reuters poll
Description: British home prices are set to extend a slow march higher next year, in part from a cut in housing transaction tax for new buyers, but London prices will fall for the first time in eight years as Britain prepares to leave the European Union.

Headline: Britons will have legal right to high-speed broadband by 2020
Description: British homes and businesses will have a right to demand high-speed broadband by 2020 after the government said it would impose new regulation to help the 1.1 million premises who cannot access decent speeds.

Headline: Britain's Brexit rebels offer compromise on latest EU exit laws row
Description: British MPs who inflicted defeat on Prime Minister Theresa May last week in parliament over Brexit have signalled a possible compromise to avoid another row on Wednesday when legislation taking Britain out of the EU is debated.

Headline: Britain's new 3 billion pound warship has a leak
Description: Britain's biggest ever warship, the new 3.1 billion pound aircraft carrier HMS Queen Elizabeth, has a leak and needs repairs, the Ministry of Defence (MoD) said on Tuesday.

Headline: Major London road blocked as police swoop on suspect car
Description: British police said they had arrested a man on suspicion of weapons offences on Tuesday after an operation that forced the brief closure of a major London road.

Headline: UK counter-terrorism police arrest four, send in bomb disposal team
Description: An army bomb disposal team was sent to a house in northern England after police arrested four men on Tuesday on suspicion of planning acts of terrorism.

Headline: Brace for a UK election next year, opposition Labour leader Corbyn says
Description: Opposition Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn said there is likely to be a British national election next year but that he opposes a second referendum on European Union membership, Grazia magazine reported.

Headline: UK employers keep hiring but see Brexit risks ahead, survey shows
Description: British employers plan to hire more workers and raise pay more quickly in 2018, but they also fear that Brexit will make the country a less attractive place to do business, a survey showed on Tuesday.

Headline: Eurosceptics baulk as May pitches status quo Brexit transition
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told parliament her plan on Monday for a Brexit transition period with broadly the same access to European Union markets but was met with scepticism from pro-Brexit lawmakers fearful of a watered-down EU exit.

Headline: Scottish companies say Brexit already making it hard to find staff
Description: Scottish businesses said on Monday that Britain's impending exit from the European Union was already making it hard to fill gaps in their workforces, citing a skills shortage, visa problems and a negative, uncertain image of the United Kingdom abroad.

Headline: Lebanon detains Uber driver suspected of murdering British embassy worker - security official
Description: A Lebanese taxi driver with a previous arrest for drug use has confessed to killing a British woman who worked at the British Embassy in Beirut, a senior Lebanese security official said on Monday.

Headline: UK sees growing threat from Russian propaganda, cyber-attacks
Description: Russia poses an increasing threat and is willing to use propaganda, subversion and cyber-attacks to undermine Britain and the rest of Europe, Britain's national security adviser said on Monday.

Headline: Shots fired by U.S. military personnel to stop man forcing entry onto British base
Description: U.S. military personnel fired shots on Monday as they stopped a man who tried to force his way into a British military base used by the U.S. Air Force, police said, although a security source said it was not thought to be a terrorism incident.

Headline: Britain not treating incident at military base as terrorism at this stage - source
Description: Britain is not treating an incident at a British military base on Monday as terrorism-related at this stage, a Western security source said.

Headline: Uber's licence in Cambridge extended for five years
Description: The British university city of Cambridge extended Uber's operating licence for five years on Monday in a boost to the taxi app which is battling to keep its cars on the road in London, its most important European market.

Headline: PM May says EU clear UK can have bespoke trade deal
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday a senior European Union negotiator had made it clear that Britain could end up agreeing a bespoke trading arrangement after it leaves the EU.

Headline: U.S. Air Force says man detained after incident at military base in Britain
Description: A man has been detained at a military base in central England used by the U.S. air force, an air force spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: British coal still burning abroad despite push for global ban
Description: Britain led calls for an end to coal-fired power generation at United Nations climate talks in Bonn last month but at the same time British companies are active in coal projects around the world, often with government help.

Headline: Prince William's daughter Charlotte to start at nursery next year
Description: Princess Charlotte, the daughter of Britain's Prince William and wife Kate, is to start at a nursery school near the family home in west London early next year, her father's office said on Monday.

Headline: After UK's Grenfell Tower fire deaths review calls for ‘culture change’
Description: An interim review into UK building regulations commissioned after the Grenfell Tower social housing block fire in London which killed 71 people in June, has called for a "culture change" in respect to fire safety.

Headline: Lebanon detains suspect in murder of British embassy worker - source
Description: Lebanese security forces have arrested a Lebanese taxi driver suspected of killing Rebecca Dykes, a British woman who worked at the British embassy in Beirut and was found dead on Saturday, a security source said.

Headline: Church of England appoints first female Bishop of London
Description: Former nurse Sarah Mullally was appointed Bishop of London on Monday, the first female to take the job which is one of the most senior in the Church of England.

Headline: Female British embassy worker found strangled near Beirut
Description: A female British embassy worker has been found strangled near a highway outside Beirut, a Lebanese security source said on Sunday.

Headline: Brexit will not be derailed, says May ahead of crunch cabinet meetings
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not be derailed from leaving the European Union, laying the groundwork for difficult meetings this week in which she will try to unite a divided cabinet behind her vision for post-Brexit Britain.

Headline: Johnson warns UK cannot become 'vassal state' of EU
Description: Britain must strike a strong trade deal with the European Union after Brexit and avoid becoming a subordinate state of the bloc, foreign minister and leading Brexiteer Boris Johnson has told the Sunday Times newspaper.

Headline: More than half of Britons now want to stay in EU  - poll
Description: A poll has found that 51 percent of Britons would now keep European Union membership while 41 percent want to leave the bloc, a near reversal of last year's referendum result.

Headline: 'Congratulations': EU moves to Brexit phase two but warns will be tough
Description: The European Union agreed on Friday to move Brexit talks onto trade and a transition pact but some leaders cautioned that the final year of divorce negotiations before Britain's exit could be fraught with peril.

Headline: Ryanair offers to recognise unions in historic shift to try to avert strikes
Description: Ryanair offered on Friday to recognise pilot unions for the first time in its 32-year history in a last-minute attempt to avert its first-ever pilot strike.

Headline: May says Britain and EU to start talks on future ties immediately
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said Britain and the European Union will begin talks on their future relationship straight away after the bloc agreed to move talks onto the next stage of negotiations.

Headline: What can possibly go wrong? Nine Brexit bear traps for 2018
Description: European Union leaders gave a green light to the main phase of Brexit negotiations on Friday after applauding Prime Minister Theresa May's efforts to settle divorce terms for Britain's withdrawal in March 2019.

Headline: EU's Tusk sees 'exploratory' talks with UK on post-Brexit trade
