Description: Britain will need a total of 1,200 government officials to help register millions of European Union citizens living in the country after the country leaves the bloc in 2019, interior minister Amber Rudd said on Tuesday.

Headline: Prince William and wife Kate say baby expected in April
Description: Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate confirmed on Tuesday that their third child will be born next April.

Headline: OECD boss advocates 'whatever it takes' approach to Brexit
Description: Britain and the European Union should adopt a "whatever it takes" approach to Brexit talks to ensure the best outcome, OECD secretary-general Angel Gurria said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain has no plans to walk away from Brexit talks - Davis says
Description: British negotiators have no plans to walk away from Brexit talks with the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday, after some lawmakers suggested the talks should end if there is no progress at a summit later this week.

Headline: Britain hopes EU summit will build on Brexit momentum - minister
Description: Britain hopes the other EU leaders will be ready to build on the momentum in Brexit talks at a summit later this week and move towards securing a deal, Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: May, Juncker call for faster Brexit talks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May and European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker agreed over dinner in Brussels on Monday that the pace of negotiations over Britain's departure from the European Union should be stepped up.

Headline: Foreign minister Johnson says 100 billion euros is too much for Brexit
Description: British foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Tuesday he thought 100 billion euros ($118 billion) was too much to pay for leaving the European Union.

Headline: UK hate crimes surge on Brexit and militant attacks
Description: Hate crimes in Britain surged by the highest amount on record last year, official figures showed on Tuesday, with the vote to leave the European Union a significant factor.

Headline: Corbyn and other MPs could lose seats in cost cutting plan
Description: The leader of the Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn, and other politicians could lose their seats if proposals to "cut the cost of politics" go ahead, a report suggested on Tuesday.

Headline: No Brexit deal would raise UK household bills by 260 pounds a year - report
Description: British households would have to pay an average of 260 pounds a year more for food, clothing and transport if their government fails to strike a post-Brexit free trade deal with the European Union, a research paper showed on Tuesday.

Headline: Chances of 'no deal' Brexit not rising, says Hammond
Description: The chance that Britain leaves the European Union without agreeing a divorce deal has not increased recently and talks have not hit an impasse, British Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Headline: Johnson says as May heads to Brussels: time to begin serious Brexit talks
Description: Britain's Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said it was time to begin "serious negotiations" on Brexit, hours before Prime Minister Theresa May visits Brussels in an attempt to unlock the stalled talks.

Headline: Owner of failed airline Monarch should contribute to customer repatriation - Grayling
Description: The owner of failed British airline Monarch should, in principle, foot some of the bill for a massive repatriation effort co-ordinated by the country's aviation authority, British transport minister Chris Grayling said on Monday.

Headline: Bearing up well - Pregnant UK royal Kate dances with Paddington
Description: Kate, Britain's Duchess of Cambridge, danced with Paddington Bear on Monday, delighting children on her return to royal duties after suffering acute morning sickness.

Headline: EU's summit Brexit gesture to May
Description: European Union leaders will make a statement on Brexit at a summit in Brussels on Friday. Following is the latest draft text submitted by summit chair Donald Tusk for approval by EU ministers on Tuesday. It was seen by Reuters.

Headline: EU maintains summit gesture to May, with conditions
Description: European Union leaders will agree this week to start preparing internally for talks with Britain on a post-Brexit transition, according to a new draft summit statement that spells out conditions which London must meet before negotiations start.

Headline: Bill Clinton called to break Northern Ireland political impasse - source
Description: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton, who played a central role in  brokering peace in Northern Ireland, may travel to Belfast this week to try to break a months-long political impasse, a source close to the talks said.

Headline: Bill Clinton called to break Northern Ireland political impasse - source
Description: Former U.S. President Bill Clinton, who played a central role in  brokering peace in Northern Ireland, may travel to Belfast this week to try to break a months-long political impasse, a source close to the talks said.

Headline: Significant gaps remain in bid to restore Northern Irish power-sharing - May's office
Description: Significant gaps still remain between parties attempting to restore Northern Ireland's power-sharing administration, British Prime Minister Theresa May's office said on Monday after she  spoke with Irish counterpart Leo Varadkar.

Headline: May heads to Brussels expecting 'constructive' meeting - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is expecting a "constructive" meeting in Brussels on Monday with senior European Union officials as part of her attempt to achieve a smooth exit from the bloc, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Scotland sees progress in Brexit talks with London but still objects to bill
Description: The British and Scottish executives have made progress in talks on how to share powers after Brexit, they said on Monday, but Edinburgh still objects to the central government's proposed law on withdrawing from the European Union.

Headline: Parliament will block 'no deal' Brexit, Labour Party says
Description: Parliament will block Britain from leaving the European Union without an exit deal, the opposition Labour Party's finance policy chief said on Sunday.

Headline: Chancellor Hammond's future questioned by May's allies as budget nears
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond on Sunday faced mounting questions over his future weeks ahead of a budget announcement, finding himself at the centre of an increasingly fraught debate over Britain's departure from the European Union.

Headline: May to travel to Brussels for meetings with EU's Barnier and Juncker
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will travel to Brussels on Monday to meet with the European Union's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier and head of the EU Commission Jean-Claude Juncker, May's office said on Sunday.

Headline: North Ireland's DUP does not recognise criticism of Hammond
Description: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) said on Sunday that they did not recognise comments criticising Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond attributed to a DUP source in a newspaper report.

Headline: Transport minister doesn't think Britain will leave EU without a deal
Description: British transport minister Chris Grayling said on Sunday he didn't think Britain would leave the European Union without a negotiated deal with the bloc.

Headline: Uber embarks on legal battle to retain London licence
Description: Uber lodged a court appeal on Friday to overturn a decision by London's transport regulator that stripped the taxi app of its operating licence in its most important European market, the first stop on what is set to be a long legal road.

Headline: Johnson to visit Moscow this year to discuss security
Description: British foreign minister Boris Johnson will travel to Moscow later this year to discuss international security issues, the British government said on Friday.

Headline: Hammond regrets calling EU "the enemy" over Brexit
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond apologised for describing the European Union as "the enemy" in the Brexit negotiations, an embarrassing stumble for a man who is under fire from within his own party over his approach to the talks.

Headline: Senior U.S. legal official meeting UK leaders to tackle online security issues
Description: A top U.S. government legal official has given strong backing to Britain's campaign to force Silicon Valley to compromise on encrypted communications, rebuking tech firms for failing to balance crime-fighting demands with privacy needs.

Headline: "Time is running out" - Germany urges UK to move in Brexit talks
Description: It is up to Britain to move Brexit talks forward, Germany said on Friday, warning that "time is running out" for London to negotiate the deal it wants.

Headline: 'They have to pay', EU's Juncker says of Britain
Description: Britain must commit to paying what it owes to the European Union before talks can begin about a future relationship with the bloc after Brexit, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said on Friday.

Headline: Ryanair resists pilot call for new industrial relations approach
Description: Ryanair  resisted moves by pilots to unionise on Thursday, after one demanded the Irish airline adopts a new approach to industrial relations.

Headline: MPs pile pressure on watchdog over RBS report
Description: MPs have hired a barrister to check if a summary of a report by regulators into how Royal Bank of Scotland treated companies in difficulties is comprehensive and fair.

Headline: EU to launch internal Brexit transition work - draft
Description: European Union leaders will tell Britain next week it must improve the terms of its withdrawal offer, but give London the prospect of a rapid move to free-trade talks in December if that happens, their draft joint statement showed.

Headline: EU to offer May hope of post-Brexit talks at summit - draft text
Description: European Union leaders could hand Theresa May an olive branch in deadlocked Brexit negotiations next week by launching their own internal preparations for a transition to a new relationship with Britain.

Headline: Brexit talks deadlock on cash, Barnier eyes move by December
Description: Brexit talks are deadlocked over money, the EU's Michel Barnier said on Thursday as he ruled out discussions on future trade being launched by EU leaders next week but spoke of possible progress by December.

Headline: Boris Johnson tells EU - put a tiger in the tank of Brexit talks
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Thursday it was time to ramp up the pace of Brexit talks after the European Union's chief negotiator said they were deadlocked over money.

Headline: Merkel - We'll conduct Brexit talks to minimise damage to Germany
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Thursday she would conduct negotiations on Britain's looming departure from the European Union in such a way that Germany suffers as little damage as possible.

Headline: Germany's Schaeuble says soft Brexit best way to minimise damage
Description: A "soft Brexit" incorporating trade deals would be the best way to minimise damage to Britain and the European Union, German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said on Thursday.

Headline: May has 'full confidence' in Hammond
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has full confidence in Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond, her spokesman said on Thursday, following criticism from former Chancellor Nigel Lawson.

Headline: Britain says to Poles in UK - You are welcome to stay here after Brexit
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Thursday he had a message for Polish people in Britain: You are welcome to stay in Britain after Brexit.

Headline: Britain hopeful of "good news" on Northern Ireland crisis - minister
Description: Britain is hopeful of some "good news" from Northern Ireland that may allow it to introduce legislation that would restore the region's power-sharing government, the leader of Britain's lower house of parliament said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain declines to comment on reported death of "white widow" jihadist
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman refused on Thursday to comment on a newspaper report that a British jihadi who recruited for the Islamic State militant group has been killed in Syria by a U.S. drone.

Headline: Britain needs to prepare for no-deal Brexit, Boris Johnson says
Description: Britain needs to prepare for the possibility that no agreement will be reached with the European Union on a Brexit deal, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Thursday.

Headline: Oxford to become first UK city to ban petrol and diesel cars from centre
Description: The university city of Oxford has unveiled plans to ban petrol and diesel cars from its centre as part of the most radical set of proposals so far in Britain to curb pollution.

Headline: May says Brexit talks making good progress
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday Britain was making good progress in its divorce talks with the European Union and that she looked forward to moving on to discuss future trade partnerships soon.

Headline: Stars of British art world donate works for Grenfell fire survivors
Description: A group of Britain's most successful contemporary artists has donated valuable works to sell at a charity auction for the survivors of the Grenfell Tower fire, which killed about 80 people at a London social housing block in June.

Headline: UK ask regulator to set price cap to mend "broken energy market"
Description: The British government put some flesh on its plans to cap consumer gas and electricity prices for millions of households, ordering the industry regulator on Thursday to come up with curbs that will initially last until 2020.

Headline: UK lenders plan biggest consumer lending curb since late 2008 -BoE
Description: British lenders are planning the biggest cutback in consumer loans in nearly 10 years, the Bank of England said on Thursday, after it warned repeatedly about the strong pace of lending to households.

Headline: Factbox - Impact on banks from Britain's vote to leave the EU
Description: Banks have said they could move thousands of jobs out of Britain to prepare for Brexit, the country's planned exit from the European Union.    Financial services companies will need a regulated subsidiary in the EU to offer products across the bloc if Britain loses access to the European single market.

Headline: Britain asks Ofgem to devise consumer energy price cap plan
Description: Britain said on Thursday it would ask the regulator Ofgem to devise a price cap for consumer energy tariffs, but did not provide any specific details on how the cap would work for suppliers trying to gauge the impact on their business.

Headline: MP asks why Equifax delayed notifying UK data hack victims
Description: The powerful chair of Britain's parliamentary treasury committee demanded on Wednesday that U.S. credit reporting agency Equifax  explain why it has taken more than a month to notify users of a massive data breach affecting more than 15 million records and nearly 700,000 UK citizens.

Headline: Britain lays out plans to meet 2050 emission reduction target
Description: Britain's government will invest 900 million pounds in smart energy systems and nuclear and renewable technology as a part of its strategy to meet its 2050 climate target, it said on Thursday.

Headline: Queen bows out of Remembrance wreath-laying ceremony
Description: Britain's 91-year-old Queen Elizabeth has asked her eldest son, Prince Charles, to lay a wreath on her behalf at London's main war memorial on Remembrance Sunday, breaking with her usual custom of laying it herself.

Headline: In Brexit poker, clock narrows transition options
Description: By Alastair Macdonald, Gabriela Baczynska and Jan Strupczewski

Headline: Government softens immigration rules for Grenfell fire survivors
Description: Illegal immigrants who survived a fire that killed about 80 people in a social housing block in London will be given a clear path to obtaining permanent residency in Britain, the government said on Wednesday.

Headline: Speed up Brexit transition talks or deal will be worthless, says UK's Hammond
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said on Wednesday the value of a transitional Brexit deal would decline rapidly if talks to agree it drag into next year, but said it was too soon to spend money on contingency plans.

Headline: UK's economy under a cloud of Brexit uncertainty - Hammond
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said on Wednesday that a "cloud of uncertainty" about Brexit was hanging over the country's economy and needed to be cleared as quickly as possible.

Headline: Royal Mail workers to ask court to let strike go ahead
Description: Britain's Communications Workers Union (CWU) is to ask the High Court in London on Thursday to allow its members working at Royal Mail   to go ahead with a strike, the union said on Wednesday.

Headline: Ireland eyes Northern Irish political breakthrough, warns on border
Description: Ireland's foreign minister said on Wednesday he hoped that talks to restore Northern Ireland's power-sharing government could reach a successful outcome by the end of the week after some further steps by the negotiating parties.

Headline: London demands answers as British rights activist barred from Hong Kong
Description: A British activist critical of Hong Kong's rights record was barred entry to the former British colony on Wednesday, prompting a demand from London for an explanation, a week before a Communist Party leadership meeting starts in Beijing.

Headline: Brexit drives EU youth orchestra from London to Italy
Description: The European Union Youth Orchestra is moving to Italy from London, its home for more than 40 years, in an early example of the cultural fallout from Brexit.

Headline: Trump to make working visit to UK in early 2018 - report
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump will make a working visit to Britain in early 2018, with a full state visit to follow later at an unspecified date, the London Evening Standard newspaper reported on Wednesday.

Headline: May's spokesman not aware of discussions on Trump 'working visit'
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump has accepted an invite for a state visit to Britain, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday, adding that he was not aware of any other discussions of a separate working visit.

Headline: Workers call on May to be more visible in Bombardier dispute
Description: Workers at Bombardier's Northern Irish plant called on Prime Minister Theresa May to be more visible in her attempts to save their jobs after the United States imposed tariffs on planes made by the Canadian aerospace firm.

Headline: UK energy price cap will not start this winter – Ofgem
Description: A government plan to cap the most common form of gas and electricity tariffs for millions of British households would not come into effect in time for this winter, energy regulator Ofgem said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK energy price cap will not start this winter – Ofgem
Description: A government plan to cap the most common form of gas and electricity tariffs for millions of British households would not come into effect in time for this winter, energy regulator Ofgem said on Wednesday.

Headline: Theresa Maybe? PM refuses to say how she'd vote in another Brexit referendum
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May refused to say whether she would vote for Brexit if there was another referendum, repeatedly avoiding giving an answer on an issue that will define Britain's fate for generations to come.

Headline: Highlights - UK's Hammond speaks on economy, Brexit in parliament
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond spoke to the Treasury Committee in parliament on Wednesday. Below are highlights from the question-and-answer session.

Headline: UK proposes internet firm levy with web safety plan
Description: Britain published proposals on Wednesday for a levy on social media firms and internet providers to help fund its online safety strategy, designed to tackle bullying, abuse and other risks for children and vulnerable users.

Headline: Duchess of Cambridge makes first public appearance since pregnancy revealed
Description: Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge, made her first public appearance on Tuesday since it was announced she was pregnant, joining husband Prince William and his brother Harry at events to mark World Mental Health Day.

Headline: Hammond won't budget now for a 'no-deal' Brexit - Times
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond believes it would be irresponsible to spend taxpayers' money now in preparation for a "no-deal" exit from the European Union, the Times reported.

Headline: May says agreement with EU on citizens' rights is 'very close'
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday negotiators were very close to agreeing a deal with the European Union on the rights of expatriate citizens - one of the key issues that need to be resolved before talks can move forward.

Headline: Scotland can still offer choice on independence from UK - Sturgeon
Description: Nicola Sturgeon told her Scottish National Party on Tuesday that Britain's impending exit from the European Union strengthened the case for Scottish independence from the UK and that her party still has a mandate to offer a choice.

Headline: EU to review Brexit approach if no deal by December - Tusk
Description: The European Union will have to reconsider its Brexit strategy if Britain fails to improve its offers to Brussels significantly by the end of the year, European Council President Donald Tusk said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK MPs join protest tea party to support medicinal marijuana
Description: Several British lawmakers lent their support to a cannabis tea party on the lawns outside parliament on Tuesday, protesting against legislation that criminalises use of the drug for medical purposes.

Headline: SNP deputy leader says there will be a new referendum on Scottish independence
Description: The deputy leader of the Scottish National Party told his party's conference on Tuesday there would be a new referendum on independence from the United Kingdom, without specifying when.

Headline: Pledging to tackle inequality, May seeks identity beyond Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May pledged on Tuesday to "hold a mirror up to society" with a study showing sharp racial disparities in Britain, as she looks for a way to demonstrate her leadership is about more than just delivering Brexit.

Headline: UK economy likely picked up a little speed in Q3 - NIESR
Description: Britain's economy probably picked up a little speed in the third quarter of 2017, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) estimated on Tuesday.

Headline: Budget watchdog expects to chop UK's productivity outlook
Description: Britain's official budget watchdog said on Tuesday it expects to "significantly" downgrade its forecasts for productivity growth in the next five years, something that could hammer the government's finances.

Headline: UK says it will support BAE Systems and workers after job cuts - PM May's spokesman
Description: Britain will look to support defence firm BAE Systems and its workers after the firm announced nearly 2,000 job cuts on Tuesday, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said.

Headline: UK parliament to debate BAE job losses - parliament twitter feed
Description: The British government will respond to the announcement of up to 1,950 job losses at BAE Systems at 1130 GMT in parliament on Tuesday, parliament's Twitter feed said.

Headline: Average UK motor insurance premium falls 1.1 percent in third quarter - survey
Description: Car insurance premiums in Britain fell by an average of 1.1 percent in the third quarter of 2017, the largest quarterly fall in more than three years, according to the Confused.com car insurance price index and Willis Towers Watson .

Headline: Most Britons want May to lead through Brexit process - Telegraph
Description: About six in 10 people want Prime Minister Theresa May to remain in her position until the Brexit process is completed, an ORB poll for the Telegraph showed on Monday.

Headline: 'Ball in your court' - Britain, EU clash over next Brexit move
Description: Britain and its European Union partners clashed on Monday over which side should make the next move to unblock Brexit talks, despite concerns they will miss a deadline for a divorce deal and that London is heading for a chaotic departure.

Headline: Any Brexit deal will come at end of two-year negotiations - May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday she expected any deal with the European Union to be struck close to the end of the two-year negotiating period and only then would Britain know the costs or benefits.

Headline: European courts could decide trade disputes during transition period - May
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said it was possible that the European Court of Justice could continue to arbitrate trade disputes during a transition period after Britain has formally left the bloc in March 2019.

Headline: EU bank watchdog to set conditions on cross-border trades after Brexit
Description: The European Union's banking watchdog will publish guidance on new EU hubs and trading risks for lenders from Britain seeking a post-Brexit base in the bloc, its chairman said on Monday.

Headline: May says Brexit talks must focus on future relationship
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said negotiations with the European Union on leaving the bloc needed to be focussed on the long-term future relationship between the two after a limited implementation period.

Headline: UK police caution woman over incident at Prince George's school
Description: British police have cautioned a woman over an incident at a London primary school attended by Prince George, the great-grandson of Queen Elizabeth, police said on Monday.

Headline: Jailed British-Iranian charity worker faces new charges - family
Description: Iranian authorities have opened a new case against a British-Iranian charity worker serving five years in jail in Tehran, levelling charges that could carry a sentence of 16 additional years in prison, her family said on Monday.

Headline: Brexit talks stutter, but EU leaders might give May break
Description: European Union negotiators see no big breakthrough in a new round of Brexit talks from Monday nor when Theresa May attends a summit next week, yet leaders could offer the beleaguered British prime minister a hand, EU officials believe.

Headline: EU says 'ball entirely in UK court' for move to next Brexit talks phase
Description: It is up to Britain, rather than the European Union, to make progress in divorce negotiations with the European Union to enable the opening of talks on the future relationship, the spokesman for the European Commission said on Monday.

Headline: Wait for the talks, says May's spokesman on possible Brexit breakthrough
Description: A speech in Italy by Prime Minister Theresa May created momentum in Brexit talks with the European Union, her spokesman said on Monday, but was non-committal on whether it would provide the breakthrough the British government says it wants.

Headline: UK energy price cap legislation to be published on Thursday - May's spokesman
Description: Draft legislation on the British government's plans to cap energy prices will be published on Thursday, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday.

Headline: British spy boss says cyber security as important as fighting terrorism
Description: Protecting Britain from cyber crime is as important as defending it against terrorism, the head of Britain's GCHQ spy agency said  on Monday.

Headline: May's party suspends two EU lawmakers over Brexit vote
Description: Britain's ruling Conservatives barred two of their own lawmakers in the European Parliament after they broke the party whip and voted for a motion demanding London do more to meet EU demands in Brexit talks.

Headline: Scottish independence case helped by 'Brexit chaos' - Sturgeon
Description: Britain's struggles to chart a way out of the European Union are boosting the case for Scottish independence, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Sunday, but she shied away from committing to a date for another referendum vote.

Headline: Police release London museum crash driver as enquiries continue
Description: British police said on Sunday a man arrested after a car collided with pedestrians in London, injuring 11, had been released under investigation while enquires continued.

Headline: May signals foreign minister Johnson could be sacked
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has signalled that she could sack Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, a Sunday newspaper said, as she tries to reassert her authority after a series of political disasters.

Headline: Woman arrested trying to scale gates of Buckingham Palace
Description: British police said they had arrested a woman who was trying to scale the front gates of Queen Elizabeth's Buckingham Palace home in central London on Saturday, saying the incident was not terrorism-related.

Headline: Eleven injured in car crash near London museum, terrorism ruled out
Description: Eleven people were injured on Saturday when a car collided with pedestrians near London's Natural History Museum, in one of the capital's busiest tourist areas, but police doused concerns it was a terrorist attack, saying it was a road traffic incident.

Headline: Conservative plotters told to get behind May amid Brexit fears
Description: Lawmakers in British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party who are trying to oust her as leader have been told to "shut up" by senior party members, including potential rival Boris Johnson, Britain's foreign minister.

Headline: London museum incident not terrorism-related, police say
Description: London police said a incident outside the city's Natural History Museum in which 11 people were hurt when a car collided with pedestrians was not terrorism-related but was being treated as a road traffic collision.

Headline: Eleven treated after London museum incident - ambulance service
Description: London's ambulance service said they had treated 11 people, mostly for head and leg injuries, with nine taken to hospital after a car collided with pedestrians near the city's Natural History Museum on Saturday.

Headline: Police say keeping an open mind as to whether London museum incident is terrorism-related
Description: London police said they were keeping an open mind after a car collided with pedestrians outside the city's Natural History Museum, contradicting an earlier comment that they were not treating the incident as terrorism-related.

Headline: EU braces for Brexit talks collapse as May falters
Description: As in-fighting consumes the British government, Europeans have stepped up quiet preparations for a possible collapse of Brexit talks that could see Britain crash out of the EU without a deal 18 months from now.

Headline: London museum says serious incident outside, working with police
Description: London's Natural History Museum said on Saturday there had been a serious incident outside and it was working with police.

Headline: May vows to stay as party plotters attempt to topple her
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday she would stay on as leader to provide stability after a former chairman of her  Conservative Party said he had garnered the support of 30 lawmakers who wanted her to quit.

Headline: Former PM Cameron lands new job, first commercial role since leaving office
Description: Former British prime minister David Cameron, who stepped down abruptly last year after failing to convince British voters to remain in the EU, has been appointed to his first high profile commercial role.

Headline: May says she will provide "calm leadership"
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday that she would provide "calm leadership" to the country, after a former chairman of her Conservative Party said earlier in the day that she should quit.

Headline: May to attend event in her local electoral district - BBC
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May, who is facing an open rebellion from some of her own lawmakers, will attend an event in her electoral district on Friday, the first engagement since a disastrous speech to her Conservative Party's conference.

Headline: May says to meet business leaders on Monday in Downing Street
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will meet business leaders next week to discuss Britain's departure from the European Union, her office said on Friday, after a former party chairman said there was a plot to topple her.

Headline: EU drugs agency, seeking staff, warns of Brexit budget hit
Description: Europe's drugs regulator has issued a 31.8 million-pound ($42 million) tender for temporary workers and warned it could face a major budget hit as it struggles with the fallout of Brexit, which will uproot it from London.

Headline: Gove says he hopes May will remain Prime Minister
Description: Environment secretary and prominent Brexiteer Michael Gove said he hoped Theresa May would remain prime minister after party divisions over her future burst into the open on Friday, revealing a plot by up to 30 MPs to unseat her.

Headline: Both pro and anti-Brexit MPs back ousting May - Shapps
Description: Former Conservative Party chairman Grant Shapps said on Friday that both supporters and opponents of Brexit were among the 30 lawmakers who back a plot to topple Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: Both pro and anti-Brexit MPs back ousting May - Shapps
Description: Former Conservative Party chairman Grant Shapps said on Friday that both supporters and opponents of Brexit were among the 30 lawmakers who back a plot to topple Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: May should call a leadership contest, former party chairman says
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May should call a leadership election and as many as 30 of her lawmakers support telling her to go, former Conservative Party chairman Grant Shapps said on  Friday.

Headline: May should stay on as PM, Amber Rudd says
Description: Theresa May should stay on as British prime minister despite mishaps in her keynote party conference speech, Home Secretary Amber Rudd wrote in The Telegraph newspaper.

Headline: Royal Mail prepared to challenge planned strike in court
Description: Britain's Royal Mail  will use all legal options at its disposal to halt a strike by postal workers this month, it said on Thursday after the industry union announced the action over a pensions dispute.

Headline: After PM May's speech fiasco, her party puzzles - Who next?
Description: It was meant to be the speech that rescued Theresa May's premiership, but her public humiliation before the assembled Conservative Party has thrust her own future into doubt.

Headline: Two hurt after report of explosion near Glasgow, Scotland
Description: Two people were injured on Thursday, police said, after a report of an explosion near the Scottish town of Glasgow.

Headline: Late PM Heath had questions to answer over child sex abuse claims - police
Description: Former British prime minister Edward Heath would have been questioned about claims he sexually abused boys if he were alive today, police said on Thursday after a two-year investigation into the allegations.

Headline: Northern Ireland - Life inside The Fountain
Description: William Jackson remembers the exodus vividly, when over 10,000 Protestants fled the west bank of Londonderry's River Foyle for the city's suburbs as Northern Ireland's "Troubles" erupted.

Headline: Supreme Court seeks clarity on how to handle EU rulings after Brexit
Description: Britain's Supreme Court would like clearer guidance from parliament on how it should deal with European Union court judgements after Brexit, its new president said on Thursday.

Headline: London mayor welcomes Uber boss' humility after licence loss
Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan welcomed the humility shown by Uber's chief executive after the city stripped the taxi app of its licence to operate, but once again criticised the company's London management on Thursday.

Headline: UK must act to stop energy companies overcharging loyal customers - Clark
Description: The British government has a duty to act to stop energy companies taking advantage of their loyal customers by overcharging them, business secretary Greg Clark said on Thursday.

Headline: Strong consensus in parliament to act on energy price caps - Clark
Description: There is a strong consensus within the British parliament that the energy market needs to be restructured and MPs will act to give the regulator the necessary power to impose price caps if needed, business secretary Greg Clark said.

Headline: May is not considering resigning after ruined speech, Sky says
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is not considering resigning, Sky news reported on Thursday, citing her Downing Street office.

Headline: After speech fiasco, Clark says ruling Conservatives must stay cool
Description: The ruling Conservative Party must remain "cool-headed", business secretary Greg Clark said on Thursday, after a speech by Prime Minister Theresa May at their annual conference was ruined by a prankster, letters falling off a slogan and coughing fits.

Headline: May showed guts and grace in conference speech, MP Clark says
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May showed guts and grace by continuing with her keynote Conservative Party conference speech despite a repeated coughing fit and an interruption by a prankster, business secretary Greg Clark told Sky on Thursday.

Headline: UK employers, already on edge over Labour, worry about May's 'tinkering'
Description: British business leaders reacted warily to Prime Minister Theresa May's plan for more government intervention in power and housing markets, and said big unanswered questions about Brexit would drag on the economy.

Headline: May orders energy price cap, shares tumble
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she would impose a price cap on the energy market to help millions of households struggling with rising prices, hitting shares in the leading providers hard.

Headline: May - We must fight for the political mainstream
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday that her  party must fight for a Conservative mainstream political agenda, speaking in her address to the annual party conference.

Headline: Britain to spend 2 billion sterling more on affordable housing - PM May
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday the government would spend an additional two billion pounds ($2.7 billion) to create a new generation of affordable housing and help fix what she said was a broken market.

Headline: Prankster, coughing fits mar Theresa May’s speech to activists
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May’s bid to reassert her dwindling authority was marred on Wednesday by a calamitous keynote speech interrupted by repeated coughing fits, a prankster and even letters of her slogan falling off the stage.

Headline: London's Angel station reopens after suspect package scare
Description: British police said they carried out a controlled explosion on a suspect package near London's Angel underground station on Wednesday before allowing the station to reopen.

Headline: Police alerted to suspect package in London's Islington area
Description: British police were alerted to a suspect package in London's Islington area on Wednesday, and a cordon was in place, a police spokesman said.

Headline: EU's Juncker courts eurosceptic easterners with dinner invite
Description: European Commission head Jean-Claude Juncker has invited the leaders of four eastern European countries to a dinner, according to a letter seen by Reuters, in an effort to ease tensions between them and wealthier western member states.

Headline: Strong chances of Brexit no deal, but UK government may collapse - Scottish minister
Description: Scotland's Brexit minister believes there is a "pretty strong" chance Britain will leave the European Union with no deal, but that the UK government could collapse before then.

Headline: Protester interrupts May's keynote party speech
Description: A protester interrupted British Prime Minister Theresa May's keynote speech at her annual conference on Wednesday to wave a P45 letter in front her, a document given to employees when they leave their job.

Headline: May's voice repeatedly fails in keynote speech
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May struggled to deliver her keynote speech to the Conservative Party's annual conference on Wednesday, repeatedly coughing and losing her voice.

Headline: May confident of winning Brexit deal that works for Britain, EU
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday she understood that some are finding the Brexit talks frustrating but that she was confident of getting a deal that will work for both Britain and the European Union.

Headline: Ryanair flight escorted by fighter jets to London airport after 'hoax'
Description: Britain on Wednesday scrambled RAF Typhoon fighter jets to escort a Ryanair flight from Lithuania to Britain after a hoax security alert, the defence ministry and airline said, adding that the flight landed safely.

Headline: Boris Johnson jokes about dead bodies in Libya
Description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson quipped on Tuesday that Libya can become a new Dubai if it can clear the dead bodies away, the latest gaffe by Britain's top diplomat.

Headline: Britain planning for no Brexit deal, but unlikely - Green
Description: Britain is getting ready for leaving the European Union without a deal by making contingency plans, but a so-called "no deal" is very unlikely, First Secretary of State Damian Green said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain to limit acid sales after steep rise in assaults
Description: Britain will limit sales of sulphuric acid and outlaw the sale of such corrosive substances to children after a spate of assaults and its possible use to make bombs, interior minister Amber Rudd said on Tuesday.

Headline: Prince Charles's tour of southeast Asia leaves out Myanmar
Description: Prince Charles will tour southeast Asia and India later this month, but the heir to the throne will not visit Myanmar, after a spate of violence and allegations that authorities are carrying out ethnic cleansing.

Headline: Trying to reset agenda, May sets out to tackle social injustice
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May set out her quest to tackle social and racial injustice on Tuesday, hoping to shift the focus of her Conservative party's annual conference away from rifts over Britain's exit from the European Union and her leadership.

Headline: Boris Johnson gives PM May advice on Brexit while parading loyalty
Description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson offered Theresa May unsolicited public advice about how to make Brexit a success on Tuesday, delicately testing the extent of the prime minister's weakened authority while pledging overt loyalty.

Headline: EU talks going well, but there's too much gloom - Johnson
Description: British Chancellor Boris Johnson said on Tuesday negotiations to leave the European Union were going well but there was too much gloom attached to Brexit.

Headline: May says Brexit will not mean a hard border with Ireland
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said the government would do everything it could to help restore Northern Ireland’s power-sharing government, adding that Brexit would not herald the return of a hard border between the British province and Ireland.

Headline: Trade minister - Unacceptable for trading nations to 'pull up drawbridges'
Description: British trade minister Liam Fox said on Tuesday it was unacceptable for trading nations to turn their back on free trade having previously reaped the benefits of such a system.

Headline: London underground drivers call off threatened rail strike
Description: Drivers on the London underground rail network have called off a 24-hour strike they had been due to stage on Thursday after making progress in talks with management, their ASLEF union said.

Headline: EU's Juncker - too little progress on Brexit to talk future ties
Description: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said on Tuesday there was not enough progress in Britain's talks on leaving the European Union for the bloc to launch negotiations on post-Brexit ties with London.

Headline: Scotland rejects fracking, citing overwhelming public opposition
Description: Scotland will block fracking indefinitely after a public consultation found overwhelming opposition to the practice, the British region's energy minister said on Tuesday in a victory for environmentalists.

Headline: Britain is ready to walk away with no deal on Brexit, Davis says
Description: Britain wants to negotiate a Brexit agreement with the European Union, but is ready to walk away with no deal, Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday, warning that any error in the talks could cost them billions of pounds.

Headline: Britain to reform aid contracts to cut out profiteering
Description: Britain said on Tuesday it would reform the way it awards aid contracts to stamp out what it describes as unethical and uncompetitive behaviour among some suppliers in the international development market.

Headline: Sinn Fein eyes Northern Ireland power-sharing deal by end October
Description: A deal can be done by the end of October to restore Northern Ireland's power-sharing government, Sinn Fein's leader in the region said on Tuesday, raising a possible compromise with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP).

Headline: No barriers between Northern Ireland, rest of UK after Brexit - party leader
Description: The head of Northern Ireland's DUP party, which is propping up Britain's Conservative government, said on Tuesday that there could not be any barriers between the province and the rest of the United Kingdom after Brexit.

Headline: 'Sack Boris', Merkel's EU ally urges May
Description: Theresa May should sack Boris Johnson if she wants progress in the Brexit talks, a leading lawmaker in the European Parliament and an ally of German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Tuesday.

Headline: EU's Barnier - 'serious divergences' on exit bill
Description: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, told European lawmakers on Tuesday there has not been sufficient progress in Britain's exit talks with the bloc and that "serious divergences" persisted, including on divorce bill.

Headline: May says does not set 'red lines' for ministers' behaviour
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday she did not set "red lines" for the behaviour of her ministers and said she welcomed different voices in her cabinet over how to secure the best Brexit deal.

Headline: May says Britain to take tougher line on extremist content
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday Britain needed to take a tougher line against those people who post and view extremist content on the internet following a number of attacks this year.

Headline: London's East Croydon station to reopen after security check - police
Description: London's East Croydon station was due to reopen on Monday after police said an item they had been investigating was not harmful.

Headline: Capitalism is the only way, Hammond says in challenge to Labour
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond defended capitalism as the only route to prosperity on Monday, in an attempt to counter the opposition Labour Party's increasingly popular vision for a more centrally-controlled economy.

Headline: Boris and Brexit sour Theresa May's party in Manchester
Description: Besides her own diminished authority, Prime Minister Theresa May has been forced to contend with two major distractions in Manchester that threaten to rip her ruling Conservative Party apart: Brexit and her ambitious foreign minister, Boris Johnson.

Headline: Britain plans deposit return scheme to clamp down on throw-away bottles
Description: Britain will work with industry to launch a deposit return scheme for plastic bottles in a bid to clamp down on the huge waste that litters the land and sea every year, Environment Secretary Michael Gove said on Monday.

Headline: Britain aims to give go-ahead to new Heathrow runway by next year
Description: Britain is aiming to give the formal go-ahead to a third runway at Heathrow Airport in the first half of next year, transport minister Chris Grayling said on Monday.

Headline: Monarch collapse is not a sign of general aviation sector problems -minister
Description: The collapse of Monarch Airlines is not indicative of wider problems in the sector, British transport minister Chris Grayling said in a speech on Monday.

Headline: Boris Johnson says not trying to overshadow May
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said he was enjoying the annual Conservative Party conference very much and dismissed speculation that he was seeking to overshadow Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: BoE tells banks to find 4 billion pounds of 'bail-in' debt by 2022
Description: Banks operating in Britain must find a net 4 billion pounds  ($5.3 billion) by 2022 to comply with rules aimed at shielding taxpayers if lenders go bust, the Bank of England said on Monday.

Headline: UK still hopeful of moving EU talks onto future ties - junior minister
Description: Britain's junior Brexit minister said on Monday he was hopeful that EU negotiators would agree to move on to discuss future relationships in October, even after the head of the European Commission said it would take "miracles" for that to happen.

Headline: Brexit will not be reversed, junior minister says
Description: Britain's junior Brexit minister Steve Baker said on Monday the country's decision to leave the European Union will not be reversed and those hoping otherwise need to accept the decision.

Headline: Tell us how Brexit will work, British companies demand
Description: British companies including pharmaceuticals giant AstraZeneca  urged the government on Monday to agree a three-year Brexit transitional deal to ease the uncertainty hampering investment decisions and the economy.

Headline: Thyssen-Tata merger puts fate of UK's top steel plant at risk amid dismal earnings
Description: Plagued by poor earnings, Britain's biggest steel plant, located in Port Talbot, is likely to be first in line for job and output cuts after the planned European merger of Thyssenkrupp  and Tata Steel , industry sources told Reuters.

Headline: Thyssen-Tata merger puts fate of UK's top steel plant at risk amid dismal earnings
Description: Plagued by poor earnings, Britain's biggest steel plant, located in Port Talbot, is likely to be first in line for job and output cuts after the planned European merger of Thyssenkrupp  and Tata Steel , industry sources told Reuters.

Headline: Britain frustrated by slow pace of Brexit talks - Hammond
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's top ministers are all frustrated by the slow pace of Brexit negotiations, but her team owes her its loyalty as she negotiates Britain's departure from the European Union, chancellor of the exchequer Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Headline: British government aware of Monarch risk, industry will restructure - Hammond
Description: Chancellor of the exchequer Philip Hammond said on Monday the government was aware that Monarch Airlines might collapse after it chose a business model that did not pay off, but the airline industry will restructure to take on its capacity.

Headline: Britain needs to offer certainty to firms, clarify Brexit plan - Hammond
Description: The sooner the British government can clarify how the country plans to leave the European Union, the quicker the economy will start growing again, Chancellor  Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Headline: Other airlines could hire workers from Monarch - Grayling
Description: British transport minister Chris Grayling said on Monday he had spoken to other airlines about hiring those employees who are losing their jobs after Monarch Airlines went into administration overnight.

Headline: Uber’s path to win back London - data, fines and fees
Description: If history is a guide, Uber Technologies new Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi is likely to dangle data sharing and a promise to pay fines and fees when he sits down with London officials to negotiate the ride service's future in one of its most important markets.

Headline: Under pressure, May says she can steer Britain through Brexit
Description: Apologising for losing her Conservative Party's majority at a June election, Prime Minister Theresa May responded to her critics on Sunday by saying she had the right strategy to lead Britain and win a Brexit deal.

Headline: Britain's Boris Johnson says completely loyal to PM May
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said he was completely loyal to Prime Minister Theresa May on Sunday.

Headline: With a smile, Boris Johnson says he's right behind May
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said he was right behind Prime Minister Theresa May when he arrived at the Conservative Party's annual conference on Sunday after days of speculation about his leadership intentions.

Headline: Protesters demand an end to Brexit at May's Conservative conference
Description: Chanting "Bollocks to Brexit" and waving the gold stars of the European Union flag, tens of thousands of protesters marched through Manchester on Sunday to the ruling Conservative Party's annual conference to demand that Britain stay in the EU.

Headline: 'I am sorry,' May says of botched election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said she was sorry her Conservative Party lost seats in June's snap election and pledged 10 billion pounds ($13.4 billion) of extra funding to help people buy new homes.

Headline: May says foreign minister Johnson supports her Brexit plans
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday her cabinet fully backed her approach to Brexit, including Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.

Headline: EU declines to rank rival bids for agencies leaving Britain over Brexit
Description: The European Commission has shied away from ranking which cities should host Europe's drugs regulator and banking authority after Brexit, saying the decision is up to the 27 member states which will remain.

Headline: Boris Johnson wants maximum two-year Brexit transition
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has said a transition period from the European Union after Britain's exit from the bloc in March 2019 must not last more than two years.

Headline: 'A better future' - May tries to rally her Conservatives
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will set out plans to build "a road to a better future" for Britain at her Conservative Party conference next week, hoping to head off a rebellion over her handling of Brexit and the June election.

Headline: Only 'miracles' can move Brexit talks forward by October, EU tells Britain
Description: Only "miracles" can move Brexit talks far enough to fulfil Britain's hopes of launching discussions next month on its future ties with the European Union, the head of the European Commission said on Friday.

Headline: Anti-EU UKIP party elects fourth leader in a year
Description: Britain's anti-European Union UKIP party elected former army officer Henry Bolton its new leader on Friday, handing him the job of trying to stop the party that helped bring about Brexit becoming irrelevant.

Headline: New Uber CEO to meet London transport boss in licence battle
Description: The new chief executive of Uber Technologies will meet the head of London's transport system next week to try to retain the licence for its ride hailing service in the British capital.

Headline: Aviation regulator CAA says Ryanair 'capitulates' to pressure on passengers' rights
Description: Britain's aviation regulator said on Friday that Ryanair  had "capitulated" to pressure to inform passengers hit by flight cancellations of their rights, and would keep pushing the airline to fully compensate them.

Headline: Hell's bells! Britain to get less bong for its buck in Big Ben blunder
Description: Renovations that will silence the Big Ben bell in the British parliament's famous clock tower for four years will cost more than double the original estimate, officials said on Friday.

Headline: Talks on future EU-UK ties before divorce settled would weaken EU - Macron
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron said on Friday the European Union would be weakened if it agreed to discuss its future trading relationship with Britain before Brexit divorce terms are settled.

Headline: UK on track for rate hike in 'relatively near term' - Carney
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Friday that Britain's economy was on track for the central bank to start raising record-low interest rates in the "relatively near term."

Headline: Bank of England's Carney says inflation pressures likely to last
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Friday that pressures pushing up inflation were likely to last.

Headline: UK court agrees to extradite suspect in Italy model kidnap plot
Description: A Polish man accused of being part of a plot to kidnap a British model in Milan should be extradited from Britain to Italy, a London judge ruled on Friday.

Headline: EU watchdogs alerted banks on Brexit risks for capital buffers
Description: Banks in the European Union have been told they may face large capital gaps if the bloc and Britain do not agree on how to treat their loss-absorbing debt after Brexit, EU banking watchdogs said on Friday.

Headline: Bank of England warns on draft law for handling failed clearing houses
Description: The European Union should not circumvent long-standing principles in insolvency proceedings when allocating losses from a failed clearing house, Bank of England Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe said on Friday.

Headline: Watchdog considers "interim" status for EU financial firms in UK
Description: Britain's regulators could grant interim permission for European Union investment and trading firms to continue operating in the UK after the country leaves the bloc in 2019.

Headline: May urges EU to respond in kind to new tone on Brexit talks
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May urged the European Union on Friday to respond in kind to proposals she set out in Italy last week that sought to unlock Brexit talks, saying forming a new partnership was in the bloc's interest as well.

Headline: May sees good progress on ensuring citizens' rights
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said Brexit negotiators had made "good progress" toward agreeing the rights of expatriate citizens and that she was committed to encouraging Europeans to stay in Britain.

Headline: Brexit bill gives UK ministers 'excessively wide' powers, parliament committee says
Description: A parliamentary committee on Thursday accused British Prime Minister Theresa May's government of giving ministers "excessively wide" powers in new bill to transfer EU law into British law.

Headline: Brexit talks warmer after May's speech, but no closure
Description: The European Union and Britain made progress in the latest round of divorce talks, but not enough to move to the next phase of discussions on a transition period after Brexit or a future trade deal, top negotiators said on Thursday.

Headline: European Parliament wants Britain to end discrimination against EU citizens - draft
Description: European parliamentarians want Britain to end "regrettable" practices that discriminate against EU citizens in the workplace and elsewhere, a draft resolution published on Thursday showed.

Headline: Addison Lee seeks more London drivers after Uber licence loss
Description: Premium car service Addison Lee plans to increase driver numbers in London by up to a quarter, it said on Friday, just as rival Uber is set to lose its licence in Britain's capital.

Headline: Copenhagen joins battle to lure financial firms from London after Brexit
Description: Denmark's business minister was meeting financial technology  firms in London on Friday as part of a two-day drive to lure them from Britain after Brexit.

Headline: Britons open wallets to secure White Cliffs of Dover for nation
Description: A British charity seeking to buy land abutting the White Cliffs of Dover to secure the landscape for the nation says it has hit its target to raise one million pounds in just three weeks.

Headline: EU's Juncker sees no move to Brexit trade talks in October
Description: EU chief executive Jean-Claude Juncker said on Friday he did not expect "sufficient progress" to be made in Brexit talks by the end of October to allow the EU to open a new phase discussing future trade relations with Britain.

Headline: May calls Uber's London ban 'disproportionate'
Description: A decision by London's transport regulator to strip Uber Technologies Inc of its licence to operate in the city was "disproportionate" and has put thousands of jobs at risk, British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain 'unconditionally committed' to EU's security, says May
Description: Britain will remain "unconditionally committed" to protecting Europe after it has left the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday, citing the need to come together in the face of threats from Russia.

Headline: 'Biggest ever' EU budget overhang casts shadow on Brexit bill
Description: The overhang of delayed payments yet to be made from the EU budget reached its highest ever level last year, the EU auditor said on Thursday, highlighting an ominous turn as Britain haggles over its Brexit bill.

Headline: May to press case with EU on security in Tallinn
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will press on Friday for Britain to have a new security partnership with the European Union after Brexit, visiting 800 British troops in northern Estonia to strengthen her case.

Headline: EU's Verhofstadt pokes fun at Theresa May but says a Brexit deal can be done
Description: The lead Brexit negotiator for the European Parliament poked fun at British Prime Minister Theresa May on Thursday, quipping that she gave her Brexit speech in Florence because she was familiar with the city's 15th century politics of betrayal.

Headline: EU's Verhofstadt says assumes a Brexit deal can be done with Britain
Description: The lead Brexit negotiator for the European Parliament, Guy Verhofstadt, said on Thursday that a Brexit withdrawal agreement could be reached with Britain.

Headline: Free market is best, May says, as Labour closes in
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Thursday defended free markets as the proper way to run an economy, a day after  emboldened opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said his left-wing ideas now represented the political mainstream.

Headline: Carney - BoE can't be expected to nullify Brexit hit to economy
Description: Governor Mark Carney said on Thursday the Bank of England could not be expected to nullify the likely hit to the economy from Brexit, although it could influence how that hit is spread across Britain.

Headline: 'Political mainstream', Corbyn says Labour ready for government
Description: Opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn told Prime Minister Theresa May on Wednesday to step aside and make way for the Labour party to lead Britain's Brexit talks, saying his leftist ideas were now the "political mainstream".

Headline: May is driving Britain to cliff-edge Brexit - Labour leader
Description: A cliff-edge Brexit is at risk of becoming a reality under Prime Minister Theresa May, the leader of Britain's main opposition party said on Wednesday, adding only Labour could win a good deal with the European Union.

Headline: UK counter-terrorism police arrest woman under official secrets act
Description: British counter-terrorism police said they had arrested a woman on Wednesday under the Official Secrets Act.

Headline: UK counter-terrorism police arrest 11 in far-right investigation
Description: British police said 11 people had been arrested by counter-terrorism officers on Wednesday as part of an investigation into a banned far-right group.

Headline: Outgoing Northern Ireland leader says U.S. Bombardier ruling 'not end of process'
Description: Northern Ireland's outgoing leader Arlene Foster, whose region produces the wings for Bombardier Inc's  CSeries jets, said a U.S. decision to slap duties on the plane was disappointing, but "not the end of the process."

Headline: Labour 'scenario planning' for run on sterling if elected
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party is drawing up a plan to counter capital flight and a run on the pound if it is elected to run the country, the party's economic policy chief has said.

Headline: Two worlds of Labour, Britain's opposition party struggles to unite
Description: A baby gurgles in the background, posters defend workers' rights and between DJ decks and a well-stocked bar of an old nightclub,  dozens of young activists flesh out their demands that Britain's Labour Party become a wider movement for the left.

Headline: British police release three more men in London tube attack probe
Description: British police said on Tuesday they had released three men who were arrested in connection with the bomb attack on a London underground train earlier this month.

Headline: Inventor James Dyson aims for electric car launch by 2020
Description: James Dyson, the billionaire British inventor of the bagless vacuum cleaner, said on Tuesday his company was working on  developing an electric car to be launched by 2020.

Headline: No, m'lud: Brexit stymies EU judges' English conversion
Description: The European Court of Justice could cut costs and speed up verdicts by letting judges speak English rather than only in French, an EU audit showed on Tuesday - but a plan to let them has been stymied by Brexit.

Headline: UK terror reinsurance fund seeks to extend coverage
Description: Britain's Pool Re, which helps insurers pay out claims on property damage caused by terror attacks, is in talks with the government to extend cover to businesses that suffer indirectly from an attack, such as through loss of custom.

Headline: Red-hot ticket - Business flocks to hear Labour Party
Description: Labour's annual conference is proving a hot ticket for businesses keen to get to know the opposition party again after its left-wing conversion proved popular with voters and edged it closer to power.

Headline: Uber rival Lyft met London transport officials - documents show
Description: Lyft, Uber’s closest U.S. rival in the taxi-hailing business, met repeatedly with officials from London's transport regulator over the past year, a sign it may be targeting the city for international expansion.

Headline: Apologising to London, Uber CEO offers change to keep licence
Description: Uber's new boss Dara Khosrowshahi apologised to Londoners for the taxi app's mistakes and pledged to make changes as the Silicon Valley firm tries to overturn a decision to strip it of its licence in one of its major markets.

Headline: Labour shifts on Brexit, proposes staying in customs union
Description: Britain could stay in a customs union with the European Union after leaving the bloc if Labour win power, the main opposition party said on Monday, putting pressure on Prime Minister Theresa May's divided government over Brexit.

Headline: Hopes and frustrations as Brexit talks resume after May speech
Description: British and EU negotiators talked up hopes for progress on Brexit as a new round of talks began in Brussels on Monday, three days after Prime Minister Theresa May tried to revive the process and improve the mood.

Headline: Hopes and frustrations as Brexit talks resume after May speech
Description: British and EU negotiators talked up hopes for progress on Brexit as a new round of talks began in Brussels on Monday, three days after Prime Minister Theresa May tried to revive the process and improve the mood.

Headline: Too early to say if UK has made sufficient progress in Brexit talks - Irish PM
Description: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Monday it was not possible to say that Britain had made sufficient progress to move onto the next phase of Brexit talks with the European Union, adding there was a "bit of a way to go yet".

Headline: Labour pledges infrastructure nationalisation, credit card cap
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party set out plans on Monday to nationalise billions of pounds of privately-funded infrastructure contracts, cap credit card interest charges, and get extra cash from large corporations.

Headline: All ears - Brussels awaits detail from Davis on May's Brexit plan
Description: Three days after Theresa May sought to revive Brexit negotiations by hinting at concessions on the divorce terms and painting a glowing picture of future friendship, EU negotiators want to hear detail on Monday.

Headline: Britain would have to accept all EU rules during Brexit transition - Barnier
Description: Britain, which asked on Friday for a two-year transition period after it leaves the European Union in 2019, would have to abide by all EU rules during this phase, the EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier said on Monday.

Headline: Milan model kidnap plot is a sham, suspect's lawyer tells court
Description: The lawyer for a man accused of being part of a plot to kidnap a British model in Italy, told a London court on Monday there were grounds to suspect the whole case was a sham.

Headline: Labour Party demands corporations 'pay their way'
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party said on Monday it would close tax loopholes used by the wealthy and ensure that corporations "pay their way", setting out its plan for the economy if it takes power from Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: Brexit can be 'comfortably' negotiated in two years - Johnson
Description: Britain can negotiate its exit from the European Union within the two-year framework envisaged, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Monday.

Headline: British lesbian wins right to spousal visa in landmark Hong Kong case
Description: A Hong Kong appeals court on Monday ruled that a British lesbian whose partner works in the city should be granted a spousal visa, a landmark decision that could lead to expatriate same-sex partners moving to the Chinese-ruled financial hub.

Headline: UK's opposition Labour pledges to take control of all 'PFI' deals - spokesman
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party said it would bring all existing 'Private Finance Initiative' deals - which fund public infrastructure with private capital - under government control if they are able to unseat the Conservative government.

Headline: Factbox - Impact on banks from Britain's vote to leave the EU
Description: Global banks have said they could move thousands of jobs out of Britain to prepare for Brexit, the country's planned exit from the European Union.

Headline: British police arrest seventh man over bomb attack on London train
Description: British police made a new arrest on Monday in their investigation into a bomb attack on a London underground train earlier this month.

Headline: Johnson opposes adopting any new EU rules during Brexit transition
Description: Foreign secretary Boris Johnson will oppose any move to adopt European Union regulations made after Britain leaves the bloc in March 2019, the Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported, risking reigniting divisions over Brexit.

Headline: London mayor says Britain should not host President Trump on state visit
Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan said on Sunday that it would be wrong for Britain to host U.S. President Donald Trump on a state visit, describing some of the U.S. leader's views on Islam as "ignorant".

Headline: Police have thwarted seven attacks since March - London mayor
Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan said police had thwarted seven attacks by militants since March this year, describing the increase in the number as a shift rather than a spike.

Headline: Britain must stay in EU's single market after Brexit - Labour MPs
Description: The Labour Party must commit to staying in the European Union's single market after Brexit and put an end to Prime Minister Theresa May's "destructive Brexit", several of its MPs said on Sunday.

Headline: Britain will diverge from EU regulations post-Brexit - David Davis
Description: Brexit secretary David Davis said on Sunday Britain's rules and regulations will diverge from those set by the European Union after Brexit because the government "will do things our own way".

Headline: Germany calls May's Brexit speech 'disappointing'
Description: German Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel on Saturday described British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit speech as "disappointing", saying it offered no concrete details on how Britain wants to structure its exit from the European Union.

Headline: May sets out transition plan in bid to unlock Brexit talks
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May set out a plan on Friday to retain full access to the EU's single market for two years after Brexit to try to reassure business and reset the tone of stalled negotiations with Brussels.

Headline: Colin Firth gets dual Italian citizenship after Brexit vote
Description: British actor Colin Firth, who has often played the role of a quintessential Englishman in his many films, has become an Italian citizen, Italy's Interior Ministry said.

Headline: Colin Firth gets dual Italian citizenship after Brexit vote
Description: British actor Colin Firth, who has often played the role of a quintessential Englishman in his many films, has become an Italian citizen, Italy's Interior Ministry said.

Headline: Minister for London slams 'blanket ban' on Uber
Description: A government minister has criticised the London authorities for deciding to strip Uber of its taxi licence, a major setback to the U.S. technology firm that has become a big player in the city's transport system.

Headline: Petition against Uber's London ban hits 500,000
Description: A petition organised by Uber against London's decision not to renew its operating licence has gathered 500,000 signatures, little more than 24 hours after the decision was announced, a website monitoring its progress showed on Saturday.

Headline: Britain says Moody's downgrade based on 'outdated' Brexit view
Description: Britain's government said on Friday that a decision by ratings agency Moody's to downgrade the country's credit rating was based on an "outdated" assessment of its plans to leave the European Union.

Headline: EU leaders want clarity on citizens, Brexit financial terms and Ireland
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron said on Friday that in Brexit talks, rules on the settlement of European Union citizens, the financial terms of Britain's departure from the bloc, and the question of Ireland must be clarified before other issues can be tackled.

Headline: Close but no hurrah - EU welcomes May Brexit speech, but warily
Description: Theresa May's "constructive spirit" won a cautious welcome from the European Union on Friday, though the British prime minister's keynote Brexit speech raised more questions than answers for some and they want more details next week.

Headline: Polish PM - Want to ensure rights of Poles in UK in Brexit talks
Description: Polish Prime Minister Beata Szydlo said on Friday that for Poland the key issue in Brexit negotiations is to focus on the rights of Polish citizens in Britain and issues related to the EU budget.

Headline: Head of G4S immigration unit at centre of abuse scandal quits
Description: The head of a G4S-run immigration unit in Britain at the centre of allegations of bullying and abuse, has resigned, the outsourcing company said on Friday.

Headline: Ireland says 'lot of work' needed to move to next phase of Brexit talks
Description: Ireland's foreign minister on Friday welcomed Theresa May's speech in Florence calling for a Brexit transition deal, but said a lot of work was still required before the EU could move on to the next phase of talks with Britain.

Headline: Factbox - Uber operates in more than 90 European cities, despite legal battles
Description: Uber faces having to withdraw ride hailing services in London, its busiest European market, after local regulator Transport for London pulled the company's licence for private hire cabs on Friday, a move Uber said it planned to appeal.

Headline: Poland says full protection of EU citizens' rights in UK key in Brexit
Description: Poland's Deputy Foreign Minister Konrad Szymanski, commenting on Brexit proposals presented on Friday by British Prime Minister Theresa May, said that protecting the rights of European Union citizens in the United Kingdom was one of the key conditions.

Headline: Irish PM says May speech 'genuine effort to move things forward'
Description: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar on Friday gave a "cautious welcome" to a speech in Florence by British Prime Minister Theresa May, who called for Britain to stay in the single market under its current terms during a two-year transition period.

Headline: 'Even more concerned' after May Brexit speech - senior EU lawmaker
Description: The head of the European Parliament's biggest group, the centre-right European People's Party, said British Prime Minister Theresa May's speech on Brexit on Thursday did not clarify London's position and had left him more concerned than before.

Headline: UK not prepared to pay for EU single market access during transition - government source
Description: Britain is not prepared to pay for access to the European Union's single market during a post-Brexit transition period, a UK government source said on Friday.

Headline: Highlights - May's main comments on Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is setting out her plan for future ties with the European Union in a speech which she hopes will help spur negotiations over the country's divorce from the bloc.

Headline: Teenager appears in court charged with London bomb attack
Description: An 18-year-old man who came to Britain after his parents were killed in Iraq appeared in a London court on Friday charged with attempted murder in last week's bomb attack on a packed commuter train in the British capital.

Headline: May says Brexit transition period to last around two years
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said that a Brexit implementation period would last for around two years.

Headline: May says will honour EU budget commitments during period of EU membership
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday that Britain will honour its budget commitments made during the period of its EU's membership during.

Headline: May says wants UK courts to take into account ECJ rulings on citizens' rights
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday she wanted UK courts to take into account judgements made by the European Court of Justice over the issue of European Union citizens' rights.

Headline: May says Brexit talks have been at times tough but made progress
