Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday that negotiations on Britain's departure from the European Union had been tough at points but made concrete progress.

Headline: May calls for post-Brexit transition in single market
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May called on Friday for Britain to stay in the European Union's single market during a roughly two-year transition out of the EU while offering concessions on a divorce deal as she appealed for a revival of Brexit negotiations.

Headline: May says EEA membership would not suit Britain after Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said during a major speech on Brexit on Friday that membership of the European Economic Area would not suit Britain after it leaves the EU and would lead to friction.

Headline: May wants to be a strong friend to the EU
Description: Britain wants to be a strong friend to the European Union and will not block reform, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday.

Headline: May to raise possibility of leaving EU before March 2019 - Telegraph
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will use a speech in Florence on Friday to raise the possibility of leaving the European Union before March 2019, the Telegraph newspaper reported.

Headline: Angry and 'invisible', expat Britons await May in Florence
Description: Expatriate Britons gathered in Florence on Friday to voice their frustration at how Brexit will impact them, awaiting the British prime minister's arrival in the Italian city to set out her vision for future ties with the European Union.

Headline: Uber says will appeal decision to strip it of licence to operate in London
Description: Uber said it would challenge a decision by London's transport regulator on Friday to strip it of its licence to operate from the end of the month.

Headline: British police feel strain from attacks after latest London bombing
Description: Two of Britain's most senior officers said the pressure on the police forces was not sustainable after last week's attack on a packed London train became the fifth major attack this year.

Headline: Australian court rules senator was British citizen when nominated
Description: Australia's High Court on Friday said nationalist politician and senator Malcolm Roberts was a citizen of Britain at the time of his nomination to parliament's upper house.

Headline: Britain will meet its Brexit financial obligations - minister
Description: Britain will meet its financial obligations when it leaves the European Union, transport minister Chris Grayling said on Friday, hours before Prime Minister Theresa May makes a high-stakes speech to reset Brexit talks.

Headline: Police release two men in Parsons Green attack probe
Description: British police said they have released two men arrested as part of the investigation into last week's Tube attack in Parsons Green, London, which injured 30 people.

Headline: Ryanair scrambles to please pilots, customers and investors
Description: Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary on Thursday scrambled to placate pilots and reassure investors as the airline's annual general meeting was dominated by the cancellation of 2,000 flights in a "cock-up" that exposed major staffing issues.

Headline: EU wants May to make firm offers now for Brexit deal - Barnier
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May should make the EU firm offers by next week to break deadlock in Brexit talks if she wants an orderly withdrawal and transition to a new relationship, the bloc's negotiator said on Thursday.

Headline: EU's Barnier says wants proposal from May on EU citizens' rights in Britain
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May should make a proposal over what legal rights European Union citizens will have in Britain after it leaves the bloc, the EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Thursday.

Headline: May wants two-year transition deal with EU - BBC
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will say she wants a two-year transition deal after leaving the European Union in March 2019 in a speech in Florence on Friday, the BBC's political editor said.

Headline: Boost for Hammond as UK posts smallest August budget deficit in 10 years
Description: Britain unexpectedly posted its smallest budget deficit for any August since 2007, helped by record sales tax revenues that could give Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond room to relax his grip on spending in an upcoming budget.

Headline: Taking back control? May to make high-stakes Brexit speech
Description: After months of Brexit talks that have made little progress and deepened rifts in her party, British Prime Minister Theresa May will try this week to put the negotiations on track and reassert her authority.

Headline: May, Macron, Gentiloni push for quick removal of extremist online content
Description: Leaders of France, Italy and the United Kingdom urged social media companies on Wednesday to more swiftly remove "terrorist content" from the internet, with the aim of stopping it from being uploaded in the first place.

Headline: We want it in writing - Scotland and Wales seek clarity on post-Brexit powers
Description: Scotland and Wales proposed changes on Wednesday to the central UK government's Brexit bill in an attempt to bed down their current powers which they fear could be weakened after Brexit.

Headline: EU's Tusk, UK's May to talk Brexit next Tuesday
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk said he would meet with British Prime Minister Theresa May in London next Tuesday to discuss Brexit, days after she is due to make a keynote speech on her vision for future ties with the EU.

Headline: Leaders of far-right group charged with religiously aggravated harassment
Description: The leaders of a far-right British political group, Britain First, were charged with causing religiously aggravated harassment on Wednesday, police said.

Headline: Bank of England survey shows little sign of UK pay growth improving
Description: Pay growth across British companies remains subdued and investment intentions among British services firms weakened further in the last quarter, a Bank of England survey of businesses showed on Wednesday.

Headline: British police arrest third man in London bomb attack investigation
Description: British police have arrested a third man over the bombing of a busy commuter train in west London last week which injured 30 people.

Headline: UK employers' optimism falls to lowest since Brexit vote - REC
Description: British employers are their most pessimistic about the outlook for the economy since last year's Brexit vote and want clarity about the departure from the European Union, a survey showed on Wednesday.

Headline: PM expected to offer to fill post-Brexit EU budget hole - FT
Description: The British government has told German Chancellor Angela Merkel to expect Prime Minister Theresa May this week to offer to fill a post-Brexit European Union budget hole of at least 20 billion euros, the Financial Times reported on Tuesday.

Headline: UK fishermen see Brexit bonanza, but there's a catch
Description: For the fishermen of this small port on the toe of England, Britain's vote to leave the European Union was an answer to their prayers.

Headline: Theft at burnt London tower adds to police's gruelling work
Description: Already facing the grim task of sifting through debris to find human remains at Grenfell Tower, the London social housing block where a fire killed about 80 people, police are now also having to investigate suspected thefts from survivors' apartments.

Headline: Foreign Secretary Johnson says he will not resign - Sky
Description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said he was not going to resign, when questioned on Tuesday following reports that he could quit before the weekend if his Brexit demands were not met by Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: May says foreign minister Johnson "doing good work"
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May backed her foreign minister Boris Johnson on Tuesday after reports he could quit over her Brexit strategy, Sky News reported.

Headline: Britain's M1 motorway partially closed after suspicious object discovered
Description: Part of Britain's M1 motorway was closed on Tuesday after what police described as a suspicious object which appeared to be "some form of chemical" was found under a bridge.

Headline: Head of anti-Brexit party appeals for help to stop EU exit
Description: Calling himself a "proud saboteur" of the Brexit process, Britain's Liberal Democrat leader Vince Cable on Tuesday appealed to opponents in all parties to put aside differences and fight a divorce from the European Union.

Headline: Head of anti-Brexit party appeals for help to stop EU exit
Description: Calling himself a "proud saboteur" of the Brexit process, Britain's Liberal Democrat leader Vince Cable on Tuesday appealed to opponents in all parties to put aside differences and fight a divorce from the European Union.

Headline: London's Leadenhall market briefly evacuated after reports of suspect package
Description: Leadenhall market in London's financial district was briefly evacuated on Tuesday after reports of a suspicious package in the area.

Headline: British police say suspect package in London's Holborn was false alarm
Description: British police said reports of a suspicious package near Holborn, central London, had turned out to be a false alarm.

Headline: 'Disaster looms,' says Lib Dem leader Cable
Description: Britain's Liberal Democrats are to set out on Tuesday their plan to stop Brexit, with party leader Vince Cable appealing to opponents in all parties to put aside "tribal differences" and fight a divorce from the European Union.

Headline: Police arrest second man over London train bomb
Description: British police arrested a second man over the bombing of a London commuter train on Friday that injured 30 people and the security services lowered the threat level for an attack from its highest setting.

Headline: British cyclist pedals around world in 78 days, smashing record
Description: A British endurance cyclist has smashed the Guinness World Record for the fastest circumnavigation of the planet on a bicycle, riding 18,000 miles (29,000km) in under 80 days.

Headline: PM May tightens grip over Brexit talks, appoints official as EU adviser
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May appointed the top official at the Brexit ministry as her EU adviser on Monday, taking tighter control of divorce negotiations just as Britain tries to shift the focus of talks onto the future relationship with Europe.

Headline: No evidence to link London attack directly to militant groups - U.S. sources
Description: British police and spy agencies have not found evidence that last week's attack on a London commuter train was ordered or organised by a recognised militant group, according to U.S. and British government sources familiar with the investigation.

Headline: UK government, including Johnson, united behind May's Brexit plan - spokeswoman
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and the rest of Prime Minister Theresa May's top team of ministers are united behind the government's plan for Brexit, May's spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: MPs seek clarity on cross-border pensions after Brexit
Description: British lawmakers on Monday urged the government to address the status of cross-border pensions and insurance contracts after Brexit, saying time to make changes ensuring people continued to be paid was running out.

Headline: Britain proposes new security treaty with EU after Brexit
Description: Britain will propose on Monday signing a new security treaty with the European Union after Brexit to maintain and intensify cooperation to thwart "ever-growing and increasingly cross-border threats".

Headline: Boris Johnson accused of Brexit 'backseat driving'
Description: Britain's foreign minister Boris Johnson was accused by cabinet colleagues on Sunday of "backseat driving" on Brexit after setting out his own vision of the country's future outside the European Union.

Headline: Johnson criticised for resurrecting 'Brexit benefit' mantra
Description: Foreign minister Boris Johnson was accused by a government statisticians of misusing state data after he repeated a pro-Leave campaign mantra that Britain would have an extra 350 million pounds a week after Brexit.

Headline: Britain lowers threat level as Tube explosion case progresses
Description: Britain lowered its national security threat level to severe from critical on Sunday after an investigation into a bomb attack on the London Underground progressed, interior minister Amber Rudd said.

Headline: Trump's tweet on London train bombing just speculation - Rudd
Description: The Home Secretary said a claim by U.S. President Donald Trump that the culprits behind a bombing on a London train were in the sights of the police, made on Twitter shortly after the attack, had been nothing more than speculation.

Headline: Police keeping open mind on number of suspects in London train bombing
Description: British police are keeping an open mind on whether more than one person was responsible for a London train bombing that injured 30 people, after they arrested an 18-year-old man earlier on Saturday.

Headline: Police evacuate, search properties in London train bomb investigation
Description: British police said they have evacuated and are searching a residential address in Surrey, southern England, after arresting an 18-year-old man in connection with a London train bombing that injured 30 on Friday.

Headline: Johnson reignites leadership speculation with Brexit plans
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson set out his plans for a "glorious" Brexit on Saturday that angered colleagues and reignited speculation he would challenge Prime Minister Theresa May for the leadership of the Conservative party.

Headline: Police arrest 18-year-old in hunt for London train bomber
Description: British police hunting those behind a bomb which injured 29 people on a London train on Friday said they had arrested an 18-year-old man in a move described as significant.

Headline: Speculation not helpful, British PM May tells Trump after attack tweet
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday it was not helpful for anyone to speculate on investigations after U.S. President Donald Trump tweeted that the culprits behind a train bombing had been "in the sights" of the police.

Headline: British police 'chasing down suspects' after train bombing
Description: British police are chasing down the people they suspect of being behind a bomb which injured 29 people on a packed commuter train in west London on Friday, the country's most senior counter-terrorism officer said.

Headline: Islamic State claims responsibility for London blast - Amaq news agency
Description: Islamic State has claimed responsibility for a blast on Friday that injured 22 people on a packed commuter train on the London underground network, the militant group's Amaq news agency said.

Headline: Police arrest suspected knifeman near Birmingham train station- paper
Description: British police arrested a suspected knifeman near Birmingham New Street Station, the Birmingham Mail newspaper reported on its website on Friday.

Headline: Part of West London metro line closed due to earlier bomb
Description: Part of London's busy underground train system was closed on Friday following a bomb attack which police are treating as a terrorist incident.

Headline: Britain seeks to smooth Brexit path for nuclear power
Description: The British government said on Thursday it was in talks with the European Union to ensure a smooth transition for its nuclear industry as Britain moves away from Euratom's regulatory regime to a domestic one.

Headline: Factbox - What we know so far about the London train bomb
Description: An improvised explosive device exploded on a packed rush-hour commuter train in London injuring 22 people on Friday in what police said was the fifth terrorism incident in Britain this year.

Headline: British police say "terrorist incident" at London metro station
Description: British police said on Friday that they were treating as a "terrorist incident" reports of a blast at a west London metro station.

Headline: May will chair meeting of emergency committee after west London incident
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will chair a meeting of Britain's emergency response committee later on Friday after an incident at a west London tube station, her office said in a statement.

Headline: May "receiving regular updates" on London tube station incident - PM's office
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is being regularly briefed after armed police rushed to an incident at a London underground station on Friday, with local media reporting there had been an explosion on a packed rush-hour commuter train.

Headline: UK transport police leading investigation of London incident, counter-terrorism police aware
Description: British counter-terrorism police were monitoring events after media reports of a blast on a train in Parsons Green station in west London on Friday, but the investigation into the incident is being led by transport police, a security source said.

Headline: Witness says injured in stampede at London station - Reuters reporter
Description: A woman at London's Parsons Green underground train station told Reuters on Friday she was injured in a stampede.

Headline: London fire inquiry starts amid anger, despair of survivors
Description: A public inquiry into a fire that killed at least 80 people at London's Grenfell Tower will get to the truth about the tragedy, its chairman pledged on Thursday, but critics said survivors of the blaze were still being failed.

Headline: UK's G4S roasted by MPs on violent abuse at immigration centres
Description: British MPs accused outsourcer G4S of repeated failures of detainee welfare safeguards and whistleblowing mechanisms at a secure immigration unit, after physical and verbal abuse by guards was revealed in a BBC documentary.

Headline: UK terrorism arrests soar to record level after attacks this year
Description: The number of people arrested in Britain on suspicion of terrorism offences rocketed by 68 percent in the last year to the highest figure on record during a period when the country suffered four deadly attacks, figures showed on Thursday.

Headline: EU workers drift from Britain just as restaurateurs need them most
Description: Business is booming for Paul Murphy's recruitment agency in northwest England. Clients are rolling in with more jobs in restaurants, bars and hotels than ever before, but finding workers to fill them has become tricky.

Headline: PM May to make Brexit speech in Italy on Sept. 22 - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will make a speech on Britain's future relationship with the European Union on Sept. 22 in the Italian city of Florence, her spokesman said on Wednesday.

Headline: Hammond says rejects 'protectionist' EU agendas after Brexit
Description: Britain will reject "protectionist" agendas from the European Union in favour of "forward-leaning" proposals when it comes to supervising cross-border financial markets after Brexit, UK finance minister Philip Hammond said on Wednesday.

Headline: May presses Northern Ireland leaders to restore power-sharing government
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has spoken with the leaders of Northern Ireland's two main parties to press them to restore a power-sharing government that collapsed in January.

Headline: London police arrest woman after incident at Prince George's school
Description: A woman has been arrested in London on suspicion of attempted burglary at a primary school attended by Prince George, the great-grandson of Queen Elizabeth, police said on Wednesday.

Headline: Nearly a quarter of Scottish engineering firms risk staff losses due to Brexit - survey
Description: Almost one quarter of Scottish engineering and manufacturing firms have lost or are at risk of losing staff because of Britain's decision to leave the European Union, a survey published on Wednesday found.

Headline: UK nuclear operator warns of plant outages if Brexit mismanaged
Description: EDF,, the French utility that runs Britain's nuclear reactors, said on Wednesday power plants could suffer extended outages if a new safeguard regime and other measures were not in place when Britain exits the European Union in 2019.

Headline: Scottish government recommends rejection of EU withdrawal bill
Description: Scotland's devolved government has recommended that its parliament at Holyrood withhold consent for legislation to withdraw Britain from the European Union, on the grounds that it could water down their powers, a document filed by the Scottish government said on Tuesday.

Headline: Factbox - What influence do Scotland and Wales have over Brexit?
Description: The governments of Scotland and Wales say they cannot consent to a UK-wide parliamentary bill on withdrawal from the European Union, arguing that the bill would strip back the powers of their devolved parliaments.

Headline: UK pay puzzle deepens, easing pressure on Bank of England
Description: Britain's job market is defying the Brexit blues but wages are still in the dumps, data showed, suggesting the Bank of England will tread carefully on Thursday with any signals about when it may finally raise interest rates.

Headline: More flexible approach needed on public sector pay, says PM May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday her government would need to be more flexible on public sector pay in the future, and that work on the issue would take place ahead of a Nov. 22 budget.

Headline: Northern Ireland fears Brexit loss of EU peacemaking and cash
Description: The European Union has long aided efforts to heal the deep divisions that plague Northern Ireland, and many people on both sides of the sectarian rift fear what might happen when Brexit forces it to walk away.

Headline: Britain eases public sector pay grip with rises for police
Description: Britain's government partially abandoned a cap on public-sector pay on Tuesday, saying it would raise wages for police and prison guard by more than its long-standing 1 percent limit.

Headline: Conservatives win vote to bolster party's numbers on committees
Description: British lawmakers voted on Tuesday in favour of handing the governing Conservatives greater say on committees that scrutinise laws, a move denounced by the opposition as an attempt to "rig parliament".

Headline: May asks Trump to help over Boeing's Bombardier challenge
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has asked President Donald Trump to intervene in a dispute between Boeing Co and Canadian rival Bombardier to help secure thousands of jobs in Northern Ireland.

Headline: UK inflation jump puts Bank of England back in spotlight on rates
Description: British inflation hit its joint highest level in more than five years in August, complicating the Bank of England's job this week of explaining why it is not raising interest rates.

Headline: May faces new parliament battle with committee vote
Description: British lawmakers will vote on Tuesday on moves by the Conservative government to bolster its numbers on committees that scrutinise laws, denounced by the opposition as an attempt to "rig parliament".

Headline: London seeks 'deep security partnership' with EU after Brexit
Description: Britain wants to have closer defence cooperation with the European Union after Brexit than other countries outside the union, according to a document that sets out a vision of "a deep security partnership" aimed at nudging talks forward.

Headline: Road blighting Stonehenge to be buried in solstice-compliant plan
Description: The prehistoric stone circle of Stonehenge in southwest England will be freed from the sight, sound and smell of traffic under plans announced on Tuesday to bury a busy road that has long blighted the World Heritage Site.

Headline: Brexit law passes hurdle in reprieve for May
Description: Britain's parliament backed a second reading of legislation to sever ties with the European Union early on Tuesday, a reprieve for Prime Minister Theresa May who now faces demands by lawmakers for concessions before it becomes law.

Headline: EU Parliament's Brexit coordinator urges May to address chamber
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May should address the European Parliament when she visits the EU legislature to clarify Britain's plans for its divorce from the European Union, the parliament's Brexit coordinator said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK unions could stage coordinated strikes over public sector pay
Description: The leader of Britain's biggest union has warned that coordinated strikes by workers in the public sector was "on the cards" in protest at the government's pay cap.

Headline: MPs back government's proposed timetable for debate of EU withdrawal bill
Description: British lawmakers on Tuesday voted in favour of the government's proposed timetable for debating legislation designed to sever political, financial and legal ties with the European Union.

Headline: Britain can now move on with Brexit talks, PM May says after parliamentary vote
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May welcomed a vote in parliament on Tuesday backing legislation to sever ties with the European Union, saying the decision meant "we can move on with negotiations with solid foundations".

Headline: Caribbean residents fend off looters after Irma; Branson urges 'Marshall Plan'
Description: Food shortages and looting on Caribbean islands hammered by Hurricane Irma sparked growing criticism of the government response, prompting British billionaire Richard Branson to call for a "Marshall plan" to help the region recover.

Headline: Police charge serving soldiers over suspected far-right terrorism
Description: Three men, including two serving soldiers, were charged by British police on Monday with terrorism offences, including belonging to a banned far-right group.

Headline: Don't throw Brexit into chaos, Davis says before parliament vote
Description: Britain faces a chaotic exit from the European Union if lawmakers vote against legislation designed to sever political, financial and legal ties with the bloc, Britain's Brexit minister David Davis said before a parliamentary vote.

Headline: UK government confident of winning vote on Brexit legislation - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government is confident of winning a vote on a major piece of Brexit legislation, due in parliament later on Monday or early Tuesday, May's spokesman said.

Headline: Britain to lift pay cap for police, prison officers - media
Description: The British government will soften its seven-year grip on public-sector pay with police and prison officers set to get increases above a 1 percent cap, media reported.

Headline: Denmark's DONG wins UK contract to build world's largest offshore wind farm
Description: Danish offshore wind firm DONG Energy  was awarded a contract to build 1.4 gigawatt (GW) capacity at its Hornsea 2 wind power project during a British auction for renewables, creating the world's largest offshore wind farm.

Headline: British trade union conference evacuated over bomb threat
Description: A hotel and nearby conference centre on the south coast of England where Britain's Trades Union Congress (TUC) is holding its annual conference were evacuated on Sunday due to a bomb threat, police said.

Headline: Police release two of group arrested over suspected far-right terrorism
Description: Two men arrested on suspicion of belonging to a banned far-right group and planning terrorist acts have been released without charge, British police said on Sunday.

Headline: UK doesn't need Brexit to curb EU immigration, says former PM Blair
Description: Britain could bring in tough new controls on immigration from the European Union without actually having to leave the bloc, former prime minister Tony Blair said on Sunday.

Headline: On cricket homage, May challenges robotic jibe
Description: Armed with a tupperware box full of home-made chocolate brownies, Prime Minister Theresa May made an appearance on Britain's most popular cricket programme on BBC radio on Friday and took to task those who call her "robotic".

Headline: Farage talks Brexit at German right-wing election rally
Description: Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage received a standing ovation at a pre-election rally of the anti-immigration Alternative for Germany (AfD) in Berlin on Friday, where he was presented as a model of what a right-wing eurosceptic politician can achieve.

Headline: Farage says May might not last until Christmas
Description: Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage said on Friday that British Prime Minister Theresa May might be out of a job by Christmas unless she manages to get her party behind her and take charge of Brexit negotiations.

Headline: UK doesn't need Brexit to curb EU immigration, says former PM Blair
Description: Britain could bring in tough new controls on immigration from the European Union without actually having to leave the bloc, former prime minister Tony Blair said on Sunday.

Headline: On cricket homage, May challenges robotic jibe
Description: Armed with a tupperware box full of home-made chocolate brownies, Prime Minister Theresa May made an appearance on Britain's most popular cricket programme on BBC radio on Friday and took to task those who call her "robotic".

Headline: Farage talks Brexit at German right-wing election rally
Description: Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage received a standing ovation at a pre-election rally of the anti-immigration Alternative for Germany (AfD) in Berlin on Friday, where he was presented as a model of what a right-wing eurosceptic politician can achieve.

Headline: Farage says May might not last until Christmas
Description: Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage said on Friday that British Prime Minister Theresa May might be out of a job by Christmas unless she manages to get her party behind her and take charge of Brexit negotiations.

Headline: Scotland's SNP must come up with 'doable' independence plan after Brexit - Salmond
Description: Scotland's former first minister believes the independence movement has a three-year window after Britain quits the European Union to push again for succession, despite the Scottish National Party's losses in an election in June.

Headline: Dublin rejects British proposal for post-Brexit Irish border
Description: Ireland dismissed British proposals for the Irish border after Brexit as unconvincing on Friday, a day after the EU chief negotiator said they amounted to a demand the bloc suspend its laws for Britain.

Headline: Hard Irish border post-Brexit would be risk to peace - Coveney
Description: A physical border between the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland after Brexit would risk decades of peace negotiations, and Britain's solutions so far are not sufficient, Ireland's Foreign Minister Simon Coveney said on Friday.

Headline: Stop fighting over Brexit and get real, Jim O'Neill tells UK
Description: The British government should stop dreaming about having its own way in Brexit negotiations and start to get more realistic about the likely outcome of divorce talks with the European Union, said Jim O'Neill, a former Goldman Sachs economist.

Headline: May to listen to concerns on EU bill, but is vital legislation - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will listen to concerns from lawmakers about legislation to sever political, financial and legal ties with the European Union, but it is a vital bill, her spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: May's government pushes Brexit bill to avoid 'chaotic' departure
Description: Brexit minister David Davis called on parliament on Thursday to back legislation to sever Britain's political, financial and legal ties with the European Union, saying that opposing the bill would lead to chaos.

Headline: Britain, EU have very different legal stances on Brexit bill - minister
Description: Britain and the European Union have very different legal stances over the so-called Brexit bill London should pay as it leaves the bloc, Britain's Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain considers tough curbs on EU migration
Description: Britain is considering measures to restrict immigration for all but the highest-skilled EU workers, a leaked government document said, plans some companies called alarming and an opposition lawmaker described as "plainly cruel".

Headline: Britons want to see immigration controlled - May
Description: Immigration is good for Britain but the public want to see it controlled as the country leaves the European Union because of the impact it can have, particularly on those on low incomes, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Factbox - Tough hurdles for EU workers to come to UK after Brexit: draft document
Description: A draft proposal for European Union immigration arrangements after Brexit, with measures to drive down the number of lower-skilled EU migrants entering Britain, was published by The Guardian newspaper.

Headline: Brexit bill row to last the length of Brexit talks - minister
Description: A row over how much money Britain should pay the European Union when it leaves the bloc will probably go on for the full duration of the EU exit talks, Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP sees formal political talks starting next week
Description: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) expects formal talks to restore a devolved power-sharing government to resume next week after positive discussions behind the scenes with nationalist rivals Sinn Fein, its leader said on Wednesday.

Headline: British civil servants' union calls nationwide strike ballot
Description: British civil servants will vote next month on nationwide strike action to put pressure on the government to abandon its 1 percent cap on public sector pay rises, their main trade union said on Wednesday.

Headline: BBC launches staff pay review to quell anger over gender gap
Description: The BBC is reviewing employee pay after it was forced to reveal that male stars were paid far more than their female counterparts, damaging the British public broadcaster's image and angering women employees.

Headline: Britain rejects Irish call for role in Northern Ireland rule
Description: Britain on Tuesday rejected an Irish demand for a role in running Northern Ireland if parties there fail to revive a devolved power-sharing government, as unionists said concessions would lead to 'grave consequences" for Theresa May's government.

Headline: Britain could still reverse Brexit, former minister Heseltine says
Description: Brexit could be reversed if economic pain prompts a change in public opinion that brings a new generation of political leaders to power in Britain, former Conservative minister Michael Heseltine said.

Headline: Prince Harry and I are in love, says actress Meghan Markle
Description: U.S. actress Meghan Markle, the girlfriend of Britain's Prince Harry, has said they are in love and happy together, in her first frank comments about their relationship since they became a couple last year.

Headline: UK employers worry about loss of research funding after Brexit
Description: Britain must seek to protect research funding for its universities when it leaves the European Union or risk losing its leading role in innovation, one of the country's main employer groups said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain hopes to work closely with EU on research after Brexit
Description: Britain will set out on Wednesday its aim to work closely with the European Union on space exploration, nuclear research and on developing medicines after Brexit, part of efforts to move talks on to discuss their future relationship.

Headline: Police arrest four, including soldiers, over suspected far-right terrorism
Description: British police arrested four men on Tuesday, including some serving soldiers, on suspicion of belonging to a banned far-right group and planning terrorist acts.

Headline: Scottish government to lift curb on public sector pay
Description: Scotland's devolved government will lift a cap on public sector wages to take account of the rising cost of living, one of a series of policy changes due to be announced on Tuesday, a Scottish government official said.

Headline: UK car sales fall again in August
Description: British new car sales fell for the fifth month in a row in August, the longest run of declines since 2011, a car industry body said on Tuesday, as uncertainty over Brexit and possible levies on diesel cars hit Europe's second-biggest market.

Headline: Chris Grayling does not rule out scrapping public sector pay cap - BBC
Description: A member of Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet on Tuesday declined to deny media reports that the government will soon relax a pay cap for British public sector workers.

Headline: Prince William and wife Kate expecting third child
Description: Prince William and his wife Kate are expecting their third child, their office said on Monday after the Duchess was forced to cancel an engagement due to severe morning sickness.

Headline: Britain says Northern Irish parties running out of time to save devolution
Description: Northern Ireland's political parties are rapidly running out of time to restore a devolved power-sharing government, Britain's minister for the region said on Monday, as he sought to avoid a return of direct rule from London.

Headline: Britain says window to restore Northern Ireland devolution closing rapidly
Description: Northern Ireland's political parties are rapidly running out of time to restore a devolved power-sharing government, Britain's minister for the region said on Monday, as he sought to avoid a return of direct rule from London.

Headline: Hammond warns lawmakers against delaying EU withdrawal legislation
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond urged lawmakers on Monday not to seek to delay legislation that will sever the country's ties with the European Union.

Headline: UK ready to intensify Brexit talks - May's spokeswoman
Description: Britain is ready to intensify Brexit talks with the European Union but nothing has been formally agreed yet, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: Hammond signals support for review of gambling machines
Description: The Chancellor of the Exchequer has indicated he will support the outcome of a review of high-stake gambling machines in betting shops even if it reduces tax revenue.

Headline: UK says defence commitment in Nordic and Baltic states won't waver after Brexit
Description: Britain will pledge on Monday that its commitment to security and defence in Nordic and Baltic nations will not change after Brexit, seeking to reassure states affected by what foreign minister Boris Johnson described as "Russian antagonism".

Headline: May says EU repeal bill best way to avoid Brexit 'cliff edge'
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May warned members of parliament that Britain could be faced with a Brexit "cliff edge" if they failed to back her EU repeal bill, as reports suggested momentum was growing within her party to unseat her.

Headline: EU commission criticism of Brexit talks was 'silly' - David Davis
Description: Britain's chief Brexit negotiator David Davis said on Sunday the European Union had made itself look silly by criticising the British approach to the talks that Brussels said had made little progress.

Headline: Theresa May's deputy urges Conservatives to back EU repeal bill - The Sunday Telegraph
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's deputy urged Conservative lawmakers late on Saturday to back the government's EU repeal bill, warning them not to help the opposition Labour Party, which is planning to seek several changes to the legislation.

Headline: Opposition to push for soft Brexit changes to EU repeal bill - The Times
Description: The opposition Labour Party will propose changes to the government's EU repeal bill to ensure it does not exclude Britain remaining in the single market and customs union as part of a transitional Brexit period, The Times reported.

Headline: Cracking deadlock on Brexit bill may require EU summit talks
Description: A 60 billion euro (£54.95 billion) gulf between the European Union and Britain over how much London owes when it quits the bloc may be the biggest obstacle to a deal on an orderly Brexit in March 2019, officials said after talks this week.

Headline: Davis sees good Brexit deal despite recent tense talks
Description: Britain's Brexit minister told a business audience in Washington on Friday that he hoped talks to leave the European Union would produce a good deal for both sides, although he conceded that discussions were "getting a bit tense".

Headline: Disorderly Brexit chances 25 percent; UK economy to slow further - Reuters poll
Description: The chances of Britain eventually exiting the European Union in a disorderly manner have eased a bit, according to a Reuters poll of economic forecasters, who still say a free trade deal, even if there is a transition period, is the most likely outcome.

Headline: Top British fee-paying schools investigated over exam cheating
Description: England's exam regulator has ordered an investigation into allegations of cheating at two of the country's most prestigious fee-paying boys' schools.

Headline: 'I'm not a quitter' says May, vowing to fight next election
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she wanted to continue as Britain's leader beyond the next parliamentary election, not due until 2022, dismissing expectations she could stand down after Brexit as early as 2019.

Headline: UK and Japan aim for trade deal straight after Brexit-source
Description: (The August 31st story corrects first name of Nissan CEO to Hiroto, not Hirohito in paragraph three.)

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP warns of 'speedy' return to rule by London
Description: Irish nationalists Sinn Fein must compromise if Northern Ireland is to avoid a "speedy" return to direct rule from London, the head of the Democratic Unionist Party said on Thursday.

Headline: G4S suspends nine staff at UK migrant centre, says to investigate conduct
Description: British outsourcer G4S  has suspended nine members of staff at an immigration removal centre while it investigates a BBC report alleging abuse in the treatment of migrants, the company said on Friday.

Headline: Britain cannot be blackmailed by EU over exit bill - minister
Description: British trade minister Liam Fox said on Friday Britain would not be blackmailed into agreeing on the cost of leaving the European Union and urged Brussels to move negotiations on to discuss Britain's future relationship with the bloc.

Headline: Majority of Germans expect Brexit to hurt Britain and EU - poll
Description: Two thirds of Germans believe Britain's exit from the European Union will have negative consequences for the bloc, with only 20 percent seeing the potential for long-term benefits, a Forschungsgruppe Wahlen poll for ZDF television showed.

Headline: Britain 'going backwards' on rights of disabled, says U.N. committee
Description: The U.N. Committee on the rights of disabled people said on Thursday it had more concerns about Britain - due to funding cuts, restricted rights and an uncertain post-Brexit future - than any other country in its 10-year history.

Headline: France's Macron says Barnier only negotiator on Brexit
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron reaffirmed on Thursday his support to EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier as the only point of contact for Brexit negotiations, dismissing talk in the British press that Paris was at odds with him.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP warns of 'speedy' return to rule by London
Description: Irish nationalists Sinn Fein must compromise if Northern Ireland is to avoid a "speedy" return to direct rule from London, the head of the Democratic Unionist Party said on Thursday.

Headline: G4S suspends nine staff at UK migrant centre, says to investigate conduct
Description: British outsourcer G4S  has suspended nine members of staff at an immigration removal centre while it investigates a BBC report alleging abuse in the treatment of migrants, the company said on Friday.

Headline: Britain cannot be blackmailed by EU over exit bill - minister
Description: British trade minister Liam Fox said on Friday Britain would not be blackmailed into agreeing on the cost of leaving the European Union and urged Brussels to move negotiations on to discuss Britain's future relationship with the bloc.

Headline: Majority of Germans expect Brexit to hurt Britain and EU - poll
Description: Two thirds of Germans believe Britain's exit from the European Union will have negative consequences for the bloc, with only 20 percent seeing the potential for long-term benefits, a Forschungsgruppe Wahlen poll for ZDF television showed.

Headline: Britain 'going backwards' on rights of disabled, says U.N. committee
Description: The U.N. Committee on the rights of disabled people said on Thursday it had more concerns about Britain - due to funding cuts, restricted rights and an uncertain post-Brexit future - than any other country in its 10-year history.

Headline: France's Macron says Barnier only negotiator on Brexit
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron reaffirmed on Thursday his support to EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier as the only point of contact for Brexit negotiations, dismissing talk in the British press that Paris was at odds with him.

Headline: EU keeps up Brexit talks pressure, Davis signals cash offer
Description: Britain's withdrawal negotiations with the European Union failed to make the kind of progress needed to move into a new phase in October, chief EU negotiator Michel Barnier said on Thursday after four days of talks.

Headline: Brexit talks make 'concrete progress', UK's Davis says
Description: Talks between the European Union and Britain over its withdrawal from the bloc have made some progress, but EU negotiators need to be more flexible and pragmatic, Britain's Brexit minister said on Thursday.

Headline: Britons gather at dawn to remember Diana 20 years after her death
Description: Fans of Princess Diana gathered at dawn at the gates of Kensington Palace on Thursday to celebrate the life of a woman who transformed Britain and its royal family when she died 20 years ago in a Paris car crash.

Headline: Sinn Fein says Ireland should block EU talks from moving to future ties
Description: Northern Ireland's main nationalist party urged Ireland on Thursday to block talks on future ties between Britain and the European Union as not enough progress had been made on agreeing the status of the Irish border once London exits the EU.

Headline: Despite derision, May might well be able to carry on... for now
Description: It was meant to silence her critics, but by pledging to lead the Conservative Party into the next election, British Prime Minister Theresa May instead unleashed a wave of derision from her foes.

Headline: After North Korea missile, Britain and Japan agree closer security ties
Description: Britain and Japan said on Thursday they would cooperate in countering the threat posed by North Korea, two days after it fired a missile over northern Japan, and will call on China to exert its leverage.

Headline: Britain, Japan discuss possible new U.N. resolution against North Korea -source
Description: Britain and Japan discussed the possibility of adopting a new U.N. Security Council resolution over North Korea, a British government source said on Thursday, after North Korea fired a missile over Japan this week.

Headline: PM May says agreed with Japan to speed up North Korea sanctions
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday she had agreed with her Japanese counterpart to work together to speed up the rate at which sanctions are imposed on North Korea after a missile test earlier this week.

Headline: UK house prices seen restrained; Brexit vote hits London - Reuters poll
Description: British house prices will at best keep up with inflation this year and next, with no rises expected at all this year in London, where the Brexit vote is holding back the market the most, according to a Reuters poll of property market experts.

Headline: Japan's Abe, May pledge cooperation on North Korea threat
Description: The leaders of Japan and Britain pledged on Thursday to cooperate in countering the threat posed by North Korea, two days after it fired a missile over northern Japan.

Headline: Brexit negotiators trade barbs, eying deadlines
Description: British and European Union negotiators exchanged recriminations on Wednesday over a lack of progress in the latest round of talks on Britain's withdrawal, with both sides demanding change to meet looming deadlines.

Headline: Tactics rather than policy shift? Labour surprises on Brexit
Description: A shift in the main British opposition party's stance on Brexit is intended to increase pressure on Prime Minister Theresa May as she struggles to unite her own party and hold on to power after an election setback.

Headline: UK report plans boost for life sciences as Brexit looms
Description: The British government has rekindled its industrial strategy, unveiled earlier this year to prepare the economy for Brexit, with plans to boost the country's pharmaceuticals sector via fresh investments and public-private collaborations.

Headline: British princes mark anniversary of Diana's death with garden visit
Description: Princes William and Harry paid a quiet tribute to their mother Princess Diana on Wednesday, a day before the 20th anniversary of her death that has reignited interest in one of the world's most famous women.

Headline: Juncker blasts Britain for 'huge' unanswered Brexit questions
Description: EU chief executive Jean-Claude Juncker blasted Britain's failure to answer "huge numbers of questions" on its Brexit plans as negotiators held a new round of talks on Tuesday on a divorce due in less than two years.

Headline: UK seeks to rein in boardroom pay with new ratio demands
Description: Listed British companies will have to justify the gap in salaries between their average worker and chief executive under proposed new rules that fall short of Prime Minister Theresa May's initial plan to tackle soaring executive pay.

Headline: EU urges swifter Brexit talks as London seeks 'flexibility'
Description: The European Union's chief negotiator Michel Barnier said on Monday he was concerned at the slow progress of Brexit talks, while his British counterpart David Davis called for "imagination and flexibility" to move on.

Headline: Britain in 'good position' in Brexit talks - May's spokeswoman
Description: Britain feels it is in a good position in Brexit negotiations and wants to agree with the European Union to move on to discussions about its future relationship by October, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Tuesday.

Headline: British police seek information on 30-year-old murder of Palestinian cartoonist
Description: British police on Tuesday launched a fresh appeal for information on the murder of a famous Palestinian political cartoonist in London 30 years ago, hoping someone might feel more able to speak up three decades later.

Headline: A mammoth engineering feat, Scotland's third Forth bridge is ready to open
Description: The Queensferry Crossing, the third bridge in as many centuries to link Edinburgh and the north of Scotland over the River Forth, was formally completed on Monday, concluding the biggest Scottish infrastructure project in a generation.

Headline: EU concerned about slow Brexit talks, Britain urges 'imagination and flexibility'
Description: The European Union's Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Monday he was worried that time was passing without progress on the terms for Britain's departure from the bloc.

Headline: Ireland calls for realism from UK on border issue in latest Brexit talks
Description: Much of the future border arrangements between Northern Ireland and Ireland can be solved before Brexit talks enter the next phase, Ireland's foreign minister said, urging Britain to be realistic in negotiating terms to leave the European Union.

Headline: Labour backs soft Brexit, putting pressure on May
Description: The opposition Labour Party has said it would keep Britain in the European single market and customs union for a transitional period after Brexit, offering an alternative to the government line after months of uncertainty over Labour's position.

Headline: London should rule out 'unthinkable' Brexit no-deal - Scottish govt
Description: Britain should rule out the possibility of leaving the EU without establishing terms of its future relationship with the bloc, Scotland's Brexit minister said on Monday, describing such an outcome as "unthinkable".

Headline: London's Notting Hill Carnival remembers Grenfell Tower fire
Description: Notting Hill Carnival, the biggest street party in Europe, fell silent for a minute on Sunday to remember the more than 80 people who were killed in June in an apartment block fire in the west London district.

Headline: Police arrest second suspect after Buckingham Palace attack
Description: British police announced on Sunday a second arrest in connection with an assault on three police officers by a man armed with a four-foot sword outside London's Buckingham Palace on Friday.

Headline: Britain to urge EU to show 'imagination' in Brexit talks
Description: Britain will urge the European Union on Monday to show "imagination" in Brexit talks and help focus discussion on future ties rather than on a divorce settlement.

Headline: Man with sword injures police outside Queen's palace
Description: A man who assaulted police officers with a four-foot sword outside Queen Elizabeth's Buckingham Palace residence shouting "Allahu Akbar" (God is greatest) was being questioned by counter-terrorism police on Saturday.

Headline: London gears up for Notting Hill carnival, in shadow of Grenfell Tower
Description: It is one of London's most colourful and noisy events - a weekend carnival to celebrate Afro-Caribbean culture in what has become Europe's biggest street festival.

Headline: Slow divorce risks leaving future Britain-EU ties in limbo
Description: Divisions between Britain and the EU over mapping out their divorce will be laid bare in Brussels next week when the two sides meet for another round of talks whose timetable already looks tight.

Headline: Britain says to rule on Fox-Sky advice as soon as possible
Description: Britain said on Friday it had received the additional advice it had requested on Rupert Murdoch's bid to buy broadcaster Sky , and it would decide whether to refer the deal for an in-depth review as soon as possible.

Headline: Semi-automated trucks to hit UK roads by end of 2018
Description: Britain will begin trials of semi-automated, wirelessly connected truck convoys on public roads by the end of 2018, in a bid to find more fuel-efficient ways to transport goods.

Headline: Britain will not pay "a penny more" than it thinks right to leave EU - Johnson
Description: Britain will pay "not a penny more, not a penny less" than what the government thinks its legal obligations are to the European Union as the country leaves the bloc, foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Friday.

Headline: Has 'ambitious' PM May aimed too high with EU demands?
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May always said she would be "ambitious" in negotiating Britain's exit from the European Union, and government documents published this month show the scale of that ambition -- wanting the closest of ties without the costs.

Headline: London gears up for Notting Hill carnival, in shadow of Grenfell Tower
Description: It is one of London's most colourful and noisy events - a weekend carnival to celebrate Afro-Caribbean culture in what has become Europe's biggest street festival.

Headline: Slow divorce risks leaving future Britain-EU ties in limbo
Description: Divisions between Britain and the EU over mapping out their divorce will be laid bare in Brussels next week when the two sides meet for another round of talks whose timetable already looks tight.

Headline: Britain says to rule on Fox-Sky advice as soon as possible
Description: Britain said on Friday it had received the additional advice it had requested on Rupert Murdoch's bid to buy broadcaster Sky , and it would decide whether to refer the deal for an in-depth review as soon as possible.

Headline: Semi-automated trucks to hit UK roads by end of 2018
Description: Britain will begin trials of semi-automated, wirelessly connected truck convoys on public roads by the end of 2018, in a bid to find more fuel-efficient ways to transport goods.

Headline: Britain will not pay "a penny more" than it thinks right to leave EU - Johnson
Description: Britain will pay "not a penny more, not a penny less" than what the government thinks its legal obligations are to the European Union as the country leaves the bloc, foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Friday.

Headline: Has 'ambitious' PM May aimed too high with EU demands?
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May always said she would be "ambitious" in negotiating Britain's exit from the European Union, and government documents published this month show the scale of that ambition -- wanting the closest of ties without the costs.

Headline: Britain to study effect of foreign students on economy
Description: Britain commissioned a report on Thursday on the economic impact of foreign students, part of an increasingly heated debate over whether they should be included in the government's target of reducing migration to the tens of thousands.

Headline: EU citizens leaving UK pushes down net migration after Brexit vote
Description: Net migration to Britain fell to its lowest level in three years in the 12 months to the end of March, with more than half the drop caused by European Union citizens leaving and fewer arriving since the Brexit vote.

Headline: EU worker exodus threatens UK food industry, some leaving already - survey
Description: Nearly half of businesses operating in Britain's food supply chain say European Union workers are thinking about leaving because of uncertainty around Brexit, an industry survey showed on Thursday.

Headline: Prince Harry says Charles 'was there for us' after Diana's death
Description: Britain's Prince Harry defended the way his father, Prince Charles, cared for him and his brother as they grieved for their mother, Princess Diana, in a documentary previewed by the BBC on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain outlines plans to break free of European Court after Brexit
Description: Britain on Wednesday outlined several escape routes from the "direct jurisdiction" of the European Court of Justice after Brexit, one of Prime Minister Theresa May's key aims in talks to unstitch 40 years of EU membership.

Headline: Factbox - Britain's paper on ending EU court supremacy
Description: Britain has outlined its stance on how disputes with the European Union should be resolved after Brexit, in a politically sensitive paper published on Wednesday.

Headline: In error, Britain tells dozens of EU citizens to leave
Description: Britain on Wednesday said it had sent dozens of letters telling European Union nationals to leave the country in error, an embarrassing mistake as the issue of the rights of such citizens in the UK is being negotiated.

Headline: Being 'constructive', Britain outlines ways to end EU court supremacy
Description: Britain will "engage constructively" with the EU to find an agreement on the future role of the European Court of Justice, but the rights of citizens in the country will be protected by British courts, a government paper said on Wednesday.

Headline: The People's Princess, Britons work to keep memory alive
Description: Abdul Daoud spilt most of the cappuccino into the saucer the first time he served Princess Diana, his nerves getting the better of him.

Headline: Princess Diana beguiles the world 20 years after death
Description: From TV documentaries and the private memories of her sons to a slew of new "revelations" and renewed theories about her death, Britain's Princess Diana is once again front page news 20 years after she died.

Headline: Scottish, Welsh govt heads unite to stop "unashamed" power grab after Brexit
Description: The heads of devolved governments in Scotland and Wales agreed on Tuesday to work together to try to set a common strategy to thwart the threat of an "unashamed" grab of parliamentary power by London after Britain leaves the European Union.

Headline: No longer an also-ran, Corbyn hits campaign trail
Description: British opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn is back on the campaign trail just weeks after losing an election, betting that Prime Minister Theresa May's minority government will soon collapse.

Headline: UK air travel could slump if no early Brexit aviation deal - report
Description: Britain's airports could see passenger numbers plunge by as much as 40 percent unless the government strikes an interim aviation deal with the European Union by October 2018, according to an industry report seen by Reuters on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain posts first July budget surplus in 15 years, outlook darker
Description: Britain unexpectedly posted its first budget surplus for any July since 2002 according to official data on Tuesday, welcome news for finance minister Philip Hammond in what still looks likely to be a difficult financial year for the government.

Headline: Britain calls on EU to move Brexit talks forward
Description: Brexit minister David Davis called on the European Union on Sunday to relax its position that the two sides must first make progress on a divorce settlement before moving on to discussing future relations.

Headline: UK to release tranche of Brexit position papers
Description: Britain will issue a cluster of new papers this week to outline its strategy positions in divorce talks with the European Union, ranging from regulation of goods to data protection, the UK's Brexit department said on Sunday.

Headline: Scientist Hawking blames UK government for health service "crisis"
Description: Physicist Stephen Hawking found himself in a war of words with Britain's Conservative government after he said it had caused a crisis in the state-run National Health Service (NHS) and was leading it towards a profit-making U.S.-style system.

Headline: PM May says looking into reports of missing child in Barcelona attack
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday that Britain was looking into reports of a missing child with dual British nationality after a suspected Islamist militant killed 14 people and wounded scores of others in Barcelona.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon says nationalism a difficult word
Description: Scotland's pro-independence First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Friday she wished her Scottish National Party (SNP) had chosen another name when it was founded because of the negative connotations of nationalism.

Headline: Northern Ireland court rules gay marriage ban doesn't violate rights
Description: Northern Ireland's refusal to recognise same-sex marriage does not violate the rights of couples affected, the Belfast High Court ruled on Thursday, in a blow to campaigners in the only part of the United Kingdom that bans gay marriage.

Headline: Brother of suspect in UK model kidnap plot denies involvement - lawyer
Description: A man accused of being part of a plot to kidnap a British model in Milan denied any involvement in the alleged scheme and will fight extradition from Britain to Italy, his lawyer told a London court on Thursday.

Headline: Britain 'confident' of new phase in Brexit talks by October
Description: Britain said on Thursday it was "confident" talks with the European Union would move towards discussing their future relationship by October, in contrast to warnings from the top EU negotiator that the target is receding.

Headline: May says still a lot to do in Brexit talks, yet confident
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday there was still a lot to be done in Brexit talks with the European Union but was confident the two would be able to negotiate a deep and special relationship.

Headline: The Queen sends condolences to victims of Sierra Leone mudslide
Description: Queen Elizabeth sent her deepest sympathies to hundreds of victims of a mudslide in Sierra Leone that swept away homes on the edge of country's capital city in one of Africa's worst flood disasters in living memory.

Headline: Most businesses have not changed strategic planning due to Brexit - Thomson Reuters CFO survey
Description: A majority of businesses are yet to change their strategic planning due to Britain's decision to leave the European Union, a survey of chief financial officers by Thomson Reuters showed.

Headline: Britain seeks Brexit without borders for Northern Ireland
Description: Britain has said there should be no border posts or immigration checks between Ireland and the British province of Northern Ireland after Brexit, in a paper that attempts to resolve one of the most complex aspects of its departure from the European Union.

Headline: Factbox - How can Britain avoid a post-Brexit border for Northern Ireland?
Description: Britain said on Wednesday there should be no border posts or immigration checks between Ireland and the British province of Northern Ireland after Brexit, in a paper that attempts to resolve one of the most complex aspects of its departure from the European Union.

Headline: UK says no new immigration checks planned along Irish border after Brexit
Description: Britain does not plan any new immigration checks between Ireland and Northern Ireland after it leaves the European Union, the government said on Wednesday, adding it was confident labour market controls would allow it to control migration.

Headline: Scottish parliament says 'brute-force' cyber-attack ongoing, has not breached defences
Description: Scotland's devolved parliament is suffering an ongoing brute-force cyber attack but the attack has not breached the assembly's IT defences, it said on Wednesday.

Headline: Dublin welcomes London moves on Northern Ireland Brexit deal
Description: Ireland on Wednesday welcomed what it called significant progress in efforts to avoid a hard border between it and Northern Ireland after Brexit, but admitted any such deal would have to be a one-off.

Headline: Four years without Big Ben's bongs? It can't be right, says PM May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday it could not be right for "Big Ben", the bell in the British parliament's clock tower whose bongs are one of the country's most familiar sounds, to fall silent for four years during renovations.

Headline: UK police arrest man over model kidnapped in Italy
Description: British police said on Wednesday they had arrested the brother of a man suspected of abducting a British model in Milan and threatening to auction her online unless a ransom was paid.

Headline: UK's biggest warship HMS Queen Elizabeth sails into home port for first time
Description: Britain's most advanced and biggest warship, the 65,000-tonne aircraft carrier HMS Queen Elizabeth, berthed for the first time at its home port of Portsmouth on Wednesday.

Headline: In rare rebuke of Trump, PM May says leaders must condemn far-right views
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday there was no equivalence between fascists and those who opposed them, a rare rebuke of U.S. President Donald Trump by one of his closest foreign allies.

Headline: UK says to consider replacing EU peace funds for Northern Ireland
Description: Britain will consider replacing European Union funding for peace projects in Northern Ireland, which advocates say have been crucial in avoiding a return to violence after a 1998 peace agreement, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK inquiry to examine Grenfell Tower fire but not broader social issues
Description: A public inquiry into the Grenfell Tower fire in London that killed 80 people in June began on Tuesday with a mission to examine the cause of and response to the tragedy, but not broader issues such as social housing policy.

Headline: Real thing or just 'fantasy'? Britain proposes new EU customs deal
Description: Britain outlined plans for a future customs agreement with the European Union on Tuesday and an interim deal to ease companies' Brexit concerns, proposals one senior EU official described as "fantasy".

Headline: Man plunges to death at London Stock Exchange
Description: A London Stock Exchange  employee plunged to his death on Tuesday from a balcony on the seventh floor of the exchange's headquarters in the heart of London's financial district.

Headline: Factbox - Britain's proposals for post-Brexit customs agreement with EU
Description: Britain sought to push forward talks with the European Union on Tuesday, setting out proposals for a temporary post-Brexit customs agreement with the bloc and two options for how its longer-term trading relationship could work.

Headline: Britain says there will be no Brexit bill figure by October
Description: Britain will not have agreed a figure with the European Union for its so called Brexit divorce bill by October, Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: Factbox - What is the Brexit divorce bill?
Description: The European Union says Britain should pay a financial settlement, or divorce bill, to leave the bloc because it has financial obligations it undertook while still a member.

Headline: London's Holborn underground station reopens after evacuation
Description: London's Holborn underground station closed briefly on Tuesday after overheating equipment on a train filled a platform with smoke.

Headline: UK hopes not to pay for interim customs deal, Davis says
Description: Britain should not have to pay to have a customs union during an interim period after leaving the European Union, Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK should have post-Brexit customs system in place by early 2019 - minister
Description: Britain hopes to have a new customs system in place by the beginning of 2019, before the country leaves the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis told Sky News on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain says EU is getting 'quite cross' over Brexit divorce bill
Description: Britain said on Tuesday that the European Union's chief negotiator was getting quite cross over the Brexit divorce bill that he thinks Britain should pay but that an agreement would be eventually made.

Headline: Barclays closures add to toll of vanishing British bank branches
Description: Barclays plans to close around 54 branches by the end of the year in an effort to cut costs, further reducing access to banking services for customers in parts of Britain.

Headline: Brexit campaigners launch bid to oust pro-EU Hammond
Description: One of the most vocal pro-Brexit campaign groups launched a campaign on Monday to oust chancellor of the exchequer Philip Hammond from parliament, saying he is part of a plot to stop Britain leaving the European Union.

Headline: Voters sense betrayal in Britain's Brexit heartlands
Description: There is a whiff of betrayal in the air across Britain's Brexit heartlands where many impatient voters fear Prime Minister Theresa May is going soft on implementing last year's decision to leave the European Union.

Headline: London Mayor Khan, ex-mayor Johnson clash over scrapped Garden Bridge
Description: A project to build a pedestrian bridge covered in vegetation across the River Thames in central London was scrapped on Monday with Mayor Sadiq Khan and his predecessor Boris Johnson trading accusations over the costly failure.

Headline: Uber improves conditions for British drivers, adds tips
Description: Taxi app Uber will improve conditions for its British drivers with changes including in-app tipping, after criticism from lawmakers and unions for not giving them more rights.

Headline: 'Big Ben' bell to fall silent for four years
Description: The "Big Ben" bell in the British parliament's famous clock tower will cease its regular bongs at noon on Aug. 21, falling silent for most of the next four years while renovation works are carried out, the House of Commons said on Monday.

Headline: After Charlottesville violence, Britain condemns racism, hatred, violence
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May condemns racism and hatred, her spokesman said on Monday when asked about U.S. President Donald Trump's response to violence at a rally of white supremacists in Charlottesville, Virginia, which killed one woman.

Headline: 'We are ready' says Britain, launching push to break Brexit stalemate
Description: Britain says it is ready to move to the next phase of Brexit talks and set out details of the future relationship it wants with the European Union.

Headline: Scotland's Salmond and Brexit Minister Davis in surprise Fringe double act
Description: Former Scottish first minister Alex Salmond charmed a home crowd at the first of his Edinburgh Fringe shows on Sunday, as he and a surprise guest, Brexit Minister David Davis, both took swipes at Brexit, the prime minister and themselves.

Headline: Britain says Brexit talks should move to next phase, as ministers show unity
Description: Britain said on Sunday that it wants talks with the EU to move on to the next phase, as it set out details of the future relationship it envisages with the bloc and senior ministers presented a united approach to negotiations.

Headline: Britons should be given second Brexit vote - David Miliband
Description: Former foreign secretary David Miliband called on Saturday for voters to be given a second referendum on whether Britain should leave the European Union.

Headline: Brexit opponent says two senior ministers sympathetic to his plans
Description: An influential former British government adviser who has called for a new political movement to block Brexit said on Friday that two senior members of Prime Minister Theresa May's government were sympathetic to his plans.

Headline: Former UK spy chief says encryption 'very positive' despite attacks
Description: A former British spy chief said on Friday that encryption of online communications was "very positive" for the country's national security interests despite the difficulties that it poses for security services attempting to tackle militants.

Headline: Hate crimes soared after UK attacks, but fell soon after - police
Description: Hate crimes in Britain spiked in the aftermath of three attacks blamed on Islamist militants earlier this year but the number quickly dropped in the following days, police said on Thursday.

Headline: Police say modern slavery far more prevalent in UK than thought
Description: Modern slavery and human trafficking are more prevalent across Britain than previously thought as more international gangs realise they can make significant sums from it, the National Crime Agency (NCA) said on Thursday.

Headline: UK says EU offers restricted post-Brexit residency rights to Britons
Description: The European Union has proposed that Britons living in the bloc after Brexit will only have the right to stay in the country where they are resident when Britain leaves, Brexit minister David Davis said in a letter on Wednesday.

Headline: Referrals to UK counter-terrorism scheme double after recent attacks - police
Description: Referrals by members of the public to the British government's counter-terrorism scheme have doubled since militants launched deadly attacks earlier this year in London and Manchester, a senior police official said on Wednesday.

Headline: Gang convicted of sex offences against vulnerable girls in England
Description: A gang of 18 people has been found guilty of trafficking and sexually abusing vulnerable teenage girls and young women for several years in northern England, prosecutors said on Wednesday, in the latest shocking case of its kind in Britain.

Headline: Man arrested over British model kidnapped in Italy
Description: Italian police said on Saturday they had arrested a 30-year-old man suspected of abducting a British model in Milan and threatening to auction her online unless a ransom of $300,000 was paid.

Headline: Stop EU exit 'catastrophe', says UK Brexit minister's ex-chief of staff
Description: Britain's exit from the European Union will be the country's biggest calamity since World War Two, the former chief of staff to Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday, calling for a new political movement to oppose the divorce.

Headline: British model denies kidnapping story was a hoax - lawyer
Description: The lawyer for a 20-year-old British model at the centre of an alleged kidnapping in Italy has denied suggestions that the case was a hoax, after local media raised doubts about her story.

Headline: UK's top judge says government must provide legal clarity on Brexit
Description: Britain's most senior judge has said the government needs to spell out how British courts should interpret rulings from the European Court of Justice after Brexit.

Headline: Let them play - kids glued to phones could save UK, ex-spy chief says
Description: Parents who think they are being responsible by limiting their children's time online should think again: they could be putting their kids and Britain's security at a disadvantage, according to a former British spy chief.

Headline: Brexit negotiations have not begun well for UK, says former top diplomat
Description: Britain's negotiations over leaving the European Union have not begun well due to disagreements among Prime Minister Theresa May's team of ministers about the kind of deal they should be seeking, a former top British diplomat said.

Headline: Cameron's hug with woman in Corbyn glitter cape goes viral
Description: Former British Prime Minister David Cameron has been pictured sharing an unexpected embrace with a pink-haired supporter of opposition Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn at a music festival.

Headline: UK ready to pay up to 40 billion euros to leave EU - Sunday Telegraph
Description: Britain is prepared to pay up to 40 billion euros (36.12 million pounds) as part of a deal to leave the European Union, the Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported, citing three unnamed sources familiar with Britain's negotiating strategy.

Headline: Election failure shakes confidence in May's Brexit strategy - ORB poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's botched gamble on a snap election has shaken public confidence in the government with nearly two thirds of voters now negative about her government's approach to Brexit talks, an ORB opinion poll indicated.

Headline: PM May's spokesman - We do not recognise reported 40 billion euro Brexit bill
Description: Britain does not recognise media reports that the government is willing to pay 40 billion euros ($36.18 billion) to exit the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Government launches review to cut long-term energy costs
Description: The government launched a review on how best to reduce long-term energy bills for households and business on Sunday, prompted in part by concern that high electricity costs could damage industrial competitiveness.
