Headline: EU commissioner sees UK payments continuing to 2020 despite Brexit
Description: Britain will have to keep making payments for long-term programmes to the European Union until at least 2020, even after it leaves the bloc in 2019, EU Budget Commissioner Guenther Oettinger told Germany's Bild newspaper.

Headline: Government sets out tougher guidelines to protect smart cars from hackers
Description: The British government issued new guidelines on Sunday requiring manufacturers of internet-connected vehicles to put in place tougher cyber protections to ensure they are better shielded against hackers.

Headline: Hammond blocks gambling curbs - Daily Mail
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond has blocked government attempts to curb high-stakes gambling machines commonly found in betting shops in order to preserve tax revenues, the Daily Mail newspaper reported on Saturday.

Headline: Irish prime minister attends gay pride event in Northern Ireland
Description: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar attended a gay rights event on Saturday during his first official visit to Northern Ireland, upsetting some social conservatives in the only region of the United Kingdom where same-sex marriage is still illegal.

Headline: UK needs Brexit fall-back position, says ex-BoE governor King
Description: Britain needs to make clear to the European Union that it is prepared to go it alone if it fails to reach a satisfactory deal in Brexit talks, former Bank of England Governor Mervyn King said on Saturday.

Headline: British cyber expert arrested in U.S. gets support from MP
Description: A British cyber security researcher arrested in the United States on hacking charges has gained the support of his MP in England.

Headline: British government flies rainbow gay rights flag over Northern Ireland office
Description: The British government on Friday ordered a rainbow gay rights flag to be flown above its main office in Belfast - Stormont House - to coincide with the largest gay pride festival in Northern Ireland, the only British region where gay marriage is illegal.

Headline: Time to define how Brexit transition period will work, says business group
Description: The British government must stop "dancing around" the details of Brexit and work out what kind of transitional deal it wants with the European Union, lobbying group the Institute of Directors said on Friday, as it set out a raft of possible options.

Headline: 'Three Musketeers' UK attack plotters given life sentences
Description: Four members of a British Islamist militant cell who referred to themselves as the "Three Musketeers" were on Thursday given life sentences in prison for plotting an attack.

Headline: UK acid attack survivors call for tougher sentences
Description: Victims of acid attacks in Britain are calling on the government to enforce longer prison sentences and tighten controls on the sale of corrosive substances, after a jump in the number of cases last year and in 2017.

Headline: 'Three Musketeers' militant cell found guilty of planning UK attack
Description: Four members of an Islamist militant cell who referred to themselves as the "Three Musketeers" were found guilty on Wednesday of plotting an attack in Britain after hashing out their plans on an encrypted messaging service.

Headline: UK sets out new powers to impose sanctions after Brexit
Description: The British government published plans on Wednesday for a bill that would give it the legal power to impose sanctions after it leaves the European Union, including making it easier to cut off terrorism funding and freeze assets.

Headline: Princess Diana's revelations about sex and sorrow to be aired on British TV
Description: Recordings of Princess Diana speaking candidly about her sex life with Prince Charles and her sorrow at the spectacular collapse of her marriage will be broadcast on British television on Sunday.

Headline: 21 EU states compete to host London-based agencies after Brexit
Description: All but six European Union states are bidding to host one or both the London-based EU agencies that will be relocated after Brexit, setting up a competition that could easily escalate into a squabble.

Headline: UK must rescue itself from abrupt Brexit 'disaster', Hague says
Description: Britain is heading towards a Brexit disaster that could amount to the biggest muddle in its history unless finance minister Philip Hammond succeeds in achieving a less abrupt exit from the EU, former Conservative Party leader William Hague said.

Headline: Rudd asks Silicon Valley to do more to counter militants
Description: Britain's home secretary will use a visit to Silicon Valley on Tuesday to ask Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter, and YouTube to step up efforts to counter or remove content that incites militants.

Headline: UK will not cut taxes below European average after Brexit - Hammond
Description: Britain does not intend to lower taxes far below the European average in order to remain competitive after Brexit but rather expects to keep a recognisably European economic and social model, finance minister Philip Hammond said.

Headline: Charlie Gard, 'beautiful little boy' at heart of dispute, dies
Description: Charlie Gard, a British baby who became the subject of a bitter dispute between his parents and doctors over whether he should be taken to the United States for experimental treatment, has died, local media said on Friday.

Headline: British Royal Marine jailed for making bombs for Irish republicans
Description: A British Royal Marine was jailed for 18 years on Monday after admitting that he worked as a bomb maker for dissident Irish Republican groups that violently oppose Northern Ireland's peace process.

Headline: 'Three Musketeers' militant cell found guilty of planning UK attack
Description: Four members of an Islamist militant cell who referred to themselves as the "Three Musketeers" were found guilty on Wednesday of plotting an attack in Britain after hashing out their plans on an encrypted messaging service.

Headline: UK must rescue itself from abrupt Brexit 'disaster', Hague says
Description: Britain is heading towards a Brexit disaster that could amount to the biggest muddle in its history unless finance minister Philip Hammond succeeds in achieving a less abrupt exit from the EU, former Conservative Party leader William Hague said.

Headline: Rudd asks Silicon Valley to do more to counter militants
Description: Britain's home secretary will use a visit to Silicon Valley on Tuesday to ask Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter, and YouTube to step up efforts to counter or remove content that incites militants.

Headline: UK will not cut taxes below European average after Brexit - Hammond
Description: Britain does not intend to lower taxes far below the European average in order to remain competitive after Brexit but rather expects to keep a recognisably European economic and social model, finance minister Philip Hammond said.

Headline: Charlie Gard, 'beautiful little boy' at heart of dispute, dies
Description: Charlie Gard, a British baby who became the subject of a bitter dispute between his parents and doctors over whether he should be taken to the United States for experimental treatment, has died, local media said on Friday.

Headline: British Royal Marine jailed for making bombs for Irish republicans
Description: A British Royal Marine was jailed for 18 years on Monday after admitting that he worked as a bomb maker for dissident Irish Republican groups that violently oppose Northern Ireland's peace process.

Headline: Government divided on free movement after Brexit
Description: Allowing free movement of people after Britain leaves the European Union would not "keep faith" with the Brexit vote, the international trade secretary said, underlining divisions in the government over the issue.

Headline: Hospital that treated Charlie Gard sends condolences to family
Description: The hospital that treated Charlie Gard, the British baby at the heart of a bitter legal dispute over his care who died on Friday, sent its condolences to the baby's parents.

Headline: UK announces fire safety review after tests identify 82 unsafe tower blocks
Description: Britain announced a review of building and fire safety rules on Friday after tests conducted following last month's deadly tower block blaze in London found a cladding system known to be used on 82 buildings breached regulations.

Headline: UK finance ministry's top cat toasts first year in office
Description: Twenty-two mice scurrying around Britain's finance ministry have fallen foul of the chief mouser to the Treasury since he took up residence one year ago with a mission to reduce the government department's rodent population.

Headline: Charlie Gard's parents say hospital denied their 'final wish' for dying son
Description: The parents of Charlie Gard, a terminally ill baby who a judge ordered should be sent to a hospice to die, said Britain's top paediatric hospital had denied them their final wish to decide the arrangements for their son's death.

Headline: Prince William steps down from ambulance job to become full-time royal
Description: Prince William will give up his day job on Thursday when he completes his last shift as an air ambulance pilot before focusing full-time on his royal duties.

Headline: British judge rejects legal challenge to counter-terrorism strategy
Description: A British judge rejected on Wednesday a case brought against the government's counter-terrorism strategy, according to lawyers for the claimant, a Muslim activist.

Headline: Parents of baby Charlie Gard given until Thursday to agree plan for death
Description: A British judge gave the parents of Charlie Gard until noon on Thursday to agree arrangements for his death with the hospital caring for him, failing which he would be transferred to a hospice where his ventilation tube would be removed.

Headline: UK lifts advisory against travel to most of Tunisia
Description: Britain is no longer advising against travel to most of Tunisia, including Tunis and major tourist destinations, the foreign office said on Wednesday.

Headline: Electric cars win? Britain to ban new petrol and diesel cars from 2040
Description: Britain will ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars from 2040 in an attempt to reduce air pollution that could herald the end of over a century of reliance on the internal combustion engine.

Headline: Six student buildings fail cladding fire safety tests
Description: Cladding from six British student accommodations operated by Unite Group Plc have failed fire tests prompted by London's deadly Grenfell Tower fire last month.

Headline: Factbox - The challenges and consequences of moving to electric cars
Description: Britain will ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars from 2040 in an attempt to reduce air pollution that could herald the end of over a century of popular use of the fossil fuel-guzzling internal combustion engine.

Headline: UK to ban sales of petrol, diesel-fuelled cars from 2040 - media
Description: Britain's government will announce on Wednesday that it will ban the sale of petrol- and diesel-fuelled cars from 2040 when all vehicles must be fully electric as part of a plan to clean up air pollution, newspapers reported on Tuesday.

Headline: Parents, UK hospital clash over taking baby Charlie Gard home to die
Description: The parents of terminally ill baby Charlie Gard on Tuesday accused a London hospital of preventing their son from coming home to die, the latest harrowing confrontation in a legal battle that has raised emotions far and wide.

Headline: UK judge to rule Wednesday on taking baby Charlie Gard home to die
Description: A British judge hearing the case of Charlie Gard said he would give his ruling on Wednesday on where the terminally ill baby should be allowed to die.

Headline: Six student buildings fail cladding fire safety tests
Description: Cladding from six British student accommodations operated by Unite Group Plc have failed fire tests prompted by London's deadly Grenfell Tower fire last month.

Headline: Factbox - The challenges and consequences of moving to electric cars
Description: Britain will ban the sale of new petrol and diesel cars from 2040 in an attempt to reduce air pollution that could herald the end of over a century of popular use of the fossil fuel-guzzling internal combustion engine.

Headline: UK to ban sales of petrol, diesel-fuelled cars from 2040 - media
Description: Britain's government will announce on Wednesday that it will ban the sale of petrol- and diesel-fuelled cars from 2040 when all vehicles must be fully electric as part of a plan to clean up air pollution, newspapers reported on Tuesday.

Headline: Parents, UK hospital clash over taking baby Charlie Gard home to die
Description: The parents of terminally ill baby Charlie Gard on Tuesday accused a London hospital of preventing their son from coming home to die, the latest harrowing confrontation in a legal battle that has raised emotions far and wide.

Headline: UK judge to rule Wednesday on taking baby Charlie Gard home to die
Description: A British judge hearing the case of Charlie Gard said he would give his ruling on Wednesday on where the terminally ill baby should be allowed to die.

Headline: Theresa May takes a break from Brexit politics on visit to northern Italy
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May was photographed with her husband Philip on holiday in Italy on Tuesday, the first leg of a three week summer holiday.

Headline: UK hospital says baby Charlie Gard's care cannot be provided at home
Description: The London hospital treating terminally ill baby Charlie Gard told a court on Tuesday that the key obstacle to Charlie being taken home to die was that the invasive ventilation he requires can only be provided in a hospital setting.

Headline: TV personality Edmonds demands $392 million compensation for Lloyds HBOS' unit fraud
Description: British TV presenter and former disc jockey Noel Edmonds has more than quadrupled the damages he is seeking from Lloyds Banking Group to 300 million pounds as he steps up a 12-year demand for compensation.

Headline: England to ban the sale of new 'leasehold' houses
Description: Britain unveiled proposals on Tuesday to ban the sale of new leasehold houses which oblige the owner of the lease to pay ground rent to a freeholder, after concern some buyers are facing sharply increasing costs for years afterwards.

Headline: Government backs plans for new cross-London rail line
Description: Britain's government backed a new 30 billion-pound passenger rail project in and around London on Monday but told the capital it will have to provide more up-front funding for it to get off the ground.

Headline: Female stars call on BBC to 'act now' to close gender pay gap
Description: Some of the most high-profile female presenters at the BBC called on the head of Britain's public broadcaster on Sunday to "act now" to address a gender pay gap that sees it pay its top male star five times more than its best-paid female presenter.

Headline: May to stay as PM until at least 2020, close ally predicts
Description: British transport minister Chris Grayling, one of Prime Minister Theresa May's closest cabinet colleagues, has predicted she will remain in the job until at least 2020 and could even fight another national election.

Headline: New portrait released as Prince George celebrates fourth birthday
Description: Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate released a new official portrait of their son George on Friday to celebrate the young prince's upcoming fourth birthday.

Headline: Brexit transition should include access to EU workers, says senior minister
Description: British firms should have access to European Union workers during a post-Brexit transitional period, a senior minister said on Friday following reports of a cabinet agreement that the EU's free movement rules could continue to apply for up to two years.

Headline: UK launches consultation on new aviation strategy for post-Brexit world
Description: Britain launched a consultation over its long-term aviation strategy on Friday, seeking input on topics from baggage to the environment as it prepares the sector for life outside the European Union.

Headline: Inflation hits UK public finances in June, adding to Hammond's headache
Description: Britain's budget deficit came in wider than expected in June as higher inflation since the Brexit vote forced the government to pay more interest on its debt, driving home the challenge facing Chancellor Philip Hammond.

Headline: Reuters poll - One-in-three chance Britain-EU divorce talks end with no deal: economists
Description: There is a near one-in-three chance Britain and the European Union will have failed to ink a deal when the official divorce negotiation period draws to a close at the end of March 2019, a Reuters poll of economists found.

Headline: Free movement of people to continue for at least two years after Brexit - media
Description: The free movement of European Union citizens to Britain will continue for at least two years after Brexit as part of a transitional deal, British media reported on Friday.

Headline: Britain's royals make pretzels, cox boat race in Germany
Description: Prince William and his wife Catherine made traditional German pretzels and coxed rival teams in a rowing boat race in the southern university town of Heidelberg as part of a three-day tour through Germany.

Headline: Few compromises at Brexit talks, minister says UK can survive without deal
Description: The European Union and Britain offered few compromises at their first full round of Brexit talks which ended on Thursday, and the pound fell on worries that British ministers were prepared to walk away without a deal.

Headline: Factbox - Brexit crunch: Where the battles lie
Description: British and European Union negotiators have laid out their disagreements after a first week of talks on a treaty to disentangle the country from the EU in 2019 while limiting disruption to the economy and people's lives.

Headline: Vince Cable becomes leader of Liberal Democrat Party
Description: Veteran lawmaker Vince Cable was elected unopposed to lead Britain's pro-European Liberal Democrat Party on Thursday, promising to restore the party's influence and use it to argue for a softer exit from the European Union.

Headline: May to start three-week European holiday on Monday - spokeswoman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will begin a three-week European holiday on Monday, with a short interruption to attend an official engagement part way through, her spokeswoman said.

Headline: In beer halls and boardrooms, the Brexit diaspora gets organised
Description: Robert Harrison was enjoying a drink with a compatriot in a Munich beer hall a few weeks before Britain's referendum on leaving the European Union when he realised he and other Britons who stood to lose a lot of rights would have to get organised.

Headline: Parliament to debate EU repeal bill on Sept. 7
Description: Britain will hold its first full parliamentary debate on Sept. 7 on legislation which will sever the country's ties with the European Union, the leader of the lower House of Commons, Andrea Leadsom, said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain's Fox says UK-EU trade deal 'easiest in human history', sterling falls
Description: British trade minister Liam Fox said on Thursday a bespoke trade deal between Britain and the European Union should be "one of the easiest in human history" to reach - although his country could manage without one if necessary.

Headline: Violent crimes up by 18 percent in England and Wales, biggest increase in a decade
Description: Violent crimes such as murder and knife attacks surged by 18 percent in England and Wales in the past year, the sharpest rise for a decade, according to official figures released on Thursday.

Headline: Murdoch made to wait few more weeks for Britain's Fox-Sky decision
Description: Rupert Murdoch will have to wait a few more weeks to know whether Twenty-First Century Fox's bid for Sky will be referred for a lengthy British investigation.

Headline: No touching - Canadian Governor-General breaks protocol with hand on Queen Elizabeth
Description: The Governor General of Canada admitted breaking royal protocol by touching the arm of Queen Elizabeth during an engagement in London, though he said the gesture was motivated by gallantry.

Headline: Fox to call for new WTO trade round
Description: Britain wants a new round of global trade liberalisation at the World Trade Organization (WTO), Trade Minister Liam Fox will say in a speech in Geneva on Thursday, according to an advance draft text seen by Reuters.

Headline: Britain's Fox says UK-EU trade deal 'easiest in human history', sterling falls
Description: British trade minister Liam Fox said on Thursday a bespoke trade deal between Britain and the European Union should be "one of the easiest in human history" to reach - although his country could manage without one if necessary.

Headline: Violent crimes up by 18 percent in England and Wales, biggest increase in a decade
Description: Violent crimes such as murder and knife attacks surged by 18 percent in England and Wales in the past year, the sharpest rise for a decade, according to official figures released on Thursday.

Headline: Murdoch made to wait few more weeks for Britain's Fox-Sky decision
Description: Rupert Murdoch will have to wait a few more weeks to know whether Twenty-First Century Fox's bid for Sky will be referred for a lengthy British investigation.

Headline: No touching - Canadian Governor-General breaks protocol with hand on Queen Elizabeth
Description: The Governor General of Canada admitted breaking royal protocol by touching the arm of Queen Elizabeth during an engagement in London, though he said the gesture was motivated by gallantry.

Headline: Fox to call for new WTO trade round
Description: Britain wants a new round of global trade liberalisation at the World Trade Organization (WTO), Trade Minister Liam Fox will say in a speech in Geneva on Thursday, according to an advance draft text seen by Reuters.

Headline: UK to give update on Fox-Sky merger on Thursday - Labour
Description: The British government will update parliament on Thursday on the next steps in Twenty-First Century Fox's bid for European pay-TV group Sky, the opposition Labour Party said on Twitter.

Headline: 'Shame on you' - survivors of tower block fire berate London council
Description: Furious survivors of the London tower block fire that killed at least 80 people booed the new leader of the local authority during chaotic scenes on Wednesday at the council's first meeting since the blaze.

Headline: U.S. and UK to begin exploring post-Brexit trade - USTR official
Description: U.S. and British officials will meet in Washington on Monday for the first meeting of a new trade and investment working group to explore a possible free trade agreement between the countries after Brexit, a U.S. official said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain, Germany to stay close, Prince William says on pre-Brexit charm tour
Description: Britain and Germany will remain close even after Brexit, Prince William said on Wednesday during a tour meant to shore up relations with EU countries before Britain leaves the bloc.

Headline: No quick results in Brexit talks, negotiators say
Description: British and EU negotiators will not announce major breakthroughs on Thursday in their public account of this week's first round of Brexit talks in Brussels, officials said on Wednesday.

Headline: Factbox - Hail or fail? Five ways to tell if Brexit talks advanced
Description: British and EU Brexit negotiators will say on Thursday how their first round of talks has gone. Here are five things to look for to gauge their progress toward a divorce settlement for Britain:

Headline: UK state pension age to rise to 68 sooner than planned - minister
Description: Britain's state pension age should rise to 68 earlier than previously planned, the government proposed on Wednesday, meaning people born between 1970 and 1978 will need to work an extra year before being able to retire.

Headline: Exclusive - Britain may need fewer than 10 new regulators post-Brexit: government source
Description: Britain will probably set up fewer than 10 new regulators after leaving the European Union, a government source said on Wednesday, offering the first assessment of how officials will tackle one of the most business-sensitive Brexit issues.

Headline: Impact on banks from Britain's vote to leave the EU
Description: Global banks have said they could move thousands of jobs out of Britain to prepare for Brexit, the country's planned exit from the European Union.

Headline: May says Brexit negotiating stance is as strong as before election
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday that Britain's Brexit negotiating position was just as strong as it was before last month's election, when her Conservative Party lost its parliamentary majority.

Headline: BBC pays top male star five times more than top woman
Description: Britain's public broadcaster, the BBC, pays its top male star five times more than its best-paid female presenter, it revealed on Wednesday after bowing to the government's demand to publish the salaries of its highest earners.

Headline: May welcomes BBC move to publish top earners' salaries
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is pleased the national broadcaster has published the salaries of its top earners and agrees that a pay gap between male and female workers must be tackled, her spokesman said on Wednesday.

Headline: May seeks to ease Brexit fears at new business council
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will chair a discussion on Brexit and the economy at the first meeting of a new business council on Thursday, a bid to rebuild bridges with companies concerned over Britain's departure from the European Union.

Headline: Brexit's effect on UK 'will be profound and unpredictable' - Lords committee
Description: Brexit poses a fundamental challenge to the future of the United Kingdom by removing the European Union law that has helped to bind it together, a committee of lawmakers from the British parliament's upper house said on Wednesday.

Headline: End to austerity? Poll gamble exposes rift in Britain's ruling party
Description: An early election was meant to bind the Conservatives to Theresa May's agenda for at least five years, but instead it has badly shaken the governing party with ministers questioning its seven-year pursuit of austerity.

Headline: Brexit on the rocks? 'Halt the EU divorce,' say prominent Scots
Description: Britain urgently needs a national debate on halting Brexit because it threatens economic prosperity and political stability, a group of prominent Scots said in one of the most overt appeals yet to overturn the 2016 referendum result.

Headline: Royal couple meets Holocaust survivors on second day of Poland tour
Description: Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate visited a former Nazi concentration camp in Poland on Tuesday where they heard the personal accounts of Holocaust survivors.

Headline: UK senior lawmakers call on government to disclose Toyota investment reassurances
Description: The British government should disclose what post-Brexit reassurances it offered Japanese carmaker Toyota  ahead of a 240-million pound investment in its English car plant, two parliamentary committee heads said on Monday.

Headline: UK inflation surprises with slowdown, easing pressure on Bank of England
Description: British inflation unexpectedly slowed last month for the first time since October, dousing expectations among investors that the Bank of England might soon raise interest rates for the first time in a decade.

Headline: UK watchdog to crack down on gender stereotypes in adverts in Britain
Description: Adverts depicting girls as ballerinas alongside boys as rock climbers are likely to become a thing of the past in Britain under new rules set out by the UK's advertising watchdog on Tuesday.

Headline: Financial watchdog expects firms to make Brexit moves after year-end
Description: Financial firms are waiting until the end of the year before moving staff and business ahead of Britain's departure from the European Union in 2019, the country's markets watchdog said.

Headline: Show 'strength and unity', May tells ministers
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told her ministers on Tuesday to show the "strength and unity" Britain needs, and to keep discussions private, blaming hostile briefings to journalists on colleagues who are "not taking their responsibilities seriously".

Headline: May tells ministers they need to show strength and unity - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told her top team of ministers on Tuesday they needed to lead a show of "strength and unity" in the country, her spokesman said.

Headline: Britain's cyber security centre says has never certified Kaspersky products
Description: Britain's National Cyber Security Centre said on Tuesday it had never certified products from Russian cyber security firm Kaspersky Lab.

Headline: Lords committee says data must move freely after Brexit
Description: British lawmakers said restricting the movement of EU citizens' data after Brexit would hurt trade and security co-operation, and transitional arrangements should be made by the government to keep information flowing after Britain leaves the bloc.

Headline: London police charge man in connection with acid attack
Description: British police said on Monday they had charged a 19-year-old man in connection with an investigation into a noxious substance attack on a man and a woman on July 4.

Headline: U.S. expert visits London hospital to examine baby Charlie Gard
Description: A U.S doctor offering experimental treatment to a critically ill British baby visited the London hospital where he is being treated on Monday as part of a last-ditch attempt to persuade a judge to keep the boy's life support switched on.

Headline: 'No notes' Davis riles anti-Brexit camp in negotiations
Description: Did David Davis forget his notes? Or does he just have no ideas?

Headline: May to warn cabinet ministers over top-level leaks - PM's spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will remind her cabinet that top level government discussions must remain private, her spokesman said on Monday, responding to a series of reported leaks after recent meetings.

Headline: UK will look to increase punishments for acid attacks - minister
Description: Britain will look at tougher punishments for people who attack others using acid, interior minister Amber Rudd said on Sunday, after a spate of incidents in London in recent months.

Headline: UK government sees need for phased Brexit - Hammond
Description: Senior members of the government are becoming convinced of the need for a phased British departure from the European Union to help protect the economy, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Sunday.

Headline: Liam Fox says Brexit transition period acceptable with time limits
Description: Trade minister Liam Fox said on Sunday he would be happy to accept a transitional period when Britain leaves the European Union but that it must be within a time limit and give Britain the freedom to negotiate its own trade deals.

Headline: EU officials seek sense of urgency as Brexit bargaining begins
Description: EU officials hope the British government shows more urgency about a Brexit deal when its negotiators come to Brussels on Monday for a first full round of talks aimed at smoothing Britain's departure.

Headline: Britain takes step towards Brexit with repeal bill
Description: Britain published legislation on Thursday to sever political, financial and legal ties with the European Union, an important  step towards Brexit but one which the opposition said it would  challenge.

Headline: EU's Barnier briefs May's opponents on Brexit
Description: British opposition chief Jeremy Corbyn and the leaders of Scotland and Wales met the EU's Brexit negotiator in Brussels on Thursday as the London government launched legislation to cut ties with the European Union.

Headline: British peer gets 12 weeks in jail for racist threat to Brexit challenger
Description: A British aristocrat was sentenced to 12 weeks in prison on Thursday for racially aggravated threats to a woman who mounted a legal challenge to the government's plans to trigger Brexit.

Headline: Red shirt for Brexit - Corbyn's Arsenal gift to Barnier
Description: What's red and international and led by a Frenchman?

Headline: UK parliament to begin debate on Brexit laws in September - May's spokeswoman
Description: The British government intends to begin a parliamentary debate on its legislative plan for Brexit in September, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Thursday, after the 'European Union (Withdrawal) Bill' was published.

Headline: May shed a 'little tear' over election failure
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she cried a "little tear" when an exit poll revealed she had failed to win an overall majority in a June 8 snap election.

Headline: Parliament has yet to set date to debate Britain's EU repeal bill
Description: Britain's parliament has yet to set a date to debate the government's legislation to sever ties with the European Union, but the discussion will not be until after the summer recess, the House of Commons said on Thursday.

Headline: UK will not pay a penny more than necessary for EU exit bill - Brexit minister
Description: Britain will not pay the European Union a penny more than it needs as part of its Brexit settlement, junior Brexit minister Steve Baker said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain fleshes out Brexit stance on nuclear, justice
Description: Britain fleshed out its Brexit negotiating stance on nuclear, justice and other matters on Thursday before the first full round of talks with the EU next week, underlining it would quit nuclear body Euratom and the jurisdiction of European courts.

Headline: May shed a 'little tear' over election failure
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said she cried a "little tear" when the exit poll revealed she had failed to win an overall majority in a June 8 snap election.

Headline: UK election jitters push house price rises to 11-month low - RICS
Description: British house price inflation slowed last month to its weakest since just after last year's Brexit vote, but this time domestic political worries played the greatest role, a property industry body said on Thursday.

Headline: Canada to name astronaut Payette as new governor general - media reports
Description: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will name retired astronaut Julie Payette as the next governor general, the acting head of state and Queen Elizabeth's representative in Canada, media outlets reported on Wednesday.

Headline: Electric vehicles could lift UK peak power demand by 3.5 GW by 2030 - National Grid
Description: The growing use of electric vehicles could increase electricity peak demand by 3.5 gigawatts (GW) in Britain by 2030, National Grid said on Thursday.

Headline: Annual Northern Ireland parades pass peacefully despite political crisis
Description: Annual parades in Northern Ireland that frequently trigger sectarian violence passed peacefully on Wednesday with little sign the province's political crisis is increasing tensions on the streets.

Headline: Pro-EU lawmaker Nicky Morgan to head Treasury Committee
Description: Pro-European Union British lawmaker Nicky Morgan was elected on Wednesday to lead parliament's Treasury Select Committee, the watchdog for the finance ministry and the Bank of England.

Headline: UK government declines to publish review on funding of extremism
Description: The British government said on Wednesday it would not publish in full its report on the sources of funding of Islamist extremism in Britain, prompting opposition charges that it was trying to protect its ally Saudi Arabia.

Headline: May orders inquiry into intimidation of election candidates
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May ordered on Wednesday a review  into reports that candidates in June's parliamentary election suffered threats, bullying and harassment.

Headline: Labour market data soothes sterling as Brexit challenges mount
Description: Slightly better than expected wages and jobs data saved Britain's pound from another downward lurch on Wednesday, offsetting a series of political and economic warning signs as talks on leaving the European Union get going in earnest.

Headline: UK household pain evident before election
Description: The failure of British Prime Minister Theresa May to strengthen her government in last month's election -- indeed, to hang on to her majority -- came as a surprise. Perhaps it should not have.

Headline: Spain's royals on state visit to Britain to cement ties before Brexit
Description: Spain's King Felipe and Queen Letizia begin a pomp-laden state visit to Britain on Wednesday to cement ties that have been strained by questions over the post-Brexit future of Gibraltar, a British territory on the southern tip of Spain.

Headline: UK watchdog may intervene as people cash in pensions
Description: People withdrawing retirement savings early has become the norm in Britain, its financial markets watchdog said on Wednesday, highlighting that some may get low returns as a result and intervention might be needed.

Headline: Warning of economic crisis, Vince Cable predicts anti-Brexit backlash
Description: Britain is heading towards a new economic crisis which could raise popular support for anti-Brexit parties, the former business minister and likely next leader of the pro-EU Liberal Democrats said on Tuesday.

Headline: Launching gig economy review, Britain's May seeks to regain authority
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May tried to wrest back control of Britain's political agenda on Tuesday by reviving her pledge to introduce sweeping social reforms at the launch of a report on how to better protect workers in the "gig economy".

Headline: Man convicted over racist threats against Brexit challenger Miller
Description: Britain's Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) said on Tuesday a man accused of making racist threats against investment manager and EU campaigner Gina Miller had been convicted.

Headline: Trump's planned state visit to UK delayed until next year - U.S. official
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump's state visit to the United Kingdom, initially planned for this year, will be delayed until next year, a senior U.S. administration official said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain planning for 'all eventualities' in Brexit talks - May's spokeswoman
Description: Britain is planning for all eventualities in Brexit talks with the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Tuesday when asked whether the government had prepared for leaving the bloc without a deal.

Headline: Britain to hold inquiry into contaminated blood scandal which killed 2,400
Description: Britain will hold a public inquiry into contaminated blood supplied to patients in the state-run National Health Service which killed at least 2,400 people, the government said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK report on "gig economy": principles and proposals
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May tried to wrest back control of Britain's political agenda on Tuesday by reviving her pledge to introduce sweeping social reforms at the launch of a report on how to better protect workers in the "gig economy".

Headline: Deliveroo says restricting "gig economy" could undermine the sector
Description: British takeaway food courier firm Deliveroo said any attempt by ministers to restrict the flexibility of the "gig economy", in which people can work simultaneously for different employers without fixed contracts, could undermine the sector.

Headline: EU money demands for Brexit deal 'seem extortionate' - Johnson
Description: The sums of money the European Union is to demand from Britain as part of its Brexit settlement "seem to be extortionate", British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Tuesday.

Headline: Brexit uncertainty to prolong UK hiring market weakness - PageGroup
Description: Weakness in the recruitment market in Britain could extend over the next two years as uncertainty around Brexit dampens sentiment, the head of PageGroup said on Tuesday.

Headline: U.S. President Trump to visit Britain next year - Sky News
Description: President Donald Trump will come to Britain on a state visit next year, Sky News quoted senior government sources as saying on Tuesday, quashing expectations that U.S. leader would make the trip this year.

Headline: UK's BMW workers accept new pensions deal, ending dispute
Description: British workers at BMW 's Mini and Rolls-Royce operations have overwhelmingly accepted a new offer from the German carmaker on Monday over the closure of its final salary pension scheme, ending a disagreement which had led to strikes.

Headline: May suspends one of her MPs for use of racist language
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May suspended one of her Conservative Party lawmakers on Monday after she used racist language at a think tank event on the implications of Brexit on the financial services sector.

Headline: Facing Brexit challenge, May vows to fight on
Description: Britain's Theresa May will promise to fight on as prime minister and pursue bold domestic reform despite her diminished authority in a speech this week relaunching her leadership after 12 tumultuous months in power.

Headline: British judge looks for new evidence in case of critically-ill baby
Description: The parents of a critically ill British baby have a few days to compile new evidence their son would benefit from experimental treatment in the United States, a judge said on Monday, adding that he would not be swayed by international interest.

Headline: British drugs body to challenge new cost rules in court
Description: Britain's pharmaceuticals trade body plans to go to court to challenge new cost rules for medicines, saying that the new arrangements would delay access to cost-effective medicines and deny treatments to patients suffering from rare diseases.

Headline: Court ruling on UK arms sales to Saudi shows export controls robust - May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May welcomed a decision by London's High Court on Monday to reject a bid to halt billions of pounds of arms sales to Saudi Arabia by campaigners who claimed they were being used in violation of international law.

Headline: Britain should give more rights to 'gig economy' workers, review to say - BBC
Description: A British government-commissioned report is to recommend that those working in the so-called "gig economy" for firms like taxi app Uber, receive rights such as sick pay and holiday entitlement, the BBC reported on Monday.

Headline: 'A damp squib' - EU parliament reacts to UK proposal on citizens
Description: British proposals to guarantee the rights of EU citizens living in Britain would cast "a dark cloud of vagueness and uncertainty" over the lives of millions of Europeans, the European Parliament's Brexit coordinator said.

Headline: Britain's parliament being evacuated after fire alarm - Reuters reporter
Description: Britain's parliament was being evacuated on Monday after a fire alarm was sounded, a Reuters witness said.

Headline: Brexit may never happen, says top Liberal Democrat Cable
Description: Britain's scheduled exit from the European Union may never happen because its main political parties are too divided on the issue, said Vince Cable, a veteran lawmaker bidding to lead the fourth largest political party, the Liberal Democrats.

Headline: Equipment failings hampered London tower block fire rescue - BBC
Description: The firefighters who battled an inferno at a London apartment block that killed at least 80 people last month were hindered by equipment failings including the lack of a high ladder, the BBC reported on Saturday.

Headline: Only politics stands in way of smooth Brexit trade deals - Fox
Description: British Trade Minister Liam Fox said on Friday there were no obstacles to replicating the current smooth trading agreements between Britain and the EU after Brexit, unless "politics got in the way of good economics".

Headline: G20 will urge Trump to rejoin Paris climate agreement - Theresa May
Description: It is possible for the United States to rejoin the Paris agreement on climate change and G20 leaders meeting in Hamburg will urge President Donald Trump to find a way to do so, British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday.

Headline: Finance firms need freedom to choose location after Brexit
Description: Finance firms should not be forced by regulators to change location after Britain leaves the European Union in 2019, Andrew Bailey, chief executive of the UK's Financial Conduct Authority told a Reuters Newsmaker event on Thursday.

Headline: No such thing as 'frictionless' trade, Barnier warns Britain
Description: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier warned British ministers and businesses who are calling for "frictionless trade" with the EU after Britain leaves that is "not possible".

Headline: Police says other people potentially involved in Manchester arena attack - Sky
Description: British police believe that other people could have been involved in a suicide bomb attack in Manchester that killed 22 people at a pop concert in May, and further arrests could be made, Sky News reported on Thursday, citing local police.

Headline: Private not state hackers likely to have targeted UK parliament  - sources
Description: A cyber attack on email accounts of British lawmakers last month is likely to have been by amateur or private hackers rather than state-sponsored, European government sources said.

Headline: Boris wants to tweet like Trump
Description: Donald Trump's approach to politics "has gripped the imagination of people around the world", British foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday, joking that he would like to be allowed to tweet as much as the U.S. president.

Headline: Britain sends in task force to help run council after tower block fire
Description: Britain said on Wednesday it was sending in a task force to help run the local authority struggling to cope with the aftermath of a London tower block blaze which killed at least 80 people.

Headline: May to hold bilateral meeting with Trump at G20 - official
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will hold a bilateral meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump at the G20 summit in Hamburg on Friday, a British government official said on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S. urges power-sharing deal in Northern Ireland
Description: The United States on Wednesday urged Northern Ireland's two major political parties to reach an agreement for a power-sharing government, after talks broke down on Tuesday between Sinn Fein and the Democratic Unionist Party.

Headline: May finds it lonely at the top, but battles on - for now
Description: It's lonely at the top for British Prime Minister Theresa May but she's holding on -- for now.

Headline: May backs hospital caring for critically ill Charlie Gard
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday she was confident the London hospital caring for a critically ill baby would consider any offers of help after his case attracted the attention of U.S. President Donald Trump and the pope.

Headline: Public sector pay must be balanced against living within means - May
Description: Any decision on lifting a pay cap on public sector workers must be balanced against the need for Britain to live within its means, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK car sales fall in June for third month in a row
Description: British new car registrations fell by an annual 4.8 percent in June, the first time in six years sales have fallen for three months in a row as the market cools from record highs, an industry body said on Wednesday.

Headline: Labour calls on government to drop European court red line
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party called on the government to drop its "deeply unhelpful red line" in Brexit talks over the European Court of Justice, saying it should be more flexible to retain access to EU bodies.

Headline: Northern Ireland parties fail to strike power-sharing deal, talks to continue
Description: The leaders of Northern Ireland's two main political parties said on Tuesday talks on a new power-sharing executive in the British province had broken down and no agreement was expected in the near future.

Headline: BoE's Saunders tells UK households - prepare for higher rates: Guardian
Description: A Bank of England policymaker who last month voted to raise interest rates was quoted as saying on Tuesday that he was "reasonably confident" that investment and exports would compensate for a consumer slowdown.

Headline: Conservative MP MacKinlay faces trial over election fraud charges
Description: An MP from Prime Minister Theresa May's minority ruling Conservative Party, will face trial after he denied on Tuesday making false declarations over his spending in a 2015 election.

Headline: Britain's 'bad bank' expects to repay Bradford & Bingley's FSCS loans by March
Description: Britain's 'bad bank', which is charged with winding down the assets of two failed lenders, said it expects to repay a significant part of the loans Bradford & Bingley received when it was bailed out by March next year.

Headline: UK car sales fall in June for third month in a row
Description: British new car registrations fell by an annual 4.8 percent in June, the first time in six years sales have fallen for three months in a row as the market cools from record highs, an industry body said on Wednesday.

Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party called on the government to drop its "deeply unhelpful red line" in Brexit talks over the European Court of Justice, saying it should be more flexible to retain access to EU bodies.

Headline: Northern Ireland parties fail to strike power-sharing deal, talks to continue
Description: The leaders of Northern Ireland's two main political parties said on Tuesday talks on a new power-sharing executive in the British province had broken down and no agreement was expected in the near future.

Headline: BoE's Saunders tells UK households - prepare for higher rates: Guardian
Description: A Bank of England policymaker who last month voted to raise interest rates was quoted as saying on Tuesday that he was "reasonably confident" that investment and exports would compensate for a consumer slowdown.

Description: An MP from Prime Minister Theresa May's minority ruling Conservative Party, will face trial after he denied on Tuesday making false declarations over his spending in a 2015 election.

Headline: Britain's 'bad bank' expects to repay Bradford & Bingley's FSCS loans by March
Description: Britain's 'bad bank', which is charged with winding down the assets of two failed lenders, said it expects to repay a significant part of the loans Bradford & Bingley received when it was bailed out by March next year.

Headline: Northern Ireland executive will not be formed in 'immediate term' - Brokenshire
Description: Progress has been made in talks to restore a power-sharing agreement in Northern Ireland but the issues cannot be resolved quickly enough to form an executive in the "immediate term", Northern Ireland Secretary said on Tuesday.

Headline: Sinn Fein blames May for Northern Ireland talks failure
Description: Northern Ireland's largest Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein on Tuesday blamed a deal between the rival Democratic Unionist Party and Prime Minister Theresa May for the failure of talks to form a new power-sharing executive in the region.

Headline: Three UK health providers have buildings that failed fire safety tests - NHS
Description: Britain's state-run National Health Service said on Tuesday three of its organisations had reported having buildings which had failed safety tests launched after a devastating fire killed at least 80 people in London.

Headline: UK government says to introduce EU 'repeal bill' to parliament next week
Description: Legislation to begin the process of transferring European Union law into British law will be presented to parliament next week, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK energy regulator proposes price cap for poorest customers
Description: Britain's energy regulator Ofgem could cap bills for some of the most vulnerable customers and make it easier to switch supplier in response to a government request to set out plans to help customers on the poorest-value tariffs.

Headline: Trump has no plans for Britain visit in near future - U.S. official
Description: President Donald Trump has no plans to visit Britain in the near future, a senior U.S. government official said on Monday, but he added that the U.S. leader could always suddenly change his mind.

Headline: Bank of England staff vote for first strike in 50 years
Description: Bank of England staff have voted to hold their first strike in more than 50 years in a push for higher pay, a union said on Monday, adding to pressure for an end to tight controls on public sector wages in Britain.

Description: The British government will respond to recommendations on pay increases for teachers, police and some other public sector workers later this year, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday when asked about pressure to drop pay caps.

Description: Britain could abandon an across-the-board cap on pay for public-sector workers such as teachers and nurses if review bodies said higher rises were needed to recruit and retain workers, Environment Secretary Michael Gove said on Sunday.

Description: Britain will withdraw from an agreement that allows some other European countries to fish between six and 12 miles from its coast in a move to "take back control" of fishing policy, Environment Secretary Michael Gove said on Sunday.

Headline: Britain says 181 high-rise buildings have failed safety tests after London fire
Description: Some 181 high-rise buildings have failed safety tests carried out after a fire that killed at least 80 people in London last month, the British government said on Sunday.

Headline: Cabinet ministers tell May to end austerity - Observer
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is under pressure from her ministers to end the government's policy of economic austerity as a new poll shows her popularity has slumped, according to the Observer.

Headline: May could walk out of Brexit talks over exit bill - Telegraph
Description: British business leaders have been told to brace for the possibility that Prime Minister Theresa May's government may walk out of Brexit talks this year, according to the Sunday Telegraph.

Headline: Theresa May's Brexit red lines leave UK negotiator 'hamstrung' - ex-adviser
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is making Brexit minister David Davis's job of delivering Brexit harder because of her "absolutist" approach, according to his chief of staff who resigned last month.

Headline: Northern Ireland power-sharing deal unlikely in coming days, Sinn Fein says
Description: Sinn Fein President Gerry Adams said on Saturday that Northern Ireland's political parties were unlikely to reach a deal to restore the province's power-sharing agreement in the next few days.

Headline: Thousands march for same-sex marriage in Northern Ireland
Description: Thousands of people marched in Belfast on Saturday to demand Northern Ireland join the rest of the United Kingdom in legalising same-sex marriage, a step blocked by the region's largest party, a key ally of British Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: London borough leader resigns after tower block fire
Description: The head of the local council in the London borough where at least 80 people died in a fire in a social housing tower block resigned on Friday after he was criticised for the organisation's handling of the disaster.

Headline: British Airways cabin crew begin two-week strike in pay dispute
Description: Some British Airways cabin crew began a two week strike on Saturday in a prolonged pay dispute, risking further brand damage and travel disruption, although the airline said most passengers would be able to fly.

Headline: Northern Irish political paralysis can't last for much longer, Britain warns
Description: Britain's Northern Ireland minister said he still believes a successful conclusion is possible in talks to restore power-sharing in the province, but that the period without devolved government cannot continue for much longer.

Headline: Prince Charles awarded Order of Canada, country's top honour
Description: Prince Charles has been awarded the Order of Canada, which is the country's top civilian honour and recognises outstanding achievement and service to the nation, officials said on Friday.

Headline: Corbyn sacks MPs over Brexit rebellion
Description: Opposition Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn has sacked three Members of Parliament from his leadership team who defied him by voting in favour of an amendment calling for Britain to stay in the EU's single market, deepening rifts in his Labour party over Brexit.

Headline: Brussels ponders deadly smoke after Grenfell Tower blaze
Description: (This June 29 story was refiled to clarify breakdown of smoke-related deaths in paragraph 19)

Headline: Lloyds misses HBOS fraud payout deadline
Description: Lloyds Banking Group said on Friday it has made compensation offers to only seven of 67 customers impacted by one of Britain's biggest banking frauds, the latest delay in a decade-long struggle by business owners for redress.

Headline: William and Harry re-dedicate grave of mother Princess Diana
Description: Princes William and Harry will attend a private service on Saturday to re-dedicate the grave of their mother Princess Diana on what would have been her 56th birthday.

Headline: Northern Irish political paralysis can't last for much longer, Britain warns
Description: Britain's Northern Ireland minister said he still believes a successful conclusion is possible in talks to restore power-sharing in the province, but that the period without devolved government cannot continue for much longer.

Headline: Prince Charles awarded Order of Canada, country's top honour
Description: Prince Charles has been awarded the Order of Canada, which is the country's top civilian honour and recognises outstanding achievement and service to the nation, officials said on Friday.
