Description: Opposition Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn has sacked three Members of Parliament from his leadership team who defied him by voting in favour of an amendment calling for Britain to stay in the EU's single market, deepening rifts in his Labour party over Brexit.

Headline: Brussels ponders deadly smoke after Grenfell Tower blaze
Description: (This June 29 story was refiled to clarify breakdown of smoke-related deaths in paragraph 19)

Headline: Lloyds misses HBOS fraud payout deadline
Description: Lloyds Banking Group said on Friday it has made compensation offers to only seven of 67 customers impacted by one of Britain's biggest banking frauds, the latest delay in a decade-long struggle by business owners for redress.

Headline: William and Harry re-dedicate grave of mother Princess Diana
Description: Princes William and Harry will attend a private service on Saturday to re-dedicate the grave of their mother Princess Diana on what would have been her 56th birthday.

Headline: Some 149 British buildings fail safety tests after west London fire
Description: Some 149 high-rise buildings have failed safety tests introduced after a deadly tower block fire in west London, a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday while criticising a decision to hold a council meeting on the disaster in private.

Headline: May wins major test in parliament over government plan
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May won backing for her policy programme with a slender parliamentary majority on Thursday in the first test of her authority after an election setback and growing pressure on her Brexit and austerity agenda.

Headline: EU wants joint committee with Britain to oversee divorce deal
Description: The European Union wants to set up a joint committee with Britain to oversee the management, implementation and enforcement of the yet-to-be-reached divorce agreement with London, documents by EU negotiators showed on Thursday.

Headline: Plane kept in London during Buhari's medical leave not costing great amount - spokesman
Description: The cost of keeping a Nigerian presidential jet at a London airport while President Muhammadu Buhari is in Britain on medical leave will not exceed $1,300, his spokesman said on Thursday, denying media reports of much higher costs.

Headline: Northern Ireland talks to continue as London takes stock
Description: The British government will grant Northern Ireland's politicians a few days for more talks after they missed a deadline to restore a power-sharing government on Thursday, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said.

Headline: Ruling that Northern Irish abortion laws breach human rights overturned
Description: A ruling that Northern Ireland's restrictive abortion laws breach human rights in certain cases was overturned by a Belfast court on Thursday, the same day Britain pledged to fund terminations for Northern Irish women who travel to England.

Headline: British government set to reflect over weekend if Northern Ireland deadline missed
Description: Britain's Northern Ireland minister told the province's party leaders on Thursday that he would "take the weekend to reflect" if they missed a 1500 GMT deadline to restore the province's power-sharing government, the leader of the Alliance Party said.

Headline: Northern Ireland parties will not meet talks deadline - DUP
Description: A breakthrough between Northern Irish politicians will not be possible before a 1500 GMT deadline to restore the province's power-sharing government, the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) said on Thursday.

Headline: Limited progress made in Northern Ireland political talks - Sinn Fein
Description: Limited progress has been made by Northern Irish politicians ahead of a 1500 GMT deadline to restore the province's power-sharing government, Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein said on Thursday.

Headline: Labour loses vote on UK austerity, pay cap
Description: The opposition Labour Party lost a vote to try to force Theresa May to change her austerity agenda and increase public sector pay on Wednesday, in the first of many expected challenges to the prime minister's ability to govern.

Headline: British police officer tells how he took on London Bridge attackers
Description: A police officer who tried to stop three militants as they attacked people on London Bridge earlier this month described on Wednesday how he took on the men armed with just his baton despite being repeatedly stabbed and temporarily blinded.

Headline: British consumer sentiment at 10-month low - EU Commission
Description: British consumer sentiment fell to its lowest level in 10 months in June, according to a European Commission survey released on Thursday, although overall sentiment including businesses recovered from a decline in May.

Headline: Britain's progress on climate change is stalling, government advisers say
Description: Britain's progress in tackling climate change is stalling and new strategies and policies are needed to ensure ambitious greenhouse gas emissions cuts continue, the government's climate advisers said in a report on Thursday.

Headline: Ex-police chiefs charged over 1989 stadium disaster that killed 96
Description: Prosecutors on Wednesday announced criminal charges against six people including ex-police chiefs over the 1989 Hillsborough football stadium crush in which 96 fans died, Britain's worst sporting disaster.

Headline: Northern Ireland political talks deadlocked on eve of deadline
Description: Northern Irish politicians were set to negotiate through the night as they remained deadlocked on Wednesday in talks to restore the British province's power-sharing executive with hours to go until a deadline to reach agreement.

Headline: "Last-chance" Cyprus peace talks open in Swiss Alps
Description: Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders began talks on Wednesday aimed at reuniting the island after more than 40 years of division, in what some activists said could be the last chance of a settlement.

Headline: Labour loses vote to lift cap on public sector pay
Description: The opposition Labour Party lost a vote to try to force Theresa May to change her austerity agenda and increase public sector pay on Wednesday, the first of many expected challenges to the prime minister's ability to govern.

Headline: Final death toll from London tower blaze may not be known until next year
Description: It will be months until the final death toll from a London tower block blaze is known, British police said on Wednesday, as Prime Minister Theresa May revealed that 120 other high-rise buildings also had exterior cladding that failed fire tests.

Headline: UK orders sweeping changes to boost transparency of funds industry
Description: Britain's markets watchdog announced radical changes to the country's 7 trillion pound asset management industry on Wednesday, seeking to improve transparency and value for money for customers.

Headline: Factbox - Regulator plans radical shake up of Britain's funds industry
Description: Britain's markets watchdog has announced a broad overhaul of the country's 7 trillion pounds ($9 trillion) asset management industry to help ensure better value for money for investors.

Headline: Turning goodwill into EU/UK border solution 'extremely difficult' - Irish PM
Description: Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said on Wednesday it will be practically and legally "extremely difficult" to find ways to  maintain an open border with Northern Ireland after Brexit, even with the sympathy and goodwill of the European Union behind it.

Headline: May says 120 failed fire tests in tower blocks show wider issue
Description: Cladding on 120 different tower blocks has failed fire tests in the wake of a blaze that killed 79 people in London, showing a widespread breach of British building regulations over previous decades, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: What is May's working majority? Answer: 13 votes
Description: After losing her majority in parliament by betting on a snap June 8 election, Prime Minister Theresa May must rely on a small Northern Irish party to ensure she can pass legislation.

Headline: UK government spokesman says listening to public-sector pay disquiet
Description: Britain's government is aware of voters' concerns about public-sector pay and will see if it can address them when it sets out its financial plans in a budget statement later this year, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK may need Brexit transition period, but it will not be unlimited - May
Description: Britain may need an implementation period to smooth its exit from the European Union but there will be no unlimited transition, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: "Profound implications" if Northern Ireland parties fail to agree deal - Britain
Description: There would be "profound and serious" implications if parties in Northern Ireland failed to agree on the creation of a new executive to govern, Britain's minister for the province said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain looking at creating new body for EU citizens' rights - Sky
Description: British ministers are looking at the option of creating some kind of new body to oversee EU citizens' rights in Britain, Sky News quoted sources as saying on Wednesday, a possible way of overcoming a standoff between London and Brussels.

Headline: Lloyds fraud victims bemoan 'pyrrhic victory' as compensation scheme drags
Description: Lloyds Banking Group  is set to miss an end-June deadline for offering compensation to victims of one of Britain's largest fraud cases, the latest delay in a decade-long struggle by business owners for redress.

Headline: May tells Scotland: take your demand for independence vote off the table
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that Scottish leader Nicola Sturgeon should take a demand for a second independence referendum off the table.

Headline: Hammond warns "petty politics" threaten good Brexit deal
Description: Petty politics pose the biggest threat to a good divorce deal between Britain and the European Union, Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said on Tuesday, warning that a bad Brexit pact could harm the economic interests of both sides.

Headline: George III, George Washington to share limelight in U.S.-UK exhibit
Description: A new exhibition will examine the overlapping worlds of two figures bound together by history on different sides of the Atlantic - King George III and President George Washington.

Headline: Sturgeon postpones second independence vote until after Brexit
Description: Scotland's secessionist leader on Tuesday postponed plans for a second independence referendum until the terms of Britain's exit from the European Union are clear.

Headline: UK says 95 buildings fail safety checks after London tower block fire
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday Britain must hold a national investigation into exterior cladding used on high-rise buildings after all those checked after the deadly London tower block blaze this month failed safety tests.

Headline: Insurance industry warned of fire risk before London tower blaze
Description: (This June 25 story was corrected to add credit to Insurance Post and change reference to Financial Times first reporting the story)

Headline: UK will continue funding EU nuclear fusion project if remains as host - government
Description: The British government said on Tuesday it would continue to fund a collaborative nuclear fusion project with the European Union to 2020 if the bloc extends Britain's contract to host the facility beyond 2018.

Headline: Canadian soldier becomes first female infantry officer to captain Queen's guard
Description: A Canadian soldier became the first female infantry officer to take command of troops guarding Queen Elizabeth's Buckingham Palace residence in London on Monday.

Headline: Ninety-five buildings fail safety tests after London fire - PM
Description: Ninety-five buildings have failed safety tests introduced after at least 79 people were killed in a fire that ravaged a tower block in west London earlier this month, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: Sinn Fein says Northern Ireland billion-pound windfall no guarantee of power-sharing deal
Description: Irish nationalists Sinn Fein said on Monday the money coming in to Northern Ireland from a pact by their pro-British rivals to prop up British Prime Minister Theresa May would not in itself help restore the province's regional administration.

Headline: Citi says May's premiership is not sustainable, UK to have another election within a year
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government is not sustainable beyond a few months and there is likely to be another British national election within the next year, Citi said in a research note.

Headline: May strikes £1 billion deal with DUP to prop up government
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May struck a deal on Monday to prop up her minority government by agreeing to at least 1 billion pounds in extra funding for Northern Ireland in return for the support of the province's biggest Protestant party.

Headline: UK's biggest warship HMS Queen Elizabeth sets sail on maiden voyage
Description: Britain's most advanced and biggest warship, 65,000-tonne aircraft carrier HMS Queen Elizabeth, set out on its maiden voyage on Monday from the Rosyth dockyard in eastern Scotland.

Headline: With housing blocks failing safety checks, May calls for more tests
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May appealed to landlords of high-rise buildings on Monday to allow potentially flammable building material to be tested, seeking to reassure residents after a tower block fire killed 79 people in London.

Headline: May offers to protect benefits of EU citizens living in Britain
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May unveiled details of her plan to protect the rights of EU nationals living in Britain on Monday, saying the government would work to offer them largely the same  benefits as British citizens.

Headline: EU gives cool reception to British offer on citizens rights
Description: The European Union's top Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier responded coolly on Monday to London's offer on EU citizen rights in Britain after it leaves the EU, saying Brussels wanted to get the same level of rights as under EU law.

Headline: Citi says May's premiership is not sustainable, UK to have another election within a year
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government is not sustainable beyond a few months and there is likely to be another British national election within the next year, Citi said in a research note.

Headline: May strikes £1 billion deal with DUP to prop up government
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May struck a deal on Monday to prop up her minority government by agreeing to at least 1 billion pounds in extra funding for Northern Ireland in return for the support of the province's biggest Protestant party.

Headline: UK's biggest warship HMS Queen Elizabeth sets sail on maiden voyage
Description: Britain's most advanced and biggest warship, 65,000-tonne aircraft carrier HMS Queen Elizabeth, set out on its maiden voyage on Monday from the Rosyth dockyard in eastern Scotland.

Headline: With housing blocks failing safety checks, May calls for more tests
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May appealed to landlords of high-rise buildings on Monday to allow potentially flammable building material to be tested, seeking to reassure residents after a tower block fire killed 79 people in London.

Headline: May offers to protect benefits of EU citizens living in Britain
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May unveiled details of her plan to protect the rights of EU nationals living in Britain on Monday, saying the government would work to offer them largely the same  benefits as British citizens.

Headline: EU gives cool reception to British offer on citizens rights
Description: The European Union's top Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier responded coolly on Monday to London's offer on EU citizen rights in Britain after it leaves the EU, saying Brussels wanted to get the same level of rights as under EU law.

Headline: Number of UK tower blocks to fail fire safety checks hits 75
Description: The number of high-rise tower blocks with external cladding in Britain that have failed fire safety tests following the deadly Grenfell Tower blaze has risen to 75, communities minister Sajid Javid said on Monday.

Headline: May tells EU migrants: "We want you to stay"
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told European Union citizens who are already living legally in Britain that she wanted them to stay after the country leaves the EU in 2019.

Headline: Dublin welcomes greater Northern Irish Brexit voice after DUP, May deal
Description: The agreement by Northern Ireland's biggest Protestant party to support Prime Minister Theresa May's minority government could give the province a greater say in defending its interests in Brexit talks, Ireland's foreign minister said on Monday.

Headline: Sinn Fein says DUP, May deal a "blank cheque" for damaging Brexit
Description: Irish nationalists Sinn Fein said a deal struck on Monday by their pro-British rivals to prop up British Prime Minister Theresa May's government provides a "blank cheque" for a Brexit that threatens peace in Northern Ireland.

Headline: Talks with Northern Ireland's DUP on UK government support progressing well - Patel
Description: Talks with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party on a deal to prop up Britain's minority government in parliament are "progressing in the right way", the international development secretary, Priti Patel, said on Sunday.

Headline: Britain to crack down on militant, criminal financing
Description: Britain will bring in new rules on Monday to crack down on funds used to finance organised crime and terrorism, requiring businesses such as banks, estate agents, accountants and payment firms to carry out more checks on money flows.

Headline: Davis 'pretty sure' he'll get good deal to leave EU
Description: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis said on Sunday he was "pretty sure" he could negotiate a good deal to leave the European Union, something that would require a transitional arrangement for around one or two years.

Headline: Corbyn puts politics centre stage at Glastonbury Festival
Description: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn got a rock star reception at Glastonbury Festival on Saturday, telling a headliner-sized crowd that millions of young people who voted for him would not be silenced or sidelined.

Headline: Brexit commission needed to draw poison from debate - Archbishop
Description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, called on Prime Minister Theresa May on Sunday to set up a cross-party commission to "draw much of the poison" from the debate over Britain's decision to exit the European Union.

Headline: Some UK ministers want Hammond as caretaker PM - Sunday Times
Description: Some leading members of Britain's ruling Conservative Party want Chancellor Philip Hammond to become prime minister, replacing Theresa May and steering the country through the Brexit process, the Sunday Times reported.

Headline: London tower blocks evacuated as 34 buildings fail fire tests
Description: Britain said 34 high-rise apartment blocks had failed fire safety checks carried out after the deadly Grenfell Tower blaze, including several in north London where residents were forced to evacuate amid chaotic scenes.

Headline: Firefighters battle blaze at low-rise building in east London
Description: Ten fire engines and 72 firefighters were battling a blaze in east London on Saturday after flames engulfed a third-floor apartment in a low-rise block of buildings, injuring one man who was taken to hospital.

Headline: British lawmakers hit by 'sustained' cyber attack
Description: Britain's parliament was hit by a "sustained and determined" cyber attack on Saturday designed to identify weak email passwords, just over a month after a ransomware worm crippled parts of the country's health service.

Headline: Arconic knowingly supplied flammable panels for use in tower - emails
Description: Six emails sent by and to an Arconic Inc  sales manager raise questions about why the company supplied combustible cladding to a distributor for use at Grenfell Tower, despite publicly warning such panels were a fire risk for tall buildings.

Headline: Police brace for trouble as far-right and anti-racist groups protest
Description: Hundreds of police officers lined the streets of London and Birmingham on Saturday to prevent far-right demonstrators from clashing with rival anti-fascism groups on a day of protest following deadly attacks in Britain.

Headline: Show some patriotism, Leadsom tells broadcasters over Brexit
Description: A prominent Brexit campaigner and leading member of Britain's government has scolded a BBC presenter for showing a lack of patriotism when asked why the country was in such political turmoil.

Headline: Government says 27 apartment blocks fail fire safety tests
Description: Twenty seven high-rise apartment blocks have failed fire cladding safety tests that were launched in the wake of the Grenfell Tower blaze which killed 79 people, the British government said on Saturday.

Headline: May defends Brexit rights offer in face of EU doubts
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May defended her offer to let millions of EU citizens stay in Britain after Brexit as fellow EU leaders responded coolly on Friday to her opening move in negotiations on Britain's withdrawal.

Headline: Tusk says British offer on expats' rights "below expectations"
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk said on Friday the offer Prime Minister Theresa May presented to other European Union leaders for safeguarding expatriates' rights after Brexit was "below expectations".

Headline: May welcomes Trump's pick for U.S. ambassador: spokeswoman
Description: The planned appointment of National Football League team owner Woody Johnson as U.S. ambassador to London shows President Donald Trump's commitment to close ties with Britain, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Friday.

Headline: Offer to let EU citizens stay is fair, insists May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May defended her offer to guarantee EU citizens living in Britain broadly the same rights as Britons on Friday, saying differences could be overcome by a "constructive" attitude to Brexit talks.

Headline: Schaeuble says British were "deceived" in Brexit campaign
Description: British people were "endlessly lied to and deceived" in last year's Brexit referendum campaign, German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said on Friday.

Headline: Man charged with terrorism-related murder in London van attack
Description: A man suspected of driving a van at Muslim worshippers leaving a London mosque has been charged with terrorism-related murder and attempted murder, British police said on Friday.

Headline: Whirlpool says working with Britain after Hotpoint fridge freezer sparked London blaze
Description: Whirlpool on Friday said it was working with British authorities investigating a deadly blaze in a London tower block after police said one of its Hotpoint fridge freezers sparked the fire.

Headline: UK orders immediate examination into Hotpoint fridge after London fire
Description: Britain said on Friday it had ordered an immediate examination of a Hotpoint fridge freezer model after police said a deadly London tower block fire began in one such appliance.

Headline: Britain's finance industry warns of threat from Brexit law changes
Description: Britain's finance industry will warn the government next week to limit ministers' powers to change legislation when it begins the mammoth task of converting European Union laws into domestic legislation in preparation for its exit from the bloc, according to a draft report seen by Reuters.

Headline: Hinkley plant could cost 30 billion pounds in electricity payment top-ups - watchdog
Description: Britain's deal with EDF to build the Hinkley Point C nuclear plant is risky and could lead to requests for more cash and electricity payment top-ups worth 30 billion pounds, a parliamentary watchdog said on Friday.

Headline: Labour leader Corbyn overtakes PM May in YouGov poll
Description: Britain's opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has overtaken Theresa May for the first time as voters' choice for who would make the best prime minister, a YouGov poll for The Times newspaper showed.

Headline: Good start, not enough - EU leaders mull May's Brexit offer
Description: Theresa May offered fellow EU leaders a "fair" deal on Thursday for compatriots living in Britain after Brexit, though her peers sounded sceptical and demanded more detail from a prime minister weakened by an electoral misfire two weeks ago.

Headline: With 'Eurovision' vote, EU agencies to leave London
Description: European Union leaders will decide this autumn where to move EU banking and medicines agencies that they are pulling out of London due to Brexit, using a voting system some liken to the Eurovision song contest.

Headline: Merkel says May's offer on expats 'good start' but many questions remain
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel described British Prime Minister Theresa May's offer on the rights of EU citizens after Brexit as "a good start" but said many other issues related to Britain's departure from the bloc still need to be resolved.

Headline: After London fire, 600 tower blocks must be tested for flammable cladding
Description: The government is urgently conducting safety checks on an estimated 600 high-rise buildings in England which have exterior cladding panels after at least 79 people died when fire consumed a London tower block last week, officials said on Thursday.

Headline: U.N. asks international court to advise on Chagos; Britain opposed
Description: The United Nations General Assembly asked the International Court of Justice on Thursday to give an advisory opinion on the legal consequences of Britain's separation of the Chagos archipelago from Mauritius more than 50 years ago.

Headline: Brexit is lose-lose for all, but especially for Britain - EU's Moscovici
Description: Britain's decision to quit the European Union is a lose-lose situation for all of Europe, but especially for Britain, the EU's Economic and Financial Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici said on Thursday.

Headline: May says will tell EU of plan to protect civil rights after Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she would tell fellow EU leaders on Thursday of her plans to protect the rights of their citizens living in Britain after Brexit and called the start of negotiations with the bloc "very constructive".

Headline: No royal wants to be king or queen, Prince Harry says
Description: Prince Harry said no one in Britain's royal family wants to be king or queen and criticised a decision to force him to parade behind his mother Princess Diana's coffin after her death in 1997, according to an interview with a U.S. magazine.

Headline: At EU summit, Macron pleads for limits to foreign takeovers
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron vowed on Thursday to convince China's closest allies in Europe that curbing foreign takeovers in strategic industries was in their interest, warning EU governments not to be naive in global trade.

Headline: "Imagine there's no Brexit" - EU boss channels Lennon
Description: Since this month's election, many British voices have joined a debate on how or even if Brexit may happen; on Thursday, one EU executive added that of John Lennon, sparking a round of more and less musical replies.

Headline: Highlights - Brexit, trade dominate EU leaders' meeting
Description: European Union leaders are meeting in Brussels on Thursday and Friday to discuss a broad range of issues from defence and security, to Brexit, trade, climate and migration.

Headline: London mayor calls on UK to retain single market membership after Brexit
Description: London mayor Sadiq Khan called on Prime Minister Theresa May to seek continued access to the European Union's single market as part of any Brexit deal.

Headline: Man died of injuries in van attack on Muslims in London - police
Description: Police said on Thursday the cause of death of a man at the scene of a van attack on Muslim worshippers in London this week was his multiple injuries.

Headline: Shhh...EU leaders try to take migration feud off table, for now
Description: European Union leaders meeting in Brussels will try to gloss over their feud about who takes in refugees, a change of tactic that some diplomats have linked to Germany's election in September.

Headline: UK faces shortage of seasonal workers for fruit, vegetable harvest
Description: Britain is facing a shortage of seasonal workers this year to harvest fruit and vegetables linked to the decision to leave the European Union and the related weakness of sterling, according to a survey issued by the National Farmers Union.

Headline: UK government expects Scotland to support EU repeal bill
Description: The British government expects Scotland to support a repeal bill which will shift European Union legislation into British law as part of the Brexit process, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Thursday.

Headline: England has 600 buildings with similar cladding to London blaze tower - May's spokeswoman
Description: An estimated 600 buildings in England have cladding similar to that used at the Grenfell Tower block where a devastating blaze killed at least 79 people, a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: Brexit uncertainty is hurting business investment - Hammond
Description: Large amounts of business investment is being postponed because of uncertainty over the future outcome of Brexit negotiations so Britain should seek clarity as early as possible over a transition arrangement, Chancellor Philip Hammond said.

Headline: Prince Philip has left London hospital, Buckingham Palace says
Description: Prince Philip, the 96-year-old husband of Britain's Queen Elizabeth, was discharged from hospital on Thursday after treatment for an infection.

Headline: Very good chance May to get deal on propping up government by Thursday - DUP
Description: There is a very good chance that British Prime Minister Theresa May will strike a deal with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party by next Thursday to prop up her minority government, a senior DUP lawmaker said on Thursday.

Headline: Government confident of deal with Northern Ireland's DUP - Hammond
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said he was confident Prime Minister Theresa May will strike a deal with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party to gain support for her minority government.

Headline: May will cut corporation tax to encourage economic growth
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday her government would continue to cut corporation tax to encourage businesses to invest in Britain and help the economy grow.

Headline: May still to be PM at year end - Hammond
Description: Theresa May will still be British leader at the end of this year, finance minister Philip Hammond said on Thursday.

Headline: After deadly London tower block fire, local council chief resigns
Description: The chief executive of a London borough where a tower block fire killed at least 79 people in Britain's worst blaze since World War Two has resigned.

Headline: Talks to support Conservatives making progress, DUP says
Description: Talks between the Conservatives and the small Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) to prop up Prime Minister Theresa May's government made progress on Wednesday, DUP lawmaker Jeffrey Donaldson said.

Headline: May apologises for London fire failures as UK secures homes for victims
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May apologised on Wednesday for the state's failure to support those people who survived the massive London tower block fire, and the government secured its first tranche of new homes for displaced residents.

Headline: Prince Philip to spend second night in hospital
Description: Prince Philip, the 96-year-old husband of Queen Elizabeth, will spend a second night in hospital on Wednesday for treatment for an infection but remains in "good spirits", Buckingham Palace said.

Headline: Serious Fraud Office wins reprieve after May fails to mention abolition plan
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Wednesday left plans to abolish the Serious Fraud Office (SFO) out of her government's two-year programme in an omission lawyers said could signal an end to the controversial pledge.

Headline: May promises to listen harder on Brexit - Queen's Speech
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May promised on Wednesday to listen more closely to business concerns about Britain leaving the European Union as she set out a Brexit-focused government programme, pared back to reflect her weakened authority.

Headline: Foreign Secretary Johnson says Trump's visit to Britain will go ahead
Description: A planned state visit by U.S. President Donald Trump to Britain will go ahead although no date for the trip has been fixed, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Wednesday following local media reports that it had been postponed.

Headline: Factbox - What's in and what's out in PM's Queen's Speech?
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May outlined her government plan on Wednesday, promising to secure the best possible Brexit deal that secures the "maximum possible support" as Britain prepares to leave the European Union.

Headline: Britain will consult more intensively with business over Brexit
Description: Britain's government will consult more intensively with businesses and others to "test and validate" its strategy to leave the European Union and build support among companies, its policy document said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK says will have powers to intervene in foreign takeovers of infrastructure
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government said it would be able to intervene in any takeover of Britain's critical infrastructure by a foreign owner that could affect national security.

Headline: U.S. Trump's visit not mentioned in Queen's speech on government policy
Description: There was no mention of a planned visit by U.S. President Donald Trump in the Queen's speech on Wednesday, when the British monarch set out the government's programme for the next two years.

Headline: UK to intervene in foreign takeovers of critical infrastructure
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May plans to give her government the powers to intervene in the takeover of any critical infrastructure by a foreign buyer to enable it to protect national security.

Headline: UK considering how to tackle household energy prices
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government said it remained committed to helping consumers hit by the most expensive energy tariffs, but had not decided how to intervene in the market and did not mention a price cap when setting out policy objectives.

Headline: EU sure about that hat, your majesty?
Description: Coincidence or a subliminal message? Britain's Queen Elizabeth stirred up social media on Wednesday when she opened parliament in a hat looking very much like a European Union flag.

Headline: May's deal with DUP unlikely this week - DUP source
Description: A deal to prop up British Prime Minister Theresa May's minority government is not likely this week though talks with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) to support her government are continuing, a DUP source told Reuters.

Headline: Rebels among ruling Conservatives to scupper 'no-deal' Brexit: media
Description: Lawmakers in Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative party believe they can stop Britain leaving the European Union without a deal if such a situation should arise, news media reported on Tuesday.

Headline: May confident of securing support for "broad" agenda
Description: Britain's government presented a "broad programme" on Wednesday and is confident that parliament will support it, a spokesman for Theresa May said, in a clear nod to the watered down agenda presented by a weakened prime minister.

Headline: After tower inferno, UK plans to create victims' advocate role
Description: The British government plans to introduce a public advocate who will act for bereaved families after any disaster, it announced on Wednesday, a week after a catastrophic fire killed 79 people at a social housing tower block in London.

Headline: UK government drops unpopular policy changes to schools, social care
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government dropped a raft of policy proposals for sectors including education and social care that were unpopular during the recent election campaign.

Headline: UK government's priority is to win best possible Brexit deal
Description: Queen Elizabeth said on Wednesday the priority for Prime Minister Theresa May's government was to secure the best possible Brexit deal for Britain and that it would seek to win the widest possible consensus on the EU exit terms.

Headline: UK budget deficit narrows in May, bringing brief respite to Hammond
Description: Britain's budget deficit narrowed last month, helped by a recovery in value-added tax receipts, giving Chancellor Philip Hammond some respite ahead of an expected increase in borrowing later this year.

Headline: Talks with Northern Irish DUP may take time, no sticking point - minister
Description: There is no one sticking point in talks between British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party but a deal to support May's minority government could take some time, her deputy said on Wednesday.

Headline: EU citizens to register in post-Brexit UK residency scheme  - Guardian
Description: The UK government will start a registration process to gauge the interest of European Union citizens in British residency as the country leaves the EU, The Guardian newspaper reported on Tuesday.

Headline: After tower inferno, UK plans to create victims' advocate role
Description: The British government plans to introduce a public advocate who will act for bereaved families after any disaster, it announced on Wednesday, a week after a catastrophic fire killed 79 people at a social housing tower block in London.

Headline: UK government drops unpopular policy changes to schools, social care
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government dropped a raft of policy proposals for sectors including education and social care that were unpopular during the recent election campaign.

Headline: UK government's priority is to win best possible Brexit deal
Description: Queen Elizabeth said on Wednesday the priority for Prime Minister Theresa May's government was to secure the best possible Brexit deal for Britain and that it would seek to win the widest possible consensus on the EU exit terms.

Headline: UK budget deficit narrows in May, bringing brief respite to Hammond
Description: Britain's budget deficit narrowed last month, helped by a recovery in value-added tax receipts, giving Chancellor Philip Hammond some respite ahead of an expected increase in borrowing later this year.

Headline: Talks with Northern Irish DUP may take time, no sticking point - minister
Description: There is no one sticking point in talks between British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party but a deal to support May's minority government could take some time, her deputy said on Wednesday.

Headline: EU citizens to register in post-Brexit UK residency scheme  - Guardian
Description: The UK government will start a registration process to gauge the interest of European Union citizens in British residency as the country leaves the EU, The Guardian newspaper reported on Tuesday.

Headline: May says will consult widely on Brexit, but Britain will leave EU
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that her government was committed to leaving the European Union and would listen to others' views while delivering a Brexit that commanded "maximum public support".

Headline: London community shows solidarity after van attack on Muslims
Description: Around 200 people of all faiths gathered in front of London's Finsbury Park Mosque on Tuesday to show solidarity after a van ploughed into worshippers in a suspected attack on a Muslim prayer-gathering during Ramadam.

Headline: Soros says Britain nearing tipping point, may reverse Brexit
Description: George Soros, the billionaire who earned fame by betting against the pound in 1992, said Britain was approaching a tipping point that would see the economy slow to such an extent that Brexit might even be reversed.

Headline: May's talks to stay in power with Northern Irish DUP not going as expected - DUP sources
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's talks on securing the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) to prop up her minority government are not going as expected, sources in the DUP said on Tuesday.

Headline: Hammond says challenge to avoid 'cliff-edge' Brexit
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said on Tuesday the world's fifth-biggest economy faced tough times as it tries to avoid a damaging "cliff-edge" departure from the European Union.

Headline: Deal between Conservatives and DUP possible this week, DUP source says
Description: The small Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party could agree a deal this week to prop up Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative party after it lost its parliamentary majority in a snap election earlier this month, a DUP source said on Tuesday.

Headline: Merkel urges EU to stick together after Brexit talks launched
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged the European Union's remaining 27 members on Tuesday to stick together during talks on Britain's exit from the bloc, which began on Monday.

Headline: Man arrested near parliament charged with possessing offensive weapon
Description: A man arrested outside the British parliament in central London has been charged with possession of an offensive weapon and assaulting an officer, police said on Tuesday.

Headline: Talkin' 'bout my generation: stark age divide in UK election
Description: Britons are politically more divided by age than at any time over the past four decades, with a surge in support for the opposition Labour Party among younger voters the key factor in a shock election result, pollster Ipsos Mori said on Tuesday.

Headline: Banks need new UK-EU regulatory process after Brexit, says Hammond
Description: British and European Union banks need a new system to let them do business with each other after Brexit to avoid splitting markets, Britain's finance minister Philip Hammond said on Tuesday.

Headline: Ofgem cuts subsidies for small-scale power producers
Description: Britain's energy regulator Ofgem said on Tuesday it will reduce subsidies to some small-scale power producers that provide back-up during peak demand, a move it previously said would cut household electricity bills by about 20 pounds a year.

Headline: Tories confident of sensible deal with Northern Irish DUP - minister
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party is confident of securing a "sensible" deal with the small Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), Transport Secretary Chris Grayling said on Tuesday.

Headline: Imam stops angry Muslims assailing London van suspect
Description: An imam intervened to stop local residents from beating a man accused of driving into people on Monday outside a London mosque after Ramadan prayers, and one official said "his bravery and courage" potentially saved the man's life.

Headline: Van rams Muslim worshippers in London, PM May condemns 'sickening' attack
Description: A van ploughed into worshippers near a London mosque in the early hours of Monday, injuring 11 people, two of them seriously, in what Prime Minister Theresa May said was a sickening, terrorist attack on Muslims.

Headline: Talkin' 'bout my generation: stark age divide in UK election
Description: Britons are politically more divided by age than at any time over the past four decades, with a surge in support for the opposition Labour Party among younger voters the key factor in a shock election result, pollster Ipsos Mori said on Tuesday.

Description: British and European Union banks need a new system to let them do business with each other after Brexit to avoid splitting markets, Britain's finance minister Philip Hammond said on Tuesday.

Description: Britain's energy regulator Ofgem said on Tuesday it will reduce subsidies to some small-scale power producers that provide back-up during peak demand, a move it previously said would cut household electricity bills by about 20 pounds a year.

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party is confident of securing a "sensible" deal with the small Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), Transport Secretary Chris Grayling said on Tuesday.
