Description: A van ploughed into worshippers near a London mosque in the early hours of Monday, injuring 11 people, two of them seriously, in what Prime Minister Theresa May said was a sickening, terrorist attack on Muslims.

Headline: Imam stops angry Muslims assailing London van suspect
Description: An imam intervened to stop local residents from beating a man accused of driving into people on Monday outside a London mosque after Ramadan prayers, and one official said "his bravery and courage" potentially saved the man's life.

Headline: With the clock ticking, Britain, EU play up chance of deal
Description: The British and EU Brexit negotiators agreed how to organise talks on Britain's divorce at a first meeting in Brussels on Monday, where both sides stressed goodwill but also the huge complexity and tight deadline.

Headline: Britons cry for London fire victims as death toll rises to 79
Description: The death toll from a fire that ravaged a London tower block last week has risen to 79, police said on Monday, as the government tried to show it was improving its handling of a tragedy that has angered the public.

Headline: White House offers support after attack near London mosque
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump is receiving regular updates on an attack near a London mosque from his senior advisers, who are in contact with their British counterparts, the White House said on Monday.

Headline: Hinkley Point likely to be only new UK nuclear plant - SSE CEO
Description: The head of one of Britain's top utilities said on Monday that EDF's planned nuclear power station at Hinkley Point is likely to be the only one to go ahead in the UK.

Headline: CBI sees progress on getting business groups formal Brexit role
Description: British business groups are making progress in persuading the government to grant them a formal role in future trade talks around Brexit, the head of the Confederation of British Industry, an employers group, said on Monday.

Headline: Britain says will be "positive and constructive" in Brexit talks
Description: The chief Brexit negotiators of the European Union and Britain began talks on Monday by stressing the need to quickly tackle uncertainties in the process and underlining their constructive attitude to reach a deal that is good for all.

Headline: UK to target "deep partnership" with EU in Brexit talks - Johnson
Description: British Foreign Minister Boris Johnson said Brexit talks set to begin on Monday should aim to prepare the ground for a "deep and special partnership" that London wants with the European Union.

Headline: Man behind mosque attack not known to security services - minister
Description: A man who drove a van into worshippers near a London mosque on Monday was not known to the security services in terms of far-right extremism, British minister Ben Wallace said.

Headline: UK police arrest man at station, say no terror link
Description: Police said they arrested a man outside London's Paddington Station on Monday but added that the incident was not terrorism-related, a few hours after a van ploughed into worshippers near a mosque in the British capital.

Headline: May visits London mosque after attack
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May visited the Finsbury Park mosque in north London near the scene of an attack where a van ploughed into worshippers on Monday.

Headline: Merkel wants good Brexit deal that works for both sides
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said she wanted a "good agreement" for both Britain and the European Union in the Brexit negotiations that started on Monday.

Headline: May says attack on Muslims near mosque is "sickening"
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said hatred and evil would never succeed after a van ploughed into worshippers near a London mosque in a deliberate attack on Muslims as they left prayers at mosques in north London on Monday.

Headline: May is leading UK through challenging times - Downing Street
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is leading the country through "incredibly challenging times," her spokeswoman said on Monday when asked about media speculation that May might face a challenge from within her Conservative Party.

Headline: In Brexit boost, Jaguar Land Rover to hire 5,000 staff
Description: Britain's biggest carmaker Jaguar Land Rover (JLR)  will hire 5,000 staff as it boosts its skills in autonomous and electric technology, a welcome business endorsement as Prime Minister Theresa May starts Brexit talks after a botched election.

Headline: UK police arrest man at station, say no terror link
Description: Police said they arrested a man outside London's Paddington Station on Monday but added that the incident was not terrorism-related, a few hours after a van ploughed into worshippers near a mosque in the British capital.

Headline: May visits London mosque after attack
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May visited the Finsbury Park mosque in north London near the scene of an attack where a van ploughed into worshippers on Monday.

Headline: Merkel wants good Brexit deal that works for both sides
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said she wanted a "good agreement" for both Britain and the European Union in the Brexit negotiations that started on Monday.

Headline: May says attack on Muslims near mosque is "sickening"
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said hatred and evil would never succeed after a van ploughed into worshippers near a London mosque in a deliberate attack on Muslims as they left prayers at mosques in north London on Monday.

Headline: May is leading UK through challenging times - Downing Street
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is leading the country through "incredibly challenging times," her spokeswoman said on Monday when asked about media speculation that May might face a challenge from within her Conservative Party.

Headline: In Brexit boost, Jaguar Land Rover to hire 5,000 staff
Description: Britain's biggest carmaker Jaguar Land Rover (JLR)  will hire 5,000 staff as it boosts its skills in autonomous and electric technology, a welcome business endorsement as Prime Minister Theresa May starts Brexit talks after a botched election.

Headline: London fire inquiry being prepared, PM May knows people want quick answers - spokeswoman
Description: The terms of reference for a public inquiry into a fire at a London tower block that killed 79 people are being drafted and Prime Minister Theresa May knows people want answers quickly on the disaster, her spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: Presumed death toll in London tower blaze rises to 79
Description: London police said 79 people were dead or missing presumed dead after a devastating tower block blaze last week.

Headline: Police says too early to say whether death near mosque was due to attack
Description: British police said it was too early to say whether a death near a mosque in north London on Monday was due to an attack by a van driver who ploughed into worshippers.

Headline: Return of the undertaker: Hammond fights back
Description: Sidelined for months by his boss Theresa May, Britain's Chancellor Philip Hammond has returned to the political frontline, criticising the prime minister over her recent election campaign and calling for pragmatism in Brexit talks that begin on Monday.

Headline: Number of people assumed dead in London tower block blaze to rise - police
Description: Police said on Sunday the number of people assumed to have died in the London tower block fire was likely to rise from its previous 58, adding they would provide an updated figure on Monday.

Headline: With a weakened leader and reeling from crisis, Britain hurtles into the Brexit unknown
Description: With her strategy unclear and her position insecure, Prime Minister Theresa May plunges this week into tortuous divorce talks with the European Union that will shape Britain's prosperity and global influence for generations to come.

Headline: Government did respond to fire safety recommendations, Philip Hammond says
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Sunday the government had acted on safety recommendations after an earlier fire in London in 2009, but it would wait for the public inquiry to make changes in regulation.

Headline: Britain needs a seamless Brexit customs transition - Hammond
Description: Britain needs a seamless Brexit transition to support jobs and investment by ensuring a new customs arrangement with the European Union that avoids bureaucratic delays to trade, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Sunday.

Headline: Leadsom says possible to strike Brexit deal in time frame
Description: British government minister Andrea Leadsom said on Sunday it was "perfectly possible" to negotiate Britain's exit from the European Union in the next two years, as required by the rules of the trading bloc.

Headline: Future EU-UK trade must be similar to trade today - Hammond
Description: After Britain leaves the European Union, British exporters should experience trade "which feels as close as possible to the way it feels now", finance minister Philip Hammond said on Sunday.

Headline: Hammond says to focus on productivity
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said his medium term focus would be to improve productivity.

Headline: Hammond says not deaf to voter weariness on spending cuts
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said he was "not deaf" to signs of weariness among voters about the country's near decade-long grip on public spending which has come under renewed criticism after a deadly fire in a London tower block.

Headline: 'No doubt' over Britain leaving EU - Brexit minister Davis
Description: British Brexit minister David Davis heads to Brussels on Monday to open divorce talks with the EU with a message that there should be "no doubt — we are leaving the European Union".

Headline: Corbyn says council did not have resources to tackle London fire
Description: Britain's opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Sunday the local authority in London where a fire killed at least 58 people last week did not have the resources to deal with an emergency of that scale.

Headline: Leadsom says possible to strike Brexit deal in time frame
Description: British government minister Andrea Leadsom said on Sunday it was "perfectly possible" to negotiate Britain's exit from the European Union in the next two years, as required by the rules of the trading bloc.

Headline: Future EU-UK trade must be similar to trade today - Hammond
Description: After Britain leaves the European Union, British exporters should experience trade "which feels as close as possible to the way it feels now", finance minister Philip Hammond said on Sunday.

Headline: Hammond says to focus on productivity
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said his medium term focus would be to improve productivity.

Headline: Hammond says not deaf to voter weariness on spending cuts
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said he was "not deaf" to signs of weariness among voters about the country's near decade-long grip on public spending which has come under renewed criticism after a deadly fire in a London tower block.

Headline: 'No doubt' over Britain leaving EU - Brexit minister Davis
Description: British Brexit minister David Davis heads to Brussels on Monday to open divorce talks with the EU with a message that there should be "no doubt — we are leaving the European Union".

Headline: Corbyn says council did not have resources to tackle London fire
Description: Britain's opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Sunday the local authority in London where a fire killed at least 58 people last week did not have the resources to deal with an emergency of that scale.

Headline: Labour Party says May has no authority before Brexit talks
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party said on Sunday that Prime Minister Theresa May's failed election gamble had left her with no authority on the eve of formal Brexit talks.

Headline: Britain to hold special two-year parliament session to tackle Brexit
Description: The British parliament will hold a rare two-year legislative session to tackle the complexities of Britain's departure from the European Union, the government said on Saturday.

Headline: Moscovici on Brexit negotiations - EU will be 'amicable and firm'
Description: The European Union will be "amicable and firm" with Britain in Brexit negotiations due to start on Monday, and all possible options are on the table, the EU's Economic and Financial Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici said.

Headline: At least 58 feared dead in London tower fire, May admits failings
Description: At least 58 people are feared to have died in the fire that engulfed a London tower block this week, police said on Saturday, as Prime Minister Theresa May admitted that the response from the authorities had not been good enough.

Headline: May will face leadership challenge if she softens Brexit - Telegraph
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will face an immediate leadership challenge from eurosceptic MPs in her party if she seeks to water down her plans for Brexit, the Sunday Telegraph reported, citing senior Conservative sources.

Headline: Jaguar Land Rover to create 5,000 new jobs in UK - Telegraph report
Description: Britain's biggest carmaker Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) is drawing up plans to hire an extra 5,000 engineers and technical staff in the next year, the Sunday Telegraph reported, in a boost to the government as it embarks on the Brexit negotiations.

Headline: Amid turmoil, Queen says Britain sombre but steadfast
Description: Amid the turmoil of militant attacks, political crisis and a deadly fire disaster, Queen Elizabeth said Britain was in a deeply sombre mood but that its people were resolute in the face of adversity.

Headline: As Brexit talks loom, May scrambles for deal to stay in power
Description: Britain is likely to enter arduous talks on its exit from the European Union without a deal to keep Prime Minister Theresa May in power as negotiations with a Northern Irish "kingmaker" party grind into a second week.

Headline: Railway track near London tower blaze closed due to debris risk
Description: A railway track which lies in the shadow of a London tower block gutted by a deadly blaze this week was closed on Saturday as the fire brigade worked to clear up debris inside the building.

Headline: London police say 58 people assumed dead in tower block blaze
Description: British police said that 58 people were now assumed to have died in this week's blaze at a London tower block.

Headline: May rushed from area of London fire after protests
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May was rushed away under heavy police guard on Friday as protesters shouted "Shame on you" after she met residents who live near a tower block in London where at least 30 people died in a fire.

Headline: Policeman killed in Westminster attack honoured by Queen
Description: Police officer Keith Palmer, who died protecting members of the public and parliament during an attack at Westminster, was given a posthumous award for bravery in Queen Elizabeth's annual birthday honours on Friday, Britain's Cabinet Office said.

Headline: Police release three men without charge in London Bridge attack probe
Description: British police investigating the deadly attacks on London Bridge said they released three men without charge on Friday.

Headline: Irish, British PMs to meet to talk Brexit, Northern Ireland crisis
Description: Ireland's new prime minister will meet his British counterpart, Theresa May, for the first time on Monday to discuss Brexit and the political deadlock in the Northern Irish regional assembly.

Headline: Missing: The desperate hunt for lost relatives after London tower block fire
Description: Since an inferno engulfed the London tower block she lived in, Sawsan Choucair has been desperately trying to find news of what happened to the other six members of her family who were living there with her.

Headline: Some people leave town hall fire protest in London - Reuters witness
Description: Some people left a local town hall on Friday after storming the building in protest at a deadly London tower block fire, Reuters reporters at the scene said.

Headline: Chanting "we want justice", protesters storm local town hall after deadly London fire
Description: Several hundred protesters chanting "we want justice" stormed a local town hall in London on Friday after a deadly fire at a block of flats killed at least 30 people, Reuters reporters at the scene said.

Headline: France eyes court to deal with post-Brexit financial contract issues
Description: France is considering creating a special court that would handle disputes over financial contracts governed by English law after Britain leaves the European Union, a move designed in part to help lure banks to Paris from the City of London.

Headline: Queen visits London fire volunteers as locals plead for answers
Description: Queen Elizabeth visited residents, volunteers and emergency services at a centre helping those affected by London's tower block fire on Friday, with grandson Prince William promising to return to hear residents' concerns.

Headline: Britain says no EU exit deal unless future relationship taken into account
Description: Britain said on Friday that no deal could be struck on exiting the European Union unless the future relationship with the bloc was taken into account.

Headline: UK mulls trial of former Ukraine tax chief on British soil
Description: Britain said on Friday it was looking into whether there were grounds to try the former head of the Ukrainian fiscal service on UK soil, after a court in Kiev dismissed evidence provided by the British authorities in a corruption case.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP wants "sensible Brexit", talks with May to continue
Description: Arlene Foster, the head of the small Northern Irish political party in talks to support Theresa May's minority government, said on Friday she wanted a "sensible Brexit" that would work for the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland.

Headline: DUP deal with May not likely before next week - source
Description: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party will not agree a deal to support Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives in government before the start of next week at the earliest, a DUP source said on Friday.

Headline: HSBC sees fewer London jobs move on softer Brexit hopes
Description: HSBC sees the chances of a hard Brexit receding after Britain's shock election result, which could result in fewer jobs moving out of London, its investment bank chief said.

Headline: Queen visits London fire volunteers as locals plead for answers
Description: Queen Elizabeth visited residents, volunteers and emergency services at a centre helping those affected by London's tower block fire on Friday, with grandson Prince William promising to return to hear residents' concerns.

Headline: Britain says no EU exit deal unless future relationship taken into account
Description: Britain said on Friday that no deal could be struck on exiting the European Union unless the future relationship with the bloc was taken into account.

Headline: UK mulls trial of former Ukraine tax chief on British soil
Description: Britain said on Friday it was looking into whether there were grounds to try the former head of the Ukrainian fiscal service on UK soil, after a court in Kiev dismissed evidence provided by the British authorities in a corruption case.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP wants "sensible Brexit", talks with May to continue
Description: Arlene Foster, the head of the small Northern Irish political party in talks to support Theresa May's minority government, said on Friday she wanted a "sensible Brexit" that would work for the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland.

Headline: DUP deal with May not likely before next week - source
Description: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party will not agree a deal to support Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives in government before the start of next week at the earliest, a DUP source said on Friday.

Headline: HSBC sees fewer London jobs move on softer Brexit hopes
Description: HSBC sees the chances of a hard Brexit receding after Britain's shock election result, which could result in fewer jobs moving out of London, its investment bank chief said.

Headline: Death toll in London tower fire rises to 30, figure expected to rise
Description: The death toll from the London tower block fire has risen to at least 30 and police are considering whether criminal offences had been committed, a senior police officer said on Friday.

Headline: UK to hold inquiry into London tower block fire as death toll rises to 17
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Thursday promised a public inquiry into a fire that gutted a 24-storey apartment block killing at least 17 people, as the government faced questions about how such a devastating blaze could have occurred.

Headline: Germany expects no delay in Brexit negotiations
Description: Germany expects Britain and the European Union to start negotiations over Britain's departure from the EU on Monday as planned, a government spokesman said on Friday.

Headline: May to visit those injured in London tower block blaze
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will on Friday visit those injured in a deadly London tower block fire after facing fierce criticism for attending the site but not meeting with residents.

Headline: Talks between May's Conservatives and Northern Ireland's DUP are ongoing - source
Description: Talks between British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party on a deal to prop up May's minority government are ongoing, a senior Conservative source said on Friday.

Headline: At least 65 people missing or feared dead in London fire - The Sun
Description: The Sun newspaper on Friday listed 65 people who it said were still missing or feared dead in a London tower block fire which police said has left 17 people dead with the death toll expected to rise.

Headline: Deadly tower blaze highlights London's rich-poor divide
Description: Within a short walk from the social housing block in west London where 17 people - and perhaps many more - died in a devastating fire are some of Britain's wealthiest streets, lined with elegant, multi-million-pound townhouses.

Headline: Nationalist government seek talks on "least bad Brexit" for Scotland
Description: Scotland's devolved nationalist government said on Thursday it wanted to meet all parties to work out "the least bad Brexit for Scotland," arguing that the change in the political landscape made such talks necessary.

Headline: May confident on deal to stay in power, parliament to open next week
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's government said on Thursday it would launch her policy programme next week, a sign of confidence she will strike a deal to stay in power after days of political uncertainty since losing her majority.

Headline: Sinn Fein cautious on DUP, May tie-up but would welcome funding
Description: Northern Ireland's largest nationalist party would oppose any deal their main unionist rival strikes to prop up British Prime Minister Theresa May that undermines peace in the province but would welcome the increased funding it may bring.

Headline: May urges Northern Irish government deal by June 29
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May urged Northern Ireland's political parties on Thursday to reach an agreement to restore government for the province by June 29, or London would need to consider alternative steps.

Headline: Conservative-DUP deal could hasten Northern Ireland settlement
Description: Northern Irish unionist support to prop up British Prime Minister Theresa May might seem like a death sentence for power-sharing with the province's Irish nationalists, but some think it could actually bring the model back from political limbo.

Headline: Pay up, make nice if you want "soft Brexit", EU to tell May
Description: Theresa May should agree to pay Britain's bills to the European Union and drop threats to walk out without a legal deal if she wants talks on the "softer Brexit" some of her allies are calling for, EU negotiators say.

Headline: Police commander says London tower block search may take months, hopes death toll not in "triple figures"
Description: Searching a London tower block gutted in a huge fire on Wednesday might take months, a police chief said on Thursday, adding he hoped the death toll would not rise from 17 to "triple figures".

Headline: City of London cancels Mansion House dinner after tower block fire
Description: Britain's annual Mansion House dinner, at which the country's finance minister and the governor of the Bank of England deliver high-profile speeches, has been cancelled on Thursday after a deadly fire at a London tower block, its organizers said.

Headline: Hammond pulls out of Mansion House speech after London fire
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said he no longer planned to deliver a high-profile speech later on Thursday because of a deadly fire which struck a London tower block on Wednesday.

Headline: Hammond will deliver speech soon after Mansion House pull-out
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond plans to deliver "in the near future" a speech replacing the one that he cancelled on Thursday out of respect for the victims of a deadly fire which struck a London tower block, a Treasury spokesman said.

Headline: May orders full public inquiry into deadly tower block fire
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May ordered a full public inquiry into the London tower block fire that killed at least 17 people early on Wednesday morning.

Headline: Talks on propping up Conservatives are "very positive" - source
Description: Talks between Britain's Conservative Party and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party to prop up Prime Minister Theresa May's government are very positive and the two parties share broad agreement on Brexit, a senior source said on Thursday.

Headline: No deal yet between Conservatives and DUP to back PM May - Sky News
Description: Britain's ruling Conservatives and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party have yet to agree a deal to support Prime Minister Theresa May's government, Sky News reported on Thursday, citing sources.

Headline: Property insurer expects London fire payouts to exceed 25 million pounds
Description: This week's fire in a 24-storey block of flats in London is expected to cost property insurers more than 25 million pounds  ($31.8 million), Norwegian insurer Protector Forsikring  told Reuters on Thursday.

Headline: Death toll from London tower block blaze rises to 17
Description: The death toll from the London tower block fire has risen to 17 and the figure is expected to rise further, police said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain to open parliament on June 21 - leader of lower house
Description: Britain will hold its state opening of parliament on June 21 when the government will set out its legislative agenda, the Press Association news agency quoted Andrea Leadsom, leader of the lower house of parliament, as saying on Thursday.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP says talks with Conservatives to continue in London
Description: Talks between British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party to secure support for a minority government are to continue in London today, a DUP spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: Talks on propping up Conservatives are "very positive" - source
Description: Talks between Britain's Conservative Party and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party to prop up Prime Minister Theresa May's government are very positive and the two parties share broad agreement on Brexit, a senior source said on Thursday.

Headline: No deal yet between Conservatives and DUP to back PM May - Sky News
Description: Britain's ruling Conservatives and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party have yet to agree a deal to support Prime Minister Theresa May's government, Sky News reported on Thursday, citing sources.

Headline: Property insurer expects London fire payouts to exceed 25 million pounds
Description: This week's fire in a 24-storey block of flats in London is expected to cost property insurers more than 25 million pounds  ($31.8 million), Norwegian insurer Protector Forsikring  told Reuters on Thursday.

Headline: Death toll from London tower block blaze rises to 17
Description: The death toll from the London tower block fire has risen to 17 and the figure is expected to rise further, police said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain to open parliament on June 21 - leader of lower house
Description: Britain will hold its state opening of parliament on June 21 when the government will set out its legislative agenda, the Press Association news agency quoted Andrea Leadsom, leader of the lower house of parliament, as saying on Thursday.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP says talks with Conservatives to continue in London
Description: Talks between British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party to secure support for a minority government are to continue in London today, a DUP spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: Labour urges protest to force PM May from power - Daily Mirror
Description: A senior lawmaker in Britain's opposition Labour Party has called for a million people to take to the streets to force a second election that he said would remove Prime Minister Theresa May from power, the Daily Mirror reported.

Headline: May arrives at burnt tower block in London - Reuters photographer
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May arrived on Thursday at the tower block in west London that was destroyed by fire, a Reuters photographer said.

Headline: UK retail sales fall sharply as consumers feel the hit of Brexit vote inflation
Description: British retail sales fell more sharply than expected in May, data showed on Thursday, the latest sign of the growing hit to the economy from rising inflation since the Brexit vote.

Headline: Firefighters yet to fully search burnt London tower block - fire brigade chief
Description: Firefighters have not been able to conduct a comprehensive search of the 24-storey block of flats in west London that went up in flames because it is not safe for them to walk to the edges of the building, the fire brigade chief said on Thursday.

Headline: Hard or soft Brexit aside, pound nervous of economic slowdown
Description: Last week's shocking British election result and the period of political uncertainty that looks set to follow may have come at the worst of times for the country's economy and the value of the pound sterling.

Headline: UK to step up support for start-ups, infrastructure ahead of EU exit
Description: The British government will step up the level of financial support it provides to everything from small start-ups to major infrastructure projects in a bid to help the economy as the country leaves the European Union.

Headline: Hammond, saved from purge, set to renew Brexit push
Description: British Chancellor Philip Hammond has the chance on Thursday to revive his calls for a more business-friendly exit from the EU in a debate blown wide open again by an election that has undermined Prime Minister Theresa May's authority.

Headline: May inches towards deal to stay in power as battle rages over Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May edged closer to clinching a deal to stay in power with the support of Northern Irish kingmakers on Wednesday, but faced a battle over Brexit just days before divorce talks are due to begin.

Headline: Planning documents for tower in fatal fire omitted safety barriers
Description: Planning documents detailing the refurbishment of a residential tower block in West London where at least 12 people died in a fire on Wednesday did not refer to a type of fire barrier that building safety experts said should be used when high rise blocks are being re-clad.

Headline: London to open Brexit talks by offering to protect rights of EU citizens in UK - FT
Description: The UK's Brexit minister, David Davis, will open divorce talks in Brussels next week with an offer to allow the three million European Union citizens living in Britain the same rights that they have now, the Financial Times reported on Wednesday.

Headline: May promises 'proper' investigation into London tower block fire
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May promised there would be a full investigation into the cause of a fire that ripped through a London tower block killing 12 residents and injuring dozens more as they slept on Wednesday.

Headline: May says DUP talks continue but London fire a real focus
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said talks with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist party aimed at securing their support for her minority government were continuing but that a fire in London had taken priority on Wednesday.

Headline: Several injured in Wales firing range incident - defence ministry
Description: A number of people have been injured during an incident at a firing range in Castlemartin, Wales, Britain's Ministry of Defence and local media said on Wednesday, without giving  further details.

Headline: Lib Dem leader quits, says can't lead party and be a Christian
Description: Tim Farron, the leader of the pro-European Union Liberal Democrat Party, resigned on Wednesday saying questions about his Christian faith ahead of last week's election meant he felt it was impossible to continue in the role.

Headline: DUP leader returns to Northern Ireland, talks continue - Sky News
Description: The leader of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party has returned home after talks with Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party in London but other senior DUP figures are continuing discussions, Sky News reported.

Headline: May to meet Sinn Fein, other Northern Ireland parties
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is to meet the leaders of Northern Ireland's main political parties on Thursday in a bid to help secure agreement between pro-British unionists and Irish nationalists to form a regional government, her office said.

Headline: UK workers suffer spending power hit, raising pressure on May
Description: British workers are suffering from an increasingly tight squeeze in their spending power, data showed on Wednesday, adding to concerns about a slowdown in the world's fifth-biggest economy and to the challenges for a weakened Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: Death toll from London tower block fire rises to 12
Description: At least 12 people died in the huge fire that engulfed a London tower block on Wednesday and the toll is likely to rise further, police said.

Headline: Scottish Conservatives want fishing protected as part of Brexit
Description: Scotland's Conservatives want the fishing industry to be protected in any deal that Britain negotiates to leave the European Union after winning seats in fishing areas in last week's national election.

Headline: Factbox: Grenfell Tower - the London tower block that went up in flames
Description: Fire engulfed a high-rise block of apartments in central London on Wednesday, killing at least six people and injuring 74. Some residents asleep inside were trapped in the inferno.

Headline: Baker says does not see Brexit strategy changing
Description: Junior Brexit minister Steve Baker said on Wednesday he did not expect Britain's strategy for leaving the European Union to change after Prime Minister Theresa May failed to win a majority in last week's national election.

Headline: France says British PM's legitimacy not called into question by election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's legitimacy was not called into question by the election result in Britain as far as President Emmanuel Macron is concerned, the French government's spokesman said on Wednesday.

Headline: Germany says no indication of changes to Brexit timetable
Description: Germany was not aware of any changes to the two-year timeframe for Britain to leave the European Union, a government spokeswoman said on Wednesday, after last week's election raised questions over Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy.

Headline: Fire service says will be dealing with London tower block fire for next 24 hours
Description: Fire crews will be tackling a fire which engulfed a 24-storey London apartment block for at least the next 24 hours, the London Fire Brigade said on Wednesday.

Headline: New UK Brexit proposal urgently needed, says Scotland's Sturgeon
Description: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has told British Prime Minister Theresa May that a new more inclusive plan for Britain to leave the European Union is urgently needed to protect the economy and bring people together.

Headline: More people may still be inside burning London tower block - police
Description: More people may still be trapped inside a 24-storey building in central London and the recovery process after a fire engulfed it could potentially be very lengthy, London police commander Stuart Cundy said on Wednesday.

Headline: PM May deeply saddened by loss of life in London tower block fire - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday she was deeply saddened by the loss of life in a fire at a London tower block which killed at least six people and injured more than 70 others.

Headline: Structural engineer monitoring stability of London tower block hit by fire
Description: A structural engineer is checking the stability of a 24-storey London apartment block which was engulfed by a fire that left a number of fatalities and over 50 people injured, the fire brigade said on Wednesday.

Headline: Children lost, baby thrown to safety in London blaze - witnesses
Description: One woman lost two of her six children when trying to escape a burning London tower block early on Wednesday morning while others tried to throw their children to safety, witnesses said.

Headline: London mayor says questions need to be answered after deadly tower block fire
Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan said questions will need to be answered over the safety of tower blocks after several people were killed on Wednesday when a fire engulfed a 24-storey building.

Headline: UK government appoints Brexit backer as City minister
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has appointed Brexit supporter Stephen Barclay as "City minister" to oversee a financial services sector facing upheaval as Britain prepares to leave the European Union.

Headline: Six dead in London tower block fire, toll expected to rise - police
Description: Six people have been confirmed dead in a huge fire at a London tower block and the death toll is expected to rise, police said on Wednesday.

Headline: Inquest opens into the death of five London attack victims
Description: A coroner on Tuesday opened an inquest into the deaths of five people killed in an Islamist militant attack in London in which three men in a van mowed down pedestrians then stabbed bystanders in a rampage through a nightlife area of the capital.

Headline: London fire brigade says still working to get tower block fire under control
Description: Fire crews are still working to bring a fire at a London apartment block under control but it is not in danger of collapsing, the London Fire Brigade said on Wednesday.

Headline: Hammond to push for UK to stay in EU customs union - The Times
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond will argue for Britain to stay in the European Union's customs union, in a bid to soften Brexit and alter Prime Minister's Theresa May approach, The Times reported on Tuesday citing several unidentified sources.

Headline: Facing competing Brexit demands, PM May nears deal with Northern Irish 'kingmakers'
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May neared a deal with a Northern Irish Protestant party to save her premiership on Tuesday and confirmed Brexit talks would begin next week, amid growing calls for her to soften her approach to leaving the European Union.

Headline: Prime Minister May's Conservatives, Northern Ireland's DUP to resume talks Wednesday - PM's office
Description: Talks between UK Prime Minister Theresa May's minority Conservative government and Northern Ireland's DUP broke up for the night on Tuesday, and will resume the following day, a spokesman for May's office said.

Headline: Cameron says May should consult rivals on Brexit - FT
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May should consult with the opposition Labour Party and others on her Brexit strategy, David Cameron, May's predecessor, said on Tuesday, according to the Financial Times.

Headline: 'Anxiety and fear' in Northern Ireland over Conservative-DUP talks - Sinn Fein
Description: A potential agreement for the Northern Irish unionist DUP to prop up a minority Conservative government led by Theresa May in Britain is causing anxiety and fear in the province, Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein said on Tuesday.

Headline: May says minority government talks 'productive', Brexit negotiation starts next week
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday said talks with Northern Ireland's DUP about a deal to support her minority government had been "productive", and confirmed that Brexit negotiations would begin next week.

Headline: UK needs unity for challenges of Brexit and security - May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told Britain's newly returned parliament on Tuesday that the country needed to come together to face the challenges of leaving the European Union and maintaining security after recent attacks by Islamist militants.

Headline: May appoints Brexit campaigner Steve Baker as junior minister
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday appointed Brexit campaigner Steve Baker to a junior ministerial role in the government department charged with negotiating Britain's exit from the European Union.

Headline: UK inflation jump tightens consumer squeeze, puts BoE on spot
Description: British inflation unexpectedly jumped to its highest level in nearly four years in May, tightening the squeeze on consumers and complicating the job of the Bank of England, which has signalled it is in no hurry to raise interest rates.

Headline: PM May to sign deal with Northern Ireland's DUP on Wednesday - BBC
Description: A deal between Prime Minister Theresa May and Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) to agree support for a minority Conservative government is expected to be signed on Wednesday, the BBC's Political Editor Laura Kuenssberg said on Twitter.

Headline: Former UK PM Major fears DUP deal could spark a return to violence in Northern Ireland
Description: Theresa May's plan to govern with the support of a Northern Irish protestant party risks thrusting the province back into turmoil by convincing 'hard men' on both sides of the divide to return to violence, former Prime Minister John Major said.

Headline: Head of Northern Ireland's DUP says hoping for deal with PM May "sooner rather than later"
Description: The head of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party, Arlene Foster, on Tuesday said she hoped to strike a deal with Prime Minister Theresa May to support the Conservative Party's minority government "sooner rather than later".

Headline: Gove says Britain will leave EU customs union after Brexit
Description: Senior British minister and prominent Brexit campaigner Michael Gove said on Tuesday that Britain will leave the EU customs union, which guarantees tariff-free trade within the bloc but prohibits members from striking third-party trade deals.

Headline: Northern Ireland's DUP wants to see devolved government restored
Description: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which is being courted by Prime Minister Theresa May to give her support in parliament and save her premiership, is working to restore devolved government in the province, its deputy leader said.

Headline: Likelihood of hard Brexit recedes after UK election - Reuters poll of economists
Description: The chances of Britain ending up outside the single market when Brexit talks are concluded have receded somewhat after last week's election, although the pound might weaken further against other currencies, a Reuters poll of economists found.

Headline: May makes no comment after DUP talks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May made no comment as she left her Number 10 Downing Street residence on Tuesday after holding talks with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party over a deal to back her government.

Headline: PM May and DUP have largely agreed support deal - BBC
Description: There are no outstanding issues between British Prime Minister Theresa May and Northern Ireland's DUP, and a deal to support May's government has been largely agreed, the BBC reported on Tuesday, citing unidentified sources.

Headline: Northern Irish DUP says hopes to successfully conclude talks with UK PM soon
Description: The leader of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party, Arlene Foster, said on Tuesday that talks with British Prime Minister Theresa May to support a new government were going well and she hoped to successfully conclude them soon.

Headline: Co-owner of Formula One team Force India could face further charges, UK court told
Description: Vijay Mallya, the co-owner of Formula One team Force India, could face further charges and a second request to extradite him from Britain to India, a London court heard on Tuesday.

Headline: Junior finance minister Neville-Rolfe says has left government
Description: British junior finance minister Lucy Neville-Rolfe, who was responsible for liaising with the financial services industry over Brexit, said on Tuesday that she had left the government.

Description: Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which is being courted by Prime Minister Theresa May to give her support in parliament and save her premiership, is working to restore devolved government in the province, its deputy leader said.

Description: The chances of Britain ending up outside the single market when Brexit talks are concluded have receded somewhat after last week's election, although the pound might weaken further against other currencies, a Reuters poll of economists found.

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May made no comment as she left her Number 10 Downing Street residence on Tuesday after holding talks with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party over a deal to back her government.

Description: There are no outstanding issues between British Prime Minister Theresa May and Northern Ireland's DUP, and a deal to support May's government has been largely agreed, the BBC reported on Tuesday, citing unidentified sources.

Description: The leader of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party, Arlene Foster, said on Tuesday that talks with British Prime Minister Theresa May to support a new government were going well and she hoped to successfully conclude them soon.

Description: Vijay Mallya, the co-owner of Formula One team Force India, could face further charges and a second request to extradite him from Britain to India, a London court heard on Tuesday.

Headline: Junior finance minister Neville-Rolfe says has left government
Description: British junior finance minister Lucy Neville-Rolfe, who was responsible for liaising with the financial services industry over Brexit, said on Tuesday that she had left the government.

Headline: Northern Irish DUP leaders arrive for talks with UK PM May
Description: The leader of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party, Arlene Foster, arrived in Downing Street on Tuesday for talks with British Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: British cabinet discussed DUP talks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday discussed with her cabinet the ongoing talks with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party that are aimed at securing support for her minority government.

Headline: EU Parliament negotiator wants Brexit clarity from London soon
Description: The European Union wants clarity from London as soon as possible on whether it intends to stick to its stance towards Brexit  negotiations or alter it following last week's election, said Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's point person for Brexit.

Headline: Danish finance minister hopes UK election will provide a time-out in Brexit talks
Description: Denmark's Finance Minister said on Tuesday he hoped the outcome of the British election would lead to a time-out and provide a chance to rethink the direction in which negotiations about the country's decision to leave the European Union are heading.

Headline: May accepts voters are tired of 'austerity' - Times reports
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has accepted that voters' patience with austerity is at an end, the Times of London newspaper reported on Tuesday, citing unidentified sources.

Headline: May must change Brexit tack to stay in power - ex-leader Hague
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May needs to start cooperating with businesses and other parties on Brexit if her government is to survive, former Conservative Party leader William Hague said.

Headline: Small blast at British station in Cyprus, criminal motive seen
Description: A small explosion occurred outside a police station at a British base in Cyprus early on Tuesday, authorities said, adding it was being treated as a criminal investigation.

Headline: Number of Britons seeking German citizenship leaps in 2016 as Brexit vote takes toll
Description: The number of Britons who became German citizens leapt 361 percent in 2016, the Federal Statistics Office said on Tuesday, with many concerned that the vote will make it more difficult for them to live and work in the European Union in future.

Headline: May tells lawmakers she'll stay as long as they want her
Description: Theresa May told her party on Monday she would serve as prime minister as long as they wanted after a botched election gamble cost the party its majority in parliament and weakened London's hand days before formal Brexit negotiations.

Headline: With a 'stonking performance', May wins stay of execution
Description: Giving a "stonking" performance, Theresa May won a stay of execution from her Conservative Party on Monday, winning support from disillusioned lawmakers after losing a parliamentary majority at last week's national election.

Description: The number of European Union nurses registering to work in Britain has dropped by 96 percent since July last year, the country's Health Foundation said on Monday, in what it described as a wake-up call to politicians.

Headline: British PM May should put economy first in Brexit strategy - Scottish Conservatives
Description: Britain's government should put boosting the economy at the heart of its strategy for Brexit, Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson said on Monday, steering the focus away from cutting immigration.

Headline: Talks about Brexit talks, but no date for negotiation
Description: British officials held "talks about talks" with the European Union's Brexit man in Brussels on Monday but actual negotiations, scheduled to start in a week's time, may be delayed by political upheaval in London.

Headline: 'Hard Brexit' plan is dead in the water - Nicola Sturgeon
Description: Supporters of a so-called hard Brexit have been left "dead in the water" by British Prime Minister Theresa May's failure to secure a parliamentary majority in last week's election, Nicola Sturgeon, the head of Scotland's devolved government, said.

Headline: Britain's political instability to harm growth - S&P economist
Description: Britain's political instability is likely to hurt economic growth this year and there is no indication that last week's inconclusive election result will mean a softer Brexit, a senior Standard & Poor's (S&P) economist said on Monday.

Headline: May not sobbing over election, Brexit minister says
Description: Brexit Secretary David Davis said British Prime Minister Theresa May was not sobbing over last week's failed election gamble when he met her after the vote, Davis said on Monday.

Headline: May's Brexit plan has not changed, her spokesman says
Description: Britain's plan for leaving the European Union has not changed, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday, despite a disastrous election gamble that has plunged British politics into chaos days before formal Brexit talks begin.

Headline: Scottish Conservatives want emphasis off immigration and on economy - source
Description: Scottish members of Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives want Brexit talks to move away from a focus on control of immigration and back onto the economy, a source close to party's Scottish leader Ruth Davidson said.

Headline: UK to delay Queen's Speech policy outline amid political turmoil - BBC
Description: Britain's government will delay the Queen's Speech, in which it traditionally spells out its policy plans, because of the upheaval caused by Prime Minister Theresa May's failure to win a parliamentary majority last week, the BBC said on Monday.

Headline: BMW's UK workers reject offer designed to end pension dispute
Description: British car workers at BMW  have rejected a pension deal designed to end a long-running dispute over plans to close the German automaker's final salary pension scheme, the Unite union said on Monday.

Headline: UK single market membership not likely to be on table in Brexit talks - senior MP
Description: Remaining in the European Union's single market is not likely to be on the table in upcoming Brexit negotiations, a senior lawmaker from British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives said on Monday.

Headline: Brexit talks to start next week but possibly not on June 19 - UK minister

Headline: DUP seeking good Brexit deal for Northern Ireland in talks with UK PM May
Description: The leader of the Democratic Unionist Party Arlene Foster will seek to strengthen the unity of the United Kingdom and get a good Brexit deal for Northern Ireland in talks with the Conservative Party, she said in a newspaper article on Monday.

Headline: Moody's sees Brexit talks delay after election, softer exit possible
Description: Ratings agency Moody's said Britain's inconclusive election result is likely to delay negotiations about the country's exit from the European Union which could be negative for Britain's credit rating.

Headline: EU and UK citizens should not fret over Brexit future, Davis says
Description: British Brexit minister David Davis said European citizens should not worry about their future rights as he hoped a deal would be reached swiftly after the start of Brexit talks on June 19.

Headline: Brexit minister Davis says UK could still walk away with no deal

Headline: Brexit minister says May not a 'dead woman walking'

Headline: Half of UK employers unprepared for immigration changes - think tank
Description: Almost half of British employers are unprepared for the government's planned changes to immigration rules after Brexit, a survey from the Resolution Foundation think tank showed on Monday.

Headline: UK consumer spending falls for first time in nearly four years - Visa
Description: British consumers cut their spending for the first time in nearly four years last month, figures from credit card firm Visa showed, as households turned more cautious even before last week's shock election result.

Headline: Corbyn sees possible new election this year or next
Description: Opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Sunday  there could be another election this year or early in 2018 after the vote on Thursday produced no clear winner.

Description: It was always a long shot - "Kebab King" Ibrahim Dogus only stood as a Labour Party candidate in one of the richest parts of London to offer voters an alternative.

Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will keep Philip Hammond in his job as Chancellor, broadcaster BBC said on Friday as May assembled a ministerial team a day after she failed to win a parliamentary majority in an election.

Headline: Even before new political chaos, British economy was limping
Description: Britain's economy appeared to be struggling to pick up pace even before Friday's inconclusive election result, with industrial output rising less than expected in April after a poor start to 2017.

Headline: Conservatives are only party who can form a UK government - May
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday the Conservatives were the only party able to form a government capable of delivering Brexit after an election that failed to deliver an outright majority.

Headline: Factbox - Unusual moments from a turbulent UK election
Description: A surprise hung parliament, misfiring high fives and candidates in costume - Britain's general election night had it all.

Headline: No appetite among Conservatives to oust May - key lawmaker
Description: Lawmakers in Britain's Conservative Party have no appetite to oust Prime Minister Theresa May after her failure to win the party a majority in an election on Thursday or to hold a fresh election soon, a senior party member said on Friday.

Headline: Northern Irish unionists to open talks with May about support
Description: The largest party representing Northern Irish unionists said on Friday it will go into talks with British Prime Minister Theresa May about supporting her Conservative Party which fell short of a parliamentary majority in a national election on Thursday.

Description: British bank shares fell on Friday as investors priced in the likely negative impact on the sector of Prime Minister Theresa May's failure to win a majority in a snap election.

Description: Britain's new government would be well advised to ask for more time to negotiate Brexit, trade experts said on Friday, as Prime Minister Theresa May's bid to strengthen her bargaining position through a quick election victory fell flat.

Description: Britain's Conservatives need to talk to other political parties and find a way to deliver an "open" Brexit, Ruth Davidson, leader of the Scottish Conservatives, said after the party failed to win a majority in a national election.

Description: Scottish secessionist dreams of a swift second independence referendum were dashed on Friday when they lost 21 of their 56 seats to parties that want to keep the United Kingdom intact.

Description: European Council President Donald Tusk congratulated Theresa May on her reappointment on Friday as British prime minister and urged her to start talks as soon as possible on Britain's exit from the EU to minimise disruption.

Description: Prime Minister Theresa May made the following statement in Downing Street on Friday after she lost her majority in a national election:

Headline: May says to form government, plans on support from Northern Irish allies
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday she would form a new government with assistance from Northern Irish unionists to provide political certainty and lead Britain in talks with the European Union to secure a successful Brexit deal.

Headline: Scottish leader Sturgeon says will work to keep Conservatives out of power
Description: The Scottish National Party will work to forge an alliance to keep Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives out of power after the inconclusive result to Britain's national election, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Friday.

Headline: Liberal Democrats leader rules out coalition with May
Description: Britain's Liberal Democrats party will not form a coalition to prop up the government of Prime Minister Theresa May after she failed to win a parliamentary majority in an election, Liberal Democrat Tim Farron said on Friday.

Headline: Colourful Conservative Davidson blunts drive for Scottish independence
Description: Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson has delivered the party's biggest success in Scotland in a generation, leading a dogged charge against independence from the United Kingdom that has left the nationalist movement reeling.

Headline: China to keep up focus on developing ties with Britain after election
Description: Beijing will keep paying attention to developing ties with Britain and hopes Brexit can be "appropriately resolved", China's Foreign Ministry said on Friday, after a snap vote that dealt a devastating blow to British Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: EU's Juncker urges London not to delay Brexit talks
Description: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said on Friday he hoped the result of Britain's elections would have "no major impact" on EU-UK divorce talks between the bloc and London, and advised London not to delay the start of negotiations.

Description: The leader of the anti-EU United Kingdom Independence Party (UKIP) Paul Nuttall said on Friday he would resign after the party failed to win any lawmakers in the British parliament and saw its vote share fall dramatically.

Description: Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon said the results of the election were disappointing for her party but were disastrous for Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: Conservatives in talks with Northern Ireland's DUP after inconclusive election - Sky
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives are in talks with Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party after failing to win a majority in Thursday's national election, Sky News reported on Friday, citing sources.

Headline: Labour Party says will seek to form minority government
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party will put itself forward to lead a minority government after Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives failed to win a majority in a national election, the party's finance spokesman John McDonnell said on Friday.

Headline: BBC political editor says May has no intention of resigning
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May does not plan to resign after losing her parliamentary majority in a snap election she had called in pursuit of a stronger mandate for Brexit talks, the BBC's political editor said on Friday.

Headline: French PM Philippe says British election does not question Brexit
Description: Brexit talks will be long and complex but the result of the British general election doesn't call into question Britain's choice to leave the European Union, French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe said on Friday.

Headline: Britain should form government quickly to start Brexit talks - Czech PM
Description: Czech Prime Minister Bohuslav Sobotka said on Friday Britain should form a new government quickly, as months have already been lost in its divorce talks with the European Union.

Headline: UK business lobby group says needs functioning government to protect economy
Description: British politicians must get their act together and form a functioning government to protect the economy, business lobby group the CBI said on Friday after Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives failed to win a majority in parliament.

Headline: We must not waste any time negotiating Brexit - Germany
Description: There is no time to lose in negotiating Britain's departure from the European Union, Germany's deputy foreign minister said after a general election left British Prime Minister Theresa May fighting to hold on to her job on Friday.

Headline: EU's Moscovici says British vote to influence 'spirit' of Brexit talks
Description: The result of the parliamentary election in Britain will have an impact on the "spirit" of the Brexit negotiations the country is due to hold with the European Union, EU Economic and Financial Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici said on Friday.

Headline: Sturgeon says election 'disastrous' for May
Description: Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon said the results of the election were disappointing for her party but were disastrous for Prime Minister Theresa May.

Description: The European Union's budget commissioner Guenther Oettinger on Friday said he was unsure if Britain's negotiations about leaving the bloc could begin on time after Thursday's U.K. parliamentary election failed to elect a clear winner.

Headline: Factbox - What happens with Brexit if there's no clear winner of election?
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party failed to win a parliamentary majority in Britain's election on Friday, a shock result that plunges domestic politics into turmoil and could delay Brexit talks.

Description: Citi said British Prime Minister Theresa May was likely to resign after she failed to win a majority in the election.

Headline: May no longer able to win outright majority in parliament - Reuters calculations

Headline: Election results show transformation in UK - Brexit minister Davis

Though the seat he is standing for has been held by left-leaning Labour for 20 years, Anthony felt change was in the air.

Description: Prime Minister Theresa May responded on Sunday to an attack in London which killed seven people, declaring "enough is enough" and calling for a review of Britain's counter-terrorism strategy.

Headline: Rudd says London attackers probably 'radical Islamist terrorists'
Description: The attackers who killed seven people and wounded 48 in central London on Saturday were probably "radical Islamist terrorists", Britain's Home Secretary Amber Rudd said on Sunday.

Headline: May calls for beefed up terror response after London attack
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May reacted on Sunday to an attack that killed seven people in London by saying things could not continue as they were and that the strategy for dealing with terrorism needed to be reviewed in four ways.

Headline: Election to go ahead on June 8 despite London attack - May
Description: Britain's national parliamentary election will go ahead on Thursday, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday after an attack in London left seven people dead and 48 injured.

Headline: UK PM May to make statement shortly on London attack
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will make a statement shortly following a meeting of the government's crisis response committee after an attack in London which killed seven people, she said on her Twitter account.

Headline: UKIP says won't suspend election campaigning after London attack
Description: The leader of the UK Independence Party Paul Nuttall said on Sunday he would not be suspending election campaigning in the wake of the London Bridge attacks, four days before a national election.

Headline: Putin says joint efforts to fight terrorism should be stepped up after London attacks
Description: Russian president Vladimir Putin expressed his condolences over attacks in London in a telegram to British prime minister Theresa May on Sunday, the Kremlin said in a statement.

Headline: London attack death toll rises to seven, incident under control - police chief
Description: Seven people are confirmed to have died in an attack by three assailants who drove a van at pedestrians on London Bridge before stabbing people in the nearby Borough Market area, London's Metropolitan Police chief Cressida Dick said on Sunday.

Headline: UK's opposition Labour Party suspends election campaign after London attack
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party suspended its national election campaign until Sunday evening following an attack in London which killed six people, party leader Jeremy Corbyn said in a statement.

Headline: Two Australian citizens caught up in London attacks - PM
Description: Two Australians were directly affected in an attack in London on Saturday night, Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said.

Headline: Corbyn says London incidents 'brutal and shocking'
Description: British opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn described incidents in central London as "brutal and shocking" after reports that a van ploughed into pedestrians on London Bridge and that there were multiple stabbings in the nearby Borough Market area.

Headline: British police say responding to incident in London's Vauxhall area
Description: British police said they were responding to an incident in the Vauxhall area of London after an incident involving a vehicle on London Bridge earlier on Saturday.

Headline: Witness says saw people who appeared to have throats cut on London Bridge
Description: A person who was on London Bridge after an incident on Saturday told a Reuters reporter that she saw three people who appeared to have their throats cut.

Headline: Police say London Bridge, Borough Market incidents are terror-related
Description: British police said incidents at London Bridge and the nearby Borough Market area on Saturday had been declared as terrorist incidents, but a separate stabbing in the Vauxhall area was unrelated.

Headline: Up to seven people feared dead in London incidents - Sun newspaper
Description: Up to seven people were feared dead after a white van ploughed into people on London Bridge on Saturday, and two attackers were shot by armed police in what appeared to be a connected incident  in nearby Borough Market, Britain's Sun newspaper said.

Headline: May says treating London incidents as potential act of terrorism
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday that the incident in London was being treated as a potential act of terrorism.

Headline: British PM May to chair security meeting on Sunday - media
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will chair a meeting of the country's top security committee on Sunday morning after attacks in central London on Saturday, media reports said.

Headline: May's election gamble in doubt as poll lead falls to one point
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's gamble on a June 8 snap election was thrust into doubt after a Survation poll showed her Conservative Party's lead had dropped to a new low of just one percentage point.

Headline: May's lead widens ahead of June 8 election - ORB poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's lead over the opposition Labour Party has widened to nine percentage points ahead of the June 8 election, according to a poll by ORB for the Sunday Telegraph newspaper.

Headline: Lead of UK Conservatives holds, May now seen negatively - ComRes poll
Description: The lead of British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party over the opposition Labour Party was unchanged at 12 points ahead of a June 8 election but May's personal approval ratings turned negative for the first time, according to a ComRes poll published on Saturday.

Headline: May sees lead slip further, still set for majority - Opinium poll
Description: The lead of British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party over the opposition Labour Party has narrowed further to six percentage points ahead of Thursday's national election, according to an Opinium poll for the Observer newspaper.

Headline: May seen 18 seats short of majority in June 8 vote - YouGov
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is on track to win 308 seats in Britain's parliament in an election on Thursday, 18 short of a 326-seat majority, according to a projection by polling company YouGov on Saturday.

Headline: Farage says no FBI contact after report of link to Trump inquiry
Description: Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage said he had not been contacted by the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation and dismissed a report that he was a "person of interest" in an FBI inquiry into possible collusion between Russia and Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.

Headline: Conservatives pledge no tax hike for top earners as vote nears
Description: An ally of British Prime Minister Theresa May has said income tax will not rise for higher earners, making a new promise to voters less than a week before a national election with opinion polls showing a narrowing of May's lead.

Headline: Torture charge for ex-wife of former Liberian president Taylor
Description: An ex-wife of former Liberian president Charles Taylor was charged by British police on Friday with four torture offences committed between 1989 and 1991 during the west African nation's civil war.

Headline: May confident Britain can get good Brexit deal, but prepared to walk away
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday that she was confident that Britain could get a good deal in negotiations to leave the European Union, but would be prepared to walk away without an accord on departure terms if necessary.

Headline: May says to consult business at every step of Brexit - FT
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said she would consult businesses at every step of the Brexit negotiation including on a new migration strategy, the Financial Times reported.

Headline: Police locate potentially significant car in Manchester bomb investigation
Description: British police investigating last week's Manchester suicide bombing said on Friday they had evacuated an area in the city centre after identifying a car which could be "significant" to their inquiry.

Headline: Police seize a car as part of Manchester attack investigation
Description: British police have lifted a cordon in the centre of Manchester and seized a car on Friday which they said could be potentially significant to their investigation into last week's suicide bombing in the city.

Headline: Protest after BBC says won't play 'liar liar' song ahead of UK vote
Description: Dozens of people protested outside the BBC's London headquarters on Friday against its decision not to broadcast a song storming the charts before next week's election that labels Prime Minister Theresa May a liar.

Headline: May considers Rudd as new Chancellor - Telegraph
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond may be replaced by Home Secretary Amber Rudd if Prime Minister Theresa May wins a landslide victory in next week's national election, the Telegraph newspaper reported on Friday.

Headline: Hammond says would like to keep job after election
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said he would like to keep his current job if the Conservative Party remains in power after next week's election, declining to comment on reports that Prime Minister Theresa May plans to sack him.

Headline: Factbox - Landslide or loss? Why pollsters can't agree on the UK election
Description: According to opinion pollsters, British Prime Minister Theresa May is either set to win a resounding election victory on Thursday or to scrape home with her authority in tatters.

Headline: Prince William pays tribute to Manchester after attack
Description: Britain's Prince William met members of the emergency services and young victims of the Manchester bombing in hospital on Friday, praising the solidarity shown by the city in the aftermath of the attack.

Headline: Conservative MP charged with campaign finance offence ahead of June 8 election
Description: A member of Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party, who beat leading Brexit figure Nigel Farage in the 2015 parliamentary election, was charged with breaking that campaign's expenses rules on Friday, a week before a fresh national vote.

Headline: May seen 13 seats short of majority - YouGov
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is on track to win 313 seats in Britain's parliament in next week's election, falling 13 seats short of a 326 seat majority, according to a projection by polling company YouGov on Friday.

Headline: MP charged with election offences to remain as candidate - May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday that a member of her Conservative Party who has been charged with criminal offences related to spending on the 2015 election will remain a  candidate for next week's national vote.

Headline: Factbox - Who might be Chancellor after next week's election?
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has declined to confirm that she will keep Philip Hammond as her Chancellor if she wins the June 8 national election, leading to speculation about who from her Conservative Party might replace him.

Headline: May's lead over Labour shrinks to 5 points - Ipsos MORI poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's lead over the opposition Labour party has shrunk to five points from 15 points just over two weeks ago, an opinion poll from Ipsos MORI showed on Friday.

Headline: Factbox - What happens with Brexit if there's no clear winner of UK election?
Description: Britain's June 8 election could be much tighter than previously thought, meaning that Prime Minister Theresa May could fail to win a clear majority in the 650-seat parliament.

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said she would consult businesses at every step of the Brexit negotiation including on a new migration strategy, the Financial Times reported.

Description: Dozens of people protested outside the BBC's London headquarters on Friday against its decision not to broadcast a song storming the charts before next week's election that labels Prime Minister Theresa May a liar.

Headline: May could win 60 seat majority - Ashcroft model estimate
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May could win a majority of 60 seats in the June 8 election, a model made by Michael Ashcroft estimated on Friday.

Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond may be replaced by Home Secretary Amber Rudd if Prime Minister Theresa May wins a landslide victory in next week's national election, the Telegraph newspaper reported on Friday.

Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said he would like to keep his current job if the Conservative Party remains in power after next week's election, declining to comment on reports that Prime Minister Theresa May plans to sack him.
