Description: Promising renationalisation of some services, measures to curb corporate excess and end healthcare cuts, Britain's Labour Party made its case on Tuesday for voters to back its move to the left and throw out the Conservatives at next month's election.

Headline: Factbox - Key election manifesto pledges from Labour Party
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party launched its manifesto on Tuesday for a June 8 election, promising to renationalise mail, rail and water services, increase tax on the highest earners and clamp down on corporate excess.

Headline: Inflation tightens screw on UK consumers as election nears
Description: British inflation hit its highest level since September 2013 last month, extending its sharp rise since the vote to leave the European Union and tightening the squeeze on living costs as a national election approaches.

Headline: Conservatives on 47 percent, stretch lead on rivals - Kantar poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have extended their lead over the opposition Labour Party ahead of the June 8 national election as support for smaller parties wanes, a poll by Kantar Public showed on Tuesday.

Headline: Labour party says would break up Royal Bank of Scotland
Description: The Labour Party would launch a consultation to break up state-owned Royal Bank of Scotland  into smaller local banks, the party said on Tuesday at the launch of its election manifesto.

Headline: UK National Grid pauses on Moorside nuclear project power line
Description: National Grid has put on hold development consent for a proposed power line connecting Britain's transmission network to the Moorside nuclear project in northwest England, in another blow to the project.

Headline: 'Fat cats keep the money', angry voter yells at May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May was confronted while out campaigning on Monday ahead of next month's election by an angry voter who scolded the British leader over cuts to disability benefits.

Headline: UK ambivalence over new EU military command centre irks allies - diplomats
Description: Conflicting signals from Britain over a planned military command centre the European Union wants to set up to run its foreign training missions have annoyed France and Germany in the countdown to the start of Brexit negotiations in June.

Headline: Sadistic British child killer, 'Moors Murderer' Ian Brady, dies
Description: One of Britain's most notorious killers, "Moors murderer" Ian Brady, who murdered five children with his lover and accomplice Myra Hindley during a sadistic two-year reign of terror in the 1960s died on Monday.

Headline: Cyber worm attack propels health funding to centre of British election campaign
Description: The most disruptive cyber attack in the history of Britain's National Health Service propelled a debate over state hospital funding to the centre of the election campaign on Monday, though officials said there had been no second wave of infections.

Headline: Most UK patients saw no change on Monday after cyber attack - minister
Description: Most patients saw no change to hospital services on Monday and all local doctors' surgeries opened after a cyber attack hit dozens of computers in Britain's health service, Home Secretary Amber Rudd said.

Headline: End of an era at the Sun tabloid as veteran provocateur dropped
Description: Britain's top-selling newspaper the Sun has turned a page in its colourful history by dropping provocative columnist Kelvin MacKenzie, a favourite of owner Rupert Murdoch, over an article that likened a soccer player to a gorilla.

Headline: Power-hunger and doublethink; Scottish politicians use Orwell to sling barbs
Description: The leader of the Scottish Conservatives Ruth Davidson used British writer George Orwell, a darling of the left, to attack her Scottish nationalist adversaries on Monday, saying no one party could purport to be the authentic voice of the nation.

Headline: English MP says swearing at a Scottish schoolgirl just 'a joke'
Description: An English MP from the ruling Conservatives who told a schoolgirl supporter of Scottish independence to "fuck off back to Scotland" and said he meant that as a joke, drew criticism on Monday from Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.

Headline: Targeting core Labour voters, May promises more workers' rights
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May promised on Monday to extend British workers' rights in the workplace and the boardroom, part of a push to win over traditional working class supporters of the opposition Labour Party in next month's election.

Headline: More disruptions feared from cyber attack; Microsoft slams government secrecy
Description: Officials across the globe scrambled over the weekend to catch the culprits behind a massive ransomware worm that disrupted operations at car factories, hospitals, shops and schools, while Microsoft on Sunday pinned blame on the U.S. government for not disclosing more software vulnerabilities.

Headline: Multinationals in Vietnam targeted by hackers linked to government - report
Description: Hackers either working for the Vietnamese government or on their behalf have broken into the computers of multinationals operating in the country as part of an increasingly sophisticated cyberespionage campaign, cybersecurity company FireEye  said.

Headline: British National Crime Agency says no second ransomware spike as yet
Description: Britain's National Crime Agency said it had not seen a second round of ransomware cyber attacks on Monday as experts had feared after 150 countries were hit last week, but added it could not rule out further disruption.

Headline: No second spike in cyber attacks is 'encouraging' - Jeremy Hunt
Description: Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt said on Monday it was "encouraging" that a predicted second spike of cyber attacks had not yet occurred, but the ransomware attack was a warning to public and private organisations.

Headline: UK energy price cap could mean job cuts, Innogy exit from UK market - Deutsche Bank
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's proposal to cap household energy prices if she is re-elected in June could mean a 600 million pound a year hit to the earnings of the country's "Big Six" energy companies and thousands of job cuts, Deutsche Bank said on Monday.

Headline: Conservatives stand 20 points ahead of Labour - ICM poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party held a 20 point lead over the opposition Labour Party, down a couple of points since last week but still a "largely impregnable" advantage, pollster ICM said on Monday.

Headline: UK government emergency committee to meet on cyber attack at 1600 GMT - spokesman
Description: The impact of the ransomware attack in Britain is much the same as it was but the government is monitoring the issue and will hold a meeting of its emergency committee at 1600 GMT on Monday, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said.

Headline: UK employers plan smallest pay rises since 2013 - survey
Description: British employers plan to increase pay at the weakest rate since 2013, a survey showed on Monday, offering poor prospects for British households already strained by higher inflation since last year's Brexit vote.

Headline: Conservatives hold 18 point poll lead - Survation
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have slightly extended their large lead over the opposition Labour Party as the state-run health service takes over from Brexit as the nation's top concern, a poll said on Monday.

Headline: Labour plans 'Robin Hood Tax', tax avoidance crackdown
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party would crack down on tax avoidance and introduce a "Robin Hood Tax" on financial transactions to fund public services if it wins next month's national election, it said on Saturday.

Headline: Australia and NZ largely escape global cyber attack
Description: Australia and New Zealand appeared to have escaped largely unscathed as they woke up for their first business day since a massive ransomware worm hit thousands of computer systems around the world, disrupting operations at hospitals, shops and schools.

Headline: Scotland needs choice on independence at end of Brexit - Sturgeon
Description: Scotland must have a choice on independence at the end of Britain's divorce with the European Union when the exit terms are clear, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Sunday.

Headline: Britain is gearing up for EU rows, Brexit minister says
Description: Britain is gearing up for rows with the EU over the structure of divorce talks and the future role of the European court, fuelling an increasingly bitter war of words before negotiations begin.

Headline: UK spending money to strengthen cyber security of health system - Fallon
Description: Britain is spending around 50 million pounds on improving the security of the National Health Service's computer systems and had warned the NHS it faced cyber threats, defence minister Michael Fallon said on Sunday.

Headline: Britain says it's a natural partner for China's new Silk Road
Description: British Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Sunday Britain is a natural partner for China's new Silk Road programme, and  as it leaves the European Union (EU) it wants more trade with the world not less.

Headline: UK Conservatives have 18 point lead over Labour - YouGov poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has an 18 point lead over the main opposition Labour Party ahead of a June 8 national election, according to an opinion poll conducted by YouGov for the Sunday Times

Headline: Conservatives have 18 point lead over Labour - Comres poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has an 18 point lead over the main opposition Labour Party ahead of a June 8 national election, according to an opinion poll conducted by Comres for the Sunday Mirror and the Independent.

Headline: Conservatives have 15 point lead over Labour - Opinium poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has a 15 point lead over the main opposition Labour Party ahead of a June 8 national election, according to an opinion poll conducted by Opinium Research.

Headline: UK interior minister Rudd says health system has recovered from cyber attack
Description: Britain's health system has recovered from the disruption caused by a global cyber attack, with 97 percent of the country's health service trusts now "working as normal", interior minister Amber Rudd said on Saturday.

Headline: Factbox - Carmakers, hospitals, others disrupted by global cyber attack
Description: A global cyber attack on Friday infected computers at businesses, healthcare facilities and other organizations in dozens of countries, disrupting operations at some facilities.

Headline: Poll gives Conservatives big lead ahead of June election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party maintained a strong lead over the main opposition Labour Party, ahead of a June 8 national election, according to an ORB opinion poll for The Telegraph.

Headline: Labour deputy leader warns of 'Thatcher style' landslide
Description: Britain's Conservative party will win a "Margaret Thatcher style" landslide in next month's national election unless the Labour party improves its poll ratings, according to Tom Watson, Labour's deputy leader.

Headline: Factbox - British hospitals suffer major cyber attack - What do we know so far?
Description: Britain's National Health Service (NHS) said it had suffered a major cyber attack on Friday, disrupting surgeries and hospitals, mainly in England.

Headline: UK government in dark over who behind cyber attack
Description: The British government does not yet know who was behind Friday's global cyber attack that disrupted the country's health system, Home Secretary Amber Rudd said on Saturday.

Headline: Factbox - Don't click: What is the 'ransomware' WannaCry worm?
Description: Malicious software called 'ransomware' has forced British hospitals to turn away patients and affected Spanish companies such as Telefonica as part of a global outbreak that has affected tens of thousands of computers.

Headline: Boris Johnson says Russia may try to interfere in election
Description: There is a "realistic possibility" Russia might try to interfere in Britain's national election next month, according to Boris Johnson, Britain's foreign secretary.

Headline: G7 nations to agree joint fight against cyber attacks - draft
Description: Finance chiefs from the Group of Seven rich countries will commit on Saturday to join forces to fight the growing threat of international cyber attacks, according to a draft statement of a meeting they are holding in Italy.

Headline: May pledges new powers to punish and tax social media firms
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May pledged to create new powers allowing her to punish social media and communications companies that fail to look after users' data, and to demand cash from firms to pay for policing the internet.

Headline: Cyberattack hits Russian Interior Ministry computers - Interfax
Description: Around 1,000 computers at the Russian Interior Ministry have been affected by the huge cyberattack that hit countries including Britain and Spain on Friday, a spokeswoman for the ministry told Interfax.

Headline: May says British hospitals not deliberately targeted in cyber attack
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said that British hospitals had not been deliberately targeted in a cyber attack on Friday that had encompassed a number of different countries.

Headline: Labour calls on government to explain health service cyber attack
Description: Britain's main opposition Labour Party called on the government to be clear about how a nationwide 'ransomware' cyber attack hit the state-run National Health Service (NHS) on Friday.

Headline: Scottish health boards also affected by cyber attacks
Description: A number of Scottish health boards have been affected by potential cyber incidents similar to those in England, Scotland's devolved government said on Friday.

Headline: British hospital workers were warned of 'ransomware' threat
Description: British hospital workers were warned on Friday that they were at threat from malicious software known as 'ransomware' that locks up computers and demands ransoms to restore access, according to an email seen by Reuters.

Headline: Corbyn says he is not a pacifist
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Friday he was not a pacifist and accepted that military action was sometimes necessary, as he sought to bolster his foreign policy credentials ahead of next month's election.

Headline: May says will publish election manifesto next week
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday her Conservative Party would publish its manifesto for a June 8 election next week.

Headline: Conservatives keep 17-point lead over Labour - Panelbase
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have kept a 17 percentage point lead over the Labour opposition, a month before Britons vote in a national election on June 8, a poll from market research company Panelbase showed on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain should stay in EU energy market in Brexit transition deal - think tank
Description: Britain should seek to remain in the European Union's energy market and carbon trading scheme in a transition period if a Brexit deal is not reached in two years, a report by think tank Chatham House said on Wednesday.

Headline: Bins, cooking, the bedroom - May offers glimpse of private life
Description: He takes the garbage out, she cooks at weekends and work never enters the bedroom - British Prime Minister Theresa May and her husband Philip offered a glimpse of their private lives in a television interview on Tuesday.

Headline: Labour leader promises good EU deal, won't say he would lead Britain out
Description: Opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Tuesday his Labour Party would negotiate a divorce deal with the EU to secure tariff-free trade if it won power next month, but declined to say whether he would lead Britain out of the bloc no matter what.

Headline: Corbyn - I won't quit if I lose election
Description: Jeremy Corbyn vowed to carry on leading Britain's opposition Labour Party if he loses a national election on June 8, defying polls showing he is on course for defeat and concerns from within his party that his leadership threatens its future.

Headline: Gibraltar says it plans for hard Brexit, end of access to EU market
Description: Gibraltar is preparing for a post-Brexit setup in which its firms will have no longer access to the European Union market but will maintain a preferential relationship with Britain, a top Gibraltar financial official said on Tuesday.

Headline: Independence is an unwanted election challenge for Scottish nationalists
Description: Calum Kerr, a parliamentarian from the Scottish National Party (SNP), is having to work hard to get his message across.

Headline: Man held near May's office in April charged with terrorism offences
Description: A man arrested near Prime Minister Theresa May's office in London last month has been charged with terrorism offences and will appear in court on Thursday, police said.

Headline: May vows energy price cap if re-elected
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May pledged on Tuesday to cap household energy prices if she is re-elected on June 8, sending stocks tumbling with the biggest market intervention since the sector was privatised almost 30 years ago.

Headline: If London were Aleppo - Buckingham Palace destroyed, 4.3 million dead or displaced
Description: The bullet-riddled, bombed-out buildings of Aleppo may bear little resemblance to London's gleaming skyscrapers but the two cities once had much in common, something German artist Hans Hack has seized on to bring home the reality of war.

Headline: May pledges annual defence spending rises until 2023
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May promised to increase the country's defence budget by at least 0.5 percent in real terms every year until 2023 if she wins a June 8 election, adding an extra two years to her party's existing spending pledge.

Headline: Three London women charged with terrorism offences - police
Description: Three women from London, including a mother and daughter, were charged on Wednesday with preparation of a terrorist act and conspiracy to murder, police said.

Headline: Germany's Schaeuble warns of cracks in EU over Brexit
Description: The European Union's remaining 27 members have managed to hold the project together since Britain voted to leave the bloc, "but the pendulum is swinging back", German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said on Wednesday.

Headline: After Macron win, EU lawmakers eye swap plan to close Strasbourg seat
Description: Plans to move the European Union's London-based medicines regulator to Strasbourg and push through a long-held project to close the EU parliament's expensive second seat in the French city are gaining traction among legislators, EU officials said.

Headline: No charges over alleged election expenses fraud by Conservatives
Description: No criminal charges will be brought over allegations of expenses fraud by Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives during their 2015 election campaign, prosecutors said on Wednesday, removing a cloud over the party before a new election next month.

Headline: Investigation proves Conservatives did nothing wrong in 2015 election - May
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday a legal investigation into the alleged misuse of election expenses by her Conservatives in the 2015 election showed the party's candidates "had done nothing wrong".

Headline: Labour to raise corporation tax to 26 percent if it wins election
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party said on Wednesday it would raise corporation tax to 26 percent from 19 percent if it wins a June 8 election, seeking to win over sceptical voters with a promise to spend the proceeds on education.

Headline: UK man held near May's office appears in court on terrorism charge
Description: A man arrested near Prime Minister Theresa May's office in London last month appeared in court on Wednesday and was remanded in custody after being charged with terrorism and explosives offences.

Headline: Conservatives keep 17-point lead over Labour - Panelbase
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have kept a 17 percentage point lead over the Labour opposition, a month before Britons vote in a national election on June 8, a poll from market research company Panelbase showed on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain should stay in EU energy market in Brexit transition deal - think tank
Description: Britain should seek to remain in the European Union's energy market and carbon trading scheme in a transition period if a Brexit deal is not reached in two years, a report by think tank Chatham House said on Wednesday.

Headline: Bins, cooking, the bedroom - May offers glimpse of private life
Description: He takes the garbage out, she cooks at weekends and work never enters the bedroom - British Prime Minister Theresa May and her husband Philip offered a glimpse of their private lives in a television interview on Tuesday.

Headline: Labour leader promises good EU deal, won't say he would lead Britain out
Description: Opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Tuesday his Labour Party would negotiate a divorce deal with the EU to secure tariff-free trade if it won power next month, but declined to say whether he would lead Britain out of the bloc no matter what.

Headline: Corbyn - I won't quit if I lose election
Description: Jeremy Corbyn vowed to carry on leading Britain's opposition Labour Party if he loses a national election on June 8, defying polls showing he is on course for defeat and concerns from within his party that his leadership threatens its future.

Headline: Gibraltar says it plans for hard Brexit, end of access to EU market
Description: Gibraltar is preparing for a post-Brexit setup in which its firms will have no longer access to the European Union market but will maintain a preferential relationship with Britain, a top Gibraltar financial official said on Tuesday.

Headline: Independence is an unwanted election challenge for Scottish nationalists
Description: Calum Kerr, a parliamentarian from the Scottish National Party (SNP), is having to work hard to get his message across.

Headline: Man held near May's office in April charged with terrorism offences
Description: A man arrested near Prime Minister Theresa May's office in London last month has been charged with terrorism offences and will appear in court on Thursday, police said.

Headline: May vows energy price cap if re-elected
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May pledged on Tuesday to cap household energy prices if she is re-elected on June 8, sending stocks tumbling with the biggest market intervention since the sector was privatised almost 30 years ago.

Headline: If London were Aleppo - Buckingham Palace destroyed, 4.3 million dead or displaced
Description: The bullet-riddled, bombed-out buildings of Aleppo may bear little resemblance to London's gleaming skyscrapers but the two cities once had much in common, something German artist Hans Hack has seized on to bring home the reality of war.

Headline: Conservatives' support slips, still hold big election lead - Kantar poll
Description: Support for British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives has slipped four percentage points ahead of a June 8 general election but they still hold a commanding lead over the opposition Labour Party, a Kantar Public poll showed on Tuesday.

Headline: Sun ousts Murdoch protege who likened football star to gorilla - FT
Description: Britain's top-selling newspaper The Sun is to oust Kelvin MacKenzie, a provocative columnist and long-time favourite of owner Rupert Murdoch, over an article widely criticised as racist, the Financial Times reported on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain's Business secretary says energy market is inefficient
Description: Britain's energy market is inefficient and gives the biggest players too much power to overcharge customers, Energy Secretary Greg Clark said on Tuesday as he set out plans to cap tariffs.

Headline: May reaffirms aim to bring down net immigration to 'tens of thousands' per year
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday her Conservative Party would keep its pledge to bring down net immigration to the United Kingdom down to "tens of thousands" per year if it wins an election next month.

Headline: May's Conservatives hold 17 point lead in election race - Survation
Description: Britain's ruling Conservative party holds a commanding 17 point lead over the opposition Labour party, a poll by Survation showed on Tuesday, with support for the anti-European Union UK Independence Party plummeting.

Headline: Facebook warns of fake news danger ahead of British election
Description: Facebook has launched a British newspaper advertising campaign to warn users of the dangers of fake news, in the latest drive by the social media giant to tackle malicious information ahead of a national election.

Headline: Macron to be tough in Brexit talks, but won't seek to punish UK - economic adviser
Description: France's President-elect Emmanuel Macron will be tough in negotiations over the terms of Britain's departure from the European Union but will not seek to punish Britain, his economic adviser said on Monday.

Headline: Conservatives open up record lead - ICM poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has opened up the biggest lead on record for polls conducted by research firm ICM, suggesting it remains on course for a sweeping win in a national election in a month's time.

Headline: Street artist Banksy tackles Brexit in Dover mural
Description: British street artist Banksy has taken on Brexit with a mural of a workman chipping away one of the 12 gold stars on the flag of the European Union on a wall in Dover, the ferry port that connects England with Calais in France.

Headline: Slowing economy likely to ruffle Bank of England hawks' feathers
Description: "Not yet" is likely to be the main message this week from Bank of England officials pondering when to start signalling an interest rate hike after a sharp slowdown rekindling doubt about Britain's economy ahead of Brexit.

Headline: Paris to redouble efforts to attract Brexit banks after Macron win
Description: Emmanuel Macron's victory in the French presidential election and his plans to swiftly implement structural reforms is a boon for Paris in its efforts to attract banks and other financial service companies seeking to move operations out of Britain, the head of lobbying group Paris Europlace said on Monday.

Headline: May maintains strong election lead in weekend opinion polls
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May maintained her strong lead in  opinion polls ahead of next month's national election, with one analyst saying she was on course for the kind of huge success Margaret Thatcher enjoyed over 30 years ago.

Headline: Conservatives maintain strong lead in ICM poll
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has an 18 percentage point lead over the main opposition Labour Party, implying a majority of at least 132 seats in a June 8 national election, according to an ICM poll for the Sun on Sunday.

Headline: Labour pledges no tax rise for middle-income earners
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party said middle and low earners would not face tax hikes to fund its spending plans if it wins next month's election, with the burden falling instead on the top five percent of earners and big business.

Headline: Conservatives extend lead by 6 points ahead of June 8 election - YouGov poll
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party extended its lead by six percentage points over the main opposition Labour Party in the past week ahead of a June 8 national election, according to a YouGov opinion poll for the Sunday Times.

Headline: Conservatives extend lead in ORB poll ahead of national election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has extended its lead slightly over the main opposition Labour party in the past week, according to an ORB opinion poll on Saturday.

Headline: Conservative lead stays strong ahead of June election - Opinium poll
Description: British Prime Minster Theresa May's Conservative Party is still a strong 16 points ahead of the main opposition Labour Party ahead of a national election on June 8, according to a poll by Opinium on Saturday.

Headline: Local polls boost May five weeks before UK national election
Description: Britain's Conservative Party made strong gains in local elections on Friday, suggesting Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy is winning over voters who should hand her an easy victory in a parliamentary poll next month.

Headline: British election candidate draws the short straw
Description: A candidate in Britain's local elections literally drew the short straw on Friday when voting officials resorted to the traditional sudden-death method of breaking a deadlock.

Headline: Influence of English is fading, says EU chief Juncker
Description: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker took a swipe at Britain on Friday, saying he would not give a speech in English because the language was becoming less significant following Brexit.

Headline: Merkel says wants good partnership with Britain after Brexit
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel called on Friday for fair and constructive negotiations with Britain over its exit from the European Union, with the aim of retaining a good partnership.

Headline: Brexit minister Davis says EU trying to bully Britain
Description: The European Commission is trying to bully Britain, Brexit minister David Davis said, ratcheting up the rhetoric before a national election in which the ruling Conservatives are asking voters to back them ahead of tough talks to leave the EU.

Headline: Text - PM May says EU seeking to affect result of British election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Wednesday accused European politicians and officials of seeking to affect the outcome of next month's national election.

Headline: British anti-terrorism police say plots contained after woman shot, arrests
Description: British counter-terrorism police said on Friday they had thwarted an active plot after a woman was shot during an armed raid on a house in north London in the second major security operation in the British capital in the space of a few hours.

Headline: Story withdrawn - London terrorism suspect was on Gaza flotilla ship in 2010: sources
Description: The story headlined "London terrorism suspect was on Gaza flotilla ship in 2010 - sources", published on April 28 is withdrawn and no substitute story will now be published.

Headline: UK Conservatives kick off formal election campaign with tax 'bombshell' poster
Description: Britain's governing Conservatives sought to move the election campaign on to the economy on Wednesday, taking aim at opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn with a poster warning of a tax "bombshell" if his Labour Party wins next month's vote.

Headline: Brexit won't be a success, but can be professionally managed - senior EU official
Description: Britain's exit from the European Union cannot be turned into a success, but it can be managed in a pragmatic way, a senior European Union official said in an interview with Politico on Wednesday.

Headline: UK Conservatives' lead over Labour widens to 24 points - Kantar poll
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has a wider lead over the opposition Labour Party than a week ago, an opinion poll published by research firm Kantar showed on Wednesday ahead of a national election on June 8.

Headline: Standard Chartered favours Frankfurt as EU hub after Brexit
Description: Standard Chartered is in talks with regulators about making Frankfurt its European base to secure market access to the European Union when Britain leaves the bloc.

Headline: EU's Juncker says British PM May is a 'tough lady'
Description: The head of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker said on Wednesday he has noted that British Prime Minister Theresa May was a "tough lady" but that he respected her and liked her as a person.

Headline: Britain must agree way of calculating exit dues - EU's Barnier
Description: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator said on Wednesday that London and the bloc needed to agree on a clear way of calculating how much Britain owed before starting any talks about a future relationship.

Headline: Corbyn suffers the curse of the election photo gaffe
Description: They are a photographer's delight and a spin doctor's nightmare - advertising posters with a message that can inadvertently ruin a carefully planned election walkabout.

Headline: Hammond warns moving clearing out of UK carries risks
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond warned on Thursday of potential risks if the European Union moves the clearing of euro-denominated securities like derivatives and bonds to within the euro zone after Brexit.

Headline: City of London's Brexit job losses limited to 'low thousands' - new policy chief
Description: A shift in banking jobs from Britain to continental Europe because of Brexit is likely be in the "low thousands", the City of London's new policy chief said on Thursday - and warned that a "turbulent" few months lay ahead.

Headline: Luxembourg says no sweetheart deals for financial firms fleeing Brexit
Description: Luxembourg is in talks with a wide range of financial firms looking to relocate out of London as Britain leaves the European Union, but it will not offer sweeteners to undercut rival centres, Finance Minister Pierre Gramegna said on Thursday.

Headline: British accounting watchdog investigates KPMG over Rolls-Royce audits
Description: Britain's accounting watchdog has opened an investigation into how KPMG checked the books of Rolls-Royce, the aero-engine group that agreed in January to pay 671 million pounds to settle a transatlantic bribery probe.

Headline: EU mulls relocation of UK clearing after Brexit, but no decision yet
Description: The European Commission is considering as a possible option the relocation of a big chunk of derivative clearing from London to the European Union after Britain leaves the bloc, but no decision has been taken yet, a top official said on Thursday.

Headline: Prince Philip, 95, to cease royal duties in autumn - palace
Description: Britain's Prince Philip, husband of Queen Elizabeth, is to permanently stand down from royal duties in the autumn, Buckingham Palace said in a statement on Thursday.

Headline: May's Conservatives hold 19-point lead in YouGov poll: The Times
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party holds a 19-point lead over opposition Labour Party ahead of a national election on June 8, according to a YouGov poll for The Times.

Headline: May says EU seeking to affect result of British election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May accused European politicians and officials on Wednesday of seeking to affect the outcome of the June 8 national election by issuing threats over Brexit.

Headline: Text - PM May says EU seeking to affect result of British election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Wednesday accused European politicians and officials of seeking to affect the outcome of next month's national election.

Headline: British anti-terrorism police say plots contained after woman shot, arrests
Description: British counter-terrorism police said on Friday they had thwarted an active plot after a woman was shot during an armed raid on a house in north London in the second major security operation in the British capital in the space of a few hours.

Headline: Story withdrawn - London terrorism suspect was on Gaza flotilla ship in 2010: sources
Description: The story headlined "London terrorism suspect was on Gaza flotilla ship in 2010 - sources", published on April 28 is withdrawn and no substitute story will now be published.

Headline: UK Conservatives kick off formal election campaign with tax 'bombshell' poster
Description: Britain's governing Conservatives sought to move the election campaign on to the economy on Wednesday, taking aim at opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn with a poster warning of a tax "bombshell" if his Labour Party wins next month's vote.

Headline: Brexit won't be a success, but can be professionally managed - senior EU official
Description: Britain's exit from the European Union cannot be turned into a success, but it can be managed in a pragmatic way, a senior European Union official said in an interview with Politico on Wednesday.

Headline: UK Conservatives' lead over Labour widens to 24 points - Kantar poll
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party has a wider lead over the opposition Labour Party than a week ago, an opinion poll published by research firm Kantar showed on Wednesday ahead of a national election on June 8.

Headline: Standard Chartered favours Frankfurt as EU hub after Brexit
Description: Standard Chartered is in talks with regulators about making Frankfurt its European base to secure market access to the European Union when Britain leaves the bloc.

Headline: EU's Juncker says British PM May is a 'tough lady'
Description: The head of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker said on Wednesday he has noted that British Prime Minister Theresa May was a "tough lady" but that he respected her and liked her as a person.

Headline: Britain must agree way of calculating exit dues - EU's Barnier
Description: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator said on Wednesday that London and the bloc needed to agree on a clear way of calculating how much Britain owed before starting any talks about a future relationship.

Headline: Corbyn suffers the curse of the election photo gaffe
Description: They are a photographer's delight and a spin doctor's nightmare - advertising posters with a message that can inadvertently ruin a carefully planned election walkabout.

Headline: UK's Brexit minister dismisses reports of rising Brexit bill
Description: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday that he did not recognise any of the figures published in the media for the bill that Britain could face when it leaves the European Union.

Headline: UK will not pay 100 billion euro EU exit bill, says Brexit minister
Description: Britain will not be paying 100 billion euros (84.58 billion pounds) to leave the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday after the Financial Times reported that the EU was preparing to demand that amount.

Headline: Britain's SSE says any energy price cap should be for limited period
Description: Any price cap on energy tariffs in Britain should be for a limited period and reviewed regularly, the country's second-largest energy supplier, SSE, said on Wednesday.

Headline: Norway opposition win could delay power cable to Britain
Description: A planned power interconnector between Norway and Britain may be delayed if the opposition Labour party, which is currently leading in the polls, wins Norway's election in September, the head of the project told Reuters.

Headline: UK Conservatives see lead cut to 17 points - Panelbase poll
Description: The Conservative Party of British Prime Minister Theresa May has a narrower lead over the opposition Labour Party than a week ago, an opinion poll published by research firm Panelbase showed on Wednesday ahead of a national election on June 8.

Headline: Rising Brexit 'bill' raises negotiating stakes
Description: EU negotiators have hiked possible payment demands for Brexit over recent weeks, officials say, widening the divide between Brussels and London, which questions whether it owes anything at all before talks start next month.

Headline: UK wants generous deal for EU residents post-Brexit - David Davis
Description: Britain's intention in negotiations over the post-Brexit status of European Union nationals already living in the United Kingdom is to give them very similar rights to those they enjoy now, Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday.

Headline: Poll shows slightly smaller lead for Conservatives
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party holds a 19-point lead over the main opposition Labour Party ahead of a national election on June 8, down a couple of points from last week, according to an opinion poll on Tuesday.

Headline: French prosecutors seek heavy fine for topless photos of the Duchess of Cambridge
Description: French prosecutors asked a court on Tuesday to impose a heavy fine on celebrity magazine Closer if it is found guilty of invading the privacy of Britain's Duchess of Cambridge, Kate Middleton, by publishing topless photos of her in 2012.

Headline: May promises to be 'bloody difficult woman' in Brexit talks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May promised EU officials on Tuesday that she would be "a bloody difficult woman" in divorce talks, after being criticised for underestimating the complexity of Brexit talks and having "illusions" over a deal.

Headline: May plays up 'bloody difficult woman' image after Juncker dinner reports
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May played up her credentials as a "bloody difficult woman" on Tuesday in response to reports of a fractious dinner with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker last week.

Headline: Dinner disaster? How to read the Brexit bust-up signals
Description: Britain is in uproar over a German newspaper account of last week's Brexit talks between Prime Minister Theresa May and EU chief executive Jean-Claude Juncker. Here are reading notes for the saga:

Headline: On day one as editor, Osborne taunts May over "unrealistic" Brexit
Description: On his first day as a newspaper editor, former finance minister George Osborne taunted British leader Theresa May over her snap election strategy and "unrealistic" Brexit stance.

Headline: UK's Brexit plan poses a risk to nuclear industry - lawmakers
Description: Britain's plan to leave the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom) when it quits the European Union will severely hinder nuclear trade and research, and threaten power supplies, a UK parliamentary committee said in a report on Tuesday.

Headline: May's spokesman says reports on London clearing regulation are speculation
Description: Media reports that the European Commission is rushing out proposals to regulate clearing houses in London are speculation, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK will not appeal court ruling on air pollution plan - PM May's spokesman
Description: The British government will not appeal a court ruling on its plans to tackle air pollution and will meet a deadline for May 9 to detail its efforts to improve air quality, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK says PM May to lead Brexit talks, approaching them with 'goodwill'
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will lead Britain's Brexit talks and is approaching the negotiations with goodwill, her spokesman said on Tuesday, responding to criticism that her government underestimated the complexity of the process.

Headline: May pledges not to increase VAT, quiet on other taxes
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not increase value-added tax (VAT) if her Conservative Party was elected on June 8, but she did not extend the same promise to other major taxes.

Headline: May dismisses 'Brussels gossip' over talks with EU's Juncker
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Monday dismissed an account of a difficult meeting between her and the head of the European Commission as "Brussels gossip", reiterating that the meeting had gone well.

Headline: Three young women arrested in London under anti-terrorism laws - police
Description: Three young women were arrested under anti-terrorism laws in east London on Monday in connection with a security operation in the capital last week, police said.

Headline: May's Conservatives hold 19 point lead over Labour - ICM poll
Description: The governing Conservative Party holds a 19 point lead over Labour, a poll by ICM said on Monday, a commanding advantage just slightly lower than the record lead recorded the previous weekend.

Headline: May expects tough talks; EU alarmed at Brexit 'illusions'
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May expects divorce talks with the European Union to be tough, she said on Sunday after EU leaders agreed stiff terms and voiced alarm at "illusions" in London that may wreck a deal.

Headline: MPs criticise social media over response to extremist content
Description: Social media were heavily criticised by a committee of British lawmakers on Monday for failing to do enough to remove illegal and extremist material posted on their sites, and for not preventing it appearing in the first place.

Headline: Labour gains in polls, but May's party keeps strong lead
Description: Three opinion polls showed a rise in support for Britain's opposition Labour Party, although Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives maintained a commanding lead ahead of a June 8 election expected to define the terms of the country's EU exit.

Headline: EU sets Britain tough divorce terms, slams budget veto
Description: European Union leaders endorsed stiff divorce terms for Britain on Saturday and warned Britons to have "no illusions" about swiftly securing a new relationship to keep their access to EU markets.

Headline: PM May's Conservatives hold 11 point lead over Labour - ORB poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative party holds an 11 point lead over the Labour opposition, a poll by ORB for the Sunday Telegraph said, showing a tighter race ahead of June's election than other pollsters.

Headline: PM May sees lead over Labour fall by 10 points in a week - YouGov
Description: Britain's governing Conservative party has seen its lead narrow considerably over the last week, a poll by YouGov showed on Sunday, the third poll of the weekend to show the party's advantage over the opposition shrink.

Headline: PM May sets out plans to protect pensions during takeovers
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May pledged to protect workers against irresponsible practices over pensions on Sunday, promising new regulations on how schemes are handled during corporate takeovers.

Headline: Britain gears up for negotiations of a 'lifetime' after EU outlines Brexit stance
Description: Britain's minister for leaving the European Union said on Saturday the country was gearing up for the most complex negotiations "in our lifetimes" after the European Union outlined its tough approach to Brexit talks.

Headline: May's Conservatives see lead slip to 17 points - Opinium poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's governing Conservative party has a 17 point lead over Labour, an Opinium poll showed on Saturday, slightly down from last week as support for smaller parties slipped.

Headline: EU says united Ireland would be automatic full member
Description: European Union leaders promised on Saturday to embrace the British province of Northern Ireland into the EU if a referendum in the future were to unite it with the Republic of Ireland.

Headline: UKIP leader Nuttall to stand in pro-Brexit stronghold in election
Description: The leader of eurosceptic party UKIP will stand in the constituency of Boston and Skegness in Britain's general election in June, the party said on Saturday, seeking to capitalise on strong pro-Brexit sentiment in the area.

Headline: Factbox - Candidates in Britain's snap election: comings and goings
Description: Britain's election on June 8 will mark the departure of some prominent lawmakers, while others are hoping to return.

Headline: 'Phased approach': How to read EU Brexit guidelines
Description: European Union leaders approved on Saturday guidelines for their chief Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier, setting priorities that the Union of 27 governments staying in the bloc wants to achieve in talks on Britain's withdrawal.

Headline: Factbox - Countdown to Brexit
Description: European Union leaders agreed a set of negotiating guidelines for talks on Britain's withdrawal from the bloc, which should be completed in two years.

Headline: Japan's Abe cautions against Brexit regulation cliff edge
Description: Japan's Shinzo Abe called on Prime Minister Theresa May to ensure a smooth transition for business as the United Kingdom leaves the European Union, to avoid a cliff edge where rules and regulations for firms change overnight.

Headline: Talks on new EU-UK ties must start quickly - Dutch PM
Description: The European Union and Britain need to make rapid progress on initial issues in Brexit negotiations and quickly start talking about their new trade and political relationship, Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte said on Saturday.

Headline: EU unity in Brexit talks in Britain's interest - Tusk
Description: The European Union will only be able to conclude talks on Britain's exit if it stays united, which means the bloc's unity is in Britain's interest, the chairman of EU summits Donald Tusk said on Saturday.

Headline: Japanese PM Abe asks May for 'smooth Brexit' for business
Description: Japanese leader Shinzo Abe asked Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday to ensure a smooth Brexit to allow Japanese companies to continue to operate as the United Kingdom exits the European Union.

Headline: More small housebuilders needed to fix UK's 'broken' market - report
Description: Britain will not fix its "broken" housing market unless it ends the dominance of the biggest housebuilders by supporting smaller providers to ramp up the rate of construction, a parliamentary committee warned on Saturday.

Headline: EU to say united Ireland would be automatic full member
Description: European Union leaders at a Brexit summit on Saturday will give a formal undertaking to embrace the British province of Northern Ireland in the EU if a referendum unites the island, diplomats said on Friday.

Headline: Anti-racism protesters crash anti-EU UKIP election launch
Description: The election campaign launch of Britain's eurosceptic UK Independence Party got off to a troubled start on Friday, when protesters accused its leader Paul Nuttall of promoting racist propaganda after he promised to ban full face veils.

Headline: Conservatives resurge as Scots shun new referendum on independence - poll
Description: Nearly half of Scottish voters do not want another referendum on independence and the issue appears to be driving up support for the Conservatives ahead of a June election, according to a YouGov poll published in The Times newspaper on Friday.

Headline: Japanese PM Abe says will work with May on North Korea, South China Sea disputes
Description: Japanese Prime Minister pledged on Friday to face down threats to international order from North Korea and building tensions over the South China Sea by working with British Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: UK government says Scottish Brexit proposal could disrupt trade - letter
Description: Trade between the United Kingdom's four nations could be disrupted if Scotland wins a different divorce deal with the European Union, a letter from Brexit minister David Davis published by the Scottish government said on Friday.

Headline: UK industry group warns against 'ill-considered' energy market regulation
Description: British lawmakers should campaign to make the energy market more competitive instead of pushing "ill-considered" regulation, the head of Britain's energy lobby group said, days after the ruling Conservative Party promised an energy price cap.

Headline: May says Merkel talk of UK illusions shows how tough Brexit talks will be
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's comments about Britain having illusions over its future relationship with the European Union show how tough the upcoming Brexit negotiations will be, Prime Minister Theresa May will say on Thursday.

Headline: London police shoot one, arrest four in counter-terrorism operation
Description: British police said officers shot a woman and arrested four other people in London and nearby Kent during a counter-terrorism investigation on Thursday.

Headline: Armed British police arrest man with knives near May's office
Description: Armed British police officers arrested a man carrying knives near Prime Minister Theresa May's office in London on Thursday on suspicion of preparing an act of terrorism.

Headline: Suspect in London knife incident may have had militant contacts outside UK - intelligence source
Description: The 27-year-old man detained carrying knives near Prime Minister Theresa May's office in London on Thursday may have had contacts with militants outside Britain and may have travelled to meet them, a source familiar with the investigation told Reuters.

Headline: Suspect packages sent to Scottish political offices before election
Description: Three suspicious packages containing "white powder type substances" were sent to political offices between April 25 and 26, the Scottish parliament said in a statement.

Headline: Britain loses case to delay submission of air pollution plan
Description: The British government has failed in a legal bid to delay the publication of its plan to tackle air pollution until after the general election on June 8.

Headline: May says government speaking to Nestle over job cuts
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday her government was talking to Nestle after the Swiss-based company announced plans to cut almost 300 jobs in Britain, a move she said was not connected to Brexit.

Headline: UK complains to Twitter over withdrawal of access to user data
Description: Britain has protested to Twitter  over restricting the government's access to data, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Number of BBC bosses on salaries over 150,000 pounds rises despite promise to cut
Description: The number of senior managers at the BBC earning more than 150,000 pounds a year has risen despite a promise by the publicly-funded broadcaster to cut the figure by a fifth, Britain's spending watchdog said on Wednesday.

Headline: May says pensioner incomes will rise, avoids hard commitment
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday that old age pension payments would continue to rise if her party wins a June 8 election, but avoided renewing a pledge made by her predecessor that mandates a minimum 2.5 percent annual rise.

Headline: 'More transparency' needed over lethal drone strike against British radical, lawmakers says
Description: Lawmakers investigating a drone strike which killed a British radical in Syria said they were disappointed by a lack of transparency which hindered their efforts to assess whether the strike was proportional.

Headline: May's Conservatives hold 22 point lead in Panelbase poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party held a 22 percentage point lead in a poll conducted by Panelbase, putting her on course for a commanding victory in the June 8 election.

Headline: UK not seeking divide and rule approach in Brexit talks - minister
Description: Britain will not seek to take a divide and rule approach with the other 27 member states of the European Union in upcoming Brexit negotiations, Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday.

Headline: Fighting for every vote, May takes on 'separatists'
Description: Despite her runaway lead in opinion polls, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday she would fight for every vote in an election she hopes will strengthen her in Brexit talks with the EU and help her prevent the break-up of the United Kingdom.

Headline: Candidates in Britain's snap election: comings and goings
Description: Britain's election on June 8 will mark the departure of some prominent lawmakers, while others are hoping to return.

Headline: Court to hold hearing on UK air quality report delay - campaigners
Description: London's High Court will hold a hearing on Thursday over the British government's bid to postpone publishing its plans to reduce air pollution, environmental campaigners said on Tuesday.

Headline: State opening of British parliament to be held on June 19 - May's spokesman
Description: Queen Elizabeth will formally open a new session of Britain's parliament on June 19 after an early election on June 8, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: UK could join U.S. action in event of new Syria chemical attack - Johnson
Description: Britain would find it difficult to refuse a request for military assistance in Syria from the United States if President Donald Trump decided to take action against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad over chemical weapons use, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said.

Headline: Poll shows smaller lead for May's Conservatives - The Times
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party holds a 16-point lead over the main opposition Labour Party ahead of a national election on June 8, an opinion poll showed on Wednesday, a smaller lead than other polls have suggested.

Headline: May's Conservatives take 23 point poll lead, matching Thatcher landslide - Ipsos MORI
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have almost twice as much voter support as the opposition Labour Party ahead of a June 8 election, a lead equal to that commanded by Margaret Thatcher before her 1983 landslide victory, Ipsos MORI said.

Headline: UK plain cigarette pack law seen cutting number of smokers by 300,000
Description: The introduction of plain packaging for tobacco cigarettes sold in Britain from next month could cut the number of smokers in the country by another 300,000 within a year, researchers said on Thursday.

Headline: Drugs firms call for phased transition of regulation after Brexit
Description: Pharmaceutical companies called on Thursday for a phased transition in drug regulation after Britain leaves the European Union, in order to avoid supply disruption and protect public health.

Headline: May tries to warm the Brexit atmosphere with EU
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on Wednesday she wanted a "deep and special relationship" with the European Union, trying to warm the atmosphere before Brexit talks begin.

Headline: May tells EU's Juncker she wants 'deep and special partnership'
Description: Britain is committed "to achieving a deep and special partnership with the European Union", British Prime Minister Theresa May told European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker on Wednesday, her spokesperson said.

Headline: 'Plaster may fall off the ceiling': Britain sees tough EU talks
Description: Divorce talks with the EU could be so tough that "plaster may fall off the ceiling", but Prime Minister Theresa May will win a deal to help Britain forge a more global role, her foreign minister said on Wednesday.

Headline: 'Have a little swagger', CEOs tell May in bid to make Brexit pay
Description: Global chief executives and investors had some sharp advice for Prime Minister Theresa May on Wednesday: Make Brexit a success by looking beyond the European Union and adopting a little swagger about the benefits of the world's fifth largest economy.

Headline: UK welcomes U.S. sanctions on those said linked to Syrian chemical weapons
Description: Britain welcomed U.S. sanctions against individuals alleged to be connected to the use of chemical weapons in Syria on Monday, saying they were a clear signal "that actions have consequences".

Headline: May's Conservatives on track for historic election win in Wales - poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives are on track to win the majority of parliamentary seats in Wales for the first time in more than 100 years, according to a YouGov poll published on Monday.

Headline: Poll gives May's Conservatives commanding lead ahead of June election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have a commanding lead over the opposition Labour Party, an ICM opinion poll for the Guardian newspaper said on Monday.

Headline: Factbox - Candidates in Britain's snap election: comings and goings
Description: Britain's election on June 8 will mark the departure of some prominent lawmakers, while others are hoping to return.

Headline: UK election cuts time for Brexit talks, key EU lawmaker says
Description: The snap general election called by British Prime Minister Theresa May will reduce the already limited time available to negotiate a Brexit deal, an influential EU lawmaker said on Monday.

Headline: UK seeks permission to delay air pollution report until Sept. 15
Description: The British government is seeking permission to delay a report on tackling air pollution until Sept. 15, breaking a court deadline for it to comply with European Union legislation.

Headline: UK Conservatives pledge energy price cap, hitting utility shares
Description: Britain's ruling Conservative Party said it would cap domestic energy prices if it retained power in an election in June, targeting an industry it accuses of not working properly and sending shares in the leading providers down sharply.

Headline: UK government plans to publish draft air quality plan by June 30
Description: The British government intends to publish a draft copy of its report on tackling air pollution by the end of June, ahead of publication of a final report in September, environment minister Andrea Leadsom said on Monday.

Headline: Factbox - Candidates in Britain's snap election: comings and goings
Description: Britain's election on June 8 will mark the departure of some prominent lawmakers, while others are hoping to return.

Headline: May's Conservatives hold 19 point lead in Opinium UK election poll
Description: Theresa May's Conservative party held a 19 percentage point lead over Labour in a poll by research group Opinium on Saturday, helped by a slide in support for the main opposition party and the anti-EU group UKIP ahead of a June election.

Headline: Court to hold hearing on UK air quality report delay - campaigners
Description: London's High Court will hold a hearing on Thursday over the British government's bid to postpone publishing its plans to reduce air pollution, environmental campaigners said on Tuesday.

Headline: Labour to guarantee EU citizens' rights if wins election
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party will immediately guarantee the rights of millions of EU citizens living in the UK if it wins a June election, it said on Tuesday, setting out a Brexit strategy aimed at eating into Prime Minister Theresa May's runaway lead.

Headline: EU tightens Brexit demands on residence, banks - document
Description: European Union leaders will insist Britain grant permanent residence to EU citizens who arrive before Brexit in 2019 and stay five more years, according to a draft negotiating plan they will endorse this weekend.

Headline: Conservatives hold big lead over Labour before June election - poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have a large lead over the opposition Labour Party, according to an opinion poll published on Tuesday by the Kantar research group.

Headline: Brexit to dominate as May sets out stall for re-election
Description: Whatever Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives promise in their manifesto before a June election, managing Britain's exit from the European Union will limit her opportunity to push wide-ranging radical domestic change.

Headline: Treasury Committee chair Tyrie says will step down as MP
Description: British lawmaker Andrew Tyrie, the chairman of parliament's Treasury Committee, said on Tuesday he would not stand in the June 8 national election.

Headline: Hammond hits budget deficit target, bigger tests ahead
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond avoided a potentially embarrassing slip-up before June's parliamentary election as he hit his budget deficit target for the 2016/17 financial year, but his fiscal challenge is likely to get harder.

Headline: Soccer referee seeks to send off senior Scottish nationalist in UK election
Description: A lawmaker from Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party who works as a soccer referee is seeking to send off one of the leading lights of the pro-independence Scottish National Party (SNP) in the United Kingdom's June 8 election.

Headline: May to host meeting with Japanese PM Abe on Friday
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will host her Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe for talks at her official country residence on Friday, May's spokesman told reporters on Tuesday.

Headline: Centrica boss says some in May's government lack faith in free markets
Description: A plan by Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party to cap energy prices suggests some in her government do not believe in free markets at a time when it is pinning its post-Brexit hopes on free trade, the head of the country's leading provider said.

Headline: Scots don't want another independence vote - Kantar poll
Description: Most Scottish voters do not want another referendum on independence from the United Kingdom and support for secession itself appears to have weakened, according to a Kantar survey.

Headline: UK welcomes U.S. sanctions on those said linked to Syrian chemical weapons
Description: Britain welcomed U.S. sanctions against individuals alleged to be connected to the use of chemical weapons in Syria on Monday, saying they were a clear signal "that actions have consequences".

Headline: May's Conservatives on track for historic election win in Wales - poll
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives are on track to win the majority of parliamentary seats in Wales for the first time in more than 100 years, according to a YouGov poll published on Monday.

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have a commanding lead over the opposition Labour Party, an ICM opinion poll for the Guardian newspaper said on Monday.
