Description: Britain's election on June 8 will mark the departure of some prominent lawmakers, while others are hoping to return.

Headline: UK election cuts time for Brexit talks, key EU lawmaker says
Description: The snap general election called by British Prime Minister Theresa May will reduce the already limited time available to negotiate a Brexit deal, an influential EU lawmaker said on Monday.

Headline: UK seeks permission to delay air pollution report until Sept. 15
Description: The British government is seeking permission to delay a report on tackling air pollution until Sept. 15, breaking a court deadline for it to comply with European Union legislation.

Headline: UK Conservatives pledge energy price cap, hitting utility shares
Description: Britain's ruling Conservative Party said it would cap domestic energy prices if it retained power in an election in June, targeting an industry it accuses of not working properly and sending shares in the leading providers down sharply.

Headline: UK government plans to publish draft air quality plan by June 30
Description: The British government intends to publish a draft copy of its report on tackling air pollution by the end of June, ahead of publication of a final report in September, environment minister Andrea Leadsom said on Monday.

Headline: Factbox - Candidates in Britain's snap election: comings and goings
Description: Britain's election on June 8 will mark the departure of some prominent lawmakers, while others are hoping to return.

Headline: May's Conservatives hold 19 point lead in Opinium UK election poll
Description: Theresa May's Conservative party held a 19 percentage point lead over Labour in a poll by research group Opinium on Saturday, helped by a slide in support for the main opposition party and the anti-EU group UKIP ahead of a June election.

Headline: May refuses to rule out personal tax hikes after election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May refused on Saturday to rule out an increase in personal taxes if she wins a June election, riling supporters at the start of a campaign designed to strengthen her hand ahead of Brexit talks.

Headline: Fallon says energy markets not working, intervention needed
Description: Conservative Party will intervene in the energy market if it wins an upcoming election in June because the current system is not working properly, Defence Secretary Michael Fallon said on Monday.

Headline: Holidays, burka bans, Brexit vote - UK parties set out election stalls
Description: More holidays, a burka ban and an end to hard Brexit - just some of the policies Britain's opposition parties hope will prevent an overwhelming election victory by Conservative Prime Minister Theresa May in June.

Headline: Conservatives hold 22-point lead ahead of UK election - ICM poll
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives have a 22 point lead over Labour, an ICM poll said on Sunday ahead of a general election on June 8.

Headline: Labour leader Corbyn says could suspend Syria air strikes if elected
Description: The leader of Britain's main opposition Labour Party Jeremy Corbyn said on Sunday he could suspend British involvement in air strikes against Syria if he was elected prime minister at a June 8 election.

Headline: Conservatives to focus on Brexit, energy in poll- minister
Description: Britain's ruling Conservative Party's election manifesto will focus on Brexit and domestic concerns, such as strengthening the economy and putting a cap on energy prices, Work and Pensions minister Damian Green said on Sunday.

Headline: May's Conservatives on course for sweeping election victory
Description: Theresa May appeared on course to win a crushing election victory in June after opinion polls put support for her ruling Conservative party at around 50 percent, double that of the opposition Labour party.

Headline: Brexit makes campsites cool again as Britons tighten belts
Description: Before last year's Brexit vote, Scott McCready was struggling to fill his holiday cabins on the coast of southwest England. Now the site is fully booked with British tourists avoiding more expensive foreign trips following a plunge in the pound.

Headline: May's Conservatives at 50 percent in poll, highest since 1991
Description: Support for Theresa May's ruling Conservatives was at 50 percent in a Comres poll published on Saturday, putting the prime minister on course for a landslide election victory on June 8.

Headline: PM May's Conservatives on 48 percent support in YouGov poll
Description: Support for Theresa May's ruling Conservatives stood at 48 percent in a YouGov poll for the Sunday Times, the third poll in as many hours to put the British prime minister on course for a sweeping election victory on June 8.

Headline: May says June election result 'not certain'
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday that she was not taking anything for granted as she geared up for a snap election in June, in which polls suggest her Conservative party was heading for a landslide victory.

Headline: Election regulator investigates pro-Brexit Leave.EU campaign group
Description: Britain's Electoral Commission said on Friday it was investigating whether the influential pro-Brexit Leave.EU campaign group broke the law over donations it received during last year's European Union referendum.

Headline: Labour MP says her party is not trying to win election
Description: A lawmaker from Britain's opposition Labour Party publicly admitted that the party is not trying to win a snap election that Conservative Prime Minister Theresa May called for June 8.

Headline: Queen celebrates 91st birthday
Description: Queen Elizabeth, the world's oldest and longest-reigning monarch, celebrated her 91st birthday in a usual low-key fashion on Friday.

Headline: State visit by Spanish king to Britain postponed due to snap election
Description: A planned state visit by King Felipe of Spain and his wife to Britain in June has been postponed for a month to avoid clashing with a snap election called by British Prime Minister Theresa May, Buckingham Palace said on Friday.

Headline: UK government says it will extend Northern Ireland talks' deadline to June 29
Description: The British government on Friday said it was willing to extend the deadline on talks to form a power-sharing executive in Northern Ireland between Irish nationalists and pro-British unionists to late June in light of a snap UK-wide election.

Headline: Former UKIP leader Farage says won't stand in 2017 election - Telegraph
Description: Former UKIP leader Nigel Farage said he will not be standing in Britain's 2017 election, in a opinion piece for the Daily Telegraph.

Headline: UK risks 22 percent tariff on EU food imports if no Brexit deal - retailers
Description: British shoppers could face an average tariff of 22 percent on food from the European Union if Prime Minister Theresa May fails to reach a trade deal with Brussels before Britain leaves in two years time, retailers said on Thursday.

Headline: Labour's Corbyn sets election tone, targeting British establishment
Description: Opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Thursday he would defeat a "cosy cartel" at the heart of British politics, casting himself as the anti-establishment challenger in a snap election called by Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: May says sticking to net migration target of less than 100,000 a year
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May plans to stick to her pledge to reduce annual net migration to below 100,000 a year, she said on Thursday, as her governing Conservatives put together their manifesto for a snap election in June.

Headline: Britain's Linklaters offers German lawyers fixed-hour career path
Description: Lawyers working for Linklaters in Germany will be able to work fewer hours for lower pay from next month, breaking the profession's mould of punishing workloads.

Headline: UK government to extend Northern Ireland talks deadline until end of June - sources
Description: The British government has decided to extend the deadline on talks to form a power-sharing executive in Northern Ireland between Irish nationalists and pro-British unionists until after a snap UK-wide election, two sources told Reuters on Thursday.

Headline: Factbox - Candidates in Britain's snap election: comings and goings
Description: Britain's election on June 8 will see some prominent lawmakers stand down, while others are hoping to return.

Headline: EU's Juncker to meet May in London next week
Description: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker will meet Prime Minister Theresa May in London next Wednesday to discuss Britain's exit from the European Union, a Commission spokeswoman said on Thursday.

Headline: On path to forecast landslide, May must win over pro-EU voters
Description: Polls show British Prime Minister Theresa May on course to a landslide in the election she has called for June. But if her Conservative Party faces one potential snag in its march towards victory, it could be in places like Lewes, a small town beneath a picturesque castle in the hills near England's southern coast.

Headline: May to make election pledge to end EU free movement of people into UK - Daily Mail
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will make a formal pledge ahead of the June 8 election to end European Union free movement of people into Britain, the Daily Mail newspaper reported, citing unidentified party sources.

Headline: Britain will lose more from Brexit than EU, bloc's foreign policy chief says
Description: Britain will lose more than the European Union from its decision to leave the bloc, the EU's top diplomat said on Thursday, and talks with London were expected to be difficult.

Headline: May wins parliament's backing for June 8 snap election
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May won parliament's backing for an early election on Wednesday, a vote she said would strengthen her hand in divorce talks with the European Union and help heal divisions in Britain.

Headline: May's Conservatives lead in latest election YouGov poll - The Times
Description: In the latest poll conducted since Britain Prime Minister Theresa May called election, the Conservative Party lead with 48 percent, followed by the Labour Party with 24 percent, The Times reported, citing YouGov poll data.

Headline: UK snap election may boost Scottish independence hopes, Sturgeon says
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's decision to seek an early election on June 8 gives Scotland a chance to reinforce its democratic mandate to hold an independence referendum, Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon suggested on Tuesday.

Headline: Factbox - May calls election: What next?
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May called on Tuesday for an early parliamentary election on June 8. Here are the steps needed before the vote happens and possible political consequences.

Headline: Germany hopes Britain's early election leads to more Brexit clarity
Description: German Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel said he hoped early elections called by Britain's prime minister would bring more "clarity and accountability" in its negotiations to leave the European Union.

Headline: May decided on early election during holiday in Wales - ITV
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that it was during a walking holiday in Wales when she decided she would hold an early election to strengthen her hand in talks with the European Union.

Headline: EU's Brexit plans unchanged by UK vote - spokesman
Description: The European Union will stick to a timetable for preparing to launch Brexit negotiations with Britain, despite Theresa May calling for a snap general election on June 8, an EU spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: May's vote call a 'Hitchcock' twist to Brexit story - EU's Tusk
Description: Theresa's May's call for a snap election is a Brexit plot twist worthy of master of suspense Alfred Hitchcock, the EU official running negotiations on Britain's withdrawal said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK election will determine future direction of Scotland - Sturgeon
Description: An early general election will help determine the future direction of Scotland, first minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Tuesday, as she seized on Theresa May's announcement to build her case for a second independence referendum.

Headline: May trying to force 'hard Brexit' with election call - Scotland's Sturgeon
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is trying to force Britain into a "hard Brexit" by calling for an early election on June 8, Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Tuesday.

Headline: Text - May calls June 8 election
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May called on Tuesday for an early election on June 8, saying she needed to strengthen her hand in divorce talks with the European Union by shoring up support for her Brexit plan.

Headline: UK Conservatives heavy odds-on favourites for most seats in election - Ladbrokes
Description: Britain's ruling Conservative Party are 1 to 10 to take the most seats in a June 8 General Election, according to odds quoted by bookmaker Ladbrokes.

Headline: Early British election won't affect Brexit talks, says Germany
Description: A planned early election in Britain, announced by Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday, will not delay negotiations on its withdrawal from the European Union, German Chancellor Angela Merkel's government said on Wednesday.

Headline: May says early election averts clash with end of Brexit talks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday that holding an early election on June 8 rather than waiting until 2020 would avert a situation where she would face a crunch time in EU talks and a domestic election at the same time.

Headline: British companies to increase ad budgets this year despite Brexit uncertainty - survey
Description: British companies plan to increase their spending on advertising this year as they expect the UK economy to remain resilient despite the Brexit vote, a survey showed on Wednesday, reversing a previous forecast for a decline in ad budgets.

Headline: May calls for early election to strengthen Brexit hand
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May called on Tuesday for an early election on June 8, saying she needed to strengthen her hand in divorce talks with the European Union by bolstering support for her Brexit plan.

Headline: Britain's May tells Trump about plans for early election - White House
Description: President Donald Trump received a phone call on Tuesday from British Prime Minister Theresa May on her plans for an early election in June, the White House said in a statement.

Headline: May could win 114-seat majority in June 8 election - paper
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May could win a landslide majority of 114 seats in a June 8 election, The Times newspaper reported, citing YouGov polling data.

Headline: Britain's May calls Trump, European leaders after poll announcement
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May called U.S. President Donald Trump, German Chancellor Angela Merkel and other European leaders after she asked parliament to agree to an early election on June 8, a spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: EU welcomes May's 'Hitchcock' twist, still expects Brexit
Description: The European Union welcomed a snap British election that one of its leaders likened to a Hitchcock plot twist, but there was conspicuously little talk in Brussels of the vote halting Britain's exit from the bloc.

Headline: Ireland fears UK election could damage talks to ease Northern Ireland impasse
Description: Ireland fears British Prime Minister Theresa May's call for an early general election in June could damage chances of resolving the political crisis in Northern Ireland, the Irish Republic's foreign minister said on Tuesday.

Headline: Hammond welcomes sterling gains after election call
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said sharp gains in sterling on Tuesday after Prime Minister Theresa May called for a snap election showed markets wanted a stronger Conservative government to lead Brexit talks.

Headline: UK Supreme Court denies Big Tobacco appeal, plain packaging to go ahead
Description: Britain's Supreme Court has denied the tobacco industry permission to appeal a new plain packaging law, meaning that from next month, as planned, all tobacco products sold in the United Kingdom will have dark brown packaging and no branding.

Headline: Honing Brexit campaign, EU takes aim at UK residence red tape
Description: The European Union should tell London to cut red tape that makes it hard for EU expats to confirm their residence in Britain, senior EU officials said after a meeting in Brussels on Tuesday to prepare for Brexit talks.

Headline: UK cost agency turns down Bristol drug for head and neck cancer
Description: Britain's healthcare cost-effectiveness watchdog NICE said on Tuesday that Bristol-Myers Squibb's immunotherapy drug Opdivo was not worth using on the state health service for treating head and neck cancer due to its high price.

Headline: Thousands of UK police pay respects to officer killed in attack
Description: Thousands of police officers across Britain marked a two-minute silence on Monday to coincide with the funeral of Constable Keith Palmer who was killed in last month's attack outside parliament in London.

Headline: Brexit to trigger UK farm policy overhaul and EU funding gap
Description: Britain is expected to radically overhaul agricultural policy after it leaves the European Union and the bloc may have to make changes too when it loses Britain's net contributions to the region's farming budget.

Headline: Twenty-one countries vie to host EU drug agency after Brexit
Description: The European Medicines Agency has had expressions of interest to host the London-based regulator from 21 of the 27 countries that will form the European Union once Britain leaves, revealing rivalry from Amsterdam to Zagreb for a prized institution.

Headline: UK car industry defends diesel as government readies pollution plan
Description: Britain's automotive industry body defended diesel cars on Monday, as the government prepares to announce proposals for improving air quality which could follow London in making it more expensive to use the most polluting vehicles.

Headline: Russia criticises UK decision to cancel Johnson visit to Moscow
Description: The decision by British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson to cancel a visit to Moscow later this month shows a lack of understanding of events in Syria, Russia's foreign ministry said on Sunday.

Headline: Sinn Fein demands new Northern Ireland elections if talks fail
Description: Northern Ireland should hold new elections if parties fail to reach agreement on forming a new government by a deadline next week, a senior member of Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein said on Friday, after a week of talks he said brought little progress.

Headline: Woman injured in Westminster attack has died - police
Description: A woman who was injured in the March 22 attack on Westminster has died, police said on Friday, taking the death toll from the incident to six including the attacker.

Headline: Michael Caine on Brexit - "I’d rather be a poor master"
Description: British actor Michael Caine, who voted for a British exit from the European Union in the June 23 referendum, said he would rather be a poor master than a rich servant and that post-Brexit Britain would endure.

Headline: UK could allow EU freedom of movement after Brexit, Boris Johnson says
Description: Britain could allow free movement of people from the European Union during an implementation phase after Brexit to allow the economy to attract talented people, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Thursday.

Headline: Irish PM says we must not return to hard border with Northern Ireland
Description: Negotiations on Britain's departure from the European Union must not undermine peace in Northern Ireland and there can be no "hard border" between the British province and the Irish Republic, Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny said on Thursday.

Headline: Tusk, May want to reduce tensions in Brexit talks
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk and British Prime Minister Theresa May agreed to seek to lower tensions in Brexit talks, especially when dealing with "inevitably difficult" issues like that of Gibraltar, an EU official said.

Headline: May and Tusk will seek to reduce tensions in Brexit talks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May and European Council President Donald Tusk agreed on Thursday to try to lower tensions in upcoming Brexit talks, especially over issues like Gibraltar.

Headline: As Brexit bites, Ryanair to pivot growth away from UK for next two years
Description: Ryanair , Europe's largest airline by passenger numbers, plans to pivot its growth away from Britain over the next two years as it fears the lack of clarity over Brexit will cause major travel disruption and hit demand.

Headline: May says government will act where consumer markets not working
Description: The British government is prepared to intervene in consumer markets to reduce costs for bill payers, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: Supreme Court rules against father who took daughter to Disney World in school time
Description: Britain's Supreme Court on Thursday ruled against a father who took his daughter on an unauthorised holiday during term-time, saying parents needed to act within school regulations.

Headline: May heads for electoral test over Brexit and her leadership
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May unleashed a scathing attack on Britain's main opposition party on Thursday, launching a campaign for local elections next month that will be the biggest electoral test so far of her leadership and her plan to leave the EU.

Headline: May suggests free movement could continue during Brexit implementation - BBC
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has not ruled out allowing the free movement of people between Britain and the European Union during "an implementation phase" after Britain leaves the bloc, the BBC reported on Wednesday.

Headline: Post-Brexit customs checks a 'catastrophe' for UK shipping - trade body
Description: The introduction of physical customs checks following Brexit would be a catastrophe for British ports and shipping and would likely reduce the volume of trade, the head of the sector's UK industry body said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK Supreme Court denies Big Tobacco appeal, plain packaging to go ahead
Description: Britain's Supreme Court has denied the tobacco industry permission to appeal a new plain packaging law, meaning that from next month, as planned, all tobacco products sold in the United Kingdom will have dark brown packaging and no branding.

Headline: Honing Brexit campaign, EU takes aim at UK residence red tape
Description: The European Union should tell London to cut red tape that makes it hard for EU expats to confirm their residence in Britain, senior EU officials said after a meeting in Brussels on Tuesday to prepare for Brexit talks.

Headline: UK cost agency turns down Bristol drug for head and neck cancer
Description: Britain's healthcare cost-effectiveness watchdog NICE said on Tuesday that Bristol-Myers Squibb's immunotherapy drug Opdivo was not worth using on the state health service for treating head and neck cancer due to its high price.

Headline: Thousands of UK police pay respects to officer killed in attack
Description: Thousands of police officers across Britain marked a two-minute silence on Monday to coincide with the funeral of Constable Keith Palmer who was killed in last month's attack outside parliament in London.

Headline: Brexit to trigger UK farm policy overhaul and EU funding gap
Description: Britain is expected to radically overhaul agricultural policy after it leaves the European Union and the bloc may have to make changes too when it loses Britain's net contributions to the region's farming budget.

Headline: Twenty-one countries vie to host EU drug agency after Brexit
Description: The European Medicines Agency has had expressions of interest to host the London-based regulator from 21 of the 27 countries that will form the European Union once Britain leaves, revealing rivalry from Amsterdam to Zagreb for a prized institution.

Headline: UK car industry defends diesel as government readies pollution plan
Description: Britain's automotive industry body defended diesel cars on Monday, as the government prepares to announce proposals for improving air quality which could follow London in making it more expensive to use the most polluting vehicles.

Headline: Russia criticises UK decision to cancel Johnson visit to Moscow
Description: The decision by British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson to cancel a visit to Moscow later this month shows a lack of understanding of events in Syria, Russia's foreign ministry said on Sunday.

Headline: Sinn Fein demands new Northern Ireland elections if talks fail
Description: Northern Ireland should hold new elections if parties fail to reach agreement on forming a new government by a deadline next week, a senior member of Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein said on Friday, after a week of talks he said brought little progress.

Headline: Hammond says government looking at range of Brexit outcomes
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said on Tuesday that the government was looking at a range of potential outcomes for forthcoming Brexit talks, but declined to say if his department had conducted a detailed economic analysis.

Headline: Britain allocates 1 billion pounds for Syrian refugees, host countries
Description: Britain said on Tuesday it has allocated 1 billion pounds  ($1.24 billion), including 160 million pounds of new money, to help Syrian refugees displaced by six years of civil war and countries that host them.

Headline: EU will release 60 million euros to help Britain repair 2015-16 flood damage
Description: Britain will get 60 million euros (51.3 million pounds) from the European Union to repair damage caused by the floods last year, a lawmaker said on Tuesday.

Headline: British police charge 13 people over attack on asylum seeker in London
Description: British police said they had now charged 13 people on Tuesday  over a brutal attack on a teenage asylum seeker in south London which detectives said he was lucky to survive.

Headline: UK tourism body calls for visa-free EU travel after Brexit
Description: Britain should aim to secure visa-free travel between the UK and the European Union in upcoming negotiations to leave the bloc, an association of travel agents said on Tuesday, adding that a transitional deal could also help the sector.

Headline: Sovereignty of Gibraltar remains unchanged - Johnson
Description: There will be no change to Gibraltar's sovereignty without Britain's consent, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Monday, while his Dutch counterpart called for calm after a British politician raised talk of defending the outpost.

Headline: Police charge five over brutal attack on teenage asylum seeker in London
Description: British police said on Monday they had charged five people over a "brutal" attack involving a gang of up to 30 assailants on a teenage asylum seeker in south London which left the victim with a fractured skull and blood clot on his brain.

Headline: Britain will wait for final EU guidelines on Gibraltar - May's spokesman
Description: Britain will wait until the end of the month to find out what guidelines the other members of the European Union have agreed regarding issues such as Gibraltar, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Britain expresses regret over 'disturbance' during Saudi aide's London visit
Description: Britain has expressed regret to Saudi Arabia after what it described as a "disturbance" during a visit by an aide to Saudi Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to London last week.

Headline: After historic week, Brexit dawns a shade warmer
Description: The week Britain filed for divorce from the European Union brought relief in London and Brussels that crockery was not smashed - far from it - but negotiators fear tantrums or even a breakdown once talks start.

Headline: Prince Charles visits earthquake-hit Italian town
Description: Britain's Prince Charles paid a visit on Sunday to one of the towns in central Italy devastated by a major earthquake last August, a day after locals protested against the government because of aid delays.

Headline: Spain eases opposition to an independent Scotland in EU
Description: Spain, at loggerheads with Britain over Gibraltar, appears to be easing its opposition to an independent Scotland in the European Union, saying it would not block such a move at least initially.

Headline: British 'implacable' in support for Gibraltar - Johnson
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has said the United Kingdom would remain "implacable and rock-like" in its support for Gibraltar after the European Union offered Spain a right of veto over the territory's future relationship with the bloc.

Headline: British role in European security 'unconditional' - foreign secretary
Description: Britain's contribution to European security is "unconditional", Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson told a French newspaper, denying the government had made a veiled threat to reduce cooperation if there was no post-Brexit trade deal.

Headline: British police says all those arrested after London attack now released
Description: All 12 people arrested in connection with the March 22 attack that left five people dead close to the British parliament have now been released without charge, London's Metropolitan Police said on Saturday.

Headline: Warning signs abound for UK economy following strong fourth quarter
Description: The British economy's strong finish to 2016 looks likely to prove a high watermark as Brexit gets underway, according to a range of indicators on Friday which pointed to a growing squeeze on consumers.

Headline: EU offers pre-Brexit trade talks, tough on transition
Description: The European Union is ready to talk to Britain on a future free trade deal before the two sides agree final terms on Brexit, draft EU negotiating guidelines issued on Friday show.

Headline: Campaigners file legal challenge over Brexit reversibility
Description: Campaigners mounting a legal challenge to determine whether Britain's divorce from the European Union can be reversed said they had filed their written legal case on Friday.

Headline: EU offers Brexit trade talks, sets tough transition terms
Description: The European Union offered Britain talks this year on a future free trade pact but made clear in negotiating guidelines issued on Friday that London must first agree to EU demands on the terms of Brexit.

Headline: No Brexit 'Armageddon' for London's financial district - policy chief
Description: The City of London should emerge largely unscathed from Brexit even though thousands of banking and insurance jobs could move to the continent, the financial district's policy chief said.

Headline: Top EU diplomat says Britain's security, defence power is no leverage in Brexit talks
Description: The European Union's top diplomat said on Friday the effect of Brexit on the bloc's joint defence and security operations would be minimal, following a veiled threat from London that it could curb such ties with the alliance if divorce talks turn sour.

Headline: Northern Ireland parties to resume talks to save devolved rule
Description: Northern Ireland's main political parties will resume talks on Monday to break a deadlock that threatens devolved government, the cornerstone of peace in the province for almost two decades, the British government said.

Headline: In a letter to May, Scotland's leader demands independence vote
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon wrote to Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday formally demanding that she allow a second referendum to be held on Scottish independence ahead of the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union.

Headline: 'Phased approach' - How to read EU Brexit guidelines
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk sent draft Brexit negotiating guidelines to leaders of Britain's 27 EU partners on Friday, hoping to agree them on April 29 so that negotiations on British withdrawal can begin.

Headline: No trade talks with Britain until Brexit contours clear - Germany
Description: Negotiations about a future free trade agreement between Britain and the European Union can take place only after the contours of the Brexit divorce talks are clear, a spokesman for German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Friday.

Headline: Draft EU guidelines show both sides constructive on Brexit talks - UK spokesman
Description: Draft negotiating guidelines from the European Union show a constructive approach ahead of negotiations on Britain's exit from the bloc, a British government spokesman said on Friday.

Headline: EU's Tusk says sure security not a bargaining chip in Brexit talks
Description: No party in British talks to leave the European Union is interested in using security issues as a bargaining chip, EU Council President Donald Tusk said on Friday, after Britain warned of weaker cooperation if no deal is struck.

Headline: EU 27 draft Brexit negotiations guidelines
Description: The chairman of the 27 European Union leaders Donald Tusk on Friday presented a draft plan for negotiating Brexit, an unprecedented departure of a member from the bloc.

Headline: EU open to May's bid for early post-Brexit trade talks
Description: The European Union is wary of Prime Minister Theresa May's call for swift negotiations on a post-Brexit free trade deal while Britain is still settling its withdrawal terms, but the bloc is not ruling out early talks.

Headline: Britain targets legal certainty with plan to convert EU law after Brexit
Description: The British government set out on Thursday how it will handle the mammoth task of converting European Union laws into domestic legislation in preparation for its exit from the bloc, seeking to ease business uncertainty about life after Brexit.

Headline: Britain targets legal certainty with plan to convert EU law after Brexit
Description: The British government set out on Thursday how it will handle the mammoth task of converting European Union laws into domestic legislation in preparation for its exit from the bloc, seeking to ease business uncertainty about life after Brexit.

Headline: Investigators suspect UK killer was lone wolf radicalised on internet
Description: A former violent criminal who converted to Islam and kept out of trouble for more than a decade, the killer who struck Britain's parliament last week was probably a "lone wolf", self-radicalised by material on the internet, investigators say.

Headline: Britain does not expect 50 billion pounds Brexit bill - Davis
Description: Brexit minister David Davis said he did not expect Britain to have to pay 50 billion pounds to the European Union as part of the Brexit process and said the era of huge sums being paid to Brussels was coming to an end.

Headline: German minister warns of tough Brexit talks, no discount available
Description: German Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel said on Thursday that negotiations about Britain's exit from the European Union would be tough before getting easier.

Headline: May's spokesman says EU leaders appreciated tone of Brexit letter
Description: European Union leaders appreciated the tone of a letter sent by Prime Minister Theresa May setting out Britain's intention to withdraw from the bloc, May's spokesman told reporters on Thursday.

Headline: ECJ will have no future role in interpreting UK law post Brexit - Davis
Description: The European Court of Justice (ECJ) will have no future role in interpreting British laws after the country leaves the European Union, Britain's Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday.

Headline: Brexit may not push Scots towards independence, survey suggests
Description: Brexit may not be a game-changer in the debate about Scottish independence, according to research published on Thursday that suggests Scots want similar outcomes as other Britons do from the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union.

Headline: Hammond to meet German finance minister in Berlin
Description: Britain's finance minister Philip Hammond is to visit his German counterpart Wolfgang Schaeuble in Berlin on Thursday, a day after the British government formally started the process of leaving the European Union, a German ministry spokeswoman said.

Headline: Britain not threatening Europe over security cooperation - Davis
Description: Britain was in not seeking to threaten Europe when it said cooperation in fighting terrorism would be weakened if it left the European Union without a comprehensive deal, Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday.

Headline: London attack a 'wake-up' call for tech firms to put house in order - police
Description: The London attack which left four people dead was a "wake up call" for technology firms to get their house in order over extremist material being circulated on the internet, the acting head of London's police force said on Wednesday.

Headline: 'No turning back' - May triggers 'historic' Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May formally began Britain's divorce from the European Union on Wednesday, declaring there was no turning back and ushering in a tortuous exit process that will test the bloc's cohesion and pitch her country into the unknown.

Headline: Brexit comes with conditions but can be reversed- EU parliament
Description: The European Parliament said on Wednesday that Brexit could be reversed, but if Britain pursued divorce from the EU it should first settle its bill and protect citizens' rights before a new trade deal with the bloc can be discussed.

Headline: Special delivery - Brexit letter makes history
Description: It's been two centuries since a British emissary arrived in Brussels bearing a dispatch of such historic portent but Sir Tim Barrow, Britain's new envoy to the EU, took it in his diplomatic stride.

Headline: UK likely to leave Europol and might "take our information with us" - interior minister
Description: Britain is likely to leave the European Union police agency Europol after Brexit and could "take our information" away if no future security deal is struck with the bloc, interior minister Amber Rudd said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK court dismisses Unaoil case against anti-fraud agency
Description: The English High Court on Wednesday dismissed an attempt by oil and gas services group Unaoil and the wealthy Ahsani family to force the UK Serious Fraud Office (SFO) to return or destroy material collected during raids in Monaco last year.

Headline: European parliament aims for general deal on future ties with Britain in 2 years
Description: The two-year Brexit negotiations should produce a divorce deal as well as an "agreement on general terms" of the future relationship between the EU of 27 and London, the European Parliament's chief negotiator said on Wednesday.

Headline: Text of PM May's letter to EU's Tusk triggering Brexit process
Description: Below is the text of the letter British Prime Minister Theresa May sent to European Council President Donald Tusk triggering Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty, the formal start of the process by which Britain will leave the European Union.

Headline: May offers EU fine words, but pushes British interests
Description: Theresa May's Brexit letter to European Union President Donald Tusk will please EU leaders by sounding constructive and acknowledging Britain must settle obligations before leaving. But the prime minister also made some tougher demands.

Headline: Merkel says aiming to cushion Brexit impact on EU citizens in UK
Description: Germany will strive in Brexit negotiations to make sure there is as little disruption as possible to the lives of European Union citizens living in Britain, Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain could walk away from EU with no Brexit deal - May's spokesman
Description: Britain is still willing to walk away from the European Union with no Brexit deal, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: EU's Tusk says Brexit will be damage control for both sides
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk told reporters on Wednesday that Britain's formal exit notification made it an unhappy day for London and Brussels and that difficult talks would simply be about limiting damage for both sides.

Headline: May says timetable to reach EU deal is 'tight'
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday she faced a "tight" timetable to negotiate the terms on which the country will leave the European Union in two years' time.

Headline: Britain will not try to 'cherry pick' in Brexit talks, says May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday she would not try to "cherry pick" parts of European Union membership as Britain leaves the bloc, saying she respected its four freedoms.

Headline: May urges Northern Ireland to form a government and engage in Brexit process
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May called on the rival political parties in Northern Ireland to come together and form a regional government so their voice can be heard in Brexit negotiations.

Headline: May says hopes to settle rights of EU nationals in Britain early
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday she hoped to be able to agree a deal to clarify the position of European Union nationals in Britain and British nationals in the EU as early as possible in the Brexit negotiations.

Headline: PM May says aims to reach deal on future UK-EU relationship within two years
Description: Britain aims to reach an agreement on its future relationship with the European Union within the two years set out under Article 50 of the bloc's Lisbon Treaty, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Germany says two-year Brexit timetable is "damn narrow"
Description: The two-year period for Britain and the European Union to settle the terms of their split after British Prime Minister Theresa May filed divorce papers on Wednesday is very tight, a spokesman for the German Foreign Ministry said.

Headline: May goes into Brexit talks with ambitions high
Description: After nine months of preparation, bitter public argument and a battle with parliament, British Prime Minister Theresa May is launching talks with the European Union armed with a plan she hopes will secure a better divorce deal than many expect.

Headline: May says has triggered Article 50 to begin Brexit process
Description: Britain has formally triggered the process of leaving the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: May says now is the time for Britain to be united
Description: Now is the time for Britain to come together and ensure it gets the best Brexit deal possible, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday after the country formally triggered its exit from the European Union.

Headline: "After nine months UK has delivered Brexit," tweets EU's Tusk
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk confirmed on Twitter that he had received Britain's Brexit notification letter on Wednesday, saying "After nine months the UK has delivered Brexit."

Headline: EU Brexit negotiator sees 'very difficult road' ahead
Description: The EU's chief negotiator in the talks on Britain's exit from the European Union said on Wednesday that "today is day one of a very difficult road".

Headline: France's Macron says post-Brexit priority is protecting EU citizens
Description: Emmanuel Macron, the centrist who is favourite to win the French presidential election in May, said on Wednesday his priority, as Britain starts the process of divorce from the European Union, would be to protect EU citizens.

Headline: Branded 'enemies of the people' over Brexit case, senior UK judges hit back
Description: Britain's most senior judges have denounced as abusive a barrage of criticism levelled at them over a ruling that displeased the pro-Brexit press, culminating in a front page branding them "Enemies of the People".

Headline: Parliament to review security, incident response after attack
Description: Two reviews will be held into the attack last week in which a man killed a police officer within the grounds of parliament, the speaker of Britain's lower house said on Wednesday.

Headline: EU leaders to vow unity, constructive approach to get exit deal with Britain
Description: European Union leaders will pledge on Wednesday to stand united in "constructive" talks with Britain on its exit from the EU to reduce uncertainty for citizens and businesses, a draft document showed just hours before London's formal notification to quit.

Headline: Barnier and Davis face off on Brexit mountain
Description: They have much in common, in public and private life, affirm a mutual respect and will be spending plenty of time in one another's company, but Brexit negotiators David Davis and Michel Barnier are poles apart on Europe.

Headline: No one wants lines of trucks at borders after Brexit - Hammond
Description: Finance minister Philip Hammond said on Wednesday he was confident Britain would negotiate a customs arrangement with the European Union that would allow for borders to be as frictionless as possible after Brexit.

Headline: Chancellor Hammond says Brexit deal with EU will need 'give and take'
Description: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said on Wednesday that Britain would need to make concessions to the European Union in order to secure the best deal for the country to leave the bloc.

Headline: PM May signs Brexit letter to EU - photograph
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May signed a letter on Tuesday to European Council President Donald Tusk notifying the European Union of Britain's intention to leave the bloc, a photograph seen by Reuters showed.

Headline: Britain to decide Northern Ireland's fate after talks fail
Description: The British government was due to decide on Monday whether to take back direct rule of Northern Ireland for the first time in a decade or call a new election after the collapse of power-sharing between Irish nationalists and British unionists.

Headline: UK to conduct major counter-terrorism exercise in October - PM May
Description: Britain will conduct a major counter-terrorism training exercise in October across parts of Scotland and northern England, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday, days after a lone attacker killed four people in London.

Headline: May will highlight common Brexit aims on Scotland visit - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will use a visit to Scotland on Monday to set out what she believes are significant areas of agreement with Scottish authorities on what sort of deal Britain needs to get from leaving the European Union.

Headline: PM May wants tech firms' help to access messages, but up to them how - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May wants technology firms to help law enforcement agencies gain access to messages sent using their platforms if needed, but how they do that is up to the companies themselves, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: UK will double export finance available to support trade with Qatar - minister
Description: Britain will double the amount of export finance available to support trade with Qatar to 4.5 billion pounds, trade minister Liam Fox said on Monday.

Headline: UK police make another arrest in parliamentary attack investigation
Description: Police have arrested a 30-year-old man in the central English city of Birmingham in connection with last week's attack on parliament, "on suspicion of preparation of terrorist acts", the Metropolitan Police said on Sunday.

Headline: May to set out plans to reclaim legislative sovereignty
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will set out how her government plans to restore sovereignty over Britain's laws on Thursday, publishing a detailed paper on ending "the supremacy of EU lawmakers".

Headline: Fresh election or direct rule looms as Northern Ireland talks fall apart
Description: Northern Ireland could be set for a fresh election or a return to direct British rule of the province after the two main parties in negotiations to form a new government said on Sunday that talks had run their course without success.

Headline: UK police still believe London attacker was acting alone
Description: British anti-terrorism police said on Saturday they still believe the man who launched a deadly attack outside parliament this week was acting alone but conceded they may never understand his motive.

Headline: Minister says encryption on messaging services is unacceptable
Description: Technology companies must cooperate more with law enforcement agencies and should stop offering a "secret place for terrorists to communicate" using encrypted messages, British interior minister Amber Rudd said on Sunday.

Headline: Cost of wide access to EU single market not yet clear - Rudd
Description: Interior minister Amber Rudd said on Sunday the British government did not yet know what kind of cost there may be for trying to get the "widest possible access" to the European Union's single market.

Headline: Britain reviewing security at parliament after deadly attack
Description: Britain will review security at parliament, ministers said on Sunday, responding to criticism that a gate for vehicles was left open for a time during a deadly attack on Wednesday.

Headline: Anti-EU UKIP party loses its only lawmaker
Description: UKIP party, widely credited as having been a major factor behind the country's decision to leave the European Union, lost its only lawmaker on Saturday when Douglas Carswell announced he was leaving the party.

Headline: Thousands demonstrate in London against leaving the EU
Description: Thousands of people marched through London on Saturday to protest against Britain leaving the European Union, just four days before Prime Minister Theresa May launches the start of the formal divorce process from the bloc it joined 44 years ago.

Headline: Queen honours minister who tried to save policeman
Description: British foreign affairs minister Tobias Ellwood who tried to resuscitate a police officer stabbed to death in the attack on Britain's parliament has been honoured by Queen Elizabeth, the prime minister's office said on Friday.

Headline: Minister who tried to save policeman greets armed officer
Description: British foreign affairs minister Tobias Ellwood greeted armed police at parliament on Friday, two days after he tried to revive an officer fatally stabbed in what security services believe was an Islamist-inspired attack.

Headline: Middle-aged London attacker was criminal who wasn't seen as threat
Description: Before he killed four people in Britain's deadliest attack since the 2005 London bombings, Khalid Masood was considered by intelligence officers to be a criminal who posed little serious threat.

Headline: Police identify British-born attacker, victim count rises to four
Description: The attacker who ploughed a car through a throng of pedestrians and then stabbed a policeman outside Britain's parliament was named on Thursday as Khalid Masood, a British-born man who was once investigated by MI5 intelligence officers over concerns about violent extremism.

Headline: Saudi Arabia says London attacker not on security radar there
Description: The man who killed four people near Britain's Houses of Parliament on Wednesday had spent time working in Saudi Arabia but did not have a criminal record there or attract the attention of the security services, the Saudi embassy in London said on Friday.

Headline: Investigators lacked basic information on London attacker - source
Description: British investigators are having to make basic checks into the background of London attacker Khalid Masood who previously crossed security officials' radar around five years ago, a European government source told Reuters on Friday.

Headline: Foreign Secretary Johnson postpones Russia trip due to NATO meeting
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has postponed a planned trip to Russia due to a NATO foreign ministers meeting being rescheduled, a spokesman for his office said on Monday.

Headline: Britain to decide Northern Ireland's fate after talks fail
Description: The British government was due to decide on Monday whether to take back direct rule of Northern Ireland for the first time in a decade or call a new election after the collapse of power-sharing between Irish nationalists and British unionists.

Description: Britain will conduct a major counter-terrorism training exercise in October across parts of Scotland and northern England, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday, days after a lone attacker killed four people in London.

Description: Britain will review security at parliament, ministers said on Sunday, responding to criticism that a gate for vehicles was left open for a time during a deadly attack on Wednesday.

Description: UKIP party, widely credited as having been a major factor behind the country's decision to leave the European Union, lost its only lawmaker on Saturday when Douglas Carswell announced he was leaving the party.

Description: Thousands of people marched through London on Saturday to protest against Britain leaving the European Union, just four days before Prime Minister Theresa May launches the start of the formal divorce process from the bloc it joined 44 years ago.

Description: British foreign affairs minister Tobias Ellwood who tried to resuscitate a police officer stabbed to death in the attack on Britain's parliament has been honoured by Queen Elizabeth, the prime minister's office said on Friday.

Description: British foreign affairs minister Tobias Ellwood greeted armed police at parliament on Friday, two days after he tried to revive an officer fatally stabbed in what security services believe was an Islamist-inspired attack.

Description: Before he killed four people in Britain's deadliest attack since the 2005 London bombings, Khalid Masood was considered by intelligence officers to be a criminal who posed little serious threat.

Description: The attacker who ploughed a car through a throng of pedestrians and then stabbed a policeman outside Britain's parliament was named on Thursday as Khalid Masood, a British-born man who was once investigated by MI5 intelligence officers over concerns about violent extremism.

Headline: Investigators lacked basic information on London attacker - source
Description: British investigators are having to make basic checks into the background of London attacker Khalid Masood who previously crossed security officials' radar around five years ago, a European government source told Reuters on Friday.

Headline: London attack bears Islamic State "signature" but no clear link
Description: The "Islamic State soldier" who killed four people in an attack on the British parliament may have been inspired by calls to arms against the West but the militant group has given no evidence yet that he acted on specific instructions.

Headline: After London attack, PM May demands more action against hate from social media firms
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May wants social media firms to do more to prevent the spread of extremist material online, her spokesman said on Friday, two days after a British-born Muslim convert killed at least four people in London.

Headline: Historic win for Labour in City of London elections
Description: Britain's Labour party won a record five seats in the City of London elections on Thursday, in a breakthrough for the party and a challenge to the centuries-old political independence of the country's financial district.

Headline: Confusion and fear - Theresa May's London attack escape
Description: In a less-than-slick escape from parliament when her staff appeared rattled as a lone assailant rampaged just yards away, Prime Minister Theresa May dashed around a car park and looked lost as she searched for her ride before escaping.

Headline: Police arrest two more over British parliament attack
Description: British police said they had made two further significant arrests in the investigation into the attack on London's parliament and gave the birth name of the man behind the assault as Adrian Russell Ajao.

Headline: Schaeuble - Trying to keep disadvantages for Britain as small as possible in Brexit
Description: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said on Friday that the European Union was trying to limit the negative effects of Brexit for Britain but stressed that countries wanting to get the benefits related to the bloc had to make commitments, too.

Headline: Hundreds gather at vigil for victims of London attack
Description: Hundreds of people gathered in London's Trafalgar Square on Thursday evening in a vigil to remember the victims of this week's attack near parliament in which four people died and some 40 were injured.

Headline: U.S. source says London attacker associated with those interested in jihadist groups
Description: A U.S government source said on Thursday the man who killed three people near the British parliament had associates with an interest in joining jihadist groups abroad.

Headline: Police say man injured in attack on parliament has died
Description: A man injured in Wednesday's attack on Britain's parliament in London has died, police said on Thursday.

Headline: Acting London head of police to attend government security meeting on Thursday
Description: The acting head of London's police force Craig Mackey said he would attend a meeting of the government's emergency security committee on Thursday after an attacker killed three people near the British parliament.

Headline: May to give statement to parliament on London attack at 1030 GMT
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will make a statement to parliament at 1030 GMT on Thursday, the leader of the lower house of parliament said on Twitter after a lone-wolf attacker killed three and injured 40 in London on Wednesday.

Headline: Police checking whether others involved in London attack - Fallon
Description: British police believe an attack in London that left four people dead and injured around 40 was linked to Islamic terrorism and are checking whether the lone attacker was supported by anyone else, the defence minister said on Thursday.

Headline: Five South Koreans wounded in UK parliament attack - ministry
Description: Five South Koreans were wounded near the British parliament on Wednesday in what police called a "marauding terrorist attack", South Korea's foreign ministry said in Seoul.

Headline: British police make seven arrests after London attack
Description: British police have made seven arrests and searched six addresses after an attack near parliament which left four people dead and 29 injured, the country's top anti-terrorism officer said on Thursday.

Headline: Five dead, around 40 injured in parliament "terrorist" attack
Description: Five people were killed and about 40 injured in London on Wednesday after a car ploughed into pedestrians and a suspected Islamist-inspired attacker stabbed a policeman close to Britain's parliament.

Headline: British police make arrests after London attack - Sky News
Description: British police made several arrests in a raid on a house in Birmingham as part of an investigation into Wednesday's attack on parliament, Sky News television channel quoted unidentified sources as saying on Thursday.

Headline: Vehicle attacks like London easy to organise, hard to prevent
Description: Militants are increasingly turning to vehicle-ramming attacks, like the one staged near Britain's parliament on Wednesday, because they are cheap, easy to organise and hard to prevent.

Headline: At the scene of the London attack - witness
Description: "I heard a thud, turned round and there was a man lying about 10 yards away from me," Reuters photographer Toby Melville recalls, describing the moment a man fell from London's Westminster Bridge to the pavement below during Wednesday's attack.

Headline: Police still seeking one assailant in London attack - report
Description: Police are still searching for one of the two people believed to have launched Wednesday's attack outside the British parliament building, assistant editor of the Daily Telegraph newspaper Christopher Hope tweeted, citing senior government sources.

Headline: Erdogan tells May - Turkey, UK partners in fight against terrorism
Description: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan called British Prime Minister Theresa May to express condolences for the attack in London and stressed that the two countries were partners in the fight against terrorism, sources in Erdogan's office said on Thursday.

Headline: Rwanda charges dual British national with treason
Description: Rwandan prosecutors charged a dual Rwandan-British citizen of treason on Thursday, accusing her of forming an armed group and conspiring to unseat the president.

Headline: Police reopen streets in east London after suspect package alert
Description: British police cordoned off streets in Shoreditch, east London, on Thursday and were investigating a suspect package, a day after an attack at the country's parliament killed three people and put the city on high alert.

Headline: 'What a mad world' - Shock gives way to defiance in parliament after attack
Description: British lawmakers reacted with defiance, shock and emotional tribute on Thursday as they came to terms with an attack which left a police officer dead on the cobbles inside the gates of the world's oldest parliament.

Headline: Islamic State claims responsibility for British parliament attack
Description: Islamic State was responsible for an attack outside Britain's parliament which left four people dead, the group's Amaq news agency said on Thursday.

Headline: London attack won't delay start of Brexit process - PM May's spokesman
Description: Britain's plan to begin the formal process of leaving the European Union on March 29 will not be delayed by an attack on parliament which left four people dead, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: Queen Elizabeth offers deepest sympathy to victims of London attack
Description: Britain's Queen Elizabeth sent her condolences on Thursday to those affected by the attack on the British parliament conducted by a lone assailant who killed three people and injured 40.

Headline: London attacker was British-born, known to intelligence services -May
Description: The man who launched Wednesday's deadly attack at parliament was born in Britain and known to the intelligence services, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: Scottish independence referendum debate to resume on Tuesday
Description: Scotland's parliament said it will resume its independence referendum debate on Tuesday after proceedings were suspended following the attack on Britain's national parliament at Westminster.

Headline: MI5 says agency fully mobilised after London attack
Description: Britain's domestic intelligence service said its operational response was fully mobilised in support of the police after an attack in London on Wednesday that killed four people.

Headline: Police investigate smoke at London's 'Gherkin' building, not a security incident
Description: The City of London police said on Thursday they were investigating reports of smoke at London's 'Gherkin' skyscraper but said it was not a "police or security incident".

Headline: Acting London head of police to attend government security meeting on Thursday
Description: The acting head of London's police force Craig Mackey said he would attend a meeting of the government's emergency security committee on Thursday after an attacker killed three people near the British parliament.

Headline: May to give statement to parliament on London attack at 1030 GMT
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will make a statement to parliament at 1030 GMT on Thursday, the leader of the lower house of parliament said on Twitter after a lone-wolf attacker killed three and injured 40 in London on Wednesday.

Description: Five South Koreans were wounded near the British parliament on Wednesday in what police called a "marauding terrorist attack", South Korea's foreign ministry said in Seoul.

Description: British police made several arrests in a raid on a house in Birmingham as part of an investigation into Wednesday's attack on parliament, Sky News television channel quoted unidentified sources as saying on Thursday.
