Description: "I heard a thud, turned round and there was a man lying about 10 yards away from me," Reuters photographer Toby Melville recalls, describing the moment a man fell from London's Westminster Bridge to the pavement below during Wednesday's attack.

Headline: Police still seeking one assailant in London attack - report
Description: Police are still searching for one of the two people believed to have launched Wednesday's attack outside the British parliament building, assistant editor of the Daily Telegraph newspaper Christopher Hope tweeted, citing senior government sources.

Headline: Germany's Merkel expresses shock at London attack
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed shock at the attack in which four people were killed and at least 20 injured in London on Wednesday, and she said her thoughts were with the British people and everyone in the capital.

Headline: May's thoughts are with killed, injured in 'appalling incident'
Description: Theresa May's thoughts are with those killed and injured in an attack close to parliament and the British prime minister is being kept updated with developments, her office said on Wednesday.

Headline: Investigators considering whether UK attack was inspired by IS-European official says
Description: Investigators are considering the possibility that the attack on the British parliament was inspired by Islamic State propaganda, a European government official told Reuters.

Headline: Security tightened at UK sites in New York after London attack
Description: New York police ramped up security at British sites across the city on Wednesday after an assailant fatally stabbed a policeman outside Britain's parliament and was then shot and killed by police.

Headline: Australia to increase security in wake of attack near British parliament
Description: Australia will increase security around the country's parliament on Thursday in the wake of a deadly attack in London, the country's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said.

Headline: Northern Ireland braces for uncertain new era after McGuinness
Description: As the tricolour-draped coffin of former IRA commander turned peacemaker Martin McGuinness was carried to his Londonderry home this week, people across Northern Ireland's sectarian divide were nervously eying a new era of uncertainty.

Headline: EU puts citizens' rights first as it sets Brexit talk conditions
Description: The European Union's chief Brexit negotiator spelled out on Wednesday the bloc's conditions for talks, saying securing the rights of some 4.5 million EU and British citizens living abroad was paramount.

Headline: Trump offers U.S. cooperation, support after London attack - White House
Description: President Donald Trump on Wednesday offered British Prime Minister Theresa May the full cooperation and support of the United States in responding to an attack close to the British Parliament, the White House said in a statement.

Headline: UK interior minister Rudd says people's security is top priority
Description: The British people's security is the government's top priority, interior minister Amber Rudd said after four people were killed and 20 injured in London during an attack close to parliament on Wednesday.

Headline: UK parliament to sit on Thursday as normal after attack
Description: Both houses of the British parliament will sit as usual on Thursday, officials said, following an attack outside the building on Wednesday in which four people died.

Headline: Four dead including police officer and assailant in London attack - police
Description: Four people, including the attacker and a police officer, died in Wednesday's terrorism incident at the British parliament, police said.

Headline: U.S. says domestic security posture unchanged after London attack
Description: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security said on Wednesday it would lend support to Britain's investigation of an attack outside its parliament building, but said the security posture in the United States was unchanged.

Headline: Hammond says shocked by attack outside parliament
Description: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said he was shocked by an attack outside parliament in London on Wednesday that left at least two dead, the first such reaction from a senior government official.

Headline: U.S. Secretary of State Tillerson condemns 'horrific' London attack
Description: U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson condemned Wednesday's attack outside parliament in London and expressed his condolences to the victims and their families.

Headline: Police officer killed in parliament attack - BBC
Description: A police officer was among the people killed in an attack just outside Britain's parliament building, the BBC reported on Wednesday, quoting a lawmaker who provided medical assistance.

Headline: British Prime Minister May is safe after attack in parliament - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is safe after an assailant was shot outside parliament by armed police on Wednesday, a spokesman for her office said.

Headline: Britain's May to meet Poland's Kaczynski
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will meet the leader of Poland's Law and Justice (PiS) party, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, on Wednesday, a spokesman said.

Headline: Woman pulled alive from River Thames after London attack - river authority
Description: A woman has been pulled from the River Thames alive after Wednesday's attack on a bridge near Britain's parliament in Westminster, the Port of London Authority (PLA) said, adding that she was being treated for serious injuries.

Headline: London Ambulance Service says treated at least 10 people on Westminster Bridge
Description: The London Ambulance Service said on Wednesday it had treated at least 10 people on Westminster Bridge, near Britain's parliament building, after an attack police have described as a terrorist incident.

Headline: Former foes salute Martin McGuinness, IRA man turned peacemaker
Description: Martin McGuinness, the Irish Republican Army commander who laid down his arms to become a major architect of peace in Northern Ireland, died on Tuesday aged 66, drawing tributes from allies and former enemies alike.

Headline: Scottish parliament begins debate on new independence referendum
Description: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon sought backing from the Edinburgh parliament on Tuesday for her proposal to hold a new referendum on independence from the United Kingdom, the first formal step in a process resisted by London.

Headline: Britain introduces electronics restrictions on flights from six countries
Description: Britain has introduced restrictions on carry-on electronic goods on direct inbound flights from Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan, Egypt, Tunisia and Saudi Arabia for the safety of the public, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: Dutch report urges strong Britain-EU trade ties after Brexit
Description: The Netherlands should push for the European Union to keep strong trade ties with Britain after the British quit the EU, a report commissioned by the Dutch parliament said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK to follow U.S. flight ban on larger electronic devices - Sky news
Description: Britain is set to ban passengers from carrying most electronic devices on flights from certain countries in the Middle East, Sky News reported on Tuesday, following similar measures introduced in the United States.

Headline: Goldman to move hundreds of staff from London pre-Brexit - Europe CEO
Description: Goldman Sachs  will begin moving hundreds of people out of London before any Brexit deal is struck as part of its contingency plans for Britain leaving the European Union, the Wall Street firm's Europe CEO said.

Headline: Trump was being a gentleman, May says on holding hands
Description: Donald Trump was being a gentleman, British Prime Minister Theresa May said, describing when the U.S. president held her hand during her visit to Washington earlier this year.

Headline: Destroyed by Islamic State, ancient winged bull to rise again in London
Description: An ancient Assyrian winged bull sculpture destroyed by Islamic State fighters in 2015 is to be remade from empty Iraqi date syrup cans and displayed in Trafalgar Square in London.

Headline: IRA street fighter turned statesman, Martin McGuinness dies aged 66
Description: Martin McGuinness, the former Irish Republican Army commander who laid down his arms and turned peacemaker to help end Northern Ireland's 30-year conflict, died on Tuesday after a decade as deputy first minister of the British province.

Headline: May says McGuinness played defining role in Northern Ireland's path to peace
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May paid tribute on Tuesday to Martin McGuinness, the late former Irish Republican Army commander and deputy first minister of Northern Ireland, saying he had played a pivotal role in the province's path to peace.

Headline: Sterling slips after as date is set for Brexit trigger
Description: Sterling fell from a three-week high against the dollar on Monday, on the news Prime Minister Theresa May will trigger Britain's divorce proceedings with the European Union on March 29, launching two years of negotiations.

Headline: EU sees Brexit summit in late April or early May
Description: The European Union has yet to set a date for a summit to respond to Britain's notice of withdrawal but it should be between four and six weeks after March 29, the day when Britain will trigger Brexit, an EU source said on Monday.

Headline: Stay or go? EU nationals struggle with UK residency rules as Brexit looms
Description: Amid the insecurity of what will happen after Brexit, tens of thousands of European nationals are struggling - and often failing - to negotiate the bureaucracy that decides whether they can stay in Britain after it leaves the European Union.

Headline: Britain to launch Brexit process on March 29 - EU sources
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will write to the European Union on March 29 formally announcing Britain's withdrawal from the bloc, EU sources told Reuters on Monday, saying Brussels had been told of the plan by British officials.

Headline: No plans for early election, says May's spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's government has no plans to hold an early general election, May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Boris Johnson says Jeremy Fleming to head GCHQ spy agency
Description: Jeremy Fleming, the deputy director general of Britain's internal security service, will become the new head of intelligence eavesdropping service GCHQ, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Monday.

Headline: EU's Tusk to issue Brexit guidelines within 2 days of March 29
Description: European Council President Donald Tusk said on Monday he would present the other 27 European Union states with draft Brexit negotiating guidelines within 48 hours from the moment Britain formally triggers its exit from the bloc.

Headline: Bookmakers offer 5/1 odds for snap UK election
Description: British bookmaker odds indicated a 17 percent probability that Prime Minister Theresa May would call a snap general election after media speculation she could go to the polls.

Headline: May starts UK tour before pulling Brexit trigger
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will visit Wales on Monday as part of a plan to engage with all the nations of the United Kingdom before she formally launches Britain's departure from the European Union.

Headline: Scottish leader softens stance on possible independence vote timing
Description: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon on Sunday softened her stance on the potential timing of a second independence referendum after Prime Minister Theresa May rejected her call to hold a vote before Britain leaves the European Union.

Headline: London police simulate Thames boat hijacking in counter-terror exercise
Description: London police simulated a hijacking of a tourist boat on the River Thames on Sunday as part of training for a possible terror attack.

Headline: Deputy director of Britain's MI5 to head GCHQ spy agency - report
Description: The deputy director-general of Britain's internal security service is to become the new head of intelligence eavesdropping service GCHQ, the Sunday Times newspaper reported without citing the source of its information.

Headline: Ignoring Scottish referendum mandate would "shatter" UK structure - Sturgeon
Description: Refusal by Britain's prime minister to discuss an independence referendum would "shatter beyond repair" the United Kingdom's constitutional structure, Nicola Sturgeon told her Scottish National Party on Saturday.

Headline: Brexit destined for failure if UK shows same 'tin ear' to EU - Sturgeon
Description: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon knuckled down on her plan to hold a referendum on independence from the UK on Saturday, saying Brexit negotiations are destined to fail if Prime Minister Theresa May showed the same attitude to European partners as she had to Scotland.

Headline: Top NSA official ridicules allegation Britain spied on Trump
Description: Allegations from the United States that British spy agency GCHQ snooped on Donald Trump during his election campaign are "arrant nonsense", the deputy head of the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA) said in an interview on Saturday.

Headline: Trump stands by Obama wiretap charge, shrugs off row with Britain
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump stood by unproven claims on Friday that the Obama administration tapped his phones during the 2016 White House race and shrugged off a dispute with Britain over the notion their spy agency had a hand in it.

Headline: U.S. allegations about GCHQ will not be repeated - May's spokesman
Description: Britain has received assurances from the United States that allegations the GCHQ intelligence agency helped former President Barack Obama eavesdrop on Donald Trump will not be repeated, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday.

Headline: Prince William tells French that Brexit won't hurt friendship
Description: Britain's Prince William and his wife Kate were greeted by French President Francois Hollande as they began a two-day trip     to Paris aimed at highlighting strong Franco-British ties despite Britain's looming exit from the European Union.

Headline: Fighting for 'precious union', May rebuffs Scottish independence ambitions
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May pledged on Friday to fight for the "precious, precious union" of the United Kingdom, unveiling what she called her Plan for Britain with a warning to Scotland not to pursue its independence plans.

Headline: In surprise, ex-Chancellor Osborne named editor of London paper
Description: George Osborne, who lost his job as Chancellor of the Exchequer last year after helping lead the doomed campaign to stay in the European Union, was given a high profile platform on Friday as the editor of London's main metropolitan daily paper.

Headline: An independent Scotland could abandon sterling union - Salmond tells FT
Description: Scotland could abandon a currency union with the rest of the United Kingdom if it gained independence, former Scottish First Minister Alex Salmond told the Financial Times.

Headline: Plan for Britain? Error messages blight new government website
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's new "Plan for Britain" website stopped working on Thursday shortly after its launch, offering error messages in place of her vision for the country's future outside the European Union.

Headline: "Now is not the time," May tells Scotland on independence vote
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told the Scottish government on Thursday "now is not the time" for a second independence referendum, saying it would be unfair to ask people to vote without knowing the result of Brexit talks.

Headline: Britain to set out energy market proposals 'shortly' - minister
Description: Britain will set out proposals "shortly" to address issues in the country's energy market, the energy minister said on Thursday without providing any more details.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon says blocking another independence vote would be undemocratic
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Thursday that any attempt to block a second independence referendum would be undemocratic and evidence that Prime Minister Theresa May fears the verdict of the Scottish people.

Headline: Independence referendum should be "made in Scotland" - SNP source
Description: A second independence referendum should be decided by the Scottish people, not determined by British Prime Minister Theresa May, a source at the Scottish National Party (SNP) leading the devolved government said on Thursday.

Headline: Sinn Fein asks U.S. Congress to support Northern Ireland bid to stay in EU
Description: Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams will call on leaders of the U.S. Congress on Thursday to support efforts by Irish nationalists to maintain Northern Ireland's place in the European Union after the rest of the United Kingdom leaves.

Headline: Regulator grants licence for Britain's first 3-parent IVF babies
Description: Britain's fertility regulator on Thursday granted doctors the first UK licence to create babies using a three-parent IVF technique designed to prevent inherited genetic diseases.

Headline: Conservatives fined over election expenses, police alerted
Description: Britain's ruling Conservative Party has been fined 70,000 pounds for breaching rules which govern spending during an election campaign and the matter has been referred to police, Britain's Electoral Commission said on Thursday.

Headline: MP urges FCA to look into possible data leaks
Description: The head of a British parliamentary committee has asked a regulator to look into media reports, including one by Reuters, about movements in financial markets ahead of economic data releases that raised the possibility of leaks.

Headline: Scottish leader softens stance on possible independence vote timing
Description: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon on Sunday softened her stance on the potential timing of a second independence referendum after Prime Minister Theresa May rejected her call to hold a vote before Britain leaves the European Union.

Headline: London police simulate Thames boat hijacking in counter-terror exercise
Description: London police simulated a hijacking of a tourist boat on the River Thames on Sunday as part of training for a possible terror attack.

Headline: Deputy director of Britain's MI5 to head GCHQ spy agency - report
Description: The deputy director-general of Britain's internal security service is to become the new head of intelligence eavesdropping service GCHQ, the Sunday Times newspaper reported without citing the source of its information.

Headline: Fighting for 'precious union', May rebuffs Scottish independence ambitions
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May pledged on Friday to fight for the "precious, precious union" of the United Kingdom, unveiling what she called her Plan for Britain with a warning to Scotland not to pursue its independence plans.

Headline: Britain would be foolish to leave EU without deal says law specialist
Description: LONDON - Britain would be foolish to walk away from the European Union without an agreed deal, an EU law specialist said on Wednesday, despite Brexit minister David Davis saying earlier that such a scenario would not be as frightening as some people think.

Headline: Scottish independence referendum in 2018/19 would not be legal - UK minister
Description: It would be impossible to hold a legal and decisive referendum on Scottish independence in the timeframe demanded by First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, the British government's Scotland minister said in a newspaper interview published on Wednesday.

Headline: Scottish independence referendum in 2018/19 would not be legal - UK minister
Description: Britain's Scotland minister David Mundell has said it would be impossible to have a legal and decisive referendum on Scottish independence in the timeframe demanded by Scotland's nationalist First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.

Headline: UK's construction industry risks losing 200,000 EU workers - RICS
Description: Britain's construction industry could lose nearly 200,000 workers from European Union countries if the UK fails to keep  access to the bloc's single market, a leading property body said on Wednesday, as it called for help for the sector.

Headline: Oxford bosses tell UK: protect EU workers or academics will flee
Description: University of Oxford bosses said Britain should guarantee the rights of European Union citizens after Brexit or Britain's oldest university could suffer enormous damage as academics leave.

Headline: Lawmakers urge cutting EU funds for eurosceptics, taking aim at Le Pen and UKIP
Description: Eurosceptic parties should not get European Union funds, the head of the largest group in the European Parliament proposed on Tuesday, a move that would strip parties like France's National Front and the UK Independence Party of millions of euros.

Headline: May wins right to launch EU divorce talks, question is when?
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has won the right to launch divorce proceedings with the European Union and begin two years of talks that will shape the future of Britain and Europe.

Headline: Sinn Fein wants vote on Northern Ireland leaving UK 'as soon as possible'
Description: Northern Ireland's largest Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein on Monday said it wanted a referendum on splitting from the United Kingdom "as soon as possible", hours after Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon demanded a new independence vote.

Headline: May says not right to have Irish border poll at this stage
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday it was "not right" to have a referendum on Northern Ireland splitting from the United Kingdom, a day after the province's largest Irish nationalist party called such a vote as "as soon as possible".

Headline: May says will notify parliament this month of Article 50 trigger
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday she would notify parliament later this month when she has triggered Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty to begin the formal Brexit process.

Headline: Brexit legislation will get queen's approval in coming days - May
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that Queen Elizabeth would formally approve legislation giving the government the power to trigger exit talks with the European Union in the coming days.

Headline: May is committed to engaging with Scotland on Brexit - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is committed to engaging with the Scottish government on Brexit plans, her spokesman said on Tuesday, a day after First Minister Nicola Sturgeon called for a new independence referendum.

Headline: Scottish government seeks quick EU deal, sees EU understanding
Description: The Scottish government thinks Europeans will understand it has a "special" case to be given EU membership as soon as possible if Scots vote for independence before Britain quits the bloc, a minister said on Monday.

Headline: Birmingham, Liverpool interested in 2022 Commonwealth Games
Description: The English cities of Birmingham and Liverpool have expressed interest in hosting the 2022 Commonwealth Games after Durban was stripped of the right on Monday.

Headline: May's hand moves closer to Brexit trigger
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May cleared the final hurdle standing between her and the start of Brexit negotiations on Monday after parliament passed legislation giving her the power to start the EU exit process.

Headline: UK to begin EU exit by end of month after parliament's approval - minister
Description: British Brexit minister David Davis welcomed parliament's approval on Monday for legislation giving Prime Minister Theresa May the power to begin formal divorce talks with the European Union.

Headline: May to reject Scottish referendum demand - Times newspaper
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is preparing to reject Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon's demand for an independence referendum on the eve of the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union, the Times newspaper reported.

Headline: PM May's spokesman underlines 'end' of March for EU exit trigger
Description: Theresa May's spokesman emphasised the word 'end' on Monday when asked at what point in March the prime minister was planning to trigger formal divorce talks with the European Union.

Headline: UK lawmakers reject attempt to give parliament greater say over Brexit terms
Description: British lawmakers on Monday voted against an attempt to give parliament more power to reject the final terms of the country's exit from European Union.

Headline: Scottish leader demands new independence vote before Brexit
Description: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon on Monday demanded a new independence referendum in late 2018 or early 2019, once the terms of the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union have become clearer.

Headline: UK lawmakers reject guarantee for EU nationals in Article 50 bill
Description: UK lawmakers voted on Monday to reject attempts to include a guarantee on the rights of EU nationals in Britain in legislation giving Prime Minister Theresa May the power to begin the country's exit from the European Union.

Headline: 'Politics is not a game,' says May after Scottish referendum call
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May chided Scottish leader Nicola Sturgeon for demanding an independence referendum on Monday, saying the Scottish National Party (SNP) had "tunnel vision" on breaking away from the United Kingdom.

Headline: Labour will not oppose second referendum if Scottish parliament wants one
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party will not oppose a call for a second Scottish independence referendum if the plan wins support from the Scottish parliament, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said on Monday.

Headline: Second Scottish referendum would be divisive, hurt economy - May
Description: A second Scottish independence referendum would be divisive and cause huge economic uncertainty at the worst possible time for Britain, a spokesman for British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday.

Headline: Call for second Scottish referendum is divisive - Scottish Conservative leader
Description: The leader of Scotland's Conservative Party said on Monday First Minister Nicola Sturgeon's call for a second independence referendum was divisive and pledged to vote against her request.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon says: I can win an independence vote
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Monday that she believed she could win a second independence vote which she has demanded to be held before the United Kingdom leaves the European Union.

Headline: UK will not let lawmakers tie May's hands in Brexit talks - spokesman
Description: The British government will not agree to any changes to its Brexit legislation that would tie Prime Minister Theresa May's hands in exit negotiations with the European Union, May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Factbox - Energy price changes by utilities in Britain
Description: Some of Britain's biggest energy companies have announced price increases citing higher wholesale prices and the cost of government policies to support renewable energy generation.

Headline: Britain has a Brexit backup plan if talks fail, says David Davis
Description: Britain is drawing up contingency plans for the unlikely event it has to walk away from divorce talks with the European Union without a deal, Brexit minister David Davis said on Sunday.

Headline: UK political parties warned of Russian hacking threat - report
Description: A British intelligence agency has told political parties to protect themselves against potential cyber attacks, citing allegations that Russian hackers tried to influence last year's U.S. presidential election.

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday she would notify parliament later this month when she has triggered Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty to begin the formal Brexit process.

Description: The English cities of Birmingham and Liverpool have expressed interest in hosting the 2022 Commonwealth Games after Durban was stripped of the right on Monday.

Description: British Brexit minister David Davis welcomed parliament's approval on Monday for legislation giving Prime Minister Theresa May the power to begin formal divorce talks with the European Union.

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is preparing to reject Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon's demand for an independence referendum on the eve of the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union, the Times newspaper reported.

Headline: PM May's spokesman underlines 'end' of March for EU exit trigger
Description: Theresa May's spokesman emphasised the word 'end' on Monday when asked at what point in March the prime minister was planning to trigger formal divorce talks with the European Union.

Headline: UK lawmakers reject attempt to give parliament greater say over Brexit terms
Description: British lawmakers on Monday voted against an attempt to give parliament more power to reject the final terms of the country's exit from European Union.

Headline: May supports Hammond in tax hike on self-employed
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May defended her finance minister on Thursday against criticism for raising a tax on some self-employed workers in his budget, saying the measure was necessary and "fair".

Headline: May says it's time to get on with leaving the European Union
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday both Britain and the European Union were ready to get on with divorce talks, but gave little away on when she will trigger the formal Brexit procedure.

Headline: EU Parliament wants trade talks with UK after deal on Brexit terms
Description: The European Union and Britain should first strike a deal on the terms of Brexit and then proceed to discuss future bilateral relations, European Parliament President Antonio Tajani said on Thursday.

Headline: Northern Ireland minister warns of fresh election if talks fail
Description: Northern Ireland faces another election unless rival parties can agree on a power-sharing arrangement within three weeks, the British government's minister for the region warned on Thursday.

Headline: Sturgeon says Scotland could hold independence vote in 'autumn of 2018'
Description: Scotland could hold an independence referendum in the autumn of 2018, just months before Britain is due to leave the European Union, Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon told the BBC, and a second poll in a month suggested rising support for secession.

Headline: Queen unveils memorial dedicated to Britons involved in Afghan, Iraq wars
Description: Queen Elizabeth unveiled a memorial on Thursday to British armed forces and civilians who served during recent wars in the Gulf, Afghanistan and Iraq and their work "to bring peace and stability".

Headline: There should be no second Scottish independence vote - PM May's spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May does not believe there should be a second Scottish independence referendum, her spokesman said on Thursday after the Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said such a vote could be held in autumn 2018.

Headline: Builders turn to bolt-together homes in Brexit Britain
Description: The prospect of Brexit choking off the supply of EU workers is reshaping Britain's homebuilding industry, with big companies increasingly looking to factory-manufacture houses in sections that can be slotted together on-site with minimal labour.

Headline: Osborne hits the jackpot with 650,000 pound part-time BlackRock job
Description: Former British Chancellor George Osborne is to be paid 650,000 pounds a year for working just 48 days a year at asset manager BlackRock , according to parliament's register of members interests.

Headline: British insurance lobby calls for EU cross-border trade deal
Description: Britain needs a new trade deal with the European Union which gives UK and EU insurers and reinsurers the right to operate across borders, an industry lobby group said on Thursday.

Headline: UK political parties warned of Russian hacking threat - report
Description: A British intelligence agency has told political parties to protect themselves against potential cyber attacks, citing allegations that Russian hackers tried to influence last year's U.S. presidential election.

Headline: Government must make plans for possibility of no Brexit deal - MPs
Description: It would be a serious dereliction of duty if the British government failed to plan for the possibility of not reaching an exit deal with the European Union, a committee of members of parliament said in a report published on Sunday.

Headline: Parliament must not have power to veto EU exit - Brexit minister
Description: Brexit minister David Davis said parliament must not be able to veto Britain's decision to leave the European Union, urging members of parliament to reject proposed changes to legislation that gives Prime Minister Theresa May the power to begin exit talks.

Headline: UK terrorism reinsurance fund hopes to include cyber - CEO
Description: Britain's 6 billion pounds terrorism reinsurance fund hopes to extend its cover to include cyber attacks on property, chief executive Julian Enoizi said.

Headline: BT resolves two-year broadband battle with Openreach deal
Description: Britain's biggest telecoms group BT has bowed to industry and regulatory pressure and agreed to legally separate its national network, as the government seeks to deliver faster broadband speeds for millions.

Headline: Airlines demand clarity from Britain on post-Brexit flying
Description: Airlines need Britain to hurry up with plans for aviation following its vote to leave the European Union, because the deadline for preparing flight schedules in a post-Brexit Europe is fast approaching, a Ryanair executive said on Friday.

Headline: Factbox - When will May trigger Brexit?
Description: Legislation giving Prime Minister Theresa May the power to begin the formal process of Britain's exit from the European Union is expected to complete its passage through parliament next week.

Headline: Britons should retain EU rights after Brexit, Verhofstadt tells BBC
Description: The lead Brexit negotiator for the European Parliament wants to ensure that Britons can retain the benefits of European Union citizenship after the UK leaves the block, he told BBC radio on Friday.

Headline: Scottish independence vote looking inevitable, FT cites unidentified UK minister
Description: A second Scottish independence referendum is now looking inevitable and ministers in the United Kingdom government have now concluded it is a question of when such a vote will be held, the Financial Times reported on Friday.

Headline: Silence is golden - May plays down Brexit talk at EU summit
Description: It was her last EU summit before launching Brexit, but British Prime Minister Theresa May was keener to talk about pretty much anything else.

Headline: Budget will increase Britain's post-Brexit economic resilience - May's spokesman
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond told the government's top team of ministers that his budget statement on Wednesday would increase Britain's economic resilience for its future outside the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said.

Headline: Exclusive - EU cannot yet say how much UK should pay on Brexit: auditor
Description: The European Union cannot yet assess how much Britain should be asked to pay Brussels when it quits the bloc, as much will have to be settled by negotiation, the EU's chief auditor has told European lawmakers.

Headline: UK government vows to reverse parliament's changes to Brexit bill
Description: The British government will seek to overturn changes made by parliament's upper chamber on Tuesday to legislation that will give Prime Minister Theresa May the power to begin EU exit talks, Brexit minister David Davis said in a statement.

Headline: May defeated as lawmakers demand power to reject final Brexit terms
Description: Britain's upper house of parliament voted on Tuesday to give lawmakers more power to reject the final terms of the country's exit from the European Union, ignoring pleas from Prime Minister Theresa May's government not to hamstring their negotiations.

Headline: Disputed Irish loughs present Brexit conundrum for fishermen
Description: Mussel fisherman Brian MacDonald shares many of the concerns about Britain's divorce from the European Union that are felt by tens of thousands of people who earn a living along the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.

Headline: May clear she wants Brexit bill to pass unamended - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has been clear she wants a bill that gives her the power to trigger formal divorce talks with the European Union to pass into law unamended, her spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: Europe should remain firm on Brexit, U.S. uncertainty - French finance minister
Description: The best response to Britain's departure from the European Union and uncertainty regarding the United States is for Europe to maintain a firm position, French Finance Minister Michel Sapin said on Tuesday.

Headline: Exclusive - Hard Brexit would trigger 'leaching' of banks from UK: draft report
Description: A draft report on the impact of Brexit on Britain's financial industry warns banks and staff would "leach" away, undermining the wider UK economy, if they do not have access to European Union markets, according to sources who have read the report.

Headline: UK needs financial reserves in the tank for Brexit - Hammond
Description: Britain's Chancellor Philip Hammond said he would keep "reserves in the tank" to see the economy through its looming Brexit challenge, signalling little room for extra spending in this week's budget despite better news on borrowing.

Headline: DUP's Foster resists Sinn Fein calls to go as Northern Ireland talks begin
Description: Talks to save Northern Ireland's devolved government ran straight into an obstacle on Monday as Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader Arlene Foster resisted renewed demands by Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein not to return as first minister.

Headline: May told GM CEO she wants to see Vauxhall jobs protected
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told the chief executive of General Motors , Mary Barra, that she wanted to see jobs at two Vauxhall car plants in Britain secured for the long term during a phone call on Sunday, May's office said in a statement.

Headline: Northern Ireland's McGuinness in hospital for past two weeks - Irish News says
Description: Martin McGuinness, Northern Ireland's former deputy first minister who stepped down in January because of illness, has spent the last two weeks in hospital due to severe side effects from his treatment, the Irish News reported on Monday.

Headline: UK ramps up skills training to tackle productivity problem
Description: Britain plans to spend an extra half a billion pounds a year to improve skills training, the government said on Sunday, seeking to address the country’s nagging productivity problems as it prepares to leave the European Union.

Headline: Battle-hardened in Britain, May prepares for Brexit talks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is unlikely to bow to political expedience in Brexit negotiations but will make up her own mind about what she believes is best and refuse to give ground - that's if past form is anything to go by.

Headline: Factbox - Countdown to Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will write to European Council President Donald Tusk this month to trigger Britain's withdrawal from the European Union under Article 50 of the EU treaty.

Headline: Brexit 'mood music' better, EU more pragmatic - Hammond
Description: The tone of private discussions between Britain and other members of the European Union about Brexit has improved since earlier this year, British Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Sunday.

Headline: Britain should make unilateral offer on post-Brexit rights of EU citizens - MPs
Description: The British government should make a unilateral decision now to protect the post-Brexit rights of European Union nationals living in Britain, a committee of MPs said in a report published on Sunday.

Headline: Tight deadline for talks after nationalist surge in Northern Ireland
Description: Northern Irish leaders prepared on Saturday for three weeks of challenging talks to save their devolved government after a snap election that could have dramatic implications for the politics and constitutional status of the British province.

Headline: Bruised DUP edge buoyant Sinn Fein in Northern Ireland election
Description: The pro-British Democratic Unionist Party narrowly remained Northern Ireland's largest party after edging Irish nationalists Sinn Fein by a single seat in snap elections ahead of arduous talks to resurrect their power-sharing government.

Headline: UK not legally bound to pay into EU budget if no Brexit deal - lawmakers
Description: If Britain leaves the European Union without agreeing an exit deal it will not be legally obliged to contribute to the bloc's budget post-Brexit, a committee of members of Britain's upper house of parliament said on Saturday.

Headline: BMW's UK workers to be balloted for strike action over pension changes
Description: British workers at BMW's  Mini and Rolls-Royce car plants are to be balloted for strike action over plans by the German automaker to close the firm's final salary pension schemes, Britain's biggest trade union said on Friday.

Headline: There is no economic case for breaking up the United Kingdom, says May
Description: There is no economic case for breaking up the United Kingdom, British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday, in a speech attacking Scottish nationalists for being "obsessed" with independence.

Headline: May accuses SNP of sacrificing Scotland for independence 'obsession'
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May took aim at Scotland's ruling party on Friday, accusing nationalists of sacrificing not only the United Kingdom but also Scotland with its "obsession" with securing independence.

Headline: MPs say May's industrial plan falls short, risks mistakes
Description: Britain's new industrial strategy, unveiled earlier this year to prepare the economy for Brexit, is lacking in long-term thinking and risks making the same mistakes as prior, failed plans, a group of MPs said.

Headline: We need to talk about Brexit - Britannia hears her people in new play
Description: Brendon O'Donnell voted to leave the European Union because he felt British money should go to struggling communities or local hospitals rather than Brussels, and his voice was not being heard.

Headline: Daniel Craig need not apply - MI6 looks to 'tap up' new spies
Description: Britain's MI6 spy agency will go back to its old, informal "tap on the shoulder" method of hiring new agents in a bid to find more black and Asian recruits.

Headline: EU watchdog calls for "transparent" Brexit negotiations
Description: The European Ombudsman called on the EU's Brexit negotiators on Thursday to give the public access to documents and accept their input during the talks on Britain's withdrawal, which are due to start in the coming weeks.

Headline: UK still on track to trigger Article 50 this month - Brexit minister
Description: Britain remains on track to trigger the legal process for leaving the European Union by the end of March despite a setback in the House of Lords, Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday.

Headline: May clear she wants Brexit bill unchanged by parliament - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has been clear that the legislation needed for her to trigger formal divorce talks with the European Union should be passed by parliament unamended, her spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: Northern Ireland bids to break political deadlock in snap election
Description: Northern Ireland goes to the polls for the second time in a year on Thursday to try to break a deadlock that could see devolved power revert to London for the first time in a decade just as Britain negotiates its exit from the European Union.

Headline: DUP's Foster resists Sinn Fein calls to go as Northern Ireland talks begin
Description: Talks to save Northern Ireland's devolved government ran straight into an obstacle on Monday as Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) leader Arlene Foster resisted renewed demands by Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein not to return as first minister.

Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told the chief executive of General Motors , Mary Barra, that she wanted to see jobs at two Vauxhall car plants in Britain secured for the long term during a phone call on Sunday, May's office said in a statement.

Description: Martin McGuinness, Northern Ireland's former deputy first minister who stepped down in January because of illness, has spent the last two weeks in hospital due to severe side effects from his treatment, the Irish News reported on Monday.

Description: Britain plans to spend an extra half a billion pounds a year to improve skills training, the government said on Sunday, seeking to address the country’s nagging productivity problems as it prepares to leave the European Union.

Description: Northern Irish leaders prepared on Saturday for three weeks of challenging talks to save their devolved government after a snap election that could have dramatic implications for the politics and constitutional status of the British province.

Headline: Bruised DUP edge buoyant Sinn Fein in Northern Ireland election
Description: The pro-British Democratic Unionist Party narrowly remained Northern Ireland's largest party after edging Irish nationalists Sinn Fein by a single seat in snap elections ahead of arduous talks to resurrect their power-sharing government.

Headline: May says government is talking to Ford on automotive sector
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday her government would hold regular talks with Ford to find ways to ensure its engine plant in Wales remains part of the car producer's "success" in Britain after leaving the European Union.

Headline: UK house prices accelerate, 2017 still seen sluggish - Nationwide
Description: British house price rose more quickly than expected in February, recovering from the weakest month for more than a year in January but concerns about Brexit are likely to weigh on the market in 2017, mortgage lender Nationwide said on Wednesday.

Headline: Austerity measure - May gives up crisps for Lent
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May, who is not known for her self-indulgence, has revealed she will be giving up crisps in the run-up to Easter -- a period called Lent when many Christians fast or give up luxuries.

Headline: Scottish leader says Britain's hard Brexit stance raises chance of new independence vote
Description: The "sheer intransigence" of the British government over Brexit could lead to a second Scottish independence referendum, the head of the devolved Scottish government said on Tuesday.

Headline: May wants Brexit deal that allow automakers to flourish
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has been clear that her government wants to secure a Brexit deal with the European Union that will allow Nissan and other automakers to flourish in Britain, her spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: Bank of England's Hogg gets rough ride from lawmakers
Description: The Bank of England's newest deputy governor came under criticism from lawmakers on Tuesday for sticking too closely to the central bank's orthodoxy and faced tough questions about her family's links to the banking industry.

Headline: Brexit minister urges preparation for deal and no Brexit deal - May's spokesman
Description: Brexit minister David Davis told Britain's top team of ministers on Tuesday to prepare not only for a negotiated settlement with the European Union but also for the "unlikely scenario" of no Brexit deal, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said.

Headline: London politicians tell UK government not to use EU workers as bargaining chip
Description: European Union workers are the "lifeblood" of London, with sectors such as health and construction reliant on their labour, and so they should be guaranteed the right to stay after Brexit, politicians from the British capital said on Tuesday.

Headline: House of Lords seeks to add conditions to Brexit notice
Description: Britain's unelected House of Lords flirted on Monday with  changing the conditions under which the country will announce its departure from the European Union, threatening to attach amendments to Prime Minister Theresa May's legislation.

Headline: UK needs more charm, less 'cheap rhetoric' for good Brexit deal - former PM Major
Description: The British government needs to approach divorce talks with the European Union with more charm and less "cheap rhetoric" if it wants to get a good deal, former Conservative prime minister John Major said on Monday.

Headline: Acrimonious election campaign deepens Northern Ireland deadlock
Description: Acrimonious campaigning ahead of Thursday snap elections in Northern Ireland has increased antagonism between pro-British unionists and Irish nationalists and exacerbated fears devolved power may revert to London for the first time in a decade.

Headline: As Brexit talks loom, EU to dodge early clearing clash
Description: The European Union will not pick an immediate fight with the City of London over its right to clear euro-denominated securities, EU officials said on Monday, as Britain prepares to trigger the process of quitting the bloc.

Headline: Three years on, Britain's child sex abuse inquiry starts hearings
Description: Britain's inquiry into historical child sex abuse scandals, some involving celebrities and politicians, finally opened its first public hearing on Monday after a sleuth of problems that led to three chairmen quitting in the three years since its launch.

Headline: May sees settling EU citizens rights a priority in Brexit talks
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May wants to settle the question of the rights of EU citizens living in Britain as a priority in talks to leave the European Union, but has not set a timetable for her migration policies, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: UK government spokesman - Scotland should not hold new independence referendum
Description: The threat of a new Scottish independence referendum is creating unnecessary uncertainty and division, a British government spokesman said on Monday, reiterating Prime Minister Theresa May's view that there was no need for another vote on the issue.

Headline: Poland sees 100,000-200,000 Poles coming home after Brexit
Description: Between 100,000 and 200,000 Poles living in Britain may return home as a result of Britain leaving the European Union, a Polish government ministry said on Monday.

Headline: Farage posts picture of 'dinner with The Donald'
Description: British anti-EU campaigner Nigel Farage posted a picture of him having "dinner with The Donald" on Twitter, the latest meeting between U.S. President Donald Trump and the critic of Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: Islamic State planning attacks in Britain - anti-terrorism lawyer
Description: Islamic State militants are planning "indiscriminate attacks on innocent civilians" in Britain on a scale similar to those staged by the Irish Republican Army 40 years ago, the head of the country's new terrorism watchdog said.

Headline: Part premiere, part Trump protest, Londoners gather for Oscar movie
Description: Thousands of people braved London's winter drizzle on Sunday for a screening of the Oscar-nominated movie that has become a rallying point for opponents of U.S. President Donald Trump’s immigration policy.

Headline: Scottish Labour rules out platform with Conservatives to fight independence
Description: Scottish Labour would not join forces with the Conservatives in a joint campaign to defend the United Kingdom if Scotland held a second independence referendum, leader Kezia Dugdale has said.

Headline: May's Conservatives gain parliament seat as rivals suffer setbacks
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservatives secured a landmark victory in a parliamentary by-election on Friday, strengthening her hand ahead of Brexit negotiations as her rivals suffered damaging setbacks.

Headline: Northern Ireland leader says rivals may force return to London rule
Description: Irish nationalists may force a prolonged collapse of Northern Ireland's devolved government and a return to direct rule from London if they cannot agree a new government with unionists, the leader of the British province said on Friday.

Headline: On visit to London, Peugeot boss offers reassuring words on Vauxhall plants
Description: The head of French carmaker PSA played down the threat to British factories when he discussed the potential takeover of GM's European operations with union officials and politicians in London on Friday.

Headline: UK minister says assured by Peugeot CEO of commitments to UK plants
Description: Britain's business minister Greg Clark said he discussed with the chief executive of Peugeot the firm's approach to expand production, rather than close plants, as the French carmaker explores taking over GM's Vauxhall and Opel brands in Europe.

Headline: Opel works council to seek contact with PSA labour bosses
Description: Opel's European works council said it had agreed to open a line of communication with its counterpart at PSA Group as the French carmaker holds talks over a tie-up with the company.

Headline: UK government intervention has made energy more expensive - lawmakers
Description: Constant government intervention in Britain's energy sector has led to a complex system of subsidies and an uncompetitive market that fails to deliver low-cost and secure electricity, a report by an upper-house parliamentary committee said on Friday.

Headline: May's Conservatives win parliamentary seat, first gain for ruling party for 35 years
Description: Britain's ruling Conservatives won a parliamentary by-election in the north-west English region of Copeland on Friday, taking control of a once safe seat held by the opposition Labour Party and the first such gain by a ruling party since 1982.

Headline: Labour Party hold off UKIP to win Stoke by-election
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party won a parliamentary by-election for the Stoke Central seat on Friday, fending off a challenge from the anti-European Union UK Independence Party which had hoped to capitalise on the area's pro-Brexit stance.

Headline: Scottish government believes it can call, win new independence vote - sources
Description: The Scottish government is increasingly confident it can win a new independence referendum and is considering calling one next year as Britain exits the European Union, sources close to the Edinburgh administration say.

Headline: Morgan Stanley weighs initial 300 Brexit job moves - Bloomberg
Description: U.S. bank Morgan Stanley may initially move 300 staff from Britain following its exit from the European Union, and is scouting for office space in Frankfurt and Dublin, Bloomberg News reported on Thursday.

Headline: UK needs more charm, less 'cheap rhetoric' for good Brexit deal - former PM Major

Headline: Scottish government believes it can call, win new independence vote - sources
Description: The Scottish government is increasingly confident it can win a new independence referendum and is considering calling one next year as Britain exits the European Union, sources close to the Edinburgh administration say.

Headline: UK union fears grow over future of GM's Vauxhall plants - source
Description: The head of Britain's biggest trade union is likely to meet the CEO of PSA Group on Friday amid growing concerns over the future of Vauxhall plants if the French carmaker buys the business from General Motors, a union source told Reuters.

Headline: UK on track to trigger Article 50 by end of March - David Davis
Description: Britain remains on track to trigger the legal process for leaving the European Union by the end of March, Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Monday, although he would not name a specific date.

Headline: UK government has no intention of revoking Article 50 - May's spokesman
Description: The British government has no intention of revoking its withdrawal from the European Union once the formal exit process has been triggered, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Greg Clark called to parliament over Peugeot-GM deal - Labour
Description: The Business Secretary will be called to parliament to answer a question on Monday regarding Peugeot's proposed takeover of General Motors' Vauxhall car and van plants in Britain, the Labour Party said on Twitter.

Headline: May to meet Peugeot head, determined to protect UK car industry
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will have a private conversation with the chief executive of Peugeot Carlos Tavares and is determined to protect Britain's car industry, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Timeline for British government's Brexit legislation
Description: The House of Lords, on Monday begins debating legislation which would give Prime Minister Theresa May the power to trigger Britain's exit from the European Union.

Headline: Pension deficit at GM's British operations stands at up to 1 billion pounds - source
Description: The pensions deficit at General Motors' British division stands at up to 1 billion pounds, a source told Reuters on Monday, amid fears over the future of its Vauxhall plants as Peugeot explores a European buyout.

Headline: Stronger growth to help UK beat 2016/17 budget target - EY ITEM Club
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond is likely to hit his 2016/17 deficit reduction target with 3 billion pounds to spare, due to recent better-than-expected growth, economists working for accountants EY said on Monday.

Headline: UK government to set out powers paving way for first space satellite launch
Description: Britain will set out powers this week which would allow the launch of space satellites from the country for the first time, the government said on Monday.

Headline: House of Lords likely to attach conditions to Brexit bill - Mandelson
Description: The House of Lords is likely to attach conditions to legislation giving Prime Minister Theresa May the power to trigger the country's exit from the European Union, a former MP from the Labour Party said on Sunday.

Headline: 'That bus has gone' - EU sees no Brexit U-turn now
Description: Tony Blair wants fellow Britons to "rise up" and block or soften Brexit, but it may now be out of their hands -- many Europeans just want them to get on and get out.

Headline: May orders officials to examine Kraft Heinz bid for Unilever - FT
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has asked top officials to examine U.S. food company Kraft Heinz's proposed takeover of Unilever Plc, the Financial Times reported on Sunday without citing any sources.

Headline: Britain's exit from EU irrevocable once triggered - MP Truss
Description: The process of Britain leaving the European Union is irrevocable once it has been triggered, a government minister said on Sunday.

Headline: RBS proposes abandoning sale of Williams & Glyn unit
Description: Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc has proposed abandoning the planned sale of its Williams & Glyn unit after a seven-year struggle to sell the small business lender to meet European Union state aid demands.

Headline: Former PM Blair urges Britons to "rise up" against May's Brexit plan
Description: Former British prime minister Tony Blair issued a battle cry against a so-called 'hard Brexit' on Friday, calling on voters, businesses and campaigners to "rise up" and back a coordinated effort to temper the terms of, or even halt, Britain's EU exit.

Headline: Cutting takeaway taxes, UKIP seeks path to voters' hearts
Description: If food is the way to a man's heart, cutting tax on Britain's much-loved fish and chips is the way Paul Nuttall, leader of the anti-EU UKIP party, hopes to win over the country's voters.

Headline: London to introduce vehicle pollution tax from October
Description: London will introduce a charge on the oldest and most polluting vehicles from October in a new effort to improve air quality, Mayor Sadiq Khan said on Friday.

Headline: UK pensions body backs rules to toughen up corporate pay votes
Description: Britain's Pensions and Lifetime Savings Association (PLSA) on Friday called for new rules to ensure a 'super majority' of investors were needed to sign of on a company's pay plans, as part of a government consultation.

Headline: German government has spoken to PSA and GM over Opel - econ ministry
Description: German government representatives have met with bosses at General Motors and Peugeot regarding talks between the two carmakers on the French group buying GM's European arm Opel, a spokeswoman for the German economy ministry said on Friday.

Headline: Britain says PSA bosses wish to build on Vauxhall's success
Description: Bosses at the Peugeot-maker PSA Group have told the British government they would seek to build on the strengths of the Vauxhall car business if they succeed in buying its parent company, Opel.

Headline: VW says it has fixed 470,000 cars in Britain affected by diesel scandal
Description: German carmaker Volkswagen  has fixed 470,000 cars out of 1.2 million affected by the diesel emissions scandal in Britain, the firm's UK managing director told lawmakers on Monday.

Headline: UK union fears grow over future of GM's Vauxhall plants - source
Description: The head of Britain's biggest trade union is likely to meet the CEO of PSA Group on Friday amid growing concerns over the future of Vauxhall plants if the French carmaker buys the business from General Motors, a union source told Reuters.

Description: Britain remains on track to trigger the legal process for leaving the European Union by the end of March, Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Monday, although he would not name a specific date.

Headline: UK government to set out powers paving way for first space satellite launch
Description: Britain will set out powers this week which would allow the launch of space satellites from the country for the first time, the government said on Monday.

Headline: Tone of British-EU divorce talks to decide path for UK growth - Reuters poll
Description: The tone of Britain's divorce negotiations with the European Union will be the main factor influencing the economy this year, according to economists polled by Reuters who also say the Bank of England will leave policy steady at least until 2019.

Headline: Britain unlikely to trigger Article 50 at March 9 EU summit - Brexit Secretary
Description: Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Tuesday the government was on course to meet its end-March deadline to launch the formal divorce procedure from the European Union but did not see Britain doing so at an EU summit next month.

Headline: Exclusive - Lloyds Bank closes in on Berlin as post-Brexit EU hub: sources
Description: Lloyds Banking Group  is close to selecting Berlin as a European base to secure market access to the European Union when Britain leaves the bloc, sources told Reuters.

Headline: UK employers worry that EU workers will leave this year - survey
Description: More than a quarter of employers in Britain say staff members from other European Union countries have considered leaving their firms or the country in 2017 after last year's Brexit vote, an industry group said on Monday.

Headline: Monsieur Brexit - EU's Barnier braces for baffling Brits
Description: Michel Barnier has a dealmaker's flair for gauging what the other side can accept but as Theresa May prepares to launch Brexit negotiations some EU officials wonder if Brussels' man can really figure out what she wants.

Headline: Northern Ireland's peace generation frozen out by politics of war
Description: The sudden collapse of a power-sharing agreement that ended decades of violence in Northern Ireland has angered a younger generation who feel robbed of their future by the failure of politicians to get over the sectarian prejudices of the past.

Headline: Factbox - Team Barnier: Going into bat for EU in Brexit talks
Description: Michel Barnier, the European Union's chief Brexit negotiator, currently has a 29-strong team to coordinate Brussels' efforts to reach a divorce deal with Britain by 2019:

Headline: Factbox - EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier
Description: The career of EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier:

Headline: Strong message sent to upper house on Brexit bill, says UK minister
Description: Britain's upper house of parliament has been given "a pretty powerful message" to pass legislation to start Brexit talks and not delay Prime Minister Theresa May's timetable for leaving the European Union, a government minister said on Sunday.

Headline: Juncker says Britain may divide EU over Brexit talks
Description: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said he fears Britain will divide the European Union's 27 remaining members by making different promises to each country during its Brexit negotiations.

Headline: UK to close Iraq war abuse unit, citing false claims
Description: Britain's government has said it will shut down a unit investigating claims of torture and unlawful killing by British soldiers in Iraq after a law firm representing alleged victims was found to have made false claims.

Headline: EU finance chief says UK faces disruption after Brexit
Description: Britain is likely to face some economic disruption and worse trading terms if it loses access to the European single market when it leaves the EU in 2019, the bloc's financial services chief said on Friday.

Headline: House of Lords aims to attach conditions to EU divorce legislation
Description: Members of the House of Lords said on Friday they would try to attach conditions to legislation giving Prime Minister Theresa May the power to trigger the country's exit from the European Union.

Headline: Not now, Nicola - Scottish town sees no haste for new independence bid
Description: Scottish independence supporters in West Lothian have some advice for their First Minister Nicola Sturgeon: bide your time on another referendum.

Headline: Despite protests, many Britons back May's attempt to court Trump
Description: Britons have protested in their thousands against Donald Trump, almost 1.9 million oppose his planned state visit to their country and the U.S. president is not welcome to address the lower house of parliament. But in Braintree, people feel differently.

Headline: Great Portland to sell Rathbone Square to German investors
Description: Great Portland has agreed to sell Rathbone Square, a mixed-use development that houses Facebook's new London headquarters, to German rival WestInvest Gesellschaft and asset manager Deka Immobilien for 435 million pounds.

Headline: Unrealistic to see UK/EU trade deal in two years - EU representative
Description: It is unrealistic for Britain to expect to negotiate its exit from the European Union and reach a free trade agreement in two years and both will probably need an implementation phase, the head of the European Commission's office in Britain said.

Headline: Britain tells Scotland - No need for second independence referendum
Description: Britain sees no need for a second Scottish independence referendum and the devolved Scottish government should focus on improving the economy and tacking domestic issues rather than flirting with secession, a senior British minister said.

Headline: The fight starts now? Corbyn criticised after Brexit battle cry
Description: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn was publicly lambasted by Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon after declaring that his fight over the government's Brexit plan "starts now", shortly after he voted in favour of triggering Britain's EU exit.

Headline: May quashes attempts to derail her Brexit plan in parliament
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May won approval from parliament's lower chamber on Wednesday to trigger Britain's exit from the European Union, defeating attempts by pro-EU lawmakers to attach extra conditions to her plan to start divorce talks by March 31.

Headline: UK names top Bank of England administrator as new deputy governor
Description: The woman who carried out Governor Mark Carney's overhaul of the Bank of England will become a deputy governor, giving her a role in overseeing the stability of financial markets as Britain prepares to leave the European Union.

Headline: May says Trump immigration order was wrong
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump's order temporarily banning entry to people from seven Muslim-majority countries is wrong and Britain does not plan to adopt a similar policy, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: May says to trigger Article 50 by end of March
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday that she would trigger formal divorce talks with the European Union by the end of March.

Headline: India applies to extradite Kingfisher tycoon Mallya from UK
Description: India said on Thursday it had applied to Britain to extradite Vijay Mallya to face trial after the liquor and aviation tycoon was charged with conspiracy and fraud over a loan to his defunct Kingfisher Airlines.

Headline: Trump's visit to Britain could happen around June - London police chief
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump's state visit to the United Kingdom could happen around June, the outgoing chief of London's Metropolitan Police said on Thursday.

Headline: Timeline for May's Brexit legislation - Holiday, Lords, Trigger
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has won approval from parliament's lower chamber to trigger Britain's exit from the European Union, defeating attempts by pro-EU MPs to attach extra conditions to her plan to start divorce talks by March 31.

Headline: UK plans to remove insurance barriers for self-driving cars
Description: Britain plans to introduce new insurance rules to ensure victims of accidents involving self-driving cars are compensated quickly in a bid to remove a major obstacle for the nascent industry.

Headline: Scottish government set to demand legal right to new independence referendum - newspaper
Description: Scottish government workers have been told to ready themselves for a second independence referendum in a notice that said First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was set to demand the legal right to another constitutional vote, The Courier newspaper in Dundee, Scotland, reported on Wednesday.

Headline: Boris Johnson no longer has U.S. citizenship - U.S. Treasury list
Description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has given up his U.S. citizenship, a U.S. Treasury Department list showed on Wednesday, a move the New York-born politician had said he would make.

Headline: May says an independent Scotland would not be in the European Union
Description: An independent Scotland would not be part of the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Support for Scottish independence rises after PM May goes for 'clean break Brexit'
Description: Support for Scottish independence has risen since British Prime Minister Theresa May came out last month in favour of Britain making a clean break with the European Union when it leaves the bloc, an opinion poll showed on Wednesday.

Headline: Who decides whether Scotland holds a new independence referendum?
Description: The June Brexit referendum called the future of the United Kingdom into question because majorities in England and Wales voted to leave but in Scotland and Northern Ireland, most people voted to stay.

Headline: British tourism to Spain hits record despite pound's post-Brexit fall
Description: The number of British tourists visiting Spain jumped by the most in over a decade to hit a record in 2016, defying expectations of a slowdown in bookings after June's Brexit vote and the subsequent tumble in sterling.

Headline: Denmark joins race to host EU drug agency instead of London after Brexit
Description: The Danish government on Wednesday teamed up with the former head of drug company Novo Nordisk in its campaign to become the new host of the London-based European Medicines Agency (EMA) after Britain's vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: McLaren Automotive to create 200 UK jobs with new chassis plant
Description: Luxury sports car maker McLaren Automotive said it will create more than 200 jobs in Britain by bringing production of its carbon-fibre chassis from Austria to northern England, a move it said had been initiated long before the Brexit vote.

Headline: There should not be a second Scottish independence vote - May's spokesman
Description: The British government does not believe there should be a second referendum on Scottish independence, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said when asked about a report it was preparing contingency plans for one.

Headline: Scotland must have say on UK's Article 50 letter - Scottish minister
Description: The British government cannot begin the process of leaving the EU before it has agreed with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland the form of the letter to launch divorce talks, Scotland's Brexit minister said on Wednesday.

Headline: China invites Britain to attend new Silk Road summit - sources
Description: China has invited British Prime Minister Theresa May to attend a major summit in May on its "One Belt, One Road" initiative to build a new Silk Road, diplomatic sources told Reuters, as London said she would visit China this year.

Headline: May anticipates call for Scottish independence referendum - report
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is developing a secret strategy in the belief that Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is two weeks away from demanding a second referendum on Scottish independence, The Courier newspaper in Dundee, Scotland reported on Tuesday.

Headline: UK government says MPs will vote on Brexit deal before EU parliament
Description: MPs will be given the chance to vote on the government's final Brexit deal before the exit terms are debated by the European Parliament, junior Brexit minister David Jones said on Tuesday.
