Description: Britain plans to introduce new insurance rules to ensure victims of accidents involving self-driving cars are compensated quickly in a bid to remove a major obstacle for the nascent industry.

Headline: Scottish government set to demand legal right to new independence referendum - newspaper
Description: Scottish government workers have been told to ready themselves for a second independence referendum in a notice that said First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was set to demand the legal right to another constitutional vote, The Courier newspaper in Dundee, Scotland, reported on Wednesday.

Headline: Boris Johnson no longer has U.S. citizenship - U.S. Treasury list
Description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has given up his U.S. citizenship, a U.S. Treasury Department list showed on Wednesday, a move the New York-born politician had said he would make.

Headline: May says an independent Scotland would not be in the European Union
Description: An independent Scotland would not be part of the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Support for Scottish independence rises after PM May goes for 'clean break Brexit'
Description: Support for Scottish independence has risen since British Prime Minister Theresa May came out last month in favour of Britain making a clean break with the European Union when it leaves the bloc, an opinion poll showed on Wednesday.

Headline: Who decides whether Scotland holds a new independence referendum?
Description: The June Brexit referendum called the future of the United Kingdom into question because majorities in England and Wales voted to leave but in Scotland and Northern Ireland, most people voted to stay.

Headline: British tourism to Spain hits record despite pound's post-Brexit fall
Description: The number of British tourists visiting Spain jumped by the most in over a decade to hit a record in 2016, defying expectations of a slowdown in bookings after June's Brexit vote and the subsequent tumble in sterling.

Headline: Denmark joins race to host EU drug agency instead of London after Brexit
Description: The Danish government on Wednesday teamed up with the former head of drug company Novo Nordisk in its campaign to become the new host of the London-based European Medicines Agency (EMA) after Britain's vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: McLaren Automotive to create 200 UK jobs with new chassis plant
Description: Luxury sports car maker McLaren Automotive said it will create more than 200 jobs in Britain by bringing production of its carbon-fibre chassis from Austria to northern England, a move it said had been initiated long before the Brexit vote.

Headline: There should not be a second Scottish independence vote - May's spokesman
Description: The British government does not believe there should be a second referendum on Scottish independence, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said when asked about a report it was preparing contingency plans for one.

Headline: Scotland must have say on UK's Article 50 letter - Scottish minister
Description: The British government cannot begin the process of leaving the EU before it has agreed with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland the form of the letter to launch divorce talks, Scotland's Brexit minister said on Wednesday.

Headline: China invites Britain to attend new Silk Road summit - sources
Description: China has invited British Prime Minister Theresa May to attend a major summit in May on its "One Belt, One Road" initiative to build a new Silk Road, diplomatic sources told Reuters, as London said she would visit China this year.

Headline: May anticipates call for Scottish independence referendum - report
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is developing a secret strategy in the belief that Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is two weeks away from demanding a second referendum on Scottish independence, The Courier newspaper in Dundee, Scotland reported on Tuesday.

Headline: UK government says MPs will vote on Brexit deal before EU parliament
Description: MPs will be given the chance to vote on the government's final Brexit deal before the exit terms are debated by the European Parliament, junior Brexit minister David Jones said on Tuesday.

Headline: China invites Britain to attend new Silk Road summit - sources
Description: China has invited British Prime Minister Theresa May to attend a major summit in May on its "One Belt, One Road" initiative to build a new Silk Road, diplomatic sources told Reuters.

Headline: No renegotiation on Brexit deal if parliament rejects it - minister
Description: Britain will not seek further talks with the European Union if parliament rejects the exit deal it reaches, the government said on Tuesday, as ministers defeated attempts to give lawmakers more say on the terms of the final agreement.

Headline: Scottish lawmakers reject triggering Brexit in symbolic vote
Description: Scotland's devolved parliament overwhelmingly rejected British Prime Minister Theresa May's plan to exit the European Union in a symbolic, non-binding vote on Tuesday.

Headline: May will raise trade at China meeting this year
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is expected to raise trade during a visit to China later this year, a trip which will underline the close relationship between the two countries, May's spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: British police say PIA jet diverted because of disruptive passenger
Description: A Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) aircraft which was intercepted and escorted by fighter jets to Stansted airport northeast of London was diverted because of reports of a disruptive passenger, British police said on Tuesday.

Headline: Lack of information on Tesco Bank hack frustrates fellow lenders
Description: British banking executives and security experts are growing frustrated at the dearth of information available more than three months after 2.5 million pounds ($3.09 million) was stolen from Tesco Bank in the UK's biggest financial cyber heist.

Headline: May faces bumpy road to her 'special relationship' with U.S.
Description: It was an invitation to seal Theresa May's bid to revitalise the "special relationship" with the United States, but the promise of a state visit for Donald Trump is turning into another headache for the British prime minister.

Headline: UK changes tack with help for renters, not just homebuyers
Description: Britain set out plans on Tuesday to make renting more affordable, protect tenants and punish developers for not building quickly enough, in a shift away from decades of policy almost solely promoting home ownership.

Headline: Hairline cracks emerge in UK consumer spending, pillar of economy
Description: The first post-Brexit vote cracks may be emerging in consumer spending, the cornerstone of Britain's economy, with a series of downbeat retail surveys suggesting inflation pressures are starting to weigh on households.

Headline: UK tax burden set to rise to highest since 1986 - IFS
Description: Britain's tax burden will rise to its highest in over 30 years by the time of the next national election in 2020, as the government tries to cut borrowing at the same time as leaving the European Union, a leading think tank said on Tuesday.

Headline: MPs reject first set of amendments to Brexit law
Description: MPs on Monday rejected the first set of proposed amendments to legislation that would give Prime Minister Theresa May the right to notify the European Union of Britain's intention to leave the bloc.

Headline: Bercow opposes letting Trump address parliament
Description: The speaker of Britain's lower house of parliament said on Monday he would not support any plans for U.S. President Donald Trump to address parliament during a state visit planned for later this year, citing Trump's temporary immigration ban as a factor.

Headline: Completing Brexit in two years will take a 'little miracle' - Katainen
Description: It will require "a little miracle" for Britain and the European Union to complete negotiations on Britain's exit from the bloc in the two-year time frame allotted, EU Commission Vice President Jyrki Katainen said on Monday.

Headline: Israel's Netanyahu urges Britain to join Iran sanctions
Description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu urged "responsible nations" to join new sanctions against Iran on Monday during a visit to London, but Britain defended a nuclear deal sealed between major powers and Tehran.

Headline: PM May told Netanyahu Britain alert to Iran's destabilising activity - spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told her Israeli counterpart on Monday that Britain supports the Iran nuclear deal but needs to be alert to Iran's pattern of destabilising behaviour in the region, her spokeswoman said.

Headline: MSPs to hold non-binding vote on rejecting Brexit
Description: Scotland's devolved government will attempt to underscore its displeasure at British Prime Minister Theresa May's plan to exit the European Union on Tuesday with a non-binding vote by MSPs to reject triggering Brexit.

Headline: Gun salute marks Queen's 65 years on British throne
Description: Queen Elizabeth, the world's longest-reigning living monarch, celebrated her Sapphire Jubilee on Monday as Britain commemorated 65 years since she ascended the British throne.

Headline: Government says will not allow MPs to block Brexit
Description: MPs seeking to change Theresa May's Brexit strategy will not be able to block Britain from leaving the European Union, May's spokeswoman said on Monday before a debate on possible amendments to legislation in parliament.

Headline: Factbox - Timeline for Britain's Brexit legislation
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is seeking parliament's approval to trigger the legal process for leaving the European Union. To do that she is trying to pass a new law giving her the right to notify the EU of Britain's intention to leave.

Headline: Britain sets out strategic aims for Brexit in policy paper
Description: Britain will outline its strategic aims for Brexit on Thursday in a so-called White Paper policy document, Brexit minister David Davis told parliament.

Headline: May says Scotland's independence bid was settled by 2014 vote
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May believes that Scotland's bid for independence was settled by a referendum in 2014, a vote that was "legal, fair and decisive", a spokeswoman for the leader said on Thursday.

Headline: London led growing ranks of EU's million euro bankers in 2015
Description: Britain boasted the most bankers earning more than a million euros a year in the European Union during 2015, with their overall ranks rising despite policymakers' efforts to curb pay.

Headline: BoE faces Brexit balancing act on growth and rates
Description: The Bank of England will probably try on Thursday to avoid adding to speculation about a first interest rate hike in nearly a decade, even as it acknowledges the resilience of Britain's economy since last year's Brexit vote shock.

Headline: Record number of anti-Semitic incidents recorded in UK last year
Description: Britain saw a record number of anti-Semitic incidents last year, fuelled by issues such as xenophobia following the EU referendum and allegations of anti-Jewish sentiment in the opposition Labour Party, an advisory body said on Thursday.

Headline: Brexit bill clears first legislative hurdle
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's plan to take Britain out of the European Union easily cleared its first legislative hurdle on Wednesday, paving the way for the government to launch divorce talks by the end of March.

Headline: Lord Price says Britain accepts it must leave EU customs union - Welt
Description: Britain has accepted that there can be "no cherry-picking" as it leaves the European Union, a German newspaper reported on Wednesday, quoting Lord Price, Britain's minister of state for trade policy.

Headline: EU court might make changes to any Brexit deal, chief justice says
Description: Britain's withdrawal from the European Union seems likely to end up under review by the EU's top court, which might insist on changes to any Brexit treaty, its chief justice told Reuters in an interview.

Headline: EU's top judge rejects charge of sweeping rulings, calls for clearer laws
Description: The European Union's top judge hit back at accusations that his court overstepped the mark with sweeping rulings imposed across the bloc, saying it was often left having to clear up vague legislation.

Headline: May says will publish Brexit 'White Paper' on Thursday
Description: The British government will publish a "White Paper" document on Thursday, setting out its plan for leaving the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May told parliament.

Headline: Kremlin calls Britain's hacking allegations 'baseless'
Description: The Kremlin said on Friday that allegations made by British Defence Secretary Michael Fallon, who accused Russia of  spreading lies and attacking critical infrastructure with hackers, were "baseless" and a source of regret.

Headline: British government is determined to stick to Brexit timetable - spokesman
Description: The British government is determined to stick to its timetable for leaving the European Union and wants to remind lawmakers of the referendum vote before they scrutinise Brexit legislation next week, a spokesman said on Friday.

Headline: Leading indicator of London new home builds slumps by a third
Description: The number of new homes built in London fell 6 percent last year and a closely watched indicator of future supply dropped by a third, industry data showed on Friday, as the Brexit vote hit a market already coming off record highs.

Headline: Npower to increase energy prices by 9.8 percent from mid-March
Description: British energy supplier npower will raise its dual-fuel annual energy bills by an average of 9.8 percent, or 109 pounds, from March 16, it said on Friday.

Headline: Britain will try to negotiate amicable EU divorce - Brexit paper
Description: Britain will do its utmost to negotiate a divorce deal with the European Union that is mutually beneficial, Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday, setting out the government's strategy in an official policy document.

Headline: Scottish parliament to hold its own vote on triggering Brexit
Description: Scotland's devolved parliament will vote on the triggering of Article 50, which formally starts the process of Britain leaving the European Union, even though its vote is not binding, the pro-independence devolved government said on Thursday.

Headline: 'Forget it,' London tells Scots who want second independence vote
Description: The UK government told Scotland on Thursday to abandon any hopes of holding another independence referendum before 2020, deepening a row with the devolved pro-independence government in Edinburgh over the impact of Brexit on possible secession.

Headline: Train drivers reach deal with Southern rail in long-running dispute
Description: One of Britain's longest and most damaging rail strikes since the industry was privatised in the 1990s appeared to be heading for resolution on Thursday as management at Southern Rail and its drivers reached provisional agreement.

Headline: Bank of England, ramping up growth forecast, in no mood for rate hike
Description: The Bank of England made its latest sharp increase to forecasts for British economic growth in 2017 on Thursday, but appeared in no rush to raise interest rates, warning of "twists and turns" on the road out of the European Union.

Headline: End of central bankers' '15 minutes of fame' draws near - BoE's Carney
Description: Central bankers' "15 minutes of fame" are coming to an end as governments around the world focus increasingly on fiscal spending and trade, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain sets out plan for third runway at London's Heathrow
Description: Britain laid out its proposals for a third runway at London's Heathrow airport on Thursday, launching a public consultation on a huge infrastructure project the government sees as key to its post-Brexit future.

Headline: Britain sets out strategic aims for Brexit in policy paper
Description: Britain will outline its strategic aims for Brexit on Thursday in a so-called White Paper policy document, Brexit minister David Davis told parliament.

Headline: May says Scotland's independence bid was settled by 2014 vote
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May believes that Scotland's bid for independence was settled by a referendum in 2014, a vote that was "legal, fair and decisive", a spokeswoman for the leader said on Thursday.

Headline: London led growing ranks of EU's million euro bankers in 2015
Description: Britain boasted the most bankers earning more than a million euros a year in the European Union during 2015, with their overall ranks rising despite policymakers' efforts to curb pay.

Description: The Bank of England will probably try on Thursday to avoid adding to speculation about a first interest rate hike in nearly a decade, even as it acknowledges the resilience of Britain's economy since last year's Brexit vote shock.

Headline: Brexit bill clears first legislative hurdle
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's plan to take Britain out of the European Union easily cleared its first legislative hurdle on Wednesday, paving the way for the government to launch divorce talks by the end of March.

Headline: Lord Price says Britain accepts it must leave EU customs union - Welt
Description: Britain has accepted that there can be "no cherry-picking" as it leaves the European Union, a German newspaper reported on Wednesday, quoting Lord Price, Britain's minister of state for trade policy.

Headline: EU court might make changes to any Brexit deal, chief justice says
Description: Britain's withdrawal from the European Union seems likely to end up under review by the EU's top court, which might insist on changes to any Brexit treaty, its chief justice told Reuters in an interview.

Headline: EU's top judge rejects charge of sweeping rulings, calls for clearer laws
Description: The European Union's top judge hit back at accusations that his court overstepped the mark with sweeping rulings imposed across the bloc, saying it was often left having to clear up vague legislation.

Headline: Despite Trump backlash, May says 'very happy' to invite him
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May was "very happy" to invite U.S. President Donald Trump for a state visit to Britain, her Downing Street office said on Monday as May faced a popular backlash at home over the planned visit.

Headline: Asked about anti-Trump petition, PM May's spokesman says UK and US have strong relationship
Description: Britain and the United States have a strong relationship and should continue working together, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday when asked about a petition calling for U.S. President Donald Trump's state visit to be cancelled.

Headline: AXA UK says travel policies to cover those hit by U.S. ban
Description: The UK division of French insurer AXA  said its travel policies would cover those denied access to the United States due to a U.S. travel ban on people from seven Muslim-majority countries.

Headline: Global backlash grows against Trump's immigration order
Description: A global backlash against U.S. President Donald Trump's immigration curbs gathered strength on Sunday as several countries including long-standing American allies criticised the measures as discriminatory and divisive.

Headline: Farah relieved he can rejoin family in U.S. amid new travel rules
Description: British Olympic champion Mo Farah said he was relieved he would be able to rejoin his family in the United States after the British government said late on Sunday the new U.S. travel restrictions did not apply to UK nationals born, like Farah, in one of the countries listed.

Headline: Under fire, May criticises Trump curb on refugees
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said Britain did not agree with U.S. President Donald Trump's curbs on immigration after coming under criticism from MPs in her own party for not condemning his executive order when initially questioned.

Headline: Britain, Turkey sign defence deal to develop Turkish fighter jet
Description: Britain and Turkey signed a defence deal worth more than 100 million pounds on Saturday to develop Turkish fighter jets, opening the way to deeper cooperation over the lifetime of the project.

Headline: May says does not agree with Trump on immigration
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Saturday Britain did not agree with "this kind of approach" on U.S. President Donald Trump's curbs on immigration into the United States.

Headline: Trump's refugee ban no solution to problems, Turkey PM says
Description: President Donald Trump's sweeping ban on people seeking refuge in the United States is no solution to problems, Turkish Prime Minister Binali Yildirim said on Saturday, adding that Western countries should do more to help ease Turkey's refugee burden.

Headline: Evoking Reagan and Thatcher, May hails new UK-U.S. 'special relationship'
Description: Evoking the closeness of U.S. President Ronald Reagan and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Theresa May and Donald Trump shared a "warm conversation" at lunch on Friday to cement their own "special relationship", a source in May's team said.

Headline: May's Brexit plan likely to survive parliamentary assault
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's plan to leave the European Union is expected to survive weeks of intense parliamentary scrutiny, which started on Tuesday, despite pro-EU lawmakers' attempts to force the government to rethink its strategy.

Headline: British lawyer plots legal bid to make Brexit reversible
Description: As British lawmakers gather to debate whether to trigger the formal exit from the European Union, London lawyer Jolyon Maugham is building a case which he hopes will ensure that British voters can still reverse it.

Headline: 'In it until you die'- convicted Nigerian politician signals comeback
Description: Former Nigerian oil state governor James Ibori, who was recently released from a British prison after serving a sentence for corruption, has signalled a possible political comeback in Africa's most populous country.

Headline: Britain pardons thousands of gay men convicted under defunct laws
Description: Britain has granted posthumous pardons to thousands of gay and bisexual men who were convicted of sexual offences under laws which have since been abolished, the government said on Tuesday.

Headline: British Airways says most flights to run as normal during Feb. 5-7 strike
Description: British Airways said on Tuesday nearly all flights will go ahead as scheduled despite strike action by cabin crew between Feb. 5-7 and only a small number of flights would be merged.

Headline: British parliament to debate petition on Trump state visit
Description: British lawmakers will hold a debate on Feb. 20 on a petition signed by more than 1.6 million people calling for a planned state visit by U.S. President Donald Trump to be cancelled to avoid embarrassing Queen Elizabeth.

Headline: Scotland launches consultation on fracking
Description: Scotland has launched a consultation on whether to allow unconventional oil and gas extraction such as fracking, its government said on Tuesday, with a vote expected at the end of the year.

Headline: London's Mayor Khan to tell U.S. envoy: travel ban cruel, prejudiced
Description: The mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, will tell the top U.S. diplomat in Britain on Tuesday that President Donald Trump's travel ban on people from a list of Muslim nations is prejudiced and will hurt rather than improve U.S. security.

Headline: Britain to have closest possible nuclear ties post-Brexit, says minister
Description: Britain will maintain the closest possible nuclear cooperation with the European Union after it leaves the bloc and the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom), Britain's Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: Trump state visit to Britain 'months away' - May spokeswoman
Description: A planned state visit to Britain by U.S. President Donald Trump is months away and any programme has yet to be worked out, a spokeswoman for British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: London underground staff, BA cabin crew, to strike next month
Description: London commuters face more travel chaos in February and March as underground train staff press their case over staffing levels with another round of strikes.

Headline: Labour Party faces rebellion over call to back Brexit trigger
Description: Britain's opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn faced a party rebellion on Friday over his support for triggering Brexit, after two MPs resigned from his policy team and others publicly promised to defy him on the issue.

Headline: 'Opposites attract,' PM May calls on Trump to renew special relationship
Description: Joking that "opposites attract," Prime Minister Theresa May called on President Donald Trump on Thursday to renew the "special relationship" between Britain and the United States and lead in a new, changed world.

Headline: Tata must fix pension deficits before any deal - Thyssenkrupp CEO
Description: India's Tata Steel  must first resolve the pension deficit at its British and Dutch operations, before any merger of its steel operations with Thyssenkrupp , the German company's chief executive told a German newspaper.

Headline: UK to respect EU rules as it strengthens trade ties around world - Hammond
Description: Britain will respect its obligations under European Union treaties while it seeks to strengthen trade ties with world partners, the British chancellor said on Friday.

Headline: Britain to publish Article 50 bill as May agrees to set out Brexit plan
Description: Britain said it would publish legislation on Thursday seeking parliament's approval to begin formal divorce talks with the European Union as Prime Minister Theresa May agreed to members of parliament demands to publish her Brexit plan.

Headline: Court case on whether Brexit can be reversed to be filed Friday
Description: A legal challenge to determine whether Britain's exit from the European Union can be reversed once triggered is to be filed in Dublin on Friday with the aim of securing a referral to the EU's top court within months, a lawyer taking the case said.

Headline: What is the process for Britain's Brexit legislation?
Description: The British government needs to pass legislation before it can trigger the formal Article 50 process of leaving the European Union. Below is a summary of the legislative process and the points to look out for.

Headline: UK, U.S. should look at removing trade barriers before Brexit - PM May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday Britain and the United States could look at areas where both could remove some trade barriers to their mutual advantage while she negotiates the country's exit from the EU.

Headline: Redefining a 'special relationship' - Trump and May to talk trade
Description: Trade will dominate the first talks between the new leaders of the United States and Britain this week, with both hoping commitments to a future deal will redefine their 'special relationship' in a new world order.

Headline: UK does not condone torture, says spokesman as May flies to see Trump
Description: Britain does not condone torture or inhumane treatment and its close relationship with the United States allows frank exchanges on areas of disagreement, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: UK government takes first step towards triggering Brexit
Description: Brexit minister David Davis began the process of passing a law that enables the government to trigger Britain's exit from the European Union, saying on Thursday he expected the legislation to pass quickly.

Headline: Britain publishes legislation to approve Brexit trigger
Description: Britain has published the legislation it will use to seek parliamentary approval for triggering the Article 50 legal process for leaving the European Union.

Headline: British astronaut Peake to make second space flight
Description: British astronaut Tim Peake is to return to the International Space Station to carry out more research, the government said on Thursday.

Headline: Article 50 Brexit bill to be published at 1230 GMT - PM's spokesman
Description: The British government's bill seeking authorisation from parliament to start the formal Brexit process by triggering Article 50 of the European Union's Lisbon Treaty will be published at 1230 GMT on Thursday, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said.

Headline: Overseas demand drives further recovery in UK commercial property - RICS
Description: Demand from overseas investors is expected to support British commercial property this year even as the UK prepares to leave the European Union, an industry survey showed on Thursday.

Headline: Factbox - 70 years of the 'special relationship' between the United States and Britain
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will meet new U.S. President Donald Trump in Washington on Friday seeking to reinvigorate what London views as the two countries' "special relationship".

Headline: "Show me the money": divorce first, then trade deal, EU tells UK
Description: Since Prime Minister Theresa May set out her Brexit goals last week, interest in Britain has focused on the future trade deals she may one day strike with the United States and other powers, as well as with the European Union.

Headline: New Sinn Fein leader warns of Irish border control threat
Description: Britain's plans for a "hard Brexit" could lead to customs controls along the Irish border, Sinn Fein's new leader in Northern Ireland said on Wednesday, putting the onus on the government in Dublin to limit the damage.

Headline: Trainspotting author sees 'bleak dystopia' in real life too
Description: The author of "Trainspotting", a grim comedy about young Scottish drug addicts that proved a huge hit in the 1990s and still enjoys cult status, sees "bleak dystopia" in the age of Donald Trump and Britain's Brexit vote.

Headline: UK government to publish Article 50 legislation on Thursday - May's spokeswoman
Description: Britain will publish legislation on Thursday seeking parliament's approval to begin formal divorce talks with the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

Headline: Wear high heels or go home - UK report finds sexist dress codes rife
Description: You must wear shoes with heels 2-4 inches (5-10 cm) high at all times when you are at work. You must wear make-up and regularly re-apply it. You must wear tights, but not opaque ones.

Headline: British police arrest man over abuse directed at Brexit court challenger
Description: British police said on Wednesday they had arrested a man on suspicion of sending racial abuse to the woman who won the court battle that means Prime Minister Theresa May must get parliament's approval before starting the Brexit process.

Headline: PIMCO sees slowing UK economy but worst over for sterling
Description: After a court ruled on Tuesday that the legal process for Brexit cannot be triggered without parliament's approval, sterling portfolio manager Mike Amey of Pacific Investment Management Co (PIMCO) said the British economy was likely to slow in 2017.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon raises independence spectre after court ruling
Description: Nicola Sturgeon raised the spectre of another Scottish independence referendum after Britain's Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that the devolved assembly in Edinburgh did not need to be consulted on triggering Brexit.

Headline: Parliament must vote before UK can trigger Brexit, top court rules
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May must give parliament a vote before she can formally start Britain's exit from the European Union, the UK Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday, giving lawmakers who oppose her Brexit plans a shot at amending them.

Headline: UK to introduce Article 50 legislation 'within days' - Brexit minister
Description: The government will introduce "straightforward" legislation within days seeking parliament's approval to trigger Britain's divorce with the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK public finances data suggest Hammond likely to hit deficit target
Description: LONDON, Jan 24 - Britain cut its budget deficit by slightly less than expected last month but a better than previously thought performance in November could help Chancellor Philip Hammond to hit his target for the current financial year.

Headline: Factbox - Reaction to UK Supreme Court ruling parliament must approve triggering Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May must get parliament's approval before she begins Britain's formal exit from the European Union, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday.

Headline: UK offshore wind costs fall nearly a third in four years – report
Description: The cost of producing electricity from wind farms off the coast of Britain has fallen 32 percent in the past four years, meeting a government target four years early, an industry report released on Tuesday said.

Headline: Britain tells EU: end-March deadline to trigger Brexit will stick - minister
Description: Britain told EU peers it would stick to an end-March deadline to trigger its exit clause from the bloc, a senior EU diplomat said, after Britain's top court ruled that London must seek parliamentary approval before invoking the so-called Article 50.

Headline: Once triggered, UK's formal divorce with EU is irreversible - May's spokesman
Description: Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty is not reversible once it is triggered launching formal divorce talks between Britain and the European Union, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK Court ruling on Brexit will dampen investment - Germany's DIHK
Description: Germany's DIHK Chambers of Commerce said a UK Supreme Court ruling that the British government must get parliament's approval to start an exit from the bloc raised new questions about the way forward and would further dampen investment.

Headline: Article 50 ruling does not change Brexit timetable - spokesman for May
Description: Britain will trigger the legal process for leaving the European Union by the end of March despite a court ruling that means the government needs to get parliamentary approval, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: Brexit plans unlikely to be slowed by Article 50 defeat
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's plans to start the process of Britain leaving the European Union by the end of March are unlikely to be hindered or slowed by Tuesday's Supreme Court ruling the government must seek parliamentary approval.

Headline: UK says will implement court decision for parliament to approve Brexit trigger
Description: Britain's Attorney General Jeremy Wright said the government would implement a UK Supreme Court decision that Prime Minister Theresa May must obtain parliament's approval before she begins Britain's formal exit from the European Union.

Headline: Labour will not frustrate Article 50 trigger, but will seek oversight - spokesman
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party said on Tuesday it would not frustrate the process of triggering Article 50 - the legal process for leaving the European Union - after a court upheld a ruling that parliament must vote on its approval.

Headline: Two Polish brothers jailed in Britain in modern slavery conviction
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Two Polish brothers were jailed under Britain's modern slavery laws for six years each on Monday for stealing wages of around 18 other Poles they tricked with promises of work in the UK, prosecutors said.

Headline: May criticised for handling of Trident test malfunction report
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday she was briefed about the successful certification of a nuclear submarine as she came under increasing pressure over her handling of reports its unarmed Trident missile misfired.

Headline: Britain launches interventionist drive for post-Brexit industrial revival
Description: Britain's government on Monday unveiled a new interventionist approach to rebalance its heavily services-based economy for the post-Brexit era, in a break with traditional Conservative laissez-faire economic policy.

Headline: Overseas demand drives further recovery in UK commercial property - RICS
Description: Demand from overseas investors is expected to support British commercial property this year even as the UK prepares to leave the European Union, an industry survey showed on Thursday.

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will meet new U.S. President Donald Trump in Washington on Friday seeking to reinvigorate what London views as the two countries' "special relationship".

Description: British police said on Wednesday they had arrested a man on suspicion of sending racial abuse to the woman who won the court battle that means Prime Minister Theresa May must get parliament's approval before starting the Brexit process.

Headline: PIMCO sees slowing UK economy but worst over for sterling
Description: After a court ruled on Tuesday that the legal process for Brexit cannot be triggered without parliament's approval, sterling portfolio manager Mike Amey of Pacific Investment Management Co (PIMCO) said the British economy was likely to slow in 2017.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon raises independence spectre after court ruling
Description: Nicola Sturgeon raised the spectre of another Scottish independence referendum after Britain's Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that the devolved assembly in Edinburgh did not need to be consulted on triggering Brexit.

Headline: Parliament must vote before UK can trigger Brexit, top court rules
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May must give parliament a vote before she can formally start Britain's exit from the European Union, the UK Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday, giving lawmakers who oppose her Brexit plans a shot at amending them.

Headline: UK to introduce Article 50 legislation 'within days' - Brexit minister
Description: The government will introduce "straightforward" legislation within days seeking parliament's approval to trigger Britain's divorce with the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK public finances data suggest Hammond likely to hit deficit target
Description: LONDON, Jan 24 - Britain cut its budget deficit by slightly less than expected last month but a better than previously thought performance in November could help Chancellor Philip Hammond to hit his target for the current financial year.

Headline: Factbox - Reaction to UK Supreme Court ruling parliament must approve triggering Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May must get parliament's approval before she begins Britain's formal exit from the European Union, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday.

Headline: UK offshore wind costs fall nearly a third in four years – report
Description: The cost of producing electricity from wind farms off the coast of Britain has fallen 32 percent in the past four years, meeting a government target four years early, an industry report released on Tuesday said.

Headline: Britain tells EU: end-March deadline to trigger Brexit will stick - minister
Description: Britain told EU peers it would stick to an end-March deadline to trigger its exit clause from the bloc, a senior EU diplomat said, after Britain's top court ruled that London must seek parliamentary approval before invoking the so-called Article 50.

Headline: Once triggered, UK's formal divorce with EU is irreversible - May's spokesman
Description: Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty is not reversible once it is triggered launching formal divorce talks between Britain and the European Union, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK Court ruling on Brexit will dampen investment - Germany's DIHK
Description: Germany's DIHK Chambers of Commerce said a UK Supreme Court ruling that the British government must get parliament's approval to start an exit from the bloc raised new questions about the way forward and would further dampen investment.

Headline: Article 50 ruling does not change Brexit timetable - spokesman for May
Description: Britain will trigger the legal process for leaving the European Union by the end of March despite a court ruling that means the government needs to get parliamentary approval, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: Brexit plans unlikely to be slowed by Article 50 defeat
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's plans to start the process of Britain leaving the European Union by the end of March are unlikely to be hindered or slowed by Tuesday's Supreme Court ruling the government must seek parliamentary approval.

Headline: Northern Irish children suffered decades of cruel abuse - report
Description: Children in Northern Ireland suffered decades of cruel sexual, physical and emotional abuse in institutions run by the state, charities and the Catholic and Protestant churches, an official report said on Friday.

Headline: National Grid warns of costs if Britain exits EU energy market
Description: Taking Britain out of Europe's energy market could stymie development of new power links designed to help avert a looming supply crunch and also drive up the cost of imported European electricity, National Grid warned on Friday.

Headline: Northern Ireland's Sinn Fein to name successor to McGuinness on Monday
Description: Sinn Fein will name a successor to Martin McGuinness on Monday to lead the Irish nationalist party into Northern Irish elections in March, its president Gerry Adams said on Friday.

Headline: 'Open question' if post-Brexit UK will favour EU migrants - Hammond
Description: British Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Friday it was an "open question" whether migrants from the European Union would enjoy easier access to Britain after Brexit than those from other parts of the world.

Headline: Trump bigger uncertainty for EU than Brexit, says Hammond
Description: Donald Trump's presidency is likely to create bigger uncertainty for the European Union than Britain's decision to leave the bloc, Britain's finance minister Philip Hammond said on Friday.

Headline: Scotland will vote for independence in two years - Salmond
Description: Scotland will vote to become independent within two years due to the hardline position being taken by British Prime Minister Theresa May over Brexit, former Scottish first minister Alex Salmond said on Friday.

Headline: Johnson to visit Myanmar, says democratic transition not yet complete
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, who will visit Myanmar on Friday, said the former British colony's transition to democracy was not yet complete but that Britain would offer its full support as a friend.

Headline: UK spent 168 million pounds on failed carbon capture initiatives - watchdog
Description: Britain spent 168 million pounds on two failed initiatives to help to fund carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology, a parliamentary watchdog said on Friday.

Headline: No rush for secession in Scotland as Brexit creates new fears
Description: The Brexit vote has made a new referendum on Scottish independence more likely, says First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, but despite Scots' misgivings about leaving the European Union there is no sign of increased enthusiasm for secession.

Headline: Illness forces Northern Ireland's McGuinness to quit politics
Description: Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness, a key figure throughout five decades of conflict and peace in Northern Ireland, said on Thursday he was bowing out of politics and would not lead his  nationalist party into elections in March.

Headline: UK scientists give cancer risk warning on overdone chips, toast
Description: Potatoes and bread cooked at high temperatures for a long time could increase the risk of cancer in people who eat them regularly, British government scientists said on Monday.

Headline: British-Iranian aid worker sentenced to jail for 'cooperation with BBC' - family
Description: The family of British-Iranian aid worker Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who has been sentenced to five years in jail in Iran on undisclosed charges, said she has been accused by a Revolutionary Court of acting against national security by cooperating with the BBC.

Headline: UK launches industry strategy to counter any Brexit turbulence
Description: Britain published the outline of its industrial strategy on Monday, putting forward proposals for a more hands-on approach to developing key industries as a way to protect the economy from any turbulence caused by leaving the European Union.

Headline: Factbox - The legal challenge over who can trigger Britain's exit talks from EU
Description: The UK Supreme Court will rule on Tuesday whether British Prime Minister Theresa May can trigger Britain's exit from the European Union without seeking prior approval from parliament.

Headline: Factbox - The 10 pillars of Britain's Modern Industrial Strategy
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has set out the first details of a 'Modern Industrial Strategy' designed to adapt the economy for a post-Brexit era and revitalise areas of the country left behind by a decades long decline in manufacturing.

Headline: British-Iranian aid worker's five-year jail term upheld in Iran
Description: An Iranian appeals court has confirmed a five-year jail sentence for British-Iranian aid worker Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe on security charges, Iran's judiciary spokesman said on Sunday.

Headline: May promises frank talk with Trump after women protest
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May promised on Sunday to challenge any "unacceptable" talk when she meets President Donald Trump later this week, as she tries to secure Britain's "special relationship" with the new U.S. administration.

Headline: May faces pressure after reports of Trident test malfunction
Description: A test firing of an unarmed British nuclear Trident missile from a submarine malfunctioned last June, the Sunday Times reported, prompting questions about why Prime Minister Theresa May did not tell parliament ahead of a vote on renewing the submarines.

Headline: Trump plans to meet with May, Mexico's Pena Nieto - White House
Description: U.S. President Donald Trump is arranging to meet soon with British Prime Minister Theresa May and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto, two long-standing U.S. allies concerned about how his presidency will affect their relationships with Washington.

Headline: Women protest against Trump on streets of Europe's capitals
Description: Thousands of women took to the streets of European capitals to join "sister marches" in Asia against newly installed U.S. President Trump ahead of a major rally in Washington expected to draw nearly a quarter of a million people.

Headline: New leader of UKIP party to stand for parliament
Description: Paul Nuttall, who succeeded Nigel Farage in November as leader of Britain's anti-EU UKIP party, said on Saturday he would stand for parliament in an election next month shaping up to be a big test for the Labour party.

Headline: British protesters tell Trump from Tower Bridge: "Build bridges not walls"
Description: A banner reading "Build bridges not walls" was draped across London's Tower Bridge as part of several protests in Europe and Asia on Friday against the inauguration of Donald Trump as U.S. president.

Headline: Republicans in London celebrate Trump's inauguration
Description: Under the gaze of a life-sized cardboard figure of Donald Trump, some 200 of his supporters gathered at an exclusive club near the Ritz hotel in London to celebrate Friday's inauguration of America's 45th president.

Headline: Fox News signs Brexit leader Nigel Farage as contributor
Description: Nigel Farage, who led the campaign for Britain to leave the European Union, will be a political analyst on Fox News and Fox Business Network, Fox News said on Friday.

Headline: British worker dies in Qatar World Cup stadium
Description: A British man has died while working on the construction of a stadium for the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, authorities said.

Headline: Northern Irish children suffered decades of cruel abuse - report
Description: Children in Northern Ireland suffered decades of cruel sexual, physical and emotional abuse in institutions run by the state, charities and the Catholic and Protestant churches, an official report said on Friday.

Headline: National Grid warns of costs if Britain exits EU energy market
Description: Taking Britain out of Europe's energy market could stymie development of new power links designed to help avert a looming supply crunch and also drive up the cost of imported European electricity, National Grid warned on Friday.

Headline: Northern Ireland's Sinn Fein to name successor to McGuinness on Monday
Description: Sinn Fein will name a successor to Martin McGuinness on Monday to lead the Irish nationalist party into Northern Irish elections in March, its president Gerry Adams said on Friday.

Headline: 'Open question' if post-Brexit UK will favour EU migrants - Hammond
Description: British Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Friday it was an "open question" whether migrants from the European Union would enjoy easier access to Britain after Brexit than those from other parts of the world.

Headline: Trump bigger uncertainty for EU than Brexit, says Hammond
Description: Donald Trump's presidency is likely to create bigger uncertainty for the European Union than Britain's decision to leave the bloc, Britain's finance minister Philip Hammond said on Friday.

Headline: EU's Juncker says wants 'balanced solution' in Brexit negotiations
Description: EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said on Wednesday he would seek a balanced deal for Britain and the European Union during London's exit negotiations.

Headline: UK receives positive responses from Brussels on leaving plan - Brexit minister
Description: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis said the government had received positive responses from Brussels after Prime Minister Theresa May set out her priorities for upcoming negotiations on leaving the European Union.

Headline: France's Hollande told May expects quick start of Brexit negotiations - source
Description: French President Francois Hollande told British Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday that negotiations over Britain's exit from the European Union should begin as soon as Britain invokes Article 50, a presidential sources said.

Headline: Europeans ask May: Where is the give for all this take?
Description: European leaders applauded Theresa May for providing clarity by finally outlining her plan for a clean break with the EU, but said she needed to be realistic about the price Britain would pay for leaving.

Headline: British advertising budgets seen up 2.1 percent in 2016, to fall in 2017 - survey
Description: British companies spent 2.1 percent more on advertising last year, according to an industry forecast, after a strong fourth quarter, although spending on advertising is set to fall 0.7 percent in 2017 as Brexit uncertainties weigh.

Headline: Britain to leave EU market as May sets 'hard Brexit' course
Description: Britain will quit the EU single market when it leaves the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday in a decisive speech that set a course for a clean break with the world's largest trading bloc.

Headline: Popular British TV drama to feature female genital mutilation plotline
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Popular British period drama "Call the Midwife" is to feature female genital mutilation (FGM) in a storyline about a pregnant Somali woman living in east London in the 1960s.

Headline: Scotland must have choice on independence if Brexit wishes ignored-Sturgeon
Description: The British government's plan for leaving the European Union is "economically catastrophic" and Scotland must have the option of voting for independence if its views on Brexit are rejected, Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Tuesday.

Headline: BMW, UK car industry say Britain needs to keep tariff-free EU trade
Description: Britain should retain tariff-free access to the European Union's single market, Germany's BMW  said on Tuesday, while a UK car industry body called for participation in the EU's customs union to hold onto trade after Brexit.

Headline: European Parliament negotiator warns Britain's May against Brexit 'illusion'
Description: The European Parliament's Brexit negotiator said on Tuesday it was an "illusion" to think that Britain could enjoy the advantages of the European Union's single market without accepting the obligations that come with it.

Headline: UK minister: No decision yet on best Brexit financial services deal
Description: Britain has yet to reach a decision on the arrangements it will seek for the financial services industry once it leaves the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis told parliament on Tuesday.

Headline: Some unskilled migration to UK likely to continue after Brexit - minister
Description: Britain will still accept some unskilled migration after it leaves the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: Rejection of Brexit deal by parliament won't stop EU exit - minister
Description: Britain will still leave the European Union even if parliament votes against the final terms of the deal, Brexit minister David Davis told parliament on Tuesday.

Headline: Highlights - British PM May sets out plans for Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May set out the principles that will guide her approach to Britain's withdrawal from the European Union in a speech in London on Tuesday.

Headline: David Davis says not seeking to cherry-pick bits of EU membership
Description: Britain's approach to leaving the European Union is not about cherry-picking, Brexit minister David Davis told parliament on Tuesday after Prime Minister Theresa May set out her priorities for upcoming negotiations.

Headline: Instant view - Reaction to Brexit speech by PM Theresa May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday Britain could not remain a member of the EU single market after leaving the European Union, but would seek an agreement to allow for the freest possible trade in goods and services.

Headline: Sterling on course for best day since 2008 after May speech
Description: Sterling saw its biggest gains since the 2008 financial crisis on Tuesday as Prime Minister Theresa May promised a parliamentary vote on Britain's deal to leave the EU and said it would seek to stay a key European partner.

Headline: Factbox - Britain's Brexit negotiation objectives
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has set out the principles that will guide her approach to Britain's withdrawal from the European Union and defined 12 negotiating objectives.

Headline: May says wants to avoid Brexit 'cliff edge' for business
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday she wanted to avoid a "disruptive cliff edge" for businesses when Britain leaves the European Union and she backed a phasing-in of changes in immigration, customs and regulation in areas such as financial services.

Headline: No Brexit deal better than 'bad deal', May says
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that not reaching a deal with the European Union would be better than concluding a bad exit deal for Britain and warned leaders of the 27 other members not to try to punish Britons for voting to leave.

Headline: May says Britain wants to keep tariff-free trade with EU
Description: Britain cannot remain a full member of the EU customs union but will seek tariff-free trade with the bloc after Brexit, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: May says no 'half in, half out' Brexit deal for UK
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that Britain would not seek a deal that left the country "half in, half out" of the European Union when it negotiates its exit from the bloc.

Headline: PM May says her plans mean Britain cannot remain in EU single market
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said her plans for Britain's exit from the European Union mean that it could no longer remain in the single market but she would seek a deal that would take in some aspects of membership.

Headline: Drivers on UK Southern rail suspend next week's strike action - TUC
Description: Drivers working for Britain's Southern Rail have agreed to suspend strike action next week which would have brought the network to a standstill once again, the Trades Union Congress (TUC) said on Tuesday.

Headline: Factbox - British PM May whittles down Brexit trade options
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will set out in more detail on Tuesday her priorities for Brexit negotiations, saying Britain will seek a new partnership rather than adopting any of the existing models used by other countries.

Headline: Brexit talks will take five years, Austrian finance minister says
Description: It will take five years for Britain to fully negotiate its secession from the European Union, rather than the two years more often cited, Austrian Finance Minister Hans Joerg Schelling said on Tuesday.

Headline: France's Sapin says UK government seems to be "improvising" on Brexit
Description: The British government was not prepared for taking Britain out of the European Union and now appears to be improvising on its Brexit policy, French Finance Minister Michel Sapin said on Tuesday.

Headline: Hard Brexit fears hit pound ahead of May speech
Description: Britain's pound fell on Monday as concern rose that the country is heading for a "hard" Brexit from the European Union and its single market, a day before a speech by Prime Minister Theresa May on the government's plans.

Headline: Northern Ireland sets March 2 election after government collapse
Description: Britain's Northern Ireland minister called an early election on Monday for March 2 following the collapse of the region's power-sharing government that risks a lengthy period of political paralysis just as Britain prepares for talks to leave the EU.

Headline: Asked about sterling fall, BoE's Carney says it moves up and down
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney declined on Monday to say if the central bank would respond to the sharp fall in the pound, saying only that the value of sterling goes up and down.

Headline: UK to test Fiat Chrysler Jeep model after U.S. emission accusations
Description: Britain said on Monday it will carry out tests on the Jeep Grand Cherokee model following U.S. accusations carmaker Fiat Chrysler Automobiles  mislead regulators on diesel car emissions.

Headline: Trump says Brexit to be 'a great thing', wants quick trade deal with UK
Description: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump said that Brexit would turn out to be a great thing and other countries would follow Britain out of the European Union but promised to strike a swift bilateral trade deal with the United Kingdom.

Headline: Merkel, responding to Trump, says Europe's fate is in its own hands
Description: Europe's destiny lies in its own hands, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Monday in response to comments from U.S. President-elect Donald Trump, who said in a newspaper interview he believed other countries would leave the EU after Britain.

Headline: Tunisian beach gunman 'walked nearly two miles' before being shot, UK inquest hears
Description: The gunman who murdered 30 Britons on a Tunisian beach in 2015 had been able to walk nearly two miles on his killing spree before being shot dead by security forces, inquests into the deaths heard on Monday.

Headline: Are fathers getting a raw deal in the workplace, UK inquiry asks
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - With more British men wanting to take an active role in raising their children, are workplaces preventing fathers from spending more time at home, asks an inquiry launched on Monday, with men's rights groups calling for a "childcare revolution".

Headline: May welcomes Trump commitment to U.S.-UK trade deal - spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May welcomes U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's commitment to working on a trade deal with Britain, her spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: May to appear in April edition of U.S. Vogue
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is to appear in the April edition of U.S. fashion magazine Vogue, her office said.

Headline: May calls Northern Ireland leaders to urge last-ditch political solution
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May made a last-ditch attempt to get Northern Irish leaders to solve a political impasse, stressing that political stability would give the province a stronger voice in Britain's Brexit preparation, her spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: May agrees on changing economic model post-Brexit if forced - spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May shares her Chancellor's view that Britain stands ready to consider alternative economic models following Brexit if forced to, her spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: May's spokeswoman says talk of hard Brexit is 'speculation'
Description: Media reports that Prime Minister Theresa May will unveil plans for a "hard" Brexit in a speech this week are "speculation", her spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: Instant view - Reaction to Brexit speech by PM Theresa May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday Britain could not remain a member of the EU single market after leaving the European Union, but would seek an agreement to allow for the freest possible trade in goods and services.

Description: Sterling saw its biggest gains since the 2008 financial crisis on Tuesday as Prime Minister Theresa May promised a parliamentary vote on Britain's deal to leave the EU and said it would seek to stay a key European partner.

Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that Britain would not seek a deal that left the country "half in, half out" of the European Union when it negotiates its exit from the bloc.

Description: Drivers working for Britain's Southern Rail have agreed to suspend strike action next week which would have brought the network to a standstill once again, the Trades Union Congress (TUC) said on Tuesday.

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will set out in more detail on Tuesday her priorities for Brexit negotiations, saying Britain will seek a new partnership rather than adopting any of the existing models used by other countries.

Description: It will take five years for Britain to fully negotiate its secession from the European Union, rather than the two years more often cited, Austrian Finance Minister Hans Joerg Schelling said on Tuesday.

Description: The British government was not prepared for taking Britain out of the European Union and now appears to be improvising on its Brexit policy, French Finance Minister Michel Sapin said on Tuesday.

Headline: Hard Brexit fears hit pound ahead of May speech
Description: Britain's pound fell on Monday as concern rose that the country is heading for a "hard" Brexit from the European Union and its single market, a day before a speech by Prime Minister Theresa May on the government's plans.

Headline: Northern Ireland sets March 2 election after government collapse
Description: Britain's Northern Ireland minister called an early election on Monday for March 2 following the collapse of the region's power-sharing government that risks a lengthy period of political paralysis just as Britain prepares for talks to leave the EU.

Headline: Asked about sterling fall, BoE's Carney says it moves up and down
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney declined on Monday to say if the central bank would respond to the sharp fall in the pound, saying only that the value of sterling goes up and down.

Headline: UK to test Fiat Chrysler Jeep model after U.S. emission accusations
Description: Britain said on Monday it will carry out tests on the Jeep Grand Cherokee model following U.S. accusations carmaker Fiat Chrysler Automobiles  mislead regulators on diesel car emissions.

Headline: Trump says Brexit to be 'a great thing', wants quick trade deal with UK
Description: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump said that Brexit would turn out to be a great thing and other countries would follow Britain out of the European Union but promised to strike a swift bilateral trade deal with the United Kingdom.
