Description: Europe's destiny lies in its own hands, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Monday in response to comments from U.S. President-elect Donald Trump, who said in a newspaper interview he believed other countries would leave the EU after Britain.

Headline: Tunisian beach gunman 'walked nearly two miles' before being shot, UK inquest hears
Description: The gunman who murdered 30 Britons on a Tunisian beach in 2015 had been able to walk nearly two miles on his killing spree before being shot dead by security forces, inquests into the deaths heard on Monday.

Headline: Are fathers getting a raw deal in the workplace, UK inquiry asks
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - With more British men wanting to take an active role in raising their children, are workplaces preventing fathers from spending more time at home, asks an inquiry launched on Monday, with men's rights groups calling for a "childcare revolution".

Headline: London Mayor Khan - Britain heading for 'muddled Brexit'
Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan will say on Thursday that urgent action is needed to prevent Britain slipping towards a "muddled Brexit", arguing that the capital needs more control over its economic policy to cope with leaving the European Union.

Headline: Northern Ireland political crisis could delay May's Brexit plans - lawyer
Description: Britain's plan to trigger Brexit talks by the end of March could be delayed by a political crisis in Northern Ireland if the British Supreme Court rules that Belfast's regional assembly must approve an EU exit, a lawyer for a Brexit challenger said.

Headline: BoE's Carney - curbing consumer lending would be 'big call'
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said it would be a "big call" for the central bank to rein in rapid growth in consumer lending, which picked up strongly last year and brought some echoes of the period before the global financial crisis.

Headline: May distances herself from immigration skills levy row
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May distanced herself on Wednesday from remarks by a junior minister who had suggested Britain was considering introducing an annual 1,000-pound "immigration skills charge" after Brexit on every skilled worker from an EU member state recruited by a British employer.

Headline: Teenage girl appears in UK court charged with murder of seven-year-old girl
Description: A 15-year-old girl appeared in court on Wednesday accused of murdering a 7-year-old girl in the northern English town of York, a case that shocked the nation and drew expressions of sympathy in parliament.

Headline: UK levy on skilled EU workers is not on agenda - May's spokeswoman
Description: The idea of introducing an annual 1,000-pound immigration skills charge after Brexit on every skilled worker from the EU is not on the government's agenda, a spokeswoman for British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK government expects to lose Brexit trigger case, making contingency plans - report
Description: The British government expects to lose its legal battle to start the Brexit process without going through parliament, and has drafted versions of a bill to put to lawmakers after the ruling, the Guardian newspaper reported on Tuesday.

Headline: May, Ireland's Kenny discuss 'seriousness' of Northern Ireland political crisis
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May and her Irish counterpart Enda Kenny recognised the difficulties and seriousness of the situation in Northern Ireland during a phone call on the political crisis there, May's office said on Wednesday.

Headline: Cracks exposed at heart of Northern Irish peace by 'cash-for-ash' scandal
Description: After a decade of bitter compromises over paramilitaries and policing, Northern Ireland's power-sharing government finally fell apart this week over the abuse by farmers of a green-energy grant to burn fuels such as wood pellets instead of coal.

Headline: Targeting Brexit voters, Labour vows to manage migration
Description: Britain's main opposition Labour Party backs "the reasonable management of migration", its leader said on Tuesday in a speech aimed at winning back millions of traditional supporters who backed Britain's split from the European Union.

Headline: Britain picks ex-BoE deputy governor Clementi as new BBC chair
Description: An ex-Bank of England deputy governor is the British government's choice to be the new chair of the BBC, culture minister Karen Bradley said on Tuesday, as the state-owned broadcaster's structure is overhauled.

Headline: Question of post-Brexit single market membership is for negotiations - UK minister
Description: The extent of Britain's future membership of the European Union's single market will be determined in upcoming Brexit negotiations with the bloc, a junior minister in Britain's Brexit department said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK court to hear challenge over access to single market next week
Description: A legal challenge to the government over whether Britain's exit from the European Union will automatically take it out of the single market will be heard in court next week, the group that initiated the action said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK to start approval process for Chinese nuclear reactor at Bradwell
Description: The British government has asked nuclear regulators to start the process for approving a Chinese-designed reactor for a proposed plant in Britain, expected to be one of the first new plants in decades.

Headline: Strike brings more rail misery for London commuters
Description: Hundreds of thousands of London commuters were left with no train service on Tuesday as the latest strike in Britain's worst rail dispute in decades brought more travel misery the day after major disruption on the capital's underground system.

Headline: London commuters endure transport misery as rail staff strike
Description: Millions of Londoners struggled to work on Monday at the start of a week of travel chaos which sees rail networks brought to a standstill by a series of strikes.

Headline: Lobby says City of London should be priority in EU divorce talks
Description: Britain's financial services sector must keep its unfettered access to the European Union's single market after Brexit given that available alternatives don't provide a sustainable long-term solution, an industry report said on Tuesday.

Headline: Hard Brexit is not inevitable, says May
Description: A clean break with the EU's single market is not inevitable, British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday, seeking to clarify comments that pushed down the pound on the possibility of a hard Brexit from the European Union.

Headline: Merkel says no 'cherry picking' for Britain in Brexit talks
Description: The European Union must consider limiting Britain's access to its market if London fails to accept the bloc's 'four freedoms' in Brexit negotiations, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Monday.

Headline: Northern Ireland faces elections as deputy leader McGuinness quits
Description: Northern Ireland's deputy leader, Martin McGuinness, resigned on Monday in protest at First Minister Arlene Foster's handling of a controversial green-energy scheme, a move likely to trigger an election in the British province.

Headline: More women lawmakers needed in UK as numbers 'shockingly low' - report
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - The number of women parliamentarians in Britain is "shockingly low" and the government should set targets to achieve equal representation by 2030, British lawmakers said in a report on Tuesday.

Headline: Watchdog urges greater protection of UK transgender prisoners as deaths climb
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Transgender prisoners in Britain need more support and greater protection from bullying and harassment, a government watchdog said on Tuesday, more than a week after a transgender woman was found dead in her cell.

Headline: More Britons want greater control of immigration than EU free trade - poll
Description: Greater control of immigration is more important for Britons than access to free trade with the European Union during negotiations for the UK's departure from the bloc, according to a poll on Monday.

Headline: May rules nothing in or out in Brexit talks - spokeswoman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is ruling nothing in or out before starting departure talks with the European Union and wants the best deal for businesses to trade with the single market, her spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: Hard Irish border likely in hard Brexit, EU's Hogan says - report
Description: The return of a "hard border" between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic looks inevitable if Britain leaves the European Union's single market, Ireland's European Union Commissioner, farm chief Phil Hogan, was quoted as saying on Monday.

Headline: British government no longer top Lloyds shareholder
Description: The British government is no longer top shareholder in Lloyds Banking Group after reducing its stake to below 6 percent as it aims to return the lender to full private ownership this year.

Headline: Queen Elizabeth makes first appearance after heavy cold
Description: Britain's Queen Elizabeth made her first public appearance since before Christmas on Sunday as she recovered from a heavy cold that caused the 90-year-old monarch to miss Christmas and New Year church services.

Headline: Britain's health service in a 'humanitarian crisis' -  Red Cross
Description: Britain's health service is engulfed in a "humanitarian crisis" that requires the support of the Red Cross to use Land Rovers to transport patients, the charity said on Saturday.

Headline: UK eyeing customs union access, work visas for some sectors - report
Description: Britain is looking to secure privileged EU customs union access, work visas and tax breaks for certain sectors as part of a plan to protect key industries when it exits the European Union, the Sunday Times newspaper reported.

Headline: Donor to PM May's party says to cut funds if single market access lost
Description: A leading donor to Theresa May's Conservative Party warned on Saturday he would cut his financial support if the government pulled Britain out of the European single market as part of Brexit negotiations.

Headline: Scotland says could put secession on hold if UK avoids 'hard Brexit'
Description: Scotland could suspend its drive to become independent if Britain avoids a "hard Brexit" in which it loses access to the European Union's single market, the head of its secessionist government said on Friday.

Headline: London tube strike set to cause commuter chaos on Monday
Description: A 24-hour strike by rail workers is set to close most underground stations in central London on Monday, transport bosses said, causing travel chaos for millions of commuters.

Headline: Maximum jail-time for stalkers to double - Ministry of Justice
Description: Britain is to introduce new measures to protect victims of stalking and harassment, including a doubling of some jail sentences for what Justice Minister Sam Gyimah called "these awful crimes."

Headline: Money can't buy single market access, ex-British EU official warns
Description: Britain will not be able to buy access to the single market following its exit from the EU, a former top UK official at European Commission warned, casting doubt on mooted government plans for Britain's future relationship with the bloc.

Headline: May to meet Trump in Washington in spring - PM's office
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will meet with Donald Trump in Washington in the spring, a representative said, in the first visit with the new president by the leader of one of the United States' closest allies.

Headline: May taps career diplomat to replace EU envoy after scathing resignation
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May appointed a senior career diplomat as envoy to the European Union on Wednesday to replace an ambassador who quit with a scathing resignation letter that exposed frustration among officials over her strategy.

Headline: Factbox - Senior British officials with EU experience who have left their posts
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has appointed a senior career diplomat as her envoy to the European Union, replacing an official who criticised the government's Brexit strategy in his resignation letter.

Headline: Southern rail strike next week cut short but union adds more dates
Description: Train drivers on Britain's Southern rail commuter network have cut a planned six-day strike on one of London's main commuter networks next week but added more stoppages later in January.

Headline: UK government seeks to assuage Brexit concerns of farmers
Description: Britain's farmers said on Wednesday their main concerns as the nation prepares to leave the European Union are how much access they will have to the EU's single market and its skilled farm workers.

Headline: Britain's top EU diplomat quits with blistering attack over Brexit
Description: Britain's top diplomat at the EU quit his post with a blistering attack on the government, giving voice to what several sources say is wider frustration among officials over Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit strategy.

Headline: Queen Elizabeth resumes duties as she recovers from cold
Description: Queen Elizabeth has given an honour to a member of her staff in a private ceremony, resuming official duties as she continued to recover from a heavy cold that forced her to miss Christmas and New Year church services, a spokeswoman said.

Headline: Hammond meeting Gulf leaders this week - finance ministry
Description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond will meet with political leaders and finance officials from the Gulf states this week as part of the country's drive to promote trade ahead of its exit from the European Union.

Headline: Text - Britain's EU envoy deplores "muddled thinking" in resignation letter
Description: Below are the key excerpts from the resignation letter of Britain's ambassador to the European Union, Ivan Rogers, less than three months before London triggers complex talks on Britain's exit from the bloc.

Headline: Royal Kate given photographic society's seal of approval
Description: Britain's Duchess of Cambridge, whose pictures of her children Prince George and Princess Charlotte have graced the front pages of newspapers and magazines worldwide, was commended on Tuesday by the Royal Photographic Society for her family snapshots.

Headline: China begins first freight train service to London - Xinhua
Description: China has begun its first freight train service to London from Yiwu, a famed wholesale market town in the eastern province of Zhejiang, the Xinhua news agency reported.

Headline: Labour 'too weak' to win an election - think tank
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party is too weak to win a national election and should look to form an alliance with other smaller parties in order to have a chance of regaining power, a Labour-supporting think tank said on Tuesday.

Headline: Man dies in police shooting incident in northern England
Description: A man has died after being shot by police during an operation in northern England, West Yorkshire Police said on Tuesday, later confirming the incident was not terrorism-linked.

Headline: Britain to build 17 towns and villages to ease housing squeeze
Description: Britain's government announced plans on Monday to build 17 new towns and villages across the English countryside in a bid to ease a chronic housing shortage.

Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May pledged in a New Year message on Sunday to seek a Brexit deal that would work for all Britons, not just those who voted to leave the European Union in a referendum she said had laid bare the nation's divisions.

Description: The leader of Britain's opposition Labour party, Jeremy Corbyn, could step down before the next national election in 2020 if its poor opinion poll ratings do not improve, the head of its biggest union backer said in an interview published on Monday.

Headline: British government no longer top Lloyds shareholder
Description: The British government is no longer top shareholder in Lloyds Banking Group after reducing its stake to below 6 percent as it aims to return the lender to full private ownership this year.

Description: Britain will not be able to buy access to the single market following its exit from the EU, a former top UK official at European Commission warned, casting doubt on mooted government plans for Britain's future relationship with the bloc.

Headline: May to meet Trump in Washington in spring - PM's office
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will meet with Donald Trump in Washington in the spring, a representative said, in the first visit with the new president by the leader of one of the United States' closest allies.

Headline: The Queen starts Christmas holiday after illness delay
Description: Queen Elizabeth, 90, and her husband Prince Philip, 95, left Buckingham Palace by helicopter on Thursday, going ahead with their Christmas travel plans following a day's delay because both were suffering from heavy colds.

Headline: Prince Charles says populism risks return to 'horrors of the past'
Description: Prince Charles said on Thursday the rise of populist groups across the world had deeply disturbing echoes of the fascism of the 1930s, and warned against a repeat of the "horrors of the past" to prevent religious persecution.

Headline: Nigerian former state governor Ibori released from British jail
Description: James Ibori, who as governor of oil-producing Delta State became one of Nigeria's richest and most powerful men, has been released from a British jail after serving a sentence for graft and now faces a fight over his assets before he can go home.

Headline: Britain to fund broadband for extra 600,000 rural homes
Description: Britain will spend 440 million pounds to roll out superfast broadband to 600,000 extra homes and businesses in rural areas that suffer from poor coverage, the government said on Thursday.

Headline: Headaches, insects and yachts; excuses for not filing British tax returns
Description: "My tax return was on my yacht ... which caught fire" - just one of the dozens of unusual excuses the British government's tax collector said it receives each year from customers who fail to complete their returns on time.

Headline: UK prepares tighter laws on drones after air safety scares
Description: The British government is preparing to tighten drone regulations after a series of near-misses with passenger planes over the last two years and growing concern about their use near prisons.

Headline: The Queen and Prince Philip suffering heavy colds; delay travel
Description: Queen Elizabeth, 90, and her husband Prince Philip, 95, delayed their Christmas travel plans on Wednesday because they are both suffering from heavy colds, Buckingham Palace said.

Headline: Brexit threatens 10 percent of London financial jobs - lobby group
Description: Up to 10 percent of jobs in London's financial district may be lost if Britain fails to secure adequate access to European Union markets after Brexit, a City of London official said on Wednesday.

Headline: Police to close some roads around Buckingham Palace after Berlin attack
Description: British police said they would temporarily close roads around Queen Elizabeth's London residence Buckingham Palace during a military ceremony on Wednesday, bringing forward plans to do so in response to a truck attack in Berlin.

Description: Britons' long-term expectations for inflation hit a more than two-year high this month, as consumers braced for a bout of higher prices after the pound's post-Brexit vote fall, a survey showed on Wednesday.

Headline: Argentina, Britain agree to identify bodies of soldiers on Falklands
Description: Argentina and Britain agreed on a framework to identify the bodies of dozens of unknown Argentine soldiers buried on the disputed Falkland Islands, Argentina's Foreign Ministry said in on Tuesday.

Headline: UK airport baggage-handlers cancel planned Christmas strike
Description: A strike planned for Dec. 23 and 24 by over 1,500 baggage-handlers, check-in staff and cargo crew at airports across Britain has been cancelled, the Unite union said on Tuesday.

Headline: The Queen eases her workload - slightly
Description: Queen Elizabeth will step down as patron from a number of national organisations in the coming months after she turned 90 in April, Buckingham Palace said in a statement on Tuesday.

Headline: May to outline more of her Brexit approach in early 2017
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday she would outline more of her approach for Brexit early next year, underlining that her government did not intend to select "bits" of EU membership but forge a new relationship.

Headline: May moots "implementation phase" after Brexit deal
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May raised the prospect of an "implementation phase" for Britain to put into place its new relationship with the European Union.

Headline: Britain sets 2017 Spring budget date for March 8
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said on Tuesday the government will publish its next Spring Budget on Wednesday 8 March 2017.

Headline: Britain can't pick bits of EU membership, needs new relationship - May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that Britain must forge a brand new relationship with the European Union, rather than trying to choose parts of its current membership it would like to keep.

Headline: May will carefully consider Scottish Brexit proposals
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will carefully consider proposals for Brexit put forward on Tuesday by Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, May's spokesman said.

Headline: London police say they are reviewing security plans after Berlin, Ankara attacks
Description: London police said on Tuesday they are reviewing their plans for protecting public events over the festive period after Russia's ambassador was killed in Ankara and a truck ploughed into people at a Christmas market in Berlin.

Description: In a satire of the 2016 Brexit vote, mashup artists lampoon Britain's leaders in a video which re-edits their words to say the European Union referendum was dumb and Prime Minister Theresa May is making a mess of Brexit.

Description: Queen Elizabeth, 90, missed a traditional Christmas church service on Sunday for the first time in decades due to a heavy cold, a Buckingham Palace spokesman said.

Headline: Homelessness on the rise, says British charity as Christmas shelters open
Description: More than 4,000 homeless people in Britain are expected to use temporary shelters set up over Christmas by charity Crisis, which said the number of people sleeping rough was rising sharply.

Description: Britain's decision to leave the European Union is an opportunity to reform the bloc, giving more say to national governments and less to Brussels institutions, Poland's eurosceptic leader Jaroslaw Kaczynski said.

Headline: The Queen starts Christmas holiday after illness delay
Description: Queen Elizabeth, 90, and her husband Prince Philip, 95, left Buckingham Palace by helicopter on Thursday, going ahead with their Christmas travel plans following a day's delay because both were suffering from heavy colds.

Description: "My tax return was on my yacht ... which caught fire" - just one of the dozens of unusual excuses the British government's tax collector said it receives each year from customers who fail to complete their returns on time.

Description: A neo-Nazi organisation that praised the murderer of lawmaker Jo Cox has become the first far-right group in Britain to be banned as a terrorist organization, the Home Office said on Friday.

Headline: Child sex-abuser, 101, becomes UK's oldest convict
Description: A 101-year-old man became the oldest Briton ever to be convicted of a criminal offence when he was found guilty on Friday of a string of historical sex crimes against young girls.

Headline: Actavis UK raised drug prices 12,000 percent, watchdog finds
Description: Drug maker Actavis UK broke competition law by raising prices of hydrocortisone tablets by more than 12,000 percent, Britain's competition watchdog said in a provisional ruling on Friday.

Headline: EU agrees on approach to Brexit talks, May left out in cold
Description: European Union leaders agreed their plan for Brexit negotiations on Thursday, pledging to move swiftly and stick together to ensure Britain does not cherry pick a sweet deal that might inspire others to unstitch the bloc.

Headline: EU prepares for Brexit talks
Description: European Union leaders agreed on Thursday how they will organise negotiations with Britain that they expect to start within four months.

Description: Britain on Thursday became the first country to formally licence an in-vitro fertilisation (IVF) treatment designed to create babies from three people.

Description: British commercial property values rose in November for the second straight month since Britain voted in June to leave the European Union, having declined in the first three months after the vote, according to a survey published on Thursday.

Description: Prime Minister Theresa May raised the prospect of an "implementation phase" for Britain to put into place its new relationship with the European Union.

Description: London's mayor Sadiq Khan appointed former EU Trade Commissioner Peter Mandelson to a panel of business and financial leaders advising on Brexit which also includes the City of London's policy chief and the head of the London Stock Exchange.

Description: The British government is working to win a Brexit deal that will work for Scotland, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday after the Scottish government said it would publish proposals for remaining in the EU's single market.

Description: Former Prime Minister Gordon Brown urged Britain to delay Rupert Murdoch's proposed deal to buy European pay-TV group Sky  until the government completes an inquiry into a phone hacking scandal, the Guardian said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK will trigger Article 50 earlier than end of March if can - Brexit minister
Description: Britain will begin formal divorce talks with the European Union earlier than the end of March if it can, Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday.

Headline: BoE raises prospect of lower capital requirements for small banks
Description: Britain's new banks are likely to obtain relief on the amount of capital they must hold to cover the risk of default on home loans, a top Bank of England official said on Wednesday.

Headline: May's Brexit plan - secret strategy or muddle?
Description: If Prime Minister Theresa May has a detailed Brexit plan, it is very secret.

Headline: Once Article 50 is triggered, it will not be withdrawn - May spokeswoman
Description: Once Britain has triggered Article 50 of the European Union's Lisbon Treaty to begin formal Brexit talks it does not plan to withdraw that notification, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

Headline: London's unused water cannon for sale in humiliation for Boris Johnson
Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan has put up for sale three water cannon that were bought in 2014 by his predecessor Boris Johnson but never used, because the government refused permission for police to use them.

Headline: Brexit minister Davis says Article 50 may not be revocable
Description: Britain's government does not know whether it could halt the process of leaving the European Union once it has begun but it does not intend to change course in any case, Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain optimistic of EU help over Irish border - Brexit minister
Description: Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday he was optimistic that the European Union would be helpful in the government's quest not to have a "hard border" between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.

Headline: British government keeping options open on EU talks - Brexit minister
Description: Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday the British government was keeping its options open before beginning talks with the European Union over its divorce.

Description: Drug maker Actavis UK broke competition law by raising prices of hydrocortisone tablets by more than 12,000 percent, Britain's competition watchdog said in a provisional ruling on Friday.

Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she was glad the other 27 EU national leaders will meet without her after a summit on Thursday to discuss how to negotiate Britain's withdrawal from the Union.

Description: Britain is confident of agreeing an exit deal with the European Union within the two-year timetable set out under Article 50 of the bloc's Lisbon Treaty, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Description: Britain’s reputation among young people in EU nations has worsened following the Brexit vote, but has improved in nations further away, according to a poll for the British Council, the UK’s international organisation for cultural relations.

Headline: London commuters face nightmare as strike brings worst rail disruption for decades
Description: Hundreds of thousands of London commuters faced travel misery on Tuesday as a strike by train drivers bought services from southern England and Gatwick Airport to a standstill in the worst rail disruption in Britain for two decades.

Headline: UK must set out plans for transitional deal with EU - peers
Description: Britain will need a transitional trade agreement with the European Union, and the government should set out plans for it before beginning formal divorce talks with the bloc, members of parliament's upper house said on Tuesday.

Description: Hundreds of thousands of commuters in south London and southern England along with travellers to Gatwick Airport were facing travel misery on Tuesday as a strike by train drivers was set to bring rail services to a standstill.

Headline: EU governments ready Brexit negotiating text - diplomats
Description: European Union leaders will set out plans this week for negotiating Britain's exit, diplomats said, after national officials met late on Monday to prepare an EU summit statement.

Headline: Hammond backs Brexit transition, says would help EU too
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond on Monday backed the idea of a transition period to smooth the process of leaving the European Union, and said EU countries also stood to gain from a gradual Brexit.

Headline: Labour to ask urgent parliamentary question on Fox bid for Sky
Description: Britain's main opposition Labour Party will ask an urgent question in parliament on Monday about the proposed bid by Rupert Murdoch's Twenty-First Century Fox  for pay-TV company Sky , the parliamentary website said.

Headline: UK should address workers forming companies to cut tax bill - Hammond
Description: Britain should address the way some workers use companies to lessen their tax bill, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday, adding that any changes were an issue for the long term.

Headline: UK won't stop flow of highly skilled workers after Brexit - Hammond
Description: Britain will introduce a system to control the flow of workers from EU countries once it leaves the bloc but will not cut off the supply of skilled staff needed by British companies, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Headline: Six held in UK anti-terrorism raids; bomb disposal called in
Description: Police said they had arrested six people in anti-terrorism raids across central England and London on Monday, with bomb disposal officers later dispatched as officers carried out searches.

Description: A British-Algerian journalist had died six months after staging a hunger strike in Algiers over his detention for publishing articles seen as offensive to President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, prison authorities and his lawyer said.

Headline: Once Article 50 is triggered, it will not be withdrawn - May spokeswoman
Description: Once Britain has triggered Article 50 of the European Union's Lisbon Treaty to begin formal Brexit talks it does not plan to withdraw that notification, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

Description: London Mayor Sadiq Khan has put up for sale three water cannon that were bought in 2014 by his predecessor Boris Johnson but never used, because the government refused permission for police to use them.

Description: Britain's government does not know whether it could halt the process of leaving the European Union once it has begun but it does not intend to change course in any case, Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday.

Description: Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday he was optimistic that the European Union would be helpful in the government's quest not to have a "hard border" between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.

Headline: British government keeping options open on EU talks - Brexit minister
Description: Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday the British government was keeping its options open before beginning talks with the European Union over its divorce.

Headline: May condemns UK's worst rail strike in two decades
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May condemned as "appalling" a rail strike that left hundreds of thousands of London commuters facing a second day of travel chaos on Wednesday.

Description: Nearly all customers of Britain's second-biggest energy supplier, SSE, are paying standard tariffs rather than cheaper rates on offer, a league table published by regulator Ofgem showed on Wednesday.

Description: British pensioner Judy Swatridge's spine is held together by titanium pins and plates since breaking her back over 10 years ago. She needs regular check-ups and takes prescription drugs for illnesses including diabetes and high blood pressure.

Headline: Boris Johnson doing excellent job as foreign minister - May
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is doing "an absolutely excellent job", Prime Minister Theresa May told parliament on Wednesday.

Headline: Boris Johnson jokes about May's leather trousers
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has publicly poked fun at Prime Minister Theresa May, telling dozens of foreign ambassadors she was so cosmopolitan that she sported leather trousers like German "lederhosen".

Headline: Brexit minister 'not really interested' in transitional Brexit deal - FT says
Description: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis is "not really interested" in a transitional deal to cushion the country from the effects of leaving the European Union, he told a private meeting with the City of London Corporation, the Financial Times reported on Friday.

Headline: Memo cited by FT is interpretation of Brexit discussion - May spokeswoman
Description: A memo suggesting that Britain's Brexit minister is "not really interested" in a transitional deal with the European Union does is merely an interpretation of one of many meetings, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Friday.

Headline: MPs urge clampdown on bookmakers' betting machines
Description: Britain should drastically reduce the amount of money gamblers can stake on fixed-odds betting terminals to tackle addiction and associated crime, a group of MPs said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain's watchdog bans ads for unhealthy foods on kids media

Description: Britain will introduce a system to control the flow of workers from EU countries once it leaves the bloc but will not cut off the supply of skilled staff needed by British companies, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Headline: Six held in UK anti-terrorism raids; bomb disposal called in
Description: Police said they had arrested six people in anti-terrorism raids across central England and London on Monday, with bomb disposal officers later dispatched as officers carried out searches.

Headline: British-Algerian journalist dies after hunger strike in Algiers
Description: A British-Algerian journalist had died six months after staging a hunger strike in Algiers over his detention for publishing articles seen as offensive to President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, prison authorities and his lawyer said.

Headline: Is Brexit trigger reversible? Irish court case planned
Description: A crowdfunded legal challenge to determine whether Britain's divorce from the European Union can be reversed once it has been triggered will be submitted to the Irish High Court before Christmas, the lawyer behind the move said on Monday.

Headline: May sticks to Brexit timetable in spite of legal challenges - spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is sticking to her timetable of triggering formal divorce talks with the European Union by the end of March despite further legal challenges, her spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: Britain to adopt new anti-Semitism definition to fight hate crime
Description: Britain said on Monday it would become one of the first countries to adopt an international definition of anti-Semitism to clamp down on hate crime after an increase in the number of reported incidents targeting Jews.

Headline: Boris Johnson in Saudi Arabia says candour important, stresses friendship
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson reiterated Britain's close ties to Saudi Arabia on a visit on Sunday and said candour was also important, days after making comments widely seen as critical of the conservative Gulf Arab country.

Headline: Murdoch's new Sky bid should be probed say opposition politicians
Description: Rupert Murdoch's new takeover approach for British pay-TV firm Sky  should be investigated by the UK's competition authorities, according to opposition politicians, though analysts said a deal should be easier to get through this time round.

Headline: Government will publish statement on Brexit strategy before triggering Article 50
Description: The British government will publish a statement on its negotiating strategy for leaving the European Union before triggering the formal divorce procedure, minister David Lidington said on Wednesday.

Headline: Lawyer challenging government in Brexit trigger case says parliament motion is not enough
Description: A motion to be debated in parliament on Wednesday which is set to back Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit timetable does not impact on a legal battle over who has the right to trigger EU divorce talks, the UK Supreme Court heard.

Headline: Government accepts call to publish Brexit plan, asks parliament to respect timetable
Description: The government has accepted the opposition Labour Party's call for it to set out its plan for leaving the European Union before formal talks begin, but has asked parliament to respect its Brexit timetable.

Headline: For London's food and wine businesses, Brexit has a bitter taste
Description: Importing fine foods from Spain has been a good trade for London firm Brindisa, but like many food and wine businesses that rely on the free movement of goods and workers within the European Union, it has been badly hit by Britain's vote to leave.

Headline: 'Keep calm and negotiate' - EU sees October 2018 Brexit deal
Description: The European Union's chief negotiator set a target of agreeing a Brexit deal with Britain by October 2018, assuming London keeps a promise to formally launch the process of leaving the EU by the end of March.

Headline: Britain will need new law to trigger Brexit if loses court battle - lawyer
Description: The British government will need to put forward a new law to trigger formal divorce talks with the European Union if it loses a legal battle over who can start the Brexit process, the Supreme Court heard on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain will need act of parliament to trigger Brexit if loses court battle - lawyer
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's government will have to put forward a parliamentary bill if it loses a Supreme Court case over whether it can begin Brexit talks without MPs' approval, a government lawyer said on Tuesday.

Headline: China's latest UK buy - the prime minister's countryside pub
Description: When Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Britain last year and  went for a drink with then Prime Minister David Cameron, he walked away with a smile on his face.

Headline: Britain plans biggest rail overhaul in 20 years
Description: The British government is planning a major overhaul of the country's much-criticised railways in a bid to improve efficiency and stop excuses for poor service like the wrong kind of snow or leaves causing delays on the line.

Headline: UK does not want to go beyond two years in Brexit talks - May's spokesman
Description: The British government does not want its Brexit negotiations to go beyond the two-year limit set under Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK's stance incompatible with smooth Brexit - Eurogroup head
Description: The British government's attitude towards impending talks to leave the European Union suggests that Britain's exit will not be smooth and orderly, the head of the group of euro zone finance ministers said on Tuesday.

Headline: Tech investors say UK must clarify Brexit immigration stance
Description: London could lose its position as the leading destination for start-ups in Europe if it does not remain open to the best talent after the British vote to leave the European Union, investors warned on Monday.

Headline: UK not ruling out continued budget payments after Brexit - Hammond
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond said on Tuesday that the government would not rule out the possibility of continuing to make payments into the European Union budget once it leaves the bloc in order to maintain good access for its exporters.

Headline: Government begins legal fight against ruling that could derail Brexit
Description: The British government launched a Supreme Court battle on Monday over who has the power to trigger the formal process of leaving the European Union, seeking to overturn a legal ruling that could derail its Brexit strategy.

Headline: Factbox - What EU has prepared for Brexit talks
Description: British judges may upset government plans to start Brexit talks soon but whatever the Supreme Court decides after hearings this week, the EU has prepared its side of the unprecedented process.

Headline: Brexit prompts tenfold rise in British lawyers registering in Ireland
Description: The number of British lawyers registering in Ireland is set to be 10 times higher this year than in 2015 as they seek to ensure they can still practise in the European Union after Brexit, the Law Society of Ireland said on Monday.

Headline: Ministers say listening closely to City of London's Brexit concerns
Description: Britain's government is listening closely to the financial services sector's Brexit concerns, Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond and the minister in charge of the process for the country's exit from the European Union, David Davis, said.

Headline: UK says to begin preparing new WTO membership terms ahead of Brexit
Description: Britain is beginning to prepare its new World Trade Organisation (WTO) membership terms ahead of its exit from the European Union and will seek to closely replicate the existing EU ones, trade minister Liam Fox said on Monday.

Headline: UK government wants to provide certainty on Brexit - May's spokeswoman
Description: The British government wants to provide certainty over its exit from the European Union by saying there is no going back once divorce talks have formally begun, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: UK government says its Brexit trigger plan not a breach of parliament's sovereignty
Description: Attorney General Jeremy Wright told the Supreme Court on Monday that the government's plan to use executive powers to trigger EU divorce proceedings was not a breach of parliamentary sovereignty.

Headline: Assange releases testimony from London questioning, says he is innocent
Description: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange released on Wednesday his testimony from last month's London questioning in a Swedish rape investigation, saying he was innocent and that it was clear the sex was consensual.

Headline: Conservationist tracks swan migration across Channel by motorised glider
Description: A conservationist has crossed the Channel in a motorised paraglider as part of a near three-month project to track the migration of swans across Europe.

Headline: Britain plans to deepen security cooperation with Gulf
Description: Britain plans to deepen security cooperation with Gulf Arab countries and work with them to counter Iranian actions in the region, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: To vote against UK govt is to thwart EU referendum - minister
Description: Any lawmaker who votes against the government in parliament on Wednesday will be voting to thwart the will of the British people who want to leave the European Union, government minister David Lidington said on Wednesday.

Headline: Man arrested over racist threats against Brexit challenger Gina Miller
Description: British police have arrested a man on suspicion of making racist threats online against Gina Miller, who has challenged the government over how to trigger Brexit in a legal battle that has inflamed passions in Britain.

Headline: Government will publish statement on Brexit strategy before triggering Article 50
Description: The British government will publish a statement on its negotiating strategy for leaving the European Union before triggering the formal divorce procedure, minister David Lidington said on Wednesday.

Headline: Lawyer challenging government in Brexit trigger case says parliament motion is not enough
Description: A motion to be debated in parliament on Wednesday which is set to back Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit timetable does not impact on a legal battle over who has the right to trigger EU divorce talks, the UK Supreme Court heard.

Headline: Government accepts call to publish Brexit plan, asks parliament to respect timetable
Description: The government has accepted the opposition Labour Party's call for it to set out its plan for leaving the European Union before formal talks begin, but has asked parliament to respect its Brexit timetable.

Headline: For London's food and wine businesses, Brexit has a bitter taste
Description: Importing fine foods from Spain has been a good trade for London firm Brindisa, but like many food and wine businesses that rely on the free movement of goods and workers within the European Union, it has been badly hit by Britain's vote to leave.

Headline: 'Keep calm and negotiate' - EU sees October 2018 Brexit deal
Description: The European Union's chief negotiator set a target of agreeing a Brexit deal with Britain by October 2018, assuming London keeps a promise to formally launch the process of leaving the EU by the end of March.

Headline: UK will play leading role in 'volatile' world post-Brexit - Johnson
Description: Britain will not play a bit-part on the world stage following its exit from the European Union and must help prevent the emergence of a more brutal world order, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Friday.

Headline: Iceland vs Iceland Foods talks fail to resolve trademark row
Description: The government of Iceland will proceed with legal action against Iceland Foods over the British retailer's trademark registration of the word "Iceland" after talks between the two parties failed, it said on Friday.

Headline: Fibre upgrade cost traps Britain in cyber slow lane
Description: Britons desperate for faster broadband are unlikely to get it from a plan to separate the country's biggest network from BT  unless the industry tackles how to pay up to 25 billion pounds ($76 billion) to upgrade to fibre-optic cables.

Headline: UK telecoms watchdog wants more powers to block M&A post Brexit
Description: British regulators should be given wider powers to block mergers, particularly if a company has strategic significance, after the country's exit from the European Union, Sharon White, head of communications watchdog Ofcom said.

Headline: Lib Dems wins parliament seat in Brexit 'shockwave'
Description: Britain's pro-European Union Liberal Democrats won a parliamentary seat previously held by the ruling Conservatives on Friday and said the surprise win was a rejection of a "hard Brexit" that would pull Britain out of the EU's single market.

Headline: Brexit minister says would consider paying into EU for market access
Description: Britain would consider making payments to the European Union after it leaves to achieve the best possible access for businesses to the bloc's markets, Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain vows to play its part to end female genital mutilation 'in a generation'
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Female genital mutilation can be "wiped out in a generation" across the globe, Britain's interior minister Amber Rudd said on Thursday, as she called for everyone to pull together to tackle this "horrendous crime".

Headline: Britain shocked by growing football child abuse scandal
Description: What began as a harrowing account of child abuse suffered by a former professional English soccer player last month has lifted the lid on what could be one of the worst paedophile scandals Britain has ever known.

Headline: Net migration from EU to Britain hit record high ahead of EU vote
Description: Net migration from the European Union to Britain hit a record high in the 12 months running up to June's referendum vote to leave the bloc, in which concerns about immigration motivated many Brexit voters.

Headline: Johnson says Brexit means taking back control of immigration
Description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Thursday that Britain's planned exit from the European Union was about taking back control of immigration.

Headline: Majority of UK pension funds say executive pay too high - survey
Description: Eighty-seven percent of UK pension funds say executives at UK listed companies are paid too much, a survey by the Pensions and Lifetime Savings Association said on Thursday, as Britain proposes changes to the way companies are run.

Headline: Britain to decide how to spend taxpayers' money post-Brexit - PM May's spokeswoman
Description: Britain will decide how it spends taxpayers' money after it leaves the EU and is looking at ways of securing the best access for businesses to the bloc after Brexit, a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday.

Headline: Bank of England sees global financial risks after Trump victory
Description: Donald Trump's victory in the U.S. presidential election has increased the threats to the world economy from higher interest rates and less trade, the Bank of England said on Wednesday.

Headline: British food industry needs access to labour post-Brexit, bosses say
Description: The bosses of Sainsbury's , Marks & Spencer  and Morrisons  have said Britain's food and supermarket sector will need continued access to EU migrant labour after the country leaves the European Union.

Headline: UK panel says new three-parent IVF technique now safe for 'cautious use'
Description: A three-parent IVF technique designed to reduce the risk of mothers passing hereditary diseases to their babies is safe enough to be offered to patients in special circumstances, a British expert review panel said on Wednesday.

Headline: In a battle over Brexit, court challenger fears Britain's demons have been unleashed
Description: When Gina Miller took the British government to court over triggering Brexit, she didn't expect death threats or the need to bring in security so that her children could get to school safely.

Headline: Industry warns of Brexit uncertainty for thousands of medicines
Description: British patients could lose access to vital medicines unless arrangements are put in place to ensure a seamless licensing system after Britain leaves the European Union, a top industry official said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK hopes to look at EU citizens rights early in Brexit negotiations - PM May
Description: Britain hopes to tackle the issue of the future rights of European Union citizens in Britain and Britons living in the EU early on in talks on Brexit, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Limits on skilled workers would hit UK growth - Mayor of London
Description: Britain will be hit by lower tax revenues and weaker economic growth if it limits the number of skilled European Union workers entering the capital as part of its Brexit negotiation, the Mayor of London warned on Wednesday.

Headline: UK firms need more clarity about Brexit - BoE's Carney
Description: British businesses need more clarity about how Britain intends to leave the European Union, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain may continue with some EU cooperation post-Brexit - Johnson
Description: Britain could pay in to some EU programmes after Brexit but the government will take back control of its own money and will no longer spend large amounts in Brussels, Foreign Minister Boris Johnson said on Sunday.

Headline: Labour party would table amendment to Brexit bill
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party plans to table an amendment to a bill on triggering the UK's formal divorce talks with the European Union, said its leader, should a court ruling that parliament needs to be involved in the process be upheld.

Headline: UK plans to buy 20 new drones from General Atomics - minister
Description: Britain has signed a $125 million (98 million pound) contract with privately held U.S. weapons maker General Atomics for development of a new drone, and plans to eventually buy 20 of the new unmanned planes, Secretary of State for Defence Michael Fallon said on Saturday.

Headline: Exclusive: Banks to Britain - stagger Brexit over years or we could leave
Description: Britain must negotiate a staggered departure from the European Union over several years or risk banks leaving the country, the biggest banking lobby group will warn the government in coming weeks, according to sources familiar with the matter.

Headline: Network Rail to share control of British rail with private sector - Telegraph
Description: In one of the biggest shake ups for Britain's public transport system, state-owned Network Rail will share control over Britain's rail network with private rail operators, the Telegraph reported on Friday.

Headline: UK will play leading role in 'volatile' world post-Brexit - Johnson
Description: Britain will not play a bit-part on the world stage following its exit from the European Union and must help prevent the emergence of a more brutal world order, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Friday.

Headline: Iceland vs Iceland Foods talks fail to resolve trademark row
Description: The government of Iceland will proceed with legal action against Iceland Foods over the British retailer's trademark registration of the word "Iceland" after talks between the two parties failed, it said on Friday.

Headline: Fibre upgrade cost traps Britain in cyber slow lane
Description: Britons desperate for faster broadband are unlikely to get it from a plan to separate the country's biggest network from BT  unless the industry tackles how to pay up to 25 billion pounds ($76 billion) to upgrade to fibre-optic cables.

Headline: UK telecoms watchdog wants more powers to block M&A post Brexit
Description: British regulators should be given wider powers to block mergers, particularly if a company has strategic significance, after the country's exit from the European Union, Sharon White, head of communications watchdog Ofcom said.

Headline: Lib Dems wins parliament seat in Brexit 'shockwave'
Description: Britain's pro-European Union Liberal Democrats won a parliamentary seat previously held by the ruling Conservatives on Friday and said the surprise win was a rejection of a "hard Brexit" that would pull Britain out of the EU's single market.

Headline: Factbox - Britain's plans to regulate company behaviour
Description: Britain announced proposals on Tuesday to encourage more responsible corporate behaviour, part of Prime Minister Theresa May's drive to support the millions of people she says voted for Brexit in protest at 'out of touch' elites.

Headline: Britain unveils proposals to regulate company behaviour
Description: Britain began consultations on encouraging better corporate behaviour and curbing excessive executive pay on Tuesday, part of Prime Minister Theresa May's campaign to help those who voted for Brexit in protest at "out of touch" elites.

Headline: Euro chief Dijsselbloem sees London losing EU finance dominance
Description: The European Union cannot let London remain the main financial centre for the euro zone after Brexit if Britain does not want to be bound by EU financial rules, Eurogroup President Jeroen Dijsselbloem said on Tuesday.

Headline: 'Have cake and eat it' - Is this the UK's Brexit strategy?
Description: Britain denied on Tuesday that a document photographed in the hands of a Conservative Party official which said the strategy for Brexit talks was to "Have cake and eat it" accurately reflected its plans for forthcoming EU divorce negotiations.

Headline: FCA to review if payday lending cap feeds loan sharks
Description: Britain's financial watchdog has begun a review to discover whether capped interest rates on payday lending have driven vulnerable consumers into borrowing from illegal loan sharks.

Headline: UKIP begins life after chief Brexiteer and Trump-backer Nigel Farage
Description: Nigel Farage, the face of Brexit who forced Britain to hold an EU referendum and then upstaged the government by forging a friendship with Donald Trump, is a hard act to follow.

Headline: BT says still working with Ofcom to agree Openreach deal
Description: BT  said it would continue to work with UK telecoms regulator Ofcom to find an agreed solution for its networks division Openreach, after the regulator said it would go to the European Commission to try to force a legal separation.

Headline: Polish foreign minister says it's in Poland's interest for Britain to stay longer in EU
Description: It is in Poland's interest that Britain remains a European Union member and pays into the bloc's budget for as long as possible, Rzeczpospolita daily quoted Polish Foreign Minister Witold Waszczykowski as saying on Tuesday.

Headline: Not out yet, Britain backs EU patent court
Description: Britain pleased and surprised some of its European Union partners on Monday by pledging to ratify a new, unified patent system for the bloc even though London is about to leave the EU.

Headline: PM May hopes for early agreement on Polish citizens in Britain
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday Britain she hoped to reach an early agreement on the status of Polish citizens in the country with Poland, as her government prepares to leave the European Union.

Headline: Britain must consider role in organisations it joined as part of EU - May
Description: Britain will have to look at its role in organisations it entered into as part of the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday, describing how her government is planning for Brexit.

Headline: Britain seeks to strengthen ties with Poland before Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May discussed defence, security and trade with Polish Prime Minister Beata Szydlo on Monday as Britain looks to strengthen ties with a key ally before it leaves the European Union.

Headline: Pope to visit Ireland, possibly Northern Ireland
Description: Pope Francis will make the first papal trip to Ireland in nearly 40 years, the country's prime minister said on Monday, amid signs he could also become the first Roman Catholic pope to visit Northern Ireland.

Headline: Anti-EU party UKIP elect new leader to replace Farage
Description: Britain's anti-European Union UK Independence Party elected its former chairman Paul Nuttall as leader on Monday, seeking to overcome months of internal turmoil and capitalise on its successful Brexit campaign.

Headline: Britain, Poland keen for reciprocity over citizens post-Brexit - UK PM's spokeswoman
Description: Britain and Poland are keen to come to a reciprocal agreement over the future of their citizens following Britain's exit from the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: UK think-tank plans legal challenge over Europe single market access
Description: A British think-tank said on Monday it planned to take legal action over whether the government can take Britain out of the single market as part of its exit from the European Union, in the latest legal attempt to challenge the Brexit process.

Headline: Coal price surge sets miners against activists by English seaside
Description: In northeastern England, a battle is raging between grass roots campaigners and a company intent on digging a new open cast mine as world coal prices soar.

Headline: BoE's Carney wants lengthy Brexit transition for UK firms - Sunday Times
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney wants British businesses to retain access to the European Union's single market for two years after the country leaves the bloc, the Sunday Times reported, without citing sources.

Headline: Brexit dealmaker Verhofstadt backs paid EU membership for Britons
Description: The European Parliament's top Brexit negotiator backed the idea of individual European Union memberships for Britons who want to stay in the bloc in an interview published on Saturday.

Headline: Scotland sets out legal case to have a say on Brexit trigger
Description: The Scottish government on Friday published legal arguments it will use to try to persuade Britain's highest court that the devolved Scottish parliament must give its approval before Prime Minister Theresa May can trigger the Brexit process.

Headline: Waiting for Theresa, EU closes ranks, draws battle plans
Description: Senior officials from Britain's EU partners gather next week to coordinate plans for looming Brexit negotiations with Prime Minister Theresa May - but they can do little in detail until London works out what it wants.

Headline: UK financial firms seen applying for licences in Dublin by early 2017
Description: Some financial firms in Britain looking for a base in the European Union after Brexit are expected to start applying for licences in Dublin by early next year, Ireland's financial services minister said on Friday.

Headline: Incoming EU president Malta signals tough Brexit talks with UK
Description: Britain cannot expect a better relationship with the European Union than it currently has once it leaves the bloc, incoming EU president Malta said on Friday, signalling a tough stance in looming Brexit negotiations.

Headline: British wage growth looks 'dreadful' after Brexit - IFS
Description: Britain's wage growth prospects look "dreadful", a leading think tank said on Thursday, after official economic forecasts showed workers were unlikely to recoup losses suffered after the financial crisis within the next five years.

Headline: Hammond says can sustain high debt because of market credibility
Description: Britain can sustain a relatively high level of government debt because of its good standing in financial markets, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Thursday.

Headline: Trump's friend Farage taunts PM May with 'ambassador's reception'
Description: Nigel Farage, the Brexit campaigner who U.S. President-elect Donald Trump said would be great as Britain's envoy to Washington, taunted Prime Minister Theresa May with a mock ambassador's reception complete with chocolate and champagne.

Headline: Factbox - The cost of Brexit: Britain's 60 billion pound question
Description: Britain's official budget forecasters have been caught up in the rancorous Brexit debate after they predicted the vote to leave the European Union will cause a sharp rise in government borrowing.

Headline: UK flags fresh infrastructure spending to help boost output
Description: Britain's finance minister freed up an extra 23 billion pounds on Wednesday to invest in rail, telecoms and housing infrastructure over the next five years to help boost the country's output.

Headline: Bracing for Brexit, UK ramps up borrowing and cuts growth forecasts
Description: Britain has ramped up its borrowing outlook by much more than expected after forecasters said its vote to leave the European Union would hurt the economy, giving the government only a little room to ease looming pressure on households and firms.

Headline: British taxpayers face 27 billion pound loss from bank bailout
Description: The British government said on Wednesday it faces an almost 27 billion pound loss from rescuing failed banks during the 2007-2009 financial crisis after a slump in the lenders' value since Britain's vote to leave European Union.

Headline: UKIP begins life after chief Brexiteer and Trump-backer Nigel Farage
Description: Nigel Farage, the face of Brexit who forced Britain to hold an EU referendum and then upstaged the government by forging a friendship with Donald Trump, is a hard act to follow.
