Description: Nigel Farage, the Brexit campaigner who U.S. President-elect Donald Trump said would be great as Britain's envoy to Washington, taunted Prime Minister Theresa May with a mock ambassador's reception complete with chocolate and champagne.

Headline: Factbox - The cost of Brexit: Britain's 60 billion pound question
Description: Britain's official budget forecasters have been caught up in the rancorous Brexit debate after they predicted the vote to leave the European Union will cause a sharp rise in government borrowing.

Headline: UK flags fresh infrastructure spending to help boost output
Description: Britain's finance minister freed up an extra 23 billion pounds on Wednesday to invest in rail, telecoms and housing infrastructure over the next five years to help boost the country's output.

Headline: Bracing for Brexit, UK ramps up borrowing and cuts growth forecasts
Description: Britain has ramped up its borrowing outlook by much more than expected after forecasters said its vote to leave the European Union would hurt the economy, giving the government only a little room to ease looming pressure on households and firms.

Headline: British taxpayers face 27 billion pound loss from bank bailout
Description: The British government said on Wednesday it faces an almost 27 billion pound loss from rescuing failed banks during the 2007-2009 financial crisis after a slump in the lenders' value since Britain's vote to leave European Union.

Headline: Nazi-obsessed loner gets life for murder of Jo Cox
Description: A loner obsessed with Nazis and extreme right-wing ideology was sentenced on Wednesday to spend the rest of his life in prison for murdering lawmaker Jo Cox in a frenzied street attack that stunned Britain a week before the European Union referendum.

Headline: Post-Brexit immigration fall to push up UK public borrowing - official forecast
Description: The British government will have to borrow an extra 16 billion pounds ($20 billion) over the next five years to make up for the impact of lower immigration following the Brexit vote, Britain's independent budget forecasters said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK government announces funding for autonomous vehicles, electric cars
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond on Wednesday announced 390 million pounds of funding to boost the development of low emission vehicles and autonomous vehicles.

Headline: Hammond sets target for cyclically-adjusted budget deficit
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Wednesday the government would aim to cut the country's budget deficit, adjusted for swings in the economy, to below 2 percent of gross domestic product by the end of the current parliament in 2020.

Headline: Key announcements in UK Autumn Statement on budget
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond delivered his first detailed statement to parliament on budget policy since taking office in July following Britain's vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: Britain maintains carbon tax freeze until April 2021
Description: Britain's carbon tax will continue to be frozen at 2015 levels of 18 pounds per tonne until April 2021, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Wednesday, while presenting the government's Autumn Statement.

Headline: UK's budget office sees little impact on growth from Hammond plan
Description: Measures announced by British finance minister Philip Hammond on Wednesday in the government's first budget plans since the Brexit vote in June are likely to add only 0.1 percentage point to economic growth next year, Britain's budget office said.

Headline: Hammond says government to cancel planned fuel duty rise
Description: The British government will cancel a planned fuel duty rise for the seventh successive year, finance minister Philip Hammond said on Wednesday.

Headline: Chancellor Hammond delivers Autumn Statement on budget policy
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond delivered his first statement on budget policy since taking office in July following Britain's vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: UK government to maintain state pension rules, could review from 2020
Description: A system of guaranteed annual pension increases for retired citizens will remain but the government will review its public spending priorities for 2020 onwards, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK raises insurance premium tax to 12 percent
Description: Britain will raise insurance premium tax by two percentage points to 12 percent from June 2017, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Wednesday in his first Autumn Statement address to Parliament.

Headline: UK seen borrowing 122 billion pounds more than expected in March - OBR figures
Description: Britain's government will end up borrowing 122 billion pounds more over the next five years than it expected before the country voted for Brexit, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Wednesday.

Headline: Hammond gives help to UK low earners, focus stays on budget gap
Description: Britain's Chancellor will say on Wednesday that he is raising the minimum wage and taking the edge off a benefits squeeze for low earners, but fixing the public finances will be a bigger priority as the country gets ready for Brexit.

Headline: UK uses 'Autumn statement' to prepare economy for 'new chapter' - May's spokeswoman
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond is using his first detailed policy announcement to help prepare the British economy for "a new chapter", a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Hammond gets boost from October borrowing data
Description: British Chancellor Philip Hammond got some rare good news about the country's finances on Tuesday as he finalises his first budget statement, which is still likely to forecast a surge in borrowing as Britain prepares to leave the EU.

Headline: Hammond to announce rise in minimum wage
Description: Britain's Chancellor, Philip Hammond, will on Wednesday announce an increase in the minimum wage from April for workers aged 25 and over to 7.50 pounds ($9.31) an hour from the current 7.20 pounds, the Treasury said.

Headline: Dubai drops case against UK woman charged over her own rape - advocates
Description: NEW YORK (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Charges against a British woman arrested in Dubai after reporting her own rape have been dropped, rights advocates said on Tuesday, bringing to a close a case that raised questions about the Gulf State's judicial system.

Headline: A soft Brexit is best for Norway, trade minister says
Description: Britain should stay as closely connected to Europe's single market as it can after it leaves the European Union, the trade minister of non-EU member Norway said on Tuesday.

Headline: JPMorgan says French labour law in way of big move to Paris post Brexit
Description: JPMorgan would be reluctant to move many jobs to Paris following Britain's exit from the European Union because of France's protectionist labour laws, the U.S.-based investment bank's France head told Reuters on Tuesday.

Headline: Hammond to raise UK borrowing target by 10 billion pounds, funded by T-bills - Poll
Description: Chancellor of the exchequer Philip Hammond will need to borrow 10 billion pounds more this financial year than the government previously planned, funded mostly by short-term treasury bills rather than gilts, according to a Reuters poll.

Headline: UK's Mr Brexit says no vacancy for ambassador to United States
Description: Britain's Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Tuesday there was no vacancy for the job of ambassador to Washington as the incumbent was very good.

Headline: Britain to Trump - 'No vacancy' for Farage as ambassador
Description: Britain on Tuesday dismissed U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's unprecedented expression of support for Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage to be made British ambassador to Washington, saying pointedly that there is no vacancy for the job.

Headline: 'We appoint our ambassadors,' says UK PM's spokesman
Description: Britain has an "incredibly strong and enduring" relationship with the United States and will build on it when Donald Trump takes office as president, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: EU conservative warns UK it can't keep best bits of relationship
Description: Britain's minister in charge of leaving the European Union told a leading EU lawmaker on Tuesday he wants to keep strong ties to the bloc's single market but the parliamentarian warned that the UK must exit the Union entirely, without special deals.

Headline: Britain says case of detained aid worker in Iran an 'utmost priority'
Description: Britain is working to resolve the case of detained Iranian-British aid worker Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Tuesday.

Headline: Modest fiscal easing ahead for Britain, but BoE likely done - Reuters poll
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond is set to announce some modest infrastructure spending and housing stimulus next week, according to a Reuters poll of economists that found widespread expectations of a marked easing-off on deficit reduction.

Headline: Hammond plans 'steady as she goes' budget - MP
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond is likely to announce a "steady as she goes" budget plan next week without big tax or spending surprises, and he will avoid setting a firm target for turning the budget deficit into a surplus, a lawmaker said.

Headline: Factbox - May's speeches show changing Brexit view
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has a reputation for choosing her words carefully on Brexit, using phrases such as "Brexit means Brexit", making "a success of it" and getting "the best deal" to describe preparations for leaving the European Union.

Headline: Britain seeks to curb pollution by small-scale power plants
Description: Britain plans to curb health damaging air pollution with emissions standards for small-scale power plants used to generate back-up electricity at short notice and to stem the rising use of diesel generators.

Headline: Britain ratifies Paris climate agreement
Description: Britain said on Thursday it had ratified the Paris Agreement, the global deal to combat climate change.

Headline: UK has kind of Brexit negotiating structure but won't be easy - Scots minister
Description: The United Kingdom has got some kind of structure in place for negotiating its exit from the European Union but divorce talks will not be easy, pro-EU Scotland's Brexit representative said on Thursday.

Headline: UK insurer body wants bulk of EU capital rules to stay after Brexit
Description: The European Union's capital rules for insurers should be copied into UK law after the country leaves the bloc to avoid "regulatory limbo," with only some elements changed to work better for UK consumers, an industry group said on Thursday.

Headline: UK government shelves plan to limit Lords' lawmaking power
Description: The government shelved plans to strip the unelected upper house of parliament of its right to veto new laws on Thursday, backing away from reforms demanded last year by then-prime minister David Cameron.

Headline: Dying MP Jo Cox told aides to escape as killer struck - court
Description: Dying British lawmaker Jo Cox pleaded with her aides to save themselves after her killer launched a frenzied attack, prompting him to return to carry on the deadly assault, a court heard on Wednesday.

Headline: British voters' Brexit wishlist - free trade, EU immigration controls, survey shows
Description: British voters want to maintain free trade with the European Union after Brexit but also want to limit immigration from countries in the bloc, according to a survey on Wednesday.

Headline: UK courts more likely to jail black than white people for same crimes - review
Description: Britain's courts are more likely to send people from ethnic minorities to prison for certain types of crime than white people convicted of the same offences, a government-commissioned review into race and the criminal justice system has found.

Headline: Trump win is an opportunity for UK-US trading relationship - PM May
Description: Donald Trump's election win provides an opportunity for Britain's trading relationship with the United States, British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: May says employment data shows strength of fundamentals of UK economy
Description: Employment data released on Wednesday show that the fundamentals of Britain's economy are strong, Prime Minister Theresa May said.

Headline: EU court: London's Westminster overcharged sex shops for license applications
Description: The European Court of Justice ruled on Wednesday that local authorities in London's Westminster were charging sex shop operators too much to apply for licences, infringing on EU rules designed to promote service activities.

Headline: In biggest boost since 1940s, BBC World Service adds 11 languages
Description: The BBC said on Wednesday that its World Service will begin broadcasting in 11 additional languages in a drive to reach millions more people, including in places like North Korea where impartial news is hard to get.

Headline: UK needs independent commission to boost home ownership - review
Description: Britain should set up an independent housing commission and review flagship government programmes to help boost home ownership, according to a review led by the CEO of one of the country's biggest housebuilders.

Headline: Banks could move from UK 18 months before a 'hard Brexit' - Carney
Description: Banks based in Britain may start to relocate activities to other countries about 1-1/2 years before a British departure from the European Union if a "hard Brexit" looks likely, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Tuesday.

Headline: Scottish parliament asks UK to ring-fence Scots EU single market membership
Description: Scotland's devolved parliament called on Tuesday for the British government to ring-fence its European Union single market membership even as Britain exits the bloc.

Headline: Disputed memo says Britain has no Brexit plan
Description: Britain has no overall strategy for leaving the European Union and splits in Prime Minister Theresa May's cabinet could delay a clear negotiating position for six months, according to a leaked Deloitte memo that the government dismissed as having no credibility.

Headline: Deloitte says leaked Brexit memo was written without UK government input
Description: A leaked Brexit note that said Britain has no overall strategy for leaving the European Union was written without input from the government, Deloitte said on Tuesday.

Headline: May's changing vocabulary signals shift from 'hard Brexit'
Description: There is a recognisable repetition in Theresa May's speeches about Britain's decision to leave the European Union: "Brexit means Brexit", making "a success of it" and getting "the best deal" for Britain are some of her stump phrases.

Headline: Merkel - can't discuss Brexit in detail as Article 50 not yet invoked
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said it would not be possible to discuss Brexit in detail with visiting Prime Minister Theresa May on Friday as the British government has not yet triggered divorce proceedings with the European Union.

Headline: UK should phase-out carbon tax to cut power prices – report
Description: Britain should phase out a carbon emissions tax levied on power producers by the mid 2020s, cutting household electricity bills by around 7 percent, an influential think tank on UK government policy said in a report on Friday.

Headline: Scottish lawyers invited to address UK Supreme Court's Brexit hearing
Description: The United Kingdom's Supreme Court said on Friday it would allow Scotland's most senior lawyer to address a December hearing on whether Prime Minister Theresa May needs parliamentary approval before triggering an exit from the European Union.

Headline: Britain to shake up fund management to give investors better value
Description: Investors get poor value for money from Britain's 7 trillion pound asset management industry because there is not enough competition and a lack of transparency on fees, the industry regulator said on Friday.

Headline: Modest fiscal easing ahead for Britain, but BoE likely done - Reuters poll
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond is set to announce some modest infrastructure spending and housing stimulus next week, according to a Reuters poll of economists that found widespread expectations of a marked easing-off on deficit reduction.

Headline: Hammond plans 'steady as she goes' budget - MP
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond is likely to announce a "steady as she goes" budget plan next week without big tax or spending surprises, and he will avoid setting a firm target for turning the budget deficit into a surplus, a lawmaker said.

Headline: Factbox - May's speeches show changing Brexit view
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has a reputation for choosing her words carefully on Brexit, using phrases such as "Brexit means Brexit", making "a success of it" and getting "the best deal" to describe preparations for leaving the European Union.

Headline: Britain seeks to curb pollution by small-scale power plants
Description: Britain plans to curb health damaging air pollution with emissions standards for small-scale power plants used to generate back-up electricity at short notice and to stem the rising use of diesel generators.

Headline: Britain ratifies Paris climate agreement
Description: Britain said on Thursday it had ratified the Paris Agreement, the global deal to combat climate change.

Headline: Brexit without transitional deal will damage economy - RBS Chairman
Description: If Britain does not agree a transitional arrangement with the European Union for the country's finance industry, it will be damaging for the economy and the financial services sector, the Chairman of Royal Bank of Scotland said on Sunday.

Headline: Lego ends Daily Mail toy giveaway after protest on migrant coverage
Description: Danish toymaker Lego said on Saturday it would stop giving away free toys with Britain's Daily Mail, following a campaign to stop advertising in newspapers accused of discrimination in their coverage of migrants.

Headline: Johnson says no need for gloom about Trump victory
Description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, setting aside his previous hostility toward Donald Trump, said on Thursday the U.S. Republican's presidential election victory offered economic opportunities and there was no need for Europeans to be despondent about it.

Headline: Paris waxworks caught out as London's Tussauds gets to work on Trump
Description: While London's Madame Tussauds is showing off work well under way on its waxwork of Donald Trump, its Paris rival has found itself on the wrong side of a bet that Hillary Clinton would win the U.S. presidency.

Headline: Britain, France fall silent to commemorate Armistice Day
Description: French President Francois Hollande and Britain's Prince Harry led commemorations as the two nations marked Armistice Day on Friday to remember those killed in war.

Headline: 'Hard' Brexit most likely outcome for UK leaving EU, says S&P
Description: A "hard" Brexit in which Britain loses its free access to the European Union market now looks like the most likely outcome of the country's plan to leave the bloc, ratings agency Standard & Poor's said on Friday.

Headline: Lib Dems will vote against triggering Brexit if no second referendum
Description: The leader of Britain's Liberal Democrat Party said on Friday his lawmakers would vote against triggering the formal process of leaving the European Union unless the government promises to hold a second referendum.

Headline: China says expects UK and EU to strike a good Brexit deal
Description: China expects Brexit negotiations between Britain and the European Union will produce a favourable outcome, Vice Finance Minister Shi Yaobin said on Thursday.

Headline: Trump invites May to visit 'as soon as possible'
Description: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump invited Theresa May to visit him as soon as possible during their first telephone call since his election victory, the British prime minister's office said on Thursday.

Headline: Philip Hammond expects 'very constructive dialogue' with Trump - BBC
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Thursday he was certain that Britain would have a constructive relationship with U.S. President-Elect Donald Trump's administration.

Headline: Britain at front of queue after Trump beats 'loathsome' Obama - Farage
Description: Welcoming Donald Trump's election triumph, prominent Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage called on the U.S. president-elect to reverse "loathsome" Barack Obama's policy by making Britain his top priority.

Headline: UK government likely to intervene in electricity market - First Utility
Description: First Utility, one of Britain's biggest independent energy suppliers, said on Thursday it expects the government to intervene in the country's electricity market to keep a lid on soaring bills.

Headline: EU will be 'neither aggressive nor naive' in Brexit talks - negotiator
Description: The European Union's approach to negotiations on Britain's departure from the bloc will be "neither aggressive nor naive", the union's chief negotiator Michel Barnier said on Thursday.

Headline: UK urged to stop locking up stateless 'ghost people'
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - (Adds Home Office comment in par 12,13 and 19)

Headline: Tata Steel may close UK pension scheme - union source
Description: Tata Steel UK  is looking at closing its defined benefit pension scheme to future accruals and move members onto a defined contribution pension instead, a union source said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK looks to rekindle China investment ties after Hinkley hiccup
Description: Britain will seek to rekindle its "Golden Era" of relations with China on Thursday in talks with Chinese Vice Premier Ma Kai focussed on trade, infrastructure investment and closer financial cooperation.

Headline: Boris Johnson says looks forward to continuing UK-U.S. partnership with Trump
Description: Britain's Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, who has previously criticised U.S. President-elect Donald Trump, congratulated him on his victory on Wednesday and said he looked forward to continuing the partnership between the two nations.

Headline: At least seven killed in London tram accident; driver arrested
Description: At least seven people were killed and more than 50 injured when a tram overturned on Wednesday morning in south London, police said and later confirmed the driver had been arrested.

Headline: Scotland calls for clarity on single market access after Brexit talks
Description: Scotland called for more clarity on Britain's Brexit strategy on Wednesday, offering a critical response to the British government's efforts to hold together a fraying United Kingdom as it prepares to leave the European Union.

Headline: MP demands Sports Direct explain alleged spying attempt
Description: A senior British lawmaker has demanded Sports Direct explain an alleged attempt to spy on a group of parliamentarians during a surprise visit this week to a company warehouse.

Headline: Britain's leaked Brexit memo
Description: The following is a copy of a leaked memo on Brexit prepared for the Cabinet Office. It was printed by The Times newspaper.

Headline: With 'change in the air', May asks business to help on economy
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May called on business leaders on Monday to help her government win back Britons disillusioned with liberal elites and globalisation by forging an economy that "works for everyone".

Headline: Accused killer of MP Jo Cox said was acting 'for Britain', court hears
Description: The man accused of murdering MP Jo Cox in June was heard saying "this is for Britain" during an attack that was motivated by politics or ideology, a London jury was told at the opening of his trial on Monday.

Headline: After Trump and Brexit shocks, Hammond hopes to ease voters' frustrations
Description: Five months to the day after Britain voted for Brexit, its finance minister will outline how the government plans to cope with the economic fallout and voters' frustrations which had echoes in Donald Trump's U.S. election triumph.

Headline: Brexit firebrand Farage meets Trump in New York
Description: Leading Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage visited Donald Trump at his home on Saturday, after suggesting he could act as a go-between to help smooth British relations with the U.S. president-elect.

Headline: Brexit without transitional deal will damage economy - RBS Chairman
Description: If Britain does not agree a transitional arrangement with the European Union for the country's finance industry, it will be damaging for the economy and the financial services sector, the Chairman of Royal Bank of Scotland said on Sunday.

Headline: Lego ends Daily Mail toy giveaway after protest on migrant coverage
Description: Danish toymaker Lego said on Saturday it would stop giving away free toys with Britain's Daily Mail, following a campaign to stop advertising in newspapers accused of discrimination in their coverage of migrants.

Description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, setting aside his previous hostility toward Donald Trump, said on Thursday the U.S. Republican's presidential election victory offered economic opportunities and there was no need for Europeans to be despondent about it.

Description: While London's Madame Tussauds is showing off work well under way on its waxwork of Donald Trump, its Paris rival has found itself on the wrong side of a bet that Hillary Clinton would win the U.S. presidency.

Description: French President Francois Hollande and Britain's Prince Harry led commemorations as the two nations marked Armistice Day on Friday to remember those killed in war.

Description: The leader of Britain's Liberal Democrat Party said on Friday his lawmakers would vote against triggering the formal process of leaving the European Union unless the government promises to hold a second referendum.

Description: China expects Brexit negotiations between Britain and the European Union will produce a favourable outcome, Vice Finance Minister Shi Yaobin said on Thursday.

Description: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump invited Theresa May to visit him as soon as possible during their first telephone call since his election victory, the British prime minister's office said on Thursday.

Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Thursday he was certain that Britain would have a constructive relationship with U.S. President-Elect Donald Trump's administration.

Headline: Britain at front of queue after Trump beats 'loathsome' Obama - Farage
Description: Welcoming Donald Trump's election triumph, prominent Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage called on the U.S. president-elect to reverse "loathsome" Barack Obama's policy by making Britain his top priority.

Headline: UK government likely to intervene in electricity market - First Utility
Description: First Utility, one of Britain's biggest independent energy suppliers, said on Thursday it expects the government to intervene in the country's electricity market to keep a lid on soaring bills.

Headline: EU will be 'neither aggressive nor naive' in Brexit talks - negotiator
Description: The European Union's approach to negotiations on Britain's departure from the bloc will be "neither aggressive nor naive", the union's chief negotiator Michel Barnier said on Thursday.

Headline: UK urged to stop locking up stateless 'ghost people'
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - (Adds Home Office comment in par 12,13 and 19)

Headline: Tata Steel may close UK pension scheme - union source
Description: Tata Steel UK  is looking at closing its defined benefit pension scheme to future accruals and move members onto a defined contribution pension instead, a union source said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK looks to rekindle China investment ties after Hinkley hiccup
Description: Britain will seek to rekindle its "Golden Era" of relations with China on Thursday in talks with Chinese Vice Premier Ma Kai focussed on trade, infrastructure investment and closer financial cooperation.

Headline: Boris Johnson says looks forward to continuing UK-U.S. partnership with Trump
Description: Britain's Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson, who has previously criticised U.S. President-elect Donald Trump, congratulated him on his victory on Wednesday and said he looked forward to continuing the partnership between the two nations.

Headline: At least seven killed in London tram accident; driver arrested
Description: At least seven people were killed and more than 50 injured when a tram overturned on Wednesday morning in south London, police said and later confirmed the driver had been arrested.

Headline: Scotland calls for clarity on single market access after Brexit talks
Description: Scotland called for more clarity on Britain's Brexit strategy on Wednesday, offering a critical response to the British government's efforts to hold together a fraying United Kingdom as it prepares to leave the European Union.

Headline: MP demands Sports Direct explain alleged spying attempt
Description: A senior British lawmaker has demanded Sports Direct explain an alleged attempt to spy on a group of parliamentarians during a surprise visit this week to a company warehouse.

Headline: London police guilty of 'serious failings' over VIP child sex cases
Description: London's police force was guilty of dozens of serious failings in investigations into alleged historical child sex abuse by high-profile figures based on claims that turned out to be not credible, a damning report said on Tuesday.

Headline: May says EU divorce timetable still deliverable - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is committed to triggering the formal European Union divorce talks by the end of March and believes such a timetable is deliverable, a spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK top court likely to rule on parliament's Brexit role in New Year
Description: Britain's Supreme Court is likely to make its ruling in the New Year on the issue of whether the government requires parliamentary approval before launching the formal process of leaving the European Union.

Headline: Scotland to join legal appeal to ensure vote on Brexit trigger
Description: Scotland will throw its weight behind campaigners trying to force the British government to seek parliamentary approval to start the formal divorce procedure from the European Union, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Tuesday.

Headline: Prince Harry hits out at media 'harassment' of new U.S. girlfriend
Description: Prince Harry issued a rare statement on Tuesday criticising the media for intruding into the private life of his American girlfriend, saying the press had subjected her to "a wave of abuse and harassment".

Headline: 'Get on with it' - English seaside town has Brexit message for May
Description: The message to Prime Minister Theresa May from this English seaside town rings loud and clear four months after it voted for Brexit: Britain should leave the European Union as soon as possible.

Headline: Sports Direct accused of botched spying attempt on MPs
Description: Embattled British retailer Sports Direct  was forced to defend itself on Tuesday after lawmakers complained of an attempt to spy on them during an unannounced visit to a warehouse that has been slated for poor working conditions.

Headline: UK committed to moving away from coal-fired power plants - minister
Description: Britain remains committed to switching from coal-fired power plants to clean energy, a minister told parliament on Tuesday when asked whether the government was considering backtracking on a plan to close coal-burning stations by 2025.

Headline: Reports Sports Direct tried to spy on MPs 'extraordinary' - minister
Description: Reports that British retailer Sports Direct  attempted to spy on lawmakers who were making an unannounced visit to one of its warehouses are "extraordinary", business minister Greg Clark told parliament on Tuesday.

Headline: 'No revenge' in Brexit but market access needs migration - Juncker
Description: The European Union will not go to "war" or seek revenge on Britain in negotiating its exit from the bloc but London cannot be part of the single market without accepting free migration, EU chief executive Jean-Claude Juncker said on Tuesday.

Headline: After Uber case, UK union pushes for pay deal at Deliveroo
Description: A trade union is seeking recognition from British food delivery firm Deliveroo to allow it to negotiate a collective pay deal for its drivers, in the latest push for greater employment rights that could hit the flourishing 'gig economy'.

Headline: Prince Harry's statement on media 'harassment' of new girlfriend
Description: Britain's Prince Harry issued an unusually forthright statement on Tuesday criticising the media for intruding into the private life of his new American girlfriend, actress Meghan Markle.

Headline: UK economy very strong, government committed to fiscal discipline - May
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said the fundamentals of the British economy were very strong and affirmed her commitment to strengthening public finances after a report indicated that Brexit will prolong the country's reliance on borrowing.

Headline: Now in charge of UK spies, gaffe-prone Boris Johnson surveys their domain
Description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has ventured into the headquarters of the MI6 foreign intelligence service for the first time, praising Britain's spies for stealing secrets in an increasingly unpredictable world.

Headline: May offers improved visa deal as India, UK launch trade talks
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May offered India a possible improved visa deal on Monday, as the two countries kicked off talks on boosting trading links ahead of Britain's departure from the European Union.

Headline: May's passage to India poses dilemma on trade, migration
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will find that the trade-off between market access and migration applies not just to Brexit when she visits India for her first non-EU bilateral trip since Britons voted to quit the bloc.

Headline: Conservative MP quits over policy differences with May's government
Description: MP Stephen Phillips has resigned with immediate effect as a result of "irreconcilable policy differences" with Prime Minister Theresa May's government.

Headline: May confident of winning appeal over Brexit trigger - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is confident of winning an appeal to overturn a court decision that the government must get parliamentary approval to trigger the formal divorce process from the European Union, her spokesman said on Friday.

Headline: BAE, UK government agree start date of 2017 for building of new warships
Description: Britain's BAE Systems said on Friday it had agreed with the UK government that the manufacturing of eight new anti-submarine warships would start in the summer of 2017, adding that a final contract was still being negotiated.

Headline: Locked out by sky-high rents, London's 'nomads' fight for a secure home
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Lillie Basil supposes she was one of the luckier residents of Boundary House, a block of short-stay apartments in rural Hertfordshire for Londoners squeezed out by the capital's chronic housing shortage.

Headline: From stray to screen, the cat putting the spotlight on homelessness in Britain
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - A ginger tabby cat called Bob brought the plight of Britain's homeless to the big screen on Thursday as new figures estimated the number of children living on the streets or in temporary accommodation this Christmas would hit a nine-year high.

Headline: BoE ditches rate cut signal after Brexit hit to sterling
Description: The Bank of England scrapped its plan to cut interest rates, which it said could now move up or down, and raised its forecasts for 2017 growth and inflation sharply due to the slide in sterling since Britain's vote to leave the EU.

Headline: BoE says it may tighten bank capital rules after Brexit relief
Description: Banks in Britain may face stricter capital requirements to counter relief given to banks in the immediate aftermath of the June vote to leave the European Union, a top Bank of England official said on Thursday.

Headline: UK court says Brexit needs parliament's approval, complicates government plans
Description: A British court ruled on Thursday that the government needs parliamentary approval to start the process of leaving the European Union, potentially delaying Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plans.

Headline: White House says EU, Britain must ensure flexible 'Brexit' process
Description: The White House on Thursday urged Britain and the European Union to ensure a flexible and smooth "Brexit" process after a British court ruled the government needed parliamentary approval to start the process of Britain leaving the EU.

Headline: May says Britain already has a good visa system with India
Description: Britain already has a good visa system with India, Prime Minister Theresa May said late on Sunday as she arrived in the country for her first bilateral trip outside of the European Union since June's Brexit vote.

Headline: UK says 600 million pounds of masala bonds to be listed in London
Description: Four rupee-denominated bonds worth a total of 600 million pounds are expected to be listed in London in the next three months, the British government said on Monday, as Prime Minister Theresa May began a two-day visit to India.

Headline: May says 'citizen of the world' criticism was aimed at firms
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said criticisms she made last month about "citizens of the world" were aimed at company executives and firms that did not pay taxes.

Headline: May signals flexibility on visas for Indians
Description: British prime minister Theresa May said on Monday that Britain could show more flexibility in offering visas to Indian visitors if it is possible to step up the pace of returning those who have outstayed their welcome.

Headline: Scrap 'unsustainable' state pension rules, says parliamentary committee
Description: Britain must scrap its system of guaranteed annual pension increases for retired citizens, a committee of lawmakers said on Sunday, calling the rules "inherently unsustainable" and unfair on younger generations.

Headline: May promises EU exit 'in full' despite legal challenge
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would deliver a full exit from the European Union, hitting back at critics of her Brexit strategy who have threatened to try to block the process in parliament.

Headline: After Brexit ruling, May says values independent judiciary
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday that she valued the independence of the judiciary after some British newspapers strongly criticised the judges involved in a court ruling which could delay Brexit.

Headline: Scotland and others expected to join Brexit legal challenge - lead claimant
Description: Scotland's devolved government is expected to join a legal challenge against the British government's plans to trigger an exit from the European Union, the lead claimant in the court case said on Sunday.

Headline: 'Highly unlikely' parliament would block Article 50 trigger - Hunt
Description: Britain's parliament is highly unlikely to block the decision to trigger the Article 50 legal process for leaving the European union, health minister Jeremy Hunt said on Sunday.

Headline: 'You're fired' - Trump effigy feels the heat on UK bonfire night
Description: He turned "You're fired" into his reality show catch-phrase, but it was Donald Trump who went up in flames on Saturday - or at least an effigy of him did, as part of Britain's annual Bonfire Night celebrations.

Headline: Police arrest nearly 50 at Anonymous protest in London
Description: British police said they arrested 47 people on Saturday at an anti-capitalism demonstration in central London organised by the Anonymous hacking group.

Headline: May seeks to boost trade ties with India before Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will use her first bilateral trade trip since taking office to try to boost ties with India before leaving the European Union.

Headline: Labour has 'bottom line' for supporting Brexit vote - Corbyn
Description: The head of Britain's opposition Labour Party will try to block divorce talks with the European Union if the government does not agree to Labour's Brexit demands, potentially leading to an early national election, a newspaper said on Saturday.

Headline: Government backs judicial independence after judges face Brexit heat
Description: Britain's government defended the independence of the country's judiciary on Saturday after three judges came under a wave of criticism from newspapers and a senior official for dealing a blow to the government's Brexit preparations.

Headline: PM May confident of Brexit plans, reassures EU leaders
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May told European Union leaders on Friday she was confident a court ruling that could delay Britain's departure from the bloc would be overturned and said she would stick to her Brexit timetable.

Headline: May's passage to India poses dilemma on trade, migration
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will find that the trade-off between market access and migration applies not just to Brexit when she visits India for her first non-EU bilateral trip since Britons voted to quit the bloc.

Headline: Conservative MP quits over policy differences with May's government
Description: MP Stephen Phillips has resigned with immediate effect as a result of "irreconcilable policy differences" with Prime Minister Theresa May's government.

Headline: May confident of winning appeal over Brexit trigger - spokesman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is confident of winning an appeal to overturn a court decision that the government must get parliamentary approval to trigger the formal divorce process from the European Union, her spokesman said on Friday.

Headline: BAE, UK government agree start date of 2017 for building of new warships
Description: Britain's BAE Systems said on Friday it had agreed with the UK government that the manufacturing of eight new anti-submarine warships would start in the summer of 2017, adding that a final contract was still being negotiated.

Headline: Locked out by sky-high rents, London's 'nomads' fight for a secure home
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Lillie Basil supposes she was one of the luckier residents of Boundary House, a block of short-stay apartments in rural Hertfordshire for Londoners squeezed out by the capital's chronic housing shortage.

Headline: From stray to screen, the cat putting the spotlight on homelessness in Britain
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - A ginger tabby cat called Bob brought the plight of Britain's homeless to the big screen on Thursday as new figures estimated the number of children living on the streets or in temporary accommodation this Christmas would hit a nine-year high.

Headline: BoE ditches rate cut signal after Brexit hit to sterling
Description: The Bank of England scrapped its plan to cut interest rates, which it said could now move up or down, and raised its forecasts for 2017 growth and inflation sharply due to the slide in sterling since Britain's vote to leave the EU.

Headline: BoE says it may tighten bank capital rules after Brexit relief
Description: Banks in Britain may face stricter capital requirements to counter relief given to banks in the immediate aftermath of the June vote to leave the European Union, a top Bank of England official said on Thursday.

Headline: UK court says Brexit needs parliament's approval, complicates government plans
Description: A British court ruled on Thursday that the government needs parliamentary approval to start the process of leaving the European Union, potentially delaying Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plans.

Headline: White House says EU, Britain must ensure flexible 'Brexit' process
Description: The White House on Thursday urged Britain and the European Union to ensure a flexible and smooth "Brexit" process after a British court ruled the government needed parliamentary approval to start the process of Britain leaving the EU.

Headline: Access to EU financial services market key to Britain's Brexit talks - minister
Description: Access to the European Union market for financial services is a key part of Britain's negotiations to leave the bloc and it is vital that the industry remains "highly competitive", financial services minister Simon Kirby said on Thursday,

Headline: Britain's appeal on Article 50 ruling to be settled in UK court - May's spokeswoman
Description: The British government's appeal against a court ruling on its Brexit plans will be settled in the country's Supreme Court, a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday, saying it was not a dispute over EU law.

Headline: UK 2017 election 'base case' after Brexit ruling - Deutsche Bank
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May is likely to have to call a general election next year after being weakened by a High Court ruling that promises far-reaching political consequences, economists at Deutsche Bank told clients on Thursday.

Headline: Labour calls on May to consult parliament on Brexit terms
Description: Britain's main opposition Labour Party said Thursday's court ruling demanding parliamentary approval for the start of the formal divorce from the EU underlined the need for Prime Minister Theresa May to consult lawmakers on her negotiating terms.

Headline: If ruling upheld, Britain to need act of parliament to trigger Brexit - Davis
Description: If upheld, a court ruling demanding parliamentary approval to trigger the formal divorce procedure with the EU would require an act of parliament involving both the upper and lower houses, Britain's Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday.

Headline: UK voters would now opt to stay in the EU - BMG poll
Description: The British electorate would now vote narrowly to stay in the European Union, according to a BMG poll published on Thursday.

Headline: Carney - broad-brush view of economy hasn't changed
Description: The Bank of England's "broad-brush" view of the British economy's progress in the next few years has not changed despite bumping up its growth forecasts for 2017, Governor Mark Carney said on Thursday.

Headline: BoE's Carney says Article 50 court ruling is example of uncertainty
Description: A court ruling that requires Britain to seek parliamentary approval to trigger the Brexit process is an example of uncertainty that could affect the economy, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Thursday.

Headline: Factbox - What now after UK government loses Brexit court case?
Description: The High Court in London has ruled that the British government requires parliamentary approval to trigger the process of exiting the European Union.

Headline: Court ruling does not derail Brexit timetable, says May's spokeswoman
Description: The British government still plans to trigger formal divorce talks with the European Union by the end of March and does not believe a court ruling demanding parliamentary approval will derail that, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said.

Headline: EU's Juncker to speak to May on Friday
Description: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker will speak by telephone to Theresa May on Friday morning at the British prime minister's request, a spokesman for the Commission said.

Headline: UK trade minister - Government will need to wait for appeal on Article 50 ruling
Description: Trade minister Liam Fox said on Thursday Britain would have to wait for a court appeal before it could proceed with plans to trigger the Article 50 legal process for exiting the European Union.

Headline: May says UK should boost trade with Colombia post-Brexit
Description: Britain should boost trade with fast-growing economies like Colombia when it leaves the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday after meeting with Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos.

Headline: UK government disappointed with Article 50 court decision, will respect referendum result
Description: The British government is disappointed with a court decision that it requires parliamentary approval to trigger the process to leave the European Union and is determined to respect the result of June referendum, a spokesman said on Thursday.

Headline: UK government to appeal court ruling on triggering Brexit
Description: The British government said on Thursday it will appeal a decision by the High Court that requires it to gain parliamentary approval before triggering the process of exiting the European Union.

Headline: UK government disappointed by court decision on Article 50 - minister
Description: The British government is disappointed with a decision by England's High Court that it requires parliamentary approval to trigger the process of leaving the European Union, trade minister Liam Fox said on Thursday.

Headline: Gaffe-prone Boris Johnson hits an iceberg
Description: Britain's gaffe-prone foreign minister Boris Johnson seemed to compare Britain's exit from the European Union to the 1912 sinking of the ill-fated Titanic cruise liner, saying Brexit would be a "titanic success".

Headline: Britain could still change its mind over EU divorce, says man who drafted Article 50
Description: Britain could still change its mind about Brexit after triggering its formal divorce talks with the European Union, the man who drafted Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty told the BBC.

Headline: Court to rule on whether London needs parliament to trigger EU exit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will learn on Thursday whether she must seek parliamentary approval before triggering the formal process of leaving the European Union, a step some investors hope will lessen the chances of an economically disruptive "hard Brexit".

Headline: UK pensions regulator targets Green for BHS redress
Description: Britain's Pensions Regulator on Wednesday formally began "enforcement action" against Philip Green, the former owner of BHS, to plug a hole in the collapsed department store's pension fund, saying the billionaire had failed to provide a credible offer.

Headline: England and Scotland to defy FIFA poppy ban
Description: England and Scotland are planning to defy a FIFA ban on players wearing poppies during their World Cup qualifier on Nov. 11, their Football Associations said on Wednesday.

Headline: London High Court to deliver verdict on EU exit case on Thursday
Description: London's High Court will deliver its verdict on Thursday on whether British lawmakers, rather than the government, must trigger the formal process of leaving the European Union, a decision that could affect the circumstances of Britain's exit.

Headline: Factbox - The legal challenge over who can trigger Britain's exit talks from EU
Description: England's High Court is due to rule on Thursday on a challenge to the British government's right to start divorce proceedings from the European Union, lawyers in the case said.

Headline: May says will do utmost to protect agriculture post-Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday the government would do everything possible to get the best deal for the agriculture sector when the country leaves the European Union.

Headline: British court rules government failing to tackle air pollution
Description: UK government measures to tackle air pollution still don't comply with European Union legislation to improve air quality and meet nitrogen dioxide limits, Britain's High Court ruled on Wednesday.

Headline: Supreme Court asked to rule on abortion funding for Northern Ireland residents
Description: Women's rights groups are to ask the British Supreme Court on Wednesday to compel the government to fund abortions for Northern Ireland residents travelling to England to avoid some of the most restrictive abortion laws in Europe.

Headline: Nissan promises indicate 'direction of travel' for Brexit talks - minister
Description: Britain's assurance to Nissan that it is seeking tariff-free trade with the European Union for the motor industry shows the government's broader aims for its EU exit talks, junior Brexit minister David Jones said on Tuesday.

Headline: Under fire, Carney to stay extra year at Bank of England
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Monday he will stay in his job for an extra year until the end of June 2019 to help smooth Britain's departure from the European Union, but he will depart two years short of a full term.

Headline: May welcomes Carney decision to extend Bank of England term - spokeswoman
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May welcomes Bank of England Governor Mark Carney's decision to extend his term at the central bank by one year, her spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: Pharma and aerospace seek Brexit assurances after Nissan deal
Description: Britain's pharmaceutical and aerospace industries, both big exporters, are stepping up pressure on the government for assurances about their future after last week's post-Brexit deal with carmaker Nissan.

Headline: UK minister says told Nissan he will emphasise common ground with EU
Description: The British government made several assurances to Japanese carmaker Nissan before last week's announcement it would build two new models in Britain, business minister Greg Clark said on Monday.

Headline: May's spokeswoman declines to comment on talks with Carney
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman on Monday declined to comment on the contents of a meeting with Bank of England Central Bank Governor Mark Carney.

Headline: Northern Ireland leader says special status for province possible after Brexit
Description: Northern Ireland could have a different relationship to the European Union's single market or customs union from the rest of the United Kingdom following its exit from the EU, the leader of the British province said on Saturday.

Headline: May believes Carney best man for BoE governor job - spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May believes Bank of England Governor Mark Carney is the best man for the job and would support him staying on in his role, her spokeswoman said on Monday.

Headline: May to hold long standing meeting with BoE's Carney on Monday - BBC
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will hold a long standing meeting with Bank of England Governor Mark Carney at her 10 Downing Street office on Monday, the BBC reported amid mounting speculation over his future.

Headline: May wants 'maximum freedom' in EU single market - spokeswoman
Description: Theresa May is seeking freedom for businesses to operate within the European Union's single market, her spokeswoman said on Monday when asked what kind of trade deal the prime minister was seeking after leaving the EU.

Headline: Britain wants tariff-free trade for motor industry after Brexit
Description: Britain told Nissan it would aim for tariff-free trade with Europe for the motor industry after Brexit, persuading the Japanese company to invest in the country's biggest car plant, a cabinet minister said on Sunday.

Headline: Nissan deal opens door for Scotland concessions - SNP
Description: The British government's promises to Japanese carmaker Nissan open the door to a special deal for Scotland if Britain leaves the European Union, Scottish nationalists said on Sunday.

Headline: Northern Irish court sides with May over Brexit challenge
Description: Northern Ireland's High Court on Friday rejected an attempt to block Britain's exit from the European Union, saying that neither the province's parliament nor its laws could override a decision by the British government.

Headline: Northern Irish Brexit ruling has 'no automatic implications' for Scotland - Scottish government
Description: A ruling by Northern Ireland's High Court to reject an attempt to block the United Kingdom's exit from the European Union had no immediate read-across to Scotland's situation, a spokesman for the Scottish government said on Friday.

Headline: May's Nissan deal opens floodgates as rivals seek Brexit reassurance
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's deal to keep Nissan  investing in Britain opened the floodgates on Friday to demands from rival car companies chasing their own assurances from the  government that they won't be hurt by Brexit.

Headline: Northern Ireland rights activist to appeal Brexit court ruling
Description: A Northern Ireland rights activist whose attempt to block Britain's exit from the European Union was rejected on Friday by the province's High Court said he would appeal to the British Supreme Court.

Headline: UK government welcomes Northern Ireland court ruling on Brexit
Description: The British government welcomed a ruling by Northern Ireland's High Court on Friday that the law of the province did not restrict the ability of Prime Minister Theresa May to trigger an exit from the European Union.

Headline: UK economy escapes short-term Brexit hit, gets Nissan boost
Description: Britain's economy slowed only slightly in the three months after the Brexit vote and carmaker Nissan said it would build more cars in the country, tempering fears about the immediate economic impact of the decision to leave the European Union.

Headline: Britain sets up funds to tackle the 'barbaric evil' of modern slavery
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Britain unveiled two multi-million pound funds on Thursday to tackle modern slavery overseas and at home as part of a drive to end the crime described as a "barbaric evil" by Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: UK car industry body says govt must give public Brexit reassurance to investors
Description: Britain should publicly reassure firms that the key advantages of European Union membership will be kept following Brexit, a car industry body said on Thursday, after Nissan  said it would build a new model at its English plant.

Headline: Hammond says economy needs support despite third quarter growth
Description: The Chancellor of exchequer Philip Hammond said he would need to take steps to support growth in his first budget statement next month, despite data on Thursday showing the economy slowed less than expected after Britain voted to leave the European Union.

Headline: UK car exports offset domestic drop in September output rise
Description: British car production rose by an annual 0.9 percent in September with a rise in exports compensating for a fall in demand at home, an industry body said on Thursday.

Headline: Northern Ireland court to rule on Brexit challenge on Friday
Description: Northern Ireland's High Court will rule on Friday on a challenge against British plans to leave the European Union without a vote in parliament, the first judgment in legal cases that are being closely watched by politicians and markets.

Headline: Britain's mixed messages deepen Brexit rifts with EU
Description: In the hours before Theresa May stepped to the podium in Birmingham earlier this month to lay out her vision for a "fully independent, sovereign" Britain, she made a discreet round of telephone calls to European leaders.

Headline: GDP data shows Britain's economy can cope with EU exit - Hammond
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said that Thursday's better-than-expected GDP growth showed the economy was resilient and well-placed to cope with the challenges thrown up by Britain's exit from the European Union.

Headline: Fewer EU nationals apply to study in Britain after Brexit vote
Description: The number of early applicants to British universities from other European Union countries has dropped by 9 percent year-on-year following Britain's vote to leave the EU, official data showed.

Headline: UK economy set to sidestep third-quarter slump, but tougher times lie ahead
Description: Britain escaped a severe economic slowdown in the three months after the Brexit referendum shock, official figures are expected to show on Thursday, further diminishing the chance of a fresh interest rate cut by the Bank of England next week.

Headline: May's office plays down pre-referendum remarks to Goldman Sachs
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's office played down the significance of comments she made before the referendum warning that companies would leave Britain if the country backed Brexit, after the Guardian newspaper published a recording of a private meeting she held with Goldman Sachs.

Headline: Man charged after suspicious item found on London tube train
Description: British police said on Wednesday a man would appear in court on Thursday in connection with an incident last week in which a suspicious item was found on a London underground train.

Headline: EU parliament refers scuffling UKIP MEPs to police
Description: French police will look into a scuffle in the European Parliament between two members of the UK Independence Party, which left one in hospital with a head injury, the speaker of the EU legislature said on Wednesday.

Headline: Liam Fox says CETA delays show need to reach UK-EU deal before Brexit
Description: The difficulties in concluding an EU-Canada trade deal show the importance of Britain reaching an agreement over its future relationship with the EU before it leaves the bloc, British trade minister Liam Fox said on Wednesday.

Headline: An UK-EU treaty would be debated by both parliamentary chambers - minister
Description: If Britain's renegotiation of its relationship with the European Union results in a new treaty, that will be examined by both houses of parliament, junior Brexit minister David Jones said on Wednesday.

Headline: Surge in British trips to Ireland eases after Brexit vote
Description: Trips by British tourists to Ireland grew at the slowest rate in over a year in the three months after Britons voted on June 23 to leave the European Union.

Headline: City of London calls for post-Brexit banking rules that aid competitiveness
Description: London's financial district has called for a UK regulatory regime that does not harm competitiveness, responding to bankers' fears that being outside the European Union will reduce the capital's clout in global markets.

Headline: May says Brexit vote will not undermine N.Ireland peace deal
Description: There is no reason Britain's June vote to leave the European Union should undermine a 1998 Northern Irish peace deal, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Carney says cannot ignore 'fairly substantial' sterling drop
Description: Chancellor Mark Carney said on Tuesday that there were limits to the central bank's ability to ignore the effect of sterling's slide on inflation, as policymakers consider whether to cut interest rates next week.

Headline: BoE's Carney says some global bank capital reforms will be cut
Description: A key element of new bank rules, widely criticised by the finance industry for unnecessarily bumping up capital requirements, will be radically cut back, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Tuesday.

Headline: Highlights - Bank of England's Carney speaks in parliament
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney spoke to a committee of lawmakers from the House of Lords in Britain's parliament on Tuesday.

Headline: Carney says UK-EU trade links could be global template
Description: Britain's future trading relations in financial services with the European Union could be a template for a global regulatory system, Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said on Tuesday.

Headline: May defies critics to back new $22 billion Heathrow runway
Description: Britain backed a $22 billion (18.06 billion pounds) expansion of London's Heathrow Airport on Tuesday, ending 25 years of indecision with an ambitious plan to boost global trade links following the vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: UK whisky lobby head steps down to help foreign minister with Brexit
Description: The head of a group representing Scotland's whisky industry will become a close aide to British Foreign Minister Boris Johnson, part of a drive to strengthen Britain's diplomatic and trading clout as it leaves the European Union.

Headline: MP from May's party resigns after Heathrow decision
Description: Conservative lawmaker Zac Goldsmith, a vocal opponent of the expansion of Heathrow Airport, on Tuesday notified the government of his decision to resign from parliament, the finance ministry said in a statement.

Headline: British Airways welcomes plans to cap charges at expanded Heathrow
Description: The chief of British Airways-owner IAG  welcomed Britain's commitment to cap airline charges in its plans to build a new runway at Heathrow.

Headline: Factbox - Reaction to UK decision to allow third runway at Heathrow
Description: The British government gave Heathrow Airport the green light on Tuesday to build a third runway.

Headline: France's Juppe - must change tax policy to attract London firms
Description: France must fix the "many mistakes" that have been made on tax policy, the leading candidate in next year's presidential election Alain Juppe said on Tuesday, saying that would help Paris win the battle to lure London-based firms worried by Brexit.

Headline: British government not planning change of heart on airport expansion - minister
Description: British transport minister Chris Grayling said on Tuesday that the public consultation process on expanding Heathrow Airport was not likely to change its position in favour of a new runway at the west London site.

Headline: Heathrow expansion 'not right thing to do' - Boris Johnson
Description: Building a third runway at Heathrow Airport is not the right thing to do and risks fuelling a clamour for a fourth runway to be built in future, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Tuesday after the government approved the expansion.

Headline: Boris Johnson says Heathrow third runway 'undeliverable'
Description: Britain's Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Tuesday a third runway at Heathrow Airport was "undeliverable", the Press Association news agency reported on Twitter.

Headline: UK transport minister promises timely consultation on Heathrow expansion
Description: Britain will conduct the required public consultation on expanding Heathrow Airport in a "timely" fashion, transport minister Chris Grayling said on Tuesday after a government decision to build a new runway at the west London site.

Headline: Police arrest teenager on terrorism offences over item found on London train
Description: British police said on Friday they had arrested a teenager  under terrorism laws following the discovery of a "suspicious item" on a London underground train near the Canary Wharf financial district a day earlier.

Headline: Central banks to hear initial verdict on sterling's October 7 crash in November - sources
Description: Officials looking into the factors behind the dramatic fall in sterling on Oct. 7 will issue an initial report to a group of global central banks in early November, sources with knowledge of the investigation said.

Headline: UK public finances worsen, adding to Hammond's headache
Description: Britain's public finances showed a much bigger than expected deficit in September, a setback for Chancellor Philip Hammond as he prepares to deliver the country's first budget plans since the Brexit vote.

Headline: UK says there are no plans to alter Calais border agreement
Description: The Le Touquet agreement which allows British officials to check passports in France and vice versa is working and there are no plans to change it, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Friday.

Headline: Sanders falls short in election - in Britain
Description: Former U.S. Democratic presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders' elder brother has failed to be elected to the British parliament.

Headline: Britain accuses Russia of "making the situation worse" in Syria
Description: Britain sought to shame Russia on Friday for its deadly air strikes on the Syrian city of Aleppo, during a special session of the United Nations Human Rights Council called by London to set up a special inquiry into violations.

Headline: May's Conservatives see majority cut in Cameron's constituency
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's ruling Conservative Party held the parliamentary constituency vacated by David Cameron but saw its majority cut significantly as thousands of voters flocked to a pro-European Union opposition party.

Headline: At her first summit, May tries to reassure EU on Brexit
Description: Attending her first European Union summit since Britain's vote to leave the bloc, Prime Minister Theresa May tried to reassure EU leaders over Brexit but was told by French President Francois Hollande to prepare for tough negotiations.

Headline: Police explode suspicious object at London station, launch terrorism inquiry
Description: British police carried out a controlled explosion on a suspicious item found at a London underground station on Thursday, and said counter-terrorism officers had launched an investigation.

Headline: MPs back stripping Philip Green of knighthood over BHS collapse
Description: British lawmakers backed stripping billionaire Philip Green of his knighthood over the collapse of BHS department store, in a symbolic move on Thursday that will raise pressure on the tycoon over his promises to resolve the company's pension problems.

Headline: UK to pardon thousands of gay men convicted under defunct laws
Description: Britain is to pardon thousands of gay and bisexual men who were convicted of crimes under sexual offence laws which have now been abolished, following on from the 2013 exoneration of celebrated World War Two codebreaker Alan Turing.

Headline: Factbox: UK heads for Brexit showdown with EU - what's at stake
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will come under pressure from other European Union leaders on Thursday to say what kind of deal she wants for Britain when it leaves the bloc.

Headline: UK will ensure stability of financial sector - Brexit minister
Description: The British government will do whatever is needed to ensure the stability of the financial services sector and markets during the process of negotiating Britain's exit from the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday.

Headline: Not in UK interest to restrict movement of talent - Brexit minister
Description: It will not be in Britain's national interest to restrict the free movement of highly talented people when it leaves the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday.

Headline: British parliament must have vote on final Brexit deal - Hilary Benn
Description: Britain's parliament must have a vote on an eventual agreement between the United Kingdom and the European Union on leaving the bloc, said a senior lawmaker who is chairman of parliament's Brexit committee.

Headline: Focus on Britain's post-Brexit future, May to tell EU leaders
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will tell European Union leaders on Thursday it is time to start talking about future EU ties with Britain and put paid to suggestions her government might reconsider Brexit.

Headline: Scottish government publishes draft bill for second independence referendum
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon publishes a draft bill for a second independence referendum on Thursday as she ramps up the pressure on the British government to make sure Scotland's voice is heard in Brexit talks.

Headline: Brexit vote was for control over immigration, but we want good exit deal - May
Description: Britain's vote to leave the European Union was clearly a vote to regain control over immigration, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday, adding that she wanted to ensure the country got a good deal for businesses from exit negotiations.

Headline: British banks call for end to surcharge on profits amid Brexit uncertainty
Description: British banks are calling for the government to phase out an extra tax on profits at a time of significant upheaval following Britain's vote to leave the European Union and its potential hit to London's financial dominance.

Headline: May says will ensure best possible access to European market
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday she would ensure Britain has the best possible access to trade with and operate within the European market after it has left the European Union.

Headline: Britain will make airport expansion decision on Oct. 25 - transport minister
Description: The British government will make a decision on Tuesday about where to allow airport expansion in south east England, transport minister Chris Grayling said on Sunday.

Headline: British anti-terrorist police find second 'suspicious item' after London arrest
Description: Counter-terrorism police investigating the discovery of a "suspicious item" on a London train this week said they found another such device on Saturday when they searched a house in Devon, western England.

Headline: Lions' den or nest of doves? May's first EU encounter was businesslike
Description: A lions' den or a nest of doves? For Theresa May, her first meeting with all the other European Union leaders since she became British prime minister ended up being described by most merely as businesslike.

Headline: May ready for tough talks, but will fight over EU market
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday Britain's negotiations to leave the European Union would take time and that she was ready for some "difficult moments", but would fight to remain part of the bloc's single market.

Headline: London firefighters leading response to airport incident - police
Description: London's fire brigade is leading the emergency response to an incident at London City airport on Friday which led to hundreds of passengers being evacuated and two taken to hospital with breathing difficulties, police said.

Headline: Police arrest teenager on terrorism offences over item found on London train
Description: British police said on Friday they had arrested a teenager  under terrorism laws following the discovery of a "suspicious item" on a London underground train near the Canary Wharf financial district a day earlier.

Headline: Central banks to hear initial verdict on sterling's October 7 crash in November - sources
Description: Officials looking into the factors behind the dramatic fall in sterling on Oct. 7 will issue an initial report to a group of global central banks in early November, sources with knowledge of the investigation said.

Headline: UK public finances worsen, adding to Hammond's headache
Description: Britain's public finances showed a much bigger than expected deficit in September, a setback for Chancellor Philip Hammond as he prepares to deliver the country's first budget plans since the Brexit vote.

Headline: UK says there are no plans to alter Calais border agreement
Description: The Le Touquet agreement which allows British officials to check passports in France and vice versa is working and there are no plans to change it, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Friday.

Headline: Sanders falls short in election - in Britain
Description: Former U.S. Democratic presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders' elder brother has failed to be elected to the British parliament.

Headline: Britain accuses Russia of "making the situation worse" in Syria
Description: Britain sought to shame Russia on Friday for its deadly air strikes on the Syrian city of Aleppo, during a special session of the United Nations Human Rights Council called by London to set up a special inquiry into violations.

Headline: May's Conservatives see majority cut in Cameron's constituency
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May's ruling Conservative Party held the parliamentary constituency vacated by David Cameron but saw its majority cut significantly as thousands of voters flocked to a pro-European Union opposition party.

Headline: At her first summit, May tries to reassure EU on Brexit
Description: Attending her first European Union summit since Britain's vote to leave the bloc, Prime Minister Theresa May tried to reassure EU leaders over Brexit but was told by French President Francois Hollande to prepare for tough negotiations.

Headline: Police explode suspicious object at London station, launch terrorism inquiry
Description: British police carried out a controlled explosion on a suspicious item found at a London underground station on Thursday, and said counter-terrorism officers had launched an investigation.

Headline: MPs back stripping Philip Green of knighthood over BHS collapse
Description: British lawmakers backed stripping billionaire Philip Green of his knighthood over the collapse of BHS department store, in a symbolic move on Thursday that will raise pressure on the tycoon over his promises to resolve the company's pension problems.

Headline: UK to pardon thousands of gay men convicted under defunct laws
Description: Britain is to pardon thousands of gay and bisexual men who were convicted of crimes under sexual offence laws which have now been abolished, following on from the 2013 exoneration of celebrated World War Two codebreaker Alan Turing.

Headline: Factbox: UK heads for Brexit showdown with EU - what's at stake
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will come under pressure from other European Union leaders on Thursday to say what kind of deal she wants for Britain when it leaves the bloc.

Headline: UK will ensure stability of financial sector - Brexit minister
Description: The British government will do whatever is needed to ensure the stability of the financial services sector and markets during the process of negotiating Britain's exit from the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday.

Headline: Not in UK interest to restrict movement of talent - Brexit minister
Description: It will not be in Britain's national interest to restrict the free movement of highly talented people when it leaves the European Union, Brexit minister David Davis said on Thursday.

Headline: British parliament must have vote on final Brexit deal - Hilary Benn
Description: Britain's parliament must have a vote on an eventual agreement between the United Kingdom and the European Union on leaving the bloc, said a senior lawmaker who is chairman of parliament's Brexit committee.

Headline: Britain looks at paying into EU budget after Brexit to get market access - FT
Description: Britain might continue to pay billions of pounds into the European Union's budget after Brexit to maintain single-market access for the City of London and other sectors under plans being discussed by government, the Financial Times reported.

Headline: Sales of double-digit million pound UK homes fall 86 percent
Description: The number of British homes worth 10 million pounds or more sold over the summer fell by an annual 86 percent, hit by property tax hikes and the Brexit vote, according to official data analysed by a residential fund.

Headline: Booming property auctions lift Brexit gloom in British real estate
