Description: Commercial property auctions are proving an unlikely bright spot in Britain's real estate market where a steep drop in sterling has attracted overseas buyers and local investors are as yet unfazed by potential fallout from Brexit.

Headline: Top Brexiteer Boris Johnson penned arguments for staying in EU - report
Description: Boris Johnson, who campaigned prominently for Britain to leave the European Union ahead of a June referendum, argued in favour of remaining in the bloc in an unpublished newspaper column two days before backing Brexit, according to a newspaper report.

Headline: MPs press Theresa May to allow a vote on EU strategy
Description: British MPs from across the political spectrum will press their bid to force Prime Minister Theresa May to give parliament a vote on her negotiating strategy for leaving the European Union, saying she had no mandate for a "hard Brexit".

Headline: Second Scottish independence vote 'highly likely' before 2020 - Sturgeon
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Sunday it was "highly likely" that Scotland would hold a new independence referendum before 2020 after Britain voted to leave the European Union.

Headline: Labour Party not doing enough on anti-Semitism - lawmakers
Description: Britain's opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has not done enough to stamp out anti-Jewish sentiment in his party, a prominent parliamentary committee said on Sunday.

Headline: PM May heads to India with eye on post-Brexit trade
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will lead a delegation of small and medium-size businesses to India in November as part of efforts to bolster trade with countries outside the European Union as Britain prepares to leave the bloc.

Headline: More Britons prioritise EU trade than immigration controls - poll
Description: Britons who want the government to prioritise favourable trade deals with the European Union when negotiating Britain's exit from the bloc outnumber those who think it should prioritise reducing immigration, a poll has found.

Headline: Britain can't get full single market access with free movement concessions - Merkel
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Saturday that Britain could not get concessions on the freedom of movement while retaining full access to the European single market, or other countries would want the same.

Headline: Theresa May to step into Brussels lions' den
Description: Theresa May's first EU summit was never going to be easy but Thursday's encounter in Brussels may be a thoroughly bleak affair now that fellow leaders feel she has taken a hard line on breaking away from the European Union.

Headline: London High Court will decide EU exit case 'as quickly as possible'
Description: London's High Court said on Tuesday it would rule "as quickly as possible" on whether British MPs, and not the government alone, must trigger the formal process of leaving the European Union, in a case closely watched by politicians and markets.

Headline: Bernie Sanders' brother Larry campaigns in rural England
Description: Larry Sanders, elder brother of former U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Bernie, was pressing the flesh in his own campaign on Tuesday as he took to the streets ahead of an election this week in rural Oxfordshire, central England.

Headline: Hammond told May he will not quit - Telegraph
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond has told Prime Minister Theresa May that he will not quit the government after media reports of a split among senior ministers over Brexit, the Daily Telegraph said, citing an unidentified Hammond ally.

Headline: Britain to make long-delayed decision on airport expansion next week
Description: Britain will make a long-awaited decision next week on where to allow airport expansion near London, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokeswoman said on Tuesday, with ministers who oppose it given the rare opportunity to publicly voice their dissent.

Headline: UK government to seek to curb immigration through 'targeted visa system'
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has tasked a team of ministers with cutting immigration, including through a "targeted visa system", according to a government document published on Tuesday.

Headline: Staying put in run-down London estate, residents resist demolition
Description: You would never guess from inside Beverley Robinson's tidy flat, with its potted plants, family photos and panoramic view of London, that her building is awaiting demolition.

Headline: May leaning toward approving Heathrow expansion - Financial Times
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is leaning toward approving a  plan to build a new runway at London's Heathrow airport, the Financial Times reported on Monday citing Whitehall officials.

Headline: Central bankers have 'lost the plot', William Hague says
Description: Unless central bankers stop sowing discord by inflating a bubble with make-believe money, the world's top central banks will find their independence challenged, former Conservative Party leader William Hague was quoted as saying on Tuesday.

Headline: Man arrested over alleged rape inside UK parliament
Description: A 23-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of rape following an alleged incident inside Britain's Houses of Parliament, London police said on Tuesday.

Headline: EU's Tusk says Britain might yet back out of Brexit
Description: Britain might ultimately decide not leave the European Union as the EU will not offer London any softer terms than a damaging "hard Brexit", Donald Tusk, who will run the negotiations for Brussels, said on Thursday.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon sparks Brexit duel with May, plans independence bill
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon raised the prospect of a second independence referendum by 2019, accusing the British government of ignoring Scotland's interests by pursuing a "hard" exit from the European Union.

Headline: Russian Orthodox Patriarch, Britain's Queen Elizabeth to meet in London - TASS
Description: The head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Kirill, will meet Britain's Queen Elizabeth during a visit to London this weekend, Russia's TASS news agency reported on Thursday.

Headline: UK's Brexit vote had no constitutional substance, court hears
Description: Britain's vote in a June referendum to leave the European Union had no constitutional substance, according to lawyers leading a bid to force the government to seek parliamentary approval before formally starting the Brexit process.

Headline: UK to force suspected criminals to reveal source of wealth
Description: Britain will give law enforcement agencies the power to force suspected criminals to explain the source of their wealth under new legislation published on Thursday.

Headline: Plunging pound and threats put EU farm workers off the UK
Description: For the last 18 years, Jerzy Kwapniewski has left his home in Poland to spend the summer months picking apples and hops on a farm in central England. He plans to look for work in Germany next year.

Headline: Britain's EU divorce won't be acrimonious, says Johnson
Description: Foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday Britain's exit from the European Union would not be acrimonious, adding he hoped to negotiate a new relationship with the bloc that would be more valuable than the current one.

Headline: Scotland to publish independence referendum consultation bill next week
Description: Scotland will publish a fresh independence referendum Bill for consultation next week, part of a strategy to ensure that Scotland's voice is heard in the negotiations to take Britain out of the European Union, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced on Thursday.

Headline: Johnson says Britain can control borders and remain open to skilled labour
Description: Britain's post-Brexit goal of lower immigration and tighter border controls does not mean that it will have to close its doors to skilled workers from around the world, foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday.

Headline: Punishing UK financial industry doesn't makes sense for EU - minister
Description: Punishing Britain's financial sector during negotiations on the country's exit from the European Union would not make economic sense for the bloc, British foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday.

Headline: Second Scottish independence vote 'highly likely' before 2020 - Sturgeon
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Sunday it was "highly likely" that Scotland would hold a new independence referendum before 2020 after Britain voted to leave the European Union.

Headline: Labour Party not doing enough on anti-Semitism - lawmakers
Description: Britain's opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has not done enough to stamp out anti-Jewish sentiment in his party, a prominent parliamentary committee said on Sunday.

Headline: PM May heads to India with eye on post-Brexit trade
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will lead a delegation of small and medium-size businesses to India in November as part of efforts to bolster trade with countries outside the European Union as Britain prepares to leave the bloc.

Headline: More Britons prioritise EU trade than immigration controls - poll
Description: Britons who want the government to prioritise favourable trade deals with the European Union when negotiating Britain's exit from the bloc outnumber those who think it should prioritise reducing immigration, a poll has found.

Headline: Britain can't get full single market access with free movement concessions - Merkel
Description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said on Saturday that Britain could not get concessions on the freedom of movement while retaining full access to the European single market, or other countries would want the same.

Headline: Sturgeon primes Scotland for all options after Brexit vote
Description: Scotland's devolved government is preparing for all possibilities including independence after Britain leaves the EU, and is planning steps to protect its trade ties with Europe, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Saturday.

Headline: After 950 years, Battle of Hastings plays out again
Description: Arrows flew and swords clanged as thousands re-enacted the Battle of Hastings on its 950th anniversary on Saturday at a sold-out event marking a bloody day that changed the course of English history.

Headline: Britain pays compensation to victims of sex attacks by Libyan cadets
Description: Britain's Ministry of Defence has paid compensation to two people who suffered sex attacks in 2014 by Libyan cadets who were being trained at a British army barracks.

Headline: BoE's Carney pushes back against criticism from PM May
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney hit back at criticism from British Prime Minister Theresa May of the central bank's low interest rates, saying on Friday that he would not "take instruction" from politicians on how to do his job.

Headline: Britain should back large-scale energy storage - parliamentary committee
Description: Britain should support large-scale electricity storage schemes to help make intermittent renewable energy sources such as wind and solar power available around the clock, a parliamentary committee report said on Saturday.

Headline: Scotland could control its own migration after Brexit, says Scots minister
Description: Scotland may try to wrest control over migration as part of a new enhanced devolution deal once Britain leaves the European Union, Scotland's minister for EU negotiations said on Friday.

Headline: Accused UK "flash crash" trader to be extradited to U.S.
Description: A London-based trader accused of contributing to the 2010 Wall Street "flash crash" by placing bogus orders to spoof the market lost his legal bid to stop extradition on Friday and will now be sent to the United States to face trial.

Headline: PM May rejects suggestion by EU's Tusk that Brexit may not happen - spokeswoman
Description: Britain is committed to leaving the European Union, a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Friday, slapping down a suggestion from European Council President Donald Tusk that the country might ultimately change its mind.

Headline: British banks keep cyber attacks under wraps to protect image
Description: Britain's banks are not reporting the full extent of cyber attacks to regulators for fear of punishment or bad publicity, bank executives and providers of security systems say.

Headline: Tesco, Unilever settle prices row after pound's Brexit dive
Description: Britain's biggest retailer, Tesco , settled a pricing row with Unilever  after halting online sales of goods produced by the Anglo-Dutch giant in a dispute caused by a plunge in the pound since Britons voted to leave the EU.

Headline: EU's Tusk says Britain might yet back out of Brexit
Description: Britain might ultimately decide not leave the European Union as the EU will not offer London any softer terms than a damaging "hard Brexit", Donald Tusk, who will run the negotiations for Brussels, said on Thursday.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon sparks Brexit duel with May, plans independence bill
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon raised the prospect of a second independence referendum by 2019, accusing the British government of ignoring Scotland's interests by pursuing a "hard" exit from the European Union.

Headline: Russian Orthodox Patriarch, Britain's Queen Elizabeth to meet in London - TASS
Description: The head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Kirill, will meet Britain's Queen Elizabeth during a visit to London this weekend, Russia's TASS news agency reported on Thursday.

Headline: UK's Brexit vote had no constitutional substance, court hears
Description: Britain's vote in a June referendum to leave the European Union had no constitutional substance, according to lawyers leading a bid to force the government to seek parliamentary approval before formally starting the Brexit process.

Headline: UK to force suspected criminals to reveal source of wealth
Description: Britain will give law enforcement agencies the power to force suspected criminals to explain the source of their wealth under new legislation published on Thursday.

Headline: Plunging pound and threats put EU farm workers off the UK
Description: For the last 18 years, Jerzy Kwapniewski has left his home in Poland to spend the summer months picking apples and hops on a farm in central England. He plans to look for work in Germany next year.

Headline: Britain's EU divorce won't be acrimonious, says Johnson
Description: Foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday Britain's exit from the European Union would not be acrimonious, adding he hoped to negotiate a new relationship with the bloc that would be more valuable than the current one.

Headline: Scotland to publish independence referendum consultation bill next week
Description: Scotland will publish a fresh independence referendum Bill for consultation next week, part of a strategy to ensure that Scotland's voice is heard in the negotiations to take Britain out of the European Union, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced on Thursday.

Headline: Johnson says Britain can control borders and remain open to skilled labour
Description: Britain's post-Brexit goal of lower immigration and tighter border controls does not mean that it will have to close its doors to skilled workers from around the world, foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday.

Headline: Punishing UK financial industry doesn't makes sense for EU - minister
Description: Punishing Britain's financial sector during negotiations on the country's exit from the European Union would not make economic sense for the bloc, British foreign minister Boris Johnson said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain lacks policies to meet emissions targets – government advisers
Description: Britain lacks the policies needed to achieve its domestic emissions targets, and should by February set out new plans to meet them, the government's climate advisers said on Thursday.

Headline: British Airways opposed to any expansion-driven hike in Heathrow fees - CEO
Description: The chief executive of British Airways said the airline would oppose any move by its main airport, Heathrow [FERHT.UL], to raise its charges if the London hub is given permission to expand.

Headline: May says MPs can debate Brexit process, no Article 50 vote
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday parliament would have every opportunity to debate her government's plans to leave the European Union, but ruled out letting it vote on triggering the formal Brexit procedure.

Headline: Brexit minister says would be 'expensive' to reveal EU exit priorities
Description: Britain cannot reveal its top priorities in upcoming talks with the European Union on leaving the bloc, because doing so would be "expensive" for the government, Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday.

Headline: Brexit minister Davis - It is the government's right to trigger Article 50
Description: Britain's government has the right to trigger Article 50, the formal legal process for leaving the European Union, before beginning exit negotiations with the bloc, Brexit minister David Davis told parliament on Wednesday.

Headline: Not possible yet for UK to state detailed EU exit aims - Brexit minister
Description: Britain is not yet in a position to give details of what it wants from negotiations on leaving the European Union beyond its "overarching aims", Brexit minister David Davis said on Wednesday.

Headline: May says parliament will get opportunity to debate Brexit
Description: The idea the British parliament would not get to discuss and debate Brexit is "completely wrong", Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: PM May says wants maximum possible access to EU market post-Brexit
Description: Britain will see a deal with the European Union that will include maximum possible access to the bloc's single market once it leaves the EU, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: British parliament will not vote on triggering EU divorce - PM's spokeswoman
Description: There will not be a vote in Britain's parliament on triggering formal divorce talks with the European Union, a spokeswoman for British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Wednesday.

Headline: Police failures undermine UK slavery fight, says commissioner
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Poor coordination and a failure to prosecute traffickers is undermining progress in Britain's fight against modern slavery, even as groundbreaking legislation starts to bite, the UK's anti-slavery tsar said.

Headline: May always saw parliament playing important Brexit role - spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May always wanted parliament to play "an important role" in Britain's departure from the European Union and her agreement to demands for a "full and transparent" debate in the chamber reflects that, her spokeswoman said.

Headline: British MP likens Russia's behaviour in Syria to that of Nazis
Description: A senior British member of parliament has accused Russia of targeting civilians in Syria in the same way the Nazis behaved at Guernica during the Spanish civil war of the 1930s.

Headline: Russia says UK allegations of aid convoy attack are 'Russophobic hysteria'
Description: Accusations by British Foreign Minster Boris Johnson of a Russian attack on an aid convoy in Syria are "Russophobic hysteria," the Russian Defence Ministry said on Wednesday.

Headline: Exclusive - In Britain, some pro-Europe MPs now back EU divorce talks: Reuters poll
Description: A number of members of parliament who opposed a British exit from the European Union in June's referendum would now back a start of formal divorce proceedings from the bloc - provided parliament gets to decide at all, a Reuters poll showed.

Headline: UK, China agree deal to more than double number of flights - PM May's spokesman
Description: The British and Chinese governments have agreed a deal to increase the number of flights between the two countries to 200 per week from 80, Prime Minister Theresa May's spokesman said on Tuesday.

Headline: A duchess and a new royal yacht - the future of British trade diplomacy?
Description: As Britain sets sail in uncharted waters on the lookout for post-Brexit trade deals, members of parliament and a former diplomat have earmarked two key weapons: the Duchess of Cambridge and a new royal yacht.

Headline: Getting best Brexit deal for banks "absolute priority" - UK minister
Description: Getting the best deal for the City of London will be an "absolute priority" in Brexit trade talks with the European Union, Britain's financial services minister said on Tuesday as banks warned they may start moving from London next year.

Headline: Bankers' love of London complicates Brexit relocation plans
Description: As Britain heads for the EU exit, financial firms intending to move London-based jobs to continental Europe face a costly choice: offer generous relocation and redundancy packages, or expect a flood of lawsuits from disgruntled staff.

Headline: May targets finance industry for failing to promote women
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May criticised Britain's finance industry for failing to promote and retain women on Tuesday as the government revealed that some of the biggest players have committed to having at least 30 percent in senior roles by 2021.

Headline: Brexit minister says UK has negotiating leverage on financial passporting
Description: Britain will have leverage in talks with the European Union over so-called "passporting" rights, which allow financial services to be sold into the EU states from London, Brexit minister David Davis told parliament on Monday.

Headline: Danish PM tells May will aim for "friendly divorce" with Britain
Description: Danish Prime Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen said on Monday he would work for a "friendly divorce" between Britain and the European Union when talks over an exit deal begin.

Headline: May says expects to guarantee rights of EU citizens in UK after Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she hoped Britain's exit from the EU would be a smooth process and that she expected to guarantee the rights of EU citizens already in Britain.

Headline: Brexit minister - We will reject any attempt to delay EU exit
Description: Britain's government will reject any attempt to ignore the result of its referendum vote to leave the European Union or to unduly delay the process of exiting the bloc, Brexit minister David Davis told parliament on Monday.

Headline: New prime minister to decide on old runway problem in October
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will decide where to allow new airport capacity near London this month, a long-awaited ruling that will help shape Britain's economy and trading ties following its vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: Second Brexit vote 'not acceptable' - PM May's spokesman
Description: The British government said on Monday that holding a second vote in parliament on the country's exit from the European Union would not be acceptable, but that lawmakers would have a role to play in scrutinising the Brexit process.

Headline: After May's Brexit pledge, Europeans close ranks
Description: The concerted response from Berlin, Paris and Brussels to British Prime Minister Theresa May's announcement last week of a March deadline to open divorce talks with the European Union made clear the bloc is not waiting idly for London to call.

Headline: British economy losing steam as business investment wilts, surveys show
Description: Britain's economy appears to be losing steam, with major business surveys showing a marked slowdown in the services sector and boardrooms beset by doubt about the future following the country's vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: British government to make airport decision in October - PM's spokesman
Description: The British government decision on whether to build new airport capacity at London's Heathrow [FERHT.UL] or Gatwick will be announced in October, the Prime Minister's spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: Police issue warning as creepy clown craze comes to Britain
Description: British police have issued warnings after a spate of creepy clown sightings across the country, mimicking a prank that began in the United States and has spread across the world.

Headline: Scottish nationalists say UK has 'no mandate' for hard Brexit
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has no democratic mandate to pursue a 'hard Brexit' that would cut political and trade ties with the European Union, the Scottish National Party said ahead of its annual conference later this week.

Headline: Mock border posts erected on Northern Irish border in Brexit protest
Description: Anti-Brexit campaigners erected six mock customs checkpoints along the Northern Ireland and Irish Republic border on Saturday, in a protest over the possible impact to peace, jobs and the free movement of workers.

Headline: Philip Hammond names HSBC economist as senior advisor
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond has appointed HSBC's  chief European economist, Karen Ward, to advise him as the country prepares to leave the European Union, the finance ministry said on Saturday.

Headline: UK businesses urge government to rule out 'worst' Brexit options
Description: Britain's government needs to immediately rule out leaving the European Union without securing preferential access to the bloc's single market, or investment will suffer, the head of a leading business organization said on Saturday.

Headline: For Scottish shortbread maker, sterling crunch pushes up Brexit costs
Description: Sterling's plunge since Britain voted to leave the European Union has pushed up costs so much for Scottish shortbread maker Bill Dean that he may have to lift prices to balance the books.

Headline: London School of Economics says Britain barred foreign experts from Brexit work
Description: A British government official told the London School of Economics that foreign academics should not do advisory work for the government on Britain's exit from the European Union, the university said.

Headline: Breaking with Conservative past, May proffers her new vision for Britain
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May laid out her vision for post-Brexit Britain on Wednesday, calling for a new approach to government that serves working-class people who voted to leave the European Union in protest at the elite.

Headline: Hammond to tell Wall Street that London still top finance hub despite Brexit
Description: Chancellor of exchequer Philip Hammond, on his first trip to Wall Street since being appointed in July, plans to assure some of the top U.S. top banks on Thursday that Britain is still the world's leading global finance hub despite its Brexit vote.

Headline: Pound hits 31-year low on 'hard' Brexit worries while UK stocks soar
Description: Sterling slid to its lowest level in more than three decades on Tuesday on fears of a "hard Brexit" from the European Union and its single market, although the weaker pound sent UK stocks surging higher.

Headline: Brexit legal challenger to PM May - We are not subverting democracy
Description: The investment manager behind a legal challenge over Britain's exit from the European Union said on Wednesday that Prime Minister Theresa May was wrong to suggest that people bringing such cases were attempting to subvert democracy.

Headline: UK defence minister launches new nuclear submarine programme
Description: The building of four new nuclear submarines for the Royal Navy began on Wednesday, part of a multi-billion pound update of Britain's defence programme providing thousands of jobs.

Headline: UK 'fake sheikh' reporter guilty of plot to alter evidence in celebrity case
Description: Mazher Mahmood, one of Britain's best known undercover reporters renowned for his "fake sheikh" sting operations, was facing jail on Wednesday after being convicted of plotting to alter evidence in a high-profile court case where he was the main witness.

Headline: 'Hard Brexit' could cost British finance firms 38 billion pounds
Description: Britain's financial industry could lose up to 38 billion pounds in revenue in a so-called 'hard Brexit' that would leave it with restricted access to the European Union's single market, according to a report commissioned by an industry group.

Headline: May to woo Labour voters in pitch for Britain's centre-ground
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will make a bid for the centre ground in British politics on Wednesday in a speech calling for a new approach to government, based on serving "ordinary working-class people".

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon slams PM May's 'ugly' Brexit Britain
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's vision of a new Britain is an ugly one where people are judged on their passport rather than their contribution to society, Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Wednesday.

Headline: Brexit without parliamentary vote not illegitimate, Northern Ireland court told
Description: It is not "illegitimate"  for Britain's prime minister to begin the process of leaving the European Union without parliamentary approval, a lawyer representing the government told a Northern Ireland court hearing on Wednesday.

Headline: France's Hollande says EU must be tough after Britain opts for 'hard' Brexit
Description: ((This October 6 story has been corrected to include "Hollande" in the headline))

Headline: Handful of wealthy donors dominated Brexit campaign funding - report
Description: More than half the money donated to groups campaigning in Britain's EU membership referendum was given by 10 individuals or companies, according to research published on Friday, raising questions over the outsize influence of the wealthy on politics.

Headline: Hammond says would like Carney to extend time at BoE
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Thursday he would like Bank of England Governor Mark Carney to serve a full eight-year term at the central bank, rather than leave in 2018 as he originally agreed.

Headline: Theresa May on BoE: new mood music or warning shot?
Description: Was Prime Minister Theresa May sending a warning to Bank of England Governor Mark Carney when she highlighted the damaging side-effects of his ultra-low interest rates?

Headline: PM May's monetary policy comments not an attack on BOE - Carney
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May's comments on the distributional consequences of the Bank of England's low interest rate policy are not an attack on the central bank's independence, Governor Mark Carney said on Friday.

Headline: UKIP's Farage condemns MEPs' "altercation", launches inquiry
Description: UKIP leader Nigel Farage said he would launch a party inquiry into what he called an "altercation" between "two grown men" at a meeting of the party's EU lawmakers in Strasbourg on Thursday that left one of them in hospital.

Headline: UK gives go-ahead to second-ever shale gas permit
Description: Britain's government approved its second-ever shale gas fracking permit on Thursday, overruling a local authority decision and boosting the country's position as Europe's most promising shale gas exploration ground.

Headline: Chancellor Hammond says to focus on per capita GDP growth after Brexit
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Thursday that he would focus on increasing the country's economic output by improving productivity, but that overall growth could slow as Britain barred most low-skilled European Union migrants.

Headline: UKIP MEP 'smiling' in hospital after incident with colleagues
Description: Steven Woolfe, who collapsed on Thursday after an altercation with fellow members of the UK Independence Party in the European Parliament, said in a statement that he was feeling better but staying in hospital overnight for observation.

Headline: UKIP politician Woolfe has bleeding on the brain - party colleague
Description: Steven Woolfe, a member of the European Parliament (MEP) from Britain's UKIP party, is suffering from bleeding on the brain following an altercation at a meeting of UKIP MEPs, fellow UKIP politician Neil Hamilton told the BBC.

Headline: Asked about sterling, PM May says British economy is strong
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that Britain's economy was strong with more positive growth rates than some had expected and, when asked about the fall in sterling, added that currencies "of course go up and down".

Headline: UK may make it harder to hire foreign workers, employer groups complain
Description: Britain said it might make it harder for foreign workers and students to move to the country under a new drive to cut immigration, drawing condemnation from employer groups who accused it of threatening the economy at a crucial time.

Headline: Northern Ireland court considers whether Brexit requires parliament vote
Description: Northern Ireland's High Court began hearing a legal challenge on Tuesday against British plans to leave the European Union without a vote in the Westminster parliament.

Headline: Not-guilty pleas entered for man accused of killing MP Jo Cox
Description: The man accused of killing British Member of Parliament Jo Cox a week before the June referendum on EU membership declined to respond when asked if he was guilty at a court hearing on Tuesday and the judge recorded pleas of not guilty to all charges.

Headline: Unprepared British consumers face Brexit-driven price squeeze
Description: Any British shoppers tempted by Apple's new iPhone are having to dig deeper into their pockets after June's Brexit vote as the U.S. tech giant raised the sterling price by 60 pounds when the model went on sale on Sept. 16.

Headline: Britain to protect soldiers serving overseas from legal claims
Description: Britain will protect its armed forces serving overseas from "vexatious" human rights claims by making it possible to suspend the European Convention on Human Rights in future conflicts, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: May says Brexit timetable important for businesses
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday it was important to set out the timing of Britain's exit from the European Union to reassure businesses after sterling plunged in the wake of her announcement of the deadline.

Headline: Hammond says will treat investment spending differently
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday he wanted to treat investment spending differently from day-to-day spending, underscoring his different approach to the public finances to that of his predecessor George Osborne.

Headline: UK government should consider targeted infrastructure investment - Hammond
Description: The British government must keep a lid on day-to-day spending but there is a case for targeted, high-value infrastructure investment following June's vote to leave the European Union, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Headline: Hammond vows to protect UK economy during Brexit, sterling falls
Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond vowed on Monday to protect the economy from any turbulence during negotiations to leave the EU, as sterling fell on worries the country is heading towards a disruptive divorce with its biggest trading partner.

Headline: Many EU nations want strong, continued trade ties with UK - Hammond
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday there were differences among European Union member countries about the stance to take over Britain's future trading relationship with the bloc.

Headline: Immigration curbs don't preclude single market access - Hammond
Description: Controlling immigration does not necessarily mean Britain will lose access to the European Union's single market following its exit from the bloc, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Headline: Hammond buries idea of extra cuts to corporation tax
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said the government would stick to its plans to lower Britain's corporation tax rate to 17 percent by 2020, burying a suggestion by his predecessor George Osborne that it might fall below 15 percent to offset the Brexit vote impact.

Headline: UK government consulting with business on immigration curbs  - minister
Description: The British government is working on its proposals for curbing immigration following the country's exit from the European Union and will consult with businesses on its plans, Home Secretary Amber Rudd said on Monday.

Headline: May says to trigger EU divorce by end of March, sterling falls
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she would trigger the process to leave the EU by the end of March, offering the first glimpse of a timetable for a divorce that will redefine Britain's ties with its biggest trading partner.

Headline: Sturgeon says May does not care about Scotland over Brexit
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon accused Theresa May of ignoring Scots over Britain's exit from the European Union after the British Prime Minister indicated that Scotland will not have a veto.

Headline: Britain sets out 5 billion-pound homebuilding boost
Description: Britain launched a 5 billion-pound homebuilding stimulus package on Monday, including plans to borrow 2 billion pounds to help address a long-term housing shortage that has become a major economic problem.

Headline: Hammond rates UK economy an 'eight out of 10'
Description: Chancellor, Philip Hammond, scored the recent performance of the country's economy at "eight out of 10" on Monday, buoyed by high employment and strong growth but he said it also faced long-term challenges.

Headline: UK to make airport expansion decision 'soon' - transport minister
Description: The British government will make a decision on increasing London airport capacity in the "not-too-distant" future, Transport Secretary Chris Grayling said on Sunday.

Headline: Highlights - May on Brexit, Article 50 and trade
Description: Britain will trigger the formal divorce process from the European Union by the end of March 2017, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday.

Headline: May to woo Labour voters in pitch for Britain's centre-ground
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will make a bid for the centre ground in British politics on Wednesday in a speech calling for a new approach to government, based on serving "ordinary working-class people".

Headline: "We are all leavers now" - PM May wins over pro-Brexit wing
Description: Few noticed, but when Prime Minister Theresa May said Britain would once again decide alone how "we label our food" after quitting the European Union it was what many of her pro-Brexit lawmakers had dreamt of.

Headline: UK banks target eurosceptic ministers as 'hard Brexit' fears grow
Description: As Britain's banks brace for a "hard Brexit" that could sever their links with the EU market, they are changing lobbying strategy and focussing efforts on eurosceptic cabinet ministers to try to secure a transitional period for their industry.

Headline: "No question" UK will address London bankers' EU-exit worries - minister
Description: Britain promised to negotiate an exit deal with the European Union that resolves deep concern in London's financial sector that Brexit will disrupt its business model, David Davis, the minister in charge of the talks, said on Tuesday.

Headline: Brexit minister says will not negotiate separate EU exit deals
Description: The British government will only negotiate one deal for when it leaves the European Union, the country's Brexit minister, David Davis, said on Tuesday, adding that there would be no separate deal for London.

Headline: Asked about sterling, PM May says British economy is strong
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday that Britain's economy was strong with more positive growth rates than some had expected and, when asked about the fall in sterling, added that currencies "of course go up and down".

Headline: UK may make it harder to hire foreign workers, employer groups complain
Description: Britain said it might make it harder for foreign workers and students to move to the country under a new drive to cut immigration, drawing condemnation from employer groups who accused it of threatening the economy at a crucial time.

Description: Northern Ireland's High Court began hearing a legal challenge on Tuesday against British plans to leave the European Union without a vote in the Westminster parliament.

Description: The man accused of killing British Member of Parliament Jo Cox a week before the June referendum on EU membership declined to respond when asked if he was guilty at a court hearing on Tuesday and the judge recorded pleas of not guilty to all charges.

Description: Any British shoppers tempted by Apple's new iPhone are having to dig deeper into their pockets after June's Brexit vote as the U.S. tech giant raised the sterling price by 60 pounds when the model went on sale on Sept. 16.

Headline: Britain to protect soldiers serving overseas from legal claims
Description: Britain will protect its armed forces serving overseas from "vexatious" human rights claims by making it possible to suspend the European Convention on Human Rights in future conflicts, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday it was important to set out the timing of Britain's exit from the European Union to reassure businesses after sterling plunged in the wake of her announcement of the deadline.

Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday he wanted to treat investment spending differently from day-to-day spending, underscoring his different approach to the public finances to that of his predecessor George Osborne.

Headline: UK government should consider targeted infrastructure investment - Hammond
Description: The British government must keep a lid on day-to-day spending but there is a case for targeted, high-value infrastructure investment following June's vote to leave the European Union, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Description: British finance minister Philip Hammond vowed on Monday to protect the economy from any turbulence during negotiations to leave the EU, as sterling fell on worries the country is heading towards a disruptive divorce with its biggest trading partner.

Headline: Many EU nations want strong, continued trade ties with UK - Hammond
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday there were differences among European Union member countries about the stance to take over Britain's future trading relationship with the bloc.

Headline: Immigration curbs don't preclude single market access - Hammond
Description: Controlling immigration does not necessarily mean Britain will lose access to the European Union's single market following its exit from the bloc, Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Monday.

Headline: Hammond buries idea of extra cuts to corporation tax
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said the government would stick to its plans to lower Britain's corporation tax rate to 17 percent by 2020, burying a suggestion by his predecessor George Osborne that it might fall below 15 percent to offset the Brexit vote impact.

Headline: UK government consulting with business on immigration curbs  - minister
Description: The British government is working on its proposals for curbing immigration following the country's exit from the European Union and will consult with businesses on its plans, Home Secretary Amber Rudd said on Monday.

Headline: May says to trigger EU divorce by end of March, sterling falls
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she would trigger the process to leave the EU by the end of March, offering the first glimpse of a timetable for a divorce that will redefine Britain's ties with its biggest trading partner.

Headline: After Nissan ultimatum, Jaguar Land Rover says Brexit must be fair for all
Description: Jaguar Land Rover will "realign its thinking" on investment after Britain's vote to leave the EU and if Nissan gets a Brexit compensation deal then other automakers would need a level playing field, Britain's biggest carmaker said.

Headline: Britain's child abuse inquiry denies crisis as top lawyer quits
Description: Britain's beleaguered national inquiry into child sex abuse, one  of its largest and most expensive ever undertaken, has denied it is in crisis after its most senior lawyer became the latest figure to quit.

Headline: British car industry body criticises Brexit uncertainty
Description: Britain's car industry body said on Friday that current uncertainty over Brexit was not conductive to attracting investment and that the government must maintain the competitiveness of the sector.

Headline: London to launch inquiry into foreign property ownership - report
Description: London's mayor Sadiq Khan will launch an inquiry into foreign ownership of property in the British capital which has helped push up housing costs, the Guardian newspaper cited him as saying on Thursday.

Headline: Boss of UK's John Lewis selected to run for West Midlands mayor
Description: British department store chain John Lewis [JLP.UL] [JLPLC.UL] will have to appoint a new leader after Managing Director Andy Street was chosen by the ruling Conservative Party as its candidate for mayor of the West Midlands in central England.

Headline: Princess Charlotte says first word in public on Canadian tour
Description: Britain's Princess Charlotte, 1, spoke for the first time in public on Thursday during her family's Canadian tour, uttering the word "pop" while she and her brother played with balloons.

Headline: China nuclear firm expects go-ahead for another plant in Britain - Xinhua
Description: China General Nuclear Power Corporation (CGN) expects its plans for a new China-led nuclear power plant in Britain to win government approval within five years, the firm's chairman said in comments reported by state media late on Thursday.

Headline: UK signs long-awaited Franco-Chinese nuclear project behind closed doors
Description: A $24-billion deal to build Britain's first new nuclear power station in decades was signed behind closed doors in London on Thursday in a private ceremony that underlined Prime Minister Theresa May's cautious approach to the Franco-Chinese project.

Headline: Brexit ball in Britain's court - Austrian finance minister
Description: The Brexit ball is in Britain's court and the country should start the procedure to exit the European Union as soon as possible, Austrian Finance Minister Hans Joerg Schelling said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain sets out reasons to bypass parliament over EU divorce papers
Description: (The story was refiled for incorrect change of the word ministers to MPs in paragraph 2)

Headline: Britain, France to sign Hinkley Point nuclear deal on Thursday - sources
Description: The British government and France's EDF  will officially sign a contract to build Britain's first new nuclear power plant in a generation on Thursday, after months of wrangling over the involvement of EDF's Chinese partner, sources said.

Headline: UK lenders approve fewest mortgages in nearly two years - BoE
Description: British lenders approved the fewest mortgages in nearly two years last month as the housing market continued to slow after June's vote to leave the European Union, raising the chance of an outright fall in prices next year.

Headline: Britain's top police officer to step down next year
Description: Britain's most senior police officer Bernard Hogan-Howe, who oversaw policing at the 2012 Olympic Games and London's efforts to tackle extremism, will retire in 2017 after five years, the Metropolitan police said on Thursday.

Headline: After Brexit, UK to seek bespoke trade deals, not WTO rules - Fox
Description: Britain must seek bespoke multi-lateral and bilateral trade arrangements after it exits the European Union rather than fall back on World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules, International Trade Secretary Liam Fox said on Thursday.

Headline: UK/EU trade post-Brexit should be at least as free as it is now - Fox
Description: It is in both Britain's and the European Union's interests for the trading environment between both parties to be at least as free as it is now after Britain exits the bloc, International Trade Secretary Liam Fox said on Thursday.

Headline: As airport decision looms, Heathrow says it can add more flights
Description: Heathrow Airport said on Thursday it could use new technology to add 5 percent more flights, as it tries to gain support ahead of a long-awaited government decision on where to increase London's airport capacity.

Headline: From robots to websites, British firms curb spending due to Brexit
Description: Heavy machinery whirrs and clanks on the factory floor of precision metalworking firm Robert Bion & Co, where a planned three-metre robotic arm would have been speeding up output by now, if Britain had not voted to leave the European Union.

Headline: Britain must explain Brexit strategy to limit uncertainty - think tank
Description: Britain needs to begin explaining its Brexit strategy to avoid prolonged uncertainty for businesses and negotiating partners, a London-based think tank said on Thursday, warning that internal squabbling risked undermining the government's position.

Headline: End 'trench warfare', Corbyn urges Labour
Description: Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the Labour Party, called on his MPs on Wednesday to end "trench warfare" and unite to challenge the ruling Conservatives and deliver "socialism of the 21st century".

Headline: Royal property manager jailed over corrupt payments
Description: A former deputy property manager in the British royal household was jailed on Wednesday over corrupt payments linked to the awarding of building work contracts at Buckingham Palace and other royal homes.

Headline: Pro-Brexit Conservatives hand PM plan to limit EU immigration
Description: High-profile Conservatives outlined proposals for a post-Brexit system of work permits on Saturday, highlighting the pressure Prime Minister Theresa May faces to cut immigration and appease eurosceptics while addressing the concerns of business leaders.

Headline: PM May says Scotland will have no veto over Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she will listen to Scotland's concerns over Britain's exit from the European Union but that the devolved Scottish government will not have a veto over the Brexit negotiations.

Headline: PM May orders employment law review as labour market changes
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May ordered a review of employment practices on Saturday, saying she wanted to ensure workers' rights were protected under changing business models and a growing trend towards flexible or self-employment.

Headline: May to set out vision of Brexit 'success' as some investors fret
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will set out her vision of a successful Brexit on Sunday as investors raise growing concern that the world's fifth largest economy could face upheaval from a disorderly exit from the European Union.

Headline: Britain must maintain close EU police links post Brexit - NCA chief
Description: Britain must maintain its close ties with European law enforcement agencies after it leaves the bloc, a senior British police chief said on Friday, amid concern that the country's security could be damaged by leaving the EU.

Headline: After Nissan ultimatum, Jaguar Land Rover says Brexit must be fair for all
Description: Jaguar Land Rover will "realign its thinking" on investment after Britain's vote to leave the EU and if Nissan gets a Brexit compensation deal then other automakers would need a level playing field, Britain's biggest carmaker said.

Headline: Britain's child abuse inquiry denies crisis as top lawyer quits
Description: Britain's beleaguered national inquiry into child sex abuse, one  of its largest and most expensive ever undertaken, has denied it is in crisis after its most senior lawyer became the latest figure to quit.

Headline: British car industry body criticises Brexit uncertainty
Description: Britain's car industry body said on Friday that current uncertainty over Brexit was not conductive to attracting investment and that the government must maintain the competitiveness of the sector.

Headline: London to launch inquiry into foreign property ownership - report
Description: London's mayor Sadiq Khan will launch an inquiry into foreign ownership of property in the British capital which has helped push up housing costs, the Guardian newspaper cited him as saying on Thursday.

Headline: Boss of UK's John Lewis selected to run for West Midlands mayor
Description: British department store chain John Lewis [JLP.UL] [JLPLC.UL] will have to appoint a new leader after Managing Director Andy Street was chosen by the ruling Conservative Party as its candidate for mayor of the West Midlands in central England.

Headline: UK appears headed for 'hard Brexit', Scots minister says after talks
Description: Britain appears to be heading for a "hard Brexit" under which links to the European Union would be reduced to little more than trade agreements, Scotland's external affairs minister Fiona Hyslop said on Monday, citing "mood music" from recent talks.

Headline: UK government must spell out Brexit plans - Labour
Description: The Labour party called on the government to spell out its strategy for negotiating Britain's exit from the European Union, saying it had no brief to "do whatever the hell they like with our country".

Headline: Labour says will ban fracking if elected
Description: The Labour Party pledged on Monday to ban fracking if elected in 2020, putting it at odds with the Conservative government and raising the risk for investors looking to put money into the nascent industry.

Headline: Optimism in Britain's finance industry hits financial crisis low
Description: Optimism about the outlook for Britain's financial services sector is at its lowest point since the financial crisis, a survey of finance firms showed on Monday.

Headline: Majority of UK CEOs considering moving operations abroad post-Brexit - survey
Description: Three-quarters of British company bosses are considering moving operations abroad following the vote to leave the European Union, according to a survey published on Monday.

Headline: Parliament must be fully informed on Brexit strategy - Corbyn
Description: Britain's parliament must be kept fully informed about the government's strategy for leaving the European Union, Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the main opposition Labour Party, said on Sunday.

Headline: Corbyn calls for unity after winning Labour leadership vote
Description: Jeremy Corbyn was re-elected leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party on Saturday and called for unity after ending a "coup" by more centrist members of parliament who say his left-wing agenda can never deliver victory at the polls.

Headline: Young Prince George shuns high-five, low-five from Canada's Trudeau
Description: Blame it on jet lag or maybe a precocious knowledge that his great-grandmother is Canada's head of state but Britain's 3-year-old Prince George just wasn't going to be charmed by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

Headline: Kids in tow, Prince William, Kate begin visit to Canada
Description: Britain's Prince William and his wife, Kate Middleton, arrived in Canada on Saturday for their second official visit, received by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at a military airport in the western province of British Columbia.

Headline: PM May rebuffed calls to play bigger role in EU referendum campaign
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May repeatedly failed to back her predecessor David Cameron in his fight to keep Britain in the European Union and hampered his attempts to rein in migration, according to extracts from two books about the referendum.

Headline: As airport decision looms, Heathrow says it can add more flights
Description: Heathrow Airport said on Thursday it could use new technology to add 5 percent more flights, as it tries to gain support ahead of a long-awaited government decision on where to increase London's airport capacity.

Headline: From robots to websites, British firms curb spending due to Brexit
Description: Heavy machinery whirrs and clanks on the factory floor of precision metalworking firm Robert Bion & Co, where a planned three-metre robotic arm would have been speeding up output by now, if Britain had not voted to leave the European Union.

Headline: Britain must explain Brexit strategy to limit uncertainty - think tank
Description: Britain needs to begin explaining its Brexit strategy to avoid prolonged uncertainty for businesses and negotiating partners, a London-based think tank said on Thursday, warning that internal squabbling risked undermining the government's position.

Headline: End 'trench warfare', Corbyn urges Labour
Description: Jeremy Corbyn, leader of the Labour Party, called on his MPs on Wednesday to end "trench warfare" and unite to challenge the ruling Conservatives and deliver "socialism of the 21st century".

Headline: Royal property manager jailed over corrupt payments
Description: A former deputy property manager in the British royal household was jailed on Wednesday over corrupt payments linked to the awarding of building work contracts at Buckingham Palace and other royal homes.

Headline: Pippa wins court ban on hacked photos
Description: Pippa Middleton, younger sister of the Duchess of Cambridge, won a court injunction on Wednesday banning publication of 3,000 photos allegedly hacked from her iCloud account.

Headline: S&P sees slowdown but no recession for UK and euro zone after Brexit
Description: Britain and the euro zone will avoid a recession but face slower economic growth as a result of the decision by British voters to leave the European Union, ratings agency Standard & Poor's said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain promises Brexit will not create legal vacuum at WTO
Description: Britain's trade secretary promised on Tuesday its departure from the European Union would not create a legal vacuum at the World Trade Organization, and said Britain was determined to champion free trade.

Headline: Deeply divided, Labour fails to challenge May on Brexit
Description: With the re-election of Jeremy Corbyn as leader unlikely to heal  deep rifts in Labour, the only significant opposition that Prime Minister Theresa May looks likely to face as she plots Britain's divorce from the EU is from her own party.

Headline: London mayor Khan challenges Labour leader to deliver election win
Description: Pro-business London mayor Sadiq Khan one of the Labour Party's most powerful figures, heaped pressure on his socialist leader Jeremy Corbyn to deliver an election win, using a speech on Tuesday to stress the importance of being in office.

Headline: Scotland tells London - Give us clarity on what Brexit means
Description: Scotland wants to have more detail about how the British government plans to leave the European Union to prevent a "hard Brexit" that would severely damage the economy, Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said on Tuesday.

Headline: Britain says economy needs an infrastructure upgrade after political drama
Description: Britain's economy needs an infrastructure and vocational education upgrade to deliver stability to businesses after months of political drama including the vote to leave the European Union, business secretary Greg Clark said on Tuesday.

Headline: Brexit could make Britain highly attractive, says Axel Springer chief
Description: Brexit will be more painful for the rest of Europe than for Britain which could emerge stronger and better off than its European neighbours, Mathias Doepfner, chief executive of Axel Springer, told the Financial Times.

Headline: Labour lock horns with business over economic reform
Description: The Labour Party clashed with business groups  on Monday after setting out a left-wing economic agenda aimed at boosting their chances of winning power by re-engaging with working class voters who backed leaving the European Union.

Headline: 'Ottoman' Boris Johnson makes first visit to Turkey since Erdogan poem
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson on Monday kicked off his first official visit to Ankara by highlighting his "proud ownership" of a Turkish washing machine and steered clear of his past prize-winning insults of President Tayyip Erdogan.

Headline: UK appears headed for 'hard Brexit', Scots minister says after talks
Description: Britain appears to be heading for a "hard Brexit" under which links to the European Union would be reduced to little more than trade agreements, Scotland's external affairs minister Fiona Hyslop said on Monday, citing "mood music" from recent talks.

Headline: UK government must spell out Brexit plans - Labour
Description: The Labour party called on the government to spell out its strategy for negotiating Britain's exit from the European Union, saying it had no brief to "do whatever the hell they like with our country".

Headline: Labour says will ban fracking if elected
Description: The Labour Party pledged on Monday to ban fracking if elected in 2020, putting it at odds with the Conservative government and raising the risk for investors looking to put money into the nascent industry.

Headline: Optimism in Britain's finance industry hits financial crisis low
Description: Optimism about the outlook for Britain's financial services sector is at its lowest point since the financial crisis, a survey of finance firms showed on Monday.

Headline: Majority of UK CEOs considering moving operations abroad post-Brexit - survey
Description: Three-quarters of British company bosses are considering moving operations abroad following the vote to leave the European Union, according to a survey published on Monday.

Headline: Buoyed by fans, Labour's Corbyn heads for re-election
Description: Thanking grassroots supporters who look set to keep him in charge of the Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn seems unruffled by accusations from fellow MPs that his left-wing agenda will never deliver election victory.

Headline: Brexit will smooth Trump's path to U.S. presidency - Farage
Description: Brexit will inspire support for Donald Trump and smooth his path to victory in the U.S. presidential election in November, according to Nigel Farage, an architect of the political uprising that saw Britons vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: Anti-Trump campaigners hit London's streets in red bus
Description: Activists urging American expats in Britain to vote in the upcoming U.S. presidential election took to the streets of London on Wednesday in a red open-top double-decker bus adorned with anti-Donald Trump posters.

Headline: MI6 spy chief says Islamist terrorist threat is here to stay
Description: The Islamist terrorist threat to the West will endure for years to come because simply taking back territory from Islamic State will not solve the deeper global fractures which have fostered militants, Britain's foreign intelligence chief has said.

Headline: UK indicating Brexit talks could start in January, February - Irish PM
Description: Members of the British government have indicated that they may be ready to launch formal negotiations to leave the European Union in late January or February next year, Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny said on Wednesday.

Headline: 'Fake Sheikh' reporter goes on trial accused of tampering with evidence
Description: Mazher Mahmood, one of Britain's best known undercover reporters renowned for his "fake sheikh" sting operations that have even caught out royalty, tampered with evidence in a criminal trial to protect his reputation, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

Headline: UK public finances in August leave Hammond little room for Brexit budget boost
Description: Britain's public finances showed a slightly bigger-than-expected deficit in August, leaving Chancellor Philip Hammond little room for manoeuvre as he prepares his first post-Brexit vote budget plans.

Headline: May pledges to ratify Paris climate deal by year-end
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has pledged to world leaders to ratify the Paris agreement to slow climate change by the end of the year.

Headline: Ex-UK PM Blair says to focus on non-profit work
Description: Former British prime minister Tony Blair, who built a multi-million pound business network advising multi-national corporations and governments after leaving office in 2007, said on Tuesday he was planning to close his commercial ventures and concentrate on not-for-profit activities.

Headline: Firms still hiring but Brexit worries dent confidence - survey
Description: British employers plan to hire more staff to meet demand but confidence about future investment and hiring has deteriorated because of worries about the impact of Britain's exit from the European Union, a survey by a recruitment body showed.

Headline: Brexit forever? Britain keeps the world waiting for EU divorce papers
Description: If investors hoped for one thing after Britain's shock vote to leave the European Union, it was clarity. But there is little.

Headline: Mr BRICS quits Treasury post after reported row over China
Description: Former Goldman Sachs chief economist Jim O'Neill resigned from the Treasury on Friday after he reportedly clashed with new Prime Minister Theresa May over Chinese investment in the country.

Headline: Bank of England may have double-counted Brexit costs - Forbes
Description: The Bank of England may need to revise up its growth forecasts after double-counting some of the costs of economic uncertainty linked to the country's Brexit vote, policymaker Kristin Forbes said in an interview published on Thursday.

Headline: Carney's choice - stay for Brexit or seek new role in 2018?
Description: Mark Carney has been taking the big decisions for Britain's economy for the past three years, but his next one will be much more personal.

Headline: UK may not need two years to get EU divorce deal - Johnson
Description: Britain expects to start the divorce procedure to leave the European Union early next year and may not need two years to negotiate a deal, Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Thursday.

Headline: British official hosts EU ambassadors to seek Brexit signals - sources
Description: A senior British official made clear during a meeting with ambassadors from European Union countries in London this week that his government wants a signal from the EU about what kind of Brexit deal it is willing to accept before triggering divorce talks, EU sources said.

Headline: Bank of England's Carney calls for progress on green bonds
Description: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney called for faster development of green bond markets to reduce climate change risks for the world economy and urged Germany to use its presidency of the Group of 20 economies in 2017 to make progress.

Headline: Seeking to protect NATO, Britain could yet thwart EU defence plans
Description: Britain will resist new European Union defence proposals if it feels they undermine NATO, British officials say, in a warning to France and Germany that London will defend its military interests even as it negotiates to leave the EU bloc.

Headline: British fighters intercept Russian bombers near UK airspace
Description: Britain scrambled Typhoon fighters from Scotland to intercept two Russian bombers near British airspace on Thursday, the Ministry of Defence said.

Headline: 'Tougher scrutiny' of Britain's aid spending sees steep rise in fraud bill
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Britain lost 40 percent more money through fraud in its overseas aid programmes in 2015/16 compared to the previous year, data shows, with the rise attributed to better reporting of its misappropriated funds, according to government officials.

Headline: Oxford ranked world's top university, just as Brexit looms
Description: The University of Oxford, the oldest university in the English-speaking world and feeder for the British elite, has topped a global education ranking for the first time, but its vice-chancellor warned that Brexit could damage its long-term prospects.

Headline: Britain complains after Hungary says migrants make London a 'no-go' area
Description: Britain has raised concerns with Hungary over a description of areas of London, Paris and Brussels as "no-go" areas dominated by illegal immigrants who increase the risk of militant attacks.

Headline: Lloyd's of London readying EU move plans
Description: The Lloyd's of London insurance market is already working on plans to move some business to the European Union, aiming to be ready for the shift as soon as Britain starts divorce proceedings from the bloc, its chairman said on Thursday.

Headline: Bank of England says UK faces 'challenging period' for financial stability
Description: Britain still faces a "challenging period" for financial stability despite resilience seen after the European Union referendum, and rules for banks must remain tight, the Bank of England said on Thursday.

Headline: MI6 to get 40 percent more spies - BBC
Description: Britain's foreign intelligence service is to get 40 percent more spies in one of the biggest expansions since the Cold War as MI6 seeks to harness new technology, the BBC said.

Headline: Buoyed by fans, Labour's Corbyn heads for re-election
Description: Thanking grassroots supporters who look set to keep him in charge of the Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn seems unruffled by accusations from fellow MPs that his left-wing agenda will never deliver election victory.

Headline: Brexit will smooth Trump's path to U.S. presidency - Farage
Description: Brexit will inspire support for Donald Trump and smooth his path to victory in the U.S. presidential election in November, according to Nigel Farage, an architect of the political uprising that saw Britons vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: Anti-Trump campaigners hit London's streets in red bus
Description: Activists urging American expats in Britain to vote in the upcoming U.S. presidential election took to the streets of London on Wednesday in a red open-top double-decker bus adorned with anti-Donald Trump posters.

Headline: MI6 spy chief says Islamist terrorist threat is here to stay
Description: The Islamist terrorist threat to the West will endure for years to come because simply taking back territory from Islamic State will not solve the deeper global fractures which have fostered militants, Britain's foreign intelligence chief has said.

Headline: UK indicating Brexit talks could start in January, February - Irish PM
Description: Members of the British government have indicated that they may be ready to launch formal negotiations to leave the European Union in late January or February next year, Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny said on Wednesday.

Headline: Sadiq Khan backs Clinton for U.S. president
Description: London's first Muslim mayor, Sadiq Khan, voiced support for Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton on Thursday, warning that anti-Muslim views like those espoused by Republican Donald Trump “plays into the hands" of Islamic State.

Headline: MPs to scrutinise executive pay and governance
Description: British MPs kept up the pressure on big businesses criticised for boosting top-level salaries whilst not fairly rewarding their workers on Friday with the launch of an inquiry into executive pay and corporate governance.

Headline: May approves Hinkley Point nuclear plant, sets tighter controls
Description: Britain gave the go-ahead for a $24 billion (£18.1 billion) nuclear power plant on Thursday, ending weeks of uncertainty that had strained ties with China, which will help pay for it, and France, which will build it.

Headline: May prepares for Brexit talks, keeps Europe guessing
Description: As Europe clamours to know how Britain plans to implement its decision to leave the European Union, new Prime Minister Theresa May is giving little away, but her strategy is becoming clear.

Headline: Exclusive- Fears for social entrepreneurs in Britain as Brexit looms large
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Britain's role as a pioneering country for social entrepreneurs could suffer as it prepares to leave the European Union after decades of the government actively promoting business leaders seeking to do good, experts said.

Headline: City of London should not suffer from Brexit - Johnson
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said on Thursday London's financial sector was a "massive asset" to the whole of Europe and should not be weakened by Britain's decision to leave the European Union.

Headline: China welcomes Britain's decision to approve nuclear plant
Description: China said on Thursday it welcomed Britain's decision to approve the construction of a part Chinese-invested nuclear plant at Hinkley Point in southern England.

Headline: UK says Nigerian's conviction stands despite bribery evidence
Description: Jailed former Nigerian state governor James Ibori's convictions remain valid despite evidence a British police officer took bribes during the investigation of his case, Britain's state prosecution agency said on Thursday.

Headline: New foreign investment rules better match UK national interest - MP Clark
Description: British business secretary Greg Clark said the government's new approach to foreign investment, announced alongside approval for a new French-built, Chinese-backed nuclear power plant, better met the national interest than previous rules.

Headline: Foreign nuclear investment is a vote of confidence in Britain - MP Clark
Description: Foreign investment in Britain's Hinkley Point nuclear project, which was approved by the government on Thursday, is a vote of confidence in the country, Business Secretary Greg Clark told parliament.

Headline: Sports Direct to order independent review of working practices
Description: British retailer Sports Direct said it will order an independent inquiry into its working practices and corporate governance, responding to demand from some shareholders as it seeks to repair its battered image.

Headline: On New York mission, Theresa May seeks to shore up UK influence after Brexit
Description: On a mission to shore up British clout after the shock vote to leave the European Union raised questions over the future unity of the West, Prime Minister Theresa May will tell leaders on Tuesday that Britain will not turn away from the world.

Headline: May meets Goldman, Amazon, IBM to discuss post-Brexit investment
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May met business chiefs from firms including Goldman Sachs, IBM and Amazon.com on Monday in an attempt to reassure investors after her country's shock vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: May says will get the right trade deal with EU
Description: Britain will get "the right deal in terms of trade" with the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May told a group of U.S. business and finance leaders on Monday, in a bid to reassure investors after her country's shock vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: Suspected killer of Jo Cox will not run medical defence
Description: The man accused of murdering MP Jo Cox in the run-up to Britain's June EU referendum vote will not present a defence case based on medical evidence, a London court heard on Monday.

Headline: London 'lifejacket graveyard' aims to send message to U.N. summit
Description: Aid organisations laid out 2,500 lifejackets symbolizing refugee crossings to Europe in a demonstration outside the British parliament on Monday timed to coincide with a United Nations summit on the worldwide migrant crisis.

Headline: British police seek to block visit by suspected female genital mutilator
Description: Police said on Monday they were looking for ways to prevent the entry into Britain of a suspected practitioner of female genital mutilation (FGM).

Headline: Britain says took part in air strikes believed to have killed Syrian soldiers
Description: Britain said on Monday it had taken part in a U.S-led air strikes in Syria over the weekend that Russia says killed Syrian soldiers.

Headline: MPs in ruling party back group pushing for 'hard Brexit'
Description: Senior members of Britain's ruling Conservative Party are supporting a new group to lobby for a so-called 'hard Brexit' and persuade Prime Minister Theresa May to leave the EU's lucrative single market, media reported on Sunday.

Headline: Mission accomplished? Britain's anti-EU party fights to retain influence
Description: "We won!" was the anti-European Union UK Independence Party's rallying cry at its annual conference as members celebrated Britain's vote to leave the EU, but underneath the euphoria lurked a fresh anxiety: what now?

Headline: EU's Tusk - May indicated could trigger Brexit talks in Jan-Feb
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has signalled that she could  be ready to launch formal Brexit negotiations in January or February next year, European Council President Donald Tusk said on Friday, citing a recent talk with May.

Headline: Ex-commander says UK's 'withered' forces could not defend country - FT
Description: Britain's armed forces would be unable to defend the country against a serious military attack because they have been "withered" by cuts, a former senior commander warned before his retirement, the Financial Times reported on Saturday.

Headline: UKIP elects new leader to fill Brexit talisman Farage's shoes
Description: The UK Independence Party picked a new leader on Friday to replace Nigel Farage, a key player in Britain's vote to leave the European Union, with the incoming Diane James pledging to ensure Britain follows through with a full withdrawal from the bloc.

Headline: Outgoing anti-EU firebrand Farage demands his party push for 'hard' Brexit
Description: Nigel Farage, the firebrand of Britain's Brexit campaign, used his final speech as leader of the UK Independence Party on Friday to demand that his successor pushes for a "hard" EU exit that meets the demands of his party's voters.

Headline: Autistic Briton can be extradited to U.S. on hacking charges, court rules
Description: A London court on Friday approved the extradition of an autistic  British man to the United States to face trial for hacking high-security state computers, despite warnings he might kill himself if sent to a U.S. jail.

Headline: Sadiq Khan backs Clinton for U.S. president
Description: London's first Muslim mayor, Sadiq Khan, voiced support for Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton on Thursday, warning that anti-Muslim views like those espoused by Republican Donald Trump “plays into the hands" of Islamic State.

Headline: MPs to scrutinise executive pay and governance
Description: British MPs kept up the pressure on big businesses criticised for boosting top-level salaries whilst not fairly rewarding their workers on Friday with the launch of an inquiry into executive pay and corporate governance.

Headline: May approves Hinkley Point nuclear plant, sets tighter controls
Description: Britain gave the go-ahead for a $24 billion (£18.1 billion) nuclear power plant on Thursday, ending weeks of uncertainty that had strained ties with China, which will help pay for it, and France, which will build it.

Headline: May prepares for Brexit talks, keeps Europe guessing
