Description: As Europe clamours to know how Britain plans to implement its decision to leave the European Union, new Prime Minister Theresa May is giving little away, but her strategy is becoming clear.

Headline: Exclusive- Fears for social entrepreneurs in Britain as Brexit looms large
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Britain's role as a pioneering country for social entrepreneurs could suffer as it prepares to leave the European Union after decades of the government actively promoting business leaders seeking to do good, experts said.

Headline: London takes steps to help black cabs as private hire firms face new rules
Description: London said on Tuesday it would introduce new measures to support its iconic black cabs including giving access to more bus lanes and boosting the number of taxi ranks, just as private hire firms such as Uber face stricter rules in the capital.

Headline: London teenager charged with preparing terrorism attacks
Description: A 19-year-old man from London has been charged under counter-terrorism law with preparing attacks, the British capital's Metropolitan Police force said on Tuesday.

Headline: No UK market access without free migration - EU parliament negotiator
Description: The new Brexit negotiator for the European Parliament reiterated on Tuesday that the EU legislature will not accept giving Britain access to Europe's single market if it blocks free access to EU immigrants.

Headline: EU lawmakers back Briton King for security commissioner
Description: A European Parliament committee endorsed Julian King on Tuesday as Britain's new member of the European Commission with responsibility for security, the committee chairman said.

Headline: MPs face uncertain future under new boundary proposals
Description: Dozens of British MPs face uncertain futures under proposals by an independent commission charged with cutting the number of parliamentary seats.

Headline: More than half of UK girls sexually harassed in school - report
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - More than half of girls in British schools and colleges have faced sexual harassment, according to a new report on Tuesday that called for sex education to be provided for all children in primary and secondary school.

Headline: 'Last British commissioner' pledges to work for Europe
Description: The diplomat nominated to take Britain's vacant seat on the EU executive pledged on Monday to serve "only the European general interest" if EU lawmakers accept him as, probably, the last ever British commissioner.

Headline: UK will have public guidelines for Brexit talks before triggering Article 50 - minister
Description: Britain will make public its guidelines for talks on leaving the European Union by the time it triggers the exit process, Brexit minister David Davis said on Monday, in the first indication of when Britons will find out what the government hopes to achieve in the talks.

Headline: Germany, France seek stronger EU defence after Brexit - document
Description: Germany and France have outlined plans to deepen European military cooperation, a document showed on Monday, as Britain's exit from the European Union removes one of the biggest obstacles to stronger EU defence in tandem with NATO.

Headline: MP Davis says must persuade 'remainers' of Brexit benefits
Description: Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Monday the government must persuade those who voted to stay in the European Union in both houses of parliament that Brexit is worthwhile.

Headline: China General Nuclear says happy with UK nuclear plant approval
Description: China General Nuclear Power Corp is "very happy" with Britain's decision to approve the construction of a part Chinese-invested nuclear plant at Hinkley Point in southern England, the company said on Thursday.

Headline: Hitachi's UK nuclear unit comfortable with government stake in new projects
Description: Horizon, a nuclear new build group in Britain owned by Japan's Hitachi's, said it was "entirely comfortable" with the British government's approach set out on Thursday that it wants to own a golden stake in new nuclear projects.

Headline: Chinese nuclear investor not concerned by new UK rules on foreign owners - source
Description: The Chinese company set to invest $8 billion (6.03 billion pounds) in the Hinkley nuclear plant welcomes Britain's decision to go ahead with the project and is not concerned by new rules around future foreign investment in the UK, a source close to the deal said.

Headline: Britain to narrowly dodge recession as economy flatlines - Reuters poll
Description: Britain is now expected to narrowly dodge a mild recession that was widely predicted after the country voted to leave the European Union, but the government will still need to add fiscal stimulus to support growth, a Reuters poll found.

Headline: Nuclear sector aims to build 1,000 GW of new reactors by 2050 - WNA
Description: The world nuclear industry aims to build about 1,000 gigawatts of new nuclear reactor capacity by 2050, World Nuclear Association Director-general Agneta Rising said on Thursday.

Headline: French finance minister applauds UK decision on Hinkley Point
Description: The French government on Thursday welcomed Britain's decision to approve the construction of a nuclear plant at Hinkley Point in southern England by French utility EDF.

Headline: Bank of England names Brexit coordinator
Description: The Bank of England has named one of its top executives to coordinate the central bank's preparations for Brexit and the impact it will have on the country's massive financial services sector.

Headline: UK, Argentina agree joint steps on Falklands in win for diplomacy
Description: Britain and Argentina have agreed to work together towards removing measures restricting the oil and gas, shipping and fishing industries around the disputed Falkland Islands, both countries said on Wednesday.

Headline: Former Murdoch executives misled parliament over phone-hacking, MPs say
Description: Two former executives from Rupert Murdoch's British newspaper arm should be formally admonished after misleading a parliamentary committee investigating claims of phone-hacking, MPs said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain's Libya intervention flawed, Cameron to blame - MPs
Description: Britain's 2011 military intervention in Libya, ordered by former prime minister David Cameron, relied on flawed intelligence and hastened the North African country's political and economic collapse, MPs said on Wednesday in a damning report.

Headline: BBC to get new boss as PM May reverses Cameron decision
Description: The BBC is to get a new boss after Prime Minister Theresa May chose not to make her predecessor David Cameron's nominee an automatic pick for the role, the latest of several breaks with his legacy.

Headline: Parliament may have to ratify Brexit legislation - Davis
Description: Britain's parliament may well have to ratify part of the legislation needed for the country to exit the European Union, Brexit Secretary David Davis told a parliamentary committee on Tuesday.

Headline: UK looking to European industry for support in Brexit talks - minister
Description: Britain will look to German, French and other European industries to reinforce its case that open trade with the European Union will be mutually beneficial after it has left the bloc, Brexit minister David Davis said on Tuesday.

Headline: No Article 50 before Brexit ministry fully staffed - Davis
Description: Britain will not trigger article 50, the formal step that will kick off negotiations on the terms of its exit from the European Union, before its dedicated Brexit ministry is operating at full capacity, the minister in charge said on Tuesday.

Headline: Scotland faces tough new budget choices post-Brexit - think tank
Description: Scotland's government faces the prospect of having to make deeper spending cuts after Britain's vote to leave the EU, a think tank said on Tuesday, adding to the challenge of implementing its new tax and spending powers.

Headline: London takes steps to help black cabs as private hire firms face new rules
Description: London said on Tuesday it would introduce new measures to support its iconic black cabs including giving access to more bus lanes and boosting the number of taxi ranks, just as private hire firms such as Uber face stricter rules in the capital.

Headline: London teenager charged with preparing terrorism attacks
Description: A 19-year-old man from London has been charged under counter-terrorism law with preparing attacks, the British capital's Metropolitan Police force said on Tuesday.

Headline: No UK market access without free migration - EU parliament negotiator
Description: The new Brexit negotiator for the European Parliament reiterated on Tuesday that the EU legislature will not accept giving Britain access to Europe's single market if it blocks free access to EU immigrants.

Headline: EU lawmakers back Briton King for security commissioner
Description: A European Parliament committee endorsed Julian King on Tuesday as Britain's new member of the European Commission with responsibility for security, the committee chairman said.

Headline: MPs face uncertain future under new boundary proposals
Description: Dozens of British MPs face uncertain futures under proposals by an independent commission charged with cutting the number of parliamentary seats.

Headline: More than half of UK girls sexually harassed in school - report
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - More than half of girls in British schools and colleges have faced sexual harassment, according to a new report on Tuesday that called for sex education to be provided for all children in primary and secondary school.

Headline: 'Last British commissioner' pledges to work for Europe
Description: The diplomat nominated to take Britain's vacant seat on the EU executive pledged on Monday to serve "only the European general interest" if EU lawmakers accept him as, probably, the last ever British commissioner.

Headline: UK will have public guidelines for Brexit talks before triggering Article 50 - minister
Description: Britain will make public its guidelines for talks on leaving the European Union by the time it triggers the exit process, Brexit minister David Davis said on Monday, in the first indication of when Britons will find out what the government hopes to achieve in the talks.

Headline: Germany, France seek stronger EU defence after Brexit - document
Description: Germany and France have outlined plans to deepen European military cooperation, a document showed on Monday, as Britain's exit from the European Union removes one of the biggest obstacles to stronger EU defence in tandem with NATO.

Headline: MP Davis says must persuade 'remainers' of Brexit benefits
Description: Brexit Secretary David Davis said on Monday the government must persuade those who voted to stay in the European Union in both houses of parliament that Brexit is worthwhile.

Headline: Ending his political career, ex-PM Cameron resigns as an MP
Description: Former prime minister David Cameron said on Monday he was resigning from his seat in parliament to avoid becoming a distraction for his successor, ending his political career just weeks after he lost a referendum to stay in the European Union.

Headline: Bank of England's Shafik to step down in Feb for top academic post
Description: Bank of England deputy governor Minouche Shafik will step down at the end of February 2017 to become director of the London School of Economics, the central bank said on Monday.

Headline: London's Heathrow sets August record as runway ruling nears
Description: London's Heathrow Airport, which is battling Gatwick for government approval for an extra runway, said it handled a record 7.34 million passengers in August, with more flying to the Middle East and Latin America.

Headline: British businesses 'lazy and fat', pro-Brexit trade minister says
Description: Britain as a trading nation has become "too lazy and too fat" and business leaders are more interested in playing golf on Friday afternoons than in seeking new export markets, International Trade Secretary Liam Fox was recorded saying.

Headline: Communities take charge in Scotland's land reform 'revolution'
Description: EDINBURGH (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - On a two acre patch of land in north Edinburgh's Leith neighbourhood, Evie Murray walks with pride between plots of carefully tended flowers and vegetables.

Headline: Britain eyeing work permits to control EU immigration - interior minister
Description: Britain's interior minister Amber Rudd said on Sunday she was looking at a work permits system to control migration from the European Union, responding to Brexit voters' demand for tighter border controls.

Headline: May tackles education, appeals to Brexit voters
Description: Setting her sights on making Britain "the world's great meritocracy", Prime Minister Theresa May unveiled reforms to widen opportunity in schools on Friday in an appeal to "frustrated" Britons who voted to leave the EU.

Headline: British steel workers face prospect of pension quick fix: sources
Description: A steel industry plan to change its pension scheme and allow the sale of Tata's British operations is likely to be scrapped in favour of a fix that avoids a political row, government and industry sources told Reuters.

Headline: Britain to miss its 2020 renewable energy targets – MPs
Description: Britain is set to miss its 2020 European renewable energy targets, a parliamentary committee report said on Friday, setting a poor example for less wealthy countries as the world tries to rein in global warming.

Headline: UKIP denies ex-leader Farage has been offered a show by Russian TV
Description: The UK Independence Party on Friday denied a newspaper report that its former leader, Nigel Farage, had been offered his own television show by a Russian state-funded broadcaster.

Headline: Scotland will not hold an independence vote for five years, says former leader
Description: Scotland will not hold another vote on independence in the next five years because there is no sign it can be won, but the risk of secession from the United Kingdom is growing, a former Scottish first minister predicts.

Headline: Boss of Britain's John Lewis wants to run for West Midlands mayor
Description: Andy Street, who has led British department store John Lewis [JLP.UL] for a decade, has confirmed he wants to run to be Mayor of the West Midlands and would step down if selected by the ruling Conservative Party as their candidate.

Headline: Hammond warns EU against attempt to break up City of London
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond warned other European Union countries they would be making a "huge mistake" if they tried to break up London's dominance as a global financial centre after the country leaves the bloc.

Headline: Hammond rejects major investment surge, backs 'modest' projects
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond played down expectations of a surge in public spending to offset the economic hit from the Brexit vote, but said he could fund modest infrastructure projects if needed.

Headline: UK firms to lower investment after Brexit - accountancy body
Description: British firms are likely to cut investment during the rest of this year and in 2017 due to the Brexit vote, and the government must show quickly how it will move forward with leaving the European Union, a professional body for accountants said.

Headline: Britain, EU must work together for smooth divorce - May
Description: Britain and the European Union must work together to make their divorce smooth and forge a new "strong relationship", Prime Minister Theresa May told European Council President Donald Tusk on Thursday.

Headline: UK abandons plans to privatise Land Registry - government source
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - The British government has abandoned plans to privatise the UK Land Registry that has recorded ownership of property in the country for more than 150 years after a change of leadership at the ministry in charge, according to a government source.

Headline: Chancellor Hammond to deliver budget statement on November 23
Description: Chancellor Philip Hammond said on Thursday he would deliver his first half-yearly budget update and new fiscal forecasts on Nov. 23.

Headline: Opposition calls for UK to publish companies' tax returns
Description: Britain's opposition Labour party called on Thursday for big companies to publish their tax returns and for parliamentary committees to have the right to see all taxpayers' returns, to aid efforts to tackle avoidance and evasion.

Headline: UK MPs should vacate parliament for six-year renovation project - report
Description: Britain's parliament should completely vacate its historic Palace of Westminster building for six years in order to allow a multi-billion pound major renovation project to take place, a committee of lawmakers said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain, EU should work together for smooth divorce - PM May
Description: Britain and the European Union should work together to smooth their divorce and forge a new strong relationship, Prime Minister Theresa May told European Council President Donald Tusk on Thursday.

Headline: UK says sets up working group with India to prepare for post-Brexit trade
Description: Britain has set up a trade working group with India to prepare for a future deal following Britain's exit from the European Union, trade minister Liam Fox said on Thursday.

Headline: London police arrest two men suspected of preparing attacks
Description: Two men were arrested in London on Thursday on suspicion of being involved in terrorism, the British capital's Metropolitan Police said in a statement.

Headline: May to discuss Brexit with EU's Tusk on Thursday
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will meet European Council President Donald Tusk in London on Thursday to discuss Britain's exit from the European Union, May's spokeswoman said.

Headline: Britain faces long road to post-Brexit trade deals
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May wants to make Britain a global leader in trade after Brexit, but former negotiators say the country faces a long slog despite warm words from some world leaders over forging new relationships.

Headline: Obama quashes prospect of fast-track Brexit UK-U.S. trade deal
Description: U.S. President Barack Obama offered Britain little hope of a fast-track post-Brexit trade deal on Sunday, but said he would work to ensure the economic relationship between the two does not unravel after the British vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: PM May says discussed Brexit with Obama
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday that she had discussed Britain leaving the European Union with U.S. President Barack Obama, and will consult on how the make sure the two countries have the closest possible trading relationship.

Headline: Childless Scottish nationalist leader Sturgeon reveals 2011 miscarriage
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, whose childlessness has been a matter of media speculation over the years, has revealed she suffered a miscarriage in 2011.

Headline: UK plans 3 billion pound house building fund to boost sector post-Brexit - report
Description: The British government is set to announce a 3 billion pound house building fund to provide developers with cheap loans to boost the sector following the vote to leave the European Union, the Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported.

Headline: May to review security risks of Chinese-funded nuclear deal
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she wanted her security advisers to help review a delayed nuclear power investment from China - a source of diplomatic tension - as she arrived for a G20 summit.

Headline: UK economy will suffer after Brexit vote - May
Description: Britain's economy will suffer as a result of the decision to leave the European Union despite signs in recent economic data that the impact has not been as severe as some predicted, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday.

Headline: British government to set out plans on post-Brexit ties with EU in coming week
Description: The British government will set out in the coming week how it plans to shape its relationship with the European Union upon leaving the bloc, Prime Minister Theresa May said in an interview broadcast on Sunday.

Headline: Australia says committed to Britain free trade deal
Description: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said on Sunday his country and Britain were both very committed to having an early free trade agreement after Britain leaves the European Union.

Headline: Insight - Unhappy with Corbyn, Labour's 'money men' channel funds in new directions
Description: Billionaire Peter Coates has stopped giving money to Britain's opposition Labour Party, seeing little prospect of election victory under left-wing leader Jeremy Corbyn.

Headline: No imminent UK decision on Chinese-backed nuclear plan as PM May heads to China
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May will not announce her keenly awaited decision on a partly-Chinese funded nuclear power project in the coming days, a British official said on Saturday as May flew to China to meet President Xi Jinping at her first G20 summit.

Headline: PM May has 'open mind' on Brexit deal - spokeswoman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May has an open mind on what Britain's relationship with the European will look like after Brexit and will not put all her cards on the table before negotiating their divorce, her spokeswoman said on Tuesday.

Headline: May says UK to become leader in free trade despite Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said she wanted Britain to become a global leader in free trade as it exits the European Union.

Headline: Britain will regain sovereignty without delay - Brexit minister
Description: Britain will leave the European Union and restore its sovereignty, the minister responsible for negotiating Britain's exit from the European Union said on Monday, vowing there would be no delay and no second referendum.

Headline: Britain presses for 'unique' deal with EU after Brexit
Description: Britain is pressing for a "unique" deal with the European Union to restore sovereignty, reduce immigration and boost trade with the bloc after their split, the minister charged with negotiating Brexit said on Monday.

Headline: MPs debate petition demanding second Brexit referendum
Description: British members of parliament on Monday debated a petition signed by more than 4.1 million people that demands a second referendum on European Union membership.

Headline: Brexit minister says rather delay divorce with EU than get it wrong
Description: Britain would be better off being a month late in starting the formal divorce procedure for leaving the European Union than getting its negotiating stance wrong, the minister who is in charge of negotiating Brexit said on Monday.

Headline: UK economy shows signs of recovery from Brexit vote, outlook still patchy
Description: Britain's economy showed its clearest sign to date of bouncing back from the initial shock of June's vote to leave the European Union, but a big slowdown in growth and a further Bank of England rate cut remain on the cards.

Headline: PM May rejects points-based immigration controls sought by Brexit campaigners
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May rejected a "points-based" system to screen immigrants, setting up a potential conflict with Brexit campaigners in her government who promised to bring in Australian-style controls over EU migrants.

Headline: May wants government control on migration, points system open to abuse
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said she wants a new system to give the government control over who is able to enter the country after it leaves the European Union, rather than a points-based system that selects candidates based on criteria.

Headline: May says MP Keith Vaz must decide his own future
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday that British Member of Parliament Keith Vaz should make his own decision about his future political career after claims in the Sunday Mirror newspaper about his personal life.

Headline: UK wants government control over migration, not points system - PM spokeswoman
Description: Britain will pursue an immigration system that enables the government to decide who enters the country and not a points-based system that gives an automatic right to those who meet certain criteria, a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Monday.

Headline: PM May says to set out proposals on corporate behaviour this year
Description: The British government will put forward proposals later this year aimed at improving corporate behaviour, including tackling excessive executive pay, British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday.

Headline: UK's Brexit minister to set out more detail on plans for future EU ties
Description: Britain's minister in charge of exiting the European Union will set out more detail on the government's plans for Brexit in a statement to parliament on Monday, amid growing international unease over how it will pan out.

Headline: Britain, Russia hope to improve strained relations
Description: Britain and Russia said on Sunday they hope to improve their relations through dialogue following the first meeting between new British Prime Minister Theresa May and Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Headline: Putin says Russia wants to restore ties with Britain - Kremlin
Description: Russian President Vladimir Putin told British Prime Minister Theresa May he wants to restore ties between the two countries, a Kremlin spokesman said on Sunday.

Headline: Obama quashes prospect of fast-track Brexit UK-U.S. trade deal
Description: U.S. President Barack Obama offered Britain little hope of a fast-track post-Brexit trade deal on Sunday, but said he would work to ensure the economic relationship between the two does not unravel after the British vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: PM May says discussed Brexit with Obama
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday that she had discussed Britain leaving the European Union with U.S. President Barack Obama, and will consult on how the make sure the two countries have the closest possible trading relationship.

Headline: Childless Scottish nationalist leader Sturgeon reveals 2011 miscarriage
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, whose childlessness has been a matter of media speculation over the years, has revealed she suffered a miscarriage in 2011.

Headline: UK plans 3 billion pound house building fund to boost sector post-Brexit - report
Description: The British government is set to announce a 3 billion pound house building fund to provide developers with cheap loans to boost the sector following the vote to leave the European Union, the Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported.

Headline: May to review security risks of Chinese-funded nuclear deal
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she wanted her security advisers to help review a delayed nuclear power investment from China - a source of diplomatic tension - as she arrived for a G20 summit.

Headline: No second vote or attempt to stay in EU by 'back door' - UK PM
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told members of her government on Wednesday that they would have to deliver Brexit, ruling out any second referendum or any attempt to stay in the European Union by the "back door".

Headline: Six teenagers arrested in Britain suspected of killing Polish man in 'hate crime'
Description: Six teenagers in a town east of London have been released on bail after being arrested on suspicion of killing a Polish man in a suspected hate crime, British police said on Wednesday.

Headline: Corbyn to win bigger mandate in Labour leadership vote - poll
Description: Jeremy Corbyn, the left-wing head of Britain's opposition Labour party, is set to win a leadership race with even more support than when he was first elected last year, according to a YouGov poll in The Times on Wednesday.

Headline: UK, France stick to Calais migrant deal 'now and when' Britain leaves EU
Description: British and French interior ministers agreed on Tuesday to develop cooperation "now and when the United Kingdom leaves the EU" to address challenges posed by flows of migrants to the European Union.

Headline: London financial groups open line to Dublin after Brexit
Description: Ireland says the Brexit vote has led to a jump in enquiries  from London firms considering opening offices in Dublin, one of a handful of European cities trying to draw business away from Britain's financial centre.

Headline: May has no legal obligation to consult parliament on EU divorce - spokesman
Description: The British government has no legal obligation to consult parliament on triggering the formal divorce procedure with the European Union, but lawmakers will have a say, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: Female author urges UK Muslims to speak out against extremism
Description: Islamic State (IS) violence can only be tackled if Muslims stand up for their views of what real Islam is, according to a rare female voice within the British Muslim community.

Headline: Brexit angst prompts UK services firms to cut expansion plans - CBI
Description: Optimism among Britain's services companies has fallen sharply, with investment plans at their leanest for more than four years, as employers wait for clearer signs of what the Brexit vote means for them, a survey published on Tuesday showed.

Headline: Britain says inward investment rose, before Brexit vote
Description: In the last financial year before Britain voted to leave the European Union, the country gained more foreign investment projects than ever before, the government said on Tuesday.

Headline: European experts float post-Brexit 'partnership' with Britain
Description: A senior German lawmaker, an adviser to the French prime minister and a former deputy head of the Bank of England have proposed that a post-Brexit Britain form a new "continental partnership" with the EU.

Headline: UK business confidence improves after post-referendum slump - YouGov/Cebr
Description: British businesses recovered some confidence about their prospects after a post-Brexit vote scare, but remained largely pessimistic about the economic outlook, a survey showed on Friday.

Headline: Scots to gauge support for independence after Brexit 'gamechanger'
Description: Tens of thousands of Scottish nationalists are to fan out across Scotland, knocking on doors to find out if there is support for a new vote on independence that could make or break First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.

Headline: UK government condemns 'irresponsible' English five-day doctor strike
Description: British Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt on Thursday condemned as "totally irresponsible" a plan by junior doctors in England to hold a five-day strike after the industry's trade union escalated a long-running dispute with the government.

Headline: Brexit minister says UK ideally seeking tariff-free access to EU single market
Description: Britain is ideally seeking tariff-free access to the European Union's single market combined with curbs on immigration, the minister in charge of negotiating the country's exit from the bloc said on Thursday.

Headline: UK to provide 20 million pounds for struggling Southern rail service
Description: The British government said it would provide 20 million pounds  ($26 million) to help improve services on the privately run Southern rail network, after passengers suffered months of strikes, cancellations and delays.

Headline: Public felt ill-informed in EU referendum campaign, says reform society
Description: The conduct of Britain's EU referendum showed "glaring democratic deficiencies," according to a report on Thursday by the Electoral Reform Society (ERS), which called for a review into how referendums are run.

Headline: UK will be outward-facing post-Brexit, continue to attract investment - Hammond
Description: Britain will continue to attract companies to invest in the UK following its vote to leave the European Union, finance minister Philip Hammond said on Thursday.

Headline: Shareholder committees could curb UK bosses' pay bonanza - report
Description: British public companies should be required to create shareholder committees responsible for proposing executive pay, to help constrain the spiralling salaries of top bosses, said a report published on Thursday.

Headline: UK government needs stronger response to VW emissions scandal - committee
Description: The British government should take a tougher stance against Volkswagen after its emissions fraud, as well as increase the use of electric cars and reduce air pollution from transport, a parliamentary environment committee said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain to seek unique deal with EU, including immigration curbs
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May and her top ministers on Wednesday agreed Britain would seek a unique relationship with the European Union, involving controls on immigration as well as a good trade deal.

Headline: Brexit town wants government to 'get on with it' and leave EU
Description: Gazing out across the calm, grey North Sea towards northern France, families in Clacton enjoy the English summer, some sipping tea, others with cans of beer, outside wooden beach huts strung with union jack flags.

Headline: UK cosmetics group Lush relocates staff to Germany post-Brexit
Description: UK cosmetics maker and retailer Lush is relocating European staff from Britain to Germany and has expanded production at its German factory in the wake of Britain's vote to leave the European Union, it said on Wednesday.

Headline: Britain will seek unique deal with EU - PM May's spokeswoman
Description: Britain will seek a unique relationship with the European Union that involves controls on immigration but is also a good deal for trade in goods and services, a spokeswoman for Prime Minister Theresa May said.

Headline: May and ministers reiterate commitment to fiscal discipline
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May and her team of top ministers reiterated the government's commitment to fiscal discipline on Wednesday, her spokeswoman said.

Headline: EDF union board members file challenge to annul Hinkley Point vote
Description: Five staff representatives on the board of EDF have filed a legal complaint seeking to annul the utility's decision to go ahead with its Hinkley Point nuclear project in Britain, EDF unions said in a joint statement on Wednesday.

Headline: No second vote or attempt to stay in EU by 'back door' - UK PM
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May told members of her government on Wednesday that they would have to deliver Brexit, ruling out any second referendum or any attempt to stay in the European Union by the "back door".

Headline: Six teenagers arrested in Britain suspected of killing Polish man in 'hate crime'
Description: Six teenagers in a town east of London have been released on bail after being arrested on suspicion of killing a Polish man in a suspected hate crime, British police said on Wednesday.

Headline: Corbyn to win bigger mandate in Labour leadership vote - poll
Description: Jeremy Corbyn, the left-wing head of Britain's opposition Labour party, is set to win a leadership race with even more support than when he was first elected last year, according to a YouGov poll in The Times on Wednesday.

Headline: UK, France stick to Calais migrant deal 'now and when' Britain leaves EU
Description: British and French interior ministers agreed on Tuesday to develop cooperation "now and when the United Kingdom leaves the EU" to address challenges posed by flows of migrants to the European Union.

Headline: London financial groups open line to Dublin after Brexit
Description: Ireland says the Brexit vote has led to a jump in enquiries  from London firms considering opening offices in Dublin, one of a handful of European cities trying to draw business away from Britain's financial centre.

Headline: May has no legal obligation to consult parliament on EU divorce - spokesman
Description: The British government has no legal obligation to consult parliament on triggering the formal divorce procedure with the European Union, but lawmakers will have a say, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday.

Headline: Female author urges UK Muslims to speak out against extremism
Description: Islamic State (IS) violence can only be tackled if Muslims stand up for their views of what real Islam is, according to a rare female voice within the British Muslim community.

Headline: Brexit angst prompts UK services firms to cut expansion plans - CBI
Description: Optimism among Britain's services companies has fallen sharply, with investment plans at their leanest for more than four years, as employers wait for clearer signs of what the Brexit vote means for them, a survey published on Tuesday showed.

Headline: Britain says inward investment rose, before Brexit vote
Description: In the last financial year before Britain voted to leave the European Union, the country gained more foreign investment projects than ever before, the government said on Tuesday.

Headline: European experts float post-Brexit 'partnership' with Britain
Description: A senior German lawmaker, an adviser to the French prime minister and a former deputy head of the Bank of England have proposed that a post-Brexit Britain form a new "continental partnership" with the EU.

Headline: UK plan to make social housing tenants 'pay to stay' won't meet aims - report
Description: LONDON (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - Britain's "pay to stay" rule requiring social housing tenants to pay higher rents may leave local councils worse off, cause stress for families and fail to generate expected revenues for central government, according to a report published on Monday.

Headline: Germany's Gabriel says poorly handled Brexit would see Europe go down the drain
Description: German Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel said on Sunday that if Britain's exit from the European Union was badly handled and other member countries followed its lead, Europe would go "down the drain".

Headline: EDF chief urges Britain to give go-ahead to nuclear plant
Description: The head of EDF Energy  has urged the British government to approve the Hinkley Point C nuclear power project, an explicit appeal by the French energy giant ahead of a decision due within weeks.

Headline: May to trigger Brexit without vote by lawmakers - Telegraph
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May will not hold a parliamentary vote on Brexit before formally triggering Britain's withdrawal from the European Union, The Daily Telegraph reported on Saturday, without specifying sources.

Headline: UK regulator to monitor WhatsApp's data sharing with Facebook
Description: Britain's data privacy regulator said on Friday it would monitor how popular messaging service WhatsApp shares data with parent Facebook Inc under a new privacy policy.

Headline: Labour party says resolves conference security stand-off
Description: Labour Party said on Friday it had found a new security company to guard its conference, avoiding an embarrassing  confrontation with a union that had objected to the previous firm and threatened to picket the event.

Headline: Factbox - UK economy suffers little immediate Brexit hit, tests to come
Description: Two months after Britain decided to leave the European Union, consumers seem to have taken the result in their stride but there are some signs that the challenge for the economy has barely begun.

Headline: British economy escapes Brexit blow, for now
Description: Britain's high streets are heaving with shoppers despite June's shock vote to leave the European Union, big companies have reported few signs of distress and some tabloid newspapers are even talking about a post-Brexit economic boom.

Headline: Rating firm DBRS considering European office as Brexit insurance
Description: The London-based credit-rating agency DBRS says it will need to open a new office in mainland Europe if Britain's vote to leave the European Union affects its business in the EU.

Headline: Britain does not need Hinkley for future energy needs -think tank
Description: Britain does not need the Hinkley Point C nuclear project and could use a mixture of alternative resources to guarantee its future energy needs at a lower cost, an energy and climate think tank said on Friday.

Headline: UK consumers recover some confidence after Brexit vote hit - survey
Description: British consumers have regained some of the confidence they lost after the Brexit vote in June, according to a survey published on Friday, the latest sign that households are largely taking the decision to leave the European Union in their stride.

Headline: Social media giants must do more to police sites - MPs
Description: Facebook, Twitter and YouTube should hire more people to monitor hate speech and material inciting violence as well as putting staff in police operation centres to remove offending posts faster, British lawmakers said.

Headline: Nigel Farage addresses Trump rally, bashes Clinton
Description: Nigel Farage, a key figure in the successful campaign to get Britain out of the European Union, lent his support to Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on Wednesday, saying Trump represented the same type of anti-establishment movement that he masterminded in his own country.

Headline: Net migration to Britain fell slightly before EU vote
Description: Net migration to Britain fell slightly in the year to March but remained close to record levels, official data showed on Thursday, the first to be released since the June 23 vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: Brexit campaigner Farage says to address Trump rally
Description: Nigel Farage, an anti-immigration politician who was a figurehead of the successful campaign to get Britain out of the European Union, intends to address a Donald Trump rally on Wednesday, a spokesman said.

Headline: 'Brexit discount' makes London property cheaper for some
Description: Price cuts of nearly 20 percent and a drop in the value of the pound have created "Brexit discount" bargains on some of the most expensive homes in central London -- if you have millions of pounds to spare.

Headline: May throwing full weight behind winning best Brexit deal - spokesman
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May is throwing the full weight of government behind her goal of winning the best Brexit deal for Britain but will not trigger the formal divorce procedure before the end of the year, her spokesman said on Monday.

Headline: RBS says main office would move if Scotland were independent - BBC
Description: Royal Bank of Scotland  would move its main office from Scotland if the nation were to split from the UK after Britain's vote to leave the European Union, although moving domicile would not mean major job losses, the head of RBS has said.

Headline: Brexit could be delayed to late-2019 as government not ready - Sunday Times
Description: Britain's exit from the European Union could be delayed until at least late 2019 because the government was too "chaotic" to start the two-year process early next year, the Sunday Times reported, citing sources it said were briefed by ministers.

Headline: Britain to plug 4.5 billion pound EU funding gap for farms, colleges
Description: Britain will fill a gap of as much as 4.5 billion pounds in funding for agriculture, universities and its regions that will open up when Britain leaves the European Union, Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond said.

Headline: Labour Party can exclude new members from leadership vote, court rules
Description: The Labour Party won the right to exclude new members from voting in its ongoing leadership contest on Friday after a successful legal appeal - a decision which party leader Jeremy Corbyn criticised as legally and democratically wrong.

Headline: UK defies firms' pleas not to impose new tax, despite Brexit worries
Description: Britain confirmed on Friday it would press ahead with plans to impose a levy on large employers from early next year to help pay for training workers, prompting dismay from business groups who want the tax delayed to soften the impact of Brexit.

Headline: Northern Ireland activist launches legal challenge against Brexit
Description: A Northern Ireland human rights activist has launched a legal challenge against any British attempt to leave the European Union, saying it would be in breach of the 1998 peace deal that brought peace to the British province.

Headline: Theresa May seeks progress on Falklands in letter to Argentine leader
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has written to Argentina's President Mauricio Macri calling for restrictions on oil exploration in the Falklands Islands to be lifted and for more flights to the British-run islands, her office said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain says it needs constructive dialogue with Russia despite differences
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson told his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov on Thursday that the two countries needed to build a constructive relationship despite their significant differences.

Headline: Britain needs bulk data interception for security, review says
Description: An independent review of draft British security legislation said bulk interception and collection of citizens' personal data was vital for the intelligence agencies to prevent attacks, a position welcomed by Prime Minister Theresa May.

Headline: Corbyn refuses to say he'd defend NATO ally from Russia
Description: The leader of Britain's opposition Labour Party has refused to say whether he would defend a NATO ally if one was invaded by Russia.

Headline: Brexit 'fireworks' give comics rich pickings at Edinburgh
Description: For comics at this year's Edinburgh festival, Britain's vote to leave the European Union has been a blessing and a curse.

Headline: British shoppers defy Brexit shock as spending jumps in July
Description: Shoppers in Britain shrugged off June's shock Brexit vote as retail sales jumped by much more than expected last month, adding to signs there has been little immediate hit for consumers.

Headline: In proudly multi-cultural London, many find Brexit hard to stomach
Description: Ask most people in inner city London how they felt when they found out that Britain had voted to leave the European Union, and the chances are the memories are not happy ones.

Headline: Britain launches soft drinks sugar tax to fight obesity
Description: Britain on Thursday said it would tax companies which sell sugary soft drinks and invest that money in health programmes for school children, part of a long-awaited strategy to curb childhood obesity that critics say is too weak.

Headline: Britain needs new race strategy as report shows 'entrenched' unfairness
Description: Ethnic minorities face "entrenched and far-reaching" inequality and, combined with a rise in hate crime since Britain voted to leave the European Union, the government must come up with a long-term strategy, an independent report said on Thursday.

Headline: BBC picks private weather forecaster as it ditches Met Office after 94 years
Description: BBC weather forecasts, closely watched by millions in Britain, will be provided from next year by a private company, replacing the Met Office after 94 years.

Headline: Britain targets financial advisers with new tax-avoidance fines
Description: Britain set out plans on Wednesday to punish financial advisers who tell their clients how to bend the law to avoid paying tax, including hefty fines designed to target what it called the "supply chain of tax avoidance".

Headline: Radical Islamist preacher Anjem Choudary guilty of inviting support for IS
Description: Anjem Choudary, Britain's most high-profile Islamist preacher whose followers have been linked to numerous plots across the world, has been found guilty of inviting support for Islamic State.

Headline: UK air force helicopter makes forced mountain landing, no casualties
Description: A Royal Air Force helicopter was forced to land high up a mountain in Wales on Tuesday because of a technical problem and all five people on board managed to get off safely before it caught fire, Britain's Ministry of Defence said.

Headline: Britain counting on fintech for banking revolution
Description: British banks will from 2018 have to share customers' data with third parties who can then show how much could be saved by using other lenders, the competition watchdog said on Tuesday.

Headline: Bank of England's McCafferty urges 'gradual' approach to monetary stimulus
Description: Bank of England policymaker Ian McCafferty voted against resuming the central bank's government bond purchases last week because he thinks it should take a "more gradual" approach to economic stimulus.

Headline: Britain defends decision to review $24 billion nuclear plant
Description: Britain on Tuesday defended its decision to review a planned $24 billion nuclear power project after criticism from China which is helping to fund the deal.

Headline: Labour members win court battle to vote in leadership contest
Description: Members of Britain's opposition Labour party who had been excluded from voting in its leadership contest have won a court battle to have their say on whether Jeremy Corbyn should stay in the job following a challenge from one of his lawmakers.

Headline: British priest wanted on child sex charges should not be extradited - Kosovo court
Description: A former priest wanted on child sex abuse charges from the 1970s and 1980s should not be extradited to Britain because the crimes were committed too long ago, a court in Kosovo ruled on Monday.

Headline: Travel misery for London commuters as union begins five-day strike
Description: Hundreds of thousands of train commuters in London and southern England were facing misery on Monday as rail staff began a five-day strike in a safety row over who opens and closes the doors.

Headline: Britons will decide how to spend 1-billion-pound shale gas fund
Description: Britons living near "fracking" developments will be able to decide how a 1 billion pound shale gas wealth fund should be spent, either by accepting direct personal payments or supporting projects such as railways or flood defences, the government said on Monday.

Headline: UK considers plan to pay households affected by fracking
Description: Some tax proceeds from shale gas developments in Britain could be given directly to residents, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday, in a bid to help clear the path for an industry hampered for years by local opposition to fracking.

Headline: EDF to take legal action over union's claims about Hinkley Point
Description: EDF  Chairman and CEO Jean-Bernard Levy had no prior knowledge of Britain's decision to review the Hinkley Point nuclear project and will sue a French union for suggesting otherwise, the French utility said.

Headline: Labour Party can exclude new members from leadership vote, court rules
Description: The Labour Party won the right to exclude new members from voting in its ongoing leadership contest on Friday after a successful legal appeal - a decision which party leader Jeremy Corbyn criticised as legally and democratically wrong.

Headline: UK defies firms' pleas not to impose new tax, despite Brexit worries
Description: Britain confirmed on Friday it would press ahead with plans to impose a levy on large employers from early next year to help pay for training workers, prompting dismay from business groups who want the tax delayed to soften the impact of Brexit.

Headline: Northern Ireland activist launches legal challenge against Brexit
Description: A Northern Ireland human rights activist has launched a legal challenge against any British attempt to leave the European Union, saying it would be in breach of the 1998 peace deal that brought peace to the British province.

Headline: Theresa May seeks progress on Falklands in letter to Argentine leader
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May has written to Argentina's President Mauricio Macri calling for restrictions on oil exploration in the Falklands Islands to be lifted and for more flights to the British-run islands, her office said on Thursday.

Headline: Britain says it needs constructive dialogue with Russia despite differences
Description: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson told his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov on Thursday that the two countries needed to build a constructive relationship despite their significant differences.

Headline: Britain appoints its fourth new head of child sex abuse inquiry
Description: Britain appointed a new head to lead a national inquiry into decades of child sex abuse on Thursday, naming social care expert Alexis Jay to lead an investigation that has been dogged by leadership problems.

Headline: Trotsky's ghost haunts Britain's Labour Party in post-Brexit vote turmoil
Description: Nearly 76 years to the day since Leon Trotsky was murdered in Mexico with an ice-pick on Josef Stalin's orders, the Russian revolutionary has returned to haunt Britain's opposition Labour Party in the turmoil sparked by the Brexit vote.

Headline: PM May heads to Switzerland for two-week holiday
Description: After a hectic first month in office following the June 23 Brexit vote, new Prime Minister Theresa May is off on holiday and she has chosen a country outside the European Union with close ties to the bloc - Switzerland.

Headline: Bouygues, Vallourec deny conflict of interest in Hinkley Point vote
Description: French firms Bouygues and Vallourec denied that members of their boards who are also on the board of EDF had a conflict of interest when they voted in favour of the French utility's Hinkley Point nuclear project in Britain.

Headline: Stumped by transgender pension case, British top court seeks EU help
Description: A complex legal dispute involving a transgender woman's pension rights over a period when her gender had not been officially recognised has divided Britain's Supreme Court, which referred the issue on Wednesday to the European Union's top court.

Headline: Britain's new government awards rail contract to Abellio
Description: Dutch-owned Abellio East Anglia has been awarded a renewed contract to run rail services in eastern England in one of the first such decisions made by Britain's new government.

Headline: May raises case of detained aid worker with Iran's Rouhani
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May raised concerns on Tuesday with Iran's President Hassan Rouhani over several cases involving dual British-Iranian nationals, including imprisoned aid worker Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, her office said.

Headline: China to UK - 'golden' ties at crucial juncture over nuclear delay
Description: China has cautioned Britain against closing the door to Chinese money and said relations were at a crucial juncture after Prime Minister Theresa May delayed signing off on a $24 billion nuclear power project.

Headline: Scotland's Sturgeon makes surprise visit to Germany
Description: Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon met the deputy foreign minister of Germany on Tuesday, seeking to strengthen her ties with Europe's economic powerhouse in the wake of Britain's vote to leave the EU - a move Scotland overwhelmingly rejected.

Headline: 'Religious disrespect' killer gets life sentence in Scotland
Description: A man was sentenced to life in prison on Tuesday for murdering a Muslim Glasgow shopkeeper he had accused of religious disrespect in an attack of "merciless violence."

Headline: UK air force helicopter makes forced mountain landing, no casualties
Description: A Royal Air Force helicopter was forced to land high up a mountain in Wales on Tuesday because of a technical problem and all five people on board managed to get off safely before it caught fire, Britain's Ministry of Defence said.

Headline: Britain counting on fintech for banking revolution
Description: British banks will from 2018 have to share customers' data with third parties who can then show how much could be saved by using other lenders, the competition watchdog said on Tuesday.

Headline: Bank of England's McCafferty urges 'gradual' approach to monetary stimulus
Description: Bank of England policymaker Ian McCafferty voted against resuming the central bank's government bond purchases last week because he thinks it should take a "more gradual" approach to economic stimulus.

Headline: Britain defends decision to review $24 billion nuclear plant
Description: Britain on Tuesday defended its decision to review a planned $24 billion nuclear power project after criticism from China which is helping to fund the deal.

Headline: Labour members win court battle to vote in leadership contest
Description: Members of Britain's opposition Labour party who had been excluded from voting in its leadership contest have won a court battle to have their say on whether Jeremy Corbyn should stay in the job following a challenge from one of his lawmakers.

Description: A former priest wanted on child sex abuse charges from the 1970s and 1980s should not be extradited to Britain because the crimes were committed too long ago, a court in Kosovo ruled on Monday.

Headline: Travel misery for London commuters as union begins five-day strike
Description: Hundreds of thousands of train commuters in London and southern England were facing misery on Monday as rail staff began a five-day strike in a safety row over who opens and closes the doors.

Headline: Britons will decide how to spend 1-billion-pound shale gas fund
Description: Britons living near "fracking" developments will be able to decide how a 1 billion pound shale gas wealth fund should be spent, either by accepting direct personal payments or supporting projects such as railways or flood defences, the government said on Monday.

Headline: UK considers plan to pay households affected by fracking
Description: Some tax proceeds from shale gas developments in Britain could be given directly to residents, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday, in a bid to help clear the path for an industry hampered for years by local opposition to fracking.

Headline: EDF to take legal action over union's claims about Hinkley Point
Description: EDF  Chairman and CEO Jean-Bernard Levy had no prior knowledge of Britain's decision to review the Hinkley Point nuclear project and will sue a French union for suggesting otherwise, the French utility said.

Headline: Man appears in court charged with murder after London knife attack
Description: A 19-year-old man appeared in court on Saturday charged with the murder of a U.S. woman during a knife attack in central London this week that left five others wounded, British media reported.

Headline: Top BoE officials flag lower rates as surveys show trouble ahead
Description: The Bank of England's top two monetary policymakers said interest rates may need to fall further, as surveys on Friday sustained their view that even a "sledgehammer" stimulus will not be enough to fully counter a post-Brexit vote slowdown.

Headline: London knife attacker charged with murder of U.S. woman
Description: A 19-year-old man was charged on Friday with the murder of a 64-year-old U.S. woman in a knife attack that wounded five others in Central London on Wednesday, London Metropolitan Police said.

Headline: Paris court confirms EDF board Hinkley Point vote
Description: A Paris court on Friday confirmed the EDF board's investment decision on the Hinkley Point nuclear newbuild project in Britain, an EDF Works Council official told Reuters.

Headline: Cameron accused of cronyism over honours for allies
Description: David Cameron was accused on Friday of cronyism that would "embarrass a medieval court" after he rewarded a long list of his political aides and allies with some of Britain's highest honours to mark his resignation as prime minister.

Headline: Britain says considering Hinkley Point carefully, needs nuclear as part of energy mix
Description: Britain said on Tuesday it was carefully considering all parts of the Hinkley Point nuclear power project and that the economy needed a secure energy supply with nuclear as an important part of the mix.

Headline: Consumed by abuse, UK's Labour faces deepening divisions with leadership contest
Description: (This story contains graphic language in the 19th paragraph)

Headline: Australians in Scottish Highlands in limbo as visa deadline passes
Description: An Australian family facing deportation from the Scottish Highlands after a change in visa rules is now in limbo, waiting to hear from the British government whether they will be given more time to meet visa requirements.

Headline: UK opposition Labour faces 'Armageddon' if it splits, says top donor
Description: Britain's opposition Labour Party would face Armageddon if it were to split following its bitter leadership contest, the party's top individual donor said on Tuesday.

Headline: UK court says NHS can fund preventative HIV drug
Description: A high court judge ruled on Tuesday that an HIV pill to prevent infection can be funded by the state health service in England, in a victory for AIDS campaigners who have been calling for its widespread use.

Headline: Man who stabbed London passenger 'for Syria' jailed for life
Description: A man who stabbed a passenger at a London underground train station in December while shouting that he was acting for Syria was jailed for life at a London court on Monday.

Headline: Cameron in cronyism storm over resignation honours
Description: David Cameron faced accusations of cronyism and rewarding failure on Monday over a leaked list of names put forward to receive some of Britain's highest honours following his resignation as prime minister.

Headline: Australian family scrambles to beat deportation from Scottish Highlands
Description: An Australian family living in the Scottish Highlands face deportation on Monday if a high-profile bid to comply with UK visa requirements fails.

Headline: PM May pledges new action to tackle 'barbaric evil' of modern slavery
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May set out a drive to tackle modern slavery in Britain on Sunday, pledging more funding and a new cross-government taskforce to help stamp out what she called a "barbaric evil".

Headline: London police chief warns terror attack a case of 'when, not if'
Description: Britain cannot be fully protected against terrorism and an attack similar to those seen recently in mainland Europe is a question of "when, not if," London's police chief said on Sunday.

Headline: May worried by China investment, intervened to delay Hinkley
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May was concerned about the security implications of a planned Chinese investment in the new Hinkley Point nuclear plant and intervened personally to delay the project, a former colleague and a source said on Saturday.

Headline: UK urges pregnant women to reconsider travel to Zika-hit Florida
Description: British health officials have urged pregnant women to consider postponing non-essential travel to Florida after the southern U.S. state confirmed the first cases of the Zika virus that were not linked to travel.

Headline: Scots back remaining in UK despite Brexit vote - poll
Description: Most Scots still back remaining in the United Kingdom despite Britons voting to leave the European Union, a move which was opposed by the majority in Scotland, according to an opinion poll published on Saturday.

Headline: Britain casts doubt on EDF's $24 billion nuclear project
Description: Britain has cast doubt on a $24 billion (18 billion pounds) project with French utility EDF to build the UK's first new nuclear plant in decades, delaying a final decision on the plan just weeks after the Brexit vote ushered in a new prime minister.

Headline: New UK home registration hits highest since 2007 in run-up to EU vote
Description: The number of new homes registered for construction in Britain rose in the second quarter to its highest since the financial crisis as building plans picked up before the EU referendum, an industry group said on Friday.

Headline: May wants bespoke terms for EU exit
Description: Britain wants a bespoke model for its future ties with the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May said on Thursday, during a tour of Eastern European allies aimed at securing support in negotiations on leaving the bloc.

Headline: May reassures Poles living in UK that they are welcome
Description: British Prime Minister Theresa May sought to reassure Poles living in Britain that they are welcome despite increased reports of abuse in the wake of the country's vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: Poland says satisfied Britain will continue as strategic ally
Description: Poland's Prime Minister Beata Szydlo said on Thursday she was satisfied that Britain would continue to be a strategic partner, despite its decision to leave the European Union.

Headline: Niceties abound as Johnson meets French minister who called him liar
Description: Modestly shaking his head to deny he was any good at speaking French, Britain's new foreign secretary Boris Johnson sought to charm a media audience in Paris during a joint appearance with his French counterpart, who recently called him a liar.

Headline: Niceties abound as UK's Johnson meets French minister who called him liar
Description: Modestly shaking his head to deny he was any good at speaking French, Britain's new foreign minister Boris Johnson sought to charm a media audience in Paris during a joint appearance with his French counterpart, who recently called him a liar.

Headline: Britain will continue to seek investment from around the world - May
Description: Britain will continue to seek investment from around the world, a spokesman for Prime Minister Theresa May said on Tuesday after a meeting of senior ministers to discuss a new economic and industrial strategy.

Headline: UK finance body urges courting 'old' friends like U.S., Japan post Brexit
Description: Deepening ties with European companies and "old friends" like the United States and Japan would help Britain preserve its global role in finance after leaving the EU, an industry body said on Wednesday.

Headline: Northern Ireland lands 300 IT jobs post-Brexit
Description: Financial services firm Tullett Prebon said on Tuesday it would create hundreds of jobs in Northern Ireland, a province regarded as highly exposed to Britain's vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: PM May resurrects industrial policy as Britain prepares for Brexit
Description: Prime Minister Theresa May on Tuesday kickstarted her bid to reshape the British economy for a post-Brexit world, reviving the once unfashionable concept of industrial policy 30 years after Margaret Thatcher killed it off.

Headline: Britain's lights could go out if Hinkley Point ditched - Labour contender
Description: Britain should get on with approving the $24 billion Hinkley Point nuclear power project otherwise the world's fifth-largest economy could face power shortages in the future, said the man seeking to lead Britain's opposition Labour Party.

Headline: Britain says considering Hinkley Point carefully, needs nuclear as part of energy mix
Description: Britain said on Tuesday it was carefully considering all parts of the Hinkley Point nuclear power project and that the economy needed a secure energy supply with nuclear as an important part of the mix.
